HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Off 8.7% In First 10 Days of May

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 15

 BODY:
A seasonal sales increase expected by automobile makers and dealers has still not materialized, with sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks falling by 8.7 percent in early May.
The eight auto manufacturers operating plants in the United States said today that they sold 185,825 cars in the first 10 days of the month, a decline of 10.4 percent from a year earlier. Cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.4 million, compared with 7.3 million in the period a year ago, and with 6.8 million in April. There were nine selling days in each May period. 
The spring sales season, usually from April to mid-June, is historically the most important selling period for American auto makers.
The biggest loser early this month was the Chrysler Corporation, whose car sales plunged by 23 percent, to 22,796. The sales of its light trucks and mini-vans, which together account for more than half of Chrysler's total sales, fell by 15.1 percent, to 23,869.
The Ford Motor Company's car sales fell by 19.8 percent, to 48,333, while those of the company's light trucks were down by 9 percent, to 37,394. The only bright spots in Ford's lineup were the sport-utility vehicles, including the Bronco II and Explorer models, and Ford's Aerostar mini-vans.
The General Motors Corporation posted the smallest decline of the large domestic auto makers. The sales of G.M. cars fell by 13.6 percent, to 89,873, but light-truck sales for the period were up by 1.4 percent, to 50,654.
Charles Brady, an automobile analyst with Oppenheimer & Company in New York, noted that G.M. continued to gain market share, mainly at Chrysler's expense.
''A slew of new G.M. products is the primary reason'' for the company's improving sales, he said, ''along with a growing perception that the quality of G.M. vehicles is improving.''
Although analysts said the overall demand for new vehicles is weak, car sales have outpaced production in recent weeks, resulting in lower inventories at most dealerships. The stocks of domestically built cars fell to a 59-day supply by April 30, the lowest level since September, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry newsletter. A 60-to-65-day supply is considered normal for dealers.
 
Replenishing Supplies
The lower inventories are a sign that auto makers may need to replenish dealers' supplies of vehicles. But manufacturers' production schedules will also depend on the strength of new-car orders from dealers in the next several weeks.
Some dealers and analysts have suggested that car companies will be forced to idle their factories longer than they have planned during the model change-over in late summer if dealer orders do not increase soon.
Honda of America Inc. reported a 32.3 percent gain in sales of its cars, to 11,238. The Mazda Motor Manufacturing USA Corporation's car sales increased by 81.1 percent, to 1,157.
The Toyota Motor Manufacturing USA Corporation's car sales more than tripled in early May, to 9,118. The gain reflects new production capacity at Toyota's plant in Georgetown, Ky.
Similarly, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation registered an increase of nearly twofold in sales of its cars, as it added production at its venture with Chrysler in Normal, Ill.
The Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation's car sales rose by 47.2 percent, to 1,543. The sales of Nissan's light trucks built in the company's plant in Smyrna, Tenn., rose by 39.6 percent, to 2,232.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Issues Dip in Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in quiet trading yesterday, as dealers took profits after the recent strong rally.
The price slide began during overnight trading in Tokyo, where a rise in the value of the yen against the dollar led to a mild selloff. Later, announcements that industrial production fell by four-tenths of a percent in April and that car sales for the first 10 days of May were weak failed to stir any enthusiasm, even though they would be a disincentive for the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates.
''The market feels a little tired, even though it continues to trade very well,'' one Government securities trader said. ''With the Fed on hold for another month at least, it looks to me like prices are at the high end of a very wide trading range that has been established over the last couple of weeks.'' 
The Federal Reserve Board's policy-making Open Market Committee gathered yesterday in Washington, and as the trader suggested, analysts and market participants are virtually unanimous that the Fed will vote to leave monetary policy unchanged.
 
Pessimism Vanishes
''It is premature to think that the Fed is going to ease policy soon,'' said Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago. ''But the deep pessimism that was so prevalent in the market a couple of weeks ago has been washed out.''
The current positive tone could be shaken if a report today on consumer prices is well above expectations.
Most economists suggest that consumer prices rose by a relatively benign two-tenths of a percent in April, and they expect the Government to announce a three-tenths of a percent increase in the index when food and energy prices are excluded.
The bulk of yesterday's price decline occurred in longer-term notes and bonds, which have rallied strongly over the last two weeks.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 101 15/32, down 13/ 32, to yield 8.61 percent, up four basis points from late Monday, when the new benchmark bond was offered at a price to yield 8.57 percent.
''Given the shift in expectations, it looks like we could be back in the trading range of 8 3/8 percent to 8 5/8 percent that we saw a little more than a month ago,'' said Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''But if the economy does show more signs of slowing down, we could see further declines. And the chances of that happening are greater now than they were six months ago.''
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 17/32, down 7/32, to yield 8.64 percent. And the 8 5/8 percent three-year notes that were auctioned on May 8 were offered at 100 5/32, down 3/32, to yield 8.56 percent.
 
Bills Are Mixed
Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.63 percent, down two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.65 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.62 percent.
The recent steep drop in interest rates encouraged a number of issuers to price new deals in both the investment-grade corporate bond and in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
Among the competitive deals priced in the municipal bond market yesterday was a $250 million offering of serial and term bonds from the State of Texas.
A bid from a group led by Chase Municipal Securities Inc. won the issue, and the serial bonds were reoffered to investors with coupons ranging from 6.30 percent on securities maturing in 1993 to 7.15 percent on bonds maturing in 2008.
The issue included two term bonds maturing in 2011 and 2020, with coupons of 7.19 percent and 7.24 percent, respectively.
The issue is rated double-A by both Moody's Investors Services and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
A group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets won a $100 million competitive issue offered by the Los Angeles Water and Power Authority.
Serial bonds maturing from 1996 to 2010 were reoffered to investors with coupons from 6.50 percent to 7.05 percent.
A 7 1/8 percent term bond maturing in 2030 was priced at $99.50 to yield 7.16 percent.
The issue is rated double-A by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
 
Corporate Bonds
In the corporate bond market, Delta Air Lines priced a two-part, $300 million offering through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The first part consisted of $175 million worth of 9 7/8 percent 10-year notes.
The notes, which mature May 15, 2000, were priced at $99.48 to yield 9.958 percent, 1.30 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 8 7/8 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $125 million was offered in the form of 10 1/8 percent 20-year bonds maturing May 15, 2010.
The bonds were priced at $100, and yielded 1.50 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 8 3/4 percent Treasury bonds of 2020 at the time of pricing.
Both parts of the issue were rated A-2 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
Traders in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities said the prices of most actively quoted bonds fell by 1/4 point to 1/2 point.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, market participants said the prices of most longer dated issues fell by 3/8 point. Meanwhile, prices of intermediate-term securities were essentially unchanged.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Against Yen; Mark and Pound Weaken

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday against the Japanese yen while firming against most other major currencies.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar declined in New York trading to close at 150.83 yen, down from 152.50 on Monday.
The dollar has now fallen almost 6 yen since last Wednesday. The decline has followed economic reports in the United States that showed the economy slowing down, which has led to the expectation that interest rates would not rise and might even decline. Lower interest rates tend to discourage dollar investments. 
The strengthening of the yen, analysts say, also follows the strengthening of European currencies against the dollar in the last two weeks.
In the latest economic report, the Federal Reserve said yesterday that industrial production fell four-tenths of a percent in April, its first decline since January.
Dealers said the market is now focusing on the release of April consumer prices today and March trade data tomorrow for further indications of the direction of the United States economy and interest rates.
Earl Johnson, a currency dealer with the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said the market was predicting higher inflation and a further worsening of the nation's trade deficit.
''We're in a bearish climate right now,'' he said.
The dollar's gains against some of the European currencies reflected continued problems across the Atlantic.
The mark remained under pressure, they said, after the surprisingly weak showing in recent West German state elections by Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative party. Those results brought some uncertainty about the pending reunification with East Germany, dealers said.
The dollar rose to 1.6465 West German marks from 1.6428.
The British pound fell against the dollar after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said she supported efforts by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, to lower the current official interest rate of 15 percent by the end of the year.
Sterling cost $1.6775 in London, less than the $1.6817 Monday, and $1.6725 in New York, down from $1.6825.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.3980 Swiss francs, up from 1.3915; 5.5540 French francs, up from 5.5360; 1,211.25 Italian lire, up from 1,208.00, and 1.17695 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17715.
Gold prices, meanwhile, rebounded yesterday after falling overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $370.90 an ounce, up $2.50 from late Monday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $370.25 an ounce, up $2.15.
Gold fell in London to $367.75 an ounce, from $369.75, and in Zurich to $367.50 an ounce, from $368.75.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $368.05 an ounce, down from $368.35.
Silver prices declined. Silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.012 an ounce, down from $5.066 Monday. Silver fell in London to $5.07 an ounce from $5.09.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Soybeans Fall for Third Day; Rise in Brazil Exports Cited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of soybean futures declined sharply yesterday for the third straight day amid profit taking and speculative sales prompted in part by rising Brazilian exports. There are signs that those exports are closing the gap between world supply and demand. 
On other commodity markets, grain futures fell, cocoa futures retreated, oil futures were mixed, precious metals were mixed, and livestock and meat futures were mixed.
Soybean futures settled 8 cents to 11 1/2 cents lower on the Chicago Board of Trade, with the contract for delivery in May down by 10 1/4 cents at $6.13 1/4 a bushel. The decline extended to about 35 cents the drop in the May soybean contract's price since Thursday, when the Agriculture Department released a report projecting rising American soybean stocks.
Some analysts attributed the weakness to increased soybean exports, especially from Brazil, the world's second-largest producer after the United States. Brazilian shipments have risen in the last 10 days after a monthlong period in which exports of newly harvested soybeans were stalled by confusion over Brazil's harsh economic changes.
Corn futures posted their steepest one-day decline this year after recently advancing on concerns about rain-delayed planting activity.
Wheat futures settled 1 1/4 cents to 2 cents lower in Chicago, with the contract for delivery in May at $3.83 a bushel, corn was 4 1/2 cents to 6 cents lower, with May at $2.84 3/4 a bushel, and oats were half-a-cent lower to a quarter-cent higher, with May at $1.56 a bushel.
Cocoa futures settled mostly lower on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange amid profit taking after Monday's gains. Cocoa settled $14 lower to $6 higher, with May at $1,375 a ton.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Japanese Help Fill Trade Center

BYLINE: By Alan S. Oser

 BODY:
''THANK heavens for the Japanese!'' George Rossi exclaimed. They are making the office leasing numbers look respectable at the World Trade Center.
Mr. Rossi has been the trade center's general manager for sales and leasing for the last 13 months. He has 10 million square feet of office space to think about, and it is no secret that these are not happy days for the downtown Manhattan office market. 
People talk about a vacancy rate there hovering around 14 percent. When secondary, or non-prime, space is considered separately, the rate may be 20 to 25 percent.
But at the World Trade Center, Mr. Rossi is happy to say, the vacancy rate is only 7 percent, or 700,000 square feet, of which 500,000 square feet are available currently. Tenants who now occupy the other 200,000 square feet intend to leave when their leases expire.
Many people have worried that a heightened presence of Japanese interests in the New York City economy symbolizes a setback to American enterprise. But for a landlord who has seen occupancy fall from 98 percent to 93 percent, the increased Japanese presence, particularly the banks, is a blessing.
The trade center's experience helps put in focus the importance of Asian financial institutions to the New York City office market.
By the end of this year, close to 10 percent of the office tenants of the World Trade Center will be Japanese concerns. The figure is 750,000 square feet already.
The leading Japanese banks -among them Fuji Bank, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, Yasuda Trust and Banking and Sumitomo Bank Ltd. - occupy 350,000 square feet. That figure will soon go up to 440,000 square feet, Mr. Rossi says.
The trade center's special affinity with the Asian financial world extends beyond its relationship with the Japanese. The total space occupied by all Asian banks, bank-service firms, investment banks and currency traders amounts to 826,000 square feet, compared with 800,000 square feet by similar American institutions and 236,000 square feet by European financial institutions.
The even better news, he says, is the rapid expansion of Japanese regional banks in the United States. They often make the World Trade Center their first location for the away-from-home headquarters.
On a square-foot basis, none of this has compensated for the trade center's occupancy losses. These are mainly a result of the decline in tenants in the shipping business. Many have either closed or moved to less expensive secondary space, Mr. Rossi said.
The center's biggest tenant, Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., has left about 300,000 square feet of space since its peak occupancy of 1.3 million square feet in the 1980's. Dean Witter Reynolds has its world headquarters at the World Trade Center.
The biggest loss of all in the 1980's has been the steady departure of New York State agencies. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo set that in motion when he took office for his first term in January 1983.
The state was occupying two million square feet of space at the time. Its agencies had moved in during the dark days of the early 1970's, one of the most dismal real estate markets of New York City's post-Depression history. The trade center was developed by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and opened in December 1970.
Governor Cuomo thought that state offices ought to be dispersed in less prestigious locations of the city, where rents were lower and office occupancy might give the subcenters an economic lift. The state has been moving out of the World Trade Center ever since. Its occupancy is down to two floors occupied by the Governor's office itself, plus two floors that will be vacated this summer. By the end of this year, the state will occupy less than 100,000 square feet.
Most of the space that the state yielded was re-rented in the mid-1980's in the middle-$30-a-square-foot range, Mr. Rossi said. But in the last two years rents have fallen about $2 a square foot a year; annual rents are now $28 to $40 a square foot.
In recent months the market and the center sustained the additional blow of the shrinkage in the space needs of Shearson American Express, and the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Together, those events have put about 750,000 square feet of space that had been committed back on the market.
The silver lining, for the present, is therefore the Japanese expansion. It has a positive effect on downtown employment as well. Although the Trade Center management lacks precise figures, it notices that space leased by Japanese banks is often filled with workers, some occupying cubicles as small as 60 square feet.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
LITHUANIA AGREES TO SUSPEND LAWS ON INDEPENDENCE

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 16

 BODY:
The Lithuanian government formally agreed today to suspend all laws it has passed since its declaration of independence on March 11 and to discuss a transition period to full separation from the Soviet Union, officials of the republic said tonight.
The offer, prepared in a closed-door session of the Parliament and Cabinet, was the Lithuanians' most concerted attempt so far to persuade President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to lift his partial economic embargo and begin negotiations.
The Lithuanian Prime Minister, Kazimiera Prunskiene, was to fly to Moscow on Thursday bearing the government declaration and a letter to Mr. Gorbachev. It was not clear whether she would be met by Kremlin officials or whether Moscow would accept the gesture as an opportunity to end the standoff. Respite for Gorbachev, Too? Mr. Gorbachev would presumably welcome a chance to end the economic sanctions against Lithuania, which could cast a pall over his meeting with President Bush in Washington. That meeting is to begin May 30, about the time that Lithuania expects to exhaust the last of its oil reserves. 
As the Lithuanians met, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union started talks in Moscow on obstacles blocking a series of arms control agreements in advance of the summit. But the increasingly unstable situation in the Soviet Baltic republics threatened to derail their efforts. [Page A10.] The proposal by the Lithuanians essentially embraced a compromise proposed last month by France and West Germany, which called for Lithuania to suspend the enforcement of its independence proclamation without actually repealing it.
 
Graceful Retreat for All
When the proposal was made by President Francois Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl, President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania and a Kremlin spokesman both praised it as a possible escape from the deadlock.
But since then, Mr. Gorbachev has insisted that Lithuania return to its status of March 10, the day before it broke with Moscow, and follow secession procedures spelled out in a new Soviet law. This would require approval of independence by referendum, a transition period of up to five years, and final approval by the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies.
Lithuania and its neighboring Baltic republics, Latvia and Estonia, were annexed by Stalin in 1940 under a secret protocol to a pact with Hitler. The three republics say they were illegally incorporated and therefore will not submit to Soviet sovereignty.
An estimated 30,000 people in Lithuania have been laid off or sent on unscheduled vacations since Mr. Gorbachev cut off oil, most natural gas, and various other supplies to the republic.
The Lithuanians declined to disclose the text of their offer, but as explained by officials, it called for the suspension of the secession laws after Moscow agreed to begin negotiations and provided assurances that it would make no moves to supplant the current leadership of the republic.
Among the measures that would be suspended are several that Moscow has cited as particularly offensive, including those abolishing the Soviet military draft and laying claim to national property.
''Basically, it's the offer Mitterrand and Kohl suggested,'' said Rita Dapkus, a spokeswoman for the Lithuanian Parliament. ''We would be prepared to temporarily suspend the unilateral realization of those resolutions, which arise from the act of restoring state independence.''
The proposal also offers to discuss an unspecified transition period to full sovereignty, to guarantee the rights of Soviet citizens in Lithuania, and to negotiate on Moscow's security concerns, which include the fate of military bases and Baltic ports.
After Lithuania declared a clean break with Moscow on March 11, Estonia announced on March 30 that it would make a step-by-step withdrawal from Soviet law. On May 4, Latvia made its declaration, apparently intended to minimize confrontation with Moscow. It established an open-ended transition period to independence, during which most Soviet laws would apply.
Lithuania's offer today would put it more into line with the gradual approach adopted by Latvia and Estonia. Mr. Gorbachev this week rebuffed the more conciliatory approach of those two republics, issuing decrees declaring their actions invalid. But he has so far not imposed sanctions on them.
Anti-independence groups stormed the Parliament buildings in Latvia and Estonia on Tuesday.
Prime Minister Edgar Savisaar of Estonia, in a telegram to Mr. Baker at the outset of his visit to Moscow, described the incident in the republic as an ''attempted coup,'' and urged the Secretary of State to take up the issue in his talks with the Soviet leadership.
In Riga, The Associated Press quoted Deputy Prime Minister Ilmars Bisers of Latvia as saying that a delegation from the republic expected to have mid-level meetings in Moscow on the situation. Mr. Bisers, speaking today after returning to the Latvian capital from his own Moscow discussions, said talks with Soviet officials would focus on ''the gaining of independence on the basis of a treaty with the Soviet Union.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 2339 words

HEADLINE: PSYCHIATRISTS UNDER PRESSURE: A SPECIAL REPORT:
HEALTH;
New Paths to Mental Health Put Strains on Some Healers

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
Many psychiatrists say they are seeing fewer patients and drawing less satisfaction from their work than ever before. Some are leaving the profession or moving to areas where the competition for patients is less fierce. And the number of newcomers to the profession is dwindling.
The signs are of a slump rather than a terminal condition, and the causes of the problem are clear:
* There are more non-psychiatrist therapists than ever, and they are willing to offer many of the same services to patients for a fraction of what a psychiatrist would charge. Indeed, many observers of the mental-health field believe that the increased competition is good for patients, although some psychiatrists dispute that.
* Bastions of psychiatric privilege are under siege: psychiatrists can no longer exclude other therapists from training in the most prestigious psychoanalytic institutes, and psychologists are battling for the rights to prescribe medication and to admit patients to psychiatric hospitals on their own, rather than under the supervision of psychiatrists. 
* Aggressive companies that manage mental health payments for insurers are slicing reimbursements for psychiatric care, often by half or more. Sessions on such companies were among the best attended - and saw some of the hottest debate - at the 143d annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association in New York, which is ending today.
* Insurance companies are now giving priority to short-term therapy focused on a single problem, rather than to long-term treatment, often lasting years, that was the bread-and-butter of many psychiatrists' practices.
* Compensation for psychiatrists remains relatively low. Their median salary in 1988, the last year for which figures are available, was $97,000. Although most Americans would feel amply paid at that salary, it was below all other medical specialties except family practice and pediatrics.
The median income for all physicians was $120,000, with half earning more and half earning less. From 1981 to 1988, psychiatrists' salaries lost ground to all other medical specialties except family practice and radiology.
''For the first time, psychiatrists have to justify their very existence to those who pay their patients' bills, to government, to other physicians,'' said Dr. Boris Rifkin, a psychiatrist at Yale who is on the American Psychiatric Association's committee on private practice. ''It's demoralizing.''
Herbert Klein, publisher of Psychotherapy Finances, a newsletter in Ridgewood, N.J., that tracks the mental health field. said, ''It's a dogfight out there.''
 
The Battle Lines
The main battle is between psychiatrists, who have medical degrees, and psychologists, social workers and other counselors with other kinds of professional degrees. All these disciplines practice psychotherapy, or ''talking cures'' for emotional problems, although only pyschiatrists can prescribe drugs. Psychoanalysis, the method of treatment developed by Freud and stressing the role of childhood conflicts, is one psychotherapy that is having particular difficulty in the new economic climate, largely because effective psychoanalysis requires frequent visits for many years.
Because of the pressure psychiatrists feel, ''you have to see more patients for less time, rather than having deeper, longer relationships with fewer patients,'' said Seymour Gers, a psychiatrist in Manhattan. ''The turnover means you just don't get the emotional satisfaction you once did for the amount of work you have to put in these days. Since psychiatry is not a big money-maker, the question is why go into it these days?''
In fact, psychiatry is attracting far fewer medical residents than it did in years past. ''Our peak year was 1969,'' said Dr. Melvin Sabshin, medical director of the the American Psychiatric Association. Numbers ''dropped steadily until a few years ago,'' when they began to rise again, he said, but ''it's down a bit this year, which worries us.''
In the long term, the prognosis for psychiatry is good, Dr. Sabshin said. There is increasingly strong evidence that maladies like schizophrenia, obsessive-compulsive disorder and many forms of depression are largely biological, and that psychiatric medications are more effective than ever before in treating them, he said. ''The budgets for psychiatric research have increased considerably over the last few years, to their highest levels ever,'' he said. ''That should pay off in the years to come with new medications and other treatments.''
But while there are optimistic signs, he added, ''there's no question that the new economics creates a problem.'' Temptations Questionable Ways To Generate Money In extreme cases, psychiatrists are resorting to questionable or unethical practices to generate income in hard times.
''There was a woman in her 11th year of psychotherapy whose main problem was loneliness,'' said Nicholas Cummings, a psychologist and chairman of American Biodyne in South San Francisco, a company that manages mental health costs for insurers. The doctor charged $175 a session, Dr. Cummings said, but the patient said ''that for the last seven or eight years she and her psychiatrist had not talked about anything serious - just what each of them had done that week.''
''She was in love with him,'' Dr. Cummings said. ''Seeing him was the one exciting contact in her life.''
Another psychiatrist, Dr. Cummings said, charged $125 for a full therapy session with a woman who came for just 10 minutes, instead of the usual 50, to maintain a relationship with a therapist.
''She said she stayed with the psychiatrist because she was convinced she was mentally ill, and he was kind to her,'' said Dr. Cummings. ''She felt that when she had the nervous breakdown she feared one day, he at least would not give her electroshock therapy. The psychiatrist sensed the woman would never blow the whistle. It was a cozy arrangement for him.''
 
Preferred the Hospital
In another case, reviewed by a prominent Los Angeles psychiatrist for an insurance company, a psychiatrist admitted a young woman with symptoms of ''borderline'' personality to a psychiatric hospital, where he kept her in treatment for two years. As long as she remained in the hospital, the psychiatrist could get $1,000 a week from her insurance company by seeing her every day in the hospital. If he treated her in his office, though, he could collect for just one visit a week, at $125.
Whenever she started to get better, the psychiatrist treated her with a drug that induces a trance-like state. ''She would fall apart, become suicidal and would have to stay in the hospital,'' said the psychiatrist who reviewed the case for an insurance company. ''There's no doubt in my mind he had a vested interest in keeping her in the hospital, where he wouldn't have if his own practice had been thriving.'' The case is still under review.
To be sure, a vast majority of psychiatrists do not take advantage of their patients. And such ethical violations are not unique to psychiatrists.
But in the past, ethical violations were more often about abuses of power, like having sex with patients. Many psychiatrists see these new cases as evidence of a trend among colleagues driven to questionable practices purely because of the new financial squeeze.
''The attitude out there is that if you find a patient with good coverage, you go after him,'' said Dr. Spencer Eth, a psychiatrist at the University of California at Los Angeles. ''There's no question some patients are being exploited.'' Turf Battles Fighting Off Psychologists Psychiatrists are fighting off psychologists, who want to be granted the right to prescribe medications for their patients. In a crucial experiment, the Department of Defense plans to train a group of psychologists to prescribe medication. The pilot program is under medical supervision, but if it is successful, psychologists would seek changes in regulations that would allow them to prescribe on their own.
That idea draws immediate fire from most psychiatrists. ''Would you want your medications managed by someone who had a 30-day summer school course in psychiatric prescribing?'' said Dr. Jonathan L. Schwartz, editor-in-chief of Psychiatric Times. ''It makes me very nervous.'' Another key battle is being waged between psychiatrists and psychologists in California over the right to admit patients to hospitals. A court ruling in July by the California Supreme Court will determine whether to give hospital privileges to psychologists.
Still another erosion of psychiatric earning power looms on July 1, when psychologists and social workers will become eligible for reimbursement by Medicare for therapy with the elderly. ''Until now, you had to be under the supervision of a psychiatrist or physician in a hospital, but now psychologists and social workers can get paid directly for therapy in their private practice,'' said Mr. Klein of Psychotherapy Finances newsletter. The Resources Who Pays for What With Money Tight?
Those taking a hard look at mental health costs argue that the challenges to psychiatry are a good development. Dr. Bernard Rapaport, a psychiatrist and medical director of American Biodyne, agreed.
''We don't think psychologists can prescribe or supervise hospitalization as well as psychiatrists,'' said Dr. Rapaport. But, he said, ''given the limited resources available, we have to apportion mental health money more reasonably, in a way that benefits patients and those who pay their bills.''
''There are a broad range of skills and abilities among mental health professionals,'' he said, ''and you don't need medical school training to do psychotherapy when there's no biological disorder. Social workers or psychologists can do it at lower cost.
''Insurers and others who foot the bill are now saying, Wait a minute, why pay a psychiatrist $120 an hour when I can pay a social worker $50 or less for the same service?''
Other pressure is coming from medical plans, like health maintenance organizations, which contract with psychiatrists to take referrals. ''A big H.M.O. here in Berkeley has 100,000 patients, including all the faculty at the University,'' said Dr. Rapaport. ''If I agree to become a preferred provider and get referrals from them, I have to agree to accept $64 for a therapy hour. That's about half my normal fee.'' Changes in Insurance Psychoanalysts and other psychiatrists whose practice was based on a small number of patients who came several times a week over several years are among those struggling the most.
''Fewer and fewer patients are looking for that kind of treatment, and insurance companies are refusing to pay for it,'' said Dr. Larry Rockland, a psychiatrist at Cornell University Medical School in Westchester County.
In 1982, a key insurance program for Federal employees cut back its coverage of psychotherapy from 80 percent for all visits to no more than half the cost up to a maximum of 50 visits. Since then other insurance companies, like Blue Cross, have followed suit, with some cutting back even more.
Until about 10 years ago, it was not unusual for an insurance plan to cover 80 percent of psychotherapy's costs, even for patients who visited a psychiatrist several times a week. Today, such plans are very rare. A common ''high option,'' or more expensive, plan at Blue Cross offers to pay for 75 percent of a maximum of 50 therapy sessions in a year, with a lifetime maximum of $75,000. A typical ''low option'' plan covers 50 percent of the cost of 25 sessions a year, with a lifetime cap of $25,000. The specifics vary from employer to employer and state to state.
''The changes have been devastating for psychoanalysts,'' said Dr. Rockland. ''In Maryland, Blue Cross is moving to eliminate coverage of psychoanalysis altogether,'' said Dr. Harold Eist, president of the American Association of Private Practicing Psychiatrists, based in Washington. ''They claim it's not a medical expense at all.''
Dr. Eist and other psychiatrists contend that the cutbacks are Draconian, cheating patients who need long-term care as well as the psychiatrists who would treat them. The Response Hard Choices In Hard Times Largely because of such cutbacks, many psychiatrists in private practice are having to seek part-time work because they can no longer fill their schedule with patients. While some are having to move away from the most desirable areas - San Francisco, West Los Angeles, Boston and Manhattan - others are leaving the field altogether.
''We have a training and supervising analyst - at the pinnacle of the psychoanalytic community - doing part-time emergency work at a local hospital because he can't fill his hours with analytic patients,'' said Dr. Eth.
Part of the competition for patients comes from a sharp increase in the numbers of other therapists, particularly in more affluent areas. ''Here in Marin County, everybody and his brother seems to be a therapist,'' said Dr. Seymour Boorstein, a psychiatrist in Kentfield, Calif. ''They charge less and promise more than psychiatrists.''
 
Some Go to Small Towns
The story is the same across the country. Dr. Rockland said, ''In Westchester County it's not only crowded with other psychiatrists, but there are increasing numbers of non-medical therapists who charge lower fees.''
There are no precise figures on the numbers of psychiatrists who are moving away from the more crowded areas, or out of the field altogether, but some psychiatrists report signs of migration.
''In Washington, D.C., I know of 10 psychiatrists we've lost; they just couldn't make it any longer in private practice,'' Dr. Eist said. ''Some moved into hospital or clinic practice, some moved away, and some left psychiatry entirely.''
''This year two psychiatrists in West Los Angeles packed up and moved away to less competitive areas,'' said Dr. Eth. ''One went to Delaware, another to a small town in Arizona. There's more competition here than ever.''

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Jobless to Soar in a Free-Market East, C.I.A. Says

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
The Central Intelligence Agency said today that it foresaw soaring unemployment in Eastern Europe as countries there broke up state monopolies and adopted free-market economic principles.
In its first comprehensive report on the region's economic problems, the agency said that ''unemployment could easily exceed 1.5 million in Poland - 9 percent of the work force'' - by the end of this year.
Moreover, the agency said that unemployment might be in the range of 15 percent to 20 percent in Yugoslavia and East Germany and would be ''5 percent or more'' in Bulgaria and Hungary.
The total output of goods and services for Eastern Europe declined last year for the region as a whole and for every country in the region except Czechoslovakia and East Germany, the C.I.A. said in a report to Congress. 
 
Drop in Living Standards Seen
The report was prepared at the request of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. Senator Jeff Bingaman, chairman of the panel's Subcommittee on Technology and National Security, first suggested the study. The C.I.A. has done similar reports on economic developments in the Soviet Union and China every year since 1974.
The new report is an antidote to any romantic notions about East Europe's economic future. ''Overall economic growth in the region is likely to deteriorate further in the short term,'' it said, and economic ''performance may be poorest in those countries pushing reform the hardest: Poland, Hungary and Yugoslavia.''
Indeed, it said, ''Economic performance and living standards - particularly in Poland, Romania and Bulgaria - are likely to decline in the near term.''
The agency said that the economic problems of Eastern Europe resulted, in part, from decades of Communist mismanagement. But in a curious way, it said, the Soviet Union had helped prop up the economies of Eastern Europe, and that crutch is now being taken away.
 
Loss of Raw Materials
As East European countries declare economic independence from Moscow, they lose the benefit of oil, coal and other raw materials sold on exceedingly favorable terms, with sizable long-term credits, the C.I.A. said.
Eastern Europe still conducts about 40 percent of its trade with the Soviet Union, and energy imports from the Soviet Union account for 25 percent of the region's total energy consumption, the report said. Looking to the future, the C.I.A. said that East European officials expect that a united Germany will replace the Soviet Union as ''the area's dominant economic partner.''
The agency warned, ''Unemployment is likely to soar if the new governments vigorously pursue plans to break up large single-enterprise state monopolies, restructure their economies away from noncompetitive heavy industries to light manufacturing and consumer-goods industries, eliminate state subisidies and let the market determine winners and losers.''
 
'Romania at the Back'
Among the seven countries covered in its report, the C.I.A. said that standards of living were highest in East Germany and Czechoslovakia and lowest in Romania, which still suffers from the ''disastrous economic legacy'' of the dictator Nicolae Ceausescu.
The report said that economic ''reform programs and actions have advanced the furthest in Poland, Hungary and Yugoslavia.'' Changes have occurred much more slowly in Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria, with ''Romania at the back of the reform pack,'' it said.
To estimate the standard of living in a country, economists use various statistics including per capita gross national product, which measures the total output of goods and services in relation to the country's population. For the United States, per capita G.N.P. was $21,036 last year.
For Eastern Europe as a whole, per capita G.N.P. was 27 percent of the American figure. By this measure, East Germany had the highest standard of living in Eastern Europe, with 46 percent of that of the United States.
It was followed, in order, by Czechoslovakia (with 37 percent), Hungary (29 percent), Bulgaria (27 percent), Yugoslavia (26 percent), Poland (22 percent) and Romania (16 percent).
The gap between Eastern Europe and the West has widened since 1975, when its per capita output was 32 percent of that in the United States.
Senator Bingaman, a Democrat from New Mexico, said the countries of Eastern Europe faced a ''long and arduous'' struggle to achieve economic well-being. ''While nothing could be more welcome than the liberation of Eastern Europe from Communism and Soviet domination, there is simply no time to be euphoric,'' he said. ''Many countries of the region are in for a period of recession and economic crises. Things will likely get worse before they improve.''
The report, ''Eastern Europe: Long Road Ahead to Economic Well-Being,'' said that most countries in the region would get a ''peace dividend'' as they reduce their armed forces and the production of tanks and other weapons.
But the C.I.A. said the countries of Eastern Europe had only begun to grapple with an ''explosive'' issue: how to distribute the wealth accumulated by the state over the last 40 years.
Already, it said, many people in Eastern Europe complain that government-owned factories, real estate and farms are being sold swiftly, at low prices, to corrupt Communists who held senior positions in the party or the state bureaucracy.

HEADLINE: BUSH PRESSES CASE FOR MANAGUA AID

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Trying to force Congress's hand on aid to Panama and Nicaragua, President Bush said today that delayed action on a relief package compelled him to reject an emergency loan to Nicaragua. He demanded that lawmakers approve the aid before taking a Memorial Day holiday next week.
Mr. Bush, speaking at a broadcast news conference, used dire language to press his case, calling Nicaragua's situation ''critical,'' with the Government ''absolutely bankrupt and strikes and demonstrations in the streets.'' He suggested that failure to pass the pending $720 million relief package for Panama and Nicaragua would risk destroying ''the hopes for freedom in these two fledgling democracies.'' 
The bill provides $320 million in economic aid to Panama and another $400 million in economic aid to Nicaragua.
The President said he had turned down a request by President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua for a $40 million emergency loan. But, turning the blame on Congress, he insisted that his ''hands are tied.'' The Treasury Department said today that the Federal Gold and Reserve Act of 1934 requires payment guarantees for such loans and all Nicaragua had to offer was the unapproved aid program.
 
Threat to Veto Bill
Mr. Bush said that if lawmakers did not enact the aid bill by their Memorial Day recess, he would ''call on the Congress to remain in session until it completes action on a bill that I can sign.''
But he stopped short of a real threat to use his constitutional powers to call Congress to a special session. And despite his urgent tones about the situation in Central America, he repeated his threat to veto the bill if it is not stripped of an amendment on financing for abortion in the District of Columbia.
The Central American aid package has been pending in Congress since March 13 and has been slowed by legislative maneuvering. In the Senate, lawmakers attached to the bill amendments on abortion financing and the use of the death penalty in Washington, along with hundreds of millions of dollars for domestic spending programs unrelated to Panama or Nicaragua. The aid is tied to a second bill in the House that includes a provision cutting military aid to the Government of El Salvador in half.
The President's remarks came as Democratic and Republican lawmakers worked in conference committees to remove some of those obstacles and the remarks immediately drew fire from Democrats on Capitol Hill.
 
Baltics and Summit Meeting
Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who chairs the House Appropriations foreign operations subcommittee, called Mr. Bush's comments a ''cheap shot.''
Mr. Obey said: ''I find it quaint that the President was willing to use the bully pulpit to ask us for money for foreign aid when he was not willing to spell out the reasons that caused him to change his position on taxes. I also think it is peculiar for the President to attack the Congress when he knew full well that we were going into conference this very afternoon to resolve the foreign aid issues.''
At the news conference, Mr. Bush also said:
* The standoff between Moscow and the Baltic republics over their demand for independence ''certainly puts some tension'' on his coming meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But he tempered that by saying he was determined to press ahead with the summit meeting. ''We have negotiated with the Soviets when all of Eastern Europe was in captivity,'' Mr. Bush said.
* He had not decided whether to continue most-favored-nation trade benefits for China, which are renewed annually. He said he did ''not want to send a signal that we're happy with the human-rights record'' of the Beijing Government, but sounded generally positive about extending the trade benefits by the June 3 deadline.
* He saw no sign that the recent release of two hostages in Lebanon signaled the start of a process that would free the others. He said that he was continuing efforts to encourage Iran to help free the remaining hostages, but that he saw ''no reason to be encouraged that the process is under way.''
* The United States could live without its military base rights in the Philippines if that country extracts too high a price in the current negotiations on a new basing agreement. Mr. Bush said he was exploring alternative basing arrangements in the Pacific.
 
'That Mischievous Language'
Although Mr. Bush's primary aim in raising the Nicaragua-Panama aid bill at the news conference was swift passage, he was equally anxious to avoid vetoing it over amendments and riders attached to the legislation.
Congress tried last year to force Mr. Bush to approve an expansion of financing for abortions for impoverished women in Washington, using the city Government's money, by attaching the provision to aid for Poland, which Mr. Bush wanted badly.
After Mr. Bush vetoed the amendment, Democrats attached it to the Central American aid package. ''I will not accept the Nicaragua-Panama bill with that mischievous language placed on it,'' Mr. Bush said today.
He did not mention another amendment, that one Republican-sponsored, that would expand the use of the death penalty in Washington.
Since the aid package was the first spending bill to reach Congress this year, it has become a magnet for domestic spending programs, including food stamps, disaster relief and veterans' benefits.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the Bush News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Issues

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
Well, today I'm making an urgent appeal to Congress to come to the assistance of the peoples of Nicaragua and Panama. I announced my original request for $500 - $500 million in assistance to Panama on Jan. 25, and on March 13 I submitted my modified request for $800 million for both Nicaragua and Panama. At the time of submission I asked the Congress for passage of the legislation by April 5. When that date passed, I asked for passage in time for Violeta Chamorro's inauguration on April 25. I also asked members of Congress, in public and in private, that the bill not be loaded up with extraneous items. And members of our Administration have met with the Congress to explain the content and the urgency of this request. 
But the Easter recess came and went with no passage. And moreover, the bill has tripled in size as extraneous items have been piled onto it. Even worse, the additional amendments include provisions that I vetoed as recently as last fall -provisions that have absolutely nothing to do with Nicaragua and Panama. And I've met repeatedly with the leadership of both Houses of the Congress to urge rapid passage. In the last several days I've shared with them the contents of this letter that I received from President Chamorro of Nicaragua, pleading for prompt passage.
The situation in Nicaragua is critical. Mrs. Chamorro's Government is absolutely bankrupt, and there are strikes and demonstrations in the streets. She's asked me for an emergency bridge loan, but I can't provide that because the Nicaraguans have no assured means of repayment. And our hands are tied and I can't provide a loan anchored on legislation which is not assured.
Panama is also in dire need of the jump-start that our assistance will give to enable it to recover from the economic devastation of the Noriega dictatorship.
We're now facing the Memorial Day recess without the assurance that this legislation will be passed. I'd like the legislation this week, certainly early next week. But I will call on the Congress to remain in session until it completes action on a bill that I can sign. We must not let this procedural gridlock in the Congress destroy the hopes for freedom in these two fledgling democracies.
I feel very strongly about it and I will again appeal to Congress to get moving on this bill.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
Strategic Arms Talks
 
Q. Mr. President, officials accompanying Secretary of State Baker to Moscow say the Soviets have backtracked on earlier agreements on arms control. Does it appear unlikely that you'll have the outlines of a Start treaty to sign at the summit, and how much of a setback would that be?
 
A. Terry, I don't - I wouldn't say that it appears unlikely. I have not heard from Jim Baker since the talks have started in Moscow. I expect we'll be hearing pretty soon, but I would not predict that this, these matters cannot be resolved in time for the summit. But if they're not, we're going to keep on because we want a Start agreement and I'm convinced the Soviets want a Start agreement.
 
Baltic Tensions
 
Q. How much of a cloud has been put over the summit by the tension, the Soviet pressure on the Baltic states?
 
A. Well, I'll be able to answer that a little more after, after Jim comes back from Moscow, but I'd say that it, it has certainly put some tension on the summit. We, we want to see negotiations or dialogue or whatever you call it, discussions, between Gorbachev and the Lithuanians get going. And then I'd like to see the release of that economic pressure on Lithuania. And that would clear the air fast. But until something like that happens, there will be tension.
But we have a broad agenda of, of items that we must go forward on. And we've negotiated with the Soviets when, when all of Eastern Europe was in captivity, and when we had cold war times. And I, I'm unhappy about the state of play in the Baltics because I'd like, like to see them attain their, their desire of, of freedom as soon as possible. But I feel it's important from our standpoint, the important standpoint of Eastern European countries and Western European allies and indeed, the whole world, that we have these discussions with Mr. Gorbachev. And I look forward to them very much, and I particularly look forward to the private ones where, where I can, I can get a better feel for the problems facing him and I can tell him of our priorities in a, in a very frank setting. Helen.
 
Talks on the Budget
 
Q. Mr. President, the Democratic leaders who came out of yesterday's first round of the budget talks indicated that before they're going to advance any proposals at all for dealing with the problem, they want to hear first the Administration's discussion of how grave the problem is and then an Administration proposal or set of proposals for dealing with it. Does the Administration have ready a set of budget proposals that would address the deficit fully?
 
A. Not fully, but Dick Darman has already begun discussions after yesterday's meeting with Congressman Gephardt. And I think that the negotiation can go forward so that both sides come to the table, say what they think and we get an agreement. I'm confident we can get one, but this mandating who does what first, that's not going to get the job done. . . .
In terms of the magnitude of the problem, I do feel that we have an obligation to be sure the Congressmen understand it. But in, Brit, in this sense of going out right now to the American people, I want to go out when we have a bipartisan answer to the problem, say here's what the problem is, and here's what the answer. And if I go out there today, we don't have a bipartisan answer and that's the only way this problem's going to be solved. It's not going to be done one party or another. And it is urgent enough and when the Congress sees the data and the estimates and then C.B.O. and O.M.B. work with the estimates, I'm convinced that we'll have a, enough of a sense of urgency that we'll go forward and get a deal.
 
Q. Well, Mr. President, surely you must recognize that part of the reason why they're so wary is that they heard what they thought were conflicting signals from the Administration last week, you saying no preconditions, Governor Sununu suggesting something quite otherwise. First of all, what happened there and second, what did you say to him about that?
 
A. I haven't said anything to him about it but I've heard conflicting signals out of Congress from the first day I said no condition; people trying to interpret what that meant, and a wide array of blasts out of Congress on both sides of the aisle. But it doesn't help for me to do anything other than to cool it down and say, look, we've got a big problem. Here's the problem, let me explain it to you all as best O.M.B. can. You tell us how C.B.O. sees it. Then let's, as Lyndon said, reason together and try to get a deal. And then make sure the American people understand how serious it is.
But, Brit, I'm not going to go out there and try to do something that might inadvertently suggest crisis and frighten markets. What I think we ought to do is come up, get agreement on the size of the problem and then have a bipartisan answer. And this is very sensitive stuff. Right now the markets are reasonably - reasonably optimistic and there are reasons to be optimistic about the economy. I've seen - earlier on there were some predictions of recession, but right now it appears that most economists don't think there'll be a recession.
So we're blessed by dealing with this problem at a time of some growth - not the robust growth that some of us would like to see, but with some growth. And yet there are still some concerns on the part of the Fed and others on inflation, so I don't want to - to inadvertently send the wrong signals to the markets. Yes, Charles.
 
Dim Outlook on Cuts
 
Q. Mr. President, Mr. Darman has already indicated that there is little probability of getting all the cuts that are necessary in a problem that's estimated at $100 billion. What is your predisposition toward stretching out or amending Gramm-Rudman so that you can do this at a more measured pace?
 
A. Charles, I hate to - it's a very good question, very direct, and I'm not going to answer it. Because I am not going to go out there with a lot of suggestions to part of the problem. And I've said that. I've agreed wtih the Congress, I think they're not supposed to do that either. So we will discuss our discussions in private and then we will have recommendations that might be part of it, because the problem is pretty big. But I don't have a position on that because I've said there are no preconditions.
 
Q. Well, sir, actually your spokesman, Mr. Fitzwater, has listed some conditions. He says you wouldn't --
 
A. Down with him, down! He's --
 
Q. -- the budget deficit and he wouldn't advocate any solutions that would be a drag on the economy. My question to you is: Can you be persuaded that a tax exists that would not be a drag on the economy? Do you know of any such taxes?
 
A. John, you're trying to get me to do that which just one second ago I said I wouldn't do. And I'm trying to negotiate and to keep the negotiating process in good faith, but I just can't - if I start going into answering questions like that, no matter how much merit they have, then I start having conditions, or preconditions. And I can't do that and deal in good faith with Congress.
 
Q. May I ask you your concept of leadership on this? You will not advocate any solutions, you will not go on prime-time television and spell out the nature of the budget defi-cit --
 
A. At the appropriate time, I will.
 
Q. When will that be?
 
A. I don't know, we've got to get on with what I told you the process is. And the process is not setting preconditions. And the process is to go forward in good faith with the Congress. And I think they're dealing in good faith, I believe that the two leaders I've been dealing with want this process to go forward in this way.
 
Urgency on Budget
 
Q. Mr. President, if I could return to the budget negotiations for a second, there's a lot of speculation without getting into details about the negotiations about why you personally decided the matter was urgent enough now to resort to this process. Is it because you're afraid interest rates might stop the economic growth that you want so much? Is it because the automatic spending cuts would be too painful for the country to absorb? Or are you just frustrated that the deficit continues to restrict your ability to maneuver on a lot of issues?
 
A. Well, I think - I want to say almost all of the above, but it's really that when you take a look at the most recent estimates - and one of the ingredients in the shortfall has been interest rates - is that the problem is of such a magnitude that we need to address it. It's more that than it is a fear of any specific category. It's just big enough that we have to do something about it, and that's why I've taken the approach I've taken.
And I think - but in here, you see, it is a place where we need to get understanding from the American people. But I want to go there saying, Look, here's the problem. Everybody's agreed on it now, we're not going to have some new organization come in and argue with the estimates - and that means getting C.B.O. and the O.M.B. together as much as possible. Here's the bipartisan answer. They can compromise here, give and take there, and this is what we must do as a nation on the deficit. 
 
Good Faith in Talks
 
Q. Mr. President, many of the participants from yesterday's budget meeting came out shaking their heads and scratching their heads in frustration at the size of the problem that you just talked about, the magnitude of this deficit problem, and the lack of trust that appeared to be in the room. In fact, one of the participants said they all turned back their papers that they had written notes on so that no one would be able to quote from them. And they all said that it's going to take a lot of leadership --
 
A. That was a heartening development, Jessica.
 
Q. -- a lot of leadership. I'm wondering what is it that you think that you can do that can move the atmosphere forward, the atmosphere of trust first of all, so that people will believe in the good faith that you are expressing?
 
A. . . . I don't think people think I'm trying to blindside them in the Congress. That might have been early on when I first said let's go, no preconditions. But I didn't get the feeling of, of distrust and when people headed, handed the papers back it was so the process could work in an orderly fashion. And it wasn't the Republicans that suggested it as I recall. It was a Democratic leader said, let's leave these and let our, our group that's going to meet on Thursday discuss these matters and discuss it in a, in a, you know, as quiet a surrounding as possible without having a big flurry out there surrounding the discussions. . . . I interpreted that as a determination to work together. . . .
 
Stalemate on Taxes
 
Q. But they all say that there's a stalemate about how to address the one side of the equation, the tax side of the equation. It's going to take leadership to move things. Someone's going to have to move first. . . .
 
A. That's what the process will do. No tricks in the bag, but when you start a negotiation, a labor management negotiation they get behind closed doors and they say, now look, here's our view and what is yours and reasonable people go forward and try to, try to negotiate. So I think the Democrats did come down, some of them, saying well, you should go first. And I said to them, wait a minute, who appropriates all the money, where's the revenue, who's got the obligation under the, under the Constitution to raise the revenue. So let's not talk about who's going first, we got a problem. We have a national problem. And I want to be a part of having the American people understand the problem and I want to have an answer to the American people that I know can, can, can work. And it's not going to work with just Republicans or just the White House or just the Democrats. . . . I'm going to try to keep my share of the bargain by not discussing what we might do or might not do, what my bottom line is, what my opening wedge is. Because once I do that, you'll have 435 people in the House doing it and 100 in the Senate. And that isn't the way we're going to solve this national problem.

GRAPHIC: photo: Richard G. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and the Budget, leaving a Congressional building yesterday after meeting with members of the House Budget Committee on the deficit problem. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cautious Bush Says Urgency of Deficit Impelled Him to Seek Talks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
In his first public explanation of why he initiated budget negotiations with Congress, President Bush said today that the deficit problem had become ''urgent enough'' that it needed to be addressed now, while the economy was reasonably strong.
But Mr. Bush, speaking at a news conference, declined to describe the nature of the problem or to say what he wanted to do about it.
''I don't want to inadvertently send the wrong signals to the markets,'' the President declared, repeating what he said in private to Congressional leaders on Tuesday in the first session of the negotiations.
Mr. Bush's refusal to make his case in detail and in prime time on television was challenged today by Democratic legislators. They maintain that Mr. Bush, and Ronald Reagan before him, sold a bill of goods to the public about the strength of the economy and the virtue of low taxes and say Mr. Bush is unwilling to take the political heat necessary to rectify past mistakes. Smoke and Mirrors? ''What we're seeing is a recognition of what has been a continuing crisis,'' said Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, chairman of the House Budget Committee. ''What we feel needs to be done is for the President to make a presentation to the American public. The problem is serious, and you can't use smoke and mirrors to get around it any longer.'' 
Democratic lawmakers told Mr. Bush on Tuesday that they would have trouble selling unpopular measures to their constituents if he did not make his own case in a televised address. Asked at his news conference why he did not do so, Mr. Bush said, ''I'm not going to go out there and do something that might inadvertently suggest crisis and frighten the markets.''
Mr. Bush also refused to say whether he had changed his mind about opposing all new taxes. But he said his Administration and Congress had to be careful not to cut spending or raise taxes so much that the economy would be damaged.
In his first 15 months in the White House, Mr. Bush never hinted that the economy was anything but rosy, that the budget deficit might require painful belt-tightening or that higher taxes might be acceptable.
Then, 10 days ago, he summoned Congressional leaders to a Sunday evening meeting in the living quarters of the White House and said he wanted to begin talks to bring down the deficit. The first session was held Tuesday, and the next is scheduled for Thursday afternoon. Bush's Biggest Test? Today he said striking a deal to cut the deficit would be the biggest test of his leadership on a domestic policy issue.
The President was asked whether his stance had changed because high interest rates threatened economic growth, because automatic spending cuts called for by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law if the deficit was not brought down enough might be too deep for the country to absorb, or because he was frustrated by the lack of money available for programs he favored. He responded:
''I want to say almost all of the above, but it's really that when you take a look at the most recent estimates, the problem is of such a magnitude that we have to address it. It's more that than it is a fear of any specific category. It's just big enough that we have to do something about it, and that's why I've taken the approach I have taken.''
Mr. Bush said the time is ripe now because ''the markets are reasonably optimistic, and there are reasons to be optimistic about the economy.''
The Dow Jones industrial average reached a new high on Tuesday and then dropped slightly today.
Mr. Bush continued: ''There were some predictions of recession, but right now it appears that most economists don't think there will be a recession. So we are blessed by dealing with this problem at a time of some growth, not the robust growth that some of us would like to see, but with some growth.''
 
TV at 'Appropriate Time'
Mr. Bush said he hoped to impress on Congress ''enough of a sense of urgency that we'll go forward and get a deal.'' He said he would address the country at an ''appropriate time.''
Late this afternoon, Richard G. Darman, Mr. Bush's budget director, met privately with the House Budget Committee to describe the dimensions of the deficit problem.
Legislators who were there reported that Mr. Darman described the impact of automatic spending cuts of more than 20 percent in many Government programs if the problem was not resolved.
 
A Theory on Motive
Cuts of that size would be ''devastating'' and ''send shock waves through the economy,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat.
Mr. Schumer said Mr. Darman seemed to be trying to persuade Democrats that after a decade of masking fiscal problems, the Republican Administration was now trying sincerely to deal with them.
Mr. Bush used figures today that suggested he might favor changing the deficit target of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law. The law requires a deficit no higher than $64 billion in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. Otherwise automatic cuts in most Government programs would go into effect.
Mr. Darman has told lawmakers that spending reductions or tax increases of more than $60 billion may be needed to meet the $64 billion goal. If spending for the bailout of failed savings and loan associations is counted, the required deficit reduction could exceed $100 billion, Mr. Darman says.
Mr. Bush said deficit reduction measures that exceeded half the annual growth in the economy would risk an economic slowdown, ''exacerbating the problem rather than making it better.''
Economists say the country's gross national product of about $5.5 trillion is growing at an annual rate of about 2 percent, or about $110 billion. So Mr. Bush seemed to be supporting a maximum deficit reduction of $55 billion, which, by Mr. Darman's calculations, might not be enough to meet the law's target.

HEADLINE: Panel Is Told of Race Pattern in Lending

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Blacks who apply for home mortgages are turned down more than twice as often as whites, a Federal regulator told a Senate subcommittee today.
The information presented today supports a trend that the Government has tracked through most of the 1980's showing that blacks and other minorities have problems getting mortgages. Another witness, a consumer advocate, said that the numbers may not reflect the magnitude of the hurdles facing minorities seeking mortgages, suggesting that many lending institutions succeed in discouraging blacks from even submitting applications.
In testimony before the Senate Banking Subcommittee on Consumer and Regulatory Affairs, Jerauld C. Kluckman, the director of compliance programs for the Office of Thrift Supervision, said that in the first six months of 1989 blacks were rejected 29 percent of the time when they applied for loans at the nation's 2,500 savings and loan associations, as against a rejection rate of 13 percent for whites. 
That was an increase over the second half of 1988, Mr. Kluckman said, when the rejection rate was 23 percent for blacks and 11 percent rate for whites.
 
Other Factors Are Cited
Mr. Kluckman's office, which is part of the Treasury Department, is the primary regulator of the nation's savings and loan industry.
Mr. Kluckman said in an interview that the change in 1989 does not necessarily represent a sudden increase in possible discrimination, but was more likely a result of rising interest rates and the problems of the savings and loan industry, the dominant originators of home mortgages in the United States. The numbers do not include data from the nation's commercial banks and other mortgage lenders, This issue of lending discrimination has been a long-standing problem for policy makers and banking regulators, with consumer advocacy groups complaining that discrimination exists, while regulators say they do not have sufficiently sophisticated statistical tools to prove discrimination.
''The financial regulatory agencies may see, hear and speak no evil, but I believe that the evidence demonstrates that discrimination in mortgage lending still exists in the country,'' said Senator Alan J. Dixon, an Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the subcommittee.
 
Lax Enforcement Charged
Contending that the Federal bank regulators are not enforcing the antidiscrimination laws, he said that after making thousands of examinations of banks and other lending institutions, the regulators had found ''only six or seven substantive violations of fair-lending laws prohibiting mortgage discrimination over the past three years.''
Mr. Kluckman cautioned against reading too much into the statistics. He said the numbers did not indicate anything about the economic standing of the applicants. Thus, a lending instiution might have a predominantly large number of high-income whites applying for mortgages and a large segment of low-income blacks, which would skew the numbers.
''We have no information in our study about credit worthiness, and that is often the thing that makes the call about whether a loan application is approved or not,'' Mr. Kluckman said.
He said he did not have any statistics on whether the actual number of mortgage applicants by blacks had increased from the second half of 1988 to the first half of 1989, nor whether the number of rejections had increased. Nor does the study break down the information by such categories as the size of the mortgage being sought or the part of the country involved.
 
Special Assistant Quits
While the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation came in for praise by the Senate panel for setting up a separate consumer compliance examination force to police its banks, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency was accused of making little progress in discouraging and detecting lending discrimination.
Indeed, shortly before the hearing Ronald E. Wienk, special assistant for fair lending, resigned, complaining that the comptroller's office had suppressed information on racial discrimination at its national banks. He asserted that the office's ''failure to adequately perform its responsibilities prompts my resignation.''
Leonora Cross, a spokesman for the comptroller's office, said Mr. Wienk was referring to a study conducted in 1987 and 1988 of its banks that the agency considered flawed and decided not to release.
Another witness before the Senate panel said government regulators did little to detect how banks and other lending institutions discourage minorities from even applying for mortgages.
 
'Testers' Pose as Applicants
Allen Fischbein, general counsel for the Center for Community Change, a consumer advocacy group, said his organization conducted a study in 1988 in which it sent ''testers'' posing as applicants to a number of banks and lending institutions, with almost identical financial profiles except that one tester was black and the other white.
''Frequently there was a different treatment,'' Mr. Fishbein said, adding that when the black tester went in, he was told that to get a mortgage with 10 percent down the bank required a deposit equal to six months of mortgage payments. When the white tester went in, he was given the additional information that with an 11 percent downpayment the bank required only two months' advance mortgage payment.
''There may be substantial discrimination problems at the preapplication stage,'' Mr. Fishbein said, ''and right now the agency does not have a system that can detect that kind of problem.''
Mr. Kluckman agreed that such tactics could hide discrimination.
''If an institution only takes a few black applications and approves them all, the statistic would look good,'' he said. ''On the other hand, you might have an institution that has a bad rejection record but a good outreach program, and is trying to get as many applications in as possible.''
Mr. Kluckman also said the agency had found instances where banks set such high standards they automatically disqualify minorities.
Some banks, for example, have set a minimum mortgage loan levels at $30,000 or $40,000. That means that buyers of low-cost homes under that amount could not get a mortgage from those institutions except by paying a higher rate of interest or higher fees.
