HEADLINE: Minnesota Lands Gorbachev: Public Relations Man's Coup

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Three months ago, Albert Eisele, a Minnesota public relations consultant, learned that Mikhail S. Gorbachev wanted to travel across the United States after his summit meeting with President Bush.
''A light went off,'' Mr. Eisele said. ''What better place to bring him than Minnesota?''
So began an effort that reached its successful conclusion on Monday with the announcement that the Soviet leader would spend six hours in Minnesota on June 3. 
Mr. Eisele's relationship with the Russians actually began in February 1987, when he went to the Soviet Union with William C. Norris, founder and chairman emeritus of the Control Data Corporation. The company, based in Minneapolis, had sold the first large American computers to the Soviet Union in 1968, and Mr. Eisele says its long relationship with the Soviets was crucial to his success. ''Control Data has been regarded as a friend even in the 1980's, when few American companies were allowed to do business there because of export restrictions on technology,'' he said.
 
From Blue Earth to Washington
Mr. Eisele (pronounced EYES-lee), 53 years old, was born and raised on a 160-acre farm between Blue Earth and Elmore, the home of Walter F. Mondale. Mr. Eisele worked for The Dispatch and The Pioneer Press of St. Paul, and then served as Mr. Mondale's Vice-Presidential press secretary. After that he worked for Control Data until last September, when he founded Cornerstone Associates, a small public relations and lobbying firm here. Its clients include Control Data.
At the 1987 meeting, V. L. Malkevich, the Soviet First Deputy Minister of Foreign Trade, spoke warmly of Control Data and added, as Mr. Eisele recalls, ''We are not Ivans who do not remember our relatives.''
Mr. Eisele and Mr. Norris made two more visits to the Soviet Union, and this February, Control Data offered to install computers in six Soviet nuclear research sites. The proposal awaits Administration approval and an export license required for such technology.
 
From Minnesota, With Love
It was also in February that Jim O'Connell, a foreign trade specialist with Control Data, learned that Mr. Gorbachev had expressed an interest in traveling around the United States. Mr. O'Connell told Mr. Eisele, who drafted a letter for Gov. Rudy Perpich, inviting Mr. Gorbachev to visit Minnesota. The letter was hand-delivered to Yuri Dubinin, the Soviet Ambassador, on Feb. 26.
The letter said the state had everything the Soviets might need: ''The Twin Cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul are home to a large number of major corporations that are world leaders in computers and microelectronics, medical technology and health-care services, agriculture and food processing, transportation, financial services and insurance, and forestry and mining.''
The Governor's letter went on to note that many Minnesota companies, large and small, were ''very interested in developing business ties with the U.S.S.R. and could provide management expertise to Soviet enterprises as well.'' He proposed that Mr. Gorbachev give a major speech on bilateral cooperation to protect the environment. ''This could serve as a model for U.S.-Soviet cooperation in other areas,'' the letter said.
Finally, the letter noted the similarities between Minnesota and the Soviet Union. ''Minnesota, which is famous for its natural resources and shares many of the climatic and geographical characteristics of the Soviet Union, would be an ideal setting for such a speech,'' it said, and added that many Minnesotans were descendants of Russian immigrants.
 
Setback, Then Success
Hopes for the visit were set back on April 3, when Eduard Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that Mr. Gorbachev's mounting problems at home precluded an extended visit. ''At that point I told everyone, 'It was a good try, but it's off,' '' Mr. Eisele said.
But on Monday afternoon, Mr. Eisele learned from a reporter that Mr. Gorbachev was indeed going to visit Minnesota. Ambassador Dubinin telephoned Mr. Perpich that evening to confirm that the visit was on.
Minnesotans are euphoric, Mr. Eisele said, and added, ''There are 4 million people in Minnesota, and 3.9 million want Gorbachev to visit their homes.''

GRAPHIC: photo: Albert Eisele, who lured Mikhail S. Gorbachev to Minnesota. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
No Summit Can Match Boisterous '59 Circus

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be emulating two of his predecessors, Nikita S. Khrushchev and Leonid I. Brezhnev, when he heads west after his summit meeting with President Bush on May 31 and June 1-2.
But even the ebullient and unpredictable Mr. Gorbachev may find it hard to match the carnival atmosphere generated by Mr. Khrushchev in September 1959 as he swept through Los Angeles, San Francisco, Des Moines, Coon Rapids, Iowa, and Pittsburgh. Six jets were required to carry the entourage. It was one of the first great events of the media age, then just dawning. 
Mr. Khrushchev boasted about Soviet prowess in space and blustered when he saw hostile signs. President Dwight D. Eisenhower had to issue orders to his aides not to argue with the guest.
Heckled during a speech at the Economic Club of New York, welcomed to Los Angeles with glacial disdain by Mayor Norris Poulson, the Soviet leader sparred testily about capitalism and Communism with Spyros P. Skouras, the president of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, and blew his top when security officials refused to let him visit Disneyland, then only four years old.
''What is it?'' he demanded, in one of the least scripted public moments in the long annals of Soviet-American relations. ''Is there an epidemic of cholera there or something? Or have gangsters taken hold of the place?''
When Mrs. Khrushchev complained at a bash for 400 Hollywood stars about having missed the Magic Kingdom, Frank Sinatra leaned over to David Niven and said, ''Tell the old broad you and I will take 'em down there this afternoon.''
Marilyn Monroe, as instructed, wore her tightest dress. ''I could tell Khrushchev liked me,'' she said later, but she found him ''fat and ugly.''
Things went little better at a meeting in San Francisco with Walter P. Reuther of the United Automobile Workers and other labor leaders; Mr. Khrushchev described the trade unionists, to their faces, as ''agents for capitalism,'' and Mr. Reuther described their differences as ''irreconcilable.''
But by the time the Soviet leader reached Iowa on Sept. 22 he was fairly beaming. Eating his first hot dog (with mustard) in a Des Moines factory, he allowed that ''we have beaten you to the moon, but you have beaten us in sausage making.''
The next day, a visit to the farm of Roswell Garst, a wealthy hybrid-corn grower, near Coon Rapids, produced chaos of a kind that the Secret Service would never let happen now. Mr. Garst, furious that reporters and camera crews were disrupting his carefully staged barbecue, threw silage at them, put some of his employees on horseback and had them stage mock cavalry charges at the photographers, and finally kicked one correspondent, Harrison E. Salisbury of The New York Times, smartly in the shins.
''You ought to have a bull to let loose on photographers,'' the Soviet leader told Mr. Garst.
In his memoirs, Mr. Khrushchev concluded that many Americans had come to see him ''more out of curiosity than friendship.'' He added: ''They had paid their 50 kopecks to see this Russian bear. What does he look like? Does he know how to sit at a table in polite society?''
For all its comic aspects, the trip convinced many Americans that Mr. Khrushchev was a shrewd, tough adversary. And he himself learned, as the historian Michael S. Beschloss put it, ''that the United States was not on the verge of falling to Communism,'' no matter what the Soviet Embassy in Washington persisted in saying.
Three decades have passed, with no similar jaunt in the interim except Mr. Brezhnev's rather tame trip to visit Richard M. Nixon at San Clemente in 1973. And it is the Soviet Union and its erstwhile satellites that are flirting with capitalism as Mr. Gorbachev heads west.

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Chief Says Bush Exerts Pressure for Statehood

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon of Puerto Rico accused President Bush today of applying ''heavy-handed political pressure'' to persuade Puerto Ricans to support statehood.
The Governor, who supports continuing the island's status as a United States commonwealth, said the President was handling the proposed plebiscite on Puerto Rico's political future ''the same way as President Gorbachev is handling the Baltic crisis.''
''Both Presidents claim they want the people to make a free choice, and then go out and tell the people what choice to make,'' Mr. Hernandez Colon said in a statement issued in San Juan. The Governor also commented on the issue in a letter today to President Bush. 
Legislation now pending before Congress would authorize a binding plebescite in which Puerto Rican voters could choose among statehood, independence or continued commonwealth status. Statehood supporters emphasize the representation in Congress and the rights and privileges of United States citizenship that would go with that choice. Proponents of independence contend that Puerto Rico should be self-governing. Commonwealth supporters say Puerto Ricans derive benefits from both their relationship with the United States and from their own culture.
 
Bush a Longtime Supporter
President Bush has been a longtime supporter of statehood.
Mr. Hernandez Colon supports the commonwealth option and with it a proposal, under discussion by some in Congress, that would include modifications of Federal laws and regulations aimed at encouraging the island's economic growth.
Mr. Hernandez Colon also criticized two White House aides, Andrew H. Card Jr., the deputy Chief of Staff, and Chase Untermeyer, the White House personnel director who is also the Puerto Rico liaison, saying they spent most of their time on the island this week lobbying for statehood.
The Governor asked Mr. Bush to ''pull back; call off your troops,'' and added, ''The people of Puerto Rico have the intelligence, the capability, the desire and the good common sense to make our own decision.''
The White House press office had no comment on the Governor's attack. Mr. Card and Mr. Untermeyer were in Puerto Rico and unavailable for comment, their secretaries said.
 
'Discharging His Commitment'
Benny F. Cerezo, a spokesman for statehood supporters, said, ''Mr. Bush made a commitment to statehood when he ran in the 1980 Puerto Rican primary. Ever since, he has been a staunch statehooder. His party has statehood as part of its platform. All the President is doing is discharging his commitment.''
A recent study by the Congressional Budget Office found that statehood for Puerto Rico could undermine the island's economy and could cost as many as 100,000 of its 900,000 jobs by the end of the decade. The study, which many people saw as a setback for statehood supporters, estimated that the island would lose 73 percent of the investment it receives from United States companies through elimination of tax benefits intended to stimulate development.

HEADLINE: HOUSE TO DEBATE BILL ON DISABLED

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
The House of Representatives is expected to start debate Thursday on legislation to bar discrimination against the disabled in the workplace and in transportation, public accommodations and telephone services.
Supporters consider the measure the most far-reaching civil rights bill in more than a quarter-century. Its opponents fear its economic impact.
But critics of the bill, the Americans With Disabilities Act, agree with advocates that its passage is virtually assured. A companion bill in the Senate was approved by a vote of 76 to 8 in September. President Bush, who promised in the 1988 Presidential campaign to help the estimated 43 million Americans who have physical or mental disabilities, says he will sign it. 
''We are on the threshold of passing the most signficant civil rights legislation since the Civil Rights Act of 1964,'' said Representative Steny H. Hoyer, a Maryland Democrat who has guided the bill through the House.
 
Wide Impact on Business
The 1964 civil rights law hastened the end of legal segregation by outlawing discrimination based on race, sex, religion, color or national origin in public accommodations, private employment and government services. The disability rights statute could require many businesses to change their offices, factories or stores to accommodate people with disabilities.
Concerned about the cost of compliance and the prospect of lawsuits from disabled people who are not hired or served as customers, business groups have lobbied against the measure.
''We don't want a lot of innocent small-business people who are trying to do the right thing to be hauled into court,'' said David Rahr, chief House lobbyist for the National Federation of Independent Business, a trade association of mainly small companies.
The measure would apply to employers with 25 or more workers, and would go into effect two years after passage. Two years after it went into effect, it would apply to businesses with 15 or more workers.
 
A Definition of Disability
The bill defines a person with a disability as someone with a physical or mental impairment that ''substantially limits a major life activity'' like walking, talking or working. It covers people with AIDS and drug abusers or alcoholics who have undergone treatment. It excludes people with emotional disorders like kleptomania, gambling compulsions and pedophilia.
Under the bill, new buses, trains and subway cars, and renovated or new hotels, retail stores and restaurants would have to be accessible to people in wheelchairs. Existing barriers should be removed if ''readily achievable,'' the bill says.
Three years after passage of the bill, telephone companies would be required to establish ''relay services'' between special telephones for people who have speech or hearing disabilities and people using ordinary telephones. The handicapped people would use the special phones to type out their messages, and an operator would act as an intermediary between them and the users of ordinary phones.
Proponents contend that changes in the bill since it was introduced two years ago have made it more sensitive to business concerns. Companies could not refuse to hire a qualified worker because of a disability, and would have to make a ''reasonable accommodation'' to allow the worker to do the job. But proponents note that employers would be exempt if they could show that the required changes would pose an ''undue hardship'': be too costly or too disruptive, or substantially alter the way they do business.
 
Factors for Exemptions
Whether an employer could be excused from making a reasonable accommodation would depend on the company's size and resources. For example, a small day care center would not be expected to spend more than a nominal sum to modify a telephone so that a speech- or hearing-impaired employee could use it. But a large school might be required to hire an aide to help a blind teacher in a classroom.
Last summer, supporters of the disabled rights bill agreed to limit sanctions to those embodied in the 1964 civil rights law: injunctions to halt biased actions by employers and back pay for victims of discrimination who were dismissed or passed over for promotion. But another pending measure, the Civil Rights Act of 1990, is aimed at expanding the 1964 civil rights law to allow for punitive damages and jury trials in the case of intentional discrimination. The Bush Administration opposes allowing increased damage awards.
After a day and a half of arguing, the House Rules Committee this afternoon approved eight amendments for consideration when the disabled rights bill comes to the floor. Among them is an amendment sponsored by Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., a Wisconsin Republican, intended to head off an automatic increase in damages if the 1990 civil rights bill is approved. The amendment would permit damages to be increased only if the disabled rights act is specifically revised to increase them or if the civil rights bill is revised to apply to the disabled rights act.
Many of the bill's requirements are already embodied in the the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, which prohibited companies and government agencies receiving Federal aid from discriminating against people with disabilities. The Americans With Disabilities Act would extend this concept to businesses and industries that are under private control.

HEADLINE: The Budget: Late and Ugly

 BODY:
Gov. Mario Cuomo tries to disown it. So do Senate Republicans, led by the majority leader, Ralph Marino. In truth, neither side can escape blame for the $1.4 billion package of new taxes and fees agreed to this week by New York State legislative leaders - a 235-page monstrosity accurately dubbed ''the Big Ugly'' by Albany insiders. 
The description also fits the abdication of political leadership that the tax plan exposes.
There's no denying the need for new revenues. The state faces a deficit that could reach $4 billion, and spending cuts alone aren't a realistic remedy. But even after more than three months of partisan haggling, Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders couldn't muster the statesmanship to meet the crisis straightforwardly, with a prudent broad-based tax program.
On the plus side, the package isn't nearly as damaging as it might have been. Responding to strong business pressure, budget negotiators abandoned an ill-conceived scheme to extend the state's 4 percent sales tax to the healthiest segment of the state's sagging economy - services like public relations, advertising and management consulting. Mr. Cuomo's attempt to reach out and put the arm on business with a tax on long-distance telephone calls was also rejected.
Still, the patchwork that finally emerged isn't nearly as equitable as broad-based taxes would have been - like the surcharge on the personal income tax proposed by Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, or an increase in the gasoline tax, proposed but never pressed by Mr. Cuomo. Instead the public will pay more for dozens of goods and services, including soda, liquor, car rentals and parking. Also thrown in is a 15 percent surcharge on corporate taxes and an increase in taxes paid by importers or processers of petroleum products - really a small backdoor gasoline tax.
The budget is now a record 46 days overdue. Localities have had to borrow to cover delayed state aid, incurring millions in needless interest costs. The struggle has also taken a toll on civility. As Mr. Miller attempted to restore order to an Assembly session Tuesday night, Glenn Warren, a Republican, blurted out ''Heil Hitler.'' Rightly outraged, Mr. Miller responded with profanity and later said, ''People like that shouldn't be serving in the New York State Assembly.''
The long weeks of chaos - not to mention a drop in the state's credit rating - might have been avoided had Mr. Cuomo exercised more forceful leadership once the full dimensions of the state's fiscal woes became apparent. But it's a wonder any agreement was reached, given Mr. Marino's shameful reluctance to acknowledge the state's ballooning deficit, and his insistence on inequitable increases in school aid.
It's too late to undo the embarrassment caused by this year's budget spectacle. But the state's political leaders have at least the duty to consider reforms of the budget process to avoid more senseless waste next year.

HEADLINE: Bolivia Is Trying to Dismantle Its Coca Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I quite agree with your April 30 editorial ''Military Aid vs. Drugs? Yes, but . . .'' Nevertheless (yes, but), I would like to point out that the Bolivian Government's program is much more far-reaching than you suggest.
We are not just focusing on a ''crop substitution program,'' attempting to replace coca with other crops. Such a task is very difficult unless it is part of a comprehensive effort aimed at the entire problem. 
We started by admitting that the Bolivian economy is currently dominated by the coca economy, which has created 300,000 jobs, guarantees $5,000 annual in-comes from coca/cocaine industry exports and generates annual economic activity calculated to be $1.5 billion.
We are trying to replace that entire coca economy with a legitimate economy, but we cannot succeed without the cooperation of not just the countries involved in the cocaine business but the whole of the international community.
We are not asking for subsidies of any kind for our products. That would be a weak solution, if only because it would violate market laws. What we are asking is that the international community help us create a healthy economy, capable of not only surviving but of succeeding in the world market.
To do so, we need foreign investment, foreign support and the confidence of foreign governments. With-out any of these, we are sure to fail.
Efforts already undertaken in this direction have allowed us to sign investment guarantee agreements with industrialized countries such as the United States, Great Britain, West Germany, Spain, Belgium and Italy.
Our laws are in the process of modernization to adjust to what we hope will be a bright economic future: A new foreign investments bill has been submitted to the Parliament, and for the first time in the history of our country we will have a law on joint ventures by state or private Bolivian enterprises on the one hand and foreign companies on the other.
The task is very difficult, but we are working very hard to achieve our goal, which is to terminate the coca economy that now dominates our country.
 
SAMUEL DORIA MEDINA
Economic Adviser
to the Presidency of Bolivia
 La Paz, Bolivia, May 4, 1990

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Moving Beyond The Melting Pot, 25 Years Later

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
The 25th anniversary of the publication of ''Beyond the Melting Pot'' was officially marked this week, 30 years after the seminal study of race and ethnicity in New York City was completed, 27 years after it was published and 20 years since it was revised. The timing could not have been better. For whichever the anniversary, the book's underlying theme seems even more evident today: That, particularly where race is concerned, the melting pot metaphor didn't hold water.
The co-authors, Nathan Glazer, a professor of education and sociology at Harvard, and Daniel P. Moynihan, now a United States Senator from New York, reflected with other members of a panel at the New York Public Library Monday night on whether their premise had withstood the test of time, however many years have elapsed since they advanced it. Mr. Glazer and Mr. Moynihan maintained that their goal had not been to celebrate ethnic and racial identities, but rather to come to grips with the resulting divisions. 
Their book, Mr. Glazer acknowledged, had not anticipated two phenomena: the subsequent surge in immigration to New York from the Caribbean, Latin America, Korea, China, Vietnam and the Soviet Union; and the general failure of American-born blacks, in particular, to be swept before the floodtide of new immigrants into the city's economic and social mainstream.
''You've got the Mayor and the police chief and you've got the city,'' Mr. Moynihan said, suggesting that blacks had, even if belatedly, demonstrated the endurance of ethnic succession in New York City politics, at least.
Mr. Glazer, because he is not a politician, was less circumspect. A measure of hope might be detected, he said, in the recent political success of blacks, most notably the election last year of David N. Dinkins.
But, Mr. Glazer said, the pattern of new immigrants propelling their immediate predecessors forward had not been duplicated among the two groups that had dominated immigration to New York during the two decades before ''Beyond the Melting Pot'' was written: blacks from the South and Puerto Ricans. Instead, he said, many have become part of a ''great dependent class.''
Mr. Glazer, who wrote the section on American blacks, began this week's retrospective not in the 1960's, but three decades earlier. He quoted from a report that called the Harlem riots of 1935 that community's ''inarticulate response'' to job discrimination, lack of affordable housing and health care, prejudice and insensitivity by municipal government.
Not only do most of those complaints persist today, but Ruth W. Messinger, who succeeded Mr. Dinkins as Manhattan Borough President and who participated in the retrospective, said that improving those very same conditions was her recipe for racial harmony.
That is not to say conditions for many blacks have not gotten better since 1935, Mr. Glazer said. But what has not changed looms larger. His assumption that blacks would be as politically and economically mobile as earlier newcomers to New York, he said, now seems naive. One consequence of their immobility has been a lingering resentment in predominantly black neighborhoods that so many local businesses are owned by outsiders.
''Blacks were boycotting the Jews in Harlem in the 1930's,'' Mr. Glazer said, ''and blacks are boycotting the Koreans 55 years later.''
As evidence of New York's enduring ethnic divisions, Mr. Moynihan recalled touring the city with Jimmy Carter during the 1976 presidential campaign. At the perennial garment center rally in Manhattan, a traditional Jewish and later Hispanic stronghold, most of the campaign placards were in Chinese. As his motorcade proceeded along Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn toward a longshoremen's gathering, Mr. Carter asked whether he was in the borough's Italian district.
''No,'' Mr. Moynihan replied. ''The Arab section.''
On a more cosmic scale, Mr. Moynihan said, the potency of ethnicity has disproved the Marxian premise that industrialization would produce a uniform proletariat. ''What Karl Marx proposed in the British Museum, Nat Glazer disproved in the New York Public Library,'' Mr. Moynihan said.
What Mr. Glazer wrote about race in 1960 proved prescient, if understated. Introducing their revised edition 10 years later, the authors concluded: ''Race has exploded to swallow up all other distinctions, or so it would appear at the moment.''
Twenty years later, as a divided city awaits the verdict on two white teen-agers accused in the racially-motivated killing of a 16-year-old black, it still does.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Budget Hurry-Up-and-Wait Helps Forehands, Harms Civility

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 16

 BODY:
When a Republican Assemblyman shouted ''Heil Hitler!'' at the Democratic Assembly Speaker during an unusual filibuster Tuesday night, the anger and frustration underlying this year's prolonged budget debate erupted into public view.
As Assembly Speaker Mel Miller was trying to restore order to an unruly session, Assemblyman Glenn E. Warren of Hopewell Junction stunned the chamber by blurting out the Nazi salute. Mr. Miller, who is Jewish, responded with profanity and later told reporters, ''People like that shouldn't be serving in the New York State Assembly.''
The scene was the most anarchic moment in a budget process that has known little order since Gov. Mario M. Cuomo convened the Legislature on Jan. 3. The state budget is now 46 days overdue, shattering the record for budget lateness. 
Until Tuesday night, the budget debacle had been best symbolized by the lowering of the state's credit rating. But this legislative session now may be best remembered for Mr. Warren's indiscretion, the bizarre filibuster that generated it and today's furor over both.
The Republicans announced the filibuster after they were handed a 275-page, $1.4 billion tax bill Tuesday morning and told the Democrats had scheduled a vote on it for Tuesday night. Although the Republicans who control the Senate were crucial in negotiating the tax legislation, members of the Assembly's Republican minority had little role in it.
To delay the vote and register their irritation, the Republicans filled three hours with angry speeches on procedure, including Mr. Warren's, until Mr. Miller called for a recess shortly after 11 P.M.
By this morning, any hope of debating the budget was buried beneath the anguish generated by Mr. Warren's comment. The Assemblyman from the Upper Hudson Valley apologized, saying he had been angry at the budget process.
The apology did not mollify the Democrats, who were angrier when Mr. Warren later told reporters that his remarks were comparable to yelling ''Kill the Ref!'' at a basketball game.
The Democrats vented their emotions in a four-hour private meeting that many compared to group therapy, and then reconvened in the chamber tonight for a cathartic 85-minute session. Seven Democrats, some of whom had lost family members in the Holocaust, publicly chastised Mr. Warren. Republicans responded that he had been thoughtless but was not an anti-Semite.
Mr. Warren choked back tears long enough to say: ''I'd like to say I'm sorry and I ask for your forgiveness. Thank you.''
 
The Wages of Sloth
Bad government, it seems, is not bad for everyone.
By breaking the record for overdue budgets, state leaders have produced a windfall for the capital district's hoteliers and restaurateurs, and its barkeeps and tennis pros.
The 211 state legislators, accustomed to staying in Albany only two nights a week, have been held hostage here for most of the last six weeks just on the off chance that they might finally be asked to vote.
Packs of idle legislators might not be something most people would wish on their hometowns. But to people in Albany, where government has long been the staple of a steady economy, there is nothing more refreshing than legislative inefficiency.
''It's great,'' said Gary J. Tenczar, manager of the Plaza Grill, a favorite watering hole of politicians, lobbyists and journalists. ''Anytime stuff like the budget is overdue, they stay in town longer, and they still have to eat and drink.''
The managers of hotels and restaurants, and of golf and tennis clubs where some legislators spend their mornings, echoed his enthusiasm.
''I was looking down the line this morning and all our courts were taken by legislators,'' said Mike Friedman, the director of the Southwood Indoor Tennis and Golf Center. ''They seem to play tennis more when they're frustrated.''
 
Intestinal Fortitude Lags
The nurses who run the Legislative Health Service, which is between the Senate and Assembly chambers, can attest that the budget ordeal has inflicted a heavy toll. They have noticed a marked increase in stress-related ailments and headaches during the last few weeks, and have referred several patients to therapists.
''There's a run on Tylenol,'' said Liz Anthony, one of the nurses. ''I guess you can call it budgetitis.''
Ms. Anthony said she also has treated legislators and aides for intestinal disorders, which are often caused by an overdose of fast food. The Governor's budget staff dines almost nightly on take-out Chinese food while calculating the cost of each day's political bargaining.
''I'm not going to eat another egg roll until next March,'' said Patrick J. Bulgaro, the division's first deputy director. ''I think it's the gastroenterologists who really make out here.''
 
Tackling Bigger Issues
With the Governor and legislative leaders conducting most of the budget negotiations in private, many legislators feel disconnected from the process. But New Yorkers should not think their legislators have not been conducting serious business.
In late April, for instance, the Senate passed legislation to outlaw dwarf-tossing contests, and the related practice of dwarf bowling, in places where alcohol is served.
There has also been consideration of bills that would prohibit the use of chemical deodorizers in boat toilets and reduce the amount of lead in coffee urns. The Assembly, which, for the record, plays no role in setting foreign policy, held an emotional debate on the correctness of the United States' invasion of Panama. The Senate, meanwhile, passed legislation allowing the National Ski Patrol to have its own license plate.

HEADLINE: New York City Is Seeking to Use M.A.C. Surplus

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
New York City and New York State are negotiating with the Municipal Assistance Corporation to free $1.5 billion in surplus corporation funds to help balance the city's operating budget over the next seven years.
In exchange, the corporation would be granted power to issue new bonds for schools and mass transit.
But the proposal, discussed quietly in recent weeks and in a closed-door M.A.C. board meeting yesterday, has irked some politicians and fiscal experts. They say that it amounts to meddling with the city's spending priorities and that it could create a false impression of fiscal disarray. 
Felix G. Rohatyn, the corporation's chairman, said yesterday that he had agreed to review the proposal at the request of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins to help the city close a budget gap of about $2 billion in the fiscal year that starts July 1 and possible gaps in future years. Legislative aides, however, said the proposal originated with M.A.C.
 
No Restrictions on Use
Under the plan, the corporation would distribute $1.5 billion to the city for unrestricted use over the next seven years. City officials have sought unfettered access to this money for years, but Mr. Rohatyn has retained control, insisting that certain conditions be met before the funds are made available for particular projects.
In recent years, in agreement with Mr. Cuomo and former Mayor Edward I. Koch, Mr. Rohatyn committed $600 million for school construction and $900 million for transit.
Now, in exchange for making that money available to the city for operating expenses, Mr. Rohatyn wants a state law that would grant M.A.C. the power to issue new bonds to keep its commitments on schools and transit in case the city did not issue enough bonds of its own to finance those projects.
''It's just an insurance policy to make sure we can carry out existing commitments,'' Mr. Rohatyn said. He added that in no case would any new bonds mature after 2008, when the last M.A.C. bonds are to expire.
 
Born in Adversity
Some officials contend that the city should have had control of the surpluses all along. The M.A.C. was established by the state in 1975 to issue bonds for the city when it was barred from the credit markets because of its precarious condition.
Its bonds are backed by city sales tax revenues, which are diverted each year to pay them off. The corporation accumulated surpluses through refinancing and favorable interest rates.
The city's budget director, Philip R. Michael, said one advantage of the plan is that the M.A.C. has a slightly higher credit rating than the city, and so could borrow at a slightly lower interest cost.
But some fiscal experts said that giving the M.A.C. new bonding power could create a false impression that the city was in fiscal disarray and hurt both its own hard-won credit rating and the M.A.C.'s.
''The sooner any talk of M.A.C. issuing any debt for capital purposes is put to rest, the better off the city will be,'' said Paul Dickstein, the city's former budget director.
But First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, who was a partner with Mr. Rohatyn at the Lazard Freres investment banking concern before joining the Dinkins administration, said the plan should not ''send the wrong signal that the city is in crisis and can't manage its own affairs.''
Peg Breen, a spokeswoman for the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said Mr. Vallone had deep philosophical concerns about the proposal.

LENGTH: 571 words

HEADLINE: Dinkins Expands Housing Plan to Assist the Poor

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
Moving to put his own stamp on New York City's $5.1 billion 12-year housing plan, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that the program would be revised and expanded to provide more housing for lower-income tenants and the homeless.
Despite what he called the ''tough fiscal times,'' the city will commit $2.1 billion in capital funds over the next four years, an increase of $101 million, the Mayor said.
Other construction projects will be reduced to help pay for the expanded housing program, Mr. Dinkins said, but he declined to identify the reductions until today, when he is to announce his preliminary capital plan for the next four years. 
''It is essential,'' Mr. Dinkins said, ''that we continue the housing program.''
 
An Ambitious Program
The plan, devised in 1986 by the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, is by far the most ambitious municipal housing program in the country. But it has long been criticized by some housing advocates for not providing enough housing for the poor.
Although Mayor Dinkins praised the program for ''enormous achievements in housing over the past four years,'' he said his plans would add ''a human face - one that's more affordable, more inclusionary and more economically integrated.''
He said 63,000 apartments would be made available under the plan in the next four years, with 26,000 consisting of either new construction or the complete rehabilitation of vacant buildings. The remaining 37,000 are to be moderately rehabilitated units.
The city, however, is rapidly exhausting its stock of vacant buildings and must increasingly rely on new construction to create ''desperately needed housing,'' the Mayor said.
 
Focus on 'Affordability'
The plan also calls for increased construction subsidies to private developers to reduce rents in apartments now in the planning stage, said Felice L. Michetti, the Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development. The subsidies now average $42,000 an apartment and are to increase to about $48,000.
''The plan is focused on affordability,'' Commissioner Michetti said.
Mr. Dinkins said $212 million would be allocated to develop 3,200 apartments for homeless individuals in city-owned buildings and single-room-occupancy hotels. Under the Koch administration, the housing program provided no rehabilitated apartments for single homeless people.
Mr. Dinkins said $50 million would go to build 500 units of mixed-income rental housing, with about 30 percent of the apartments reserved for homeless families. This is the first time that the city plans to build new housing for mixed-income families.
The Mayor said about 89 percent of the $2.1 billion in spending in the next four years would be devoted to low- and moderate-income households.
 
'This City Is the Leader'
''This city houses more people than any other and is home to more housing challenges than any other metropolis,'' he said. ''For generations, we've also been home to more innovative housing solutions. In housing, this city is the leader, and that's where we will stay.''
Bonnie Brower, executive director of the Association for Neighborhood and Housing Development, said that the original housing plan had failed to provide enough low-income housing but that ''now Mayor Dinkins is moving to correct those flaws.''
''These are absolutely essential, beneficial changes,'' she said. ''They should have been done four years ago.''

HEADLINE: An Invitation to Tea Sets

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE

 BODY:
TEAPOTS that resemble trumpets, Gothic spires or guards at Buckingham Palace are in ''Spirit of Europe,'' an exhibition of tea sets designed by students at Parsons School of Design. The exhibition, the result of a design competition sponsored by Villeroy & Boch, a German manufacturer of ceramics, is at the company's store at 974 Madison Avenue (76th Street).
In 1989 the company invited the 15 students who were majoring in ceramics at Parsons to submit drawings for tea sets. Ten of the students were chosen by Villeroy & Boch's design staff to spend three months last summer at its factory in Mettlach, West Germany, where the students learned to make their designs functional and then to manufacture 50 copies of each. 
''The students were judged according to the possibility of making and marketing the sets,'' said Marek Cecula, coordinator of the ceramic design department at Parsons. ''At the factory the students actually made the objects themselves from vitrified stoneware. They produced the decals, made the models, made the molds and fired the sets.''
The idea for the competition originated three years ago with Wendelin von Boch, managing director of the company. In 1988 he invited students at the Vienna Academy of Applied Arts to design tea sets on the theme ''Spirit of the U.S.A.''
''We had to encourage students to get interested in our industry in terms of design and artistic expression,'' said Dale Ritter, president of Villeroy & Boch in the United States. ''We're trying to excite them that it is an innovative industry, but that there are technical and commercial limitations to translating designs to production.''
At the factory Jessica Rust, a junior at Parsons, discovered one limitation after another, she said. Her design, ''Wines of Europe,'' included a raised grapevine motif. The pale green cup was shaped like a goblet. ''I wanted my cups to have thinner stems, but if I were to do that the cups fell down in the kilns, or they melted,'' Ms. Rust said. ''At Parsons, if the stem was too thin the cup would still fall over, but we'd stick a metal rod in it. We didn't have to make it functional.''
The designs in the exhibition range from the literal to the abstract. One of the most successful designs is ''Arms and Armor'' by Soojin Choi. The white pot is in the shape of a metal helmet, and it is decorated with a delicate filigree design in black. The creamer is designed like a gauntlet.
In ''Gothic Cathedrals'' Marta Schlitzer's teapot is a Gothic spire, the colored plate resembles a stained glass rosette, and the creamer is a fragment of a fluted column.
''Unity,'' a design by Alejandra Mark, features old and new imagery of Europe. An antique map of Europe decorates the globe-shaped teapot, while its handle has the blue background and gold stars of the flag of the European Economic Community. For the cup and saucer, the imagery is reversed: the cup is banded in blue and gold, while the handle and saucer depict the map.
Aaron Lown's ''Changing of the Guard'' is an abstract design based on the red jackets and tall black bearskin hats of the guards at Buckingham Palace. On the teapot the black hat is the lid and the handle is the guard's arm, held rigidly at the waist. For the cup the handle, also an abstracton of the guard's arm, looks as if it is in a salute.
Each set costs $2,000. The exhibition runs through June 2.

HEADLINE: Executive Director Resigns From Joffrey

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
The executive director of the Joffrey Ballet, Penelope Curry, said yesterday that she had submitted her resignation at a Joffrey board meeting on Tuesday.
Ms. Curry, who has supervised the ballet company's season this month at the Music Center of Los Angeles County, where the Joffrey is the resident dance company, said that her resignation was effective immediately but that she would stay on through the company's Los Angeles season, which ends on May 27.
''I have been asked by the board if I would stay on as consultant for the next two weeks,'' Ms. Curry said yesterday. ''I have agreed to do that. I will be happy to do anything that is necessary during the transition. I love this company very much. I have spent the last 22 years of my life with it. I will do anything I can to insure the company goes forward.'' 
 
Latest of Several Departures
Ms. Curry declined to comment on her reasons for resigning. Her resignation follows those of the Joffrey board's co-chairmen, Anthony A. Bliss and David H. Murdock. Yesterday Mr. Murdock issued a statement confirming earlier reports that he had resigned.
''The Joffrey is an outstanding ballet company that has performed superbly,'' Mr. Murdock said in his statement. ''I have been active as a co-chairman of the board for seven years, and I feel it is time to step down. It has been an honor and a privilege to serve with this fine ballet company.''
 
A Series of Crises
The three resignations followed a financial and administrative crisis at the Joffrey that became public when Gerald Arpino resigned as its artistic director and resident choreographer on May 1. His resignation was not accepted by the board. Mr. Arpino, who founded the company with Robert Joffrey, who died in March 1988, also withdrew his ballets from the company's repertory. On Tuesday he gave the Joffrey permission to perform them again starting May 25.
Mr. Arpino resigned when the board voted to establish an operating committee to run the company. The vote followed the discovery that the company owed $800,000 in payroll withholding taxes, as well as a $1 million accumulated deficit.
Mr. Arpino and his lawyer, Harold Messing, have been negotiating with the board since May 4.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up By 0.2%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
In a report that largely dispelled fears of accelerating inflation, the Labor Department said today that consumer prices climbed a modest two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the smallest increase since September.
Economists said the report on the Consumer Price Index was important confirmation that price pressures have abated since a late-winter surge and that inflation might turn out to be little, if any, worse this year than the 4.6 percent increase in prices recorded for 1989.
The report for April was in sharp contrast to the one for March, which showed an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent and was even higher when the erratic food and energy components were excluded. The March data worked out to a worrisome annual pace of 8.5 percent for the first quarter. But factoring in today's report, the annual rate for 1990 now stands at 6.8 percent. 
 
Fearing a 5% Rate
''There was a fear out there that we were moving toward 5 percent inflation'' for a sustained period, commented Kevin Logan, chief economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
With today's report, and the one last Friday showing a decline in the price that American producers received for their goods in April, Mr. Logan said inflation now had probably stabilized.
The low overall rise in last month's price index was largely anticipated and thus made little impact on the financial markets. Still, analysts said they were heartened by the fact that so-called core inflation, which excludes food and energy, eased to two-tenths of 1 percent from seven-tenths of 1 percent in March.
This meant that the better performance of the index did not depend entirely on food prices, which posted their first decline since July 1987, or on energy prices, which registered their third straight decline.
 
Other Factors at Work
In other words, while much of the improvement represented the reversal of weather-related price jumps during the winter, other factors were also working to keep price pressures in check.
The recent inflation figures are consistent with other economic gauges - including employment, retail sales and industrial production -that signal a resumption of slow economic growth after some late-winter vigor that owed much to unseasonably warm weather stimulating construction activity. But housing starts fell sharply last month, according to a separate report today. [Page D19.] For inflation over all, ''things look somewhat better,'' declared Patrick C. Jackman, a senior price analyst at the Labor Department. He said that the 6.8 percent annual rate for the first four months of this year was scarcely worse than the 6.6 percent recorded at this time last year, and thus the rise for all of 1990 could be held below 5 percent.
On the other hand, today's price report was not so good as to inspire thoughts that the Federal Reserve would be able to move soon to ease monetary policy. Analysts said the Fed's strategy-setting arm, which met yesterday, probably decided to make no significant change.
The cost of medical care, for example, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent for the third straight month, a 9.8 percent annual rate. Health benefits have been a major factor pushing up costs to businesses and those costs tend to be passed on to consumers.
Today's report also showed that the metropolitan areas of New York, Philadelphia and San Francisco each had price increases of five-tenths of 1 percent last month, while prices in Chicago surged seven-tenths of 1 percent. Los Angeles, the other city for which monthly data are published, posted a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Big Drop in Vegetables
The April drop in food prices was mainly the result of a sharp decline in the price of fresh vegetables, which skidded a total of 20 percent in March and April after rising 30 percent in January and February. Dairy products fell for the second straight month after rising nearly 11 percent during the preceding six months.
On the other hand, prices rose sharply for cereal and bakery products and for the component comprising meat, poultry, fish and eggs.
Housing prices rose just one-tenth of 1 percent after a March surge. Fuel oil retreated to its December level, and natural gas fell 3 percent, the biggest decline in almost three years. Charges for collecting trash, however, rose sharply for the fifth straight month.
Apparel rose a negligible one-tenth of 1 percent after two very sharp increases, and transportation rose the same amount, because gasoline prices turned up. Unlike fuel oil, gasoline prices have held onto nearly all of the 7.7 percent advance they recorded in January.
Entertainment and ''other'' goods and services both rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the report showed.
 
Services Cost More
The price of services rose three-tenths of 1 percent, compared with seven-tenths in March, while commodity prices declined one-tenth of 1 percent.
The Consumer Price Index covering all urban consumers now stands at 128.9, which means that a group of goods and services that cost $10 in 1982-84 now costs $12.89. Before rounding, the April increase was 0.155159 percent, a hair's breadth from being reported as up only one-tenth of 1 percent.
A companion price index covering a smaller universe of urban wage warners and clerical workers rose one-tenth of 1 percent after rising four-tenths in March and five-tenths in February.

HEADLINE: New Goal for Accountants: Director

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Each spring, as the nation's major accounting firms conduct the ritual of naming their best up-and-comers as partners, James A. Gibson remembers four years ago when his turn came at Arthur Young, the large New York firm.
After spending eight years on the firm's fast track, the 37-year-old knew exactly what was at stake: people either made partner or they left the firm. Sure enough, he got the news at the end of the day. He would get a larger office, a six-figure salary, more vacation time, secretarial help and a paid membership in an executive health club.
The funny thing was, he had been turned down for the partner's position. 
 
A New Position
Instead, Mr. Gibson became a director, a permanent, salaried executive position that Arthur Young, now part of Ernst & Young, created that year as an alternative to a partnership. While they do not share in the firm's profits or have as much decision-making power, directors receive most of the perquisites of partners and rank just below partners in the firm's hierarchy.
Arthur Young created the position as way to retain employees who are valued but considered unsuitable for partnerships because they have narrow specialties, like economic analysis, which keep them behind the scenes, removed from client contact.
Several other firms have adopted similar tactics to address a decline in the number of talented college graduates who choose accounting as a career. In January, Coopers & Lybrand created a permanent executive position other than partner, and Arthur Andersen said it was committed to doing so. Other firms are testing new positions.
This trend is a major departure from the profession's age-old ''up-or-out'' policy, in which people either make partner or leave the firm.
''The up-or-out route is good management in an environment where you only need to keep the best or brightest and there's always another group coming through,'' said David Maister, a Boston-based consultant who has taught at the Harvard Business School about the service sector. ''But that is not today's demographic environment and won't be for the next 15 years.''
 
Similar to the Legal Field
Much like the legal profession, which created ''permanent associate'' positions in the early 1980's, accounting is labor intensive. That makes executives acutely concerned about the shrinking number of post-baby-boomers entering the work force.
For years, accounting firms could be cavalier about inviting only the most talented recruits to join the partnership ranks. Replacing those who failed to make the cut posed little hardship when there were more than 50,000 graduates in accounting each year and when there was a brisk progression up the ranks.
The odds of making partner at the big firms were slim - about one in 10 in the early career years and about one in two if they stuck it out for 10 to 12 years. But the rewards were enormous for the 600 or so who got the nod each year.
 
Profit-Sharing Plans
These partners are paid through profit-sharing plans and at the large accounting firms typically earn $150,000 to $400,000 a year, not including fringe benefits. Directors earn salaries in the low $100,000 area.
In the past, those who fell short of their dream walked away with a consolation prize: years of professional training and industry contacts.
''It used to be the poor person's M.B.A.,'' said Robert N. McDowell, the partner in charge of personnel administration for Coopers & Lybrand.
But now, recruitment and training costs are eating into profits, and there are mounting concerns that the quality of accounting graduates is declining along with quantity as the best business students pursue a growing choice careers. That shortfall suggests employers will have to spend even more on training.
 
Push Toward Specialities
Another factor is the push by many firms into specialties beyond tax and auditing, which means they vie with other businesses for experienced talent in a wider range of fields. And the growing interest of many career-minded employees in trying to balance work and family life also argues for the introduction of alternative career paths. Some women, for example, may choose to become a director, rather than a more-involved partner, because they want to take time out to raise children.
Officials of the firms on the vanguard of the trend say their motives have little to do with a change of heart about pushing loyal employees out the door. ''Some people think up-or-out is a bit too severe,'' said Richard L. Measelle, the managing partner of Andersen's audit, accounting and tax business unit. ''I'm not too troubled by that. What is driving me to this is demographics, and the specialization that is growing so rapidly within the profession.'' He hopes to have a program in place by this fall for at least a few of those who fall off the firm's partnership track each year.
 
Not a Booby Prize
Arthur Young, the first accounting firm to create the title of director, also appears to have the largest contingent, having retained 44 of the 47 managers offered the title. Paul J. Ostling, a partner and the firm's vice chairman for human resources, said the key was to keep the job from being seen as a dead end or booby prize. While making partner after having been named a director is a long shot at many firms, it is not out of the question.
''We don't want this to be a parking place for people who are not good enough to be partner,'' he said. ''If we put rejects in the director position, it would never become something people would aspire to.''
Among the major firms, only KPMG Peat Marwick said it was opposed to tampering with its partnership structure.
''We as a firm have no interest in doing that,'' said Bernard J. Milano, KPMG's partner in charge of recruiting and personnel administration. ''To recruit and motivate people, you need to be able to display an opportunity for growth, and the more people you have occupying positions below partner on a permanent basis, obviously the fewer opportunities you can offer.''
 
Satisfaction With Decision
But at Ernst & Young, many directors seem satisfied with the path their careers have taken.
Rosemarie Meschi, a 37-year-old accountant who rose through the auditing ranks at Young, switched to the human resources department in 1983. The transfer practically killed her chances of making partner because it meant giving up her clients, but Ms. Meschi liked the work better. ''The title of partner was not as important to me as having job satisfaction,'' she said.
Ms. Meschi continued to impress her superiors - she recently headed the firm's effort to provide its New York employees with emergency child care. Last year, after being considered for partner after all, she became one of eight to advance to director.
''My friends, all say, 'Aren't you ever going to leave?' '' said Ms. Meschi, who has been with the firm for 16 years. For now anyway, her answer is no.
 
Choice of Living Style
Mr. Gibson's problem was that he worked for a small branch office in Northern California. When his turn for partner came up, he was told he could stay in Sacramento as a director or take his chances at a larger office that might be able to absorb another partner. Since he liked his job and its location, he stayed.
''I've made a conscious decision to trade off some perceived quality of life that I have here for a partnership position in a larger city,'' Mr. Gibson said.
In other cases, the director's title has helped attract and keep outside specialists who are not straight out of college. One is R. Allen Saville, 45. He had a doctorate in environmental design, a law degree, and 10 years of consulting experience before he joined Young's office in Reston, Va., as an internal consultant in 1986. With no client contacts, Mr. Saville has never come up for partner and said that he frankly did not care.
''Just as the up-or-out model is fading, the model about what defines success is also changing,'' said Mr. Saville, who became a director two years ago. ''The mere fact I'm not called a partner does not bother me a whole lot.''

HEADLINE: Soviet Union Becomes Observer in Trade Body

BYLINE: By BURTON BOLLAG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 16

 BODY:
The Soviet Union was accepted today as an observer in the world organization that oversees international trade, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The move, which was expected, is seen as a significant step in that country's efforts to integrate itself into the world trading system.
As one of more than 20 observers, the Soviet Union will be able to attend most meetings of the 96-nation group that serves as a watchdog on trade. But it will not be able to participate in decison making or in the settlement of trade disputes. Nor will it be able to take part in the current trade negotiations, known as the Uruguay Round, that are scheduled to finish in December. The Uruguay Round is the GATT-sponsored effort to eliminate trade barriers in services and farm products and to provide better protection for patents, copyrights and other intellectual property. 
 
Adopted by Consensus
Soviet observer status was adopted by consensus at a meeting of most of the member countries at the organization's granite headquarters in a park along the shores of Lake Geneva.
As soon as the decision was made, the Soviet delegation of about five members was invited to enter the richly wood-paneled meeting hall as reporters and television camera crews crowded around. ''We've never had such a ceremony for the admission of an observer,'' one Western delegate said Yevgeny N. Makeyev, the Soviet delegate to the United Nations in Geneva, then told the meeting that the new status would allow his country to ''get acquainted'' with the workings of GATT and study ''the conditions for a future accession'' as a full member.
So many countries requested the floor to welcome the Soviets that the chairman finally cut short the discussion. But many countries made it clear that they expect the Soviet Union to use its new status to help push forward important domestic economic reforms and to report back regularly on progress, as promised.
At a summit meeting in Malta in December, President Bush informed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union that the United States had dropped its objections to the granting of observer status to the Soviet Union. But the United States wanted the move put off until the end of the Uruguay Round in December.
On Monday, however, a Bush Administration official in Washington said the President wanted a favorable decision before his meeting with Mr. Gorbachev in two weeks as ''a tangible sign of American interest in bringing the Soviet Union into the world economy.'' And today the United States representative to GATT, Rufus Yerxa, formally told the meeting that in the face of broad international support for the move, the United States was dropping its objections.
 
Japan Drops Opposition
Japan also dropped its previously stated objections. Japan had used the issue of GATT observer status to signal its displeasure with the continued Soviet occupation of four Japanese islands off Hokkaido, seized in 1945. But Japanese officials have also said they want to see the Soviet Union move toward a market-oriented economy, and they said recently that they did not intend to let the occupation issue block the new Soviet status.
The United States representative made it clear the Soviet Union had far to go before it could be considered for full membership. ''The Soviet economic and trade system is clearly not, at this time, compatible'' with GATT principles, Mr. Yerxa said.
He added that it was ''the sincere hope'' of the United States that the Soviet Union proceed with its reforms and ''eventually embrace a market-based price and distribution system.''
Various countries and the GATT Director General, Arthur Dunkel, had strongly urged the Bush Administration in recent months to accept Soviet observer status, in the hope of encouraging Soviet economic reforms.
The Soviet Union was the last big country not in GATT or in the process of joining. Still, the move from observer status to full membership can take years. Negotiations on China's request to move from its current observer status have been virtually frozen since the country crushed student demonstrations last June.
According to GATT economists, the Soviet Union had $108 billion worth of exports in 1989, making it the eighth-ranking exporter.

HEADLINE: Retirement Is Set at Deere

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MOLINE, Ill., May 16

 BODY:
Robert A. Hanson, who directed Deere & Company through its stormiest financial period and into profitability, announced today that he would retire as chairman.
Mr. Hanson, who is 65 years old, said he will step down on June 1. He has spent 40 years with the company, which manufactures tractors and agricultural equipment.
Deere's president and chief executive, Hans W. Becherer, is expected to be named chairman at the company's next board meeting.
Last August, Mr. Hanson gave up the chief executive title in anticipation of his retirement, which is mandatory at Deere when an executive reaches age 66. Mr. Hanson, a native of East Moline, was the first person to run the 153-year-old company who was not a member of the Deere family by blood or marriage.
He became president in 1978, and a year later was named chief operating officer. He became chairman in 1982 as the company stood on the brink of economic collapse.
Deere accumulated $328 million in losses in two years and its operating losses totaled $637 million in the six-year period beginning in 1982.
Mr. Hanson instituted a deep cost-cutting program and laid off about 12,000 workers. His problems were compounded by a 163-day work stoppage at 13 Deere plants in six states that ended on Feb. 1, 1987.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Investor Joins Citibank In Private Bank Group

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
A longtime investor in stocks and bonds, James R. Hocking, has joined Citibank's private banking group. Mr. Hocking came to Citibank this week from Templeton International, an investment advisory firm in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
While at Templeton, a subsidiary of Templeton, Galbraith & Hausberger Ltd., Mr. Hocking developed a mutual fund that invests in bonds from around the world. Now, as chief investment officer of Citibank's United States investment division, Mr. Hocking, who is 60, will oversee the investing of $15 billion managed by the private banking group. Citibank, which manages more money in its private banking group than any other non-Swiss bank, has an additional $45 billion under management in foreign offices. 
''I am a firm believer in global investing, and Citibank is a place that has made a firm commitment to managing money of retail accounts around the world,'' Mr. Hocking said.
The private banking groups of large banks like Citibank offer investment advice, special lending arrangements and other services to wealthy individuals. At Citibank, private banking customers are expected to have at least $250,000 under management.
Although Citicorp sold its institutional investment advisory business last year, it has identified investment advice for individuals as a business with a bright future as the ''baby boom'' generation grows older and accumulates more savings. At the same time, Mr. Hocking noted that investment opportunities around the world are multiplying, as more economies mature and businesses once controlled by governments become privately held.
Even after the sharp rise in American stock prices in the last week, Mr. Hocking said, ''We don't think the stock market is at a level that makes it unattractive.'' He declined to identify any companies or industry groups, but he said he favors high-quality investments in both the stock and bond markets.
''In an economy that is growing only modestly, high quality and the ability to sustain earnings is important,'' he said. While the American economy might grow no faster than a few percent a year after inflation, he does not expect a recession.
He is advising investors in both the American stock and bond markets to remain nearly fully invested, holding only small cash reserves.
Describing himself as ''an opera lover'' and a frequent visitor to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Mr. Hocking said he and his wife, Jane, who have five grown children, expect to find a new home in Manhattan within walking distance of the museum.

HEADLINE: New Futures Contract On Insurance Planned

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 16

 BODY:
The Chicago Board of Trade said today that it would seek Federal approval to begin trading futures contracts related to health insurance and automobile insurance. The contract would give insurance companies a mechanism to lock in the price they must pay for reinsurance, which involves spreading their risk by selling policies among other insurers.
''These new contracts will bring down the cost of health care and bring down the cost of auto insurance and health insurance to the public,'' said Leslie Rosenthal, the chairman of the Board of Trade committee that designed the new contracts.
One of the designers of the new contracts, Richard Sandor, said, ''These new contracts could be as major an innovation as interest-rate futures.'' He is also considered one of the architects of interest-rate futures, which allow banks, insurance companies and other institutional investors to hedge against swings in interest rates. 
 
'The Timing Is Right'
''The timing is right because the risks faced by insurers are greater than ever, as is the capital needed to write these types of insurance,'' Mr. Sandor said.
To the extent that the new futures contracts would allow insurance companies to know before they write policies how much they would have to pay for reinsurance, proponents said that consumers could benefit in a big way.
Christian Milton, the head of reinsurance buying at the American International Group, a big New York-based insurer, said, ''If I could lock in the price of reinsurance for my property-and-casualty portfolio, that would be just fine.''
But both Mr. Milton and other insurance executives interviewed today questioned whether the board could actually design a standardized reinsurance agreement on which to base trading. They noted that reinsurance agreements are typically renegotiated every year, with the insurance companies involved changing the amount of insurance covered by the reinsurance agreement and changing what risks are excluded from reinsurance.
''Each time we go back to renegotiate, our client companies may have a higher appetite for risk or lower,'' said Robert Faber, a reinsurance executive at the Allstate Insurance Company. ''There just isn't any standard reinsurance arrangement.''
 
Others Skeptical
Some analysts were also skeptical. Michael Sutton, a Shearson Lehman Hutton analyst, told Reuters, ''The insurance industry is looking for security in its reinsurance relationships, and this won't be viewed as secure.'' He predicted the new product would have a tough time winning approval from state insurance commissioners. 'Who Backs It Up? ''There are clearly numerous questions that have to be asked,'' Myron Picoult, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company, told the news service. ''The most obvious question is who backs it up. Who would make payments on a reinsurance futures contract? What's the balance sheet?''
Answers to these questions were not immediately available. Citing competition with other exchanges, Mark Prout, a spokesman for the Board of Trade, the world's largest futures market, declined to give any details of how the new futures would work.
Mr. Sandor said that like other futures contracts, they would provide a hedge against price swings. An insurance company that dealt in reinsurance futures would be protected against increases in the price of reinsurance, he said, since any such increase would be offset by an equal profit in the insurance company's futures position.
Reinsurers, he added, would be in a similar position: Any increase or decrease in the amount of premium income they received for entering into reinsurance agreements would be offset by a gain or loss on their futures contracts.
Futures contracts involve the delivery of a commodity - either a physical commodity like grain, or a financial instrument like cash or Treasury securities. Mr. Sandor, a former Board of Trade economist who is now president of the Banque Indosuez International Capital Markets, would not disclose what that commodity would be in the case of reinsurance futures. Presumably, though, the Board of Trade will attempt to design a standard reinsurance agreement, and as the price of that agreement changes in the normal, ''cash'' market, the futures price will change.
Although the idea of reinsurance futures has been bandied about for years, today's announcement marked the first time that a major American futures exchange had embraced the concept.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 19, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Thursday about a proposal for the creation of futures contracts related to insurance misidentified an insurance industry analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton. He is Michael Smith, not Michael Sutton.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money-Fund Yields Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday.
Analysts at Donoghue's said the well-received government quarterly refunding last week, plus reduced fears of inflation, both here and abroad, helped move rates lower in the fixed-income markets. ''And the markets are in the process of correcting those earlier expectations,'' said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at Donoghue's. 
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund rose 4 basis points, to 8 percent. The temporary increase was the result of the recent rally in short-term fixed-income securities, analysts noted. The 30-day average yield remained unchanged at 7.98 percent.
Assets of taxable funds decreased by $2.3 billion for the week, to a total of $374.7 billion, with institutional assets up by $200 million, to $79.3 billion. Consumer assets, meanwhile, were off by $2.5 billion, to $295.4 billion. Fund managers pointed to the Treasury's refunding and stock market rally as explanations.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios was unchanged at 44.
Among the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million that are surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's, Summit Cash Reserves, distributed by Merrill Lynch Funds Distributors Inc., Princeton, N.J., led with a yield of 9.62 percent.
Yields of tax-exempt funds were down for the week ended yesterday, as assets decreased by $262 million, to total $75.3 billion. The decline was not viewed by analysts as significant. The average seven-day compounded yield was down 7 basis points, to 5.67 percent. For investors in a 28 percent tax bracket the equivalent yield in taxable securities is 7.875 percent, and 8.462 percent for those in a 33 percent bracket.
Donoghue's reported that for the third consecutive week the Calvert Tax Free Reserve California portfolio, distributed by the Calvert Group, Washington, had the best yield at 6.40 percent, down 9 basis points from the previous week. The spread over the seven-day average yield narrowed by two basis points, to 73.
By comparison, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index shows bank money market account yields off a basis point, to 6.22 percent, and six-month certificates off 3 basis points, to 7.99 percent. One-year certificates declined by a basis point, to 8.17 percent, and five-year certificates fell 3 basis points, to 8.21 percent. Two-and-a-half year certificates remained unchanged at 8.20 percent.
