HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Japanese Rally Made in the U.S.A.

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
WHEN the Japanese stock market was tumbling in January, February and March, there was concern that the malady would spread to the United States and other world markets. But Japan's problems, for the most part, stayed at home, despite an anemic yen and rising interest rates.
Now, as if it were a payback for Japan's quarantine of these financial troubles, the United States is helping to restart the Japanese markets.
The American help came with the new forecasts this month that interest rates here would not be rising. This sent the yen, which had weakened to 160 to the dollar in April, on its strongest rally of the year as it gained 6 yen against the dollar in three trading days to settle just above 150. 
With this stronger yen, the Tokyo stock market shot up more than 500 points on Friday and Monday. Even with small declines in the last two days, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks, at 31,967.62 yesterday, is 14 percent above its low and has regained almost 4,000 of the 11,000 points it lost this year.
In the bargain, the New York Stock Exchange set its own new high this week, 2,822.45 on the Dow Jones industrial average on Tuesday.
Christopher M. Mitchinson, Salomon Brothers' Japanese expert in London, gives the United States ''about 100 percent'' credit for the revival in Japan. Because of the changes in May, he said yesterday, he sees a new bull market starting in Tokyo. He raised his near-term forecast for the Nikkei by 1,000 points, to a range of 29,500 to 33,000.
''I don't think there has been a lot in Japan that has changed,'' added Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities in New York.
The change in the outlook for interest rates started with the release of the surprisingly weak United States employment report for April. The report was released on May 4, the end of Japan's so-called Golden Week, when the markets are closed for three days.
This new perception has been reinforced since then by the six-tenths of a percent fall in April retail sales, the four-tenths of a percent decline in industrial production and the 5.8 percent dip in housing starts. At the same time, the inflation outlook has eased, with the Producer Price Index for finished goods falling three-tenths of a percent and the Consumer Price Index, which was reported yesterday, rising only two-tenths of a percent in April.
Some analysts say the new signs of weakness in the economy, combined with the reassuring numbers on inflation, will even tip the Federal Reserve toward easing interest rates a little. Certainly, by the middle of last week, most investors were no longer thinking that the Fed might raise interest rates.
In this climate, Japanese investors began buying yen again. The result, which was followed by investors around the world, knocked the dollar down almost 4 yen Friday and 1.5 yen Tuesday. The dollar moved up yesterday to 151.67, but it is still well below the 158.45 level on Friday, May 4.
''If the economy is slowing down, it is not so good to chase the dollar so much,'' said Hideaki Matsuura, executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc. ''So they reversed.''
''Japanese investors can change their minds very quickly and Japanese investors always have the same opinion,'' Mr. Matsura added, explaining the yen's sudden, sharp rise against the dollar.
''They got confidence from these reports, so it was very easy for the Japanese investors to take this position,'' he said.
Mr. Matsuura and Mr. Mitchinson have also seen early signs of Japanese investors selling American bonds so they can take advantage of low prices in the Japanese stock and bond markets.
Mr. Mitchinson added that Japanese were beginning to reverse their hedging positions in favor of a slightly stronger yen. By his estimates, they have bought $5 billion to $15 billion worth of yen recently, after selling as much as $175 billion in the first three months of the year in anticipation of a weaker yen.
Psychological assistance may also come from the muting of the unusually public dispute between the Bank of Japan and the Ministry of Finance over interest-rate policy.
Because of this new impetus from the United States, many analysts have declared the start of a new rally in Japan, although they caution that there may be some backsliding.
But if the yen rally is reversed - or if it does not break through the 150 level - there may be more steps backward for a while than expected.
Peter Rona, president of IBJ Schroder Bank and Trust Company, is worried that the yen's turnaround will not last. While he is not concerned about consumer inflation, which is very low, the rapid rise in land and other asset values means the economy is still at risk. Mr. Rona is also not yet assured that West German pressure for higher interest rates has abated.
''The difficulities in the Japanese market are not resolved,'' he said, ''and this incredible rise in the yen is just that, incredible.''

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower; Gold Prices Retreat in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mostly lower on world currency markets yesterday in light trading. Gold prices retreated after rising overseas.
Traders said the dollar was barely affected by fresh Government data pointing to slow economic growth and moderate inflation. The Government said consumer prices rose a seasonally adjusted two-tenths of 1 percent in April, while housing starts were down a larger-than-expected 5.8 percent. 
The figures were ''enough to weaken the dollar, but it has not gone down that much,'' said Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
There was a feeling in the market that the dollar had bottomed out for the time being, traders said. Some noted that they were unable to push the dollar below 150 Japanese yen, which proved to be a ''formidable barrier,'' Mr. Johnson said.
Most market participants were awaiting today's release of merchandise trade data for March to confirm their suspicions that the dollar is headed lower. The expectation is for a deficit of between $7.7 billion and $8.5 billion. February's deficit totaled $6.49 billion.
A large deficit is negative for the dollar. When the United States imports more than it exports, it diminishes the need for dollars by foreigners to purchase United States goods. But over time a weak dollar helps the trade picture by making United States goods more competitive overseas.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 151.95 yen, up from 151.30 on Tuesday. Later in London, the dollar traded lower at 151.33 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 151.67 yen, up from 150.83.
In London, the pound rose to $1.6805 from Tuesday's late $1.6775. In New York, one pound fetched $1.6805, more expensive than $1.6725 on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late rates, included: 1.6450 West German marks, down from 1.6465; 1.4005 Swiss francs, up from 1.3980; 5.5460 French francs, down from 5.5540; 1,210.00 Italian lire, down from 1,211.75, and 1.1751 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1770.

In overseas precious metals markets, gold traded at a late bid price of $370.00 a troy ounce in London, up from $367.75. The closing bid price in Zurich was $369.85, up from $367.50. Gold closed in Hong Kong at $369.95 bid, up from $368.10.

HEADLINE: Senate Control: Who Cares?

BYLINE: By Ken Bode; Ken Bode directs the Center for Contemporary Media, at DePauw University.

DATELINE: GREENCASTLE, Ind.

 BODY:
The Senate is in danger of losing its leading student of U.F.O. abductions, near-death experiences and other psychic phenomena.
Claiborne Pell, sixth-ranking in Senate seniority and chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, is rated as no better than a toss-up to beat Representative Claudine Schneider in a race that is as near as there is to a bellwether indicator for 1990.
For the G.O.P. to regain control of the Senate - which is more than a theoretical possibility - Representative Schneider, a moderate Republican, must beat Mr. Pell, a moderate Democrat, in a race that lacks burning issues. Republicans also must win four other Democratic seats (they're within hailing distance of winning a total of six), while holding all those they now occupy (no Republican seat is now in serious jeopardy). A 50-50 split would cast Vice President Dan Quayle as the permanent tie-breaker. 
This year's main issue ought to be who controls the Senate. But the way the Senate operates, it doesn't much matter who is in the driver's seat.
Senate elections have proved more volatile than any others in recent cycles. In 1980, fueled by Jimmy Carter's high-inflation, high-interest economics, all the close races broke in the same direction as the Reagan landslide, giving the G.O.P. control for the first time in 25 years. Six years later, when Ronald Reagan put his prestige on the line to save the G.O.P. incumbents, all the close races broke the other way, creating the Democrats' 55-to-45 margin.
This year, substituting, say, the liberal, pro-choice Republican Lynn Martin in Illinois for the liberal, pro-choice Democrat Paul Simon, and the Republican Tom Tauke for the Democrat Tom Harkin in Iowa won't mean much one way or the other.
A Republican-controlled Senate wouldn't embrace Daniel Patrick Moynihan's Social Security plan, but the Democrats didn't either. It wouldn't give George Bush much trouble on dicey foreign policy choices like Lithuania, but neither did the Democrats.
How much it matters may be seen in the faces of the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, and House Speaker Tom Foley as they arrived at the White House to do the tax lambada. Interest rates are nudging up; Mr. Bush needs cover so he can duck out on his no-new-taxes pledge; Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Foley were there to help. No teen-agers ever looked happier to be invited to a party.
With no firm national agenda, Mr. Bush is not asking the Senate to do much, but when he does, the Democrats go along, with or without a veto.
Granted, without control of the committee structure, the Democrats would not be able to put a Supreme Court nominee through the torture they organized for Robert Bork. Yet, on a partisan issue like renewing the Chinese students' visas, would a G.O.P.-controlled Senate be any less accommodating to Mr. Bush than the Democrats?
Cowed by his poll ratings, the Democrats have become a party of policy freelancers who communicate with each other through Op-Ed pages.
Here in Indiana, Representative Lee Hamilton might have won Dan Quayle's old Senate seat, but he declined to run. Mr. Hamilton now tells Democratic audiences that they must not think of the Democrats only as the opposition party. ''We're also the governing party,'' he says. ''We have a joint responsibility [with President Bush] to make the country work. We're in an uneasy coalition.'' That is a good statement of the problem. U.S. coalition governments are for wartime. Both parties have been propping each other up long enough; it's time for opposition.
Richard Nixon used to say that a President who is not irritating his own political base isn't doing all he could as a leader. George Bush isn't even irritating the Democrats.
In an issueless election cycle, with the economy teetering but not falling and little to stir public interest, it's a long shot that the G.O.P. could beat enough Democratic incumbents to take over the Senate. But if it does happen, Senator Pell will no longer be around to receive special back-room briefings from Uri Geller, the psychic spoon-bender. Without Mr. Pell, research support for sneak peeks at the hereafter will be endangered. Apart from that, it's hard to see how things will be much different.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
GORBACHEV MEETS WITH LITHUANIAN; 'BIG STEP' IS CITED

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 17

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with the Prime Minister of Lithuania in the Kremlin tonight and agreed to begin talks with the breakaway republic if the Lithuanian Parliament suspends its declaration of independence.
The official, Kazimiera Prunskiene, said tonight that the meeting, the first face-to-face encounter between Mr. Gorbachev and a leader of the Baltic republic, was a significant move toward negotiations that could lower the tension surrounding Lithuania's claim of sovereignty, made on March 11, and possibly end the limited economic blockade that Moscow has imposed in retribution.
Both the Lithuanian Prime Minister and the Soviet press agency Tass, reporting on the meeting tonight, said a serious hurdle remained in the way of beginning talks.
 
Status of the Argument
Lithuania has offered to suspend the application of its independence proclamation, including laws repealing the Soviet military draft and laying claim to national property, but the republic has previously insisted that suspending the act itself might jeopardize its status as an equal partner in talks with Moscow. 
Mrs. Prunskiene indicated that this difference should not be insurmountable. She said she would offer a version of a new compromise that might be considered by the Lithuanian Parliament as early as Saturday.
She emphasized that she had told Mr. Gorbachev that independence itself was not negotiable, and said he did not dispute the point.
''He said the fact that we met, that we discussed the issues, that we made progress from our previous positions - this was a big step forward,'' Mrs. Prunskiene said.
 
Freer Hand for U.S. Talks
The meeting, which lasted an hour and 40 minutes, also appeared likely to ease the threat that the Lithuania conflict could overshadow Mr. Gorbachev's meeting with President Bush in Washington, beginning May 30.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, reached tonight in Moscow, said that from what he had heard of the Kremlin meeting, ''it would be a very encouraging step.''
Mr. Baker is scheduled to see Mrs. Prunskiene on Friday after a meeting with Mr. Gorbachev, a session that tonight promised to be a bit more relaxed.
''One of the things we have wanted to see throughout this was the two sides talking face to face,'' said a senior American official who is here with Mr. Baker. ''Here, you have them not only talking face to face, but at a high level.''
The official added: ''We're pleased. You don't want to get carried away with it, either. But it's a real positive step in the right direction.''
The Lithuanian offer and Mrs. Prunskiene's mission to Moscow were timed to catch Mr. Gorbachev at a moment when he would be eager for progress toward a settlement. Unless Moscow eases its embargo on fuel and other supplies, Lithuania is expected to exhaust its oil supplies around the time of the Washington meeting.
 
Quickly Invited In
Mrs. Prunskiene had no assurance she would be welcomed in Moscow when she arrived this afternoon, bearing a compromise offer approved by the Lithuanian Parliament in a closed session on Wednesday.
But soon after her arrival, she said, Mr. Gorbachev telephoned and invited her to meet there this evening. They were joined by the Soviet Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov.
Mrs. Prunskiene said she got no firm commitment that Moscow would lift the economic sanctions that have caused an estimated 30,000 workers in Lithuania to be sent home from fuel-starved factories.
But she said the issue was discussed, and she left with an understanding that ''there will be an appropriate decision'' if the Soviet leadership is satisfied by the Lithuanian Parliament's next move.
 
Paris-Bonn Blueprint
The offer that Mrs. Prunskiene brought to Moscow closely resembled a compromise suggested last month by President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany. They proposed that Lithuania's sovereignty be accepted, but that the republic suspend any actions flowing from the decision as a basis for opening talks.
The meeting with Mr. Gorbachev was a significant step forward for several reasons.
First, the Soviet President has forsaken his earlier insistence that he would not meet with Lithuanian leaders until they had agreed to abide by Soviet law.
Second, it was the most explicit statement to date of the Kremlin's position, which has at times seemed deliberately ambiguous - at one point praising the Mitterrand-Kohl proposal, at other points insisting that Lithuania retreat all the way back to March 10, the day before it voted on independence.
 
How Moscow Views It
Tass confirmed tonight that if the declaration was not repealed but suspended, it would be sufficient.
Third, Mrs. Prunskiene got a clear and direct promise that if Lithuania agreed to those terms, this would lead to the long-sought talks.
Suspending the independence act, Tass said, ''will immediately pave the way for the discussion of issues that worry peoples inhabiting Lithuania and that give rise to grave concern of Soviet republics, Soviet, and world opinion.''
This promise, along with whatever message she takes home from her meeting with Mr. Baker on Friday, may be enough to ease suspicions on the Lithuanian side.
 
Effect on Neighbors
Lithuania's situation is likely to affect the two other Baltic republics, Estonia and Latvia. After Lithuania's declaration of independence, announced as a clean break with Moscow, Estonia said on March 30 that it would make a gradual withdrawal from the Soviet Union. On May 4, Latvia declared independence. In a move seemingly intended to reduce the possibilities for confrontation with Moscow, it established an open-ended transition period to independence, during which most Soviet laws would apply.
Mr. Gorbachev has insisted that any move to leave the Soviet Union must follow the procedures spelled out in a new Soviet law. These procedures include approval of independence by the republic's residents in a referendum, a transition period up to five years, and final approval by the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies.
But Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia have said that they were illegally incorporated into the Soviet Union and that therefore they will not submit to such laws. In 1940, Stalin annexed the three republics under a secret protocol to a pact with Hitler.
 
Freedom Is Another Matter
Mrs. Prunskiene, now a seasoned diplomat after her missions to the White House, Canada and European capitals, appeared buoyed by the Kremlin reception.
''Now we know to what the extent the other side has moved ahead, that there has been major progress, and what are the sticking points on the main issues,'' she told reporters tonight at the Lithuanian mission in Moscow. ''We can say quite clearly that the desire and intentions to begin a discussion on the entire range of issues, within a framework of interests on both sides, have been expressed.''
Mrs. Prunskiene said that while the Soviet leaders seemed eager to end the stalemate, they were far from enthusiastic about the idea of Lithuania actually getting its freedom from the Soviet Union.
''Do they want or welcome the independence of Lithuania?'' she asked rhetorically. ''I not only doubt this, but I am sure they have no such desire. I confirmed once again today that they have trouble with this kind of decision, when a people independently decides an issue without the involvement of the Kremlin.''

HEADLINE: NEGOTIATORS SEE A $60 BILLION LIMIT ON CUTS IN DEFICIT

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
White House and Congressional negotiators ended their second day of budget talks today in general consensus that the Federal deficit for the fiscal year that begins next Oct. 1 could not be cut more than $60 billion without tipping the economy into a recession.
That assessment complicated the negotiators' task, because even the most optimistic forecasts suggested that a cut of $50 billion to $60 billion would not be enough to bring the deficit down to the $64 billion ceiling mandated for 1991 by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law. Such a cut would also be more than twice what has ever been achieved in a single year since the Government began the effort to rein in the defiicit five years ago.
The consensus that emerged today, therefore, seemed to enhance the likelihood that in addition to cutting spending and raising taxes, the negotiators will ultimately have to raise the Gramm-Rudman ceiling. 
 
Bush Turnabout on Taxes
The negotiations between Congress and the White House got under way Tuesday, two weeks after President Bush had abandoned his staunch position against new taxes and called for the talks. In the days since the President's appeal, it has become apparent that Administration officials saw negotiations as a way of remedying incorrect signals sent early this year when the White House offered a budget proposal based on economic forecasts that were far too optimistic. [News analysis, page A15.] Participants in the talks said today that an early item on the table when the negotiators begin examining their options would be removing the cost of the savings-and-loan bailout from the formula used to calculate the budget deficit.
Even after that, however, the deficit would be $65 billion to $100 billion or more above the Gramm-Rudman target, participants said. The negotiators are thus facing unpalatable choices: risk recession, in their view. with spending cuts and tax increases totaling more than $60 billion; raise the target in the budget-balancing law and thus loosen the only current form of discipline that governs the Federal budget-making process, or both.
The negotiatiors were far from having to face such difficult decisions, since they have not been able to agree on the ground rules for their bargaining: the figure that will be used as the estimated size of the deficit from which they will be paring.
The Gramm-Rudman law requires automatic cuts in domestic and military spending if the ceiling that the law sets is not met. According to documents distributed after the talks today, Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, said automatic cuts would total from $59 billion to $74 billion, with as much as 20 percent coming from military programs and 27 percent from domestic spending.
Congressional estimates for automatic spending cuts were even more pessimistic, ranging from $85 billion to $95 billion. Neither estimate takes into account the estimated $50 billion that the savings-and-loan bailout will cost in 1991.
 
Political Risks Likely
A decision to abandon the rules that have governed fiscal policy for the last five years by raising the ceiling of the budget-balancing law would allow the Government to avoid larger cuts than officials believe the economy can handle, but it would be politically risky.
Such a decision could raise questions in the financial markets about the Government's will to control the deficit. It could also affect local elections if lawmakers appear to be reneging on their commitment to get the deficit under control, and might encourage the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
Participants in the budget negotiations said today's two hours of discussions, which took place on Capitol Hill between a team from the White House and a bipartisan Congressional delegation, were devoted to exploring the vast differences between the economic forecasts and the deficit estimates provided by economists in the Administration and on Capitol Hill.
Before discussing in detail ways to cut spending and raise taxes, Congress and the White House must first agree on a way to estimate how big the gap between Government spending and Government revenue will be in the next fiscal year. To do so, they must agree on forecasts for interest rates and other economic indicators, on estimates of how much the Government will make in taxes in the next fiscal year and on other economic factors.
Several participants in the budget negotiations said the two sides have been narrowing their differences, but that a significant gap remained.
Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, said the Congressional estimate for the budget deficit was still about $26 billion higher than the White House estimate. And that did not include the cost of the savings-and-loan bailout.
 
Some White House Flexibility
Representative Leon E. Panetta, a California Democrat who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, said the Administration seemed more flexible about its budget figures than it had in the past. ''If there is any change that we've seen, it is that Darman is willing now to move toward more realistic assumptions,'' Mr. Panetta said.
But he and other Democratic lawmakers said there was much work to be done on this issue, and the negotiators asked Mr. Darman and Mr. Reischauer to work over the weekend to reconcile their deficit estimates.
The next session of the budget talks is set for next Tuesday, but Representative Richard G. Gephardt, the House majority leader, indicated that it did not seem likely the dispute over the deficit figures would be resolved by then.
Mr. Panetta said that in today's negotiations Mr. Reischauer suggested that the deficit could not be reduced by more than about 1 percent of the gross national product, or $50 billion to $60 billion, without risking damage to the economy.
He said Mr. Darman and Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, concurred with that assessment. But Mr. Panetta indicated he was not convinced that even that much could be achieved.
Other Democratic lawmakers said they agreed in concept that there is a point at which cutting the deficit would do more harm than good to the economy. But they said they did not know what that figure was because they remained skeptical about the Administration's economic estimates, which have been changing over the last few months.

Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Robert H. Michel, the House minority leader. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Pulse; The Farm Belt;
New Decade Finds New Hope on Farm

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 17

 BODY:
This is a springtime of renewed hope in the nation's Grain Belt.
After a decade of widely varying fortunes and misfortunes, including an economic crisis in the early 1980's and a drought across some of the most productive grain-growing areas in the last two years, farmers have entered the first growing season of the 1990's with more money to spend, lower debts to pay and the benefits of a three-year resurgence of profits.
Those changes have taken place against some longer-term changes in agriculture. Big farms keep getting bigger and small farms, while still the most numerous, are likely to be the avocations of people who make most of their money elsewhere.
 
Big Farms Are Big Gainers
The big farms continue to enjoy disproportional shares of the profits from agriculture, as they have long done, because they are aided by the biggest shares of Government subsidy payments. But these big farmers end up spending their income farther and farther from the home town: small rural towns in agricultural counties continue to lose people and stores. 
Agricultural economists say most of what is happening in the dozen states in the Grain Belt, from North Dakota to Texas, is also taking place in predominantly agricultural counties throughout the United States.
Mark Drabenstott, an assistant vice president and economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Mo., sketched the broad picture in a few strokes: ''The farm economy is very strong. The weaker farmers have already been squeezed out. Farming now is mostly in the hands of efficient producers with reduced debt loads.''
 
Rural Towns Are Hurting
''The big farms,'' he said, ''are getting larger and more profitable, and they have seen three years of record farm income, but all that has not done much for most of our small rural towns.''
Gary Benjamin, a vice president and economic adviser at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, offered much the same assessment.
''If you look at the farmers' balance sheet, you see a very strong picture,'' he said. ''Land values have recovered, and farm debts have declined 30 percent from the peak of 1983. In fact, the national farm debt in relation to farm assets is as low as it has been at any time since the 1960's.''
 
The Bumpy Decade
Soaring Heights To Rock Bottom
In some ways, the optimism spreading across the Grain Belt recalls the crest of optimism at the start of the 1980's. Farmers entered the decade with a sense of well-being buoyed by steadily rising land values that could, if growers had sold out at the peak, have made millionaires of many people.
In the early 1970's, Communist countries had opened their markets to American farm products. Drought-stricken developing countries turned to the United States for food. Richard M. Nixon's Administration devalued the dollar, making American farm goods cheaper for foreign customers.
In response, American growers eagerly expanded production. American farmers were told they had a mission, to feed the world, and they set out to do it. Prices kept rising. The future seemed limitless, and many farmers bought up all the land their neighbors were willing to sell, blithely paying steadily escalating prices for new acreage and plunging still deeper into dept for new machinery to farm it.
 
World Competition Increases
By 1982, the situation had changed. Because crops were bringing such high prices in international markets, largely because of the guaranteed prices under the United States farm policy, increasing numbers of growers around the world decided to compete for part of the pie. Former customer countries began to vie for markets the American farmers had long regarded as their own.
Exports, which reached a peak of nearly $44 billion in 1981, dropped 40 percent, to $26.3 billion in 1986. The country's agricultural trade surplus, $26.5 billion in 1981, plunged to $5.5 billion in 1986.
Suddenly, farmers who had borrowed lavishly found themselves under mountains of debt, with bills for interest they could not pay. Surpluses mounted, prices fell, and the nation's farmers, who had earned more than $27 billion in 1979, made only $23.5 billion in 1982. And that looked like a good year by 1983 when they earned only $12.7 billion.
 
Horror Story of Farm Sales
By 1985, many farmers, in the grip of the worst agricultural depression in 50 years, were surrendering their land and equipment to rural bankers, who often found themselves in trouble, too. County sheriffs plastered their bulletin boards with notices of bankruptcy sales, and in small towns like Plattsburg, Mo., about 50 miles north of here, sheriffs' sales of bankrupt farms became a weekly horror story.
Congress came to the rescue, and, as it had done so often, it poured money on the farm troubles, passing the Food Security Act of 1985. The bill was intended to cut farm price supports enough to recapture foreign markets for American growers. To make up the difference for farmers, the Government gave them increased subsidy payments.
The bill did most of what it was intended to do, but at a heavy cost to taxpayers. Federal outlays on farm programs totaled $26 billion in 1986 - more than all the income all farmers earned in 1982 and twice what they made in 1983. But farm exports began to recover, and farm income started rising.
By 1987, the recovery was well under way. Land values, which had fallen anywhere from about 30 to more than 50 percent across the Grain Belt, began a long, slow recovery.
 
Weather Presents Problem
But in 1988, yet another blow fell. The weather turned hot and dry, and from Nebraska across Illinois and Indiana eastward to Ohio, corn and soybeans withered. In Missouri and Iowa, farm ponds dried up. In some states whole fields blew away.
Once again, Congress came to the rescue, this time with $3.9 billion in drought relief. And when the Corn Belt's drought of 1988 was followed in 1989 by a dry summer in Kansas and other winter-wheat states, Congress voted still another rescue bill, with nearly $1 billion for farmers.
Even dust clouds can have silver linings, as farmers like Mark Borchers and Barry Bergman discovered when they started to harvest their 1988 crops near Ida Grove in western Iowa. The vagaries of the weather gave them decent rains while other Iowans were suffering. As the drought created shortages that helped to deplete surpluses in the nation's grain bins, it produced a bonus for thousands of farmers like them. Not only did they get good prices for their new crops, they also found a better market for the thousands of bushels of corn and soybeans stored in their bins.
And now, as economists assess the results of the influences on the farm economy for the last two years, they find that even the drought did not stop the recovery.
 
The Harvest
Ebullience In Grain Fields
Their assessment is borne out by changes that have taken place in the grain fields and at rural auctions as well as in the offices of groups like Prairiefire that provided both comfort and aid for farmers through the depths of the farm crisis.
Although there are still some areas that are too dry and many, especially in the Southern Plains, where heavy rains have not only delayed spring planting but also caused severe flooding, most farmers across the broad midlands have seen improvements in the weather this year as well as in the agricultural economy.
Darwin McCall, for example, has been watching lush green stands of wheat grow in fields where both topsoil and seedlings blew away in dust clouds a year ago. With a hint of a smile, Mr. McCall remarked the other day, ''It looks like 1990 is going to be a little different.''
David Ostendorf, Prairiefire's director, said, ''There is no question the dynamics of the situation has changed.'' The group's toll-free telephone line, set up to counsel distressed farmers, now receives about a dozen calls a week, he said; in 1985 and 1986 the numbers were 20 to 30 a day.
 
Different Reason for Auctions
At a recent auction of used farm equipment at Larned, near Great Bend in central Kansas wheat country, Larry Carr of Carr Auctions and Real Estate pointed out a still more striking illustration of changing moods. In 1985 and 1986, most of the sales were signs of farm failures, he said. In a dismal atmosphere, neighbors of the farmers who could no longer hang on gloomily watched the process. The bidding was languid and often tinged with a sense of guilt.
The other day the bidding was spirited with hundreds of items, including 56 tractors and more than 100 farm trucks up for sale. ''I don't think I've ever seen used farm equipment sell so well,'' Mr. Carr said.
He said that rather than making distress sales, farmers were selling machinery they no longer needed because of the Federal Government's Conservation Reserve Program, which pays farmers to leave land fallow for 10-year periods. Many bidders had money from subsidies received through the Food Security Act of 1985.
Behind such signs, economists note, are figures reflecting improvements in farmers' finances. For three years in a row, farmers' net income nationwide has exceeded $40 billion, a level reached for the first time in 1987. Last year the net farm income was $49 billion. In constant dollars, adjusting for inflation, that was more than three times as much as growers earned in 1983.
Economists say the outlook for the year ahead is equally strong, with both crop producers and livestock growers expected to do well, a rare combination on the farm front. Total cash revenue from livestock and crop production is expected to exceed $160 billion this year for the first time ever. The forecast for net farm income is $45 billion to $49 billion. In 1983, when farmers' net income hit bottom at $12.7 billion, their sales totaled $135 billion.
 
Word From the Other Side
Not everyone is as ebullient as Mr. Drabenstott and Mr. Benjamin of the Federal Reserve Bank.
''It's a shallow rebound,'' said Mr. Ostendorf of Prairiefire. ''The Federal Government made a decision to buy its way out of the farm crisis and pumped dollars into the agricultural economy. But nothing basically has changed except that the most economically distressed are now gone. They had already been wiped out.''
Mr. Drabenstott had a similar concern. ''What is very bothersome is that after three years of a strong recovery, agriculture is still so dependent on Government payments,'' he said.
Although they are likely to drop slightly this year, he said, ''direct Government payments of $9 billion to $10 billion will continue to remind us of Washington's role in the recovery.''
 
The Future
Changing Face Of Rural America
Not everyone has participated to the same extent in the benefits of the agricultural turnaround.
The latest analysis of farm-income data by the Agriculture Department, published in December, is based on figures for 1988 from the agency's annual Farm Costs and Returns Survey. It shows total net income for farmers continuing to rise despite that year's severe drought. On average, the increase was about $350 a farm.
But only the largest category of farms analyzed, those with sales of more than $500,000 a year, showed an increase in profits in 1988. The middle-size farms held relatively steady, continuing to improve their financial picture by reducing their debts, but showing little change in income.
 
Money Made Off the Farm
The profit picture of the small farmers is more complicated. Even though many lose money and few make more than a few thousand dollars a year on farming, which is usually a part-time business, most have substantial incomes from nonfarm vocations.
The average combined farm and nonfarm income for those with operations producing $10,000 to $20,000 in sales, for example, was $46,934 in 1988. Most of that - $41,217 - was income that had nothing to do with farming.
Other disparities can be found in the effects of the farm recovery on rural communities, the experts say.
''The breakpoint now is a population of about 5,000,'' said Kenneth Stone of Iowa State University, who has studied the rise and fall of his state's small towns for many years.
''There seems to be a point where they have a critical mass,'' he continued. ''If they lose important stores, other trade slips away, too. Grocery stores seem pivotal. If the grocery store leaves, the hardware trade won't be far behind.''
Mike Cheese, who runs the only grocery store left in Lenox, a town of about 1,300 people in Taylor County, Iowa, is all too familiar with the problems. A competing grocery store, a farm-implement dealer, an automobile dealer and a feed store, among others, closed during the farm crisis. And, though his own business has picked up, Mr. Cheese said nothing had replaced the closed stores.
 
'Slowdown in Deterioration'
''What you are seeing is a sort of slowdown in the deterioration, but in the small towns you are not going to see a turnaround,'' said Barry L. Flinchbaugh, an economist at Kansas State University. ''Agriculture is not a people-intensive industry anymore, and there aren't enough to support the number of small rural towns we still have. And when those small towns lose their bank, lose their grocery store and lose their machinery dealer, those things just don't come back.''
Kenneth Deavers, an economist who heads the rural development division in the Agriculture Department's Economic Research Service, agrees with the two professors.
''The process they are describing is one that has been going on for 10 or 15 years,'' he said. ''And it is happening not only there but across the rest of rural America.''

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Baker Has New Arms Deal For Moscow, Officials Say

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has taken new ideas for reducing conventional forces in Europe to Moscow, in an attempt to accommodate the Soviet position on a number of issues that have slowed completion of a treaty, American and Western diplomats said today.
Mr. Baker told NATO foreign ministers in a letter sent on Tuesday, the day he arrived in Moscow, that he planned to explore the compromise ideas in his meetings with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union. The ideas include a higher limit on tactical aircraft, which has been a major point of contention in conventional force talks in Vienna.
The Soviet press agency Tass said today that Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze had a thorough discussion of conventional arms questions in their talks in Moscow, but provided no details. 
 
Growing Concern Over Talks
Mr. Baker's trip to Moscow comes as concern grows in the Administration over the lagging pace of the East-West conventional arms talks, which involve 23 NATO and Warsaw Pact nations.
The two sides have said they hope to conclude a treaty this year. But NATO and the Warsaw Pact have been at odds over what limits to set on tactical aircraft and other technical issues.
A Bush Administration official said this week that the Administration wanted to speed the talks, fearing that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev might have second thoughts about the large reductions in Soviet forces and weapons in Eastern Europe that are under discussion.
''We wanted to give Gorbachev an incentive to move ahead and complete this treaty as quickly as possible,'' the official said.
The Bush Administration's interest in negotiating cuts in conventional forces comes as the United States and Western European nations are looking to cut their militiary force and budgets. The Pentagon said today that the United States would not formally ask NATO allies to increase after-inflation defense spending by 3 percent a year when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney goes to Brussels next week for a meeting of NATO defense ministers.
 
Pentagon Sets Percent of Cuts
''Given the changes in European security requirements, we are no longer asking our allies to increase their defense budgets by 3 percent,'' the Pentagon statement said. Instead, the United States will ask its allies to ''contribute to the military force structure required by the NATO military command.''
The Pentagon is projecting 2 percent annual cuts in its budget over the next six years, after inflation has been taken into account.
In his letter to the NATO foreign ministers, Mr. Baker identified six areas in which he hoped to find common ground with Mr. Shevardnadze during his talks in Moscow, officials said.
 
Limit on Aircraft
Mr. Baker reportedly said in his letter that he was prepared to discuss a limit on aircraft in the 6,000 range, a higher level than NATO had previously been willing to accept. Such a limit would be intended to partially accommodate the Russians, who have resisted earlier Western demands for deeper cuts in their conventional aircraft, officials said.
Mr. Baker also reportedly indicated a willingness to explore a compromise on another difficult issue - the maximum number of weapons that any single country would be permitted.
NATO has previously said that no more than 60 percent of total tanks, artillery pieces and armored troop carriers held by the Warsaw Pact could be Soviet. Moscow has said that this limit is too low, especially since the Warsaw Pact is becoming an alliance in name only.
Other issues identified by Mr. Baker for potential compromise include the rate at which equipment is to be destroyed, the definition of ground equipment, and the extent of verification provisions.
 
Concerns About Inspections
Moscow, which would have to destroy far more equipment under the emerging accord than the United States would, has indicated that it would have difficulty quickly eliminating its tanks, artillery pieces, armored troop carriers and aircraft. And the Soviet Union has reportedly raised concerns about the number of inspections that would be held on its military bases.
Officials familiar with Mr. Baker's letter said that the Secretary expressed his intention to explore possible compromises with an eye to developing formal proposals for presentation in the Vienna talks.
''The general sense of the letter is exploring Soviet flexibility and splitting the difference,'' a Western official said.
Mr. Baker also indicated that he would assure Moscow that the United States would begin a second round of conventional arms talks after an initial pact is reached on reducing conventional forces in Europe.
 
Ceiling on German Army
During a recent meeting in Bonn with Mr. Shevardnadze on German reunification, Mr. Baker reportedly indicated that the United States would consider a Soviet proposal to limit troops in central Europe in a second round of talks, Administration officials said.
The Soviets have sought such a limit in the current negotiations to establish a ceiling on the size of the German Army. The West has rejected such a limit in the current talks, but Mr. Baker's indication that Washington would take this up in the second round was intended as a conciliatory move.
On tactical aircraft, the United States had previously proposed an effective limit of 5,200 combat aircraft. Moscow, in contrast, has proposed an effective limit of 7,700 combat planes, though the two sides do not agree on all of the types of planes that should be covered by the accord.
A limit in the 6,000 range would appear to roughly split the difference between the two sides. Depending on what precise limit is specified, such a provision might not require any cuts in NATO forces because the West has fewer planes. Previously, NATO has said that it was seeking a limit on weapons that would be 15 percent below its current holdings.

HEADLINE: Awaiting Gorbachev Are Cookies, Song and Friendly Advice From Ex-Foes: Minnesota;
Companies Hoping for New Market

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, May 17

 BODY:
A man who lives on the St. Croix River called to offer Mikhail S. Gorbachev use of his cabin, in case he wanted to rest up before his flight.
A woman telephoned, saying she wanted to bake the Soviet President some cookies. Students at a local elementary school asked if they could sing him a song. And in case he needs a car, when he is here, a dealership has set aside a nice four-door, free of charge. 
Two days after Minnesota learned officially that Mr. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, would be passing through town on June 3, state officials have been inundated with invitations, offers of gifts and advice.
''I've had to set up a phone bank to handle the volume,'' said Richard Bohr, who as head of the state trade office is in charge of arrangements.
Some of the most eager suitors have been business leaders who hope to use the visit to tout the state's business and industry, in the hopes of tapping into the Soviet market.
 
The Biggest Dividend
But with more than two weeks to go before Mr. Gorbachev arrives, the biggest dividend has already been earned by Gov. Rudy Perpich.
By accepting Mr. Perpich's formal invitation to visit Minnesota, following his summit meeting with President Bush, Mr. Gorbachev just gave the Governor's sagging political fortunes a world-class election-year lift.
Mr. Perpich, a member of the Democrat Farm Labor Party, had been fading in the polls in his bid for a third term as Governor. Some doubted he would even win his party's nomination in the primary next fall.
''Pre-Gorbachev, and I mean just a few days ago, I don't think anyone took him seriously,'' said D. J. Leary, who edits a political newsletter here. ''Now he looks like a kind of visionary. It's given him credence he didn't have.''
 
Grudging Congratulations
Doug Kelley, one of four Republicans who are planning to run for governor, said he had to offer Governor Perpich grudging congratulations. ''I don't know who deserves the credit,'' he told The St. Paul Pioneer Press earlier this week. ''But I know who will take the credit.''
Mr. Gorbachev's planned visit to Minnesota marks the second time a Soviet leader has stopped over in the Midwest. In 1959, Nikita S. Khrushchev spent two days in Iowa, where he sampled hot dogs at a meat-packing plant, and toured a farm where he complained that American corn had ''too much stalk and not enough corn.''
If an Iowa farm served as the appropriate metaphor for the Midwest in 1959, then Minneapolis and St. Paul describe a more accurate contemporary illustration of the region.
 
Diverse and Prosperous Economy
While the Twin Cities still reflect the prowess of Midwestern agriculture, their skyscraper-like grain elevators, spread out freeways and ranks of steel-and-glass office towers underscore an increasingly diverse and prosperous urban economy, in which computers and high technology now play a very large role.
Tom Triplett, the executive director of the Minnesota Business Parternship, which represents the state's 90 largest companies, said Soviet leaders see in Minnesota ''the ABC's they need -agriculture, biotech and computers.''
It was one of those companies, Control Data, that had an important role in steering Mr. Gorbachev toward Minnesota. Control Data sold the first large American computers to the Soviet Union in 1968, and the company has maintained a strong relationship with Moscow ever since.
 
Invitations and Gifts
The news of the Gorbachev visit has taken Minnesota by storm.
Moscow Township, a rural community in southeastern Minnesota, has invited Mr. Gorbachev to visit the town, the namesake of the Soviet capital. As an added lure, the township clerk, J. Michael Taylor, said they have even promised him some Rubles, as in the family of Richard Ruble, chairman of township board.
So far, no one has come up with a schedule for the visit, which Governor Perpich and his staff are still planning in consultation with Soviet officials.
Several different events are being considered. There is talk about a trip to a farm, or motorcade through the city, or a public appearance at the state Capitol.
 
Possible Protests
Some political groups representing Baltic organizations also talked about possible protests during Mr. Gorbachev's visit, although it was expected they would be low key.
''This is a very polite, a very well-mannered state,'' said Mr. Leary. ''It took people here 20 years before they decided it was okay to boo the Vikings.''
There are plans to put signs around the city, welcoming Mr. and Mrs. Gorbachev. But the Gorbachevs might also catch a glimpse of other billboards that were put up several weeks ago, and which use Mr. Gorbachev's face to advertise a locally manufactured vodka brand.
The billboard shows Mr. Gorbachev, appearing to hold a bottle of the vodka. The text alongside reads: ''The party's over,'' an apparent reference to the demise of Communist power. There have been calls to cover the billboards during the visit, but so far no action has been taken.
State officials said the public reaction to the visit underscored the good will Mr. Gorbachev has among Americans. A state poll last summer showed that two out of every three Minnesotans regarded him favorably.
With the primary just four months off, that's good news for Mr. Perpich, who could use Mr. Gorbachev's coattails. In recent polls here, only one in three voters gave the Governor a favorable rating.

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 941 words

HEADLINE: Awaiting Gorbachev Are Cookies, Song and Friendly Advice From Ex-Foes: Stanford;
Red Carpet Readied by Conservatives

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif., May 17

 BODY:
The archivist at the Hoover Institution here is readying a display of Soviet historical documents that will include the final draft of the abdication letter of Czar Nicholas II, a rare first edition of the Communist Manifesto and the only surviving copy of Pravda's first issue.
Meanwhile, the economists at this conservative think tank, which was a source of policy ideas and personnel for the Reagan Administration, are polishing their presentation of how free market principles are best applied to taxes, spending, welfare and business regulation.
These are heady days at the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace, which shares a bucolic campus on the peninsula south of San Francisco with Stanford University. On June 4, if all goes according to plan, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union will spend at least several hours here as the centerpiece of his visit to the San Francisco Bay Area after his summit meeting with President Bush. 
Officials of the Hoover Institution and the university, who are often at ideological odds, have joined forces to submit a proposed itinerary to the Soviet Embassy in Washington. That itinerary is expected to include a visit to the archives, with its peerless 20th-century Russian collection, a meeting with economists who have already offered advice to officials from Poland and Romania and an introduction to various Silicon Valley entrepreneurs.
 
George Shultz's Role
Officials and fellows at the Hoover Institution see the Gorbachev visit as a way to show the world that they have taken a new role, that this bastion of anti-Soviet thinking has recast itself as a guide and resource for Eastern European nations trying to reshape themselves economically and politically.
The key link in this process is George P. Shultz, who as Secretary of State for President Ronald Reagan was the principal architect of the United State's rapprochement with the Soviet Union. He is now a distinguished fellow at the Hoover Institution and a professor of international economics at the Graduate School of Business at Stanford. ''George Shultz is the linchpin in this whole business,'' said John Raisian, Hoover's new director and a labor economist.
Mr. Shultz was traveling home from South Korea and unavailable for comment. Charles Hill, Mr. Shultz's right-hand man at the State Department and now a fellow at Hoover, said that Shultz had made no formal invitation to Mr. Gorbachev and that he was reluctant to speculate that the Soviet leader wanted to come here solely because of his fond relationship with the former Secretary of State.
''We don't want to attribute motives to the Soviets,'' Mr. Hill said. He cited an array of possible attractions here, including the archives, where both Aleksandr Kerensky, Russia's first democratic leader, and Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel laureate, studied, and Silicon Valley, where the computer revolution was born.
''The combination of past and future is so dramatic here,'' Mr. Hill added.
 
A Legion of Foreign Visits
Mr. Shultz was a major reason Sergei F. Akhromeyev, Mr. Gorbachev's chief national security adviser, visited the Hoover Institution last summer. Mr. Akhromeyev's two-day stay, after a trip to Washington to meet with the Joint Chiefs of Staff, included seeing the archives, the university's linear accelerator and genetics research center, and riding a helicopter above the graceful landscape of the Bay area. Mr. Akhromeyev was a guest in the Shultz's home on the campus.
The Hoover Institution has also recently entertained dignitaries from Poland and Romania. The Polish visitor, Jerzy Makarczyk, the deputy foreign minister of foreign affairs, also saw the archives, including the records of the Polish government in exile after the Nazi invasion.
At the end of Mr. Makarczyk's visit, an exchange agreement was signed that called for the Polish government to provide copies of current documents and the Institution to send microfilm of historical material that has been unavailable in Poland. In addition, according to Mr. Raisian, the deputy foreign minister asked for help training young diplomats. Mr. Raisian said he hopes to put together a 12-week seminar in the fall.
Then came a contingent from Romania, including the foreign minister, the minister of finance and an adviser to the prime minister. Mr. Raisian said they brought a 100-page document about the transition to a market economy, which was reviewed and criticized by a panel of Hoover fellows. The economists at Hoover include Milton Friedman, Michael Boskin, Martin Anderson and John Taylor.
 
Smugness Among the Fellows
Mr. Raisian said he hoped the Hoover Institution, founded by Herbert C. Hoover in 1919 as a repository for the records of World War I, can similarly be a resource to Mr. Gorbachev, and a place to ''network'' with economic scholars and high-technology experts. ''The idea is to put him in touch with people he can continue to interact with,'' Mr. Raisian said.
Throughout the halls, offices and courtyards here today, the Institution's fellows seemed to be gloating a bit, as if Mr. Gorbachev's visit vindicated their longstanding ideologies, particularly on economic matters, which many of them predicted would be the focus of the dialogue here in June.
''We've been saying all along that the Marxist system is a bad system,'' said Mr. Hill. ''Now the Soviets themselves agree with us. These people have read our stuff and underlined it very carefully. They know what we say has to be done. It isn't a matter of 'We're smarter than they are.' What is needed is a conversation among economic people.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charles Hill, a fellow at the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace in Stanford, Calif., with Soviet historical documents from the Institution's archives. (Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1416 words

HEADLINE: Behind Bush's Turnaround on Taxes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
Why, after whistling a happy tune about the economy for 15 months and singing ''no new taxes'' as the anthem of his Administration, did President Bush suddenly change his tune, demand full-scale budget negotiations with Congress and imply that he was prepared to support higher taxes?
The President's turnabout seems to be primarily a result of having overestimated the strength of the economy, either as a political gambit or as an honest miscalculation. The savings and loan mess has worsened the problem, not only in budget terms but also in economic terms.
What the White House is seeking to remedy is the incorrect signal that Mr. Bush and his economic advisers sent early this year when they based the Administration's budget on wildly optimistic economic forecasts. Now they apparently fear that if the mistake is not corrected quickly it could damage the financial markets, send the economy into a tailspin, hurt Republicans' chances in the November elections and perhaps even jeopardize Mr. Bush's own re-election prospects in 1992. 
 
A Shared Assessment
In the budget he submitted in January, the President told the nation and the financial markets that the Federal budget deficit could be reduced enough in the next fiscal year to meet the requirement of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law without unpopular spending cuts or new taxes. That, it is now clear, cannot be done. Mr. Bush and his advisers seem to believe that if they are not perceived as acting to reduce what they now concede is the real budget deficit, interest rates for private borrowers will rise, business costs will go up and investment will be choked off, a set of circumstances that could lead to a recession. That assessment is shared on Wall Street.
Furthermore, massive additional Government borrowing to liquidate failed savings and loan institutions and pay off the depositors could push up interest rates, at least temporarily.
 
Tighter Lending Practices
Even more important, commercial banks seem to be feeling a ripple effect from the savings and loan disaster and have tightened their lending practices. Tougher credit and the impending ''fire sale'' of property repossessed by the failed savings institutions threaten to drive down real estate prices, lowering homeowners' estimates of their own wealth and inducing them to spend and invest less.
The main concern on Wall Street is high interest rates. Economists for the investment banking houses are telling their customers that it does not matter whether the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings target is met precisely, but that it is important for the Administration and Congress to take bold steps to lower the deficit. Otherwise, these economists say, the Federal Reserve will have to keep a strong hand on the money supply lest inflation get out of hand, and interest rates will stay high.
Wall Street figures said they found preposterous the President's statement at his news conference Wednesday that he could not spell out publicly the real nature of the problem now because to do so would ''frighten the markets.''
''By saying that,'' said Robert H. Chandross, chief economist in the New York office of Lloyds Bank, ''he's implicitly saying, 'You'd better be scared.' ''
''The markets are pretty astute,'' Mr. Chandross added. ''They realize the true position of the budget is worse than he's been saying.''
 
Unlikely Economic Forecasts
In January, Mr. Bush and his advisers took a gamble by basing the Administration's budget on barely plausible economic forecasts. If they had proved to be correct, only $36 billion would have had to be found in spending cuts or revenue increases to meet the $64 billion deficit target under the budget-balancing law.
But Richard G. Darman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, is now saying that deficit reduction of twice or three times what the President predicted will be needed to meet the target. If it is not met, automatic spending cuts in most Government programs will be required.
A Congressional study shows that if the target is missed by $50 billion, a reasonable figure if belt-tightening measures are not taken, the result would be, for instance, an $18 billion cut in Pentagon spending, a $550 million cut in aid to Israel, 1,000 fewer air traffic controllers, 600 fewer air safety inspectors and the elimination of 75,000 children from the Head Start preschool program.
That would be politically intolerable, so Mr. Bush and Congress must find a way to meet the budget law's target through spending reductions or tax increases, or change the law. $55 Billion Target Suggested Keynesian analysis suggests that reducing spending or raising taxes would slow economic growth. But the President seems to feel that would be offset by the lower interest rates that would result from less Government borrowing. He suggested at the news conference that the deficit could be reduced by $55 billion without risking a recession.
By Mr. Darman's new calculations, that might not be enough to meet the law's deficit target. But if the deficit could be reduced by $55 billion, an amount that would almost certainly require a tax increase, the financial markets would probably be satisfied that a serious effort was under way in Washington, and the law could be changed to accommodate the new figures.
Many Democrats hold the conspiratorial view that Mr. Darman doctored the forecasts so that Mr. Bush could maintain his no-taxes pledge for the first 18 months of his Presidency. Mr. Darman responds that the Administration's forecasts in 1989 were also more favorable than those of private economists, and that the Administration proved to be closer to the mark. He also said some outside economists were as optimistic early this year as he was.
The budget director has given three main reasons why the Administration got into this box.
First, he says, Government tax receipts are not as high as the Administration expected. Second, interest rates are higher than anticipated, and the Government thus must pay more on its bonds. Finally, the savings and loan bailout is costing more than expected.
The first two are the result of the overly optimistic forecasts.
Receipts are less largely because the Administration vastly overestimated corporate profits and thus corporate tax payments. The Administration predicted that corporate profits would rise by 18.8 percent in 1990 and 16.9 percent in 1991. The consensus of 50 leading private economists in January, when Mr. Bush submitted his budget, was that profits would fall by 1.9 percent this year and rise by 4.7 percent next year. The private forecasters have proved so far to be more accurate.
Similarly, the Administration predicted that the average rate on three-month Treasury Bills would be 6.7 percent this year and 5.4 percent next year. The private economists put the figures at 7.1 percent and 7.2 percent. So far this year, the rate has run between 7.5 percent and 8 percent.
 
'Read My Book,' Official Says
No one in Congress should be surprised by the revised budget figures. They jibe with what the Congressional Budget Office forecast.
''I am tempted to say, 'Read my book,' '' said Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the budget office, who is Congress's chief economist. Mr. Reischauer was referring to the book his office published in March analyzing the President's budget.
The budgetary cost of the savings and loan bailout is another matter. Mr. Darman put no money in the budget in January to liquidate failed savings institutions because he said it was impossible to determine how much would have to be spent in the next fiscal year to pay off depositors, and how much would be returned to the Government when the assets of those institutions are sold.
Mr. Darman is now saying the difference could be as high as $50 billion, although it is not clear how he arrived at that figure. In any event this matter is probably moot, since both Congress and the White House are prepared to remove this part of the bailout program from the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings calculations.
Mr. Bush said Wednesday that reaching an accommodation on the budget would be the biggest test of his leadership on domestic policy. It is also likely to be the first time he had to go before the public with bad news. That might lower his 70 percent popularity rating. But if he can pull off a solution without a recession, he will have succeeded not only in economic terms, but also in political terms.

HEADLINE: Aiming to Carry the Torch

BYLINE: By JERRY SCHWARTZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 17

 BODY:
Once considered a long shot, Atlanta will submit itself to close scrutiny this week as a possible host city for the 1996 Summer Olympic Games.
A team of Olympic officials arrived in Atlanta today to begin inspections of the city and its sports facilities amid growing speculation that Athens, the sentimental favorite to stage the 1996 Summer Games, may have difficulty winning the bid.
For the next month, Olympic officials will be in Atlanta to study the city's hotels, sports facilities, airport, crime statistics, weather, hospitals, drinking water, symphony orchestra - even its hairdressers and laundries.
Political and economic instability in Greece coupled with recent blunt statements by members of the International Olympic Committee have given rival cities hope that they can overcome the sentimental desire of Olympic officials to return to the birthplace of the Olympic movement. 
 
Binder Full of Detail
''Sentiment isn't going to be the only factor in this vote,'' said William Porter Payne, a former defensive end for the University of Georgia who heads Atlanta's Olympic effort.
''If they were only going to vote with their hearts, they wouldn't be asking for all of this information,'' Payne said, holding aloft a three-inch thick binder filled with detailed analyses of Atlanta and its facilities.
The three Olympic technical committees studying Atlanta this month will report to the full I.O.C. in September at a meeting in Tokyo at which the 1996 host city will be chosen from among six candidates.
Conventional wisdom places Atlanta among the leading contenders, along with Toronto and Melbourne, Australia. The two dark horse candidates are Belgrade, Yugoslavia, and Manchester, England.
During an informal visit to Atlanta last month, three members of the I.O.C. expressed doubts about the ability of the Greek Government to make physical improvements considered necessary for the 1996 Games.
The French I.O.C. member, Maurice Herzog, said he had visited Greek political leaders and Olympic officials to warn them that their antiquated airport, congested streets and air pollution put the Athens bid in jeopardy.
 
Very Strong Pollution
''It's a fact, and I told them I think it's very serious,'' Herzog told reporters here. ''It's not possible with the transportation as it is to insure a good organization for the Games. The lack of a good airport, for example. The lack of an underground, because the traffic in Athens is completely blocked. The pollution is very strong.''
Last month, one of Greece's three major political parties was able to claim a one-seat majority in the 300-member Parliament for first time since voters ousted the two-term Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, in June.
''Athens is the sentimental candidate for everyone,'' said Fernando Ferreira Lima Bello, an I.O.C. member from Portugal. ''But the problem is the economic situation. If they don't quickly get a stable government moving things ahead, improving their economic situation, it's a serious problem.''
Robert Helmick, president of the United States Olympic Committee and a member of the I.O.C., said this week that his informal conversations with I.O.C. members convince him that there no longer is any front-runner.
''I tell you quite candidly that it is a serious mistake to assume any corporate mentality on the part of the I.O.C. members,'' Helmick said. ''It's simply not correct to assume that the I.O.C., as a group, wants to go to Athens. There are 90 individuals who will vote. The factors involved are very complex. To read any negotiated consensus would be incorrect.''
Sentiment aside, the I.O.C. members are asking an array of questions about potential host cities. The I.O.C. and its various sports federations have sent the potential host cities 43 pages of questions.
 
Covering All Matters
They cover everything from the height of ceilings above the proposed badminton courts to the status of diplomatic relations between the host country and all other Olympic countries.
While there are numerous questions about the proposed Olympic village and sports venues, there are even more questions covering such issues as the gross national product and inflation rate of the host country, the local school system, the laws in place to protect the Olympics and local racial, ethnic and religious problems.
Although I.O.C. members have said they are suitably impressed with Atlanta's enthusiasm and technical prowess, they also have said the I.O.C. will have difficulty voting to hold the Olympics in either the United States or Canada since each country has staged both winter and summer games within the last 14 years.
 
Matter of Safety
Atlanta must also convince the I.O.C. that the city will be safe for the Olympics. Statistics released by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last month showed Atlanta has the highest rate of serious crime of any American city.
''The fact is, Atlanta is extraordinarily safe for visitors and conventioneers,'' Payne said. ''Our crime, regrettably, is domestic; it's drug related. That said, however, we've got to be able to demonstrate that we are taking steps to deal with the problem.''

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
A Rage To Kill

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
''One of the most striking differences between the United States and other industrial countries is America's enthusiasm for execution.'' The Economist of London thus summed up a phenomenon that puzzles many foreign friends of the United States.
The death penalty has been effectively abandoned in all the countries of Western Europe and most in Latin America. South Africa used to execute more prisoners than any other country; but on Feb. 2 President de Klerk, in announcing steps toward negotiation, suspended all executions. 
The United States is now the execution capital of the Western world. There are about 2,200 prisoners on death row. And executions are taking place at a quickening pace as legal constraints are removed.
It used to be assumed that a juvenile who committed a capital crime would not be put to death. But the Supreme Court has now held that there is no constitutional barrier to such executions, and they have begun.
Mental retardation is not a reason for withholding the death penalty either. We learn that from the case of Dalton Prejean, who is scheduled to be electrocuted in Louisiana a few hours after this column is written.
Dalton Prejean killed a policeman in 1977. His guilt was not in issue. His responsibility was. To put it another way, the question was whether a civilized society would take the life of a criminal whose nature had been shaped as Mr. Prejean's had.
He was 17 when he shot the policeman. Doctors found that he had suffered brain damage at birth or in childhood. The aunt who brought him up beat him with belts and sticks. He had an I.Q. of 76.
An all-white jury imposed the death sentence on Mr. Prejean, a black man. Studies have shown that prosecutors are far more likely to seek the death penalty, and juries to impose it, when blacks kill whites. The Supreme Court has held that fact, too, to be constitutionally irrelevant.
This week Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist again urged a swifter legal process for executions. He sought passage of a bill before Congress that would allow prisoners on death row to bring only one constitutional challenge in a habeas corpus petition in the Federal courts.
At present prisoners may bring successive petitions. It may take eight years or more between the time a person is convicted in a state court and the moment when Federal courts end their consideration and remove the last obstacle to execution.
The Chief Justice said a system that allows such delays ''verges on the chaotic.'' Certainly it imposes cruelty and frustration on the parties. But speeding the process up by limiting constitutional challenges would not deal with the real legal problem underlying that process.
The problem is inadequate legal representation at the start. Inadequate is indeed too weak a word. Most of the people who are on death row in this country got there simply because they had no effective lawyer's help at their trial or original appeal.
Stephen B. Bright, a lawyer for the Southern Prisoners Defense Committee in Atlanta, was teaching in Washington, D.C., 10 years ago when he was asked to help prepare a petition to the Supreme Court in a death case. He expected to find a massive trial record reflecting a careful defense. He found almost nothing. ''The students in our clinical program tried shoplifting cases better than this capital case had been tried,'' Mr. Bright told a House Judiciary subcommittee last week. The defendant had a court-appointed lawyer, but he presented no evidence.
Many lawyers have had Mr. Bright's experience, coming in to represent someone already on death row and finding that crucial evidence was never presented. Dalton Prejean's jury was never told about his mental problems or history of abuse.
For those reasons, the idea that only especially evil criminals are selected for execution is a joke. The ones who lose are poor, mentally impaired, black - and had lawyers who did not take the case seriously. The results are so unfair that half of all state death sentences have been set aside in recent years during the long process of Federal habeas corpus.
But the American public wants executions, even though there is no evidence that capital punishment deters crime. And politicians respond. The Louisiana parole board recommended that Gov. Buddy Roemer commute Dalton Prejean's sentence, but he refused. Candidates everywhere are vying to say who can push the execution switch faster.
Why? Somewhere in our history and our violent society must lie the reasons for the rage to kill.
