SECTION: Section A; Page 32, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1927 words

HEADLINE: LAW;
Tide Rises on Suits for Bilingual Work Bonuses

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
As government agencies and private companies have struggled to serve more and more people who do not speak English, they have leaned hard on their bilingual employees for help. Now the employees are leaning back.
In a swelling tide of lawsuits, job grievances and contract demands, employees who say their foreign-language abilities bring them extra work are demanding extra pay.
From California beach towns to New York City, Spanish-speaking police officers, teachers and hospital workers are pressing for bonus money, salary differentials and promotion points.
Employees fighting the police department of Tucson, Ariz., for bilingual bonuses are heading for a trial in Federal District Court. Hispanic patrolmen just beginning a similar case in Miami have threatened to selectively forget their Spanish on the job. 
A court ruling in favor of Hispanic agents who charged the Federal Bureau of Investigation with shunting them to undesirable Spanish-speaking jobs has unleashed a stream of similar complaints against other Federal law-enforcement agencies.
 
Widely Watch Suit in West
And from California's Central Valley has come a Federal court suit that could have wide implications for the private sector. Backed by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and her union, Paula Soriano, a 58-year-old telephone service representative, has charged that because she is the daughter of Mexican parents - and fluent in Spanish - her job duties have been made overwhelming. Her Anglo co-workers, she says, have faced no such demands, and in fact have made money for the work she performed with them.
''All of this, I think, is going to be the new frontier of equal protection and anti-discrimination legislation and litigation,'' said Laurence H. Tribe, a professor of constitutional law at Harvard Law School. ''It's a little surprising that there wasn't more ferment along these lines before.''
The rising demands are partly the product of earlier battles against discrimination - of the job opportunities they helped to create, the pride they bolstered and the growing economic power they brought to ethnic minorities.
Yet perhaps even more sharply than the lingering debate over bilingual education, the workplace dispute has brought into focus a basic issue of America's changing ethnic makeup: To what extent will the ability to speak languages besides English come to be accepted as a valuable skill even among workers hired to do other jobs? Or will it simply be regarded as a product of cultural circumstance, to be used as circumstances require and meriting no special rewards?
 
New Demands by Consumers
Companies and government agencies have scrambled in recent years to service growing legions of non-English-speaking consumers. Yet for Hispanic as well as other bilingual employees, a chasm remains between the fees commanded by a professional translator and the value assigned a stop-gap interpreter.
Into the gap have plunged thousands of bilingual nurses, dishwashers and secret service personnel who, in a pinch or out of habit, are called on to answer the telephone, write a letter, read a suspect his rights for monolingual colleagues.
''It's a constant source of irritation for the bilingual workers,'' said Ruben Castillo, a Chicago lawyer representing Hispanic agents in a suit against the United States Customs Service. ''Virtually every level of government employee has talked to me about doing some kind of case.''
For a shoe salesperson, the extra time spent helping co-workers might mean fewer commissions. For law-enforcement officials and social workers, the result is often less time for their own cases and nothing to show for their efforts.
Hispanic and Asian rights advocates say the situation often begets a discriminatory pattern in which bilingual employees must work harder to qualify for promotions. If their language skills become indispensable, they are sometimes kept in lower-level jobs dealing directly with the public regardless of their performance, the advocates contend. Extra Pay Rare in U.S. Although not unheard of in schools, police departments and social service agencies, especially in the Southwest, extra pay for bilingual work is rare elsewhere in the country and in the private sector generally, employer associations say.
In the Federal Government, the first extensive foreign-language bonus policy is just being set up in the F.B.I. and Drug Enforcement Administration, two years after Congress voted to allow them to pay agents differentials of up to 25 percent of their salaries for bilingual work.
Legal experts say the mere handful of lawsuits now pending in court are less a measure of the problem's scope than test cases in a realm where laws are ill-defined.
''I would have absolutely no trouble filing 10 of these cases tomorrow if I had 10 lawyers to handle them,'' said Jose Roberto Juarez Jr. of Los Angeles, who like Mr. Castillo is a regional counsel for the Mexican-American Legal Defense and Educational Fund. ''Really what they're going to have to do is await the outcome of these cases.''
 
Impetus for the Lawsuits
The relatively few disputes that have reached the courts have been propelled by demographic and socioeconomic shifts of extraordinary speed.
Paula Soriano began only a decade ago taking orders for new telephones for the Contel Service Corporation near Fresno, Calif. But even then, she never expected that migrant farm workers in the area would become established enough to abandon the roadside shape-ups where they used to find work, rely on telephones and answering machines, and overwhelm her office with Spanish-speaking customers.
Hispanic agents who joined the F.B.I. and D.E.A. in the 1960's and 70's might have guessed that illegal drugs would remain a growth industry. But they could hardly have predicted the cocaine boom that pushed them into the most dangerous undercover assignments and tedious tasks like listening to wire-tapped conversations in Spanish for days on end.
Nor could young Latins who joined the Miami police years ago have foreseen that they would shrink into an even smaller minority - the few officers able to communicate with the great majority of people they were to protect and serve.
What legal precedent does exist on the issue of bilingual work rests largely on the 1988 ruling against the F.B.I. by Federal District Judge Lucius D. Bunton of El Paso, and the remedies he ordered last May.
Judge Bunton found that the bureau had systematically discriminated against its Hispanic employees in promotions and assignments.
Hugo Rodriguez, a Miami lawyer who represented the plaintiffs, said the decision could be interpreted to mean that bilingual employees should receive extra compensation under certain circumstances: if they are required to use their foreign-language skills, were not expressly hired to do so, and end up because of those duties on footing unequal to that of their colleagues.
 
Scope of the Legal Issue
While language was at the heart of broader charges of discrimination by the bureau, Mr. Rodriguez said that on its own, the legal issue surrounding bilingual compensation was not necessarily one of equal protection.
''It's a contracts issue in my mind,'' said Mr. Rodriguez, who also is representing Hispanic officers in suits against three South Florida police departments. ''If you hire me and I understand that I was hired to speak Spanish as a condition of my employment, then you've got me.''
Other lawyers speculated that for all of the complaints, there would be relatively few cases where an employer's demand for work in a foreign language might constitute clear proof of discrimination.
In Mrs. Soriano's case, an employment commission lawyer, Stephen P. Passek, said that Contel had assumed because of her appearance and accent that she could speak Spanish and dispatched her to deal with Spanish-speaking clients. Lawyers for Contel were said to be traveling yesterday and unavailable for comment. In the past they have said that Mrs. Soriano's duties never exceeded those of her English-speaking co-workers.
In one of two cases against the Tucson police, Richard Martinez, a lawyer for the plaintiff, argued that a patrolman was suspended for refusing to speak Spanish even though, like roughly three-fourths of Hispanic people in the United States, he did not know the language.
Both private and public employers have sought to meet new demands for bilingual service with their old employees. But several business executives said they believed the private sector would face fewer complaints because they had been clearer in describing the language duties of their jobs to prospective employees.
Others, like banks and fast-food restaurants, have found that where immigrant communities demand service in a foreign language, they also tend to provide more than enough job applicants willing to do the same job for the same pay in two languages.
 
Another Response on Issue
For each worker who has openly complained about bilingual duties, there appear to be scores more willing, even grateful to use their other languages.
''I enjoy what I do,'' said Rita Rodriguez, 40, the lone Spanish speaker advising new mothers about the mysteries of child care for a toll-free telephone service of the Gerber Products Company in Fremont, Mich. ''My gratuity is to know that I can help them.''
But lawyers and immigrant-rights advocates also say that many disgruntled workers have kept quiet about their foreign language burdens out of fear. And as a few public cases have illuminated the predicament of others, they say, that fear has begun to recede.
''It has always been a problem,'' said Kathryn K. Imahara, a lawyer at the Asian Pacific Legal Center in Los Angeles. ''What's happening now is that people are finally complaining about it.''
Ms. Imahara said that while many Asians share the predicament of Spanish-speaking workers, she knew of none so far who had taken legal action against their employers. She added, ''They all say, 'I don't want to lose my job, I need this job.' ''
Some Hispanic people have argued against demanding higher pay for bilingual work because they fear it could produce a backlash of resentment.
In the Los Angeles Unified School District, which has the largest number of non-English-speaking students of any in the country, English-only advocates fought bitterly to overturn annual bonuses of $5,000 for bilingual teachers. The bonuses passed in March by a 2-to-1 union vote.
Walter Alicea, a New York police detective who is president of the Hispanic Society, a police group, acknowledged similar sensitivities in saying that Hispanic officers had set aside their demands for bilingual pay after a meeting 10 days ago with Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown.
But like others, he said a number of steps could be taken to reward bilingual abilities, like awarding points in hiring and on promotional examinations. .
After years of assignments on what Hispanic agents disparagingly called ''the taco circuit,'' the chief plaintiff in the discrimination suit against the F.B.I., Bernardo M. Perez, now runs programs established by bureau to reward foreign language skills. But he insisted that neither the turn of his personal fortunes nor the advent of higher pay for bilingual work had brought the change he has sought.
''There is an ignorance in this country of what it means to speak another language,'' Mr. Perez said. ''The change will come in seeing bilingual skills as a benefit and not a detriment.''

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
A Plan for Land Vs. 8 Generations Of a Family Farm

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

DATELINE: RAMAPO, N.Y.

 BODY:
Since before the American Revolution, Concklins have farmed here. ''Eight generations,'' Richard Concklin said. ''We hope many more.'' The ninth is in the pipeline: Scott, a junior at Cornell agricultural school.
They run a you-pick-it apple orchard and farm store, one of the last in a suburbanized area. Each year thousands of schoolchildren make trips to Concklin's and learn that apples do not come from a greengrocer's back room. The Concklins are the sort who save trees near the road for handicapped children. 
Even the environmentalists whose lawsuit may finish the farm know better than to attack the Concklins personally. Still, June 1 foreclosure is to begin.
A hailstorm killed 90 percent of the crop, a fire damaged buildings and by 1986 the Concklins were $1.6 million in debt. To keep the farm they had a plan: sell 37 of their 100 acres, retire the debt and modernize. They found a builder who wanted to buy 23 acres and put 10 $750,000 homes on two-acre lots. The area is zoned for two-acre lots. In November 1988, after two years of review, the town approved.
A local environmental group, West Branch Conservation, did not. It prefers clustering the 10 homes on eight acres and leaving the extra 12 acres wild.
The Concklins say they cannot afford to cluster, that the developer will pay them half as much if they do. ''We're trying to maximize our profit to retain the most farmland,'' Richard Concklin said. The town Supervisor, Herbert Reisman, says two-acre wooded lots provide plenty of open space.
In late 1988 West Branch sued, charging that the Concklins had failed to file a mandated environmental impact study. And there it has sat for 17 months with no court decision yet, the Concklins prevented from selling the land and two weeks to foreclosure.
It's a terrible game of chicken. The Concklins seem to be winning far more hearts, but it may not matter. The Rockland County Legislature passed a motion 18 to 2 asking West Branch to withdraw its suit. West Branch has in the past enjoyed considerable popularity for preserving 600 acres. This time, many members have deserted to the Concklins, saying the difference between a clustered plan and two-acre lots is not worth destroying a rarer species, a family farm. ''Environmentalism gone bananas,'' said a West Branch deserter, Arthur Wang. A civil rights lawyer, Conrad Lynn, has volunteered time to the Concklins. ''They are conservative; I represent the left, but I see a human issue. Are you telling me two-acre lots menace the environment?''
Since the suit was filed the Concklins' debt has grown by $225,000 in added interest. Another West Branch deserter, John Holmes, says the Concklins' problem is that they were not cynical enough. He says most developers would conduct a token impact statement justifying two-acre zoning. ''The real-estate market gets softer by the day,'' Mr. Holmes said. ''West Branch figures the longer the suit goes the more concessions it gets. If the farm's foreclosed, it will go to a developer to cut up any way he pleases.''
A lot of the anger has focused on Martus Granirer, West Branch's president, who has stood firm. He acknowledges that the law mandating impact statements is weak and developers often get away with tokenism. ''If they had filed one,'' he said, ''we'd be boxed in now. But they didn't.''
''We're really looking for a better plan,'' he said. He believes the Concklins intend to keep farming but asks what happens in a few years if they face problems and decide to sell out. He says there should be a clustering plan for all 100 acres. He says he doesn't want them to lose the farm - ''We care about this farm'' - but if there is a foreclosure people shouldn't think a big developer would mean environmental disaster. ''Because of what we've done here, I think a developer would deal with us.''
Mr. Granirer says the Concklins should have pressed the county for a grant to preserve the farm. County leaders say they face budget cuts. Mr. Granirer wanted the American Farmland Trust to donate money to perserve the farm. Robert Wagner of the trust says that funds are limited and that he believes the Concklins' plan is good. He found West Branch ''unsympathetic and unrealistic.''
The Concklins pursued these tacks at Mr. Granirer's urging, though it galled them. ''We don't want special consideration,'' Mr. Concklin said. ''We're not that type of person. We're realists. To ask for money for something we can achieve by doing a responsible development does not make economic sense.'' His sister, Linda, says: ''We've farmed the same land 250 years. It's not worn out; it's not abused. We've kept it sweet. We think we understand our land.''
Two weeks to foreclosure.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 22, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
The Our Towns column on May 18, about efforts to save a farm in Ramapo, N.Y., misstated the role of a local group, the West Branch Conservation Association, in seeking the aid of the American Farmland Trust. The head of West Branch, Martus Granirer, proposed that the trust help the farm's owners obtain Federal relief under the 1985 farm bill; he did not ask it to donate money. (Mr. Granirer reported the error soon after publication, but some authorities involved were not available promptly to resolve conflicting accounts of the preservation effort.)

HEADLINE: Paulette Goddard Left N.Y.U. $20 Million

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
The actress Paulette Goddard has left more than $20 million to New York University to establish scholarships, endowed professorships and a development fund for junior faculty members, the school's president announced yesterday.
The president, Dr. John Brademas, said the gift from Miss Goddard, who died last month, was the largest bequest and the third largest gift in the history of the university and culminates more than a decade of donations from her.
''There is a harmony between this bequest and what we are now doing and hope to do academically at N.Y.U.'' Dr. Brademas said. ''It will enable us to build on the major commitments of N.Y.U.: performing arts, public service and European studies.'' 
Dr. Brademas announced the bequest during the university's 158th commencement exercises in Washington Square Park, where more than 7,000 students, clad in purple gowns, and as many parents and friends defied grim overcast skies, filling the park and overflowing into the streets and nearby buildings, where television monitors had been set up.
The university awarded five honorary degrees, the first of which was presented to Johnnetta B. Cole, president of Spelman College in Atlanta. Later, responding on behalf of the others, all of whom were men, she said, ''Let us mark the day a woman is speaking for all of the men,'' prompting a round of applause. Then she challenged the students receiving undergraduate, graduate and professional degrees to ''think, feel and act in terms of our interdependence.'' She welcomed the freedom in Eastern Europe as an example of how human needs and dreams are intimately tied together. ''In the spirit of an African saying,'' she said, '' 'I am because we are. We are because I am.' ''
Besides Dr. Cole, honorary degrees were conferred upon Placido Domingo, the operatic tenor, for ''a searching intellect and reservoirs of energy that have taken you where few other singers have dared to go;'' Thomas H. Kean, former governor of New Jersey and president of Drew University in Madison, N.J., for demonstrating ''the precepts of good government based on broad support cutting across ethnic and racial lines;'' Roald Zinnurovich Sagdeyev, a physicist, for dedication ''to the pursuit of scientific knowledge to expand human horizons to the edge of the universe,'' and Elie Wiesel, the nobel laureate and author, as an ''impassioned advocate for persecuted people throughout the world.''
The students cheered the announcement of Ms. Goddard's gift. Dr. Brademas said that an initial pledge of $13.4 million was made by Ms. Goddard in 1984, but that it was to remain anonymous until after her death. Ms. Goddard, famous for performances in classics like Charlie Chaplin's ''Modern Times'' and ''The Great Dictator'' and Jean Renoir's ''The Diary of a Chambermaid,'' died April 23. She left her entire estate to the university, Dr. Brademas said, which included $7 million more than her initial pledge, bringing the gift to more than $20 million.
Although not an alumna of N.Y.U., Dr. Brademas said that the actress was a longtime friend of the university and that her interests in theater, film, dance, art and literature motivated her contributions. In 1977, Ms. Goddard created a $3 million scholarship fund for students at the Tisch School of the Arts, which has provided more than 300 students with scholarships in the past 12 years. In 1984, Ms. Goddard presented N.Y.U. with the collected writings of her husband, Erich Maria Remarque, author of ''All Quiet on the Western Front.''
''She wanted her money to be used for people, as distinguished from buildings,'' Dr. Brademas said. Her gift will establish seven endowed chairs: a film chair in the Tisch School, an urban planning chair and chairs in creative writing, literature, European studies, languages and political economics. The bequest also creates a $3 million junior faculty fund, providing stipends for research, publications and travel.
 
Naming a Residence Hall for Her
The largest single gift to N.Y.U., for $31.2 million, was made in 1988 by Leonard Stern, a 1957 and 1959 graduate. It is being used to relocate and expand the business school.
The largest gift to a single institution is believed to be $105 million to Emory University in Atlanta from Robert W. Woodruff, the former chairman of the Coca-Cola Company. Less than two weeks ago, Yale University received $20 million from the Bass family of Fort Worth to establish an institute of biospheric studies.
Other recent large gifts include $25 million pledged to Columbia University in 1987 by John W. Kluge, the founder of the Metromedia Company, and $20 million to Spelman College in 1988 by the comedian Bill Cosby.
Dr. Brademas said the university would name one of its Washington Square residence halls in Ms. Goddard's honor. ''She was a woman who, at the age of most of you, was much like many of you: young, brainy, adventurous, full of spunk,'' Dr. Brademas said. ''She was determined to take on the world and she did.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Graduates filled Washington Square Park yesterday as New York University held its 158th commencement. (Neal Boenzi/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Spending Cap Seen as Last Hurdle to Adopting a Budget in Albany

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 17

 BODY:
With virtually all of their differences over this year's spending resolved, lawmakers today continued to wrangle over the state budget because of Republican demands for a spending cap that would not take effect until next year.
''The spending cap is really the last issue,'' said a spokesman for the State Senate's Republican majority, John McArdle.
The issue of a spending cap is perennial in Albany, where the urge to overspend is almost irrepressible. The issue is viewed as largely symbolic. Even lawmakers acknowledge that the cap has not yet been invented that the New York State Legislature could not slip past. 
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has long advocated a spending cap, but his proposal differs substantially from that of the Republican-controlled State Senate. The Governor said today that he did not believe the spending cap should hold up the budget, which is now almost seven weeks overdue.
 
'Hold the Whole Budget Hostage'
''What they're saying is we're going to hold the whole budget hostage until you give us what we want,'' he said.
Under the cap proposed by the Senate, the growth in state spending each year would be limited to the average growth in personal income over the previous three years, or to the prior year's inflation rate, whichever was lower. The cap could be lifted if the Legislature declared a ''financial emergency,'' defined as an ''extraordinary occurrence.''
Republican senators say a spending cap is the only way to cure the state of its habitual spending problems. But members of the Democratic-led Assembly say a cap would worsen the state's problems in hard times and make little difference in good times.
Democrats accused Senate Republicans today of trying to use the spending cap to bolster their image as fiscal conservatives. That image has been badly tarnished during the last several months, as the Senate agreed to almost $1.4 billion in new taxes.
 
'Deliberate Process of Stall'
''They want a spending cap so they can say they reduced spending while they're raising it,'' Mr. Cuomo said.
Some Democratic lawmakers suggested today that the reason the Senate was holding out for a spending cap was that the majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I., has not been able to muster enough votes to pass some of the more unpopular budget bills, like the $1.4 billion tax package agreed to earlier this week.
''I think there has been almost a deliberate process of stall here,'' the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, said at a news conference. ''Is it the game of hostage or is it the game of there's no votes to pass the tax package?''
Mr. McArdle denied that the Senate lacked the votes to pass the tax package. ''They say that every year,'' he said. ''We'll have the votes.''
After an all-night debate, the Assembly approved the tax measure early this morning. No vote has been scheduled in the Senate. Many Republican senators have said they are unhappy with the package, which raises taxes on goods ranging from liquor to rental cars, but not one has said publicly that he would not vote for it.

HEADLINE: Teacher Who Broke Boycott Seeks a Transfer

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
The Brooklyn teacher who led his high school class into a Korean-owned grocery store to protest a boycott there requested a transfer from his school yesterday, saying his life and the lives of his family have been threatened.
James S. Vlasto, press secretary for the Board of Education, said that Fred McCray, a 40-year-old economics teacher, notified officials yesterday ''that he is endangered if he remains at Erasmus Hall High School and he has asked to be reassigned.''
Mr. McCray was not in school yesterday and was described by officials of his union, the United Federation of Teachers, as incommunicado. 
On Monday, Mr. McCray and 30 of his students walked four blocks from Erasmus on Flatbush Avenue to the Family Red Apple market, which has been the scene of a four-month boycott, and bought some food. The students and Mr. McCray, who is black, were harangued by the protesters, who are also black. The boycott began after a dispute between a Haitian customer and a store employee.
 
Meeting With Parents
Susan Amlung, a spokeswoman for the teachers union, said Mr. McCray attended a meeting of the executive board of the high school parents association Wednesday night, then told union officials afterward that he had been asked by parents to resign.
''He says that the parents who are demanding his resignation are tools of Sonny Carson,'' said Ms. Amlung, referring to the community organizer who was instrumental in starting the boycott. ''There are plenty of parents who support him but they have told him they dare not speak up.'' Mr. Carson held a rally at Erasmus the same night, Ms. Amlung said.
Another union official said the school's principal, Stanley Saretsky, disputed Mr. McCray's account of the meeting with parents. But Mr. Saretsky has reported receiving 20 telephone calls assailing Mr. McCray's actions, some including death threats, Ms. Amlung said. Mr. Saretsky could not be reached yesterday.
 
Revealing His Past
In an appearance on ''The Joan Rivers Show'' on CBS yesterday, Mr. McCray said some parents had threatened to reveal his past as a drug addict and convict to ''discredit me with the students, with the press.'' Crying at one point, Mr. McCray told Ms. Rivers that after receiving an honorable discharge from the Army, he had become a drug addict and ''committed some crimes.'' He said he had been sentenced to up to life in prison at Elmira state prison, but did not say what he was convicted for or how long he was in prison.
School officials declined to disclose details of Mr. McCray's background. They said he disclosed his criminal record when he joined the school system in 1980, and was permitted to teach after a review. Mr. McCray received a bachelor's degree from Cornell University and is pursuing a doctorate at New York University.

HEADLINE: Character Actors Are Taking a Star Turn

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW

 BODY:
IN his book ''On Acting,'' Laurence Olivier expressed his admiration for John Gielgud, with direct reference not to his Shakespearean performances but to his stage roles in plays by Harold Pinter and David Storey. ''Today, for me, John has somehow completed the acting circle,'' he wrote. ''He has found his center, he is a brilliant character actor.''
From Olivier, that must be taken as the highest compliment. In Britain, the art of the character actor is an honored tradition. Actors have often made careers by not playing leading roles, or by playing leading roles as if they are character parts. (Olivier qualifies in that latter category.) In the United States, however, the character actor has sometimes been regarded as a lesser artist, the theatrical equivalent of baseball's relief pitcher. If he had his choice, he would prefer to be a starter - or star. This is in spite of the fact that many of America's most celebrated performers (like Spencer Tracy and James Cagney) have been character actors as well as stars. Because of the work of Dustin Hoffman, Robert De Niro and Robert Duvall, among others, that perception has been altered. Now, many people, here as in Britain, are flattered to be considered character actors. 
There have always been outstanding performances by character actors in the New York theater, many of them given by Philip Bosco, who, as a kind of one-man repertory company, has proven that an actor can have a full, gratifying career on the New York stage. Mr. Bosco is not appearing in a play at this moment - a most unusual absence. But this season has been particularly active for character actors, beginning with Mr. Hoffman, who returned to Broadway as Shylock last December, and extending through a number of current productions. This weekend theatergoers may see the following:
* Josef Sommer as Polonius in ''Hamlet.''
* Larry Bryggman in ''Prelude to a Kiss.''
* Nathan Lane in ''Some Americans Abroad.''
* Charles S. Dutton and S. Epatha Merkerson in ''The Piano Lesson.''
* Danitra Vance in ''Spunk.''
* Gary Sinise and Terry Kinney in ''The Grapes of Wrath.''
* Charles Durning in ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.''
* Stephen Lang in ''A Few Good Men.''
Though the styles of acting and the kinds of roles vary widely, these actors and actresses are united by the fact that they immerse themselves within a character - a kind of artistic self-effacement. This is not to suggest that they lose their individuality, but through an exercise of a chameleonlike talent, they can change markedly from role to role. This is the opposite of a star appearance by a performer who has made an impact (usually on a television series or in the movies) and continues to play a variation of that persona.
The difference between a leading man or leading lady and a character actor can seem arbitrary. Any principal role, beginning with Hamlet, could be approached as a character part, but some performances are more richly charactered than others. An actor can bring distinction to the smallest of roles. Character actors are created partly through choice, partly through opportunity. Sometimes an actor's visage can limit his possibilities in romantic parts; conversely, good looks may make it difficult for audiences to accept him in character roles.
Olivier accomplished his transformations with the help of makeup and accents. He often said that in playing a character, he began by choosing a specific false nose. Alec Guinness is another English master of what could be called the cosmetics of character acting, although in both of their cases the personification has always been penetrating.
In the United States, there are actors like Josef Sommer, who seldom changes his appearance or his accent (even when playing a foreigner), yet manages to incarnate a diversity of human traits - heroic, villainous and everything in between. Although he has had a distinguished career, he is still not known by name to the general public; his relative anonymity is itself a tribute to his versatility.
Mr. Sommer has had leading roles onstage in New York as well as in regional theater. (He was, most memorably, the Soviet diplomat in the original Yale Repertory Theater production of ''A Walk in the Woods.'') Often he is one in an ensemble, as is the case in Kevin Kline's production of ''Hamlet.'' Mr. Sommer approaches the often-ridiculed figure of Polonius as a sincere, though still obsequious, father and counselor -not, as is often the case, as a buffoon who cannot tell a cloud from a whale.
In that sense, he reminds one somewhat of other character actors who have preceded him in the role, people like Hume Cronyn, who was Polonius in Richard Burton's Broadway ''Hamlet,'' and Michael Bryant, who played Polonius in Daniel Day-Lewis's recent ''Hamlet'' at the National Theater in London.
Mr. Kline's production at the Public Theater is very much an actor's ''Hamlet,'' one might say, a character actor's ''Hamlet,'' with Mr. Kline as the leading character actor in residence. As director, he has surrounded himself with performers of his choice and led them to concentrate on diction, clarity and details of character while de-emphasizing matters of directorial concept and design.
Larry Bryggman, an exacting professional in scores of plays on the New York stage, can do more with a cameo than many of his peers can do with a major role. Such is certainly the case in ''Prelude to a Kiss,'' in which he plays the father of the bride with a knowing look of laissez faire -if this is what his daughter wants to do, he will not impose his will. Lane's Triple-Header Nathan Lane, an actor with the most expressive eyebrows on the New York stage, deserves this year's Philip Bosco Award for three fine performances in a single season. Without a break, he moved from his bravura performance in ''The Lisbon Traviata'' to two nutty roles (as doctor and patient) in the revival of ''Bad Habits'' to ''Some Americans Abroad,'' in which he plays a teacher about to be relieved of his position at a New England college.
Usually cast in flamboyant roles, Mr. Lane can be an actor of great subtlety, as he demonstrates in ''Some Americans Abroad,'' where his overeagerness to please his employers moves the audience to empathy. From his first Broadway performance, in George C. Scott's production of ''Present Laughter,'' he has been a devastatingly funny actor. Increasingly he has been revealing the breadth of his talent. Were there a lively classical theater in this country, he might next move on to Shakespearean clowns and Restoration comedy. Egos and Ensembles Charles S. Dutton is a dynamic force who can, as Boy Willie in August Wilson's ''Piano Lesson,'' overwhelm others when he is onstage. But that heightened quality of acting is demanded by the role, which is meant to energize the conflict between Boy Willie and his sister, Berniece. In contrast, in Mr. Wilson's ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' he was indelibly part of an ensemble.
In performance, he can display the most sizable of egos and emotions, which is why he was such a striking Othello several seasons ago at the Yale Repertory Theater. As with Mr. Lane, he could have - if opportunity presented itself - a future in classics.
Berniece, his antagonist in ''The Piano Lesson,'' is played by S. Epatha Merkerson, who lends a quiet resilience to her role as a woman who chooses the perpetuation of a family legacy (the piano of the title) over economic advancement. Until now, Ms. Merkerson has been a figure in the background, as in ''Moms,'' in which she added luster to her role as a faithful aide to Clarice Taylor's Moms Mabley. ''The Piano Lesson'' offers signs of her ability to dominate a stage.
In contrast to Ms. Merkerson's reserve, there is Danitra Vance's ebullience, as demonstrated in her performance as three different Zora Neale Hurston women in George Wolfe's ''Spunk'' and, several seasons ago, in Mr. Wolfe's ''Colored Museum.'' Appearing on stage, she has a cheerful effect on theatergoers; then her acting validates the anticipation.
The Steppenwolf Theater Company has redefined character acting in its own image. This troupe achieved its reputation for visceral performances in works by Sam Shepard, Lanford Wilson and others. But there is another, understated dimension to Steppenwolf acting, as is demonstrated in ''The Grapes of Wrath'' and, in particular, by the performances of Gary Sinise and Terry Kinney. Their roles as Tom Joad and Jim Casy, the preacher, are, of course, pivotal, but in the hands of these astute actors, they are integrated into the symphonic whole. Durning's Domain Before becoming known for his film roles, Charles Durning had a long, rewarding career in the New York theater, much of it spent at the New York Shakespeare Festival. Admiration increases when one considers the range of his roles - from the inept mayor in ''That Championship Season'' to his authoritative Big Daddy in the current production of ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.''
Big Daddy is certainly the most colorful character in ''Cat,'' although he is onstage for only one act. With his usual circumspection, Mr. Durning avoids overplaying his hand, becoming a powerful presence through a kind of actor's right of eminent domain.
Mr. Durning and Mr. Dutton, among others, have been deservedly nominated for Tony Awards. (The winners will be announced on June 3.) The one major oversight in the acting categories was the omission of Stephen Lang. As the autocratic Marine colonel in ''A Few Good Men,'' he is a loose cannon about to implode. In the play, the actor offers an object lesson in stage menace, intimating violence without activating it. This colonel is a 180-degree turn from his last Broadway appearance as Happy, the cheerfully sybaritic younger brother in ''Death of a Salesman,'' starring Dustin Hoffman.
For many actors, Mr. Lang included, Mr. Hoffman could be a role model. He began his career on stage playing the most diverse range of unusual characters, conquered Hollywood as a character juvenile and went on to play everything from the ancient ''Little Big Man'' to a woman, herself a character actress. At the outset of his career, he expressed his desire to be the world's first character lover. He has achieved that goal - and a great deal more, proving that, talent permitting, there are no limits to the roles of a character actor.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Still in New Orleans And Singing the Blues

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
''Further Mo,' '' Vernel Bagneris's rollicking sequel to his successful 1979 blues and jazz revue, ''One Mo' Time,'' returns to the original show's seedy stomping grounds, the Lyric Theater of New Orleans, to catch up with its four vaudevillian troupers. It is a year later (1927), and bawdy blues songs are still the specialty of the house.
Like its forerunner, the sequel offers lusty performances of vintage blues, jazz and popular tunes arranged in a modified Dixieland style for a small jazz ensemble. While the program's high points are its hilariously salacious numbers like ''One-Hour Mama'' and ''Positively No (Construction Gang),'' its two dozen songs offer a fairly wide cross section of styles from torch (''My Man'') to jazz (''Alabamy Bound''). 
Two cast members of ''One Mo' Time'' - Mr. Bagneris and Topsy Chapman - again portray their characters (Papa Du and Thelma) from the original show. The sequel opened last night, downstairs at the Village Gate, where the original show had also opened. As the loose-limbed vaudeville singer and dancer who juggles relationships with two women, Mr. Bagneris has only a passable singing voice, but he dances superbly and projects a cool devil-may-care charisma. Using a minimum of fancy footwork, he slinks around the stage with a grace so airy in its confidence that at moments he almost seems to be floating.
Ms. Chapman is a versatile pop-blues stylist whose singing suggests a bluesier Nancy Wilson. Frozine Thomas, who plays Ma Reed, the least flamboyant of the four, has a smooth gutbucket blues delivery that contrasts with the more raucous style of the show's most vivid character, Big Bertha.
The role of the huffy blues diva, which was originally played by Sylvia (Kuumba) Williams, has been taken over in the sequel by Sandra Reaves-Phillips, who with her earthy roar seems ideally cast. In ''Further Mo,' '' the character, who has just returned from a European tour, flounces about the stage fantasizing about imminent stardom in the movies.
In ''One Mo' Time,'' Mr. Bagneris, who conceived, wrote and directed both shows, took a standard nostalgia-revue format and gave it a mild political twist by following its four black vaudevillians backstage. Without seriously dampening the high spirits, he was able to suggest how even in a town as relaxed as New Orleans in the 1920's, blacks were exploited and restricted. And this double vision of euphoric hijinks on the stage and the exploitation and bickering behind the scenes gave the music a historical dimension.
The sequel also insinuates racial politics into the raunchy fun. Early in the evening the Lyric's white owner, played by James (Red) Wilcher, confides to Papa Du that after that evening's performance, the theater, which has not been profitable, will be burned to the ground for the insurance money. The performers will be out of work, and the closest city with a comparable vaudeville house is Mobile, Ala. Though warned in advance of the fire so they can remove their costumes and other belongings, the performers are afraid to leave the theater loaded with baggage lest they be arrested for theft.
Because ''Further Mo' '' crams its story into the nooks and crannies between numbers, its little backstage dramas remain undeveloped, and much remains unclear. In the most enigmatic scene, the theater owner disguises himself in drag to go on an unexplained mission in behalf of his soon-to-be-unemployed troupe.
Although the drama fizzles, the music sails. The singers' voices are well matched, and the five-member New Orleans Blue Serenaders play with verve and fluency. Pepsi Bethel's undemanding choreography gives the show an easygoing lilt without taxing the performers. For those who insist on high-style virtuosity, the show to see for this sort of thing is ''Black and Blue'' on Broadway. ''Further Mo,' '' though not as ambitious as its uptown cousin, still offers plenty of hot music, steamy atmosphere and lowdown fun.

HEADLINE: Treasuries Drop After Fed Signal

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board sent a strong signal that it has not eased monetary policy.
Speculation that the central bank's Open Market Committee might have voted to ease its grip on credit at Tuesday's meeting was raised late Wednesday, when the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market dipped slightly.
The funds rate, the rate most closely controlled by the Fed, was trading at 8 1/8 percent late Wednesday, and remained at that level during morning trading yesterday.
 
Fed Drains Reserves
 The softness in the funds rate prompted dealers to buy securities early in the session. But just before noon the Fed quashed any notion that it had eased policy when it entered the open market to drain reserves from the banking system. 
The funds rate, which had been trading at 8 1/8 percent at the time of the Fed's move, quickly returned to the 8 1/4 percent level it has occupied since mid-December.
The speculative buying took most analysts and traders by surprise, since Wall Street appears firmly convinced that current economic conditions make it highly unlikely the Fed will change policy for some time yet.
''The fact that the Fed came into the market was not as interesting an event as the fact that there were some people who actually thought the Fed had eased,'' one government bond trader said. ''At the earliest, the Fed won't move until it gets a look at the May employment data at the beginning of June.''
Any lingering doubt about the intent of the Fed's action was erased after remarks by Edward G. Boehme, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, flashed across dealers' screens.
In a speech yesterday, Mr. Boehme said that the Fed has not changed policy since December.
''If you couldn't read between the lines earlier, Mr. Boehme's remarks put it in black and white for the market,'' said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. ''We have had a long period when the funds rate has been very stable, and it looks like that period is going to last for a while longer.''
The speculative activity surrounding the Fed's move was the only real focal point yesterday, dealers said.
 
Jump in Trade Deficit
 A big jump in the merchandise trade deficit, which rose to $8.4 billion in March, had little impact on prices. While the composition of the figures was something of a surprise, most economists had projected a widening in the deficit.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 101 1/8, down 6/32, to yield 8.64 percent. Late Wednesday the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.63 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 101 9/32, down 1/8 point, to yield 8.68 percent. And the 8 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 19/32, down 2/32, to yield 8.53 percent.
''Right now we are in a counter-trading market,'' the bond trader said. ''That means you buy on the dips and sell on the upticks. It will probably be that until we get through the employment number.''
Meanwhile, short-term Treasury bill rates rose modestly.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 7.67 percent, up three basis points, or hundreths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were offered in late trading at 7.68 percent, up five basis points. And one-year bill rates rose by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.64 percent.
 
Continued Flow of New Issues
 New issues continued to flow into the investment-grade corporate bond market.
Among the deals priced yesterday was a $150 million offering of 20-year debentures from Dow Capital B.V.
The 9 percent debentures, which mature May 15, 2010, carry a ''put'' that is exercisable on May 15, 1995. The securities were priced at $99.870, to yield 9.032 percent, 42 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/2 percent five year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
Nassau County, L.I., offered $71 million of insured serial bonds at competitive bid in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
The issue, which is insured by Ambac Inc., consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1991 to 2009. Coupons on the bonds range from 6 percent on bonds maturing in 1991 to 7.10 percent on securities that mature in 2009.
A bid from an investment group led by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. won the issue, which is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Services and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Activity in the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt bonds was light, dealers said. Traders in both markets said that prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended May 7. The narrowest measure, M-1, fell by $200 million.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Widened In March

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit widened substantially in March, to $8.4 billion, as exports and imports both surged, the Commerce Department reported today.
Although the deficit in international trade - the amount by which purchases from abroad exceed goods sold to foreign customers - rose somewhat more than expected, economists and the financial markets took the news in stride.
The March deficit was not out of line with most other recent months and was lower than the $8.9 billion of March 1989. But this year's March performance followed a sharp narrowing of the deficit in February, when the trade gap was the lowest in more than six years. The February plunge resulted from a steep drop in spending on imports, and few experts expected that to be repeated. 
 
Exports at Record Level
 Imports in March rebounded by 10 percent, to a level just short of the peak reached last October. Exports rose to a record $33.3 billion, or 4.6 percent above the February level. That rise was hailed by some analysts who have been counting on foreign orders to help sustain American economic growth.
''The thing is the exports, which means that we continue to see growth from the external side,'' said Rimmer de Vries, chief economist for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
Others, however, were a bit more wary, noting that the trade figures were for March, not April, and that more recent statistics appeared to belie a pickup in the industrial sector. Manufactured goods account for some 80 percent of exports.
''I wouldn't regard it as a sign that the economy is recovering,'' said Christopher S. Rupkey, an economist at Mitsubishi Bank in New York.
 
Assessing the Dollar's Drop
 As for imports, analysts tended to agree that their growth would probably start to ease, and for two reasons. The dollar has recently been weakening in value, which reduces American purchasing power, and Japan and some other trading partners are trying to reduce their surpluses with the United States.
Nevertheless, today's report said the American deficit with Japan bounced back to $3.6 billion in March, from $3.1 billion. The deficit with South Korea did shrink significantly and there were slight reductions in the gaps with Taiwan and Singapore.
For the first three months of the year, the cumulative deficit was $23.9 billion, down from $26.4 billion in the comparable 1989 period and $30.9 billion in the 1988 period.
The improvement is not an unmixed blessing. With fewer dollars going abroad to pay for imports, foreign investors are less able to help finance the United States' budget deficit. This increases the demand on the domestic savings pool and adds to upward pressure on interest rates, with higher rates perhaps choking off economic growth. Some analysts said concerns about this possible chain of events helped prompt the Bush Administration to seek the budget talks with Congressional leaders that began this week.
 
Both Sides of Ledger
 The rise in March exports was $1.5 billion, to $33.3 billion, surpassing the previous high of $31.9 billion posted in January. The increase in imports was $3.8 billion, to $41.7 billion, supplanting January's $41.3 billion as the second-highest level after October's $41.9 billion.
The February deficit, which had initially been reported at $6.5 billion, was revised even lower today, to $6.1 billion. The nation's spending on imports, particularly oil, fell sharply that month, while exports were basically unchanged. Oil prices had surged in January because of extreme cold early in the winter.
Motor vehicles, parts and engines had the biggest impact on both sides of the ledger in March, raising imports by $1.5 billion and exports by $600 million. Imports of Japanese cars rebounded to $1.8 billion, from $1.5 billion in February. Exports of aircraft declined after a surge of deliveries related to the end of last fall's strike at the Boeing Company.
Spending for imported oil remained at $4.7 billion in March, as the effect of bringing in an additional 18 million barrels that month was offset by an average price decline of $1.21 for each imported barrel. Oil accounted for 56 percent of the March trade deficit, down from February's extraordinarily high 77 percent. Because imports in general, including oil, fell in February, the huge oil component made up a large part of a shrunken category.
 
Regional Variations
 The overall March deficit with Western Europe edged down to $714 million, from $960 million. The deficit with West Germany widened by $110 million, but a surplus with Britain expanded by $185 million. The deficit with Canada, the nation's biggest trading partner, eased to $90 million from $227 million.
In terms of goods traded, two of the biggest surpluses for the United States in March were $3.6 billion in advanced-technology products and $1.8 billion in farm commodities.
Measured on a three-month moving average, the overall trade deficit was calculated at $8 billion for March, in between the $7.7 billion of February and the $9 billion of January.
In constant 1987 dollars, the deficit for the month was $7.9 billion, compared with $5.5 billion in February.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
German Worries On Unification

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
The stunning defeat of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union by the Social Democratic Party in two key West German states reflected voters' anxieties that unification with East Germany will cost them heavily. Mr. Kohl is now moving to head off a buildup of political pressures that could disrupt unification.
There are also anxieties in the markets and industry that economic and monetary union could unleash inflation and undermine the remarkable stability and prosperity that have made West Germany the strongest economy in Europe.
The official Government line is that such inflationary fears are misplaced because German monetary growth has been low and will continue to be so under the control of the independent Bundesbank. Further, say the reassuring voices in Bonn, East Germany's economy is small, only 10 percent the size of West Germany's, and the tail cannot wag the dog. Indeed, they add, low-paid East German workers are likely to put downward pressure on West German wages, and troop reductions in both East and West Germany will hold down wages and economic activity. 
But anxieties persist in West Germany that the party line pressing for early unification is rose-colored - and election-colored. Many in the West believe the currency conversion deal offered to East Germany by the Kohl Government is too generous, with the feeble East marks to be converted at a 1-to-1 rate for the strong West marks for wages and at a 2-to-1 rate for cash and savings up to 6,000 marks.
Dr. Wilfrid Guth, chairman of the supervisory board of the Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest bank, said in a speech in New York on May 8 that the 1-to-1 conversion rate for wages ''puts great responsibility on those who will negotiate new contracts since this rate leaves no room for wage increases to compensate for the upward adjustment of the heavily subsidized prices of food and other essentials.''
Dr. Guth said it was important to note that monetary control and monetary stability in the enlarged D-mark area would be ''the exclusive responsibility of the Bundesbank, which has endorsed the agreement between the two Governments.''
After earlier resistance because of his own concerns about inflation, the president of the Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, accepted the Government's conversion deal. But he has privately continued to express his concerns about inflation stemming from the East.
The Bundesbank is not yet in control of the money supply in East Germany, and the German Democratic Republic's central bank is printing an extra 5 billion East marks a month, according to West German officials. At the official rates of exchange, that means a continuing rapid growth of the unified German money supply. That is another reason why the West Germans would like to bring about economic and monetary union as soon as possible.
In his speech to the American Council on Germany in New York, Dr. Guth said that currency conversion by itself was not the decisive issue but should be seen in a much wider context. ''Of much greater significance,'' he said, ''will be that a new entrepreneurial spirit and dynamism emerges and everything will be done to make the G.D.R. an attractive location for investment. We are already seeing many approaches by West German companies, and there are plenty of concrete plans.''
The crucial contribution toward revitalizing the East German economy, he said, would come from ''our business sector and from companies of other Western nations.'' East Germany, he added, ''is not a privileged territory for West German firms.''
Nevertheless, the costs to the West German Government of unification, even beyond the currency conversion, will be huge. This week West Germany announced a plan to set up a ''German unity fund'' of $70 billion, to help pay for the reconstruction of East Germany's economy through 1994. Other Eastern European countries are going to worry that a disproportionately large share of private and public West German capital will be flowing into East Germany, to their own disadvantage.
To avoid intensifying unification anxieties, Chancellor Kohl has said that there will be no tax increase and that the new unity fund will be kept off budget. The money is to be borrowed in capital markets, with half to be raised by the federal Government and half by the states. But given the electoral defeats the Christian Democrats encountered in the elections in North-Rhine Westphalia and Lower Saxony, there could be foot-dragging in those states and possibly others.
Mr. Kohl may also encounter resistance to swift unification from East Germany. Indeed, East Germany's Christian Union Prime Minister, Lothar de Maiziere, is resisting Mr. Kohl's suggestion that all-German elections could be held as early as December. Rising unemployment, which could get worse as state-mismanaged companies shut down, and rising prices, as East Germany shifts to a market economy, could throw an election to the opponents of capitalism on the West German model.
Worried that the political situation could deteriorate as time wears on, Mr. Kohl and his supporters have a new battle cry: ''Now or never!''

HEADLINE: Problem Real Estate Loans Rise Sharply at First Fidelity

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The First Fidelity Bancorporation in Lawrenceville, N.J., the 20th-largest banking company in the country, announced a sharp rise in problem real estate loans yesterday. Analysts expect the problems to result in a large loss for the second quarter.
The company's problems with real estate loans and other borrowers were not a surprise. Despite the financial setback, which includes a cut in its quarterly dividend to 30 cents a share, from 50 cents, First Fidelity's stock rose sharply yesterday after the announcement, closing at $19.50, up $1.875, in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. 
Analysts said that the loss would not be as great as feared, and that by recognizing it now, the company's new management could move forward with a cost-cutting program that would improve profits.
On Wednesday, the company's shares traded at the lowest price of the year, reflecting investor anticipation of more losses upon completion of a review of its loans. Like many other banking companies in the Northeast, First Fidelity has been hurt by the slowdown in economic activity and a glut of unsold real estate projects built in the late 1980's.
 
Not 'Life-Threatening'
 ''Today's news is not a life-threatening event,'' said James Rosenberg, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. He said the problems were anticipated in the second quarter.
In March, the company announced a program to reduce its payroll by 1,400, or nearly 10 percent. The savings from payroll cuts, plus reductions in other expenses, are expected to save First Fidelity $95 million this year and about $115 million annually in future years.
Anthony P. Terraciano, First Fidelity's stern-faced chairman, came to the company in early February from the Mellon Bank Corporation, another banking company that fell on hard times but has recovered. He said First Fidelity should return to profitability in the second quarter, when the need to set aside reserves for bad loans would be much smaller.
As the company recovers from the second-quarter setback, Mr. Terraciano said he did not expect much growth, ''but I do expect a better mix of loans, with more lending to consumers.''
First Fidelity, which is New Jersey's largest banking company, said yesterday that it would add as much as $300 million to its reserves for loan losses. That amount, which is subtracted from income, is far greater than average quarterly profits of about $64 million the company earned in the first half of last year.
The additional reserves were needed, the company said, because the weaker economy in New Jersey has increased the likelihood of losses on many loans. It said nonperforming loans - those that are not paying interest or that are clearly in trouble - could rise by as much as 40 percent, or $240 million, from the March 31 level of $604 million.
''Accepting a large loss now is a pre-emptive action that puts the company ahead of any rigorous examination by the regulators,'' James McDermott, the head of research at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., a securities firm specializing in banking companies. ''Unless the New Jersey economy turns significantly weaker, they have recognized most of the credit problems.''
 
Plagued by Slow Economy
 Since First Fidelity was created in 1988 in a merger of banking companies in Newark and Philadelphia, it has been plagued by softness in its local economy and falling real estate prices. Those problems resulted in losses in the fourth quarters of 1988 and 1989, led to the departure of senior management and delayed a program of expense reductions expected from the merger.
Stocks of other large New Jersey-based banking companies have been weak in recent months, but they did not weaken appreciably yesterday in sympathy with First Fidelity. But analysts said that First Fidelity's real estate problems suggest that other New Jersey banks also face big troubles.

HEADLINE: Study on '89 By C.F.T.C.

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
A study by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has found no evidence of manipulation of stock index futures or intramarket trading activity that would have hastened the stock market plunge last October.
The report by the C.F.T.C.'s Division of Economic Analysis studied the relationship between the stock market and stock-index futures on Oct. 13, 16 and 24, days of significant stock market and index futures declines.
The report comes as the C.F.T.C. is fighting a move by the Treasury Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission to move stock-index futures regulation from the C.F.T.C. to the S.E.C. Those agencies contend that stock markets and the stock index futures markets based on them should be under one regulator.

HEADLINE: Milk Hormone Poses Health and Welfare Risks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your editorial ''Crying Wolf About Milk'' (May 1), opposing the banning of synthetic bovine growth hormone by Wisconsin and Minnesota, is misinformed and misleading.
You state that opposition to this genetically engineered animal drug, which is administered to dairy cattle to increase milk production, has two adversaries, the Foundation on Economic Trends and small farmers.
While the foundation has spearheaded opposition to bovine growth hormone, several of the country's leading farm, animal protection and environmental groups have also taken anti-BGH positions. These include the Humane Society of the United States, the National Farmers Union, the National Toxics Campaign and dozens of similar groups. Together they represent millions of Americans. You also neglect to mention that opposition to the drug is international and that there is a moratorium on its use in Europe. 
There is widespread opposition to bovine growth hormone because it is bad for the cow, bad for the farmer, bad for the taxpayer and potentially bad for the consumer. Independent studies by university scientists have determined that the drug causes significant health impacts on cattle and will drive large numbers of dairy farmers out of business. These claims are not disputed by the Food and Drug Administration, which has yet to approve the drug.
While you may believe that animal suffering and the destruction of the small dairy farmer are the price to be paid for ''new technology,'' Govs. Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin and Rudy Perpich of Minnesota are justifiably concerned about a product that could cause a flooding of the milk market, destroy farm communities, and cost their states tens of millions of dollars annually.
It's not just Wisconsin and Minnesota. In recent years, the Federal Government has spent more than one billion tax dollars to buy out dairy farmers and kill cows in a desperate attempt to hold down the level of milk production. Bovine growth hormone would undermine Federal policy by worsening the problem, and taxpayers would inevitably again be asked to pay for a new effort to cut milk production.
You recite chemical companies' claims that humans will suffer no adverse health effects from consuming dairy products containing the hormone. But researchers, including Dr. Samuel Epstein of the University of Illinois School of Public Health, warn of potentially significant adverse health effects, especially on infants. Although the F.D.A. has promised to respond, it has yet to release any scientific data proving the hormone's safety for human consumption.
Finally, you fail to mention the widely publicized testimony of whistleblowers inside the scandal-ridden F.D.A., who have said the agency has colluded with chemical companies to downplay the hormone's adverse health effects on cows and humans. These charges led Senator Patrick Leahy of Vermont to call for a General Accounting Office investigation, now under way.
Governors Thompson and Perpich are to be congratulated for enacting a moratorium on the hormone to study the health, welfare and safety risks it poses to their constituents. They understand well that technology should not control human choices, but that human choices need to control technology.
 
ANDREW KIMBRELL
Policy Director, Foundation on Economic Trends
 Washington, May 3, 1990

HEADLINE: Phase Out the Philippine Bases

 BODY:
If the Philippines truly doesn't want the United States to keep its bases there, the thing to do is simple: Leave. Maintaining a good relationship and avoiding rancor is more important to American security than holding on to the bases. But there's a better answer: Leave gradually. 
The two giant installations - the naval base at Subic Bay and the air base at Clark Field - remain important but are no longer critical. Just as the cold war is melting in Europe, there's a thaw in Asia and the Pacific. In the emerging Pacific world, American air and naval forces can be reduced and otherwise accommodated.
The Philippines recently served notice that it would terminate the current 25-year base pact when it expires in September 1991. The action was more a bargaining step for more aid than a threat. But it also reflected growing nationalist resentment of the old colonial relationship.
Even so, the U.S. presence has strongly supported Philippine as well as American security. And to operate the bases, the U.S. injects $1 billion a year into the Philippine economy, some 3 percent of its gross national product. This year, U.S. aid includes an additional $513 million, most of which is considered rent for the bases.
But many Filipinos also bridle at the U.S. presence, attributing the predatory dictatorship of Ferdinand Marcos to Washington's enduring power. Even President Corazon Aquino, a friend of the U.S., cannot envision an indefinite large-scale American presence.
There is a way to reconcile American bases with Philippine nationalism: gradualism. The two sides could agree now to phase out the bases by the end of the century. Such an arrangement would allow the Philippines time to make the necessary economic adjustments.
Meanwhile, the U.S. could arrange alternate bases in Japan, Guam, Hawaii or Singapore. Manila also could follow Singapore's example, commercialize the facilities and make private contracts with U.S. forces.
Whatever strategic value the two U.S. bases still possess would be more than negated if they come to poison the relationship between the two countries. Phasing out the bases gradually can meet everyone's needs.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Auctions' Big Spenders: The Japanese

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Japanese art buyers dominated the bidding for Impressionist and modern paintings this week at Christie's and Sotheby's auction houses in New York. The sales were high points of the spring auctions in New York.
In all, Japanese buyers acquired 23 of the 58 artworks sold at Sotheby's on Thursday night, paying $185.2 million in a sale that totaled $286.2 million, a record for any art sale. At Christie's on Tuesday night, Japanese bidders came away with 25 of the 57 works sold, paying $154.9 million in a sale that brought $268.4 million. 
When asked to assess the impact of Japanese buyers on the current market, Julian Agnew, a London dealer, said: ''At the moment they are the principal buyers and supporters. I think it is very similar to the Americans in the period of 1880 to 1914, and again in the 1920's.'' Societies that have experienced tremendous industrial growth generally want to enjoy their wealth, Mr. Agnew said, and buying art is one of the more desirable ways.
 
Art and Economics
Richard L. Feigen, a New York dealer, said: ''What is clear is there is no abatement of the influx of Japanese investment in the art market. This is now flight money - an escape from their stock market and real-estate market. There is volatility in the yen and vulnerability in the Japanese real-estate market. And the Japanese view art as an intrinsically valuable financial instrument, an idea that has been successfully propounded by the auction houses.
''The Japanese economy is in a state of flux, and Japanese art-buying is also in a state of flux: they are moving out of Impressionists and into the 20th century and into Old Masters.''
One Japanese industrialist, Ryoei Saito, established himself as perhaps the world's most flamboyant art-buyer by spending $160.6 million on two paintings. He paid a record $82.5 million for Vincent van Gogh's ''Portrait of Dr. Gachet,'' which was auctioned Tuesday night at Christie's, and $78.1 million for Pierre Auguste Renoir's outdoor cafe scene ''At the Moulin de la Galette'' on Thursday night at Sotheby's.
 
Dozens of New Buyers
After Sotheby's Thursday auction, at which 12 works of the 70 offered did not sell and 8 others brought prices below their presale estimates, Diana D. Brooks, president of Sotheby's North America, said the Japanese were responsible to a great degree for the results of this sale.
''They were active at all price levels in the sales over the last two weeks,'' she said. ''We had more Japanese in the salesroom than ever before - approximately 30 to 40 new Japanese buyers requested to be cleared before the sale. I would guess about half of them bought - not necessarily in any major way, but they bought something.
''A great many paintings that came to this country in the 1920's and 30's are now going out of this country -and many are going to Japan. Why? It's primarily because of the tax laws and the extraordinary appreciation in the values of works of art.''
Christopher Burge, president of Christie's in New York, said the figures for Japanese buying ''are obviously a bit swollen because of the two big pictures.'' More than just the huge amount of money was different at these sales, he said.
''You saw the Japanese bidding not only on pictures known as traditional Japanese taste in Renoir and Monet paintings, but also on top-quality 20th-century pictures,'' Mr. Burge said. ''The upward curve has flattened to some extent, but I don't think this is a downward curve.''
 
An Offstage Buyer
Hideto Kobayashi, the Tokyo dealer who bid for Mr. Saito at this week's sales, made additional purchases for Mr. Saito and other clients at Sotheby's on Thursday night and yesterday. Among them were Auguste Rodin's bronze ''Thinker,'' from 1880-81, for $1.2 million; Rodin's ''Burghers of Calais,'' six huge bronze figures, each about 80 inches or more in height, for $4.3 million; Paul Klee's watercolor of a theater from 1923, $1.3 million, and Tsuguharu Foujita's ''Girl With Cat'' from 1958, for $77,000.
Mr. Kobayashi never appeared in Sotheby's salesroom Thursday night. He and his party were secluded in a room above the auction floor, where Mr. Kobayashi relayed Mr. Saito's bids through Kazuko Shiumi of Sotheby's Tokyo office to Debra Hatch of the order-bid department, next to the auctioneer's rostrum. Before the sale ended, Mr. Kobayashi left the building through a side door.
Another Tokyo dealer, Kiyotaka Kori of the Gallery Aoyama in Tokyo, part of the Aska International Corporation, said he spent more than $30 million this week for the artworks he bought, mostly in the evening sales at Christie's and Sotheby's. Last November Mr. Kori bought $115 million worth of art in New York and London and acquired additional artworks worth $6.5 million at the New York sales of Habsburg, Feldman, a Geneva-based auction house.
As always, Mr. Kori bid this week from his seat in the auction room, a telephone in one hand and the bidding paddle in the other. Aska is a subsidiary of the Aichi Corporation, a Tokyo-based finance company headed by Yasumichi Morishita, which owns 6.4 percent of Christie's.
 
Renoirs Preferred
Mr. Kori spent about $10 million on Tuesday night at Christie's, where he bought four Renoirs. At Sotheby's on Thursday night he paid $19.5 million for six paintings - four by Renoir, one by Berthe Morisot and one by Marc Chagall.
Mr. Kori said he buys Renoirs because his clients prefer them to other works.
''In Japan every gallery has its specialties,'' he said. ''One has Monets, another Renoirs. Last year we sold many Renoirs and 99 percent of them were bought by corporations. In Japan it is very difficult for private collectors to buy big paintings.''
The Tokyo dealer Kazuo Fujii also bought artworks worth more than $30 million at Christie's and Sotheby's sales of contemporary, Impressionist and modern art. He said yesterday that major changes have occurred in the approximately 50 years he has been an art dealer.
''Until recently, Japanese people bought Impressionist paintings -even if they were not masterpieces,'' he said. ''Now some Japanese people want to buy high-quality Impressionist paintings - at any price.''
''The main reason is that Japanese people became rich and they have the potential to buy the masterpieces,'' Mr. Fujii said. ''Now Japanese people would like to leave some culture to Japan and to their children.''
