HEADLINE: A Writer Moves Up, This Time in Hungary

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
He is a playwright. He became the symbol of his nation's resistance to Soviet domination. He spent years in jail. The head of his country's writers' union, he was recently voted President of a newly non-Communist nation in Eastern Europe.
His name is not Vaclav Havel, the oft-jailed playwright and current President of Czechoslovakia.
He is Arpad Goncz, the 68-year-old interim President of Hungary, who is also a translator, essayist and novelist and who was jailed for six years after the 1956 uprising in Hungary. 
Yesterday, only three months after Mr. Havel met President Bush in the White House, Mr. Goncz's own good-will mission to the United States took him to the Oval Office. During the meeting, President Bush assured Mr. Goncz that the issue of Soviet troop withdrawals from Eastern Europe would be on the agenda at the coming United States-Soviet summit conference.
 
A Most Unlikely Script
The story of the ascendancy of these writers to the leadership of two Eastern European nations was a script that few playwrights would have ventured only a year ago. Mr. Goncz seemed delighted, in an earlier interview, to point out some of the other similarities between himself and his friend Mr. Havel.
''He and I are part of the same conspiracy,'' Mr. Goncz said, eyes twinkling, leaning closer to his interviewer and lowering his voice. ''It is the international conspiracy of writers. We're trying to grab all the power in the world!''
But Mr. Goncz, during a brief visit to New York this week, said he had not been able to do ''any writing at all'' since he was voted President on May 2. ''Except, of course, for my signature! Signing bills, you know.''
''So far,'' he added more seriously, ''the legislative acts I've been signing have created 85 percent of the constitutional and institutional framework that is needed to insure that Hungary is smoothly governed. And we are bearing down on our responsibility to the economy and to restabilization.''
On Thursday, Mr. Goncz said at a Washington news conference that he was seeking American support for his country's economic changes. He also said Hungary wanted to leave the Warsaw Pact and become a neutral country.
Earlier on his American trip, Mr. Goncz received an honorary degree at the University of Indiana and met in New York with members of the World Jewish Congress to discuss the dedication of a Holocaust memorial in Budapest, 'A Figure of Immense Integrity'
''In a way, he's very like Havel,'' the American novelist E. L. Doctorow said of Mr. Goncz in an interview. The novelist met Mr. Goncz after he translated Mr. Doctorow's novels ''Ragtime'' and ''World's Fair'' into Hungarian. ''Because he was outside the system, Arpad became for the people of Hungary a figure of immense integrity and a truth-teller, in much the way that writers and poets and musicians in Czechoslovakia were perceived.''
''He's terribly modest about his attainments, but he's a real patriot,'' said Mr. Doctorow of Mr. Goncz. Hungary's future leader fought against the Nazis as a member of the underground and was wounded in 1944. Subsequently, he earned a law degree and joined the Independent Smallholders' Party, which won Hungary's last free elections in 1945.
Denied other employment after the Communists consolidated power in 1948, Mr. Goncz worked in agriculture and as a welder and pipe fitter, ''quite a good pipe fitter, I assure you,'' he said with a laugh.
After the insurgency failed in 1956, Mr. Goncz was sentenced to life in prison for conspiracy and high treason.
''Prison was a real party,'' he said. ''The best minds of Hungary were in prison.''
To challenge his intellect while in prison, his wife, Susan, gave him an English grammar, ''and I taught myself the language,'' he said.
''You will have to forgive my pronunciation,'' Mr. Goncz said in his strongly accented English. ''Since I learned English in prison - well, I had to invent something similar to English - I have what you would call a real Hungarian prison accent.'' He shook his head with mock sorrow. ''You have probably never heard this kind of English accent before.''
 
Translating Kennedy's Speeches
After a few years in prison and even though he was a dissident, Mr. Goncz found himself translating World War II memoirs and the speeches of John F. Kennedy into Hungarian for the Ministry of the Interior.
Then he translated part of John Galsworthy's ''Forsyte Saga'' and smuggled it out to his wife, who sold it to a publisher and earned Mr. Goncz his first money as a translator. ''This was necessary,'' he said. ''I had to put four children through university.''
Mr. Goncz was released in a general amnesty in 1963, and subsequently his chief source of income came from the translations of English works into Hungarian. Among the authors he has translated are Mr. Doctorow, William Faulkner, William Golding, Ernest Hemingway, William Styron, John Updike and Edith Wharton. Mr. Havel said he also translated President Bush's 1988 campaign book, ''Looking Forward: An Autobiography.''
''American writers are very popular in Hungary,'' he said, ''Faulkner most of all. 'The Sound and the Fury' sold more than 150,000 copies in hard cover. That's the same as two million in America.''
The author of six plays, Mr. Goncz has also written a collection of short stories and one novel. ''He's considered one of Hungary's best playwrights, and at least one of his plays is classically impressive,'' Mr. Doctorow said. The play is called ''Men of God,'' and ostensibly it is about the Waldensian heresy, which figured in the Reformation. ''But of course it really applied to the political situation under Communism,'' Mr. Doctorow said.
Mr. Goncz's plays have been performed in eight countries, but not yet in America. ''Who knows what the future may bring?'' he said.
In July, the future will bring the American publication of a collection of his work, ''Plays and Other Writings of Arpad Goncz.'' The anthology, translated from the Hungarian by Katharina M. Wilson and Christopher C. Wilson, will make Mr. Goncz's collected works available in English translation for the first time. Mr. Doctorow has written an introduction to the collection, which will be issued by Garland Publishing of New York.
 
The Virtues of Amateurism
''I have a theory that, as new democracies, Czechoslovakia and Hungary believe in amateurism,'' Mr. Doctorow said. ''They turned to Havel and Goncz just as we turned to Jefferson and Madison. Of course, Jefferson and Madison were writers, too. To them, politics was seen as a temporary public service. They were not afraid to act on principle. They were freer to speak and to act because they didn't see politics as a career, as a job they had to protect. And I'm sorry that that seems to be an idea we've lost.''
On May 2, the first freely elected Hungarian Parliament in four decades elected Mr. Goncz interim President of the nation. Mr. Goncz, a founder of the Alliance of Free Democrats, was supported by Jozsef Antall, a leader of the Hungarian Democratic Forum, the largest of six parties that that won seats in Parliament in elections on March 25 and April 8. Mr. Goncz named Mr. Antall Prime Minister the next day.
''You know, I am two times a president, and I wear two presidential hats,'' Mr. Goncz said, referring to his continuing leadership of the National Writers' Association. ''I believe being president of the writers' union is the far more difficult task!''

CORRECTION-DATE: June 6, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 19 about Arpad Goncz, the playwright who is interim President of Hungary, misidentified the American university that recently gave him an honorary degree.
It was Butler University in Indianapolis, not Indiana University.

HEADLINE: Chinese Aide May Seek U.S. Refuge

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD

 BODY:
A senior Chinese official who disagreed with the military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators last spring has quietly arrived in the United States, apparently seeking refuge, American officials said yesterday.
The arrival of the official, Xu Jiatun, who until last fall served as China's top representative in Hong Kong, could further strain United States-Chinese relations, which are already upset by American outrage at the killing of protesters in Beijing last June.
Mr. Xu arrived in Los Angeles with two relatives around May 1, traveling on a tourist visa arranged by the United States Consulate in Hong Kong, Administration officials said yesterday. They said Mr. Xu has not applied for political asylum, but they said they believed that he left China to escape attacks by hard-liners. 
 
'Just a Tourist'
Mr. Xu could not be located for comment, and his plans remain unclear.
A spokesman for the Chinese Embassy in Washington said it had been told by the official New China News Agency in Hong Kong that Mr. Xu had come to the United States ''for a rest,'' and was in this country ''just as a tourist.'' He said the embassy had no information on how long Mr. Xu would remain.
Mr. Xu, 74 years old, was a member of the Communist Party Central Committee, and if he does seek asylum he would be the highest-ranking Chinese leader to ask for refuge in the United States.
Mr. Xu was serving as director of the New China News Agency in Hong Hong. The position made him China's unofficial governor in the British colony, which in the eyes of many residents gave him greater power than the British Governor.
 
Movie Stars and Nightclubs
As an indication of Mr. Xu's status, when he took over the job in 1983, Hong Kong was effectively elevated to the provincial level in China. Mr. Xu reported directly to the central Government in Beijing, Chinese analysts say.
Mr. Xu was a veteran Communist revolutionary who served as a political commissar in the Red Army before the Communists' victory in 1949 and rose to be first party secretary of Jiangsu Province.
When he arrived in Hong Kong he was regarded as a hard-liner, an impression he confirmed during a speech by banging his glasses on the lectern and warning that China would not tolerate steps toward democracy in the British colony.
But Mr. Xu rapidly underwent a change, hobnobbing with wealthy Hong Kong business executives and escorting movie stars to Hong Kong nightclubs. He wrote articles suggesting China should learn from capitalism.
This may have been in part his mission in Hong Kong, to reassure the colony about China's intentions as Hong Kong faces a return to Beijing's control in 1997. Mr. Xu's actions may also have reflected the market-oriented economic changes then being carried out in China by Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang.
 
High-Level Connections
Mr. Xu often boasted of his close connections to both Mr. Zhao and Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader.
Last spring, when student protesters called for greater democracy in Beijing, Mr. Xu is said to have urged a conciliatory solution as the only way to maintain Hong Kong's confidence.
But this January, Beijing announced that Mr. Xu's ''request to retire'' had been accepted. He apparently hoped to stay on in the new city of Shenzhen, just across the border from Hong Kong, but in April the Hong Kong press reported that Beijing had ordered Mr. Xu to return to his hometown, Nanjing, in central China.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Xu Jiatun, a Chinese official who opposed last summer's crackdown, is apparently seeking refuge in the United States. (The South China Morning Post)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Saberhagen's 2-Hitter Too Much for Yanks

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
Bret Saberhagen had not won a game in more than a month. After winning 23 games and the Cy Young Award last year, Saberhagen struggled and managed one victory in his first seven starts.
Mike Macfarlane had not hit a home run this year. He plays once every three games. 
Both players saw their fortunes change last night, and their splendid performances helped the Royals to a 4-1 victory over the Yankees at the Stadium.
If Saberhagen continues to pitch the way he did last night, he might not lose a game for the next month. Saberhagen mixed a nasty curve with a fastball that was humming, and held the Yankees to two hits.
 
Dominant and Economical
From the time he took the mound until he shook Macfarlane's hand after the game, there was no doubting his dominance. It was a tidy outing. Saberhagen faced only 29 batters and threw 108 pitches.
''It is as good as you can pitch without throwing a shutout,'' said John Wathan, the Royals' manager.
Macfarlane probably deserved more than a handshake from Saberhagen. In addition to calling Saberhagen's pitches, Macfarlane was the Yankees' nemesis with two doubles, a home run and four runs batted in.
Kansas City, which had lost 15 of its last 21 games, limped into New York with the highest payroll in the majors and the worst record. Expected to challenge the Oakland Athletics for the American League West title, the Royals instead have been perhaps the season's biggest disappointment.
 
Feeling Fresh Motivation
''There has been a lot of talk about all the money we're making,'' Saberhagen said. ''We have to go out there and do what we're capable of doing.''
In the first six innings, Saberhagen faced 19 batters. The only hit was a sinking liner to left by Claudell Washington in the second that dropped a foot in front of a diving Willie Wilson. Saberhagen promptly picked Washington off first.
Macfarlane, who entered the game with six runs batted in, drilled a long double over Roberto Kelly's head in center field in the second. He opened the seventh with a homer to left that put the Royals on top, 3-0, and hastened the exit of Tim Leary. Macfarlane closed out his night with a run-scoring double in the eighth.
The Yankees scored in the seventh when Kelly doubled and moved to third on a groundout by Don Mattingly. Mel Hall drove in Kelly with a sacrifice fly.
In the eighth, Saberhagen started to trot off the field even though there were only two outs. It didn't matter much. He quickly got the third out.
Macfarlane said his three hits were more than he remembered getting against the Yankees all of last season.
''Right before I left, my wife told me not to get into that Yankee rut,'' Macfarlane said. ''I think I had two hits off them. Tonight was just one of those nights.''
 
 Pascual Perez, who has been on the disabled list since April 29 with a strained shoulder, threw for 12 minutes without pain before the game and is expected to be sent to Tampa, Fla., for rehabilitation. . . . Danny Tartabull, out since the season opener with a leg injury, was activated yesterday by the Royals. . . . A hitting streak by the Royals' Kevin Seitzer was snapped at 17 games.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher; Traders Focus on Pound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar gained against most currencies in light trading yesterday, while the spotlight remained on the British pound.
Gold prices, meanwhile, rose worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $374.70 an ounce, up $5.20 from late Thursday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $373.25 an ounce, up $4.15. 
Currency dealers said the dollar was partly helped by the continued strength of the British pound, particularly in the European market.
 
Speculation About Britain
 With demand for the pound up, foreign traders sold their currencies to buy sterling, and that made the dollar more valuable against those currencies, explained Zlatko Glamuzina, the chief dealer at the New York office of Banco di Sicilia.
The pound has been supported in recent days by speculation that Britain was preparing to enter the European Monetary System. Some traders acknowledged imminent entry was unlikely, but they said the prospect of entry alone would provide underlying support for the pound for several weeks.
Trading was described as quiet in New York in the absence of any new economic indicators or financial developments. Also, some dealers have already departed for next week's annual gathering of foreign exchange dealers in Copenhagen.
Sterling rose to $1.6910 in London, from $1.6905 Thursday, but it eased slightly on profit taking, to $1.6900 from $1.6920, in New York.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar rose in New York to 153.00 yen from 152.15. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 152.90 yen, up 0.90 yen from Thursday's 152.00-yen finish. And in London it traded at 152.80 yen. The dollar fell, however, against the West German currency, to 1.6483 marks, from 1.6498 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's quotes, included: 1.4050 Swiss francs, up from 1.4045; 5.5595 French francs, up from 5.5570; 1,212.75 Italian lire, up from 1,212.50, and 1.17975 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17475.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $369.75 an ounce, from $369.25 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, gold rose to $370.60 an ounce, from $369 Thursday.
In Hong Kong, gold rose 15 cents an ounce to close at $370.30.
Silver prices also gained ground. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.122 an ounce, up from $5.026 late Thursday. Silver rose in London to $5.06 an ounce from $5.05.

HEADLINE: Fed Voted in March for Tight Rein

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers concluded at their March meeting that excessive inflation would continue and decided to maintain high interest rate policies in the face of a moderately growing economy, according to minutes of the meeting released today.
The minutes were made available amid signs that the policy makers, who met in secret again on Tuesday, decided at the latest meeting to continue the policies at least for the next seven weeks while they try to determine the economy's direction before they meet again.
 
 Recession Is Feared
 The Fed has tried for more than two years to stem inflation by keeping a tight grip on credit and thus slowing the economy. Some analysts fear that the tight-money policies could restrain the economy too much and push it into a recession. 
But at its March 27 meeting, the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee reviewed information that ''suggested that the economy was likely to expand at a somewhat faster pace over the next several quarters than in the fourth quarter of 1989,'' the minutes said.
At the same time, a staff projection said that ''little improvement was anticipated in the underlying trend of inflation.'' And some members commented that ''the prospects for inflation remained the most disturbing aspect of the economic outlook.''
''On balance,'' the minutes said, ''little or no progress in reducing inflation appeared to be in prospect for the quarters immediately ahead.''
 
Two Dissented in Vote
 As a result, most members indicated a preference for an unchanged policy, although several preferred an immediate move toward a tighter stance to achieve price stability. The vote for maintaining policy was 9 to 2, with W. Lee Hoskins of the Cleveland district and Robert H. Boykin of the Dallas district dissenting.
Until several weeks ago, many analysts thought the Fed might tighten credit at its meeting this week. However, statistics for employment, industrial production, retail sales and inflation all pointed to a return to slower growth in April.
In fact, some traders thought the central bank had loosened credit to stimulate growth when the Federal funds rate dropped below the Fed's 8.25 percent target late Wednesday and early Thursday. But the Fed took steps on Thursday to push up the rate, which is what banks charge each other for overnight loans. That signaled to many market watchers that a relaxation of monetary policy was not imminent. The Federal funds rate is the primary lever the Fed uses to control short-term interest rates.
Edward G. Boehne, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia and a member of the committee, also told a bankers group on Thursday that Fed policy had been unchanged since December.
 
Funds Rate at 8.25 Percent
 The Federal funds rate has remained at 8.25 percent since Dec. 21, when the central bank permitted it to drop from 8.50 percent. That move followed its Dec. 18-19 meeting.
The open market committee, which is made up of the seven Fed governors and five of the presidents of the 12 Fed regional banks, meets in secret eight times a year to formulate monetary policy and confers by telephone as needed. Minutes of the meeting are released six to seven weeks later.

HEADLINE: A G.M. Plant Adjusts To the 'New Brazil'

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAO CAETANO DO SUL, Brazil

 BODY:
Robert B. Stone, the American who heads the General Motors Corporation's subsidiary here, will not soon forget March 16, when Brazil's new Government announced its radical attack on inflation.
President Fernando Collor de Mello's main weapon was a freeze on 80 percent of the nation's savings held by individuals and private companies. The Government program all but halted inflation, which had been running at almost 5,000 percent over the 12 months ending in March, but it also closed factories and left shops deserted.
''It was panicville,'' Mr. Stone, the managing director of General Motors do Brasil Ltd., recalled during an interview at his office here, 10 miles from Sao Paulo, in Brazil's industrial belt. ''It took everyone by storm.'' 
The G.M. experience provides a glimpse of how Mr. Collor's economic blueprint for a ''New Brazil'' is working and how corporations are coping with the changes.
In the last two weeks of March, General Motors do Brasil, a $2.5 billion-a-year operation that builds 22,000 cars a month and holds 28 percent of the Brazilian auto market, did not sell a single car. By April, 19,000 of the company's 24,000 employees had been sent home with pay.
Yet the economic package prompted a flurry of activity at the headquarters of the G.M. subsidiary as the corporate staff hurried to devise a strategy for dealing with the Government program, which also included a new currency and a series of free-market reforms. For Mr. Stone and his staff, it meant emergency weekend meetings, daily reports to headquarters in Detroit and, the 40-year-old Michigan native recalled, ''sleepless nights and a few gray hairs.''
Today, thanks to the company's tactics and a recent easing of Government policy to revive consumer demand, G.M.'s Brazilian business is starting to return to normal. Some 20,000 of the auto company's employees are back at work and its two plants are producing vehicles at nearly 70 percent of capacity, with a 75 percent rate expected for June.
The Brazilian economy, like the G.M. operation, seems to be bouncing back from the shock recession that began in mid-March. But while the impact of the Government's financial squeeze is proving less harsh than many had expected, Mr. Collor's free-market policies, which are just beginning, promise to have a wrenching effect on Brazilian industry.
Mr. Collor, for instance, has said that he believes Brazil's car industry, the 11th largest in the world, is an oligopoly that has grown inefficient, overpriced and out of date because of decades of protectionism, namely price controls and heavy import duties. Thus the 40-year-old President is starting to allow auto imports - he ended a 15-year ban on May 4 - and plans to free exchange rates and encourage foreign investment.
For Brazilian companies, the Government's program presented a formidable financial challenge. Savings in cruzados novos, Brazil's currency until mid-March, were blocked and companies had to find a way to convert to the new currency, cruzeiros, as quickly and inexpensively as possible. The ease with which concerns like G.M. have made the transition to the new currency has surprised many economists. ''We're entirely on cruzeiros now,'' Mr. Stone said.
 
Hedging Against the Unknown
 The chore was made easier because before Mr. Collor's inauguration G.M., like other Brazilian companies, took a classic Latin American hedge against the unknown: They spent and invested most of their cash, thus reducing their liquidity and risk. Mr. Stone declined to say how much of his company's money had been frozen.
To unload deposits of cruzados novos, which are frozen until September 1991, G.M. took advantage of new rules allowing the old currency to be used to pay state and federal taxes and invoices dated before March. The ruling caused tax collection to soar after the currency switch. Brazil's car industry, one of the most heavily taxed in the world, pays a tax of 43 percent on its sales to dealers.
In another tactic, some Brazilian companies sold cruzados novos for cruzeiros at discounts of about 70 percent to parties who could use them to pay taxes.
The General Motors subsidiary was forced to borrow money to pay idled workers and to shut down several production lines after the freeze because few people had money to buy cars. It finally developed cash flow by converting earnings from car exports that had been retained, as usual, at the central bank, into cruzeiros. Few multinational companies in Brazil heeded the Government's suggestion that they request fresh funds from headquarters.
But for several weeks, the Brazilian auto industry almost ground to a halt. Layoffs spread throughout the industry, affecting Volvo do Brasil, Mercedes do Brasil and Autolatina, a joint venture of Ford do Brasil and Volkswagen do Brasil. Sales were so slow that Luiz Carlos Mello, president of Ford do Brasil, spent an April weekend promoting his cars in a Sao Paulo dealership.
Fiat do Brasil was the only manufacturer going full tilt, solely because most of its production here is for export. G.M. also kept its engine export line open.
 
Funds Released
 Slowly in April, as the Government's financial tourniquet eased, consumers had more money to spend and started to buy again. For example, the Government, as planned, unblocked the money of car credit unions to stimulate auto demand. And it stretched the allowable terms of bank loans for car purchases to 30 months from 4.
In fact, the turn in auto demand came so sharply that it generated new problems. Dealer stocks ran low and the period of temporary layoffs interrupted the normal supply of new cars. Some dealers soon started charging customers under-the-table surcharges of 15 to 20 percent on the prices fixed by the Government.
On May 1, Mr. Collor lashed out at the car companies. A Volkswagen dealer in Sao Paulo was arrested on May 2 for imposing the surcharge.
 
Credit Restricted
 ''High demand with fixed prices'' created the environment for illegal surcharges, Mr. Stone said. In an attempt to temper demand, the Government restricted credit this week.
The Government says that for now it will not decontrol the prices of goods like cement and autos produced by oligopolies, but will instead encourage price competition by relaxing import bans.
Still, an 85 percent tariff on imported cars should give the local auto industry time to adjust. Only a few hundred luxury cars are expected to be imported this year because tariffs, taxes and freight should triple the cost of these autos. But a schedule to reduce tariffs to the 20 percent range over the next three years is expected from the Government next month.
The Brazilian auto industry seems a model of inefficiency, supported by protectionism, taxation and local-content regulations. Accordingly, the lowest-priced new car in Brazil sells for $10,000, almost double the cheapest cars in the United States, even though hourly labor costs in Brazil are about one-seventh of those in the United States and less than one-third the rate in Japan.
The prospect of lowering protectionist barriers to auto imports is viewed with alarm by Brazilian unions and some industry executives. The resistance to such Government proposals underlines the political obstacles that Mr. Collor's free-market reforms are likely to encounter increasingly as they move forward.
''If imported vehicles enter Brazil at a competitive or lower price than Brazilian cars, there will be brutal unemployment in this country,'' warned Pedro Eberhardt, president of the National Auto Parts Industry Union.
 
'A Generation Behind'
 For his part, Mr. Stone welcomes the trend toward opening the Brazilian market. It should make the nation's auto industry more competitive internationally, he said, as long as the market for parts and factory equipment is freed, as well as the market for finished cars. Indeed, the Government is considering relaxing tariffs on car parts, robots and other automated equipment.
''We are a generation behind in electronics,'' Mr. Stone said. ''If you really believe in freedom, let us set prices and import parts, accessories and raw materials without heavy duties.''
Mr. Stone said that in response to the removal of import bans, he was studying the economics of importing General Motors cars to sell through his distribution network.

HEADLINE: Some Curb On Credit Is Reported

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
A Federal Reserve Board study confirmed today what many financial experts have been saying for weeks: the nation's commercial banks are restricting loans and other types of credit to small and medium-sized companies.
But at the same time, the Fed's study of 60 banking institutions found that while loan growth to some businesses this year had slowed, total lending had not declined, indicating that warnings of a recessionary nationwide credit tightening are unfounded.
''The bottom line is that you don't see the kind of horror stories in the data that you've seen in the anecdotes,'' said Robert E. Litan, senior fellow and a banking expert at the Brookings Institution. ''There has been some moderate degree of tightening, but there has not been the systemic kind of credit crunch we've heard about.'' 
 
Real Estate Loans Affected
 The survey, which is done three times a year, did find that almost all banks surveyed reported tighter policies on loans involving real estate. A large share of the bankers said they had imposed ''considerably'' tighter restrictions on developers of property, indicating that that industry was experiencing a ''credit crunch.''
''For marginal borrowers, who to a considerable degree are companies involved in and related to real estate, it feels like a credit crunch,'' said Robert Dugger, chief economist of the American Bankers Association. ''But in the economy as a whole, sound borrowers are still getting credit.''
The survey of senior loan officers at small, medium and large banks, comes one week after the nation's three top bank regulators held an unusual meeting with the directors of the bankers association and urged them to continue lending to creditworthy customers.
 
Weaker Economy Cited
 Bankers indicated in the survey that their tightening up on some loans was largely motivated by what the Fed survey described as a ''less favorable economic outlook.''
A second reason cited was the deterioration of the banks' loan portfolio, which would also be an indication of a weakening economy.
Last week's meeting with the association officials was seen as the clearest signal the regulators could make to bankers that they did not want them to overreact to reports of pressure to tighten lending. The meeting was attended by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman; L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency.
The regulators stressed that they wanted prudent lending to continue, hoping to prevent a significant slowdown in economic growth that would occur if bankers on a broad scale stopped making loans to mid-sized businesses.
 
Implications for the Fed
 The survey, which was completed before the meeting, now appears to buttress the regulators' actions. It also underscores concerns by some economists that in the face of a softening economy, the Fed's monetary policy has been too restrictive. They say that if Fed officials cannot persuade the banking industry to continue making credit available, the Fed may face the unwanted chore of sharply lowering interest rates to keep the economy from entering a recession.
''The regulators came to the A.B.A. to make sure that there was not overreaction,'' Mr. Dugger said. ''They don't want the economy to tailspin into a recession as a result of an overreaction. They do not want a regulatory-induced recession.''
In the minutes of the March 27 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, which were released today, panel members were reporting concern in the banking industry about a tightening of credit, but they did not seem to be overly worried.
''Outside of lending for corporate-restructuring purposes and certain real estate transactions,'' the minutes stated, ''it was difficult to find firm indications of greater credit rationing. Some tightening of credit standards probably was a desirable development in terms of correcting for past excesses and adjusting to a more moderate pace of business activity, but a number of members expressed concern that significant further restraint, should it occur, could have adverse consequences for the overall economy.''
The Fed survey of banks reported that ''about 30 percent of banks indicated that since late 1989 they had reduced the size of credit lines they were making available to middle-market firms.''
In general, the banks said their lending policies toward large companies had not changed and that credit to them was still plentiful. The survey found, however, that some large borrowers had reduced their demand for loans because of a greater reliance on the commercial paper market, which is a way large companies can borrow from the investing public without using a bank as an intermediary.

HEADLINE: News Analysis;
Who Loses in Yearly Budget Brawls

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 18

 BODY:
Ever since Gov. Mario M. Cuomo presented his budget plan in January, he and the legislative leaders have been engaged in a high-stakes game of hot-potato, devoting at least as much energy to minimizing political losses as to devising a spending plan.
There are no clear victors. But the big loser has been the state itself.
Communities around the state, which were forced to borrow to compensate for missed state-aid payments, lost millions of dollars in interest costs because of the delay. School districts suffered similarly. 
While its leaders haggled, New York's credit rating dropped to its lowest level ever, a development that is likely to raise the cost of borrowing for years.
As is often the case with political jockeying, in the end, none of the politicians seem to have come out ahead.
 
'Really Nobody Wins'
Mr. Cuomo, who has sought a national reputation as a governor able to balance social concern with fiscal responsibility, has been badly damaged by the yawning deficit, the $1.4 billion in new taxes to close it and the perception that he cannot control the state government.
The State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, has gained a reputation for being unable to bring his members into line. Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, Democrat of Brooklyn, who earned high marks in the negotiatiions, is unlikely to be remembered for his efforts, given the length of the entire process.
''Really nobody wins,'' Gerald Benjamin, a professor of political science at the State University at New Paltz, said. ''What people conclude is that government doesn't work in New York. It just reinforces the cynicism.''
 
Array of Problems
Looking over the months of fumbling and procrastination that finally yielded up a budget agreement today, political and financial analysts have in recent days identified several long-term problems that contributed to the delay. These are some of the factors:
* Mr. Cuomo's failure, three years in a row, to present a strategy that would provide an enduring solution for the fiscal problems.
* The continuing efforts of the Republican-controlled Senate to minimize the seriousness of the problems.
* A breakdown in party discipline, which has made it increasingly difficult for the legislative leaders to gain support for unpopular decisions.
 
Slide in Tax Collections
''You see the legislative leaders' not being able to make agreements stick,'' Professor Benjamin said. ''That's a real change in the process. The party as glue is just not there anymore.''
Most political analysts, and even many politicians, agree that the stage for the budget debacle this year was set two years ago, when tax collections began what turned out to be a long and unrelenting slide.
The administration was surprisingly slow to respond to the decline and, indeed, still appears to be struggling to comprehend the magnitude of the problem. Every few months, the adminstration announces that the revenue collections have, once again, fallen short of expectations. The news has become so predictable that it barely makes lunchtime conversation in the Capitol.
''It's like Vietnam,'' the director of the Urban Research Center at New York University, Mitchell Moss, said. ''Every few months they would announce they were sending over a few thousand more troops. Every few months the Governor finds another $300 million shortfall. You lose credibility that way.''
 
Matter of Weeks
Just weeks after the Governor presented his proposed budget to the Legislature in January, he announced that revenues would be $1.5 billion lower than originally projected. That made the executive budget, which is traditionally a blueprint for negotiations, obsolete.
Instead of presenting a plan to bring his proposal up to date, Mr. Cuomo said he would work with legislative leaders to close the gap, cooperatively.
Mr. Cuomo insisted that he was trying to hasten the process. But in Albany cooperation is something that politicians indulge in just as a last resort. Even the Governor's supporters concede that the administration's failure to produce a plan to deal with the $1.5 billion gap, which eventually grew to almost $2 billion, reflected a reluctance to take responsibility for new taxes.
''They didn't want to have their fingerprints on anything,'' said one Democratic politicians who is friendly with the Governor.
 
Jockeying by Republicans
From the beginning of the negotiations, the stance of the Republican-controlled Senate did not bode well for cooperative efforts. For weeks, Republican senators insisted that the Governor was exaggerating the economic problems and maintained that the state should not delay the income-tax cut planned for this year.
The Republicans' insistence on the cut seemed intended to score political points for November, when the Governor and all 211 legislators are up for re-election.
Even after giving in and agreeing to delay the cut, Republican senators continued to insist on extracting some political benefit from the budget. They first refused to agree to new taxes, then pressed to add school aid for the suburban districts that are their core constituencies and finally insisted on a spending cap intended to shore up their image as fiscal conservatives.
This evening, some Republican lawmakers were still insisting on a spending cap as a condition of voting on the budget. Even though their threat to hold up the budget was never carried out, it contradicted the expressed wishes of Mr. Marino, who scheduled a vote on the budget bills for tonight.
Such a conflict between legislators and and a leader was once unthinkable here. But such conflicts have become commonplace in recent years, making the decision making increasingly diffuse and time consuming.
''We cannot fail to recognize that the State Senate is out of control,'' Mr. Moss said. ''What we have here is a collective failure of political leadership.''

TYPE: NEWS ANALYSIS

HEADLINE: Woman Sues Boycotted Grocery in Flatbush

BYLINE: By ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

 BODY:
A $6 million lawsuit was filed yesterday by the Haitian woman whose claim that she was assaulted in a Korean grocery in Brooklyn in January touched off protests and a boycott that continue.
The woman's lawyer, Colin A. Moore, announced the suit at a news conference in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.
He said the woman, Giselaine Felissaint, had been struck by three employees in the Korean store, the Family Red Apple, at 1823 Church Avenue in the Flatbush section. The owners of the store said that the woman had refused to pay for some items and that she was not attacked. Another nearby Korean-owned store, Church Fruits, has also been a target of the boycott. 
Mr. Moore said that he represents the woman, not those boycotting the stores, but that the demonstrators are ''well within their First Amendment rights.''
Among those attending the news conference were Robert (Sonny) Carson, a black community organizer who is leading the boycott. Some others who attended shouted ''the boycott will continue'' as they left.
 
Trying to Set Up Meetings
The city's Human Rights Commission, which is trying to mediate the bitter dispute, had observers at the news conference, said a spokesman for the commission, Lonnie Soury. ''We are hopeful that we can still move in a positive direction,'' Mr. Soury said. ''We are definitely trying to get more meetings set up.''
A lawyer for the owners of Family Red Apple and Church Fruits, Richard A. Izzo, described yesterday's lawsuit as a ''baseless claim'' and ''attempted extortion.'' But he said it could turn into ''a positive development'' if it moves the dispute into court and off the street.
Mr. Izzo said he and the two Korean merchants want to resolve the dispute, but the demonstrators have ''no one representing them.''
The question of who speaks for the demonstrators became more perplexing this week when their lawyer, Stephen G. James, withdrew because they had rejected discussions with the other side. Later, Mr. James said, ''I would not foreclose the possibility of representing the demonstrators at the discussion table if they asked me to.'' #2 Groups Claim 17 Members Mr. James had represented the two groups that started the boycott, the Flatbush Coalition for Economic Empowerment and the Flatbush Frontline Collective, which are the defendants in a civil suit that the Korean merchants filed against the demonstrators.
At a hearing in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, two people testified for the groups. Sabine Albert, speaking for the Frontline Collective, said it had 10 members. George Dames, speaking for the Flatbush Coalition, said it had seven members.
Justice Gerald S. Held has issued a temporary order to bar the demonstrators from picketing within 50 feet of the two Korean stores. But the police have refrained from enforcing the order so far, saying it involves a civil dispute.

HEADLINE: HOUSE FOR THE HOMELESS PROVOKES DISPUTE

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

DATELINE: TRUMBULL, Conn.

 BODY:
Donna Russell says God led her to open her lakefront house to homeless families, but her neighbors say she is breaking the law.
One of them, Vincent Smith, complained to town zoning officials that Mrs. Russell is violating a local law that requires three-quarters of the residents of a single-family dwelling to be related by blood, marriage or adoption.
Mr. Smith said his complaint was not motivated by any bias against homeless people or against religion. ''I was born and raised a Christian,'' he said. ''I don't really practice any religion now. I believe there's a God, but I also believe there is a law and the law has to be followed.'' 
Mrs. Russell is to appear before the town Zoning Board of Appeals on June 6, where a lawyer from the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union will present her case. Does Law Violate Due Process? ''Basically, it's an outdated family restriction, which as we read it would prevent an unmarried couple from living together,'' said William Olds, the executive director of the civil liberties group. ''Our view is that it's unconstitutional under the state of Connecticut constitution.''
He said that the law violates due process, the right to privacy and freedom of association and that several states, including New York and New Jersey, have struck down similar zoning restrictions. Connecticut state laws allow day-care centers and homes for the mentally or physically disabled to operate in single-family residences.
Although the Trumbull official charged with enforcing the regulation said he thought it was ''way behind the times,'' he also said Mrs. Russell must obey the law.
''The woman is a very nice woman, very religious, and she has her views and genuinely, I think, wants to help people,'' said Donald G. Murray, the Trumbull building inspector who is also charged with enforcing zoning codes. ''God bless her, but she can't do it without permission.''
Other neighbors in the secluded Pinewood Estates subdivision in this town of 33,000 outside Bridgeport declined to be interviewed, but Mr. Murray said several are suspicious that Mrs. Russell's stance is a ploy to get money to finance the mortgage on the $400,000 house.
If the zoning board upholds the law, she intends to continue her fight in the courts, and the civil liberties union will represent her.
Mrs. Russell conceded that the real-estate brokerage and mortgage business she owns has been hit by the region's declining economy, and the white paint that is peeling from her clapboard home attests to a shortage of capital.
But she said she would continue the shelter regardless of whether she received state financing or donations from private sources. ''Money is tight,'' she said. ''But whether I'm living here on Pinewood Lake or somewhere else, I'm going to have this home.''
The 42-year-old mother of three said she expected people to question her motives for opening the shelter, which she has named the Alfred L. Bowles Jr. Home in memory of a friend's husband who was known for helping the homeless. ''I'm not surprised by the opposition, but I know that God's using it for his glory,'' she said.
She said her neighbors' concern is more for their property values than upholding the law.
 
Christmas Card to Neighbors
She said God first told her to open a homeless shelter in August 1983. ''I never heard any more about it until maybe June of 1988, when I was told by the Lord that this was the house,'' she said.
She was showing it to clients but felt compelled to buy it herself. She waited a few months more, and after hearing the director of a homeless shelter in Bridgeport speak at her church, she sought his advice on opening her house to homeless families.
She hosted her first family, a Thai woman and her small child, in December. After she sent a Christmas card from the shelter to her neighbors, Mr. Smith complained to city officials. Until then, the neighbors were unaware that anyone besides Mrs. Russell and her son Daniel, 18 years old, were living in the house.
On a recent visit to the two-story house almost hidden from view by oak trees and dense shrubbery, the only indication that anyone other than the Russells live there was the faint sound of a baby's cry.
The two young homeless mothers living there now declined to be interviewed. One of them has earned her general education degree and plans to attend a local business school. Mrs. Russell said two other homeless women have graduated from the shelter, one to a small apartment of her own and the other after a reconciliation with her family.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Luck and Pluck: From Poverty To Mega-Dealing

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
''The man happens to be lucky,'' said the big man's dapper driver.
Point taken. Dick Gidron owns lavish homes and a 36-foot boat, and is, according to Black Enterprise magazine, the nation's fourth-largest Afro-American car dealer. His best friend is Muhammad Ali, the most famous person in the world. 
Mr. Gidron, 49 years old, earned his luck. He grew up on Chicago's South Side, where he was raised by his mother and his grandmother after his father died when he was 6, 7 or 8 years old. He isn't sure which. He avoided the omnipresent youth gangs (''no future there''), throwing himself into a job in the parts department of a local Cadillac dealership instead. By the time he was 26, he had graduated from college, become Cadillac's first black salesman and was soon selling more freeway schooners than anybody else on this planet.
The big chance came in 1972. General Motors was selling its factory-owned outlets and wanted one of the four in the New York metropolitan area to go to a minority. Mr. Gidron edged out such big-name competitors as Hank Aaron and Sammy Davis Jr. for the chance to bet his last cent on a Caddy emporium.
Mr. Gidron makes light of the difficulties that he has overcome - the poverty he escaped as well as the effects of racism. Others don't.
''There are some things that are very difficult for us to crack into,'' said Mayor David N. Dinkins, a friend who has visited Mr. Gidron's home in Scarsdale.
''He has accomplished all this against all kinds of odds.''
This bear-like man with the huge head and alert eyes doesn't come across as a super pitchman.
There is a slight guardedness, even as he throws himself into such civic duties as serving four terms as president of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce. ''He's a tough guy to get close to,'' allowed John Dunn, a New York Telephone executive who nonetheless did.
Somehow Mr. Gidron became a fast friend to both George Steinbrenner and Dave Winfield, a rare feat. He races to ease the sting of even slightly controversial remarks. For example, after joking that he has personally autographed half the photos of Muhammad Ali, he retracted the remark. ''Those pictures mean too much to people,'' he said.
Not that he doesn't know how to speak his mind. When the fiance of his daughter, Bridget, one of two children, came to ask him for her hand, he blurted out, ''What makes you think she wants to marry you?''
Mr. Gidron is a man of grand gestures -most of which help sell cars. When he learned that the Westchester County black debutante ball might not be held because of financial problems, he dashed off a personal check for $3,000. Not only did he sponsor a youth job fair, he invited an astronaut.
Mr. Gidron says New York has far fewer minority-owned businesses than Chicago, a situation he thinks government should help remedy. He also stresses that blacks must concentrate on selling to whites, who constitute the great bulk of his trade.
But not to the exclusion of blacks. ''The epitome for any black American has always been to own a Cadillac,'' Mr. Gidron declared. ''It shows we've arrived a little bit and are kind of enjoying life.''
Daily, Mr. Gidron spends upward of 15 hours prowling between his Cadillac dealership and two Ford stores in the Bronx and another Ford outlet in Westchester County. He changes cars periodically so he arrives at Ford in a Ford, and so on.
He bargains price here, exhorts a salesman there, picks up a scrap of paper from a sidewalk, forces himself to spew out small talk. He tells a preacher he certainly is saved but not so saved he will buy new windows for his church.
He politely turns down a customer's request that he move his yacht so the two can again dock next to each other. He sells a man known as Hustler on the wisdom of trading up to a $50,000 model.
It seems downright magical how he starts out chatting about a broken alternator and within minutes has a man agreeing to cancel his contract to buy a Plymouth and look at Fords.
This big man has big plans, perhaps running for office. In the last election, he almost took a shot at Bronx borough president. Today's news, though, is that Mr. Gidron is opening what he calls a ''mega-dealership'' in Westchester County. Seven brands and 300 different makes under one roof!
Time will tell whether mega-dealing will make him America's largest black auto dealer. Whatever, Mr. Gidron insists that nothing compares with seeing a first-time Cadillac buyer's sparkling smile.
''You can't express that in words,'' he said.

HEADLINE: GLOBAL CHANGE AND BUDGET CUTS TEST PENTAGON

SERIES: Shrinking the Military - First of four articles: Making Cuts and Changing Missions

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON with ERIK ECKHOLM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
Beyond disputes over dollars and weapons, the battle of the military budget reflects a debate over the shape of the American military in a transformed world.
The Bush Administration has, without apology, taken a cautious approach to the end of the cold war and proposed a modest decline in the military budget. In plans developed so far, the armed forces would be scaled back significantly but without changing their basic structure or missions.
This is ''the worst possible time to contemplate changes in defense strategy,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said earlier this year.
 
'Analyze What Is Right'
''What we need to do is to analyze what is right with that strategy and make adjustments,'' the Defense Secretary added. 
But in interviews a broad variety of experts, including three former Defense Secretaries, former top officers and private experts on the military, called for major, even radical, shifts in America's military posture that would permit deeper cuts in the budget.
Many leading experts say the Pentagon has been timid in reshaping American military forces for a changing world. They have put forth more far-reaching ideas, like withdrawing virtually all combat ground forces from Europe, relying far more on reserve units, spending much less on new long-range nuclear weapons, which the Administration plans to buy even as it cuts the nuclear arsenal under a new arms agreement, and perhaps reallocating missions among the services.
These and other measures would permit the annual military budget, now around $300 billion, to be reduced by 25 percent over five years, yielding a far greater annual ''peace dividend'' than would the annual decline of roughly 10 percent proposed by the Administration for the same period.
''The threats are likely to be very different in thefuture,'' said Harold Brown, Defense Secretary in the Carter Administration, who favors a 25 percent budget cut. ''That requires a more fundamental restructuring of the forces and missions.''
Even conservatives have castigated the Pentagon as engaging in old thinking. Fred C. Ikle, Ronald Reagan's Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, has written that Mr. Cheney's Pentagon is dominated by an ''obsolete mindset.''
''Despite the prudently chosen cuts that Defense Secretary Cheney proposed to Congress for the 1991 budget, about half our defense effort is essentially still devoted to fighting a massive conventional war in Europe,'' Mr. Ikle wrote in The National Interest, a conservative journal. ''Stalin has been buried twice in Moscow, but his ghost lives on in the Pentagon.''
As the extent of the change in the Soviet Union sinks in, the debate over the military budget is building into a full-fledged political war, cutting across party lines and ideologies. And it often pits service against service in an escalating contest for ever scarcer military dollars.
Behind the heated oratory is a deeper debate about the structure of the nation's military forces.
The Pentagon leadership, defending a traditional approach to military planning, sees itself as taking the prudent course.
''In Europe, we want to show the Soviet Union the same picture they have seen all along - a group of nations that are willing to make a real investment in their security,'' Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said in an interview. ''And a real investment is combat forces, not quartermaster clerks.''
Responding to the call by critics for more radical restructuring, he said: ''It's not at all clear to me that a balanced downsizing is not the right answer. I've seen no particular Soviet capability disappear; I've seen no part of the world where we have an interest go off the map.''
But where the Pentagon leadership sees prudence, others see an unimaginative failure to grasp a rare opportunity to create a new military structure.
''The Defense Department calculations still focus on the Soviet Union, reducing as the changes in the Warsaw Pact allow,'' said Les Aspin, a Pentagon analyst during the 1960's who now heads the House Armed Services committee. ''We need to do some really fundamental new thinking about where does it all go beyond this and what the threat is out there to which we gear our forces.''
 
The Goals
Readiness Vs. Risk
 Much of the debate involves differing calculations of the risk to national security posed by cutbacks in the armed forces. How likely is it that the Soviet military threat to Europe would or could be rebuilt? How likely is it that the United States will want to intervene in upheavals in the third world, how often and with what kinds of force?
While there are no absolute answers to these questions, the economic and diplomatic stakes are enormous. At its foundation, the budget debate reflects visions of how best to secure America's place in the world.
A 25 percent cut in the military budget would mean $50 billion a year less by 1995 than projected by the Bush Administration. This would be a tidy sum for reducing the deficit, aiding valued allies or fighting domestic ills. Some experts even believe that if Moscow's military retreat and preoccupation with overwhelming domestic problems continue, the American military should shrink still more in the closing years of the decade, to an annual budget level that is only 50 percent of today's $300 billion.
Secretary Cheney has charged that cutting the military budget in half ''would give us the defense budget for a second-class power, the budget of an America in decline,'' and the weight of opinion among leading military experts appears to be that cuts of this magnitude may go too far. General Powell said he worried about ''a drawdown so precipitous that we are seen to be leaving the world stage as the leader of the Atlantic and Pacific alliances.''
 
Concerns About Cutbacks
''The fundamental question is the level of risk that the American public is willing to live with,'' said James Schlesinger, Defense Secretary in the Nixon Administration. I've witnessed two major cuts since World War II and both times we lived to regret it,'' he cautioned, referring to the late 1940's and the 1970's, after the Vietnam War. Still, with a carefully planned reduction of 25 percent, he said, ''I think we can continue to play the role of global superpower that we're accustomed to.''
But William W. Kaufmann, a former Defense Department official who is a leading proponent of the 50 percent cut, replied, ''I don't regard the size of the defense budget or armed forces as the only index of U.S. power.''
''If we don't get our economy and society in order,'' he added, ''we may have a great military facade but we won't be a very great power.''
Mr. Ikle, who favors somewhat deeper budget cuts over five years than Mr. Cheney has proposed, said United States security would be served by redirecting a portion of the military dollars to security assistance to allies around the world and aid to the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe.
Mr. Ikle said economic aid to Eastern Europe might now be the front-line weapon. ''One-third of a percent of the defense budget would make a whale of a difference there,'' he said.
 
The Critics' Views
Leaner Forces, Narrower Roles
 Several major policy changes were proposed by many leading experts, although not every critic of current Pentagon plans endorsed each one.
One proposal calls for radically revising NATO's time-honored sharing of labor. The United States Army would no longer keep more than a symbolic number of ground combat forces in Europe, instead leaving logistical units there prepared to receive reinforcements. While a strong Air Force contingent would remain, only about one-third as many troops as the 225,000 envisioned by President Bush would stay in Europe.
Proponents including Mr. Schlesinger and Senator Sam Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services committee, say that these smaller forces might show more realism, given rising West German resentment over the large American military presence.
Under another proposed policy change, the services would cut active forces deeply and rely far more on the Reserves. In particular, the Army would keep fewer heavy, armored forces on active duty, and would assign to Reserves the task of defending Europe in a crisis. Proponents say the approach is justified by the remote chances of a Soviet attack and the months or years it would take the Soviet Union to rebuild an offensive threat once its forces have pulled back.
Some critics also believe the Navy should shift more of its vessels into reserve status, reduce the number of aircraft carriers and cut back their patrolling of far-flung waters.
All these experts would preserve a capacity to mount small-scale attacks, like the recent invasion of Panama, and to make lightning strikes against foes who, for example, sponsor terrorists or threaten oil traffic.
Many experts say costly new long-range nuclear weapons the Administration says it needs to match advances in the Soviet arsenal should be bought over a much longer period than now planned. They also think that drastic cuts in nuclear arms should be sought in new negotiations that would follow the strategic arms treaty now nearing completion. That treaty would reduce American and Soviet arsenals by roughly 30 percent and would permit the deployment of new weapons.
Some critics also believe that the Pentagon should review the assignment of missions to the services, largely set four decades ago, with an eye to meeting goals more efficiently. Some say the Air Force might, for example, be given additional responsibilities for attacking enemy ships at sea, a task now entrusted largely to the Navy, while the mission of providing close air support to Army troops should be taken over by the Army from the Air Force.
 
The Pentagon's Stand
Big Threat Eases; Others Emerge
 General Powell, reflecting the Bush Administration's cautious approach to the Soviet transformation, reacted coolly to many of the proposals that would bring about a steep drop in forces.
Nonetheless, he said that he and Defense Secretary Cheney were seeking to define the ''base line'' forces needed to protect American interests and that deeper budget reductions than they have proposed might prove feasible.
Another senior Pentagon official, speaking on condition that he not be identified, acknowledged that some basic planning choices had yet to be made. ''If Europe needs heavy reinforcement, do we still have the capability to send heavy forces to the Middle East?'' he mused. ''We haven't decided if we want that simultaneous capability.''
The Army, Navy and Air Force offered to Pentagon leaders their plans for meeting the Administration's budget guidelines through 1997. The services projected a significant cutback in forces: active Army divisions would fall to 14 from 18, aircraft carriers to 12 from 14, tactical airwings to 28 from 36. But there would be no changes in basic strategy.
But these were only early salvoes in what is already a contentious review, often pitting service against service and military against civilian leadership, that will last through the year.
''We are planning on the basis of a radical change in the Soviet threat,'' the senior Pentagon official insisted. The changes many critics are proposing ''are not so different from what we're thinking about,'' said the official, who indicated that Pentagon leaders were already considering much deeper cuts in the Army than revealed so far.
 
The Next War
Super Conflict? Or Intervention?
 At least four-fifths of the $300 billion the country will spend this year on the military is devoted to conventional forces: tank battalions, infantry and paratroop units, jet fighters, aircraft carriers and attack submarines that are intended to fight war without a nuclear conflagration. Most of these forces were designed to fight the Soviet Union.
With the Soviet threat receding and the budget shrinking, all the military services are competing for the lead role in future assaults in the third world.
Still, a fight with well-armed countries like Iraq and Syria would require some of the same heavy forces and advanced weaponry needed to fight the Soviets. How well-prepared the country should be for large-scale conflict depends, in the end, on a judgment of the likelihood that it will enter such a war, or that it might at least want to threaten a fight during a showdown.
Former Defense Secretary Brown, who said he would like to see an annual budget ''in the $200 to $250 billion range,'' acknowledged that the smaller active-duty military he advocates would be unable to fight a prolonged war. What this military could do in a crisis, he said, ''is get us there early, put the U.S. on the line.''
He asked: ''Are we prepared, for example, to fight the Iraqis, the Panamanians, the Vietnamese or the North Koreans with more than an early show of air and naval power, and a modest ground force very early to show we're committed? No. We are prepared to play a peripheral role, as we did recently in the Persian Gulf.'' There, the Navy provided escorts for commercial oil tankers in the midst of the Iran-Iraq war.
While a significant mobilization would be required to sustain a major conflict, he said, such a confrontation now appears to be so unlikely that the risk of relying on Reserves is worth running.
More sweeping proposals for reductions have come from Mr. Kaufmann, Robert S. McNamara, a former Defense Secretary, and the Defense Budget Task Force, a private group of 11 former Government officials headed by Lawrence J. Korb, an Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Reagan Administration.
 
More Radical Cuts
These critics say the budget should be halved by the year 2000, to about $150 billion in today's dollars. Such a reduction would require, in addition to the changes envisioned by other experts, the cancellation of many more new weapons and, later in the decade, deeper cuts in active forces, like shrinking the Navy's fleet of aircraft carriers to six or nine, in various plans, instead of the 10 or 12 proposed by many other experts.
Under this approach, the country would still be prepared for minor interventions but not for prolonged heavy fighting. Patrolling of the seas by aircraft carriers would be curbed significantly, with the Navy becoming more of a reactive force. This option also presumes a giant cut in superpower nuclear arsenals and an end to buying new long-range nuclear weapons.
''It's very hard to imagine something that would require more than the eight divisions we had in Korea,'' said Mr. Kaufmann, a Defense Department consultant in the 1960's and 1970's who now teaches at Harvard University. ''It's also hard to imagine more than one contingency of that size, or two lesser contingencies that would happen simultaneously.''
He added, ''And I reject the argument that the Navy performs some pacifying function by floating around the South China Sea or something.''
At least for now, cutting the budget in half appears to go beyond what is regarded as prudent by a majority of the country's leading military strategists, including many critics of the Pentagon.
The huge reductions in Army and Navy forces proposed by some ''amount to saying we are going to defend ourselves and let others defend themselves,'' Mr. Brown asserted.
General Powell warned, ''It's hard to see what's wrong with all of this going down until you have a crisis - until you suddenly have to mass forces to deal with a situation and discover you have to strip from just about everywhere else in the world.''
 
NEXT: The Army and the Air Force redefine their missions.

HEADLINE: States' Prisons Continue to Bulge, Overwhelming Efforts at Reform

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WALLA WALLA, Wash.

 BODY:
Fueled by new laws and stiffer sentences endorsed by an impatient public, the states' prison population grew more than 10 percent last year and began to overwhelm even states like Washington, which had been among the few to avoid overcrowding.
By the year's end, state prisons, after a decade of constant rapid growth, housed a record 644,000 inmates, about 67,000 more than the year before. Federal prisons held 56,500 inmates, an increase of 12,000.
Virtually every state prison system is being pushed beyond its intended capacity despite court orders in 37 states to ease overcrowding. Even $4 billion in new prison construction authorized last year, in addition to $4.4 billion in 1988, cannot keep pace with the growing number of convicted felons, many involved with drugs. 
 
Mushrooming Drug Arrests
In California last winter, the Corrections Department opened two new prisons that added 2,200 beds and brought the state's inmate capacity to 49,800. But that is still 37,000 short of the prison population, with 250 new convicts arriving every week to sleep on cots in gyms and dayrooms. In New York the prison population rose 15 percent in 1989, to 51,234 from 44,559.
The pressures on prisons are a result of mushrooming drug arrests, a decline in paroles and the stiffening of criminal laws to create new classes of felonies. The flood of inmates is forcing many states to examine alternative penalties for nonviolent offenders in an effort to insure that convicts receive at least some punishment and to avoid taking up prison space needed for violent offenders.
Some states, especially Washington, Georgia and Missouri, have made extensive use of alternative punishments like halfway houses and house arrest under the intensive supervision of a probation officer. But the proportion of violent offenders has grown with the rising number of drug arrests, and now many prison systems are hard pressed to find enough nonviolent inmates to qualify for such diversions.
 
'Rent-a-Cell' Programs
Until recently, the alternative strategies were so effective that some states had vacant cells, which they rented out to others for a fee. For instance, Washington had 1,800 Federal inmates and prisoners from other states in its Rent-a-Cell Program last year; at $65 a day per inmate, the state collected nearly $40 million over the past few years.
Missouri leased to other states 800 of the 5,000 prison beds that it built in the mid-1980's. Estimating an increase of 150 inmates a year, officials assumed the new cells would handle Missouri's prison population until nearly the year 2000. But in 1989 the number of prisoners increased 1,600, to 13,437. ''Last year was a disaster,'' said Gail Hughes, Deputy Director of Missouri's Department of Corrections.
The extra cells were used up in a few weeks. And this month the last of 800 prisoners from Illinois, Colorado and the District of Columbia will be shipped home to already crowded prisons.
The situation is even worse in Georgia, widely hailed as the leader in imaginative alternatives to simple but costly prison sentences. ''We're being overwhelmed now simply by raw numbers,'' said Vince Fallin, Deputy Commissioner of the Georgia Department of Corrections.
 
Lock Them Up, But Not Here
Last spring Georgia had 19,300 prisoners and 12,000 slots in other punishment programs, from house arrest to intensive probation. Today Georgia prisons hold 21,000 inmates, with 3,200 waiting in overcrowded county jails and 14,000 new beds under construction. Another 20,000 convicts are enrolled in the diversion programs. And Georgia's problems are just beginning: officials expect the prison population to reach 34,000 in the next 21 months, an increase of more than 60 percent.
At Washington State Penitentiary here, workers are installing four beds in cells where one or two used to be, and the state is making plans for housing 700 inmates beyond the prison's capacity of 1,800. That can be avoided only if each of seven new prisons opens on schedule, starting in 14 months.
Last month the office of Chase Riveland, head of Washington's Department of Corrections, mailed 735 letters to towns, cities, civic leaders and others seeking applications for prison sites. So far, he said, he has received 41 inquiries, mainly from economically strapped communities eager for a new, nonpolluting industry and its jobs. (The prison here pumps $30 million a year into the economy, in everything from wages and potato chip purchases to video rentals for the prison's TV station. Twenty percent of the salaries at the community college cover instruction of inmates.) Officials say many other communities are eager to have the criminals locked up, but not in their backyard.
 
Cells as a Scarce Resource
Washington avoided the crowding problem until now largely by presenting an uncommon question in American penology. In the early 80's, instead of asking why they did not have enough cells, the state's leaders asked why they had so many prisoners. That examination led to an unusual alliance.
Liberals wanted more equity in criminal sentencing; conservatives wanted more certainty in the punishment system. Both were bothered by broad judicial discretion that produced widely divergent sentences for people convicted of identical crimes, and by a parole system that could turn a 20-year sentence into a fraction of that. And both believed that just as the growth of urban traffic always overwhelmed new expressways, endless prison building would not end overcrowding.
''We treat prison cells as a scarce resource,'' Mr. Riveland said. ''It sounds simple, but it's an important distinction.'' The new thinking led to the state's Sentencing Reform Act of 1984, which established a chart for judges to consult.
In the form of a grid, the chart matched the severity of a crime (armed robbery, for instance, as opposed to armed robbery resulting in an injury) with the convict's criminal history. Where the lines meet tells a judge how many months' sentence must be assessed. Inmates sentenced under this system could no longer be paroled; they would serve until their sentences were up.
''It's worked,'' said Mr. Riveland. ''We get not necessarily longer sentences, but longer sentences served. Now, instead of getting 20 years but being released in 3, what you get is what you serve.''
The law kept many less serious offenders out of prison and produced a temporary decline in the inmate population. That, in turn, was filled with boarders from other states.
Mr. Riveland said he had steered more money into intensive supervision and other special programs for those convicted of first and second offenses, hoping to head off more serious problems later. A burglar convicted for the second time, for instance, would serve 30 days in a county jail and spend one year under strict supervision while working. Without parole, Washington also avoids imprisoning parole violators; such offenders make up more than one-third of California's prison admissions.
 
'Cafeteria of Sanctions'
But now Washington's system is feeling the effects of longer terms served by violent offenders, along with sharp increases in drug arrests and reported sexual offenses.
The same is true in Georgia, which for years has offered what Mr. Fallin calls ''a cafeteria of sanctions'' to avoid sending everyone to prison. The state has also invested heavily in speeches, open houses and videos to sell this approach to the news media and the public, which can be leery of anything that smacks of softness toward criminals.
''This is the historic problem in American corrections,'' said Tony Travisono, executive director of the American Correctional Association, the nationwide organization of prison administrators. ''People can see a prison. They don't see treatment or counseling.''
Georgia's diversions for nonviolent offenders include electronic bracelets that keep prisoners under house arrest, regular probation, community service and halfway houses, all of which cost less than boot camps or prisons.
There are some unintended side effects. The removal of so many nonviolent offenders leaves heavier concentrations of violent criminals in the prisons, presenting greater control problems. Such offenders cannot be assigned as ''trusties'' for chores like cooking, cleaning, and grounds and road maintenance; states now have to hire civilian laborers, at greater expense.
Some states have commissioned public opinion surveys to see if average citizens are indeed as retribution-minded as believed. Along with several more years of ambitious prison building, Mr. Travisono sees such re-examinations of old assumptions as crucial.
''Why should probation officers only work from nine to five?'' he asked. ''We could have 24-hour checks on convicts out there holding a job, paying taxes and restitution to their victims. We could have special centers for short-term punishment of parole violators.''
He suggested that traditional procedures and expensive heavy-handed punishments might have to give way to more sophisticated application of a wide variety of sanctions, not only in states that have long been overcrowded but in those that are new to the problem. ''What's important is not the length of a sentence; it's the certainty of punishment,'' he said. ''And we don't need an expensive baseball bat for every wrongdoer.''
