HEADLINE: Bolivians Switch Crops as Coca Market Falls

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ETERAMASAMA, Bolivia

 BODY:
Felix Lazo's harvest of coca leaves lay on the floor of his cinder-block house, unsold because actions against drug dealers and processing laboratories in Bolivia and elsewhere have destroyed the market for the raw material of cocaine.
A hundred pounds of coca today may bring only 15 to 20 bolivianos, the equivalent of $5 to $7, he said, ''and for that I have to carry the bags of leaves up to the crossroads on my back, then pay for transport to market.'' It is a familiar predicament for the small farmers here who produce a third of the world's coca, a crop that once provided a secure cash flow, as much as $400 to $500 for 100 pounds.
Drug experts say the price drop, which has led farmers to plant other crops, is a result of the crackdown on major drug traffickers in Colombia and the relentless assaults on drug laboratories and wholesale buyers of coca paste here in Bolivia.
 
Quick Pace of Substitution
Those actions are believed to have interrupted processing activities and lowered demand for coca leaves. Some of Bolivia's coca is turned into cocaine inside the country and more is processed in Colombia, with virtually all of the marketing done by Colombian dealers. 
''Since the price fell, there is almost nothing for the people here,'' Mr. Lazo said as he led the way through the insects and interminable tropical rain to his remaining patch of coca - about two and a half acres, a third of what he had three years ago. For lack of money, he said, he has stopped fertilizing and spraying it.
Mr. Lazo and other farmers here in the Chapare rain forest, Bolivia's main coca-growing region, have begun to substitute fruit and other crops.
They are doing it at such a quick pace that the aid programs run by the Bolivian Government, the United States, the United Nations and others are unable to keep up with the demand for seeds, plants and eradication payments.
A State Department official in La Paz said that when the United States does its annual aerial survey of drug-producing countries this year, Bolivia will show its first ever decline in total coca acreage.
 
Bolivia's 'Dying Industry'
Drug experts attribute the race to other crops to the almost total collapse in the price of coca leaves in the last six months. Although there are skeptics among them who say they believe that the price drop is temporary or maintain that the farmers are eradicating coca along the roads while going deeper into the jungle to start new seed beds, more of the experts say they believe that in just a few years, Bolivia's part in the cocaine business could be reduced to a minor role.
The State Department official called it a ''dying industry'' in Bolivia. He and other experts said the sharp decline in coca production in Bolivia would not necessarily lower the total supply of cocaine because the Upper Huallaga Valley in Peru, the leading source of coca leaf, is capable of expanded production.
Drug experts in La Paz said the presence of the Shining Path guerrilla organization in Peru greatly inhibited raids and other interdiction activities against drug laboratories and traffickers there. As a result, they said, the price of coca leaf in Peru has not collapsed as in Bolivia, and recent reports from Peru say farmers there are planting more acres in coca than ever before.
But officials say that in the Chapare, farmers have voluntarily dug up more than 8,000 acres of coca plants this year - more than was eliminated in all of 1989 and more than the Government, in an agreement with the United States, promised to eradicate in all of this year. The Chapare was estimated to have 100,000 acres of coca last year.
Some Government officials say they fear that the mass retreat from coca by Bolivian farmers will gather steam faster than economic development programs can find ways to replace the $500 million to $600 million that coca is thought to represent in hard-currency income.
 
A Switch to Rice and Corn
It is the lost income that worries Mr. Lazo and about 40,000 other farmers producing coca in the Chapare. Despite the big money associated with cocaine, their place at the bottom of the ladder earned them an income only slightly above subsistence level. But it was better than most Bolivians had.
Now, the coca farmers say they fear that they and their families will have nothing to eat and and that there will be nowhere to sell the other products that agronomists and extension agents are persuading them to grow.
Down the road from Mr. Lazo, Guillermo Grandon lighted an oil lamp, filled his guests' glasses from a half-gallon bottle of Coca-Cola, and said his ''only hope'' lay in the 750 young plants growing in his greenhouse, including citrus, macadamia, coconut and black pepper. He said he planned to mix them with subsistence crops like rice and corn.
Like his friend Hilario Claros, Mr. Grandon eradicated part of his coca for a one-time payment of $2,000 per 2.5 acres and joined a United States-financed crop-substitution program that helped them start the perennials that they hope will pay off in the future.
 
Limited 'Export Mentality'
Both men traveled to Costa Rica in the last two years under the substitution program to see how small farmers there were succeeding with tropical crops. They returned enthusiastic and have signed on as promoters of the subsitution program to spread the word to others.
''The Costa Rican trip convinced us that this can work,'' said Mr. Claros. ''But it won't work if we don't get some agro-industry in here to process and sell what we produce.''
Jose Decker, who directs the substitution program from offices in Cochabamba, the departmental capital, said his biggest worry was finding markets for the products - citrus, pineapple, macadamia, ginger, pepper, exotic fruits and flowers, and more - that will be pouring out of the Chapare in the next few years.
''The problem is that private national firms in Bolivia have no experience in international marketing,'' he said. ''Except concerning tin and coca, this country has never had an export mentality. Coca, in fact, is the only product that Bolivians have ever exported with value added.''
 
Plan for Macadamia Nuts
Joe Lopez, a New Mexico-born tropical agriculture specialist who serves as a consultant to the crop substitution program, is less worried. He is convinced that as the crops come into production, the markets and processing plants will appear. He said several foreign companies had expressed interest in buying from the Chapare.
Among other things, Mr. Lopez was instrumental in bringing in the macadamia nuts from Costa Rica that are now sprouting into tiny trees in makeshift greenhouses across the Chapare. Although they will not begin to produce for about seven years, he said that world demand for the nuts was strong and growing and that he was convinced that Bolivia can join Hawaii and Costa Rica as major producers. Many farmers are putting their faith in that possibility.
Joaquin Valderrama, head of a local growers' group, complained bitterly about the lack of roads and electricity in the area and the Government's failure to keep promises of help in the past. Then he said he had eradicated half his coca and planned to plant macadamia trees, among other things.
Told that a small container of macadamia nuts costs several dollars in the United States, he said he hoped the price remained high ''because we're going to produce a lot of those nuts.''

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Text of Statement by Baker

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 19

 BODY:
Following is the text of the statement today by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d after talks with Soviet leaders:
 
Four Days of Talks
We have just finished four days of long and detailed talks with President Gorbachev, Foreign Minister Shevardnadze and their colleagues. These have been some of the most intensive discussions we have had with our Soviet counterparts during this Administration. In the end game of negotiations, it is reasonable to expect both the intensity and difficulty of the work to increase. In short, we have been engaged in some heavy lifting to lock in agreements by the summit between President Bush and President Gorbachev. 
I think our discussions have resulted in some real accomplishments, and the progress we have made here makes me optimistic that we will have a productive summit in Washington, beginning less than two weeks from now.
In the five hours of meetings with President Gorbachev, we covered a number of issues, including some arms control, Baltic, and in particular, Lithuanian, desires for independence; German unification; and the Soviet economy. We had a full exchange of views on these issues.
I might just say that in the discussions I had here on Lithuania, the parties expressed a desire to find a way to peaceful dialogue. I can't say at this point that the Soviets and Lithuanians have yet arrived at a common basis on which to proceed. I think they are now more actively seeking to develop that basis, but they are not there yet.
 
Discussions on Start
Let me briefly cover the results of our talks and where our relationship stands as we get ready for the summit.
On Start, our goal has been to reach agreement on the major substantive issues by the summit, and we are now in a position to do so. While some issues remain, we have now reached agreement at this ministerial on what have been two of the most vexing problems we have faced in Start: air-launched cruise missiles and sea-launched cruise missiles. On A.L.C.M.'s, we have agreed to a complicated formula which equitably meets the needs of both sides.
On S.L.C.M.'s, we have agreed to a politically binding declaration which will stand outside of the Start treaty itself. The declaration will enhance both strategic stability and predictability without creating verification difficulties for either side.
We resolved a number of other Start issues and also agreed to begin to work on the objectives for follow-on negotiations on Start.
 
Chemical Arms Accord
On chemical weapons, we have reached agreement on a precedent-setting accord. I believe that this agreement is very significant, particularly as it provides a real pathway toward a global ban on horrific weapons that we already know from bitter experience actually get used.
Very simply put, this U.S.-Soviet accord is a trailblazing agreement that implements the President's initiative on C.W.
On nuclear testing, we have completed work on the protocols to the nuclear testing treaties. These are now ready for signing at the summit.
We also have agreed to a summit joint statement on nuclear, chemical and missile nonproliferation.
The one area where we made less progress in arms control than we had hoped for is C.F.E. We had come with ideas designed to push this process forward, but our counterparts apparently weren't able to respond meaningfully at this time.
On regional issues, we had a full discussion on Afghanistan. I believe we are close to developing a common basis on which to move to free and fair elections - the surest path to reconciliation, peace and legitimacy in that war-torn country.
On Central America, our discussions reaffirmed the importance of continued adherence to Esquipulas and the need to end the insurgency in El Salvador and promote a political dialogue.
On human rights and democratization, we stressed our continuing concern over the remaining refusenik cases in the Soviet Union and the need to resolve all of them as soon as possible. I also raised my concerns about anti-Semitism and the vital need for the Soviet leadership to speak out strongly against it.
We had exchanges on economics, transnational and bilateral issues. We have finalized for signing at the summit several U.S.-Soviet agreements in the commercial area, including the Long-Term Grains Agreement and the Maritime Transportation Agreement.
In terms of transnational and bilateral issues, we are ready to sign a maritime boundary agreement, an agreement on oceans study, an accord to open cultural and information centers in Moscow and Washington, and perhaps others. We also will be able to sign the Thousand-Thousand Agreement - an exchange of a thousand undergraduate students between our countries.
In closing, we have worked to prepare the ground so that our Presidents can lock in and institutionalize mutual points of advantage in our relationship.

HEADLINE: How the Politics Shifted on AIDS Funds

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
The politics of AIDS has fundamentally shifted in Congress, turning lawmakers who once cringed at voting for money to combat the epidemic or assist its victims into vocal supporters of more Federal aid.
Like other political turnarounds, this one reflects a combination of forces: constituent pressures, finely tuned lobbying efforts and a health care crisis too overwhelming to be ignored.
But lawmakers and AIDS lobbying groups say the most powerful factor has been the personal experiences that members of Congress have had with those who suffer from the disease, experiences that have allowed them to see it and address it as a public health issue rather than one defined by morality and life style.
''I think more and more members have been sensitized by people in our own districts and neigborhoods who are afflicted,'' said Representative John Lewis, a Georgia Democrat who is in some ways a symbol of the changing political equation on AIDS. 
 
A Reluctant Involvement
Mr. Lewis is a member of the Congressional Black Caucus. He acknowledged that while individual caucus members have long been quietly supportive of AIDS legislation, the caucus as a group has been reluctant to be publicly involved in the issue.
''AIDS is having a tremendous effect on the black community,'' Mr. Lewis said, ''but people didn't want to talk about it. It was not the issue to raised, to be identified with.''
Now, he said, ''there is no way we can go around anymore saying this is an issue just affecting the gay community. In recent days, the life and death of Ryan White brought it home to many, many people.''
Other lawmakers besides Mr. Lewis cited Ryan White, a hemophiliac who contracted the AIDS virus through a blood transfusion several years ago and died recently at 18. The lawmakers mentioned him as a politically safe symbol of the disease's devastation, a symbol that compelled changing the terms of the debate on providing funds to deal with AIDS.
In comments on the Senate floor last week during debate on an AIDS funding measure, Senator Daniel R. Coats, a conservative Republican from Indiana, Ryan's home state, expressed the broad acceptance that such funding now has. ''Every case of HIV infection is a tragedy, regardless of how contracted,'' he said. ''And I trust that everyone agrees that we must provide every victim who is medically and economically eligible with the best possible treatment.''
Although Congress has steadily increased money for research and education programs over the past seven years, the additional money has generally been provided quietly, as part of broader spending bills that did not require a visible vote on AIDS.
 
'Right Thing to Do'
That began to change in 1988, with passage of the first comprehensive AIDS legislation authorizing increases in research personnel. But the most vivid demonstration of the shift came this week with the Senate's 95-to-4 vote approving a measure to funnel $2.9 billion in emergency relief to hospitals, community-based organizations and home-care programs in cities and states that have been hardest hit by AIDS.
''The last vote on an AIDS issue that lopsided was in 1987, when it went in the opposite direction,'' said Jeff Levi, a political consultant on AIDS assistance. ''What we're seeing is a dramatic reversal of what politicians consider the right thing to do.''
The reversal is also the product of more sophisticated lobbying by those who provide care for AIDS patients. They have spent three years carefully building ties to local elected officials, minority groups and health and medical professionals.
Two years ago, such lobbying efforts were primarily defensive, aimed at blunting opposition to AIDS measures from conservative Republicans like Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Representative William E. Dannemeyer of California, who emphasized that the majority of people with AIDS were either homosexuals or intravenous drug abusers.
But this year, advocates of AIDS assistance were able to take the offensive, building persuasive cases that the public hospital system that provides care for the poor was crumbling under the weight of the epidemic.
 
At the Same Table
''We brought people to the table who don't usually like each other,'' said Jean McGuire, executive director of the AIDS Action Council, an umbrella organization representing providers of services to AIDS patients.
''Everyone had something in this bill,'' she said, referring to the provisions that allocate some relief money directly to hospital clinics and community organizations, and some to the states to distribute.
That approach drew support from unexpected quarters, other lobbyists said, citing Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida. as an example.
''It's an issue that has a major impact on a state like Florida, particularly Miami,'' Mr. Mack said, recalling a recent visit to Jackson Memorial Hospital and his shock at seeing room after room filled with newborns suffering from AIDS.
''Jackson Memorial is the only major provider of care for the indigent in South Florida,'' he said. ''It's having severe financial problems.''
Representative Henry Waxman, a California Democrat who has sought money to battle AIDS since the early 1980's, said the change in the political climate was gratifying. But he worries about whether it is enough.
Both the Senate bill and Mr. Waxman's broader companion measure merely authorize the emergency relief money. In the separate legislation needed to actually provide the money, the AIDS programs will be competing with other needs, and at a time when Congress faces new pressures to cut the budget deficit.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 27, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about increasing Congressional support for helping cities hit hard by AIDS rendered the name of a California Congressman incorrectly in some copies.
He is William E. Dannemeyer Jr.

HEADLINE: 1 Killed in Second Shooting on Montana Campuses

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HELENA, Mont., May 19

 BODY:
A man who appeared to be drunk walked into a college cafeteria and opened fire with a revolver on Friday, killing one college employee and wounding another, the authorities said.
The attack, at Carroll College here, was the second fatal shooting incident on a Montana campus this week. On Tuesday, two students were killed by shotgun blasts at Montana State University in Bozeman, 100 miles southeast of here. A fellow student was arrested several hours later in that case. 
The shooting at Carroll College, a four-year Roman Catholic school with an enrollment of about 1,200 students, occurred at 3:30 P.M. Half an hour later, a man believed to be an unemployed ranch hand was arrested on the campus for investigation of murder. He was identified as Darrell Randall Stahl, 36 years old.
 
Officials Call Attack Random
Mr. Stahl has no known connection to the college, and officials there said they were certain his attack had been random.
A first court appearance for Mr. Stahl was canceled Friday because he appeared intoxicated, said County Attorney Mike McGrath, who added that the authorities were considering charges of murder and attempted murder.
Russ Ritter, the college's vice president for development, said the assailant had ''entered the east door of the Carroll Commons, walked to a group of Carroll employees who were having a coffee break - food service employees - asked them a question about where he could find somebody, and then proceeded to shoot the two individuals.''
The employee who was killed in the attack was identified as Sharon Hance, 52, a secretary for the college. The wounded employee also was a woman, a food service worker for Marriott Foods, which runs the college's cafeteria. The woman, whose name was being withheld, was reported in stable condition today at St. Peter's Community Hospital.
 
Motive in First Shooting Unclear
In the attack on Tuesday at Montana State, Brett Byers, a 19-year-old student, is accused of killing two freshmen in a dormitory. The authorities say Mr. Byers, who is being held without bond, apparently did not know the victims, and, four days after the shootings, they say they still do not know his motive.
Michael Bloom, assistant police chief in Helena, refused to comment on whether Mr. Stahl had known the two women. He said that no motive had been determined but that the police were interviewing a woman who might have been with Mr. Stahl before the shooting.

HEADLINE: News Analysis;
Budget in Albany: Cheers and Fears

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 19

 BODY:
When New York's long-overdue budget received final approval at 4:01 A.M. today, state lawmakers congratulated themselves for having found a solution to the worst financial problems that the state has seen in more than a decade. But critics both inside and outside government say they fear that, even though the budget includes the largest tax increase in the state's history, it will not guarantee balanced budgets in coming years.
This year's excruciating budget process produced a political compromise built on taxes that are neither so equitable nor so reliable as many would prefer. By refusing to raise rates on broad-based taxes like the personal income tax and the gasoline tax, which produce vast revenues but pick the pockets of large numbers of voters, state leaders have left themselves open to charges that they chose election-year expediency over fiscal responsibility. 
''They were afraid to do something concrete that a lot of voters would notice,'' said Matthew P. Drennan, a professor of economics at New York University. ''Ever since the Mondale defeat, I think politicians across the country have been wary of any kind of broad taxes and instead have opted for these emergency taxes.''
 
'Huge Structural Imbalance'
An analyst with the Citizens Budget Commission, Cynthia Green, said the $1.4 billion tax bill, which has been dubbed ''The Big Ugly,'' will do little to solve a structural budget gap created by years of overspending, overborrowing and an unwise reliance on nonrecurring revenue sources.
''When you're looking at a huge structural imbalance,'' she said, ''there's only one way to solve the problem and that's with broad-based taxes.''
This year's budget gap ultimately reached $4 billion. But the tax package forged by the Governor and the Legislature left rates untouched on the state's three broadest taxes - the personal income tax, which would raise almost $1 billion with a 1 percentage point increase in the maximum rate; the sales tax, which last year raised almost $1.4 billion for each of its 4 percentage points, and the 8-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax, which is worth almost $60 million for each penny.
Instead, they agreed on a hodgepodge package of taxes on alcohol, cigarettes, soda containers, ''900 number'' telephone calls, hotel rooms, car rentals, cleaning services, security services and parking garages, as well as imposing a 15 percent surcharge on the corporate income tax and a slew of fee increases. The package, which is supposed to raise $1.4 billion, was approved by the Assembly on Thursday and by the Senate late Friday night.
 
Concern About Package
It was the second year in a row that lawmakers had enacted more than $1 billion in new taxes without touching the state's broad-based taxes.
Given the dearth of hopeful news about the state economy, many budget analysts predict that those taxes will raise too little to maintain spending next year at current levels plus inflation. They are particularly concerned because the state this year largely depleted its supply of nonrecurring revenue sources, like sales of state property and raids on trust funds.
Many fiscal analysts, including the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, also are not yet convinced that this year's tax package will raise the money it is supposed to, meaning the state may have to borrow or cut spending later in the year.
''Many of these taxes are untested, and we don't know at what point the law of diminishing returns starts to take effect,'' Mr. Regan said on Friday. ''The more you tax an activity, the less of that activity you're likely to get.''
 
Political Bombshell
The saga of this year's tax bill opened on Jan. 16, when Gov. Mario M. Cuomo presented his budget for the 1991 fiscal year, which was to begin on April 1. That document projected a $2 billion gap between predicted tax revenues and the spending needed to maintain existing programs at current levels.
Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, proposed closing the gap with about $1 billion in new taxes, with the rest of the hole filled through spending cuts and nonrecurring revenues. His proposal hinged on a political bombshell that ultimately drove more than four months of budget talks - the deferral of the last year of a four-year cut in the personal income tax.
The Republicans who control the State Senate seized on the proposal as a ready-made campaign issue in a year when Mr. Cuomo and all 211 legislators face re-election.
''The tax cut was a Republican initiative, and we weren't easily going to give it up,'' said the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino of Oyster Bay, L.I. ''As Republicans, we have to make a difference or why would people vote for us?''
As the Republicans waged a public relations war to keep the tax cut, the state's fiscal condition began to deteriorate. By the middle of March, Mr. Regan had concluded that the budget gap for the coming year would be $1.5 billion wider than Mr. Cuomo had predicted.
 
'We Made Our Case'
Only after New York's credit rating was dropped to the lowest level in state history did the Republicans concede that the budget gap had grown. Even then, they said the tax cut, which would cost the state $400 million this year and $1.4 billion next year, was sacrosanct.
On April 5, with budget negotiations stalled, Mr. Cuomo and Assembly Speaker Mel Miller gave Mr. Marino the political cover that he wanted by agreeing to phase in the tax cut. To compensate for the lost revenue, the leaders imposed a three-year surcharge on corporate income taxes.
''We made our case and lost,'' said Mr. Cuomo, adding that the Democrats compromised to accommodate ''political expediency'' by the Republicans.
The tax cut agreement, and the growth of the budget gap by an additional $500 million, forced the leaders to look for more taxes and fees.
Mr. Cuomo pushed, although not very hard, for raising the gasoline tax, which is one of the lowest in the country. But higher gasoline taxes were opposed as inequitable by Republicans from upstate New York and Long Island, where driving is closer to a necessity than in the Democratic stronghold of New York City.
Meanwhile, a proposal to place sales taxes on services like consulting and public relations ignited a furor in New York City, where the service sector is the healthiest segment of an otherwise bleak economy. It, too, was scrapped.
Critics said the taxes finally approved were politically palatable because they afford consumers the option of incurring them. Many blasted state leaders for not having the political will to support more farsighted taxes.
''There's going to have to be a restructuring of the budget,'' said Edwin L. Crawford, executive director of the New York State Association of Counties, ''probably by three leaders who have decided not to seek re-election.''

LENGTH: 1029 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
A Loner With a Strong Emotional Center

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. PINCUS; Andrew L. Pincus is the music critic of The Berkshire Eagle in Pittsfield, Mass.

 BODY:
Eduard Tubin is one of music's loners. Estonian by birth, the composer spent the last half of his life in Sweden. He followed no fashions, belonged to no school. When he died in 1982, he left a legacy of 10 symphonies, two operas, two ballets and a variety of concertos, cantatas and works in smaller forms. Virtually none of this music is widely known in the United States.
The release of the 10 symphonies and seven other works on seven Bis compact disks shows that the loss has been ours. In harmonic and expressive range, Tubin's nearest kin are Bartok and Prokofiev. But Tubin speaks with his own voice, which - like Bartok's and Prokofiev's - is that of a 20th-century European uprooted by war, persecution and flight from his homeland. The works on these disks are not merely well crafted; they move strongly and surely toward emotional centers. 
Born in 1905, Tubin studied composition in Estonia and Budapest, where he learned the music of Kodaly and Bartok. Though primarily a composer, he became the conductor of a theater orchestra in Tartu, Estonia, and later married one of the theater's dancers.
Tubin remained in Tartu through the successive Soviet and German occupations of Estonia in World War II. When Soviet forces advanced on the country again in 1944, he and his family fled across the Baltic to Sweden. He spent the rest of his life in Stockholm, but without allegiance to the prevailing avant-garde. Anthony Hodgson's 1984 ''Scandinavian Music,'' one of the few studies in English to deal with Tubin, allots him only one paragraph, which places him outside the ''Swedish line of 20th-century development'' because of his Estonian roots.
It took an Estonian-born conductor, Neeme Jarvi, and a Swedish label, Bis, to bring the music to a wider audience through the recorded cycle. The project was a lengthy one, beginning in the early 1980's, reaching fruition this year and involving four Scandinavian and German orchestras. Bis is issuing the series only as CD's (CD-227, CD-297, CD-304, CD-306, CD-342, CD-351 and CD-401), but LP versions of some of the earlier releases may still be available.
Tautness is the music's most striking quality. The symphonies last about a half-hour each, typically in three movements. Themes reappear from movement to movement in changing contexts and guises, providing a unifying force. Unexpected overlays and juxtapositions of ideas - a kaleidoscope of dance rhythms in the Sixth Symphony, for instance - heighten the drama. Restless energy and a strong rhythmic drive find release in arching melodies, distant fanfares and horn calls, and brooding or spectral touches.
Like Bartok, Tubin draws on his folk heritage, which saturates the music with a resiliency that transcends mere nationalism. Like Prokofiev and Shostakovich, he celebrates the endurance of the human spirit amid the hardships of war.
Especially in the early works, the music is strongly contrapuntal; that and a predilection for surging timpani, trombones and basses sometimes create a bottom-heavy web of sound, as in Hindemith. Some melodramatic and tawdry touches also intrude. Yet there is a clear progression from extroversion and profusion of ideas to introspection and economy of means, with the wartime Symphonies Nos. 3 and 4 as the dividing line. While the First and Second (the ''Legendary'') symphonies suggest Carl Nielsen's ''Sinfonia espansiva'' in sheer exuberance of event, the later works grow sparer and darker, seemingly shadowed by tragedy.
Together with the 1946 Fifth Symphony, the Third and Fourth form a powerful war trilogy. Composed in 1940-42, the Third has the ominous repetitions and epic sweep of Shostakovich's wartime symphonies, though it ends with a march of triumph that recalls the Roman legions' thunderous tread in Respighi's ''Pines of Rome.''
The Fourth was completed in 1943. In a Soviet air raid just before the 1944 premiere in Tallinn, the manuscript was singed when the safe containing it fell into the cellar of the burning theater. The performance went on, but the score finally crumbled and Tubin had to redo it in condensed form in Sweden.
Lyrical and reflective, the Fourth carries only distant echoes of war. Olav Roots, who conducted the Tallinn premiere, said that after the Third's heroic struggles, in the Fourth the Nordic night seems to have ''spread a soft light over the countryside of the homeland, whose features had lost their sharpness in the gloom.'' To end the trilogy, the Fifth Symphony, which draws its lyricism from Estonian folk melody, bursts into exultation.
In the subsequent symphonies Tubin continued to refine his craft. The anguished, restless Seventh is almost a chamber symphony; the Eighth and Ninth look more deeply inward. The Tenth, in one movement like Sibelius's final symphony, is the most concise and introspective of the series.
The shorter works that fill out the disks are equally varied and striking. The suite from the ballet ''Kratt,'' in which a peasant sells his soul to the devil, is colorful and folklike, in the vein of Stravinsky's and Falla's ballets on folk subjects; the Piano Concertino has the brilliance and driving energy of the Prokofiev concertos.
Most remarkable - and atypical - of all is the 1979 ''Requiem for Fallen Soldiers,'' scored for mezzo-soprano soloist, male chorus, organ, drums and trumpet. Recalling Estonia's defeat in a 1919 war of independence, it is at once a dirge and an expression of patriotism. A Swedish student choir sings it radiantly.
The Swedish Radio Symphony, Gothenburg Symphony Orchestra, Bergen Philharmonic Society and Bamberg Symphony do not always have the seamless finish and blend of the best European and American orchestras, but under Mr. Jarvi's direction they have something more important - fire and conviction. The Bergen performance of the Fourth Symphony is outstanding. It is the 1981 premiere of Tubin's revision, recorded live, and the playing pours out of the speakers like molten lava.
The recorded sound loses focus on some disks, but never enough to interfere with listening. The records whet the appetite to hear our American orchestras play these absorbing works.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
AFTER OPULENCE, A NEW 'LITE' ARCHITECTURE

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER

 BODY:
This is not an age with any consensus about style: for all that certain ideologues may claim otherwise, the 90's are starting out to be as eclectic as the 80's. There is still plenty of post-modernism, there is still plenty of late-modernism, and there is still every possible thing in between. But one thing is coming to stand out, and it is less a style than a sense that architecture is going to be asking less of us, whatever form it takes.
If the Reagan years were symbolized by a kind of opulence, by a grandiose classicism that masqueraded as the latest thing but was in fact not much more than a wallowing in traditional forms of luxury, the Bush years are going to be characterized by pulling back. Architecture and design won't be reversing course so much as pulling in their reins, moving back to a kind of undemanding ease. Stripped down, simplified, basic and, above all, easy: after a generation of architecture that, whatever its style, has been consistently intense, we are going to see a lot more things that are not intense at all, but laid back and comfortable. In an age of ''lite'' beer, ''lite'' cuisine, lightweight laptop computers and lite-FM, does it not make sense that it should all culminate in lite architecture? 
Almost everything built today in the commercial landscape looks, feels, and often is, light in weight. Traditionally, architecture has been associated with bulk, with a feeling of great weight and substance. But buildings now almost never have a sense of heft: like cars, clothes, telephones, electronics and everything else, they have quite literally been becoming lighter, smaller and more compact for more than a generation. Compare the sleek metal facade of Citicorp Center in New York to the limestone walls of Rockefeller Center: Citicorp, finished in the late 1970's, seems so light it could float up to the sky, while Rockefeller Center, built in the 1930's, seems anchored to the ground.
It's not merely a matter of building materials. Metal and glass, which are inherently lighter in weight and feel than stone, are hardly new to the last few years. Indeed, in the last decade the trend in architecture has moved away from these materials and back to stone and masonry. But even where we do build in stone, we build lightly. Stone today isn't the same as stone a generation or two ago. It's a thin veneer, a lightweight wafer applied to the surface, sometimes barely thicker than the polished metal it so often resembles. Technology now permits stone to be cut nearly as thin as salami, which dramatically changes our perceptions of what this material - once the very embodiment of architectural solidity - can mean.
Lite architecture is happening everywhere, from cities to small towns to sprawling developments beside the freeways. But a few New York skyscrapers can start to show what all this thinness can do to our traditional perceptions of architecture. One, Worldwide Plaza by David Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, finished in 1989, is a classical tower topped by a copper-clad pyramid, a frank attempt to replicate the spirit of the great romantic skyscrapers of the 1920's. But where many of the great buildings of the 1920's seemed almost to have been carved out of solid stone, Worldwide Plaza's granite lower floors are more like stone wallpaper. It looks almost as if it could be peeled off.
Worldwide Plaza is to architecture what ''lite classical'' is to music: easy listening, comfortable, lacking in either heft or challenge. (Here it's worth excepting the building's splendid elliptical arcade, the one place where Worldwide Plaza soars to genuine monumentality and true architectural strength.) There's another side to lite architecture in the I.B.M. tower by Edward Larrabee Barnes, finished in 1983, where thin slabs of green granite have been polished finely and applied to the structure to create a sleek, smooth surface that looks for all the world like metal. The building has a cantilevered corner, so the whole skyscraper is rather like a ballet dancer balanced on point. Here, there is no attempt to try to make old-style classicism out of new-style thin stone veneer. Instead, everything in this tower, from the stone trying to look like metal to the building trying to look as if it were leaping in the air, is all directed toward making it look and feel light.
And there are plenty of less ambitious versions of these buildings, architecture that is lighter still, so to speak. Similar to Worldwide Plaza, but lacking its strengths, is the Americas Tower by Swanke, Hayden & Connell, now under construction, where thin slices of granite have been assembled in a skyscraper that tries to echo the mood of the setback towers of the 1930's - buildings that had a visual weight to them that this one can only pathetically yearn for. And a block away from that building's site at 45th Street and Avenue of the Americas is a new tower of mirrored glass on Fifth Avenue that shows the other aspect of lite architecture; it is so weightless in appearance that you wonder whether it should be tied down.
Where did lite architecture come from? The roots would seem, at first, to lie in modern architecture, which since the 1920's has sought a kind of visual lightness, sometimes even to the point of transparency, as a way of celebrating 20th-century technology and of breaking away from the heavy, dark architecture of the Edwardian age. Le Corbusier lifted his buildings off the ground on ''pilotis,'' or columns, to prove their lightness; Mies van der Rohe struggled to make many of his buildings appear almost to float.
But all that is light architecture, not lite architecture. What we are seeing now is less a continuation of modernism's long march toward lightness of form and structure than a move toward lightness of image. Modernism was light in appearance and often light in weight, but it was quite the opposite of lightweight: it was among the most intellectual of architectures, its esthetic among the most demanding in terms of the relationship of form to idea.
 
Light in Weight And Lightweight
 Today's light, or lite, architecture isn't like that. Its goal is to reduce intellectual demand, not increase it. Its real parent is not modernism at all, but the stage set, the idea that architecture is a matter of facades crafted primarily for quick and easy pleasure. Take the ever greater ability of modern technology to make almost everything lighter and lighter, thinner and thinner, and cross it with the hedonistic sensibility of the stage set, and it's no wonder that architecture now is light in weight and lightweight: light visually, light physically and light intellectually.
Lite architecture couldn't have come without both conditions: new technologies, which make materials so light and thin they have ever less substance to them, and the image-conscious culture of the last few years, which has sought a kind of continuous easy visual fix. Together they make a potent combination. We look at architecture now almost the way we look at television - demanding new images, new pictures, new scenes, all the time. Image is not only more important than reality: in a sense image is reality in our culture, a reality that comes faster and faster, in ever more facile form.
The idea that there is merit to a building possessing substance - physical or intellectual substance - seems to be fading rapidly. How long has it been since a critic has praised a building by calling it solid, by thinking of it in terms of gravity and permanence, by saying something like Louis Sullivan's wonderful comment about Henry Hobson Richardson's Marshall Field store, that it ''stood like a man, a virile force''? Architecture, like the movies, is entertainment, and it is increasingly judged by the same standard.
And that, in the end, is the real problem. It's not that all architecture must be Serious, Important and Intellectually Demanding. Given that we must live with architecture in a way that we do not have to live in constant exposure to serious art, literature or music, it's perfectly reasonable that it not challenge us intellectually at every turn. But if the architecture that surrounds us does not exist primarily to make the intellectual demands upon us that great art does, neither is it merely a passing piece of entertainment, there to play on our emotions and then be forgotten. At its best architecture is a nurturing and civilizing force, and it is with us not for a passing moment, but forever.
 
Modern, But Not Modernist
 It should be said that the most creative late modern architecture, the high-tech buildings of Norman Foster and Richard Rogers, or the so-called deconstructivist work of architects like Peter Eisenman and Bernard Tschumi, is not what I am talking about here. This work - buildings like Mr. Rogers's Lloyds headquarters in London or Mr. Eisenman's Wexner Center in Columbus, Ohio - possesses great intellectual ambition, whatever its sense of physical lightness, and a lot of it can be justified as an attempt to evolve a demanding and serious esthetic out of the technological capabilities of our time: to show that there can be great architectural power in light, tensile structure. At the very least, the brilliance of architects like Mr. Foster and Mr. Rogers stands as a stunning reproof to those who would automatically equate a sense of physical lightness with intellectual lightness.
No, the real lite architecture is rarely modernist, and more often it is quite the opposite: those post-modernist or traditionally styled buildings that try to convey the sense of gravity and substance of older kinds of architecture without possessing any of their weight. We now make classical moldings out of Fiberglas, and facades out of synthetic materials intended - from a distance - to look like stone or wood or precast concrete (which is itself, of course, a kind of imitation stone). From close up it's another matter.
Take, for example, the Home Savings Bank headquarters in downtown Los Angeles, designed by Tim Vreeland of the firm of A. C. Martin. This office building bears a more than casual resemblance to the Plaza Hotel in New York. But unlike the Plaza, whose facade of brick and stone has a magnificent, sumptuous presence, the Home Savings building is sheathed in a cheap precast concrete material, its very thinness completely at odds with the image the architect is hoping to convey. It's not so much the Plaza as a quick and facile attempt to evoke the aura of the Plaza.
 
Architecture As Aura
 Architecture as aura: maybe that's what lite architecture is. Graham Gund, like Tim Vreeland an architect of considerable sophistication, has been seduced into playing the same game in several projects in New England, like the Golden Eagle Lodge and Waterville Valley Town Square in Waterville Valley, N.H., an amiable, rambling, vaguely Victorian resort hotel with an adjacent set of clapboard, dormered buildings housing retail stores, or his Village Commons at South Hadley, Mass., an even more blatantly picturesque cluster of evocative, old-style wooden retail buildings.
It's hard not to like these buildings: they are gracious, welcoming, friendly, and full of the traditional spirit of a New England town. Compared to the city-destroying malls out on the highway, projects like Graham Gund's represent all the right values. But it's equally hard not to think of all of this as a bit too easy, a bit too right - a bit too much like Disneyland. Like Robert A. M. Stern, whose shingle-style houses, eclectic academic buildings and commercial structures have made him at this point probably the American master of evocative architecture, Mr. Gund is smart enough to know how to mix his details well, and include a modicum of eccentricity to make the whole place feel a little more real and a little less pat. But it is still lite architecture however you cut it: the built world's equivalent of easy-listening music.
I keep coming back to Disney, not to disparage this work but to place it in its proper category. The Walt Disney Company is perhaps our most brilliant packager of architectural experience today, creating remarkable environments that, like Mr. Gund's town squares and Mr. Stern's houses and hotels, evoke the aura of a comfortable, idyllic world. We wallow in Disney architecture; it is often more satisfying than the real thing that inspired it. But part of the satisfaction comes from knowing that it's all a game, an amusing frolic through a vast architectural folly. Walt Disney World and Disneyland have to be lite architecture: if they were not, the whole spirit of these places would evaporate. Buildings like Mr. Stern's exuberant casting center for Disney in Orlando, half cartoon, half Venetian palazzo, make perfect sense.
But real life isn't the same as the world inside Disney's gates. It demands to be more - well, real. That doesn't mean its architecture has to be harsh or shrill, and it doesn't mean it has to be inaccessible to the average person who uses it. This is not an argument against using historical styles, or against making buildings inviting and friendly. But there is a point, hard to pin down but very real, at which architecture can become so soft, so inviting, so intensely eager to be liked that it comes off as cute more than anything else, and loses a sense of credibility in the real world. To be picturesque is one thing; to be cuddly is quite another.
The landscape these days is full of things that cross the line from the picturesque to the cute, as architecture everywhere becomes more and more like Disney's. (The Walt Disney Company itself has become a major architectural patron, hiring architects like Michael Graves and Robert Stern to do its buildings - a program that has succeeded not only because Disney has reached out to the world of architecture but because the world of architecture had been becoming so much more Disney-like anyway.) And thus we have instant classical office buildings with pasted-on pediments, mirror-glass Gothic, and Georgian houses in the suburbs masquerading as major architectural statements that are little different, in the end, from the builders' colonials that are still mass-produced all over the place. It's the glibness of it all that is so disturbing, and the implicit belief underlying it that our age has no greater mission than to get a quick fix from the past. There's always been plenty of facile historicism in ordinary roadside architecture, but never has architecture with serious ambitions been so close in spirit to it.
 
Sweetness That Passes for Profundity
 What's the answer to all this? It's worth remembering that the best architecture produced today - the work of architects like Robert Venturi, Frank Gehry and James Stirling, to name but three - follows no precise models. It is consistently energetic visually, but it is also consistently challenging; Mr. Venturi in particular has evolved an approach that accepts the thinness and lightness that are endemic to our age, and uses them brilliantly as the basis for ironic and often profound architectural gestures. But all these architects, when they use historical form, do so inventively, and almost never descend to the sentimental. That, I think, is the problem with lite architecture - like the music on a lite-FM station, it appeals mainly to sentiment. It is less Mozart than Henry Mancini, oozing sweetness that passes for profundity. Not every building can or should be a challenging foreground object, of course, and fitting into an existing urban fabric can be a noble goal for a work of architecture. But lite architecture doesn't even give us a very satisfying background, for the very reason that it can often be glib, even cloying. It isn't the truly discreet background architecture that we need, since it's too eager to have us love it. Lite architecture may pretend to neutrality, but it's a disingenuous act: this is architecture that wants to leap to the foreground.
It's obvious that we're not going to turn back the clock so far as technology is concerned: once we can slice stone like salami, economics will never again permit us to think of it as a slab 10 inches thick. We will have to accommodate to a new sense of what integrity of this material means. Similarly, Fiberglas is not going to go away, and we are going to see more and more traditional details crafted in it. As the 19th century accommodated itself to the shocking idea of classical columns made out of cast iron, so will we have to integrate certain technological developments into our basic architectural perceptions.
The cast-iron buildings, of course, turned out to be among the architectural triumphs of the 19th century. They created a powerful new urban landscape that still holds sway over us today. Will we be able to do as well with the technology of today? We are struggling toward a light architecture - but so far, what we have mainly produced is its sentimental sibling, lite architecture.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY;
THE ECONOMY

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:

Dealing With the Deficit - Sort Of
 
If the suit doesn't fit, why lose weight when you can let out the pants instead? Budget negotiators appear likely to loosen the Gramm-Rudman deficit strictures and disregard the cost of the savings-and-loan bailout. They agreed on Thursday that cutting the budget more than $60 billion would risk a recession. But White House and Congressional leaders quarreled over just how wide a budget gap they have to close. James R. Jones, the American Stock Exchange chairman and former House Budget Committee chairman, says that despite all the posturing, Democratic lawmakers and a Republican President can compromise on taxes and spending as readily as they did in 1982. With a presidential election in 1992, he warns, ''If they don't put together a major package this year, they probably won't be able to until 1993.'' 
 
 
Those Crazy Inflation Figures
 
Last Wednesday's inflation report caused more joy on Wall Street than in Washington. Consumer prices in April rose just two-tenths of 1 percent, after rising at an 8.5 percent annual rate for the first three months. The April results, said Albert T. Sommers, a senior fellow at The Conference Board, ''correct a misappraisal of the inflation condition that arose from those crazy figures during the first quarter.'' Traders said they had already bid bonds up in anticipation of favorable news. But the Federal Reserve Board entered the financial markets on Thursday to signal that it is not about to ease credit, and a board member said the Fed's policies have been unchanged for six months.
 
 
Trade Worsens, Markets Shrug
 
United States exports set a record in March, but imports went higher still. The result was an $8.4 billion trade deficit, up $2.3 billion from February. March exports reached $33.3 billion even though aircraft shipments, a strong category of late, were lower. News of higher trade deficits used to convulse the financial markets, but no longer. Economists had expected a better report, but they noticed that the March figure was still an improvement over the trend last year. Said Richard S. Peterson, chief economist at Continental Bank, ''Overall, we're doing pretty well.''
 
 
Give Me Your Poor
 
Nathan Glazer said last week that, in ''Beyond the Melting Pot,'' he and Daniel P. Moynihan failed 30 years ago to anticipate a new wave of American immigration. The latest figures from the United Nations Population Fund suggest that immigration from poorer nations is likely to intensify. Last week, the agency raised its growth projections, estimating the world's population at 5.3 billion now, with 6.25 billion expected by the end of the century and more than 10 billion in 2025. And while the numbers in wealthier nations level off, poorer nations will expand to 80 percent of the world's people in the year 2000 - causing more residents of these nations to leave. Said Nafis Sadik, the report's author and the fund's executive director, ''The push from the southern countries to the northern countries will increase dramatically.''
 
 
In Brief
 
A bill drafted by the House Commerce Committee - and said to reflect the wishes of its chairman, John D. Dingell - would weaken local cable television monopolies and allow the Government to limit rates.
 
 
Another Leveraged van Gogh
 
Another van Gogh, another auction record, and maybe this time the painting won't have to be repossessed. Van Gogh's ''Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' was sold for $82.5 million at Christie's last Tuesday, reportedly to a Japanese paper executive, Ryoei Saito. The last record, $53.9 million for van Gogh's ''Irises,'' in 1987, was set when Sotheby's agreed to provide 50 percent financing for Alan Bond of Australia. When Mr. Bond failed to come up with enough cash, the painting had to be resold. Mr. Saito told a Japanese newspaper that he, too, needed to borrow. No wonder, because on Thursday he bought a Renoir for $78.1 million. But his loan is secured by more than the paintings, probably because the lender is a bank. The problem with leveraged buyouts of paintings is, you can't sell off pieces to pay debts.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
German Unification: Who Pays?
 
A dowry of $70 billion will help pay for German matrimony. West Germany agreed last week to raise this much to rebuild East Germany's economy. On Friday, the two nations signed a treaty to form a single economic entity on July 2. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has hinted that the first all-German elections could take place Dec. 2. West German leaders say that selling bonds and raising equal amounts from the federal and state governments will avert the need for higher taxes. Nonsense, say Mr. Kohl's opponents, who accuse him of understating costs and hiding a tax plan. Charles Gati, a professor at Union College, told American business leaders at a symposium last week that East Germany will achieve an ''economic miracle,'' but ''whether West Germany can afford this is another question,'' he said. ''I'm very bullish on East Germany and very bearish on West Germany.''
 
 
Soviet Foot Is Inside the Door
 
The Soviet Union has won a trial membership in the international capitalist club. On Wednesday, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade agreed to grant the Soviet Union observer status. The Soviets can attend meetings, but not vote or enjoy reduced tariffs on their exports. For them to achieve full membership, they need to get the hang of free trade and open markets. It might take years, says Herbert S. Levine, a Soviet specialist at the University of Pennsylvania. But the Soviets seem willing to wait. They have been lobbying to enter GATT and the International Monetary Fund since 1986 - even before a faltering economy made their case more desperate. ''When they started talking about involvement in I.M.F., they would have been a lender,'' Prof. Levine said. ''Now they would probably qualify as a borrower.''
 
 
 
CONPANIES
 
Chips Ahoy
 
The technology to make the world's most sophisticated computer chips will remain under United States ownership. The Perkin-Elmer Corporation announced on Tuesday that it was selling its chip-making machine division to the Silicon Valley Group. Perkin-Elmer had held talks with the Nikon Corporation, raising fears that the United States would depend on Japan for equipment to make advanced semiconductors. The International Business Machines Corporation, the division's major customer, orchestrated the sale.
 
 
Debt Traps
 
Circle K crashes, Charter Medicalloses altitude. Analysts say both companies owe many of their woes to the craze for restructuring and debt. Circle K filed for bankruptcy protection Tuesday. Acquisitions financed by ''junk bonds'' made it the nation's second-largest chain of convenience stores. Management tried to increase profits amid growing competition by raising prices and hoping customers wouldn't notice. The junk bond prices went in the opposite direction, to less than 20 cents on the dollar last week.
 
*
 
The Charter Medical Corporation lost $53.7 million in the first quarter, causing some analysts to ask whether it could keep paying its debts. The company, which runs psychiatric hospitals, went private in a leveraged buyout in 1988.
 
 
Dressing Up a Stock
 
Playboy Enterprises Inc. wants men with an eye for women to buy its magazines, not necessarily its shares. The company said last week that the nude form of Willy Rey, the February 1971 Playmate, will no longer appear on its stock certificates. Of Playboy's 28,000 stockholders, 14,000 had bought just one share. ''We were spending about $100,000 annually servicing those shareholders,'' said Terri Tomcisin, the manager of corporate communications. The company plans to cash all the single-share owners out. In a recapitalization plan, other investors will be issued new certificates with a female figure - clothed - that looks more statue-like than statuesque.
 
 
Car Campaign Gets Real
 
Nissan called it ''building up brand awareness.'' Madison Avenue called it a spaced-out joke. The ''Nature'' campaign for Nissan's Infiniti luxury cars has ended, with rocks and waves and buds finally being replaced by advertisements that feature cars. Not to worry about the Zen-like quiet and tranquility in the showrooms, say executives of the Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc. advertising agency. Toyota's rival Lexus might be selling many more cars, but Infiniti, they say, has penetrated more deeply into consumer consciousness.
 
 
Philips Meets Japan
 
American companies aren't the only ones rattled by competition from the Japanese. Cornelis J. van der Klugt was forced out as chairman of Philips N.V. on Monday, about two weeks after the company announced a 97.3 drop in operating earnings for the first quarter. Mr. van der Klugt, who had predicted earnings would rise, has said that his company has trouble matching Japan's labor costs. Analysts say that the Dutch company also has been slower than the Japanese to transform its inventions - the videocassette recorder, the compact disc - into popular consumer products. Mr. van der Klugt is being replaced by Jan D. Timmer, the director of the consumer-electronics division and a respected cost-cutter.
 
 
In Brief
The Pan Am Shuttle is for sale. The Pan Am Corporation plans to sell the shuttle and some German operations to help compensate for continuing losses.
 
*
 
S. Parker Gilbert announced his retirement as chairman of Morgan Stanley & Company on Thursday. He led the firm through Wall Street's boom in the 1980's while avoiding the industry's recent bust. He has picked Richard B. Fisher, the company's president, to succeed him.
 
*
 
Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is considering whether to revive the Lehman Brothers name for its investment banking business. The company would keep the Shearson name for its brokerage.

The New York Times

SECTION: Section 3; Page 13, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2610 words

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Poland's 'Big Bang': Too Much Too Fast?

BYLINE: By JEFF MADRICK; Jeff Madrick, a correspondent for NBC Television, recently returned from Poland.

 BODY:
I have just returned from Poland where I met with many of its leading economists and politicians. From the vantage point of the United States, it may look like that country's commitment to a quick transition to a market economy, which some call the ''big bang,'' is universal. But my discussion with economists and politicans in Warsaw, revealed that some Polish leaders think the pendulum has swung too far too fast.
While there are sharp divisions among the economic and political leadership of Poland, their backgrounds and training are remarkably similar.
Poland has a long tradition of academic dissent and Warsaw University professors have long provided the impetus behind the partial reforms that began in Poland as far back as 1956. This tradition still holds. Virtually every high-level official in the Government holds a doctoral degree in economics from either Warsaw University's economics department or its School of Planning and Statistics. The latter was the academic home of one of Europe's most prominent economists, Michael Kalecki, Eastern Europe's equivalent of John Maynard Keynes: an ardent critic of capitalism and a supporter of government planning. 
There are few precedents for making the transition from a planned economy to a market economy. But some economists say the course which the Government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and Leszek Balcerowicz, the Minister of Finance, have been pursuing is too harsh.
As a result of the program put into place by Mr. Balcerowicz in the first three months of this year, Poland's industrial production sank a stunning 30 percent from the previous year's levels. Incomes after inflation are down even more and unemployment, once unheard of, is rising rapidly.
''This kind of shock therapy has typically only worked under authoritarian governments,'' said Andras Blaho, a United Nations specialist on Poland.''
The pain, members of the new Government told me, is the price that must be paid for transforming Poland's economy into a market economy.
In the face of a tenfold increase in prices, the 43-year-old Mr. Balcerowicz, who is also Deputy Prime Minister, slashed the budget deficit, clamped down on money and credit, set prices almost completely free to float to market levels, restricted wages and sharply devalued the Polish currency, the zloty. Why the abrupt policy? ''I know of no example of any country in the world that stopped hyperinflation gradually,'' he said.
Because of these harsh measures, the leadership in Warsaw and the Polish people are asking two questions: Will sweeping free-market reforms work? And more important, how long will they take?
Mr. Balcerowicz long ago departed from the Kalecki tradition of economics at Warsaw University. As an academic, he was able to speak out in favor of a market economy even when the Communists ruled in Warsaw.
''Professors like Balcerowicz could talk about a free market in the classroom, in discussion groups, at conferences, quite openly, as long as it was all hypothetical,'' said Andrzej Wroblewski, a Balcerowicz supporter and editor of Gazeta Bankowa, a leading financial publication in Warsaw.
Academic dissent remains as strong as ever, however, and Mr. Balcerowicz has many vocal critics inside Poland, even among supporters of free markets. Grzegorz Kolodko is the head of the Finance Institute, a Polish think tank, and he says Mr. Balcerowicz's claim that the new measures were necessary to combat hyperinflation were an exaggeration. ''What hyperinflation? We only had hyperinflation for a few months,'' he says. ''Israel and Vietnam had it for years.''
Zdzislaw Sadowski, president of the Polish Economic Society, an influential professional association, and Ryszard Bugaj, a member of Solidarity, the Polish trade union movement, and head of the budget committee in Parliament, worry that the severity of the economic program will only make matters worse later on. ''The Government promised too much,'' said Mr. Bugaj. ''Inflation could come back even stronger,'' said Mr. Sadowski.
Mr. Balcerowicz's critics trace his conversion to the big-bang to the influence of the Harvard University economist Jeffrey Sachs, who advised the Bolivian Government to apply a similar all-or-nothing solution and later became a key adviser to Solidarity.
Mr. Sachs predicted that if the Polish experiment fails, free markets are in danger throughout Eastern Europe.
''Some Government economists have fallen too much under the influence of Western economists,'' said Mr. Sadowski, who was once a deputy prime minister and is now the leader of the older economic guard.
Mr. Balcerowicz's critics see in him the dangers of a romantic ideologue, and in the program merely a highly fashionable equal-and-opposite reaction to what preceded it.
Many of the economists I talked with believe the greatest gift the Government could have given the Polish people would have been to learn patience. It is necessary, they say, for the Polish people to understand that economic reform will take time.
The following people are Poland's leading economic thinkers.
 
Leszek Balcerowicz
Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister
Mr. Balcerowicz, 43, received his doctorate from the Central School of Planning and Statistics in Warsaw and an M.B.A. from St. John's University in Queens, New York. Long a proponent of free markets as a Warsaw University professor, Mr. Balcerowicz is the chief architect of Poland's stringent new economic program. He is considered by many an extremist whose main priority is the control of inflation, and whose economic heroes include the monetarist economist Milton Friedman and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Some of his critics think this is a sign of his naivete. But Mr. Balcerowicz insists his is the only practical way to move towards serious reforms. His current concern is that the Polish Government will make concessions too quickly, end the restrictions on wages and Government spending and create another round of hyperinflation. He says there are signs this spring that the Polish economy is stabilizing, and he believes the level of pain is exaggerated. In a society that once had shortages, a fall in real income is not a fair measure of consumer welfare, he says.
Mr. Balcerowicz's current posts are his first formal positions in government; he has been active in past reform movements. He maintains his philosophy is self-taught, but he is a close associate of Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard. Although he was not the first choice of Mr. Mazowiecki, he now enjoys the Prime Minister's support. Most believe Mr. Balcerowicz has no more than an additional six months to turn the economy back toward growth. He has made one concession to critics, adopting what Westerners call an industrial policy. He has recently set up two agencies to help corporations ''with good prospects'' avoid bankruptcy caused by current tight credit policies. Some think this will inevitably pave the path towards considerable government intervention. For Mr. Balcerowicz, the next big step is to manage the privatization of industry.
 
Wladyslaw Baka
President of the National Bank of Poland
The National Bank of Poland is the country's central bank, and Mr. Baka, 53, is its president. He is a former member of the Politburo with a doctorate from Warsaw University in economics. A participant in economic reforms throughout the 1980's who once lost a Government post for his outspokenness, Mr. Baka is a strong proponent of the new reforms, though not as extreme as Mr. Balcerowicz. ''I have passed from the middle,'' he said about his position on reform, ''to somewhere between the middle and the extreme.'' He said the German Bundesbank's strong anti-inflationary policies are now the model for Poland's central bank.
Mr. Baka says his principal objective is to defend the currency. It is a goal with which Mr. Balcerowicz agrees. Mr. Baka also insists it is important to maintain ''real positive interest rates,'' another key part of Mr. Balcerowicz's reforms.
Mr. Baka is working to develop a banking infrastructure suitable for foreign investors. The lack of such a structure at the present time is a frequent complaint among foreign investors otherwise interested in Poland. He believes strongly in Government support for companies on the verge of bankruptcy. He does not believe the Polish economic reforms can succeed without compromise on repaying Poland's onerous foreign debt. He notes that West Germany is the principal creditor, which adds a political dimension to the issue of debt reduction.
 
Zdzislaw Sadowski
President of the Polish Economic Society
Mr. Sadowski, 65, is head of the Polish Economic Society, a leading professional association where Mr. Balcerowicz once held a high post. Mr. Sadowski is a former deputy prime minister with a doctorate from the Central School of Planning and Statistics, where he worked with the economist Michael Kalecki.
Mr. Sadowski is a leader of the older guard who supports free markets but favors a far more gradual pace of reform. He thinks the Government will eventually compromise on wages and credit policies, and proposes that they do it sooner than later.
But Mr. Sadowski worries that the current measures are so punishing that inflation will come back stronger once these measures are lifted. His principal theoretical argument is that Poland has no free enterprise structure to fall back on and no experienced level of business management that knows how to adjust to market forces. Just because the currency is stabilized and the costs of business are reduced, he says, does not mean that business will be restored. ''We don't know what the floor is for the Polish economy,'' he said. ''Paul Volcker came here with a group, and he said of course you must go through a recession. That is very naive about our economy. We won't just bounce right back.'' Mr. Sadowski added: ''The economy cannot fall by 30 percent for the entire year; there will have to be changes.''
 
Ryszard Bugaj
Chairman of the Budget Committee of Parliament
A member of Solidarity, Mr. Bugaj, 45, is the head of the finance and budget committee in Parliament. He holds a doctorate from Warsaw University's economics department. Mr. Bugaj is the leading Parliamentary critic of the new economic reforms and favors a more gradual appoach to change.
He said the Government's promise that economic pain will be short-lived is too optimistic. He is concerned with the ultimate reaction of the Polish people to change if the reforms are not successful. However, he acknowledges that the reforms have produced two successes: the currency is now stable and people work harder.
''Worker productivity was a big problem in Poland,'' he said. He says he is not impressed by the cuts in interest rates and inflation so far, and contends they are still too high. He is an important figure in the debate on privatizing the economy. He says he believes the Polish people can learn to become entrepreneurs, but says the principal problem with privatization is the scarcity of capital. ''Who is going to buy the businesses?'' he asked. He is among Poland's most popular politicians, more for his intelligence and sincerity than for his oratory. His political speeches are generally considered dull.
 
Grzegorz Kolodko
Polish Finance Institute
At 40, Mr. Kolodko is Poland's young Turk. He is head of the Finance Institute, Poland's economic think tank. He has a doctorate from the Central School of Planning and Statistics in Warsaw.
Mr. Kolodko largely believes in the same free-market objectives as Mr. Balcerowicz. However, he says the program is moving too quickly and mistakes are being made. ''They raised interest rates for borrowers,'' he said angrily, ''but they did not raise rates nearly as much for savers.''
Mr. Kolodko does not subscribe to Mr. Balcerowicz's view that hyperinflation can only be stopped abruptly. He has visited Vietnam and Israel, where he says progress against soaring inflation has been made more gradually. He is also concerned that the Government's implicit promises have been too optimistic.
''Privatization will take years, not months,'' he said. He points out that similar reforms in Chile took nine years of strong measures, unequal distribution of income and the force of an autocratic government.
Mr. Kolodko is a critic of Harvard's Jeffrey Sachs, saying his success in Bolivia does not apply to Poland. ''In Bolivia the industrial sector is far less important than it is in Poland,'' he said. Mr. Sachs response is that he proposes different solutions for different economies, and he does not think Vietnam's reforms have been all that gradual.
 
Jerzy Osiatynski
Minister of the Central Office of Planning
A disciple of Michael Kalecki, Mr. Osiatynski, 46, is Minister of the Central Office of Planning. He worked toward a doctorate in economics at the Central School of Planning and Statistics but was deprived of his Ph.D. in a 1968 ''revisionist'' purge that some claim was also anti-Semitic.
Mr. Osiatynski is a proponent of the new economic principles of free markets and entrepreneurialism, but he believes the state's role will remain important; he is a stronger proponent of government intervention than Mr. Balcerowicz and is considered among the more traditional of the cabinet ministers concerning the role of government planning.
Mr Osiatynski is editor of the collected works of Michael Kalecki, to be published by Oxford University Press later this year.
''Kalecki's ideas about central planning were very progressive for his times,'' he said, ''but we no longer believe this. Now, entrepreneurs are the key.''
But Mr. Osiatynski does not think free markets are the complete answer. ''Labor was not regulated by completely free markets in Japan and it worked very well,'' he said. He favors privatization but also notes that private capital to purchase companies will be scarce ''Ninety percent of employment is still in the Government,'' he pointed out. He said some industries should remain in Government hands: ''the infrastructure, railway transportation, electric power and maybe some part of telecommunications should be controlled by Government.'' Unlike Mr. Bugaj, he believes changing the attitude of the people towards doing business will be difficult and is the key to success.
 
Marcin Swiecicki
Minister of Foreign Economic Relations
Another graduate of Warsaw University, with a Ph.D. in economics, Mr. Swiecicki, 42, is Minister of Foreign Economic Relations. He was a Fulbright scholar at Harvard where he studied market deregulation. He strongly believes in free markets.
Mr. Swiecicki is almost as strong a proponent of economic reforms as Mr. Balcerowicz, who also studied in the United States. He says he was strongly influenced by his studies here.
As the minister in charge of attracting foreign investment, he believes privatization is going too slowly. He contends American companies are waiting too long to invest in Poland, pointing out that there have been 1,200 joint ventures since 1988 - 500 with Germany and only 80 with the United States. Mr. Swiecicki also says foreign debt must be reduced and wants to see new debt reduction schemes.
''The debt was not wisely taken,'' he acknowledged. ''But nor was it wisely given.''
Mr. Swiecicki said even under Balcerowicz reform will not be as pure as Westerners hope: ''We have inherited a deeply rooted respect for social responsibility which we will not abandon.'' He would like to relax credit policies for Poland's companies more than the Government has.
