PUB-DATE: May 20, 1990,

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2730 words

HEADLINE: Rousing a Sleeping Industrial Giant

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: NAGOYA, Japan

 BODY:
Not long after he became president of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries last year, Kentaro Aikawa took a tour of the company's sprawling aerospace works here. Mr. Aikawa spent most of his career as a shipbuilder and turbine engineer for the company in Nagasaki, so he was something of a stranger to the rows of F-15 fighters, Boeing 767 fuselages and Japanese rockets under construction. But he knew that while Mitsubishi's capabilities in aerospace are much feared in Washington, they are poor business in Japan.
Mr. Aikawa, according to accounts in the Japanese press, gathered the aerospace workers and told them they produced smaller profits per person than a ''mama-san,'' the legendary women who ply Japan's tired office workers with drinks and conversation at bars. Mr. Aikawa says the newspapers got it wrong.
''I told them that they make less than sweet-potato vendors on the street,'' he said recently in his office in Tokyo. ''If they earned as much as a mama-san, I'd be quite happy.'' 
It is still an open question whether Mr. Aikawa will succeed in shaking the Nagoya works out of its post-World War II sleepiness - and with it the rest of a 120-year-old company that is the centerpiece of the Mitsubishi empire, Japan's largest corporate group.
 
Deals and Compromises
 But if the Nagoya works is still having trouble generating profits for Mitsubishi, it has had no trouble engendering political controversy. After 45 years of postwar obscurity, it has over the last 18 months become Washington's symbol - some say its nightmare - of Japan's industrial ambitions for the 1990's, particularly in aerospace. Whether or not those fears are well-founded, the Nagoya works has been the central stage for a series of international political compromises, deals and rumored deals - among them the FSX project, a new relationship with the Boeing Corporation, a potential one with Daimler-Benz A.G. of West Germany and a curious new effort in space.
Indeed, enough Americans have become jittery about Mitsubishi that Mr. Aikawa feels the need to play down the company's recent stirrings. ''We harbor this dream'' to build big planes, he says, but it is only a dream, and a distant one at that. ''There will never be the day when the Japanese aircraft industry will catch up with the American aircraft industry.''
''Maybe so,'' said a ranking Republican senator on a recent visit. ''But 20 years ago, Toyota would have said it could never catch up to G.M.''
While the 62-year-old Mr. Aikawa will likely be measured from abroad by how well he navigates Mitsubishi Heavy out of this growing vortex of tensions between the United States and Japan, the job he is facing in Tokyo is even more complex. For reasons that have as much to do with Japanese politics as with business, Mitsubishi remains one of the Western allies' most inefficient producers of arms and aircraft.
Mr. Aikawa's job is to fix that, while pushing Mitsubishi into new and far more profitable businesses. He has already done it once, at the company's enormous shipyard in Nagasaki. The most visible sign of his success there will make its maiden voyage next month: the Crystal Harmony, Japan's first giant luxury liner.
But these days, Mr. Aikawa spends as much time mollifying the Americans as engineering the company's economic revival. Mitsubishi's political troubles started with the FSX, what should have been a run-of-the-mill joint effort with the United States to develop a next-generation jet fighter for Japan's Air Self-Defense Forces. The Japanese fighter, based on the F-16 built by the General Dynamics Corporation, quickly sparked a bitter battle in Congress last year.
At issue was whether the United States was naive in continuing to put its military alliance with Japan ahead of commercial concerns - and specifically whether the FSX would teach Japan the basic skills needed to assault America's commanding position in commercial aviation. The deal was narrowly approved, but only after six months of debate that surprised Tokyo by revealing a deep American distrust of Japan.
The FSX proved only the beginning. Over the past few months the same fears arose again - twice. The first surrounded Japanese participation in Boeing's yet-to-be-developed 777, what may be one of the biggest efforts of the 90's to produce a new commercial aircraft. Early on, Boeing hoped that Japan - meaning Mitsubishi, Kawasaki and Fuji Heavy Industries - would invest heavily in the project, financing up to 25 percent of the $4 billion project. That would have been a major step up from subcontractor status; for 10 years Mitsubishi has been building the rear fuselage of the 767.
 
Glorified Subcontractor
 The prospect of giving Japan an inside view of how the 777 is created and marketed, however, was the source of ''a lot of back-channel phone calls from Washington,'' said one American Government official involved. In the end, Japan took a role as a glorified subcontractor, building 20 percent of the plane but gaining less of a voice and inside look at the development process it coveted. Mitsubishi says that it is happy with the arrangement; Boeing says the Japanese balked at the $1 billion price tag.
Just as the Boeing deal was under negotiation, rumors began to circulate about an alliance between Mitsubishi Heavy and Daimler-Benz, the auto and aerospace conglomerate.
The rumors hardly came out of the blue: at a meeting in Singapore held in secret earlier this year and revealed a few weeks later, the heads of several Mitsubishi companies and the hard-driving leadership of Daimler agreed to explore a variety of joint ventures and technology-sharing arrangements. So far, there is no formal deal, and there may never be one, but the rumors involve everything from aircraft to gas turbines. Again there are political objections, particularly because the prospect of a German-Japanese alliance sets many in Washington on edge.
Mr. Aikawa has been trying to smooth the waters. ''Our meeting with Daimler might have seemed provocative,'' he said. ''But our American friends should watch it calmly.''
And then there is space. Mitsubishi Heavy makes Japan's biggest rockets, but until now its only customer has been the Government. Now, it is helping to organize a consortium of companies that will try to sell launch services using Japan's next-generation rocket, the H-II, due out in 1993. Though the companies deny they are trying to compete with France's Ariane or similar services in the United States, the Soviet Union and China, that seems inevitable.
If all this has made Mitsubishi seem fearsome in the United States, it is a different story back home.
Not long ago, Yotaro Iida, Mr. Aikawa's predecessor and now the company's chairman, complained that Mitsubishi Heavy is still regarded as a ''fifth-rate company,'' something it decidedly was not when he and Mr. Aikawa started toiling in the hulls of half-completed warships during World War II.
In part, Mitsubishi suffers by comparison with its brethren companies in the Mitsubishi Group and with its own history. Once Japan's biggest industrial enterprise, Mitsubishi Heavy has been surpassed - financially and technologically - by glitzier, faster-growing companies. Mitsubishi Motors, which spun out from Mitsubishi Heavy 20 years ago, is now bigger than its parent.
Moreover, Mitsubishi Heavy's near-monopoly status as arms-maker to the Japanese Government is also its burden. Ever since the Meiji Emperor began industrializing Japan in the late 1800's, Mitsubishi Heavy has been a national resource. As a result, it has often been under the Government's thumb. Today it is Japan's most important arms contractor - even though military aircraft, ships and tanks represent only 15 to 20 percent of its revenues. But the Government business yields tiny profits, in the neighborhood of 3 percent.
''I have been a good child, and obedient,'' says Mr. Iida. ''I never talk back. If the Government says, 'Build this, carry out this R.&D.,' I simply say, 'Thank you very much.' ''
Government officials say Mr. Iida is unduly modest about his influence - Mitsubishi's ties to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party are enormously strong, and the company plays a larger role in Japanese defense strategy than its executives care to admit.
In any event, under Mr. Aikawa the company is beginning a drive to diversify its businesses into high-growth areas where the Government has little interest - air-conditioning systems, refrigeration, printing presses, industrial machinery, snow blowers, even pleasure boats and sports stadiums. Mitsubishi's leadership has set a goal of raising sales by 40 to 50 percent by the end of 1993, from about $15 billion now.
In most of the new targeted areas, ''competition in Japan is very keen,'' conceded Koichi Danno, a board member and one of Mr. Aikawa's key aides. For the first time, Mitsubishi Heavy will have to face off against giant electronics companies like Matsushita. ''We have to better them with innovation,'' said Mr. Danno. The company is coy about its exact plans, however.
But in Nagasaki, one gets a glimpse of how the company has managed to turn itself around in businesses other than arms and aerospace. After the war, it learned the turbine business from the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, where Mr. Iida spent three years. He calls Westinghouse ''my mentor,'' but today Westinghouse is often turning to Mitsubishi for turbine technology.
 
Shipbuilding Pays Off
 What has revived Mitsubishi's profits, however, is shipbuilding - a business that seemed dead since the early 70's. Faced with Korean competition, Mr. Aikawa slashed costs to get Mitsubishi back into the tanker and transport business.
But Mitsubishi's World War II history still haunts its effort to get its aerospace business back into shape.
Not long after Mitsubishi began building knockoffs of Ford's early cars in the 20's, it learned enough about engines and aerodynamics to become Asia's biggest aircraft manufacturer. In the two decades ending with Japan's surrender in 1945, 18,000 planes rolled out of the factory here, including the famous Zero.
But since the war, Mitsubishi has only produced 1,232 fixed-wing planes and that explains many of its problems today.
Under Japan's ''peace principles,'' companies are forbidden to export weapons systems, including military aircraft. As a result, planes come out of Nagoya these days at a trickle, often one or two a month. Almost all, like the F-15 and F-4 fighters that Japan uses to defend its shores, have been built under license from American companies. Because of the small volumes, they cost 30 to 100 percent more than building them in the United States. Like many countries, Japan pays that price because it wants to produce its own weapons.
The FSX debate shifted the focus from whether Japan should make its own military aircraft to how that expertise might bolster its efforts to produce commercial planes.
The Congressional argument against the FSX was that Mitsubishi engineers would learn the art of ''system integration'' for aircraft - and quickly transfer the skill to civilian projects. They would not have to walk far to do so. On the shop floor in Nagoya, the FSX assembly room is under construction only steps from where parts are assembled for the Boeing 767.
But building small fighter planes, Mitsubishi says, has nothing to do with learning how to build big commercial jets.
''Some people say it is just too late for us to be a major manufacturer'' of commercial aircraft, said Takaaki Yamada, the head of Mitsubishi's aerospace ventures. ''The only way is to join hands with the strongest player, Boeing, and to take charge of certain parts of the aircraft.''
As a result, Mr. Yamada says, Mitsubishi must survive as a parts maker or ''in the small commercial aircraft area, where Boeing pays no attention at all.'' So for the next few years, Mitsubishi is likely to be a partner - watching and learning, as it did in turbines.
But Mr. Iida, the chairman, says Mitsubishi is nothing for Americans to worry about. ''In Japan, to show respect to a mentor, you should stay seven steps behind and never step on shadows,'' he said. ''So I make sure I am seven or 10 steps behind, and never step on the United States.''
Mitsubishi likely will not be a major aerospace threat to the United States for the next decade, maybe two. But it will stay seven steps behind only as long as the American aircraft industry remains on the technological forefront. Otherwise, the Americans are bound to hear Japan's footsteps, both as a partner and a competitor, get louder.
 
 
 
SAYINGS TO WORK BY
 
1. Treasure originality and creativity.
 
2. United efforts make us stronger.
 
3. Once you make up your mind, do it without hesitation.
 
 
 
THE TIES THAT BIND IN JAPAN
On the second Friday of every month, a parade of limousines pulls up in front of a nondescript building in downtown Tokyo, and one by one the leaders of the main companies of the Mitsubishi Group emerge for a lunch.
That lunch, a long tradition, is only one of the many ties that bind Japan's largest keiretsu, or business group. Technically, the links between the keiretsu members are often a bit remote: some Mitsubishi companies hold minority stakes in other Mitsubishi companies, and they occasionally share board members.
But as is often the case in Japan, the relationship is far more important than the formality. At a Mitsubishi party, you will be served only Kirin beer - the brewery is part of the group - and the official photographer uses cameras made by Nikon, also a member.
It is those ironclad, intragroup deals that Americans claim are Japan's biggest remaining trade barrier. Such arrangements also exclude many Japanese companies and Japan has just now reluctantly agreed to collect data on intragroup transactions.
The Mitsubishi Group's history is inextricably entwined with the history of modern Japan. Its first president, Yataro Iwasaki, was an aggressive samurai who started a shipping business in the 1870's.
In the 1890's, the company bought 80 acres of land that is now most of downtown Tokyo, much of it belonging to Mitsubishi Real Estate, which last year bought a controlling interest in Rockefeller Center. By the time World War II broke out, the Mitsubishi empire embraced steel, oil, chemicals, a trading company and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, and more. But after the war, Gen. Douglas MacArthur forced the Iwasaki family out of management and broke up the central control of the Mitsubishi headquarters.
For much of the postwar period, the group's businesses grew slowly. But in recent years that has changed dramatically, and the Mitsubishi Group has overtaken Japan's three other giant keiretsu: Mitsui, Sumitomo and Fuyo. Companies are still splitting apart - as Mitsubishi Motors did from Mitsubishi Heavy - or merging when their businesses sour, as Mitsubishi Mining and Cement and Mitsubishi Metal announced last month.
 
 
 
TURBINES TO POLITICS
Kentaro Aikawa discovered his calling in the same place he discovered his wife: inside the hull of a warship in the midst of World War II.
Mr. Aikawa was born in Nagasaki, and he, his wife, Haruko, and most other students in the city were pressed into service as the Allies began to close in. It was his first taste of the giant Nagasaki Shipyard and Machinery Works. Starting in the early 1950's, he spent his career there, until he became president of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in June 1989.
Like his predecessor, Yotaro Iida, Mr. Aikawa comes from Mitsubishi Heavy's traditional discipline: both men are steam-turbine engineers. Mr. Aikawa later turned to geothermal power plants, and today Mitsubishi uses technology he helped develop to draw power from volcanic rumblings.
But in Nagasaki, Mr. Aikawa gained a reputation as a cost-cutter, and it was his success there that brought him to Tokyo. His aides say there is no question that he brings a new emphasis on the bottom line. ''He wants to make this a first-class company again,'' said Koichi Danno, a senior executive, and that means ''he wants to make money.''
What Mr. Aikawa lacks, as do many Japanese businessmen, is much international political experience, and confesses that is increasingly what his job requires.

HEADLINE: Teetering on the High Wire in Brazil

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
Two months after taking office, President Fernando Collor de Mello is fast approaching the moment of truth for his plan to integrate Brazil into the world economy.
At stake is a radical economic blueprint to end hyperinflation, remove barriers to imports and encourage foreign investment. Among other things, the plan would open Latin America's largest economy to private ownership in highway construction, telephone service and electric power generation, sectors that are now tightly controlled by the state.
Two crucial elements of the plan will soon come into play. By June 18, Brazil's ministers are to submit plans to cut payrolls by 20 to 25 percent - a total cut of up to 400,000 state workers. And by August, Mr. Collor, a staunch free-marketeer, is to start a quick-march privatization that is designed to put two-thirds of Brazil's 190 state companies into investor hands by 1995. 
The goal is to attack the root cause of Brazil's chronic inflation - a Government deficit papered over during the 1980's by printing money. By trimming administrative costs and selling off companies - and by raising taxes and cracking down on tax cheats - Mr. Collor hopes to convert Brazil's 1989 budget deficit of $28 billion into a 1990 surplus of $7 billion.
A lot is on the line, not only for domestic companies but also for Americans and other foreigners who do business here - or hope to.
''If they get 70 to 80 percent of it right, Brazil is going to be a fabulous place for private investment in the 1990's,'' said J. Dolph Johnson, an American executive-search consultant in Sao Paulo who has worked in Brazil for 20 years. ''If they blow it, it's going to be a disaster.''
An American banker in Sao Paulo agreed. ''The tension level is quite high,'' said the banker, who asked not to be identified. ''Either Collor will be able to reduce the public sector, or you will see Brazil dragged into an Argentina-type situation,'' in which inflation surges once more.
Whatever its ultimate fate, the Collor program began with a paradox: in the name of a free-market revolution, Brazil experienced the greatest state intervention in decades when the Government sought to stop inflation literally overnight by freezing most of the money in circulation. For those doing business here, that set off a period of chaos that they are only now emerging from.
The ''shock therapy'' started on March 16, a day after the 40-year-old Mr. Collor was inaugurated as Brazil's first freely elected President in three decades. On that day, the Government froze for 18 months roughly 80 percent of savings and money market funds - about $90 billion - including the cash balances of businesses. It also imposed across-the-board wage and price controls.
And, to push its program to sell off state-owned companies, it announced that banks, insurers and pension plans would be required to buy ''privatization certificates'' that would be used to purchase shares in state companies. Last week, the Government issued guidelines under which banks would be forced to buy certificates equal to 3 percent of their circulating assets. The figure for insurance companies is 10 percent and for pension plans between 15 and 25 percent.
''The great paradox is that to get to the free-market paradise, we have to go through the inferno of more intervention, more control and more bureaucracy,'' said Carlos Langoni, a financial consultant who was central bank president in the early 1980's.
Indeed, during the first two months of the Collor Administration, Brazilians have seen a lot of inferno and little paradise.
The sharp, unexpected liquidity freeze snapped this nation of 140 million people into the sharpest recession in a decade.
But the hard times have already begun to ease a bit. For example, in Sao Paulo, the nation's economic powerhouse, energy use is up and so are retail sales. Polls of business leaders indicate that the economy is recovering to a no-growth level.
The squeeze on money is at the heart of the economy's volatility. Liquidity was reduced March 16 from 40 percent of Brazil's $350 billion gross national product to 9 percent, according to Zelia Cardoso de Mello, the new economy minister. But today it is back up to 14 percent - partly through Government infusions to various sectors and partly through the knack that Brazilians have for knocking illegal loopholes in barriers.
By paying taxes and past bills, most large companies legally emptied their frozen accounts, which held the old currency, the cruzado novo. In addition, the Government says that about $480 million of blocked money was illegally converted into the new currency, the cruzeiro.
For the moment, at least, the Government is enjoying a budget surplus - largely due to a 50 percent increase in tax collection and a series of new, one-time taxes on ownership of stocks, gold and savings accounts.
Tax collection has also been spurred by a series of arrests on tax-evasion charges of prominent business executives in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. The crackdown cut into Brazil's underground economy, estimated to be $100 billion a year.
The money squeeze, the wage and price freeze and the tax hikes allowed Mr. Collor to crow victory last month as Brazil's official monthly inflation rate plummeted to 3 percent, from 84 percent in March.
But Mr. Collor inherited massive governmental obligations from his predecessor, obligations that could greedily - and quickly - devour the new tax collections.
''It's a two-month surplus - April and May,'' Roberto Campos, a Congressman and former Government minister, said in an interview here. ''If spending is not cut and the deficit comes back, everything goes down the drain.''
To shrink the state sector, Mr. Collor is relying on pruning the Government work force and selling state companies.
But Brazil's civil servants are tenacious about holding on to their jobs, a tenacity enshrined in the country's 1988 Constitution, which gives job security to Federal employees after five years.
The major cut in the Federal payroll for 1.6 million workers will probably come through privatization. By the end of the year, officials hope to earn $7 billion through the sale of four steel companies, one petrochemical company and one bus manufacturer.
To spur the sales, Brazil's foreign creditors will be allowed to convert their debt holdings into privatization certificates. Brazil's foreign debt is $115 billion, the largest in the third world. Foreigners will be limited to purchasing 40 percent of a company's voting capital.
''They could make this the world's fastest privatization,'' said Mr. Campos, the Congressman, referring to the desire of many foreign creditors to convert Brazil debt into equity.
But skeptics note that in Argentina, the Government that came to power last July also promised widespread privatization. It will probably celebrate its first anniversary with only two sales, both of television stations.
In Brazil, as in Argentina, the left is expected to mobilize a nationalist campaign against privatization and civil service layoffs.
If Mr. Collor succeeds in curbing the deficit and hence inflation it would give him the political power to continue with the long-term goal of opening Brazil to more foreign investment and imports.
Sending up a signal flare to Brazil's highly protected industry, Mr. Collor this month abolished a list of 1,500 banned import items - ranging from cars to ceiling fans. High import duties, up to 105 percent, were immediately placed on the items, to cushion the shock for domestic competitors. But in June, officials plan to announce a three-year schedule for gradually reducing the duties. Brazilian supermarket and department-store chains have already sent buyers to the United States, Europe and Asia to look for high-quality consumer goods.
On two trade issues of long-term concern to Washington, the new Government has said it wants to negotiate a gradual recognition of pharmaceutical patents and a gradual opening to computer imports.
Encouraged by the moves, Carla Hills, the United States Trade Representative, removed Brazil this month from a list of countries facing retaliatory tariffs for protectionism. Mrs. Hills is to visit Brazil in June.
Support for Brazil's new direction has also come from the nation's multilateral creditors. A team from the International Monetary Fund is to come here next month to start negotiations that could lead to a reduction of Brazil's service load on its debt.
But everything depends on the deficit, experts agree. ''Either Collor does away with the deficit or the deficit does away with his plan,'' Antonio Delfim Netto, a Congressman, recently told a newspaper here. ''Everything else is 'economese.' ''
 
 
 
A NEW LOOK AT THE MINISTRY
 
BRASILIA
The top-floor, corner office of what is now the Economy Ministry has typically been occupied by a balding bureaucrat in a business suit.
In a change of gender and of generation, Brazil's top economic official is now Zelia Cardoso de Mello, a 36-year-old economist known simply as Zelia.
Miss Mello is scheduled to arrive tomorrow in Washington to meet with American bankers in preliminary talks over restructuring Brazil's foreign debt.
No relation to the country's new President, Fernando Collor de Mello, Miss Mello has emerged from a cabinet restructuring as the most powerful economic official in Brazilian history, at least on paper.
As economy minister, she oversees the former ministries of Finance, Industry and Commerce, the Central Bank, the Government Savings Bank, the National Bank for Economic and Social Development and the secretariats of Planning and Treasury.
With her most recent Government experience as a mid-level Treasury analyst, some critics here say that Miss Mello lacks the background to manage such an enormous bureaucratic empire. Criticism increased last week as the new Government reversed itself on the latest of a series of economic decrees that opponents have called unconstitutional.
On her way to a doctorate in economics at the University of Sao Paulo, Miss Mello briefly passed through the ranks of the Brazilian Communist Party. More recently, she has embraced the free-market economics espoused by Mr. Collor.
Asked in an interview in her office here why she wants to privatize more state companies in five years than Margaret Thatcher has privatized in 11, Miss Mello replied: ''Mrs. Thatcher did not have the urgency we have.''

HEADLINE: The Minority Community's Shopping-Mall Hard Sell

BYLINE: By GREG KRIKORIAN; Greg Krikorian, who has been a freelance writer, recently joined the staff of The Los Angeles Times.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
For some time now, business has been bleak at the Radiance Boutique. And it's starting to wear on owner Ruby Golden, who for 18 years made a good living in the competitive world of retailing. ''I'm not doing well at all. I hate you to print that. But it's the truth,'' Ms. Golden said. ''And I'm not doing well because there aren't enough stores here.''
Here is the Baldwin Hills Crenshaw Plaza, an 800,000-square-foot mall in southwest Los Angeles that is finding, like many retail centers in minority communities, that the hardest sell is to retailers. Indeed, from Los Angeles to New York, Atlanta to Chicago, retail centers in predominantly minority communities are often struggling more than they think they should to attract tenants.
''A lot of big retailers are being squeezed right now. But a lot of them also don't see minority communities as having buying power, which is totally fallacious,'' said Alan L. Carsrud, a visiting economics professor at the University of California at Los Angeles. ''A good hunk of it is racist and a good hunk of it is perception. And the irritating thing is that it is totally wrong.'' Experts in the field warn as well that retailers' wariness of locating in minority neighborhoods poses a problem for the entire retail industry as well as ethnic communities. 
''We can no longer shut our eyes to these emerging ethnic groups. Each market has to be weighed on its own merits. But it hurts me to think we might be color blind to opportunities,'' said Jody Martin, vice president of marketing for Stillerman Jones & Company, an Indianapolis-based consulting firm for shopping-center developers and retailers. ''We just have to open our eyes and realize that if retailing is in trouble, maybe we need to look at new markets.''
Indeed, minority shoppers already account for 20 percent of the nation's sales at regional shopping centers even though most of the centers are still located in the suburbs, inconvenient to the inner-cities, according to Stillerman Jones, which has surveyed some 40,000 shoppers nationwide. The firm's research also indicates that that blacks are America's most frequent shoppers, Hispanic people the biggest spenders - that is, they spend the most per shopper per excursion - and Asians the most affluent. Combined, these three minority groups were found to represent a purchasing power of more than $400 billion annually, with blacks accounting for half that amount.
So the Baldwin Hills Crenshaw center - whose $120 million renovation was completed little more than a year ago - might be expected to draw like a magnet. There are more than 1.1 million residents, predominantly black, in a five-mile radius, with an average family income of $38,522. Yet only half the center's 100 shop sites are open, and it has been unable to lure major national retailers to serve as anchor stores. Now the joint developers, the Alexander Haagen Company and the city of Los Angeles, are ready to spend another $5.5 million to attract tenants by helping with their construction costs.
''Many retailers just say they're not interested,'' said Andrew J. Natker, project developer for the Alexander Haagen, Southern California's largest shopping-center developer. ''Either they're afraid of the community, which they shouldn't be, or there's something else going on. I just don't know.'' He said the center has talked to more than 650 national chains and smaller stores but has commitments from only 60. Among those who have declined, he said, are the Nordstrom, Bullock's and Robinson's department stores, and The Brown Group, a St. Louis chain with 4,000 stores and 20 subsidiaries, and the U.S. Shoe Corporation, with 807 stores under 15 different names including Casual Corner and Lens Crafters. Such specialty stores as Oshman's Sporting Goods Inc., See's Candy Shops Inc., The Pottery Barn East Inc., Crabtree & Evelyn, and The Walt Disney Company stores have similarly resisted, said Mr. Natker, who described the standard response as: ''No thanks. It's not our market.''
Tim Doke, Nordstrom's public-relations consultant, said its decision against locating in Baldwin Hills Crenshaw Plaza was driven by economics. ''We have stores in Oakland and other cities with large minority populations. So obviously Nordstrom's decision on Baldwin Hills had nothing to do with race. It was purely a business decision,'' Mr. Doke said. His statement generally reflected the comments or views of the other major retailers, who stayed out.
Sears, Roebuck & Co. did move in, after closing down another outlet a few miles away; and the May Company and Broadway Hardware Inc., which moved in before the renovation, have remained. But the center says these companies are not enough to anchor a mall.
At the Greenbriar Mall, outside Atlanta, which two years ago completed a $20 million renovation, the experience with retailers was similar. John Gerdes, its general manager, said, ''We've been trying for several years to attract a third anchor store. But we just haven't had any success. If this was a predominantly white community, we'd be turning people away every day for leasing space.'' The mall is in an area where the average income is $32,555, 15 percent above the average for Atlanta. ''A few years ago, if you had asked me about the problem, I would have been a lot less direct because it's a sensitive matter,'' Mr. Gerdes said, ''but having been here since the renovation and having tried to make various retail deals, I don't pull too many punches anymore. There are just a lot of retailers who are not doing business in this community for the wrong reasons.''
''It's a frustrating problem,'' said Charlotte Ellis, a vice-president of the Lehndorff Group of Dallas, which owns Greenbriar. ''Frankly, I thought we'd fought this battle for equity in minority communities a long time ago. But it's still a battle,'' she said.
Not all centers in minority communities are struggling. In fact, the Haagen firm has developed three smaller malls in Los Angeles, one in predominantly black Watts, that are doing well. It proves ''you can do business in the inner city,'' said Robert O'Neill, editor-in-chief of Monitor, an industry magazine. And the first phase of Chicago's Grand Boulevard Plaza, a 200,000-square-foot center across from the Robert Taylor Homes housing project, has been highly successful, according to Mike Harris, sales manager for the center, owned by the Matanky Realty Group: ''We have some major national tenants, some local businesses and we're over 85 percent leased for some time now.'' But if the center were a low-income white area, he said, retailers would make their decisions ''a lot quicker and easier - the prejudice is still real.''
In an environment of modest real growth, ''many chains are looking for reasons not to locate in new areas. The screening process is much greater today than it was 15 or 20 years ago,'' said Allan D. Kotin of Kotin, Regan and Mouchly, real-estate consultants. And the changing nature of neighborhoods unsettles retailers. ''The perception of transition is a perception of uncertainty and independent of any racial stereotypes, transition means change. So there is a real concern that racial shifts are a harbinger of economic decline,'' he said.
Such concern appears to have frightened away retailers, even in areas that soon thereafter proved their worth. Bruce D. Phillips, head of research for the Small Business Administration's Office of Advocacy, which functions as an in-house lobbyist for small businesses, said that Washington, D.C.'s Georgetown - today one of the nation's most fashionable retail addresses - once had severe problems in securing businesses. ''Most people don't realize that it was a very economically distressed area some years ago and if a retailer was asked to open a business there, they might well have said 'no.' So the timing may not be right for retailers when they look at an area and try to decide if it fits into their marketing strategy. They may want to wait a little longer in the cycle,'' Mr. Phillips said. ''Is that de facto discrimination? Or it is not seeing enough of a market?''
There is concern, too, about city crime. Harriet Zocks, a marketing consultant, said, ''The hesitancy is in what we face in any city environment: There is the fear of more crime, and because retailing is in tough times, the risk of going to a center may be magnified by the general fears of the city environment.'' To arrest those fears, many inner-city centers have put a premium on security. ''One thing what's unique about our center is that it was built with the secure mall concept,'' said Mr. Harris of Grand Boulevard. The Chicago center's security measures range from its basic design, with only two entrances and wrought-iron fencing, to its staffing by officers who patrol and monitor its parking lot from a tower staffed around the clock. High-profile security has also been a mainstay of Haagen's centers in Los Angeles.
Notwithstanding the complications, inner cities clearly have new appeal to some business people. Bernard J. Rosenshein, who believes his $100 million Concourse Plaza Shopping Center, opening next year, will bring new vitality and commerce to New York City's South Bronx, said: ''There are great opportunities in these areas because most of them are under-stored. Some retailers are astute enough to realize there is a market that has great potential. They understand and are not frightened away from opportunity.''
Then there are other retailers who over time have adjusted their businesses to the changing demographics of big cities. ''When you look at inner-city markets, people are intimidated by the environment. But because we have always been in inner-city markets, we have learned how to grow and we are still making money,'' said Bob Lynn, president of F.W. Woolworth Company. With about 450 of Woolworth's 1,000 stores located in predominantly minority neighborhoods, Mr. Lynn said experience has shown that they hold their own against outlets situated in more suburban settings. ''The rest of the retailing world is fighting it out in the suburbs and has neglected, to some degree, these inner-city markets. Yet we do a tremendous business,'' Mr. Lynn said. Are other retail chains ignoring opportunities? ''Yes, and I hope they keep missing the boat.''
 
THERE'S MONEY TO BE MADE
Despite the problems, there does seem to be opportunity for retailers in inner-city shopping centers - at the right place and at the right time.
That is suggested by Alexander Haagen's development or rebuilding of three modest-size shopping centers in inner-city neighborhoods of Los Angeles.
A decade ago, Mr. Haagen realized that residents who lived near such centers were traveling elsewhere to shop, and he saw potential in one that had long been neglected. In a joint venture with a city-formed nonprofit corporation, he set out to upgrade it and recapture its customers.
Today, the Vermont-Slauson Shopping Center - the first of three such centers rebuilt by the Alexander Haagen Company in cooperation with the city and county of Los Angeles - is flourishing. ''Unbelievable business,'' says Andrew J. Natker of the Haagen firm. ''In excess of $300 per square foot in sales.'' The mall has succeeded because, to borrow one of Mr. Haagen's favorite expressions, it provides area residents with ''equal shopping opportunities.''
Similarly, the Martin Luther King Jr. Center in Watts, a project whose profits now go to the city of Los Angeles, is highly profitable.
Finally, the Kenneth Hahn Plaza in Willowbrook is doing ''good, not fantastic'' business, Mr. Natker says. ''We opened a year too soon.''
But he adds that once a light-rail commuter line and a new freeway open nearby, ''that place will be solid gold.''

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Bracing for Tougher Times

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Once upon a time - more than 120 years ago - a small East Texas river town called Jefferson was thriving as steamships carried cotton and timber down the Red River to the Mississippi and thence to New Orleans. Then one day, the railroad magnate Jay Gould (no relation to this writer) came to Jefferson. He wanted to bring his railroad through town, but local leaders scoffed and Jay Gould took his railroad plans somewhere else. Not long afterward, the Red River around Jefferson became unnavigable and the once-booming town boomed no more.
Historians say this is not just a tall tale, although they can't confirm all the details. But when Thomas R. Powers, chairman of the Investment Company Institute's board of governors, told it at the industry's recent convention, it left an uneasy stillness in a room crowded with hundreds of fund executives. One man who has attended seven of these annual gatherings said he had never heard a speech that left the audience so quiet. 
Mr. Powers clearly wasn't the only one who saw this as an apocryphal tale about the industry's struggle to keep up with changing times. Such sobering fare is not the usual stuff of the industry's conventions. Sure, there was some of the back-slapping and self-congratulation so prevalent in earlier years. Yet for an industry that just broke the $1 trillion mark, the tone was oddly subdued. ''I'm not hearing a lot of 'atta-boys' this year,'' one executive said.
For some, the pessimism was subsumed in anger. ''The industry had better sit up and start paying attention,'' said Palomba Weingarten, chairman of the Los Angeles-based Pilgrim Group, who believes that most executives underestimate the competitive impact of banks, especially foreign ones.
There were plenty of other reasons for pinched faces. There has been a clear shift away from the easy money of the 1980's. The industry's explosive growth during the past decade cannot be sustained and its increasingly important role in financial markets makes it fair game for competitors and regulators alike. Funds will be forced to struggle just to keep the money they already manage. Clearly, boom times are over.
''Today's friendly competition will probably turn ugly,'' said Heidi S. Fiske, a New York City consultant on financial services and marketing, who was commissioned by the institute to look at industry conditions in the coming decade. A preview of her report, scheduled for release to institute members this summer, shows what's behind the industry's pessimism.
She forecasts industry growth as ''healthy but probably slower,'' with yearly growth in assets of about 12 percent, almost two-thirds less than the annual rate recorded during the 80's. There are two reasons for the slowdown: Funds will have to compete against each other, and they will begin to lose market share to banks and other outside competitors. The investment pie is expected to reach $3 trillion by the end of the decade, said Alfred P. Johnson, a mutual fund consultant based in McLean, Va. ''Demand will be there, but supply will be there in spades,'' he said.
As a result, fund executives will probably start viewing each other with a more jaundiced eye. At conventions in the past, they could afford to be generous, to swap stories and try to come up with new schemes to split an ever-expanding pool of investors' money.
But price wars are pushing down revenues. For example, two industry giants - Fidelity Investments and the Dreyfus Corporation - are in a battle for investor money, subsidizing expenses to raise yields but shaving profit margins. At the same time, fund expenses - for labor, technology and marketing - are rising. The industry's average expense ratio - funds' expenses as a percentage of average assets - has been up steadily since 1985, said Morningstar Inc., a Chicago mutual fund research firm.
And expenses are likely to rise even faster this decade. The market is saturated with new types of funds, and now fund groups are trying to grab market share with better service. But that will require large capital investments in computers and telecommunications. ''It's a tough act, and expensive, but there's a need for funds to differentiate themselves with service,'' said Brian S. Mattes, a spokesman for the Vanguard Group, a fund company based in Valley Forge, Pa.
The resulting margin squeeze is expected to shrink some fund group's profits badly by mid-decade. One likely consequence is industry consolidation. Smaller groups unable to compete on price or carve out a niche may fail. It is already more economical to buy existing funds than create new ones. There were 15 mergers last year and six so far this year, and in coming years, merging funds ''will be the thing to do,'' said Wayne S. Huff, a research associate with Charles E. Simon & Company, a Washington research firm.
The industry is clearly at a crossroads and the memory of Jefferson is fresh in the minds of fund executives. But one beneficiary of all the turmoil may be you: According to Mr. Johnson, investors are likely to reap the rewards of lower fees and charges as competition accelerates.
 
 
 
THE TOO-HIGH RETURNS
Traditionally, stock market investments return about 10 percent and bonds return about 7 percent. But the raging bull market of the 1980's knocked that standard out of kilter, and only recently have bonds moved back to their traditional levels.
Stocks have not followed suit. The accompanying chart shows just far stocks have to fall to return to levels that market analysts consider normal.
Right now, the return on stock funds is about 30 percent higher than the historic norm. Although bond fund returns were clearly higher than usual for the five-year period, they dropped to a more traditional level in the last year.
Market experts say investors who were spoiled by the fat gains in the stock market during the 1980's will have to adjust their expectations of gains in coming years. Indeed, they should expect returns to go back to the norm - that is, for the market to drop 30 percent. But nobody is willing to say when that could happen.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Ending the Week on an Up Note

 BODY:
It was an up week, but just a little, for the dollar. After falling against the Japanese yen in the beginning of the week, the dollar inched back Thursday and Friday. It also rose those two days against other major currencies, except for the British pound. It is not clear if the rally is just a correction after the sharp drop of the week before or rather the start of a new trend. But the overall outlook for the dollar is still bearish because of the expectation that interest rates in the United States will remain stable or even decline. Meanwhile, the British pound got its lift from new signals that the Conservative Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher would move into the European Monetary System soon. Such a move would add some stability to the pound.

HEADLINE: Many Jobs Clean Up on the Environment

BYLINE: By Claudia H. Deutsch

 BODY:
Item: The Jefferson Group, a Washington, D.C.-based government affairs firm, is hiring for a new office that will focus on environmental and workplace safety. Why? ''Many companies will need help n understanding and meeting the new requirements,'' said Mark D. Cowan, Jefferson's chief executive.
Item: B. E. & K. Inc., a construction company in Birmingham, Ala., that specializes in building paper plants, is increasing its staff of environmental specialists by 25 percent. ''We need more process engineers who can work with recycled fiber, and we need more people who can analyze air and water quality,'' explained T. Michael Goodrich, B. E. & K.'s president. 
Item: Kimmins Environmental Service Corporation, a Tampa, Fla., company specializing in hazardous-waste cleanup, has seen its need for environmental experts quadruple. ''The number of jobs going out for bid is 20, 30, 40 times what it was 20 years ago,'' said Charles Baker, a Kimmins vice president.
These days, a good way to clean up on cash is to clean up the earth. The national preoccupation with restoring befouled air, water and soil to health is opening lucrative career doors for lawyers, entrepreneurs, engineers, professors - anyone who is conversant with environmental issues, or at least willing to learn.
There are not nearly enough of them to go around. ''At least four jobs come calling for every one available person,'' said William Alfred, a New York recruiter who specializes in environmental jobs. In university placement offices, the phones are ringing off the hook. ''I get several calls a week from employers looking for environmental engineers,'' said Richard G. Luthy, head of civil engineering at the Carnegie Institute of Technology in Pittsburgh.
For now, the most heady demand is for engineers. Recent chemical engineering grads are, for the first time since the early 1970's, being offered higher starting salaries than computer engineers. Engineers with a few years of environmental experience can practically write their own tickets. And executives with both engineering and managerial experience are getting six-figure offers for jobs as corporate vice presidents in charge of environmental affairs.
But the environmental mania sweeping the nation has caught fire in other fields, too. These are boom times for packaging specialists who can reduce trash at the source, for compensation specialists who know how to link managers' bonuses to environmental compliance, for lobbyists and politicians who can persuade localities to accept a landfill in their area, for scientists of all kinds who can prevent pollution at the source.
''Imagine being the person who develops the plant that can protect itself against insects without needing an insecticide - that's the kind of challenge that attracts the best people,'' said Valentino Martinez, manager of professional staffing for the Monsanto Agricultural Company.
Environmental interest is running rampant at business schools too. Lester B. Lave, an economics professor at Carnegie-Mellon's Graduate School of Industrial Administration, says that more than half the school's students are taking his elective course in managing environmental risks. ''They recognize that today's managers have to understand environmental issues,'' he said, ''the same way that the managers of the 1940's had to understand labor relations.''
The business students are up against a problem their engineering colleagues are not, however: most of the high-paying jobs are with small environmental start-ups that will pay top dollar for technological help but see little need to bring in sophisticated business expertise.
''They could use M.B.A.'s in finance or marketing, but they are still resistant to hiring us,'' said Timothy Butler, a graduate student at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. James Beirne, Wharton's director of career development, hears that complaint a lot. ''The companies just haven't figured out how to use M.B.A.'s yet,'' he said, ''and it's a little frustrating for the students.''
Increasingly, business students are taking it upon themselves to ''sell the type of position we are looking for before we start selling ourselves,'' said Benjamin J. Lee, a graduate student at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management.
Mr. Lee got Kellogg's placement office to ask about 100 environmental-cleanup companies about their staffing needs. Kellogg students have been contacting the companies that responded, persuading them first that they need business expertise, then offering their services. Mr. Lee says that one company asked him to develop a sales plan and form a marketing group; another is looking for someone to deal with community boards and write sales presentations.
Mr. Lee and other business students are asking high salaries, but there is more going on than greed. ''The environment is both a good career opportunity and a chance to repair some of the damage that's been done,'' said Justin Rogers, a first-year graduate student at Kellogg.
In a sense, Mr. Rogers and many other students of the 1990's are sociological hybrids. They are a cross between the anti-establishment students of the 1960's, many of whom cared deeply about the environment but did not want to work within the system, and the ''me generation'' of the 1980's, which used the industrial establishment to foster their own materialistic goals.
''The students are excited about environmental careers, partly because they like to work for small firms, but just as much because they want to help,'' said Robert K. Weatherall, head of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Office of Career Services.
Of course, there is always the risk that environmentalism is a passing fad. When the Clean Air Act was first passed in 1970, followed by the Federal Water Pollution Control Act in 1972, environmentalists were certain that the nation's consciousness had been permanently raised. Yet environmentalism all but died away in the 1980's. Amid all the hoopla over the 20th anniversary of Earth Day this year, few people thought to mention that Earth Day's 10th anniversary had passed all but unnoticed.
''There is a history of boom and bust in environmental issues, and it remains to be seen whether solid waste or any other trendy issue will have the staying power to sustain careers,'' warned Lewis Erwin, a mechanical engineering professor at Northwestern.
Other specialists say there is a quantitative difference this time around. ''People finally realize that the threats will not go away,'' said Mr. Weatherall of M.I.T. ''Railroad cars carrying noxious chemicals will still get tipped over, oil tankers will leak, smokestacks will emit things. All these will make environmentalism, and the jobs it creates, a fact of modern industrial life.''

CORRECTION-DATE: May 27, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in the special Careers section last Sunday about jobs in the environmental safety industry misidentified a New York recruiter who specializes in the area. He is William Alford.

PUB-DATE: May 20, 1990,

SECTION: Section 3; Part 2, Page 29, Column 3; Careers Supplement

LENGTH: 1510 words

HEADLINE: THE JOB MARKET;
EASTERN EUROPE SEEKS THE SKILLED

BYLINE: By John Holusha

 BODY:
As a young girl in Detroit, Carolyn A. Kley often listened to her grandmother's tales of what life was like in Poland before she immigrated to America. This summer, Caroline, now a student at the University of Michigan School of Business Administration, is going to Poland to help its Government manage the difficult transition from a planned to a capitalist economy.
Ms. Kley is one of seven students at the business school who will spend this summer as interns at private and state-owned businesses in Poland, sharing some of the management techniques they have been taught and learning the customs and business realities of a country that has spent more than 40 years under Communism. ''These people know they are going to be dealing in a global economy and they hope the summer will help give them a global insight,'' said Edwin L. Miller, an associate dean at the school, which set up the internship program and is financing it for this summer. ''Some of them may even be thinking about setting up companies in Eastern Europe.''
Ms. Kley, who will spend the summer working with a computer software concern in Cracow, said the experience may well shape her career. ''I'm already set on a career in the international sphere,'' she said. ''This should be a fascinating experiment.'' 
The radical changes that have taken place in Eastern Europe in the last few years - the rise to power of Solidarity in Poland, perestroika in the Soviet Union and the displacement of Communist governments in Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary and Romania - are providing career opportunities for people with energy, a sense of adventure and needed skills.
Last year, for instance, Michelle Siren was a consultant with Price Waterhouse's Washington office working with the World Bank. Today she is based in the firm's London office and travels regularly to East bloc countries to help transform state-owned enterprises into self-sustaining businesses.
''We are here because the market is heating up in the East,'' said Ms. Siren, who has an M.B.A. with a specialty in international marketing. ''We help commercialize enterprises that are not commercial now. And we advise clients on entry strategy.''
Eastern Europe represents a vast, largely untapped market for Western goods and expertise. The population of the region, including the Soviet Union, totals about 430 million, compared with 325 million in the European Community. There are drawbacks, such as outdated production facilities, unconvertible currencies and widespread pollution. But that has not stopped hundreds of American companies from setting up joint ventures.
Executive recruiters are chiefly looking for experienced people, generally in their late 40's or early 50's, whose children are grown and who can relocate without much difficulty. Most assignments will be temporary, they say, with Americans and West Europeans returning home as East bloc nationals learn Western business skills.
For younger people, internships, like the Michigan project, and less formal contacts can lead to opportunities. ''They should not be afraid of taking a flier and going there to visit during summer breaks,'' said Stuart Anderson, editor of Bloc magazine, which reports on economic developments in Eastern Europe. ''I know of one person who did that and now works for Citibank in Budapest.''
Said Ron Weber, president of Weber Executive Search, a management-recruiting concern in Huntington, L.I.: ''For the large multinationals, Eastern Europe is where the action is. There is a huge pent-up demand there for consumer goods.''
Mr. Weber said the skills most in demand were sales, marketing and distribution. Familiarity with operating procedures in countries still dominated by government bureaucracies is important as well. ''People who know Western consumerism and also know how to work with government agencies in these countries are really in demand,'' Mr. Weber said.
Since most of the Eastern countries have currencies that are worthless outside their own borders, demand often cannot be immediately translated into cash sales. To get paid, Western companies often have to construct elaborate barter or counter-trade arrangements in which they accept payment in goods that can be resold on world markets.
The best-known of these arrangements is the one in which Pepsico sells its soft drinks in the Soviet Union for rubles, then uses the rubles to purchase Stolichnaya vodka and tanker ships for resale in the West. ''It is an exciting time, but selling goods to people with no money is not fun,'' observed Jeffrey K. Smith, who represented the General Electric Company in Moscow and is now director of the center for Soviet management development at Duke University's Fuqua School of Business. ''The real need is for people who can successfully put together deals,'' said Peter Schmidt, managing director of Boyden International Inc. ''They have to find markets for products that are relatively unsophisticated in nature.''
Language skills are critical, authorities on the region say, both as a means of communication and to help understand the cultural peculiarities of each country. Americans are often at a disadvantage in this regard, compared with Western Europeans, since most European executives are proficient in more than one tongue.
Rather than trying to learn all the languages of the region, many veterans of the East say it's smarter to learn German or Russian, which are the most common second languages in those countries. ''Russian may not be the language of choice these days in Eastern Europe, but when things get difficult my Russian usually gets me through,'' Ms. Siren said.
There may be other applications for the multilingual as well. ''The clearest opportunity is going to be teaching English as a second language,'' said Deborah Milenkovitch, director of the Institute on East Central Europe at Columbia University. The number of students seeking certification from the institute doubled in a year, she noted.
Following the multinational corporations and entrepreneurs to Eastern Europe are accountants, who have the daunting task of rearranging the books for enterprises that had no profit motive for four decades, and establishing a valuation for companies being converted to private ownership.
Bruce Edwards, head of Price Waterhouse's London office, said the number of people in the office his firm maintains in Budapest increased from 2 to 54 in a year and a half. He said most East bloc enterprises had good records on production, but that information on costs and revenues was scanty to nonexistent because profit was not an object. Indeed, Mr. Edwards said profit was an uncomfortable topic with some Eastern European managers, particularly older ones long immersed in Socialism. These misgivings sometimes slow the pace of deal-making. ''They have the notion that interest is wrong and that if someone makes a profit, someone else loses,'' he said.
Western investment in the East appears to be following a predictable pattern, according to Paul R. Ray Jr., the head of a management-recruiting firm based in Fort Worth, Tex., that bears his name. The first wave was in the tourist industry, with the Marriott hotel in Warsaw and the McDonald's fast-food restaurant in Moscow among the most prominent examples. But since both companies plan to staff these enterprises almost completely with nationals, opportunities for Westerners are limited.
Still largely in the negotiating stage are investments in advanced-technology fields like biotechnology, chemistry and scientific research, where Western companies will attempt to develop research that has been stalled in Eastern European laboratories. Another wave of investment, Mr. Ray said, will come as the Eastern countries attempt to improve their links to the rest of the world through better telecommunications and information-processing capability.
Further in the future are investments in heavy-manufacturing industries that are expected to seek to utilize the inexpensive and generally well-educated labor forces of Eastern Europe. ''We may see a demand for people with Detroit-type mass assembly skills, but that will wait until they are ready to export,'' Mr. Ray said. ''That may be 5 to 10 years away.'' The badly ravaged environment of the East, where much of the ground water is too polluted for industrial processes and air pollution is eating away at stone statues that lasted hundreds of years relatively unscathed, may provide other opportunities. Scott Stricoff, a vice president of Arthur D. Little, a consulting company in Cambridge, Mass., said more inquiries about environmental remediation were coming from the East. But he acknowledged that the feeble economies of the region would be hard pressed to pay cleanup costs.
''They are going to have to do something, because Western companies are reluctant to go in there unless these problems start getting solved,'' Mr. Stricoff said. ''So I think something will start in the next few years, but the pace of progress is uncertain.''

HEADLINE: Engineering Fields Fertile For the Rest of the Century

BYLINE: By Calvin Sims

 BODY:
Bolstered by mounting demands from industry and a national shortage of technical students, career opportunities for science and engineering graduates are making a strong comeback after recently experiencing a slump.
Only three years ago, demand for technical graduates had slowed considerably, as many high-technology industries like computers, electronics and autos, feeling the pressure of foreign competition, imposed hiring freezes to restructure their operations and increase productivity. Although engineering and computer science positions were available then, offers of employment were substantially lower than in previous years, and jobs were not so plentiful as they are expected to be in the 1990's.
The Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates that the number of employed engineers in the United States will reach 1.72 million by the year 2000, a 25 percent increase from the 1.38 million engineers employed in 1988. Demand will be strongest for electrical, industrial, mechanical, civil, petroleum and chemical engineers and computer scientists, as a bigger role in government and business is assumed by the environment, infrastructure, computers, telecommunications and manufacturing. 
Meanwhile, the number of students studying science and engineering is expected to decline as the college-age population shrinks. Meanwhile, competition for technical graduates should expand rapidly as financial-services companies and other sectors seek engineers and computer scientists to help utilize computer and communications technologies in managing their affairs.
''Short of a major depression or recession, there will be a plethora of jobs available throughout this decade for students who study math and science,'' said Betty Vetter, executive director of the Commission on Professionals in Science and Technology, a nonprofit group in Washington, D.C., financed by technology-oriented industries. ''Even if we hire every engineering graduate in the coming years, it is unlikely there will be enough technical talent to meet skyrocketing demand because there are so few students in the pipeline.''
The Census Bureau has projected a 25 percent decline in the college-age population, from which most new engineers and scientists are drawn, over the next 10 years. Between 1986 and 1989 the number of engineering graduates nationwide dropped 12 percent, to 68,824, and is expected to fall another 12 percent, to 60,500, by 1992.
To attract the shrinking number of technical graduates, companies are increasing starting salaries. The College Placement Council, an employment-research group that conducts a yearly survey of career placement offices at colleges and universities around the nation, reports that the average salary offer for petroleum engineering majors increased 10 percent in the last year, to $36,120. Average starting salaries for chemical engineering rose 6.8 percent, to $35,204; 5.1 percent, to $31,800, for chemical engineering, and 5.2 percent, to $32,083, for mechanical engineering.
Employment opportunities are expected to be even stronger for women and minority members, who are grossly underrepresented in the science and engineering fields. ''If you are a woman or member of a minority group, there is no better time to go into engineering,'' said Dr. George Campbell Jr., president of the National Action Council for Minorities in Engineering. ''We can almost promise that you will find a job when you finish school.''
The council, a nonprofit group based in New York City and financed by industry, recently reported a 28.4 percent increase in the number of minority-group freshmen engineering students from 1986 to 1989.
Bell Laboratories, the research and development arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, plans to hire 500 to 600 new scientists and engineers this year. According to Jeannette Galvanek, Bell Labs' executive director of human resources, applicants should understand the changing telecommunications market. ''The prospects are extremely good for engineers and people who have a strong technology base and want to work in the business environment where there is an emphasis on quality,'' Ms. Galvanek said.
Elsewhere, Gary Dixon, a recent industrial-engineering graduate of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, now works as a marketing representative for the insurance branch of the International Business Machines Corporation in Hartford. Mr. Dixon, who hopes to become a corporate officer, said his engineering background ''has provided me with a strong basis for management and solving the customer's problems.''
Eleanor Baum, dean of engineering at Cooper Union, in New York City, described engineering as ''one of the few professions that after only four years of college allows people to solve real problems and move directly into the middle class in terms of salary.''
''The problem is that we in the profession have not done a good job of selling engineering to our young people,'' said Dean Baum. ''It's engineers who design solutions to our environmental problems, build new highways and develop new surgical equipment. I can't think of a more rewarding undertaking.''
