HEADLINE: Good Grief, It's Glasgow!

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY; CRAIG R. WHITNEY is head of the London bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
GLASGOW, the 1990 European City of Culture, after such choices as Athens, Florence, Amsterdam, West Berlin and Paris? People who think of Glasgow as it was in the 1960's, a place of sooty slums and idle shipyards along the River Clyde, will shake their heads in disbelief.
''Auld Reekie'' still has plenty of problems, and looks a little ragged around the edges of the huge high-rise housing projects that replaced neighborhoods like the Gorbals after they were razed in the 1970's. But the city also has a gritty sense of community pride in triumphing over the odds, a splendid architectural heritage from its Victorian heyday, and some of the most distinctive art collections in all of Europe. ''Raw, rich, Glasgow,'' the German art critic Hermann Muthesius called it at the beginning of this century, a description still fully apposite now that it's ending.
Community spirit suffuses the distinctive sandstone ''tenement'' neighborhoods, now being restored and gentrified like the brownstones of Brooklyn, from the east end of the city, dominated by the medieval spire of St. Mungo's Cathedral, to the Victorian Gothic tower of Glasgow University in the west end. 
Glasgow is an acquired taste, perhaps, with all the character, complexity and pungency of fine single-malt Scotch whisky. It became a crowded industrial city in the 19th century, its tenements swelling to slums as Irish immigrants and descendants of Scottish Highlanders driven out of the mountains by savage English resettlement measures poured in. Politically and culturally, many people in Glasgow today still feel a sense of grievance, and not at all a part of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's free-enterprise take-it-if-you-can-get-it Britain. Glasgow votes for the Labor Party, or even (in the old shipbuilding neighborhood of Govan) for the Scottish Nationalist Party.
It's the kind of city where people take strangers asking for directions on the streets under their wing with friendly answers that often start with ''Well, dearie, you take the next right . . .''
This year the city authorities are determined to show that unlike Edinburgh, the other place 44 miles down the road with the annual three-week festival in August, Glasgow has one that never stops. The European Community underscored its confidence by designating the city as the 1990 European City of Culture. Fortuitously, the city on the Clyde has just become a particuarly convenient destination for Americans, since the British Government has given up its futile insistence on making trans-Atlantic flights to Scotland go through remote Prestwick Airport and now allows nonstop scheduled flights to Glasgow Airport, 15 minutes from the center of town, from Boston, Chicago and New York (beginning Aug. 3), with direct connections to other American cities in the south and midwest.
The summer season has been under way since this month, with the annual Mayfest for theater, dance and music. Besides what is permanently on show - and more of that in a minute - the special artistic attractions later this year include the Bolshoi Opera, which is coming to the Scottish Exhibition and Conference Center in August before it goes to the Edinburgh Festival, the first time it has ever visited Britain. The program keeps changing, but the latest is Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Mlada'' Aug. 3 to 6 and Tchaikovsky's '' Maid of Orleans'' Aug. 10 to 12. A new international concert hall will open Oct. 8, with a dazzling schedule that begins with the Scottish National Orchestra and continues with the Berlin Philharmonic (Oct. 9 and 10), the Bolshoi Symphony Orchestra (Oct. 12), the London Philharmonic (Oct. 30), the Leipziger Gewandhaus Orchestra with Kurt Masur conducting on Oct. 31 and Peter Donohoe and Alfred Brendel playing the Brahms piano concertos successively on Nov. 1 and 2.
Other guest orchestras, for which there has been no suitable concert hall since St. Andrews Halls burned down 27 years ago, include the Israel Philharmonic (Nov. 21) with Zubin Mehta and the Orchestre de Paris with Semyon Bychkov (Dec. 16). Tickets for all these and other major performances can be ordered in the United States through Show Line, 800-962-9246.
But you don't need to wait until August or October to feast on the arts in Glasgow, which is also home to the Scottish Ballet, the Scottish Orchestra, 17 museums, 25 art galleries and 9 theaters. Two classically Scots characters, Sir William Burrell and Charles Rennie Mackintosh, have seen to that.
What sort of character Sir William was can be deduced from the Burrell collection in Pollok Park on the southern outskirts of the city, in a stunning modern building displaying Egyptian, Greek and Roman pottery, medieval stained glass, oriental carpets and French Impressionist paintings, to name just a few of the categories of the many objets d'art he assembled. Sir William was a shipowner who got out of that business at the right time and then used his money to do what he enjoyed best, which was collecting art from around the world. With Scottish shrewdness and thrift, he got his money's worth.
BUT in 1944, when he decided to donate the collection to the people of Glasgow, the air was so thick with pollution that most of the pink sandstone of the city had turned pitch black - so black that 19th-century repairers of the cathedral used black stone to plug up holes. Sandblasting and cleaning the cathedral today would leave it looking as if it had polka dots. Seeking to prevent any such depredations to his collection, Sir William stipulated that the Burrell collection be displayed far away from all the corruption, not less than 16 miles from the center of Glasgow.
He died in 1958 and no suitable place was found to display it until 1967, when Anne Maxwell MacDonald donated her Pollok Estate, about five miles out of town, to the city. By that time, antipollution regulations had led to considerable progress in cleaning up the air, and the Burrell trustees altered the terms of the gift to allow it to be housed in the splendid museum building constructed for it by private, municipal and government donations on the Pollok grounds. The building opened in 1983 to critical and popular acclaim. This summer the open lawn that surrounds it is graced by a special exhibit of nine of Henry Moore's largest works, which you may want to visit as part of a picnic lunchafter you've paid homage to Sir William.
Solidarity between the rich and the poor seems to be typically Glaswegian. In the splendid Kelvingrove museum and art gallery closer to town, for example, is one of the finest collections of medieval armor in the world, assembled by R. L. Scott, a shipbuilder whose company was later absorbed by the famous John Brown works until it and the rest of the industry died in the 1980's. Scott, the museum tells us, loved armor but, as a man with a social conscience, more or less gave up collecting in the 1930's because he thought it unseemly to be spending money that way with so many shipyard workers out of work. He gave in to temptation only once after that, when a unique suit of 15th-century Italian field armor came on the market in 1938.
The ships of Scott's and Sir William Burrell's day live on today in the Glasgow Transport Museum, across Argyle Street from the Kelvingrove, in one of the world's greatest collections of scale models. Most of the actual vessels, from the Queen Mary to the battleship Howe, were built right here. The museum is also a paradise for steam locomotive buffs, antique automobile fanatics and even admirers of fine prams.
The other principal character who left his artistic imprint on Glasgow was Charles Rennie Mackintosh, not only a true eccentric but also a brilliant architect, artist and designer of furniture. He and his wife, Margaret Macdonald, together with her sister Frances and her husband Herbert Macnair created the Art Deco movement known as the Glasgow Style.
Examples of Mackintosh's work abound today. The Glasgow School of Art building, up the hill on Renfrew Street, still serves the purpose for which it was designed in 1896. The extraordinary wrought-iron window brackets, which both brace the huge studio windows and provide a place for window cleaners to put their ladders, are worth a visit all by themselves, but from the beginning of June to the end of August, the School of Art will also house an exhibition called ''Mackintosh in Context.''
If you want to find out more about Mackintosh and the rest of the ''Glasgow Boys,'' who included the painters E. A. Walton, James Guthrie, George Henry and E. A. Hornel, there are plenty of other places to go.
The best, after a stroll through the magnificent Victorian campus of Glasgow University (not to be confused with the modern high-rises of Strathclyde University at the other end of town, near the cathedral) is the Hunterian art gallery, where Mackintosh's three-story home at 78 Southpark Avenue, has been lovingly reconstructed as the Mackintosh Wing, fitted out with all the high-backed Chinese chairs, teardrop lamps and mirror cases and white-painted furniture that it had when he lived in it.
After you finish immersing yourself in Mackintosh's designs, go straight to the James McNeill Whistler room, with one of the world's most extensive collections of this eccentric American painter's work. The Glasgow Boys much admired Whistler, who spent most of the last part of his life working in a studio in Glasgow. Its contents were given by his wife's sister, Whistler's heir, Rosalind Birnie Philip, to the university when he died, and it is fascinating to imagine how perfectly his somber studies of Miss Birnie Philip, ''harmonies'' in various dark colors, would have fitted right into Mackintosh's Art Deco rooms if he had had the money to put them there. Whistler's mother isn't here, but she was the daughter of a McNeill from Scotland who emigrated to the United States in 1746.
Mackintosh's design for a House for an Art Lover, set to paper in 1901, will finally be realized in August in Bellahouston Park; the Kelvingrove also has a fine collection of Mackintosh furniture.
Kelvingrove Museum (which, like all of Glasgow's public museums, has no admission fees, but asks visitors to make donations), is host to the first half of a two-week festival of choral music that begins June 22 and moves on June 30 to Glasgow Cathedral.
THE museum, which has a magnificent central court with resonant acoustics, also has a 1901 three-manual, 46-stop pipe organ built by Lewis & Co. of Brixton, England, in absolutely mint condition after an extensive restoration.
A few years ago, after German bombardments and years of dirty air, it wasn't even playable. ''The organ sort of sums Glasgow up at the moment,'' said Robert C. Woosnam-Savage, curator of the arms collection, who looks after the musical instruments as a sideline.
The instrument in the cathedral, a splendid example of 13th-century Gothic architecture, is by the legendary 19th-century English builder Henry Willis; the choral works sung there in August by the Cappella Nova will feature all five masses of Robert Carver, the Scottish Renaissance composer. Other amusements include Glasgow's Glasgow, an exhibition in 22 brick-vaulted arches recently rediscovered beneath the Victorian splendor of Central Station, displaying thousands of objects associated with the city.
Like the massive and opulent Glasgow City Chambers on George Square, or the insurance companies and stock market buildings along Buchanan Street, the exhibition, with videos, films and live workshops and performances, will remind visitors how Glasgow was once the richest city in the world, the place where money was made and banked from the cotton and tobacco trade with the colonies in Asia and the New World.
Proud Glaswegians point out that their city, with its trading tradition, has always been more ''European'' than much of the rest of the British Isles. A visitor walking down Queen Street might also be pardoned for thinking that the pure vowels and guttural glottal-stops of the native speech sound more German or Dutch than English.
''The decline of shipbuilding on Clydeside was not the first economic crisis we've been through,'' said Eddie Friel, head of the Greater Glasgow Tourist Board and Convention Bureau. ''It was 1776,'' he said, ''when almost overnight after the American declaration of independence the tobacco trade collapsed. After that it was the textile industry that rose, and fell.''
What Glaswegians have to see them through is a tradition, culture and heritage that is also manifested in their commitment to education.
For a city that has often felt itself on the periphery of Europe, vulnerable to decisions taken far away, designation as the European City of Culture is a chance to remind the world that it has never lost sight of its better days, even in the worst of times.
 
 
From Pissarro to the Rolling Stones: A cultural diary
The following cultural events are scheduled to take place in Glasgow in the coming months. Times and performers are subject to change and should be checked closer to the date.
 
Art
The Henry Moore Exhibition, in Pollok Park, Pollokshaws Road, will run through Oct. 14. Nine bronze sculptures are on display. Open from dawn to dusk; admission free.
An exhibition of 70 paintings, drawings and watercolors by Impressionist Camille Pissarro will run at the Burrell Collection in Pollok Park through June 17. Open Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Wednesday 10 A.M. to 10 P.M., Sunday noon to 6 P.M. Admission free.
 
Drama
Glenda Jackson stars in Bertolt Brecht's ''Mother Courage,'' presented for Mayfest by the Citizens' Company in association with the Goethe Institut. It will run through June 2 at the Citizens' Theater, the Gorbals. Performances at 7:30 P.M. Monday to Saturday; closed Sunday. Admission $8, calculated at a rate of $1.60 to the pound. Information: telephone 429-0022.
The Bolshoi Theater will stage the British premiere of Tchaikovsky's ''Maid of Orleans'' at the Scottish Exhibition and Conference Centre, Finnieston, Aug. 10 to 12. The company will also present Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Mlada'' from Aug. 3 to 6 at the same venue. Tickets range from $12 to $120 and can be obtained at the Ticket Center, Candleriggs; 227-5511.
The Royal Shakespeare Company will bring ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses,'' adapted by Christopher Hampton from the novel by Choderlos de Laclos, to the Mitchell Theater, Granville Street, from July 9 to Sept. 22; 221-3198. Performances Monday to Saturday at 7:30 P.M. and Saturday at 2:30 P.M.; closed Sunday. Tickets from $12.75 to $20.
Street Biz, a street theater festival, will run from Aug. 11 to 26e in shopping centers and parks as well as on the streets. Artists include Stalker, an Australian who performs acrobatic dance on stilts and the Balalaika Music and Dance Ensemble from the Soviet Union. Information: 204-4059. All events are free.
 
Music
Scottish National Orchestra Proms will be held June 15 to June 30. Guests include Sir Peter Maxwell Davies, conducting music from Gilbert and Sulliavan, on June 19. The season also features a night of Broadway classics conducted by Carl Davis on June 20, and Beethoven's Eighth Symphony and Choral Symphony No. 9 on June 27, conducted by Norman Del Mar. The Proms will be held at Kelvin Hall, Argyle Street. Information: Scottish National Orchestra, 3 La Belle Place, Glasgow G3 7LH. Tickets from $3.25 to $19 for individual concerts, and from $28 to $160 for tickets good for 12 concerts. Tickets available from the Ticket Center, Candleriggs; 227-5511.
''The Big Day'' on June 3 is being billed as the biggest music event ever staged in Scotland, with more than 50 musicians and musical groups playing all over the city. The main venues include George Square, with rock and pop bands from Glasgow and Dublin; the Riverside at Custom House Quay, with jazz, folk and classical music; People's Palace on Glasgow Green, with international music, and the Haugh on Glasgow Green, at 9:30 p.m., rock and pop musicians in aid of the homeless. All events are free.
Glasgow International Early Music Festival will be held Aug. 4 to 11, with ticket prices from $3.20 to $19 and a season ticket good for all events $112. A highlight will be the modern world premiere of Marazzoli's opera ''La Vita Humana'' written and last performed in 1656. It will be produced by the Scottish Early Music Consort, 22 Falkland Street, Glasgow G12 9PR; 334-9229. Tickets available from the Ticket Center, Candleriggs; 227-5511.
The Rolling Stones will play the only Scottish date of their world tour in Glasgow's Hampden Park on July 9. Tickets, $32 and limited to six a person, can be obtained from the Ticket Center, Candleriggs; 227-5511.
The Scottish Opera, beginning Monday, will present Nuria Espert's production of ''Madama Butterfly,'' conducted by John Mauceri, Additional performances May 23, 26, 31 and June 5 at 7:15 P.M. and June 2 at 2:15 P.M. Tickets from $8 to $40. Information: Theater Royal, Hope Street, Glasgow G2 3QA; 331-1234.
Fourth Glasgow International Jazz Festival will open June 29 with the Kronos Quartet and will run to July 8. Performers include B. B. King on June 30, the Dizzy Gillespie United Nations All-Star Orchestra on July 7, the Miles Davis Group July 3 and The Jazz Warriors July 5. Tickets from $4.80 to $40;from the Ticket Center, Candleriggs; 227-5511. Some free events are planned. Information: 226-3262.
 
Dance
''Dance Into Glasgow'' will open June 8 at the Theater Royal with the Belgian company Rosas performing the British premiere of ''Stella'' by Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker. The season continues until June 28 and will feature the London Contemporary Dance Theater, Nederlands Dans Theater 2 from The Hague and the Trisha Brown Dance Company from New York. Theater Royal, Hope Street; 331-1234. Performances start at 7.30 P.M.; tickets from $5.60 to $17.
 
Architecture
Doors Open Day, on Sept. 1, will feature the opening of more than 60 buildings normally closed to visitors. Among them will be Gothic churches, Georgian merchant houses, Victorian civic halls and modern offices. Admission is free. A map will be available from city center locations and at the buildings involved.

PUB-DATE: May 20, 1990,

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3, Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1203 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Condos Surging As Resort Choice

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
RENTALS of resort condominium are booming. What is propelling them is the need of families with two or three children to economize on food by having some meals in and to get enough space while spending a week skiing or visiting Disney World. Anyone who has crowded a family with two children into a motel room needs no hard sell to know why renting a place with two rooms for sleeping, two baths, two television sets and a kitchen is a step forward.
Resort condominiums, which are concentrated in popular vacation areas like the Colorado Rockies, Hawaii, Florida and the Caribbean, cannot easily be defined. The individual units, which may be suites in a high-rise building, side-by-side units or cottages - known usually as ''villas'' - may be privately owned, usually as a second home, or may have several owners who use it at different times. Sometimes units are rented when they have not been sold yet. A central managing company operates and maintains the condominium, sometimes in conjunction with a convention center or a hotel. 
According to a survey made by John Dalton, a consultant to the travel industry, condo rental is growing faster than another hot vacation option, ship cruises. In 1988, 17 million people stayed in the 2.5 million resort condominiums in North America, compared with 3.1 million people who took cruises. In 1989, his figures showed, condo rentals rose 13 percent while the figures for cruising rose 5 percent.
Condominiums are used mainly by people who drive rather than fly. And United States Travel Data Center figures for 1988 show that 80 percent of leisure travelers moved on their own wheels, while 16 percent used planes.
Richard H. Fisher, head of a new network for travel agents, Condominium Travel Associates, says that 60 percent of the renters of condos are young families, who do not travel by plane because of the cost of individual tickets for children. The other big blocks of customers, Mr. Fisher says, are older travelers, extended families or couples traveling together, and golfers.
When you peruse catalogues and surveys, it is quickly apparent that the majority of resort condominiums include units with two bedrooms, providing a common room and privacy.
 
Saving on Breakfasts
Lower costs are as important as space. Mr. Dalton analyzed figures gathered by state tourism bureaus and found that the biggest portion of travelers' budgets went for food and that lodging costs were second. An equipped kitchen with a refrigerator for milk, juice, fruit and cereal eliminates the need for expensive breakfasts out. Other meals in are possible if the cooks in the family are agreeable.
You can presume that since this resort condominium is someone's home, it will be a place where you can be self-sustaining, as you cannot in a bed-and-breakfast or a motel. You may presume that there will be a kitchen, fully equipped and that parking comes with the rental. You will be told the name and number of someone to summon if things are not right, which may be a front desk clerk or a real estate agent several miles down the road. In the preponderance of two-bedroom units, there is a bath for each bedroom, but ask about this. Swimming pools are almost standard, and hot tubs are common.
A prospective renter should begin by asking the travel agent, real estate agent or managing company about the size and equipment of the facilities and what will be in the kitchen.
If you have children, you may be less interested in elegance than in durability. At Amelia Island in Florida, the beds were large and comfortable and the decoration ran to cabbage roses, but the china was neat stacks of Pyroceram.
Price is the good news. Catalogues and surveys indicate that you can get a condo suite for the price of a hotel room, or cheaper, in many popular areas, although obviously Florida is going to cost more in the winter, and Vail will be higher in ski season. Clinton Burr of Chicago, president of a group called Resort Property Owners Association, recently surveyed members who owned time-share condos. They were concentrated in the big resort condo areas, California, Colorado, Florida, Hawaii and Mexico. Answers from 1,123 owners showed that 32 percent of weekly rentals were in the $501 to $750 bracket and 27 percent in the $251 to $500 range. Weekly rental prices went as low as $100 (0.5 percent) and up to $1,300 (0.9 percent).
One organization, for example, Endless Vacation Travel (Post Office Box 80014, Indianapolis, Ind. 46280; 800-447-8004) is offering two-bedroom condos in Orlando for $806 a week to Sept. 7 and $662 to $806 Sept. 7 to mid-November.
The bad news seems to be heard from time-share condos: heavy sales pitches to the renting tenants to buy a time-share, or a unit. Mr. Burr, a lawyer, began to organize his owners' association after a sales person with a prospective buyer and a super-hard sell disrupted him and his family at the pool at the condo they own in Hawaii. Alan Coffin, president of Fair Winds Tours in Stoneham, Mass., says he will not offer condominium stays to his clients any more because of sales pressures. One client at a condo in the Orlando are was awakened at 7 A.M., he said, by a summons to a sales breakfast.
The best way to rent a condominium, most experts say, is to use a travel agent in your hometown where you have some leverage if things turn out to be not as you were led to believe, since you will probably pay in advance and thus you cannot use the threat of withholding payment.
 
Specialists and Directories
Mr. Fisher's organization, now a year old, is in touch with condo-specialist travel agents in 70 areas; names and numbers are available from Condominium Travel Associates, 2001 West Main Street, Suite 140, Stamford, Conn. 06902; 203-975-7714.
Mr. Burr and his wife, Ellen, have visited 2,000 condos in recent years and have published two regional guides in which they rate 500 of them. Mr. Burr, who formed his owners' association in 1987, acknowledges that their early ratings are more generous than they would be today; some ''highly recommended'' 8's, on a scale of 10, would be ''average'' 7's or ''adequate'' 6's. He estimates that of the 2,000 condos, 700 rank 6 or better.
''Resort Property Owners Association Travel Guide Southeast,'' published in 1989, rates 260 places. The guide to the Southwest, also 1989, rates 240. Either book is $12.95 from Resort Property Owners Association, 175 West Jackson Boulevard, Suite 1901, Chicago, Ill. 60604; 312-939-0141. Later this year Pequot Press will publish the Burrs' book rating 600 top places, ''Condo Critic.'' It will be in bookstores.
Pamela Lanier has compiled a directory of 2,000 vacation condominiums in the United States, including Hawaii, and the Caribbean. This paperback, ''Condo Vacations,'' is now in its second edition. She charges condominiums $125 for a full entry, which includes a promotional paragraph provided by the condo, along with price range, location, phone numbers and other data. Simple listings are free. Ms. Lanier says she drops places about which she receives complaints. The 1990 edition, distributed to bookstores by Ten Speed Press, Box 7123, Berkeley, Calif. 94707, costs $14.95.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: May 20, 1990,

SECTION: Section 6; Page 30, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5090 words

HEADLINE: READ HIS LIPS: MORE TAXES

BYLINE: By Peter Kerr: Peter Kerr is chief of the New Jersey bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
OUTSIDERS FIRST SUSPECTED THAT SOMETHING UNUSUAL WAS AFOOT in Trenton, the sleepy capital on the bank of the Delaware River, several hours before Jim Florio took the oath of office as the 49th Governor of New Jersey.
His press office issued a 25-page plan for the Governor's first day, replete with details of each moment and movement, including the number of the state parking lot from which howitzers would fire a 19-gun salute.
''8:25 P.M. Photo Opportunity: Governor and Mrs. Florio to proceed to a designated table to stage right for an appetizer,'' the release promised. A reporter jokingly asked Florio's press secretary, Jon Shure, how long his boss planned to keep up such a frenetic and metronomically perfect schedule. ''Eight years,'' Shure replied. Seven days later, the Governor announced his plan to bring down automobile-insurance rates, a drastically pro-consumer move that would cost the insurance industry $1.4 billion over seven years. Then Florio assailed the Exxon Corporation as environmentally irresponsible, dismissed the powerful head of the State Police and endorsed a ban on assault rifles. Meanwhile, his band of policy experts, quickly dubbed Floriocrats, worked on plans to solve the state's health-care crisis, and debated how New Jersey could save the children of its inner cities. 
Florio explained his initiatives in a voice salted by the tough accent of a childhood in Brooklyn, where his father painted ships on the Red Hook waterfront. Florio is a former amateur boxer; his left cheekbone remains sunken from a punch. The whole tone of politics has been transformed from that of Florio's predecessor, an affable patrician named Thomas H. Kean.
''They call themselves 'the good hands people,' '' Florio said the day after the Allstate Insurance Company announced it would sue to block the new Governor's auto-insurance plan. ''The question is which part of our anatomy do they have their good hands around?''
It wasn't until Day 58 that it became clear what Jim Florio was up to: he was determined to pronounce the age of Ronald Reagan dead in New Jersey.
Faced with a yawning deficit, Florio declared in his first budget address that he planned to raise more than $2.6 billion in new taxes, including a doubling of income taxes for the state's most affluent residents; he would also cut more than a billion dollars in popular programs. Wall Street approved. Florio's fellow Democrats were stunned.
The Governor believed that the worst thing a Democrat could do at a time of budget deficit was act like a Reagan Republican, his aides explained. Florio argued that Trenton and Washington had grown flabby and muddleheaded over the last decade. They had eschewed sound public policy for communications-media politics. New Jersey was now receiving a dose of old-fashioned efficiency, administered by a lean, mean liberal. Florio's strategy, political experts say, is a high-risk experiment that assumes that the Governor will be able to explain why tax increases and service cuts are necessary. Unlike other governors in the Northeast, Florio did not wait until he was forced to raise taxes; he took the initiative and taxed and cut more than anyone had expected.
Because public-policy debates in Washington have been dominated for the last 18 months by George Bush's 1988 campaign pledge not to raise taxes, the Florio experiment is being watched particularly closely in Washington now that President Bush is finding it harder and harder to hold the line as the deficit rises. New Jersey is also being closely scrutinized by national Democratic leaders, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who attempted to delay higher taxes even as Wall Street was losing faith in New York's fiscal management. And Florio is being eyed by his former colleagues in Congress, who have long believed that Democrats caught advocating tax increases were doomed.
''What Jim Florio has done is set up a test case for the Democratic Party,'' said Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat from suburban Bergen County. ''For a decade, Democrats have been intimidated from offering substantive alternatives to the politics and rhetoric of Ronald Reagan. Now they are watching Jim Florio because he represents either the last defeat of a terrible decade, or our first success story in a new time when politics in America can be redefined.''
Already Florio's Democratic allies in the State Legislature are hearing howls about budget cuts from everyone from school-board activists to local arts groups. Republicans predict that Florio will soon be seen by voters as a stiff-necked ideologue, a Robespierre-like figure seeking purity of government at the expense of real people.
But Florio, who as a Congressman wrote the nation's ''superfund'' law to clean up toxic wastes, and who developed a passionate constituency among the blue-collar workers in Camden County, the very voters who were otherwise abandoning the Democratic Party for Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan, says he senses that people in the 1990's are ready to accept temporary hardship if they believe they are getting good government in return.
''Reagan's choice between more government and less government is no longer the relevant question,'' Florio said. ''It is a now a choice between dumb government and smart government. ''
ON TUESDAYS at 8:15 A.M., JIM Florio gathers a half-dozen top Floriocrats into a cavernous paneled room, which Gov. Woodrow Wilson once used as his office. This morning, Florio's forehead is scrunched into wrinkles. His finger is pointed like a pistol. He is imitating the elderly man he met last night at a seder for Russian emigres.
''He's the uncle you've got in every family, lecturing everyone, telling everybody how you do it right,'' Florio says. ''And the kid's great. Seven years old, he's already reading from the Haggadah. Then he wants to talk a little public policy.''
The Floriocrats are laughing. This is the loose Florio, the man the public rarely sees. When not among friends, he can appear formal and rigid. But among his closest assistants, rational workaholics weighted with Ivy League degrees, his humor is breezy.
Florio rattles through disputes at agencies that his people are still trying to take control of. His aides describe the gathering storm: gun owners are irate; groups of the disabled plan a demonstration; Assembly Republicans have compared him to a dictator; Floyd Abrams, the New York constitutional lawyer hired by Allstate, filed suit in Federal District Court - demanding, in effect, that Florio refrain from acting like a tyrant. Florio is confident that the suit will go nowhere.
''There is a real good example of lawyer entrepreneurship,'' Florio says with a contemptuous chuckle.
A few minutes later, Florio enters his small corner study. The walls are adorned with a painting of Franklin D. Roosevelt; another, of a bald eagle, and two photographs of heavyweight fights.
''Ronald Reagan used the right rhetoric for the wrong policies,'' says Florio, who served nearly 15 years as a United States Representative before coming to Trenton. ''There is no such thing as a free lunch. But I sense there is now a tremendous desire out there to have somebody make some hard decisions.''
At first glance, New Jersey seems an unlikely place to launch an assault on the Reagan Revolution. During the 1980's, its economy blossomed, attracting high-technology industries and creating nearly 650,000 new jobs. Like Reagan, Kean used the press to instill confidence in a dispirited public and generate enormous popularity for himself. The scion of a wealthy family that traces its roots to the state's first Governor, Kean promoted New Jersey's strengths, from its shoreline to its tax advantages for businesses. Also like Reagan, Kean was re-elected by a landslide.
But there was a dark side to the Kean years. Along highways like Route 1, a once-bucolic road from New Brunswick to Trenton, the boom produced mile after mile of uncontrolled sprawl. At rush hours, traffic was choked. New Jersey ran out of space to dump its garbage. Automobile-insurance premiums rose to become among the highest in the nation, and local property taxes skyrocketed. In the state's aging cities, where 12 percent of the population lived, the economic boom never happened at all. Jersey City's HIV infection rate - RATE TK - rivals that of parts of Africa; Camden's children were the poorest of any city in the nation. Despite Reaganite rhetoric, the state's government doubled in size under Kean, and although the roaring suburban economy gave it surpluses of up to $1 billion during the boom years, New Jersey put little aside for lean years.
Critics charged that Governor Kean had waited for a public consensus to develop, and thus avoided making unpopular decisions. Often, they say, he let public policy wander and problems languish. ''Tom Kean was a wonderful communicator and a decent man,'' said Richard W. Roper, the director of the Program for New Jersey Affairs at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, at Princeton University. ''But regarding many of the state's most profound problems, he was not prepared to lead.''
Only hours after Jim Florio took office, on Jan. 16, he began to centralize the power that (Continued on Page 51) had been dispersed across a bureaucracy. Among the first of the heads to roll was that of Col. Clinton L. Pagano, the much-feared Superintendent of State Police, who had run an independent fiefdom for 14 years. Among his questionable priorities was a two-year undercover crusade against homosexuals in the men's room of the Vince Lombardi rest stop, on the New Jersey Turnpike.
Just as quickly, Florio acted on policies he had been studying for more than a decade. Florio's automobile-insurance proposal, based on months of hearings before a House subcommittee that he headed, concluded that insurance companies had taken advantage of New Jersey's no-fault insurance system.
Foremost in the Governor's plan was getting rid of the Joint Underwriting Association, a body that, under Kean, began in 1984 to insure high-risk drivers. The law permitted insurers to make money by selling J.U.A. policies, but they were not responsible for any losses of the association, nor of J.U.A.-insured drivers. The J.U.A. eventually insured half the state's drivers and paid out the majority of claims. As the insurer of poor drivers, it ran a deficit of more than $3.1 billion. To keep the association afloat, a car owner in New Jersey by last year was paying $222 per car each year just to keep the association afloat.
Florio made his explanation of the problem clear: the insurance companies pillaged the public, and it was time for them to pay the people back. The Governor's plan would impose taxes and assessments of $1.4 billion against insurance companies over seven years to pay off the association debt. Florio's strategy was to bring down the average premium in the state from $1,112 a year to about $860. It whipped through the Legislature and Florio signed it into law.
Spokesmen for the industry said Florio had made insurance companies scapegoats for a complex problem with no quick solutions. Taking an unusual legal tack, Floyd Abrams, the lawyer hired by Allstate, the largest insurer of automobiles in the state, asked the court in Newark not only to declare the new law unconstitutional but to issue an injunction to stop Florio from what Abrams describes as an attempt to intimidate Allstate.
''We need an injunction against him personally,'' Abrams said. ''Anyone who disagrees with him is morally tainted and worthy of punishment. He is, in short, treating this like a crusade.''
It was with the budget that Florio took his biggest political risks. By January, New Jersey's budget, like those of states throughout the Northeast, was falling into a tailspin. If no major changes were made in Kean's budget proposals, Florio aides said, the shortfall would reach into the billions.
Consequently, in the first year Florio's cuts would devastate school boards and gut programs in the environment, health care, education and just about every other field but welfare and prisons. Florio's cuts included programs he himself endorsed and they angered interest groups that support Democrats; it was necessary, his aides said, to show that he must first bring government under control before he can achieve any other goals. It put him in an unusual position for a Democrat: Florio could be accused of being heartless, but not of being a slave to special interests.
Together with a 1 percent rise in the sales tax, the Florio plan, with a bit of luck from the economy, could generate a sizable surplus by the end of his first term. Florio also proposed a legal cap on state spending and a rainy-day fund, to save surpluses and avoid crises in the future.
But his proposal went even further than balancing the budget; he proposed restructuring the tax system, one of the most ideologically charged subjects in New Jersey politics. His income-tax increase would raise $1.25 billion, with most of the burden falling on people making more than $100,000. And it would aid poor school districts and help lift the cost of welfare and social services from cities and counties.
Although Florio described his fiscal package as aid to the middle classes, others called it liberal social engineering. A Bergen Record reporter labeled him Robin Hood. Conservative economists and others predicted that raising the income tax would chase away corporate leaders and destroy the business climate with which Kean had lured companies and jobs from New York.
Already, daily demonstrations by groups protesting cuts have become the norm in front of the Trenton State House. The talk in shopping malls is about a strange new Governor and the taxes he has wrought. But as the Democratic-controlled Legislature faces a June 30 deadline to approve the new budget, most legislators are saying, at least for now, that they expect to follow Florio on a white-knuckled trip into an uncharted future.
JIM FLORIO SPENT HIS adult life preparing to become Governor of New Jersey. From his early years, people recall a drive in the man, a relentless and lonely struggle for self-perfection that even his friends find difficult to fathom. Often he took on people more powerful than himself. Perhaps his greatest strength, they say, was that he was not afraid to lose.
''I can't imagine anyone with more discipline or ability to concentrate on a goal,'' said a former aide and close friend, Joseph C. Salema. ''Some people find it a little inhuman. Those of us who like him find it inspiring.''
James Joseph Florio was born on Aug. 29, 1937, to parents who lived in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn. His father was the son of an emigre from Bari, Italy. His mother, a Protestant of Irish, Scottish and German descent, was the daughter of another shipyard worker, a master pipe fitter.
After World War II, work became scarce for the senior Florio. The Governor clearly recalls accompanying his father one day to find a job along the docks. Men stood in line as union officials walked by. Each man was desperate to be picked for a day's employment.
''People were trying to stick their chins out or their chests out to be noticed,'' Florio said. ''It was like a damn slave market. Nobody should have to be that dependent for their life and their livelihood.''
At age 12, Florio began to hold two jobs at a time, delivering The Brooklyn Eagle and kosher meat for Louis Balitsky, a nearby butcher. At times, his mother served oatmeal for dinner. He often spent Saturdays alone, reading, at the Brooklyn Public Library.
Florio dropped out of high school in his senior year, to join the Navy; he served as a weather specialist in Florida and Alaska.
As a boxer, after running up a string of knockouts as a light middleweight, one day he stepped into the ring with a Sea Bee who outweighed him by 16 pounds. Each blow he took broke something, Florio recalls. He staggered away with a broken jaw, a broken nose, a split lip and a crushed cheekbone. His mouth was wired shut for six weeks.
Florio earned his equivalency diploma in the Navy and, after his discharge, entered Trenton State College. After a half-ring of his alarm clock at 5:30 A.M., a former roommate recalls, he would slide out of bed, study until 7, then go to breakfast, a meal he rarely missed, because it was included in his room and board.
Florio won election as president of the student body, earned top grades, to become among the first Trenton State students to win a Woodrow Wilson Fellowship to Columbia University. He married another top Trenton student, Maryanne Spaeth, who dropped out of college to give birth to their first son, Christopher, in 1961. In the following three years, they had a second son, Gregory, and a daughter, Catherine.
In 1963, Florio arrived in Camden with a pregnant wife, two babies, a beat-up station wagon and plans to run for public office. He worked as a laborer, a nightwatchman, a government clerk. While attending law school, he began his ascent in the Democratic Party, attracting attention as a highly efficient district leader who beefed up registration by knocking on doors with a small notebook in hand.
By the late 1960's, Florio was a practicing lawyer and president of the Camden Young Democrats. Val Raugas, a fellow student at Trenton State, recalls seeing Florio at a party in 1969 and hearing him say he wanted to be Governor.
Over the next 21 years, Florio ran in 15 races. In 1969, he was elected to the State Assembly. Three years later, he ran and nearly beat a conservative Republican incumbent Congressman, Representative John Hunt, even though the district included rural Republican towns and blue-collar suburbs filled with refugees from riot-torn Camden. Many of the Florio voters split the ticket that year, and voted for Richard Nixon against George McGovern.
Hunt was the first Republican to find that accusations of liberalism didn't shake voters' attraction to Florio. Hunt accused Florio of supporting ''the white flag sellout of our prisoners of war, legalization of marijuana, lawful prostitution, public drunkenness and sexual activities between persons of the same sex.'' But Florio spoke the language of blue-collar voters. He talked tough on crime. He addressed everyday concerns. And for many anxious ethnic voters, Florio personified the ideal of a young man who achieves success through hard work. In a 1974 rematch against Hunt, Florio won.
Camden County's new Congressman was the consummate retail politician. His district offices were known for excellent constituent services. Almost every moment Florio was not in Washington, he was in his district, appearing at veterans halls, senior centers, yard sales, wherever voters gathered.
''There was a running joke in Washington; if someone in the district needed a fourth for bridge, he would be there,'' said Daniel J. Dalton, a former aide who is now the State Senate majority leader. ''He was non-stop. He would get into the office at 7 A.M. He would leave at 7 at night, with a file under his arm. That was four days a week. On Friday afternoons, I'd take him to the train station. He had events in the district Friday night, all day Saturday, all day Sunday.''
Florio became enormously popular in the district, and after a failed race for the gubernatorial nomination in 1977, he led a slate of dissident Democrats in a challenge to the Democratic power structure, including the old-style urban machine of Camden. The Florio team won, establishing him as the dominant Democratic figure in Southern New Jersey.
Florio also broke from the Democratic establishment in 1978 by backing the senatorial candidacy of a former basketball star named Bill Bradley, against a candidate backed by the Democratic Governor, Brendan Byrne. Ever since then, the Bradley-Florio relationship has been like those with other politicians Florio respects: cordial, professional, but not close personally.
IN WASHINGTON, FLORIO had no time for the social swirl; he spent most evenings at home, in a spartan apartment over a liquor store, reading. Florio was known as a brilliant, hardworking, and not terribly warm master of policy. He was a bitter antagonist of the Reagan Administration. Many fellow Democrats were put off by his refusal to compromise.
Other Congressmen were unimpressed with Florio's public speaking style, which was as clear and moving as a guide to industrial software. One former campaign aide, Fred Hillmann, called it ''bureaucratese, no, fractured bureaucratese.''
''He tended to add words to sentences to make them more complicated, as if people who speak with lots of big words were smarter,'' a former administrative assistant, Bill Roberts, said. ''Maybe it was the lower-class kid's idea of what a Congressman should sound like. He never went to Ivy League schools, and showed trepidation around those people who did.''
The demeanor that Florio considered appropriate for the serious work of government, other Congressmen sometimes perceived as formal, almost robotic. His dress was meticulous. Photographers usually found him in a jacket and tie. Florio's public persona allowed little room for emotion, none for frivolity. But colleagues agreed that Florio excelled on issues. After two terms, he jumped over six Democrats with more seniority to gain chairmanship of a subcommittee on transportation and commerce. There he engineered deregulation of the railroad freight industry, successfully fighting a Reagan Administration proposal to have the Government sell off Conrail before it could reorganize into a more-profitable venture. Florio also fought to save funds for Amtrak and helped force the dismissal of the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Anne Gorsuch Burford, after charges of mismanagement of the superfund.
The Superfund Bill of 1980 was designed to shift the cost of cleaning up waste sites to polluters, and allowed the Federal Government and the states to charge polluters up to three times the cost of cleanups.
Almost all of the issues Florio took on over a decade and a half were also New Jersey issues. In addition to making laws, he was also preparing himself to be Governor. In 1981, many politicians expected Jim Florio to breeze to victory over his opponent, Tom Kean. But with too many stops on his campaign schedule, he often arrived late and left brusquely. On television, he appeared cold. Kean, meanwhile, campaigned with lackadaisical ease, charming the press and public alike with a folksy optimism. The irony of the 1981 race was this: The son of a ship painter, cursed by a rigid formality, was seen by the voters as arrogant. The son of American aristocrats, blessed with a fluid self-confidence, campaigned as Everyman.
Florio's lead dwindled away, and on Election Day he lost by 1,797 votes. After a month of recounts, Florio, ill and exhausted, conceded defeat.
''WHEN I MET JAMES, HE lived in an apartment that was all borrowed things, odds and ends, really,'' said Lucinda Florio, the Governor's second wife. ''He would invite his own children over for dinner and say, 'Bring your own silverware.' ''
Florio had been legally separated from his wife, Maryanne, in 1978. His life had been so dominated by work that he had spent little time with his family, and on the campaign trail he rarely showed off his wife or children. After the divorce, friends say he dated in Washington, but most of his life was still work. He owned one pair of shoes. He drove a Ford Escort.
Following the 1981 defeat, Florio had moved to a small apartment in Pine Hill, a suburb of Camden. One day the attractive blond third-grade teacher who lived on the floor above received a note from ''Jim downstairs,'' asking her out to dinner. She accepted.
Lucinda Coleman, also divorced, a former high school dropout, and also the daughter of a shipyard worker, found Florio delightfully unpretentious. Together, they read books, viewed videos at home, went bird-watching. Occasionally, they spent weekends at the Shore. He admitted to a weakness he never could master: Haagen-Dazs coffee ice cream. They were married on Valentine's Day in 1988.
The love affair with Lucinda, friends say, brought a dramatic change in Florio, in the way he viewed the world and the way the world viewed him. Over time, he became more relaxed, talked about emotions, and began making jokes at his own expense.
''At about that time, I went out with Jim to a restaurant,'' said Benjamin Palumbo, a friend. ''He was humming. I said, 'Jim, I've never heard you hum.' He just smiled and kept on humming.''
Florio prepared for his 1989 run for Governor the way he did for everything else, methodically trying to rectify his past mistakes. For five years, he met with the state's politicians, journalists, business and religious leaders. Florio hired a top Washington media consultant, Carter Eskew, and sucked up information on modern media campaigns like a sponge.
Lucinda, it turned out, was a political godsend. She had all the human qualities he appeared to lack in 1981. Florio now stood in public, radiating warmth as he held her hand. Florio now chirped on about his new grandson, Matthew, as he never had about his own children. Lucinda also provided quick, lively quotes. ''My husband is the only man I know who can talk passionately about sludge,'' Lucinda told a reporter, interrupting one of her husband's discourses on recycling.
But the Florio campaign faced a new problem. Republicans in Camden were charging that since Florio's allies had taken control of Camden County government, they had created an unsavory political machine that used government jobs and contracts to reward friends.
In one case, Joseph C. Salema, Florio's chief of staff, and Nicholas Rudi, a campaign aide who became the County Administrator and Treasurer, left their jobs to form a consulting concern that then received hundreds of thousands of dollars in contracts from the county. In another, Salema, Rudi and Florio, with other investors, bought the land and building of the faltering Continental Bank of New Jersey with promissory notes that would be paid off in rent from the bank's future profits. After newspapers raised questions of impropriety, Florio sold his interest in the bank and donated the profits to Trenton State College.
Florio, in fact, had been distant from the day-to-day workings of the county, and he later pressed for reforms after the practices had been outlined in a local newspaper series. But he pointed out that there was never any evidence of corruption among his former aides and that their practices were no different from those in most other counties in the state.
Florio's opponent, a conservative from the northwestern corner of the state, Representative Jim Courter, had arranged to hire Roger Stone and Roger Ailes, two media consultants who helped maul Michael Dukakis in 1988. From Republican literature and statements to the press, Democrats believed their opponents would portray Florio as a corrupt boss, a liberal, and, taking advantage of his Italian name and sunken cheek, a politician with links to the Mafia.
Florio decided his campaign would avoid the mistakes of Democratic disasters past, particularly those of Dukakis. He agreed to seize the low ground first, by hitting the Republicans harder, sooner and nastier than they hit him. Also, he planned to say he saw no need for new taxes, even as the state's fiscal situation turned grim. Finally, the Florio of 1989, unlike the Florio of 1981, boiled his policies down to simple phrases, such as ''clean water,'' ''lower auto-insurance rates'' and ''opportunity.''
Courter opened with: ''If you liked Michael Dukakis, you'll love Jim Florio.'' It was the same mistake Hunt had made 15 years earlier.
When the Republicans questioned why Florio had failed to vote for a state bill establishing penalties for desecrating the flag, Florio held a news conference the next day at the Trenton War Memorial. He surrounded himself with fellow veterans and a former prisoner of war.
''If you are challenging my patriotism,'' Florio said to Courter, ''come out and say it like a man.'' Courter had never served in the military.
Florio labeled Courter ''toxic polluter,'' because of a small spill of fuel oil that took place on one of Courter's properties. He questioned how Courter had ''grown rich in Congress'' (Courter's mother had died while he was in office, leaving him a substantial inheritance). By October, Courter was reeling from each new Florio blow. The day after Florio defeated Courter, 61.2 to 37.2 percent, sweeping a Democratic majority into the Legislature, a reporter asked the Governor-elect what other Democrats around the nation could learn from the campaign.
''Don't be a patsy,'' Florio said.
DAY. Florio sits wearing earphones in the studio of radio station WHWH, in Princeton. It is a tiny, cramped space. Florio is practicing the retail politics he learned in Camden, but now he's attempting to reach 7.5 million constituents. Some are enraged. Others are confused.
''It's like your own budget, Jean,'' Florio says to a caller from Ewing who asks the Governor not to raise the sales tax. ''If you have got more expenditures than you have money, you have to cut down on your expenditures. So we are making the cuts. But that is not even enough. We have got to raise some money, just to get ourselves even.'' ''What about my property taxes?'' says a resident of Colonia. ''Can you confirm rumors you are hiring 1,000 new police to confiscate guns?'' asks a constituent from Summit.
Florio answers patiently, sometimes providing more details than his listeners can follow. The lines are backed up with hundreds of calls. Who knows if Jean feels any better, having heard the Governor's words? Who knows if his message is working at all?
But Florio is already thinking about the next appearance tonight and the long drive ahead before he and Lucinda can rest. There won't be time for dinner, he tells his wife, who has been waiting outside the studio. Just time to pick up a quart of coffee ice cream at a grocery. In his pocket, he has packed a spoon. ''You brought your own spoon,'' says Lucinda. ''I'll share,'' says the Governor. ''But you control the spoon,'' says Lucinda.
In matters he cares about, Lucinda says later, Jim Florio always remains in control.

PUB-DATE: May 20, 1990,

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 20, Column 1; Sophisticated Traveler Magazine

LENGTH: 2873 words

HEADLINE: BOMBAY: OLD AND NEW GATEWAY TO INDIA

BYLINE: By GILLIAN TINDALL; Gillian Tindall is the author of ''Journey of a Lifetime and Other Stories,'' forthcoming from Hutchinson.

 BODY:

By Pa and Ma I'm daily told
To marry now's my time,
For though I'm very far from old,
I'm rather in my prime.
They say while we have any sun
We ought to make our hay -
And India has so hot a one,
I'm going to Bombay!
 
 
 
Thomas Hood's famous ditty, ''I'm Going to Bombay,'' embodies just one aspect of the great 19th-century saga of British imperialism. The hopeful young woman making the Victorian journey on one of the new steam vessels - complete with a tropical outfit, camphor, smelling salts, letters of introduction and a Bible - confidently expected to catch a husband among the homesick British Army officers, administrators and businessmen congregated on Indian soil. 
 
My cousin writes from Hyderapot,
 My only chance to snatch,
And says the Climate is so hot,
 It's sure to light a match . . .
 
 From the time that the Pilgrim Fathers set sail westward, Englishmen have been making forays eastward, ''going to Bombay'' and to what were to become Calcutta and Madras, seeking their fortunes in the future Indian empire. The would-be traders in silk, spices, ivory and jute formed themselves into the British East India Company and opened up other trades between India and China. In the late 18th century, around the time of the American Declaration of Independence, the British Government turned its attention more seriously to the East and by degrees took over the Company, transforming it from ''a ramshackle company trading in tea and opium'' into a vast enterprise of imperial administration that was to endure till 1947. Once the journey out had become shorter and less hazardous than it had been in the days of sail, the native women who had satisfied the early settlers were supplanted by Nice Girls from Home who, in turn, added their own demands and habits to the rich mixture of daily life in the Indian Presidency cities.
One way and another, people of both sexes have been going to Bombay for centuries, but this traffic has not been solely, or even mainly, British. The British founded Bombay on the site of a Portuguese trading station, but right from the start people of other European and Middle Eastern nations, as well as very many from other parts of India, were drawn to the place. The huge city is a melting pot of different cultures, races and political and social affiliations. At a roughly estimated 10 million people, it is second only in size to Calcutta and is more prosperous, in its chaotic way, than Calcutta has been for decades. It is one of India's major ports - indeed a major world port. It is also a major manufacturing center, though the traditional textile mills in the heart of Bombay are at last giving way to more diversified manufactory on the edges and in adjacent cities; the triangle of land formed by Bombay, Poona and Nasik is now one of the largest industrialized areas on mainland Asia.
Although downtown Bombay has some splendid 19th-century Indo-Gothic buildings that remind the traveler of London, the vista of docks and mill chimneys has traditionally been called ''Manchester and Liverpool rolled into one.'' For Americans, San Francisco is sometimes invoked, for Bombay is an oceanside city, and the fashionable postcard view of curving Marine Drive may kid the air-conditioned visitor that he or she has arrived in California - a notion that exposure to Bombay's humid, salt-swamp airs will rapidly dispel. New Orleans (one of Bombay's old-time competitors in the cotton trade) would be nearer the mark. Bombay never, ever gets cold. The natural vegetation - where it is still allowed to push up between the densely massed buildings - is subtropical: coconut palms, date palms and mangoes. It is, however, true that, like an Eastern Hollywood, Bombay is the center of Indian film making, that intensive industry for the production of luscious song-and-dance epics that are exported to Indian communities around the world. Bombay holds glamour as well as promise for all who have arrived there through the decades to seek their fortunes - or, at the very least, to scrape some sort of living in a land where so many are poor.
''Ah, Bombay! You can almost smell the money in the streets there!'' an Indian businessman far from home once said to me nostalgically. And although this remark may seem unfeeling to the Western visitor who sees the poverty all around at ground level - in the families of street hawkers, scavengers, laborers and beggars living on the sidewalks and on the polluted beaches - my Indian friend had a point. At the higher social levels (literally higher, in the grand high-rise apartments on Malabar Hill), there is a lot of money in Bombay, and money at the top means jobs, handouts and pickings further down the scale. The barefoot man on the street from whom you buy a soft drink, a handkerchief or a couple of bananas sleeps on his handcart or in some plastic-and-matting hovel, because here in the city he can make some sort of a living. There are slums, certainly, in Bombay, indescribable agglomerations of shacks, sometimes nestling under the very walls of prestige office blocks or in the shade of gaudy billboards advertising films, but economists call them ''slums of hope.''
Like Manhattan, with its cosmopolitan, money-oriented atmosphere, Bombay is on a long narrow island, with the dockside facing the mainland and the other side facing onto a great sea. But Bombay developed near the tip of its island - or rather, on the largest of the seven islands that were once there and which have now been turned by reclamation and landfill into one. Today the city proper occupies this entire consolidated island. The northern creek separating it from the mainland has been bridged, and greater Bombay has continued to expand in that direction, the only way it can - mile after unplanned mile of mingled industry and suburb. It is this that greets the modern visitor on his way in from the airport. But the city proper is contained between two shorelines. Inevitably but sadly, the old, beautiful bungalows in their individual gardens are being progressively torn down to create space for more intensive development; while on the newest piece of land claimed from the sea (Nariman Point) the winking glass skyscrapers rise, towering over the solid, intricately magnificent older buildings three blocks to the east that have lost their ocean view. At least these old buildings are now appreciated again, some even floodlighted at night.
Travelers in the past were luckier than present-day ones. They arrived, not via the backdoor urban sprawl, but at Apollo Bunder, the downtown harbor where the fantasy Mogul Gateway of India stands, opposite the splendid Taj Hotel. Ships have been docking at this jetty, or at earlier ones on the site, for centuries: troopships landing men during World War II, 19th-century ironclads of the P & O Steamship Lines, the slim clippers that used to race before the prevailing winds, pot-bellied 18th-century ''East Indiamen'' that had taken seven months or more on the voyage. The passengers on these saw a small, walled town on the shore: white houses with red-tiled roofs and, beyond them, coconut plantations stretching away to the beautiful hills.
In those early days, many ships tied up a few hundred yards north in Bombay's small, original natural harbor, Mody Bay, under the walls of the old castle. But the casual visitor today will seek in vain for this bay and the castle itself, for both have long been corralled off as part of the naval dockyard and are inaccessible except by special permission. If you should be so lucky as to visit the spot, the Indian naval officers who proudly maintain the crenelated battlements may tell you these walls are Portuguese remains; in fact, except for a couple of carved stones, they are British-built. But the place is the site of the original Portuguese stockade, which the British wrested from the reluctant local traders when Bombay was made part of the dowry of Charles II's Portuguese queen in 1661. Seldom can a marriage of convenience have had such far-reaching consequences.
On the eastern foreshore of Bombay island, from the castle northward for about seven miles, lie Bombay's dockyards, where much of the city's 19th-century wealth and prestige was founded; today they are still an important part of her economy, handling 35 percent of India's maritime trade. The export of cotton continues. Grown on the Deccan and processed in Bombay's mills, raw cotton used to be the city's staple product, but today much more of it goes out as ready-made garments. India has become a world source of cheap shirts and pants.
Bombay's shipyards still do refitting for ships of other countries whose own skilled labor is more expensive, but it has recently lost its premier position in this to Singapore, Malaysia and Korea. The city's tradition of shipbuilding is an ancient one. In the late 17th century, after the East India Company had acquired the insignificant, fever-ridden island of Bombay from the British Crown but did not know quite what to do with it, the company invited Parsee shipwrights to come down from Surat to get the Bombay shipyards going. The Parsees (the descendants of Persian immigrants to India) came, stayed and displayed talents for which they became famous. Ships built in Bombay of Indian teak fought at the Battle of Trafalgar. Parsees later diversified into other occupations and became not only the richest but also the most respected members of the local community. They are still to be found in positions of influence, but many of them have left for England, Canada or the United States. Their only near rivals in Bombay were the immensely successful Sassoons, all descended from the David Sassoon who came from Mesopotamia in the 1830's to set up business in India. Today there are no Sassoons left in Bombay, but two fine synagogues testify to their influence, as does the Sassoon Dock, on Calaba Causeway, whose fishy smell proclaims its presence from afar.
If you want an impression of the way the demands of a great port have transformed Bombay's contours, go uptown to Mazagaon, an old Portuguese-Christian district that still has a few ancient, gingerbread-carved bungalows. Follow Dockyard Road round to the flight of steps leading up a miniature mountain to Joseph Baptista Park. This garden stands like an oasis of the past on the remains of a rocky outcrop, the rest of which has been demolished to create the land below. Today, you look out east over an electricity-generating station, a railway track, a new container-truck road and a vista of wharves, but once the sea lapped the foot of this hill. Two hundred years ago a house standing here was occupied by a British merchant called Draper and his young wife, Eliza, one of the many who were sent out to find husbands. Eliza, however, became dissatisfied with Mr. Draper (who was not himself a model marriage partner) and staged a romantic elopement, descending by a rope into the arms of her lover waiting in a boat below. The lover proved unfaithful also, and Eliza, having returned to England and encountered various other gentlemen, came to a Bad End. Her ghost was long said to haunt the place, and in the little park at dusk you could believe she is still there, a wistful wraith far removed from the noise and ceaseless movement of what has become one of the most densely populated cities in the world.
The kind of boat that would have been familiar to Eliza - gaff-rigged wooden sailing vessels - are still built and ply up and down the coast as fishing vessels; they can be seen with their glistening cargoes at Ferry Wharf, off Malet Road. Here, you can enter freely, though you may be assailed with offers of produce including ''Bombay Duck,'' the pungent, sun-dried fish that is a local delicacy. Indeed there is a run of traditional harbors north of here into which the truly interested visitor may penetrate (inconspicuous clothing and an air of quiet busyness are recommended): the bunder where red tiles from Mangalore are landed, Hay Wharf, Lakri Bunder, with its stacks of wood, and Daru Khana (''Fire House''), where old iron ships are broken and the breakers' families keep their goats, their children and a renowned Muslim shrine amid a Dickensian vista of blackened chains.
All this is the underpinning of the commercial prosperity whose outward expression is the huge bazaar area of central Bombay. Here you can buy every kind of textile, from the cheapest man-made fiber and unbleached muslin to the finest silks and gorgeously embroidered and incrusted wedding saris. In the Jhaveri Bazaar acres of silver and diamonds greet you, while around the corner, in Tamba Kata and Gulal Wadi, are streets of copper and tinsmiths. Other lanes specialize in bicycles, electrical goods, shoes, cane furniture and motor parts new and used. Although conspicuous concern for preservation is in short supply in India, inanimate objects seem to acquiesce to the Hindu belief in a series of reincarnated lives: hardly anything is thrown away and, when it is, an army of scavengers work over the tips.
Whatever you want, someone will sell it to you. The innocent scents of fruits, vegetables and flowers brought in from the country perfume the streets each morning, briefly driving out the more enduring Indian smells of hot dust, roasting peanuts and urine, while later in the day girls are for sale in certain small shops known as ''cages.'' A liquor merchant offers Bagpipe (Indian) whiskey; a holy man offers sacred sugar; ragged children wheedle for alms at the windows of cars stuck in traffic jams. Outside one of the big public hospitals laborers queue to sell their blood, while across the road a sign proclaims that Dr. Shah Cures Incurable Diseases with Herbs. No one language predominates in Bombay, so English words are widely used and street signs clamor in four different major scripts.
In the Chor Bazaar, the ''Thieves Market'' around Mutton Street, delicate Mogul paintings testify to another kind of life, but there are many different trace elements also: the place is like an archeological site revealing the varied cultures that have contributed to Bombay. Hindu gods, so nonchalant compared with the yearning saints of Christianity, stand next to jade lions from China and the Staffordshire pottery figures left behind by Englishmen who went home. Indeed, relics of the Raj abound - as if, banished from elsewhere, in the Chor Bazaar they have found their resting place. Sporting prints repose here, and teapots and horned gramophones faintly churning out Irving Berlin melodies above the ringing of bicycle bells. Here are French and Latin Grammars, here a ''Hindustanee Primer.'' Somewhere about must be examples of the very type of Bible, smelling-salt bottle and tropical weight chemises that Thomas Hood's hopeful lady brought out with her on her quest for a husband.
 
 
 
ALL THE COMFORTS OF HOME
Bombay has a wide range of accommodations, from student hostels and guest houses to luxury hotels overlooking the Arabian Sea. Among those that can be booked in the United States are the following, all of which have air-conditioned rooms with private baths and such amenities as swimming pools, health clubs and 24-hour room service. The price of a hotel meal for two ranges from about $15, for lunch or dinner at a casual cafe or grill room, to $100, for dinner with wine in a formal room with a Continental menu (tax not included). Rates are computed at 17.3 rupees to $1.
The Taj Mahal Hotel, Apollo Bunder, Colaba, Bombay 400 039 (22-2023366; in the United States, 800-223-6800 or 212-838-3110; telex, 112442). The ornate old Taj was built in 1903, its adjoining 30-story tower in 1972. The hotel's 282 rooms and 48 suites range in price from $135, for a double, to $490, for a suite with a view of the sea. There are several restaurants, including a rooftop room serving French cuisine.
The Leela Kempinski Bombay, Sahar, Bombay 400 059 (telephone: 22-6363636; 800-426-3135; telex, 79241). Many of the hotel's 252 rooms and 28 suites look out on the surrounding gardens. Double rooms range from $115 to $135 and suites begin at $155 - guaranteed prices and dollar rate through October 1. There are several restaurants, serving Chinese and Indian cuisines.
The Oberoi, Bombay, Nariman Point, Bombay 400 021 (22-2025757; 800-223-6800 or 212-838-3110; telex, 4153). Situated on Marine Drive, the city's main promenade, the hotel has 350 rooms, including 22 suites. Prices range from $105, for a double room, to $695, for the Kohinoor suite, on the 21st floor. Restaurants include La Rotisserie, a French grill room, and Kandahar, which features food from Pakistan, Afghanistan and the northwest region of India.
Holiday Inn, Balraj Sahani Marg, Juhu, Bombay 400 049 (22-6204444; 800-465-4329; telex, 78404). Situated on Juhu Beach, this 210-room hotel is a 15-minute drive from the city's commercial district; its amenities include a courtesy coach to midtown and back as well as a resident astrologer. Rates range from $80, for a double room, to $345, for the presidential suite. Several restaurants serve Chinese, Continental and Indian food.
