PUB-DATE: May 20, 1990,

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2108 words

HEADLINE: REAGAN'S DISRAELI

BYLINE: By SIDNEY BLUMENTHAL; Sidney Blumenthal, a former Washington Post reporter, is the author of the forthcoming ''Pledging Allegiance: The Last Campaign of the Cold War.''

 BODY:

FIGHTING FOR PEACE
Seven Critical Years in the Pentagon.
By Caspar W. Weinberger.
464 pp. New York:
Warner Books. $24.95.
It has been years since a Reagan-era confessional has failed to grace the best-seller list. Within this flourishing literary genre, Caspar W. Weinberger, the former Secretary of Defense and now the publisher of Forbes magazine, has begun a new subgroup: the memoir of the loyalist as national savior. 
While other memoirists, such as Donald Regan (the executive as spin controller) and Peggy Noonan (the ingenue as ventriloquist), have strained to explain the peculiar workings of the Reagan White House (''a ghost ship,'' according to the former Secretary of State Alexander Haig), in ''Fighting for Peace'' Mr. Weinberger offers only a panegyric to Ronald Reagan. He writes of ''the first time I had ever seen the electric and electrifying nature of the President's smile'' and how ''I have never failed to see that magic at work.'' Mr. Reagan made Mr. Weinberger feel good, as he did so many people. It is this warm sensation that Mr. Weinberger submits as the rationale for his own actions. Mr. Reagan's ''personality was so open and friendly, and he was so funny, that he always succeeded in making people around him laugh and feel comfortable and happy at the same time he was inspiring great loyalty.''
When Mr. Weinberger left the Administration, Mr. Reagan, perhaps remembering George Arliss's film portrayal of a British prime minister, called his Secretary of Defense ''my Disraeli.'' Mr. Weinberger's own model, however, was another prime minister, Winston Churchill, whose battle for preparedness in the 1930's Mr. Weinberger says he followed as a Harvard student with a ''deep sense of almost personal involvement.'' Inspired by Churchill's example 40 years later, Mr. Weinberger describes his determination ''to prevent America from continuing down that path of drift and self-disparagement and weakness that I was sure could lead to another war.'' That America's position in the 1970's in relation to the Soviets was equivalent to Britain's in the 1930's in relation to the Nazis, he had no doubt.
Mr. Weinberger's self-image was framed by his notion of Churchill. In his Pentagon office, he hung a Churchill injunction: ''Never give in, never, never, never, never - in things great or small, large or petty.'' He collected Churchilliana and an extensive library of works by and about Churchill. The Munich analogy was wielded as a Weinbergerian theme to intimidate opponents of his views. His private memos to the President frequently brandished the Munich reference to argue for a more hard-line United States policy toward the Soviet Union. As if closing the ring, Mr. Weinberger was honored by the Queen for his gallant bureaucratic assistance in the Falklands war as an Honorary Knight Grand Cross in the Civil Division of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire.
Mr. Weinberger devotes more of his book to his adoration of Churchill than to his own personal background. He describes how his father (a ''skillful storyteller and an extraordinarily understanding and effective parent'') brought him to a rally for Herbert Hoover in 1932, but never tells us what his father did for a living or why the Weinbergers had converted to Episcopalianism from Judaism, though he mentions ''my mother's New England ancestry.'' Mr. Weinberger refers to his job as general counsel for the Bechtel Group before becoming Secretary of Defense, but does not remark on his conflicts with the company's president, George Shultz, who became Mr. Reagan's Secretary of State, or the course of their relationship in the Administration. Though Mr. Weinberger, as the director of finance in California under Governor Reagan, worked closely with Edwin Meese, then Mr. Reagan's chief of staff, his most detailed assessment of Mr. Reagan's Presidential counselor and Attorney General is that he ''is affable, very well informed, and effective in argument - as is Jim Baker'' - an absurd comparison of one of the most bumbling members of the Reagan Administration with one of the most polished. Mr. Weinberger does not sully his portrait of Mr. Meese by noting the Wedtech scandal.
When Mr. Weinberger was the director of the Office of Management and Budget and the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the Nixon Administration, he was generally regarded in Washington as a colorless numbers-cruncher, renowned as ''Cap the Knife,'' mainly for his budget cutting. But as the Secretary of Defense he yearned to be a swashbuckling titan so great as to be dubbed Sir Caspar (G.B.E.).
Under Mr. Reagan, he realized his Churchillian longings by presiding over a gigantic increase in the budget of the Defense Department, which lacked for nothing except strategy. Mr. Weinberger, however, does not detail a decisive meeting on Sept. 9, 1981, at which he made his case for arms increases before the President. It was, according to David Stockman, the budget director, ''a masterpiece of obfuscation.'' Mr. Weinberger's presentation, Mr. Stockman said, featured three cartoons: a midget without a rifle, described as the Carter military budget; a bespectacled wimp with a little gun, described as the Stockman budget; and a G.I. Joe look-alike with an imposing M-60, described as the Weinberger budget. ''Did he think the White House was on Sesame Street?'' wrote the disillusioned Mr. Stockman in his memoir, ''The Triumph of Politics.'' (For his part, Mr. Weinberger says here that Mr. Stockman's sniping at his bloated budget was ''quite inconsistent with any loyalty to the President.'') In this contest, Mr. Weinberger emerged the victor. Clearly, in California he had learned a great deal about how to get what he wanted out of Mr. Reagan that had no correlation in Churchill's experience.
Mr. Weinberger's Deputy Secretary, Paul Thayer, who helped oversee the buildup but was imprisoned for obstruction of justice in an insider-trading case, goes unheralded in the memoir. Nor does Mr. Weinberger refer to the F.B.I.'s Operation Ill Wind, which uncovered a vast Pentagon procurement scandal, perhaps invited by the indiscriminate buildup.
Churchill, however, is periodically reintroduced. His description of the British fleet on the eve of World War I is lovingly tendered as a justification for the Strategic Defense Initiative. The defense provided by the Royal Navy, Mr. Weinberger suggests, is the proper analogy for S.D.I. He pursues this logic by arguing, as he did as Pentagon chief, for setting aside the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, which prohibits the United States and the Soviet Union from constructing missile defense systems. He cites the review of the treaty made by the State Department's legal adviser, Abraham Sofaer, as the basis for lifting its restrictions. But he does not mention that Mr. Sofaer's case was built on contrived and tendentious evidence, and that when this was exposed, Mr. Sofaer sought to blame the shabby brief on ''young lawyers'' on his staff. Mr. Weinberger also does not record that the impetus and pressure for Mr. Sofaer's review came from the Defense Department itself, specifically from Mr. Weinberger's exceedingly clever neoconservative Assistant Secretary, Richard Perle, who had been a crusader against the ABM Treaty and arms controllers in general since the treaty was first ratified in 1972.
Mr. Perle's indispensable role in the Pentagon as its prime tactician in frustrating moves toward arms control goes uncredited. When Mr. Weinberger came to his post, he had an agenda for arms spending (as much as possible) but not for arms control. Mr. Perle filled this particular vacuum. It was his idea, the so-called ''double zero'' proposal, that helped rupture progress on arms control in the early years of the Reagan Administration, but unexpectedly led to the treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces after its surprise acceptance by the new Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Yet Mr. Weinberger does not discuss the role played by the most interesting man who worked for him.
Mr. Weinberger's loyalty to Mr. Reagan is depicted most dramatically, if somewhat evasively, in his chapter on the Iran-contra scandal. He writes that he opposed the idea of trading arms with the Iranians for hostages when he first heard of it on Aug. 6, 1985. He was subsequently cut out of the cable traffic on the project, but arranged to receive the cables beginning in September 1985. Two months later, the shipment of Israeli Hawk missiles to Iran as part of the deal required protracted negotiations between the Pentagon and the White House on how to replace the Israeli missiles from United States stocks. Mr. Weinberger mentions nothing about this incident. He was the last witness called before the select Congressional committee investigating the scandal, which was rushing to complete its work before its self-imposed deadline. In a deposition he gave in June 1987, Mr. Weinberger claimed that he did not know of the arms shipments in 1985, though his department was directly involved in them.
He fully exonerates Mr. Reagan of knowing about the diversion of funds to the contras, blaming the entire affair on the former national security adviser Robert C. McFarlane, whom he calls ''strange, indrawn, moody.'' But Mr. Weinberger does not address the defense Mr. McFarlane put forward in his Congressional testimony. The reason he did not tell the President that funding the contras was a futile exercise, Mr. McFarlane explained, was because ''Cap Weinberger would have said I was some kind of commie.''
Mr. Weinberger gives great credence to Mr. McFarlane's successor at the National Security Council, John M. Poindexter, who testified that Mr. Reagan was ignorant of the diversion, and who was recently found guilty of five felony counts for his role in the affair. Mr. Weinberger quotes Mr. Reagan as saying ''I don't remember - period,'' and adds, ''I believe the President.''
Earlier in his book, however, in his extended encomium to Mr. Reagan, Mr. Weinberger writes, ''He was easy to brief and his memory was phenomenal.'' Perhaps Mr. Reagan just goes blank in public, as he did in his testimony during the trial of Mr. Poindexter, who also had a reputation for a phenomenal memory. Mr. Poindexter's memory failed him whenever he was asked about details of his role in the Iran-contra scandal. Mr. Weinberger may be inadvertently telling us that Mr. Reagan does indeed have a memory, and that the rest is an act.
For most of the Reagan Presidency, Mr. Weinberger had been successful in thwarting arms control. He had undermined the 1982 ''walk in the woods'' agreement on intermediate nuclear forces tentatively negotiated by Paul Nitze, persuaded the President to stop United States compliance with the provisions of the 1979 arms limitation agreement and threatened the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. Mr. Weinberger insists that the military buildup - the ''restoration of the West's security'' - compelled the Soviets to sign the I.N.F. treaty. He does not mention factors within the Soviet Union, such as its economy, or give any credit to Mr. Gorbachev, whom he dismisses as a totalitarian more adept than Soviet leaders of the past at public relations. Mr. Weinberger does not note that at the Reykjavik summit Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev momentarily agreed to the elimination of all nuclear missiles, nor does he refer to the cordial relationship that developed between the two leaders. Mr. Weinberger had won the internal bureaucratic battle only to see his years of maneuvering frustrated by the appearance of a greater outside force. In the end, the Secretary of Defense was outplayed by the General Secretary.
Historians may turn to Mr. Weinberger's book for the banal tone of the period's official orthodoxy, a tone remarkably similar to that found in Andrei Gromyko's recently published memoir. They will find a less self-serving and more informative account of the Reagan Presidency in '' 'What Does Joan Say?' '' by Joan Quigley, Nancy Reagan's astrologer.
The 1990's have begun with chisels slowly being applied to Mr. Weinberger's monument, the defense buildup of the early 1980's. But more than his programmatic legacy is being undone. If Mr. Gorbachev does not resemble Hitler, then it is difficult to see anybody as Churchill. The analogies drawn from the pre-World War II era about appeasement and preparedness, which played such a large part in American politics during the cold war, have only now started to lose their mesmerizing compulsion. This may not be the end of history, but simply of mythology.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: May 20, 1990,

SECTION: Section 7; Page 47, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1081 words

HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
WOODMAN, SPARE THAT TREE!

BYLINE: By SUSAN BOLOTIN; Susan Bolotin is the former editorial director of 7 Days magazine.

 BODY:

HEY! GET OFF OUR TRAIN
Written and illustrated
by John Burningham.
Unpaged. New York:
Crown Publishers.
$14.95. (Ages 5 and up)
 
THE GREAT KAPOK TREE
A Tale of the Amazon
Rain Forest.
Written and illustrated
by Lynne Cherry.
Unpaged. San Diego:
Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.
$14.95. (Ages 4 to 8) 
I'm guessing, but I'm willing to bet that it's been a long time since two children's books, published in the same month, no less, carried nearly identical dedications to a murdered union leader. But Chico Mendes, who was killed defending the rights of freelance rubber tappers in the Amazon rain forest in December 1988, was no ordinary laborite. He was a martyr waiting to happen, a man assassinated for being in the wrong place at the wrong time, but remembered for being in the right place at the right time.
As last month's Earth Day festivities made clear, Americans have seen the environmental light: they are ready to embrace green (particularly when it comes with an outdoor concert or two), to take it into their hearts and homes, to testify that making a difference - whether by using cloth diapers or by separating cans from bottles - has changed their lives. Who could argue? Feeling powerful (and righteous to boot) is a rare and delicious commodity these days; besides, it takes an unseemly streak of perversity to be against the environment.
Also, now that we have been granted some distance from our nuclear nightmares, we can concede that, as slogans, ''Don't bungle the jungle'' and ''Up with green heads! Down with garbage heads!'' (my personal Earth Day favorite) have a jaunty energy that phrases like ''nuclear winter'' and ''psychic numbing'' can't compete with. And unlike the images of the antinuclear movement, say, those of environmentalism - whales graceful in their enormity, landscapes so beautiful they melt your heart, a life of harvesting and gathering and getting your hands dirty - are accessible, appealing, suitable for family viewing, for sitcoms. And, yes, even for children's books.
With his entry into the save-the-endangered-species market, John Burningham, the British author of the hilarious ''Mr. Gumpy's Outing,'' among others, has gone serious. ''Hey! Get Off Our Train'' (an allusion perhaps for those Rolling Stones fans turned parents? Hm, unlikely) tells the story of a little boy who, after being put unaffectionately to bed by a woman one can only hope is not his mother, dreams of escape (who wouldn't?) on his toy train.
Accompanied by his loyal ''pajama-case dog'' (this is an English book, after all), he scouts the world, dreaming of picnics, kites and snowballs, stopping only when various endangered animals plead for sanctuary. This latter-day Noah, not old enough to share his toys or his dreams gladly, orders each to get off his train, until he hears its tale of woe: ''Someone is coming to cut off my tusks,'' or ''They are cutting down the forests where I live.'' He then welcomes each aboard for the night.
Mr. Burningham's drawings are at their best, whimsically abstract and technically accomplished; one collage of the boy and his friends holding up umbrellas against the rain is particularly offbeat and winning. But some of the drawings, while beautiful, are so dark as to be inaccessible to a young child.
But, then, the whole book is inaccessible to young children - not because it's too hard, but quite specifically because no species' problem gets more than a dribble of explanation. A bird, presumably a heron (would naming it be too direct?), gets to say the most: ''I live in the marshes and they are draining the water out of them. I can't live on dry land, and soon there will be none of us left.'' Leaving aside the problem of how this poor bird is going to make it on a train, who are ''they''? One can only assume that ''they'' are adults (or witches or ogres), the kind of people who say good night to children without hugs or kisses.
The problem is that this vaguely xenophobic labeling of an enemy as ''the other'' is potentially dangerous and a silly thing to teach a child. The already converted adult who is up on his endangered-species rap could lead a discussion of, say, the realities of the fur, jewelry and cosmetics industries, but that seems a bit much for even a 7- or 8-year-old, and ridiculous for those younger.
 
* * *
 The jacket for Lynne Cherry's lushly illustrated book, ''The Great Kapok Tree,'' informs us that she traveled to the Amazon to research the illustrations for her save-the-rain-forest entry. It shows. She's drawn the animals and vegetation in great detail and with loads of color; yet the effect is flat and uninviting, somehow stilted.
In the story, a young man - handsomely characterless, an ethnic Ken doll - has been instructed by a ''larger man'' to chop down a Kapok tree. After giving a few whacks, the fellow gets tired, takes a nap, and is visited in his sleep by a string of animals, insects and a young Indian boy who all whisper in his ear how their lives (and his) will be ruined if he chops down the tree. Surprise: when he wakes up, he throws down his ax and walks off into the jungle, perhaps to check out Brazil's unemployment-insurance policy.
The book's peculiar language - ''If you destroy the beauty of the rain forest,'' a three-toed sloth asks, ''on what would you feast your eyes?'' - might at least make sense to an older child, but, then, 8-year-olds abhor preachiness more than little kids.
What is going on here? A cynic might wonder whether publishers have simply decided to tap into a hot market and a profitable us-against-them mentality. A nice person would probably think that these are well-intentioned books that fall short. I find myself somewhere in the middle: incredulous that people who care about the environment - a right-minded issue if ever there was one - have so little faith in their material. To teach children to care about their world is a simple matter: read them books and magazines about animals, show them gentleness, walk with them, swim with them, run with them, teach them by example that waste is bad and that conservation is good.
Children are awfully smart. They get the message, particularly when it's not doctrinaire. But they do get bored. As one 4-year-old I know remarked, midway through Mr. Rogers's own Earth Day extravaganza, ''When is he going to talk about something else besides recycling?'' Maybe she has a future as an environmentalist.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 45, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 677 words

HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
GROWING UP NORTH OF THE BORDER

BYLINE: By ROBERTO GONZALEZ ECHEVARRIA; Roberto Gonzalez Echevarria is the R. Selden Rose Professor of Spanish and Comparative Literature at Yale University.

 BODY:

BASEBALL IN APRIL
And Other Stories.
By Gary Soto.
111 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.
$14.95. (Ages 12 and up)
Gary Soto's sensitive and economical short stories center on Mexican-American boys and girls becoming teen-agers. They are set in homogeneous lower-middle-class Hispanic neighborhoods in California. At the same time the young people are turning into adolescents, their milieu is becoming progressively Americanized, largely through the pervasive influence of the media. The overall theme of the book is thus individual and social change being provoked by strong outside forces. The boys and girls are transforming themselves awkwardly into facsimiles of adults; the world of adults is turning into an anxious copy of the Anglo world. 
Mr. Soto, who was born and raised in Fresno, Calif., teaches Chicano studies and English at the University of California, Berkeley. Because he stays within the teen-agers' universe in ''Baseball in April,'' he manages to convey all the social change and stress without bathos or didacticism. In fact, his stories are moving, yet humorous and entertaining. The best are also quite subtle.
In ''Two Dreamers,'' Luis, Hector's grandfather, is inspired by some advertisements to plot a real estate deal that will make him rich, so he can return to the Mexican town of Jalapa in triumph. But to make phone calls, he needs Hector as interpreter - a common situation in immigrants' homes. Hector, both skeptical and embarrassed, demurs. At the same time he is fascinated by Luis's knowledge and his memories of Mexico (''his hometown with its clip-clop of horse and donkey hooves''). As Hector grows older, the situation is reversed. With his command of English, Hector is now a probe into the future, and into the alien yet alluring world that surrounds him. The story is about this swap of roles. It is very revealing that the contrast of generations skips the father, a figure generally absent in this collection. Luis and Hector better embody the generational differences. The grandfather is unwaveringly Mexican; Hector is on his way to becoming something still undefined, but certainly not Mexican anymore.
The title story is a poignant tale about compromise and resignation. Michael and Jesse practice hard to make the Little League. At the tryout, nervously watched by other boys' fathers (obviously Anglo and middle-class), they both fail. But they join an independent team, the Hobos, run by Manuel, a fatherly man who coaches with affection and compassion. The team does not do very well, and neither do Jesse and Michael, who are not very good. The Hobos disband slowly, as the boys lose interest in baseball. April is over. What was a consuming interest is suddenly left behind, like so many other things. Life can and will go on without baseball - a somewhat melancholy lesson.
The same air of resignation prevails in other stories, like ''Barbie,'' where Veronica finally gets the doll she wants, only to have it lose its head. This story has a lurking sexual subtext that gives it a more serious and compelling tone than the others, though everything is very understated. The best by far is ''The Karate Kid,'' which has a quixotic theme. Gilbert Sanchez, who is delicate and sensitive, is overwhelmed by the movie ''The Karate Kid.'' He assumes the persona of his movie hero and challenges his tormentor at school, Pete the Heat, who beats him up unmercifully. Gilbert begs his mother to pay for karate classes. She gives in and he attends a school run by a Mr. Lopez, who is something of an impostor. After a few months, Gilbert feels ready for his second sally. The Heat demolishes him again before all his friends. Gilbert gives up karate gleefully for fiction -that is, for ''super-hero comic books; they were more real than karate. And they didn't hurt.'' ''Baseball in April'' is more than literature for teen-agers. The stories give a bittersweet account of reconciliation to the givens of self and life while growing up that will be recognized as authentic by all.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 4, Column 4; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 763 words

HEADLINE: About Cars;
Escort Evolves Into Mainstay

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
The 1991 model Ford Escort hatchbacks and station wagons are the most significant new cars from Ford Motor Company in at least two decades. -Thomas J. Wagner
 
That is fairly strong stuff, coming as it does from the general manager of the Ford division, which is generally thought to be wealthy and bullish because of its immense success with the Taurus, not because of Escort.
But when Wagner amplifies, it is to say that the $2 billion that Ford has spent on its replacement for the compact Escort was money aimed at a redefinition of auto making.
There are the new technologies in design and manufacturing, for example, and those have been abetted by a new era, in which the Escort and its twin, the Mercury Tracer, have fulfilled their promise and become world cars in every sense. 
It is hard to believe that Escort has been around for 10 years, but the car that introduced the ''world-car'' theme has indeed populated roads everywhere for the last decade with bodies and powertrains made of iron, glass, plastics and textiles from hither, thither and, in no small way, yon.
Escort, Wagner says, has been the butter that allowed Ford to design and sell those fancier cars that brought in the company's bread.
When it was introduced Sept. 2, 1980, the 1981 Escort was an early bulwark in Detroit's defense against the imports. It didn't hurt that the car was a replacement for the Pinto, which had a reputation for bursting into flames when it was treated rudely in its rear quarters.
In the ensuing years, seven million Escorts have rolled off the line. And the most surprising thing to me is that four million have been running around Europe, most of them in the British Isles.
And all of this has happened with only a minor facelift in spring of 1988.
So it is certainly time for Ford's new mainstay, and the 1991 model offers better aerodynamics, more room, more power and even more mongrelization.
The car is based on the 323 from Ford's Japanese partner, Mazda, and the top of the line GT hatchback gets its spunk from a Mazda engine, while other Escorts carry a homegrown powerplant.
There are three model lines, the two-door Pony, the LX in two- and four-door hatchbacks and a four-door wagon, and the sporty GT. And the new car is far superior to its predecessor. In GT dress, it is quick. It is comfortable, quiet, economical and nicely put together.
Oddly, given its Mazda lineage, the new Escort does look an awful lot like an Acura Integra from Honda.
There is the wedge profile, and the low cowl to provide better visibility. The windows have been made semiflush to improve aerodynamics. The new shape gives the '91 Escort a coefficient of drag of .35, down from last year's .39.
If you opt for the GT, you get blackout trim, but all of the Escorts have an odd asymetrical grille, with eight slanted cutouts on the right and a simple blue-and-chrome Ford emblem on the left.
Inside, the instrument panel blends into the doors, and there are analog gauges, including a 120-m.p.h. speedometer and an 8,000-r.p.m. tachometer. Tinted glass is standard, and the new interior is roomier, both for passengers and for cargo.
Soft plastic makes fit-and-finish the same as that found in most Japanese cars, and there is ample stowage by way of a dashboard shelf, a reasonable glovebox and a console bin with dual cupholders. And, the award for worst ashtray can no longer be awarded to the Escort; it is now useful.
Up front, there are bucket seats, and the hatchback's rear has a bench whose twin seatbacks fold down for toting. The buckets are fairly flat and without much support, but the cloth upholstery does tend to keep you glued in place.
There are all new front and rear suspension components, and the handling is stable and reassuring.
Less expensive models get the 1.9-liter Ford four-cylinder engine that puts out 88 horsepower. The GT has a 127-horse engine with four valves per cylinder and double overhead cams.
Economy with either powerplant is good, and the domestic engine can be expected to get about 30 miles to the gallon. The hotter Japanese engine, hooked to an automatic transmission in the test car, averaged 24 m.p.g.
And economy, of course, is what Escort is about. Ford needs the high-volume gas miser to keep its corporate average fuel economy down so that it can sell more big cars.
But that ledgerdemain will mean little to the average Escort customer. What matters is a sticker that starts at $7,565 for the Pony and doesn't get much beyond $13,000 for the top-of-the-line GT. These days, that's real magic.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 8; Page 5, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1273 words

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Owners Meet to Confront New and Old Issues

BYLINE: By THOMAS GEORGE

 BODY:
The National Football League owners will gather in Dallas on Wednesday and Thursday to address a bushel of items. The agenda includes awarding Super Bowl XXVIII in 1994 to either Atlanta, New Orleans, Tampa, Fla., or Miami; the introduction of the league's new drug advisers, Dr. John Lombardo (steroids) and Dr. Lawrence S. Brown (street drugs), and discussing the merits of allowing corporations to own franchises.
High atop the list, however, is a long look at the collective bargaining status between management and the Players Association.
Presently there is little encouragement that the league will avoid entering a fourth consecutive season without an agreement. The sides are not negotiating and are so far apart that they cannot even agree on whether the Players Association indeed remains a full-fledged union. 
And both sides are entrenched in their positions, with management still seeking to bargain and the association intent on seeking a resolution only through the courts.
 
Panel for Exploring
In March in Orlando, Fla., at the owners' last meeting, Paul Tagliabue, the N.F.L. commissioner, named a panel of four club executives to assist Jack Donlan, the Management Council executive director, in exploring new alternatives to reach an agreement with the association.
The group has met at least five times with Donlan, and part of its report in Dallas represents a major shift in management's approach: everything would be on the table in the new negotiations, including free agency.
''We've discussed many free-agency ideas in our meetings along with ideas on benefits and other areas where money can be spent,'' Donlan said. ''But who do we discuss our ideas with? The N.F.L.P.A. is a certified labor organization that won't meet. Players have no one bargaining their share of TV money teams would guarantee as part of a new labor contract.''
Gene Upshaw, executive director of the Players Association, said his goals remain the same: ''For players to receive their fair share of revenues and their freedom to decide who they want to play for.''
 
Similiar Situation
But Upshaw said management's new stance was similar to proposals it made in 1987 but withdrew after initial talks. Last November the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in Minneapolis ruled that the free-agency clauses of the last labor agreement in 1982 cannot be challenged as antitrust violations just because negotiations were at an impasse.
After that, Upshaw's group began to decertify so that antitrust laws could apply and so that players could file individual lawsuits. The association changed its tax laws and bylaws and informed players and management that it was no longer a bargaining arm.
''For some reason they believe that if there's a table in front of us, we can get things done,'' Upshaw said. ''If we had just one stick of furniture left in here, they'd still call us a union. But we are never going back to the table to bargain with these people. No way. There is nothing they can say out of Dallas that will get me back at the table. We're not going to bargain and we can't according to our new bylaws. The courts will settle this.''
Management and Tagliabue have called the association a ''union in hiding.'' Both sides have invaded the courts seeking resolutions.
Management's chief court action is a declaratory judgment lawsuit in Minneapolis that asks the judge to examine the record and clarify if the union is still a union. Opening arguments are scheduled for Aug. 12.
 
Cases in Question
The union is hoping three court cases will aid its cause: a petition that the Supreme Court hear its case on whether management should be subject to antitrust laws; a case in Newark filed against the league by eight players including Freeman McNeil of the Jets and Dan Majkowski of the Green Bay Packers that charges collusion by management and argues that they should be free agents because their contracts expired earlier this year while there was no collective bargaining agreement or union in place, and a group of eight developmental players from around the league who charge that the uniform salaries paid to developmental players is unlawful.
Management believes both latter suits will be invalid if it wins the declaratory judgment lawsuit. It has also asked that the McNeil case be moved from Newark to Minneapolis. Arguments for that move are scheduled for June 11 in Newark.
Is the association still a union? That could be the pivotal issue. ''They are still engaging in union activities and admit they have not gone to the National Labor Relations Board to decertify,'' said John Jones, a management council spokesman. ''They continue to certify agents, circulate salary information and effect prices for the entire draft.
''Clearly, they are the union of record.''
 
In the Trade Business
Upshaw now describes his group as a trade association.
''All trade associations support members, give advice and publish facts; they are no different from the Amercian Bar Association, which I am a member of and is certainly not a union,'' said Jeff Kessler, an association attorney. ''The bottom line that the courts will have to decide is what steps are neccessary for a union to decertify.''
A collective bargaining agreement affects many facets of N.F.L. business, including free agency and the Plan B system, drug testing, some owners desire for a rookie wage scale and team salary cap, changes in pensions and benefits and expansion.
Tagliabue wants expansion by 1993. For the first time he and other owners have said that expansion will not be delayed simply because an agreement with the players is not in place.
''I intend to have an affirmative agenda for the league,'' Tagliabue said. ''I do not intend to have the union's policy of confrontation wreck the league's positive agenda and possibly ruin the future of the N.F.L. This is true of expansion and the internationalization of our sport, our drug program and many other issues.''
Norman Braman, the Philadelphia Eagles owner, said: ''Why can't we go on with expansion? What choice do we have? We certainly can't cancel the season or stop growing because of the labor situation.''
 
Diluting the Income
But Art Modell, the Cleveland Browns owner and a member of the league's realignment and expansion committee, said: ''My personal feeling is that expansion cannot go ahead without an agreement. Every two teams you add dilutes by 7.1 percent each team's TV income.
''Before I vote for expansion, I want to know the ground rules of our business. The biggest cost is players. Whatever the end result, through the courts or collective bargaining, everyone needs to know the cost of players and of doing business.''
Gerald Scully, a professor of economics at the University of Texas in Dallas and author of ''The Business of Major League Baseball'' (University of Chicago Press) said the players association's fight over free agency will produce less than it hopes. He questions the association's strategy, and so have others, including the former Miami Dolphins running back, Larry Csonka, who is attempting to form a new union.
The association's course, Scully said, ''helps the union but not the players, and that's not the same thing.''
''I assure you that if 70 percent of the players were actively behind the union, they would be in talks,'' he said. ''But for the last five years fewer than 30 percent of the players have paid union dues largely due to apathy. You're looking at the most ineffective union in professional sports and the most ridiculous labor situation in that arena, too.''

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Moving Day for the 1834 Gillette House

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
IN 1834, when Francis Gillette built his country house at what is now 511 Bloomfield Avenue in Hartford, people came by carriage from miles around to admire it. The multicolored stone building in Greek Revival style was a rarity in those days of predominantly wooden construction.
Next Tuesday another gathering is expected to rubber-neck the 4,000-square-foot house in its currently altered state - minus the elegant porches, trussed like a chicken for roasting with its windows and doors boarded up, amputated from its basement - as the house is hoisted onto 140 tons of steel beams.
They will watch the house, mounted on 16 sets of dollies, creep laboriously backward down a grassy slope and over a paved road to 545 Bloomfield Avenue, where it will be lowered onto new footings and refurbished after lying vacant for 17 years. 
When renovations are completed in the fall it will become a group home for six to eight clients of the Oak Hill School, a nonprofit institution for the blind founded in Hartford in 1893. The school currently rents a house from the Cigna Corporation that is scheduled for demolition. The lease will continue in the new location.
''Once we decided to preserve the Gillette house we had a strong bias toward using it for something that had a social purpose,'' said George Trumbull, president of the Cigna Corporation Investment Group.
Cigna, an insurance and financial services company, has owned 655 acres on Bloomfield Avenue and Cottage Grove Road for more than three decades. The Oak Hill and Gillette houses and an additional 29 homes were acquired with the purchase. Three are used for company functions, the rest are rented. Over the years Cigna has built three office buildings for 6,000 employees, a day-care center and two service buildings on the grounds. The Gillette house was nominated by Cigna for listing on the National Register of Historic Places and accepted in 1982 ''based on its significance as an affluent home of the period and the importance of its original owner,'' said Jack Shannahan, director of the Connecticut Historical Commission.
Francis Gillette died in 1879 at the age of 72. He had been a fervent abolitionist, a state senator, a founding member of the Republican Party in Connecticut, an education reformer, founder of The Hartford Evening Press and father of the noted actor William Gillette. During the Civil War, his house was an overnight stop on the underground railroad sheltering escaped slaves enroute from the south to Canada.
Mr. Trumbull said Cigna opted for preservation when the question arose in connection with plans for the company's $300 million mixed-use development called Silver Brook, to be built on land that includes the Gillette property, Oak Hill and three other houses that will be razed.
''Phase one on 75 acres has been approved by the city and we are ready to proceed when the market improves,'' said Mr. Trumbull, referring to a $100 million project with 350,000 square feet of rental office space, 100,000 square feet of retail and restaurant space, a health club and a small hotel.
Oak Hill operates 45 federally and state-supported group homes throughout Connecticut. Visually impaired people of all ages who meet income requirements live in the houses under staff supervision, learning to deal with daily life in an atmosphere resembling a family home. The children go to schools in the community.
''We are very excited at the prospect of moving into the Gillette house,'' said Dr. Lars Guldager, director of Oak Hill. Work on the site began in February. ''It took two weeks to bring in the steel beams, and several weeks more to lower the basement, get the house up on the beams, and grade the back slope down which the house will travel,'' said Brian Payne, who is directing the operation as president of Payne Building Movers of Hampton, N.H. ''The biggest problem was dealing with 22- to 28-inch stone walls where the mortar is a little tender.''
Steel braces were attached to the corners and three lines of cable were run around and through the building, plus diagonal cables across each face. The footprint of the dollies is a few feet larger than the 38- by 67-foot building, and 45 tons of ballast will be added to one side where the house jogs inward.
Pulled by two truck-mounted winches and held back by another winch, the house will travel 2,800 feet. The journey will take five days. The total cost, including moving, landscaping and other site work at both sites, and restoration, will be $1.2 million; no separate cost for the moving alone was made available. Cigna will foot the entire bill.
''The first day we will move 500 feet down the slope and turn right toward the road'' said Mr. Payne. To better negotiate the grassy hill, 100,000 feet of planking will be laid as flooring.
On the second day the house will move along 2,000 feet of level paved road, then stop for two days while the planking is moved to cover a 400-foot grass approach to the excavated site.
The house will be set onto its new footings on the fifth day, after which a contractor will pour the foundation and the steel beams will be extracted.
According to the International Association of Structural Movers, a trade organization based in Elbridge, N.Y., house moving is on the wane, heavily dependent as it is upon upswings of the economic pendulum.
''When the economy is poor and nothing is going on, people don't move houses,'' said Carl Tuxill, executive administrator of the organization.
''When the economy is good and homes are threatened by new highways under construction or industrial plants and big housing developments, we get busy.''
Joseph and James Kazak, brothers who own AA House Movers, based in Euclid, Ohio, estimate that it would cost $20,000 to move a simple, lightweight 3,000-square-foot frame house two miles. This does not include charges by a local utility company to move power lines block after block while the building passes through. That can cost $10,000 or more.
Before hiring Mr. Payne, Cigna contacted 12 companies and considered three bids, learning that most movers operate without insurance and do not have the equipment to handle a 750-ton load such as this.
One of Mr. Payne's employees will manipulate the hydraulically controlled dollies under the house, steering each set over the bumps and adjusting levels to keep the building upright on turns. ''We haven't lost a house yet,'' said Mr. Payne, who has engineered more than 500 such events since 1974.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brian Payne, a house mover, with Gillette House ready for its trip in Hartford. (Steven Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Rising Costs of Closing on a Home

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
WHEN Beth and Timothy Dennis went house hunting on Long Island three years ago, about a year after their marriage, they thought their biggest challenge would be scraping together the down payment and making sure their salaries covered monthly mortgage and tax bills.
That turned out to be the easy part. The shock for the Long Island couple was the amount of cash they discovered they would need for closing costs.
''We were looking for something in the range of $120,000 to $125,000,'' said Mrs. Dennis, who with her husband had accumulated about $25,000 in savings and gift money. ''We had enough for the down payment, but not the closing costs. It was either one or the other, but not both.'' 
In the New York metropolitan area, it is not unusual for closing costs to range from 5 to 7 percent of the purchase price. That means that the cash needed to close a deal on a $200,000 residence - a modest price for a home in this region - can range from $10,000 to $14,000. Added to that is a mortgage down payment of 10 to 20 percent required by most lenders. So just to get in the door, the buyer of a $200,000 residence is looking at a cash outlay of $30,000 to $42,000.
The Dennises deferred their dream of home ownership for nearly two years and moved instead to an apartment with a rent low enough to let them build up their savings. Earlier this month, they were finally able to buy a house, a $110,000 handyman's special in Brentwood, L.I., that they got in a bank foreclosure. They put $23,000 down and their closing costs came to approximately $7,000. Even though Mr. Dennis, who is an electrician, will do much of the work on the house, the couple expect to spend at least $10,000 on renovations before moving in.
''It was hard putting it all together,'' said Mrs. Dennis, who just completed a master's degree in business administration at New York Institute of Technology in Westbury, L.I. ''And we had help from our parents. I can see why most young couples just can't do it, even if they have two incomes.''
More than any other expense associated with buying a home, the cumulative impact of closing costs - loan origination fees, title insurance, charges for credit checks and land surveys, tax escrow money and legal fees - can be the biggest budget-busters for the average home buyer.
''Closing costs come as a shock to many, many people,'' said Stanley Greenstein, vice president of the Mortgage Clearing House, a Long Island mortgage brokerage company. ''This is particularly true for first-time buyers. They know that they need more cash than what they set aside for the down payment, but how much more is usually a surprise.''
For many people buying for the first time, Mr. Greenstein said, the biggest concern is finding a bank that will approve their loan and getting the best deal on a mortgage interest rate.
''The other costs are the last thing on their minds,'' he added, ''so being presented with the complete list for the first time can be almost frightening.''
To help buffer the shock, the Federal Government since 1974 has required lenders to give loan applicants estimates of closing costs. The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act provides that within three days of the application the lender must provide in writing a ''good faith'' estimate of the settlement fees.
But the bank's portion of the closing costs can be viewed as the short list of what buyers are likely to have to pay. In addition, there will be state and local taxes, legal fees and other charges.
If it can be said that there are any bargains in closing costs, they go to buyers of cooperative apartments, who buy not real property, but shares in a corporation, thereby escaping such upfront expenses as a title search and insurance and the prepayment of property taxes.
House buyers, on the other hand, pay the highestJU tariff when such expenses as those for property surveys and termite inspections are added to the prepaid property taxes and standard closing costs.
The sellers in any transaction also have closing costs, but they are usually limited to transfer taxes and legal fees and they are rarely as high as those paid by buyers. The biggest expense for sellers is the commission they pay if they sell through a broker. The commission varies, but usually is about six percent of the selling price.
While most closing costs cannot be avoided, there are ways for buyers to ease the financial burden.
''Planning ahead is the key,'' said Joy Borgos, a housing consultant with Westchester Housing Opportunities, a moderate-income home-buying advisory agency in White Plains. ''It is important that buyers know as early as possible exactly what expenses they face so they can start working on making sure that the money will be there when it is time to start writing the checks and so they can shop around for not only the best loan and fee package, but also for ways of reducing the closing costs.'' Mortgage-related closing costs include the loan-origination fee; charges for a title search to insure not only that the owner has the right to sell the house but also that there are no judgments against him or liens against the property; the costs of title insurance, which is the bank's backup for the search; the fee for an appraisal to make sure the loan does not exceed the property's value and, in the case of houses, a land-survey fee.
In addition to the above charges, the bank's costs of processing the loan and a credit check are passed on to the borrower.
ON top of the bank's fees are various property taxes and recording charges imposed by the city and state. Moreover, banks often require that borrowers set up escrow accounts for the prepayment of local property and school taxes.
To these payments the buyer can add legal fees, for his own lawyer and the bank's lawyer, and adjustments owed to the seller for things like heating oil.
Nearly all of these charges are paid at the very end of the transaction when buyer, seller, bankers and lawyers assemble to sign all the papers. The ritual, called a closing, has been known to leave more than a few buyers with check-writer's cramp.
Adding to the financial pressure for buyers these days is the fact that closing costs have risen over the past decade. And the higher price of homes is not the only culprit.
According to the Mortgage Bankers Association, a trade group based in Washington that represents some 3,300 independently owned mortgage companies and bank mortgage companies, in the mid-70's the settlement fees on the average residential transaction were 3 to 4 percent of the purchase price.
The rise in closing costs can be traced to higher property transfer and mortgage taxes in some places and the volatility of interest rates on home mortgage.
''These days nearly all residential mortgages are sold by the lender to another investor like a pension fund or insurance company,'' said Richard Peach, deputy chief economist of the Mortgage Bankers Association. ''It used to take three or four years for long-term interest rates to rise just 50 basis points. Now, rates can do that in a day.
''So in order for the original lender to protect his investment from a loss on a drop in the rates before the resale in the secondary mortgage market, points are added to the loan. They are sort of an insurance policy for the lender, and the customer pays for the lender's protection.''
Each point on a mortgage is 1 percent of the loan. The going rate charged by most lenders in the metropolitan area is 2 or 3 points, depending on the type of loan.
Adding to the confusion and uncertainty for some buyers is that closing costs can vary significantly from place to place.
In New York State there is a mortgage recording tax, usually 1 percent of the loan. Of that 1 percent, three-fourths is paid by the buyer and one-fourth by the bank.
IN some cases transfer taxes - usually paid by the seller - are the responsibility of the buyer. In Mount Vernon, for example, a real estate transfer tax of 1 percent of the purchase price, less the first $100,000, is paid by the buyer.
''When it comes to taxes and closings,'' said Vincent D'Andrea, an attorney who practices in Mount Vernon, ''this area is a crazy quilt. Taxes are among the items that can mean a difference of hundreds or thousands of dollars in closing costs for homes that are basically the same price. It all depends on where they are located.''
According to Gary Garrity, a vice president of the American Land Title Association, some regional variations on closing costs have as much to do with local real estate customs as they do with laws or tax policies.
''Take the title search and title insurance for example,'' said Mr. Garrity. ''On the East Coast it is nearly universal for the buyer to pay this charge. But as you move farther west it becomes common for the seller to pay. These differences are not mandated by law but are just the way things are done.''
Another closing cost dictated, in part, by custom is the legal fee. While it is standard for the buyer to pay for the bank's lawyer, there is no legal requirement that he hire an attorney to handle his part of the transaction.
In some parts of the country, like California, while a buyer might have an attorney look over his sales contract and other documents, is not unusual for closings to take place without lawyers in attendance.
Yet in the New York metropolitan area, few buyers or sellers feel comfortable about completing property sales without their lawyers at their side.
In part, this may be the result of rules in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut that prohibit brokers and sales agents from serving as legal advisers. Brokers in this area ususally warn clients that they cannot provide legal advice and this may prompt buyers to seek it from lawyers.
While most closing costs are set, there are ways to whittle them down a bit. One of the first places buyers can look to cut the amount of upfront cash they will need is in choosing a mortgage. Most lenders offer mortgages that allow buyers to trade off points for higher interest rates. But careful consideration of the value of this arrangement is important because the rule of thumb is, the lower the points, the higher the interest rate.
A bank might offer a no-points loan that carries an interest rate of 10.75 percent while a mortgage with the same terms would carry 3 points at a 10.15 rate.
Another option that helps in an initial cash crunch is to add the points and origination fee to the loan amount. The interest rate would not be affected but this plan would add to the overall cost of the loan. Nevertheless, it is an option that some cash-short buyers take to make a purchase possible.
Mrs. Borgos of Westchester Housing Opportunities advises buyers to shop around for some of the services like surveys, appraisals and legal fees, that are not fixed.
She suggested that these days buyers might also be able to use the market's softness as leverage to get sellers to share some closing costs that buyers traditionally take on in order to make a deal.
''This strategy can work for costs that fall into the category of adjustments, like for heating oil left in the tank,'' she said, ''But there is no reason why the buyer should not try for a share arrangement on other expenses like the survey or title search, termite inspection or engineer's report.''
David L. Smith, a partner in the law firm of Rand Rosenzweig Smith & Radley of Manhattan, who practices in both New York and New Jersey, says there are even ways to save on legal fees.
''Hiring a lawyer is like spreading a safety net,'' said Mr. Smith. ''With so much at stake most people just don't want to take the chance that something will go wrong to complicate or ruin a deal. But sometimes lawyers and the people in their office end up doing work that could be done by the client.''
Mr. Smith suggest, for example, that home buyers take on some of the leg work or phone calling required during the transaction.
''Every time I have to make a call to check on a survey or track down a co-op's financial statement or pay a messenger to pick up or deliver a document,'' said Mr. Smith, ''the fee clock is on. At $150 or $200 an hour, the money saved when the buyer does this sort of stuff can add up.''

PUB-DATE: May 20, 1990,

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 34, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 898 words

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT OPINION;
The Auto Age May Be Exhausted, but What Comes Next?

BYLINE: By Stephen B. Goddard is a lawyer in Hartford.

 BODY:
A CRITIC wrote of Philip II of Spain, who raised political ambition to high art, ''no experience of the failure of his policy could shake his belief in its essential excellence.''
Resonating through time, Philip's moral touched the Hartford area last month, as 125 of the region's powerful gathered to negotiate the terms of what they foresaw as a bitter divorce between its million residents and their gone-to-seed lover, the automobile.
Philip could have conquered all the planets with the money Detroit has spent in this century on marketing. But motorists (that's you and me, folks), who witness the chickens coming home to roost each rush hour, continue their asphalt addiction like one more bad habit. 
When nearly a half-million people commute to work each day, and 80 percent drive alone, it's easy to see why Hartford has a parking and traffic-congestion crisis. So the Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce and the Greater Hartford Transit District have assembled some of the best local minds around to start pulling us out of the quicksand. Their answer: more car pooling, downtown short-hop buses, making downtown employee parking most costly and the use of an abandoned rail line for mass transit.
Now that the cognoscenti are on board, relief cannot be far behind, right? Well, don't bet the farm before considering historical precedent.
In 1957, the most prestigious national transportation conference ever held took place on the Cigna (then Connecticut General) grounds in Bloomfield. Its focus? Traffic congestion. And the Interstate Highway System wasn't even built yet! But the conferees saw it coming. ''We've got a steamroller'' - the Interstates - ''coming our way,'' an economist at the conference said. ''We've got to do something about it or get run over.''
The social critic Lewis Mumford took the podium to excoriate as a phony jingoistic excuse the national defense rationale President Eisenhower had used in championing a public works project that dwarfed the Marshall Plan and the building of the Panama Canal. (The full name of the Interstates is the National System of Interstate and Defense Highways.) Mumford saw the Interstates as ''striking a mortal blow at our railroad system by giving our trucking industry more free roads than they ever had before,'' and he saw as wrongheaded the two-birds-with-one-stone motive of routing the expressways through bulldozed slums.
Few car-related ills that came to pass were not foreseen at that conference, including these:
* The building of the highways through cities rather than around them would intensify congestion.
* The failure of cities and suburbs to plan for the effects of the highways could wreck their financial, social and residential foundations.
* Land-use planning should assert the value that ''highest and best use'' can mean something more than best potential economic return or an ugly sprawl will result.
* Improved arterial highways will be meaningless, unless cities provide adequate parking facilities for increased traffic.
And on that September day when Gov. Orval Faubus of Arkansas was resisting the National Guard's attempt to integrate Little Rock schools, a speaker prophetically addressed these words to the leaders of a metropolitan area that was to become one of the nation's most segregated regions: ''Ten years from now do we want to see cities which are inhabited by low-income white and colored people, while around the city lives a ring of middle and higher-income whites?''
Well, the steamroller did come. We ignored the warning, and while we're not dead yet, we're clearly in intensive care. To their credit, the leaders of the recent transit conference have been working on plans for some time, in the methodical Hartford way, which bring as many diverse factions as possible from private and public sectors under the tent.
Perhaps the most promising plan lies in a commuter link between Union Station in Hartford and Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks, along the Griffin Rail Line, heading northwest out of Hartford through Bloomfield. While buses and trolley-style railways were both discussed, most who expressed an opinion weighed in for the perceived long-term efficiencies of light-rail use, patterned after successful ventures in San Diego, Sacramento, Pittsburgh and Baltimore.
When Hitler started at ground zero to build a road, within five years his Autobahnen made up the most sophisticated highway system in the world. But in a pluralistic democracy like ours, clamoring competing needs mandate ladling a dollop on every plate rather than hard-nosed priority setting. To build a Griffin Line mass-transit system appears likely to cost $5 million to $7 million a mile, a hard kernel to crunch in these perilous economic times.
And as long as ''no new taxes'' continues to be the national mantra, don't look for a way out of our deepening transportation dilemma. President Bush served notice in March that states and cities can expect less Federal transportation aid. The news came as New England entered its worst economic slump in a decade.
A despairing President John Adams, who no doubt would be grateful that he was spared the automobile, observed nearly two centuries ago: ''While all other sciences have advanced, government is at a stand; little better practiced now than three or four thousand years ago.''

HEADLINE: 11 Vie for Florio and Courter House Seats

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

 BODY:
NOTHING hates a vacuum as much as politics, and the Congressional vacancies created by last year's gubernatorial election are attracting much of the attention in this year's elections.
Jim Florio had served his First Congressional District, in Burlington, Camden and Gloucester Counties, for nearly 16 years when he resigned shortly before taking his oath as Governor in January.
His Republican gubernatorial opponent last November, Representative Jim Courter of Hackettstown, is a 12-year veteran and ranking minority member of the House Armed Services Committee. After initially indicating he would seek re-election to his 12th District seat, Mr. Courter announced that he wanted to spend more time with his family and would leave Congress at the end of this term in January.
Because of the political complexions of the two districts, the winners of the Democratic primary in the First District and the Republican primary in the 12th District on June 5 will be the favorites going into the fall campaign. Each race has attracted four candidates. 
Those running in the First District, in the southern part of the state, are Robert E. Andrews, 32 years old, of Bellmawr, the director of the Camden County Board of Chosen Freeholders: Linda Bowker, 41, of Barrington, the president of the New Jersey chapter of the National Organization for Women; John A. Dramesi, 51, of Blackwood, a Vietnam veteran who served seven years as deputy director of the Office of Veterans' Affairs, until last September, and Joel S. Farley, 35, a Collingswood lawyer.
Mr. Andrews began his political activity by stuffing envelopes in some of Mr. Florio's previous elections. Although Mr. Florio will not endorse anyone in the Democratic primary, his aides say, he might show up for some photo opportunities in his role as Governor and Mr. Andrews's as Freeholder.
 
'The Forgotten Middle Class'
Mr. Andrews said he was running on issues important to ''the forgotten middle class,'' pocketbook issues, crime and the death penalty. He also supports a woman's right to choose to have an abortion. He supports a ban on assault rifles and said the public was being frustrated by New Jersey Supreme Court decisions that have thrown out the first 16 death penalties voted by juries.
He said the district was in need of strategies to create jobs after the recent decision by the Campbell Soup Company to shut down its Camden plant and General Electric's decision to reduce its operations. ''This might sound strange for a Democrat, but I would support President Bush's call for a cut in the capital gains tax on the condition that there be legal assurances that the proceeds of the tax break would be reinvested in the domestic economy,'' he said.
In her bid to win the nomination, Ms. Bowker said she would emphasize her support for abortion rights, for an environmental position that calls for greater recycling efforts and for a national health care program.
She said the nation had a long way to go with its recycling efforts to match the programs in Japan and Europe. ''The Federal Government must develop new markets for recycled material and encourage producers not to package their products with excess material that adds to our disposal problems,'' she said. Ms. Bowker said she was also presenting herself as a change from ''politics as usual.''
Mr. Dramesi ran against Mr. Florio as the Republican Congressional candidate in 1982, but last year came to Mr. Florio's aid when the Democrat's patriotism was attacked during the campaign by Mr. Courter. Mr. Dramesi, who is running this time as a Democrat, said support for veterans' programs was waning both in the state and in Washington. For this reason, he said, groups of veterans circulated nominating petitions for his candidacy without asking him.
 
Trying 'to Be Their Voice'
''I feel a responsibility to them to follow through and try to be their voice in Congress,'' he said.
Mr. Farley is banking on his experience as a staff aide on Capitol Hill, and his experience in winning Democratic committee posts when he was still a teen-ager, to help him win the nomination. He is a former intern in the office of Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, who died in 1988, and was a staff investigator for the House Subcommittee on Employment and Housing.
The Republican nominee will be Daniel J. Mangini, 56, of Turnersville, a Gloucester County Freeholder, who is running unopposed.
The Republican candidates in the 12th District are Dick Zimmer, 45, of Flemington, a member of the State Senate; Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, 44, of Morristown, a State Assemblyman; Phil McConkey, 33, of Flemington, a professional football player, and Joseph F. Shanahan, 76, of Lambertville, the president of the Hunterdon County Citizens and Taxpayers Association.
Mr. Frelinghuysen, whose family has produced four United States Senators and a Representative, is hoping that the family name and his record of service as a Morris County Freeholder and a three-term Assemblyman will help him win the nomination. His chief problem is geographical since his Morris County base makes up only a small part of the Congressional district, which also includes all of Hunterdon County and parts of Somerset, Sussex, Mercer, Middlesex and Warren.
But Mr. Frelinghuysen said the support he was receiving from the Somerset County Republican Party chairman, Jack Penn, former State Senator Raymond H. Bateman and former Representative Millicent Fenwick has broadened his base of support.
''I also have a fairly strong presence in Princeton, which was represented for several years in Congress by my father and where several family members live,'' he said. The economy and the environment, ''especially the disappearance of open space,'' are the chief issues in the campaign, he said.
 
Advisers on Issues Enlisted
Mr. Zimmer, whose Senate district includes parts of four counties in the Congressional district, has been endorsed by the party organizations of Hunterdon, Mercer and Middlesex Counties. He also has enlisted some prominent Republicans, including former State Attorney General Cary Edwards and Senator John Bennett of Monmouth County, as advisers on drugs, the environment and other issues.
Both state legislators are members of the State Joint Appropriations Committee and oppose Governor Florio's proposed tax increases to balance the budget. Mr. Zimmer said he also voted against the last three state budgets ''because I knew we couldn't continue to increase spending at a breakneck pace without hitting a brick wall.'' He was the sponsor of the Farmland Preservation Act, which he said has saved 40,000 acres of farmland from development.
Mr. Courter has not endorsed anyone in the race, although he has agreed to become an adviser for Mr. Zimmer and Mr. McConkey on foreign affairs and defense. Both men supported his gubernatorial campaign last year. Mr. Frelinghuysen backed former Assembly Speaker Chuck Hardwick of Westfield in the gubernatorial primary, and in 1982 opposed Mr. Courter in the Congressional primary.
Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who is now the president of Drew University, has appeared in campaign videos made for both Mr. Zimmer and Mr. Frelinghuysen. The candidates will mail copies to potential Republican voters in the district.
Mr. McConkey, the former punt returner and receiver for the New York Giants, now plays for the San Diego Chargers. He does not have the name recognition problem of most first-time candidates and has been waging an active campaign tied to top foreign news developments. He recently criticized the White House for what he called ''abandoning the Lithuanian people in their hour of need,'' and for granting the Soviet Union favored nation'' trade status at a time when it was using embargoes against Lithuania to force the Baltic state to abandon its independence movement.
Mr. Shanahan, a former Lambertville Councilman, describes himself as a ''semiretired'' lawyer and an ''independent-minded Republican.'' He argues that he will make the best fiscal watchdog in the race ''because both political parties are committed to spending.''
On the abortion issue, Mr. Frelinghuysen and Mr. Zimmer have long supported a woman's right to choose abortion, while Mr. McConkey and Mr. Shanahan are opposed to abortion.
There is also a contest for the Democratic nomination, between Marguerite Chandler, 46, of Somerville, a businesswoman, and James F. Cleary of Bound Brook, a supporter of Lyndon H. LaRouche, the political extremist who was sentenced last year to 15 years in prison on charges that included mail fraud.

HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
Installing a Ceiling Fan

BYLINE: By JOHN WARDE

 BODY:
LARGE-BLADED ceiling fans are more economical to operate than air-conditioners and can add to comfort and energy savings the year round.
In summer, a fan produces a feeling of coolness by creating wind chill - air currents passing over the skin - even though air temperature is not actually reduced. An air-conditioned room in which a fan is operating also will feel cooler, and as a result the air-conditioner's thermostat can be set higher. This saves energy because the air-conditioner is used less. In winter, operating a ceiling fan mixes warm and cool layers of air. By running the fan in reverse (most ceiling fans are reversible), warm air that rises naturally toward the ceiling, where it is wasted, is instead forced toward the floor, where it can be felt. This permits setting the thermostat controlling the home's heating system lower, again saving energy because the system is used less. 
When choosing a fan, consider the characteristics of the room where it is to be installed. Fans provide the greatest benefit when in rooms occupied most frequently. For approximately square rooms that measure no more than 12 feet on a side, select a fan with a blade-span of about 40 inches. For rooms measuring up to 12 by 18 feet, select a fan with a blade-span of about 50 inches.
Fans spanning as much as 60 inches are also available. These work well in large entry halls or in stairwells. However, for large rooms longer than 18 feet, two or more medium-size fans will produce better results.
Hang a single fan in the center of a room. Hang multiple fans at equal distances from each other at intervals recommended by the manufacturer. To prevent a fan from wobbling because of uneven air flow, the tips of the blades must be at least 24 inches from walls, sloping ceilings and tall furniture. With tall furniture, be sure to allow room for opening cabinet doors.
To improve air circulation where it is needed most, fans should be hung so that the blades are no higher than nine feet above the floor. For safety, blades must not be lower than seven feet. The minimum space between the blades and the ceiling should be about 12 inches, else the fan will lose considerable effectiveness.
Most fans meet these requirements when attached to a standard eight-foot-high ceiling. For higher ceilings, extension rods are available from fan manufacturers. For lower ceilings or where lights attached beneath a fan will interfere with headroom, low-ceiling adapter kits can be obtained. Adapter kits are also available for hanging fans from slanted ceilings.
The easiest method for installing a ceiling fan is to attach it in place of an existing ceiling light. Before starting, check with a local building inspector to ascertain whether amateurs are allowed to do the work and what procedures must be followed.
Begin by shutting off all power to the ceiling circuit by removing the fuse or tripping the circuit-breaker at the service panel. Then remove the ceiling light and examine the outlet box above it.
Fans weighing up to 35 pounds can usually be mounted to a standard 4-inch-wide octagonal metal outlet box, provided the box is attached to a metal bar or sturdy wooden support fastened between two of the ceiling joists. Instructions included with the fan should specifiy mounting requirements. Plastic outlet boxes cannot be used.
If the box is not attached this way, or is plastic, or if no ceiling light is present, obtain a hanger kit (available from most fan manufacturers). The kit usually consists of telescoping metal bars that can be extended between a pair of joists after being inserted through an opening cut in the ceiling with a keyhole saw or saber saw.
Where no wiring is present, surface wiring, available at home centers, can be used to bring current to the fan from another location and for installing a wall switch.
After the outlet box is securely anchored, attach the fan's mounting bracket to it with screws. A common style of bracket is slotted, and designed to accept the ball-shaped end of the fan's hanger pole.
Next, slip the decorative canopy that covers the mounting bracket over the end of the pole. Then lift the hanger pole, to which the fan motor is attached at the other end, into place on the bracket.
Connect the wires from the motor to those of the ceiling circuit, following the fan manufacturer's instructions. The procedure is usually simple. It involves joining wires of similar colors with threaded plastic caps called wire nuts, which are generally included.
Inspect your work when finished, then tuck the wiring inside the mounting bracket. Slide the canopy over the bracket and attach it with the screws provided.
Lay the fan blades flat on a table and check for warping. If any are warped, obtain replacements from the manufacturer. Blades are usually attached with bolts and nuts to brackets; these, in turn, are attached to the motor. When attaching a blade to a bracket, tighten the bolts in stages to prevent warping.
Bolt the brackets to the fan motor after all the blades are attached. Make sure the brackets are right side up so that the angle of the blades is correct. If the fan is equipped with a light fixture, install the bulbs.
Test the fan when it is completely assembled. If it wobbles, stop the motor and measure the distance between the tip of each blade and the ceiling by holding a ruler or yardstick vertically against the ceiling and revolving the fan blades by hand against it.
If different measurements are obtained, gently bend the blade brackets where they join the motor until all are equal. During this test, be sure the fan hangs level.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
After a Pause, A Prospect Of New Growth

BYLINE: By Stephen J. Kukan; Stephen J. Kukan is general manager of area development for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company in Newark.

 BODY:
THE New Jersey economy softened considerably in 1989. But the existing inventory of office space was reduced, since new construction was minimal. There are many economic-development professionals who have said that this moderation in the level of development activity has been for the better. 
Planning toward a goal of balanced and practical development is given the opportunity to take place as we pause to catch our collective breath after a period of unprecedented growth. Infrastructure improvements are being made, through joint public and private-sector efforts.
The true development professional is awaiting the absorption of available building inventory before constructing new speculative buildings. This absorption is becoming apparent. Vacancy rates as high as 30 percent or above in certain areas are being replaced with a much improved average of 20 percent or below. Some areas, like the Metro Park section of Woodbridge, have virtually no available space.
It is important that we remember that the commercial and industrial construction business is one of peaks and valleys; high demand and low inventory create the valleys of available space, and low demand and high inventory levels create the peaks. As the present inventory stays relatively constant, the demand for space will reduce the inventory and serve to encourage developers to begin new construction.
As in recent years, commercial users of space will represent the bulk of this new business activity. In particular, the finance, insurance and real-estate industries will be well represented. Traditional operating and occupancy costs savings in New Jersey are attractive to back-office operations for these types of companies.
Also, telecommunications capabilities offered in New Jersey are state of the art. These benefits will continue to play an important part in making the state attractive for corporate investment.
Similarly, locations with exceptional accessibility to markets like northeastern New Jersey (Bergen, Hudson, Essex and Passaic Counties) and southwestern New Jersey (Burlington and Camden Counties) promise to do well. Northwestern and southeastern New Jersey should enjoy a continuation of high levels of residential and smaller-scale commercial and industrial activity.
Speaking of industrial activity, certain market-oriented industrial-type companies have been showing surprising locational strength. For instance, companies involved in printing, software and apparel continue to seek New Jersey locations to be near the markets for their goods. Certain of these market-oriented companies have been seeking urban location opportunities in an effort to reduce facility costs by occupying older tenant mill-type space.
At the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, we feel that New Jersey's urban areas represent new redevelopment efforts. The cities typically are well located with underutilized infrastructure (albeit in need of upgrading). Unemployment levels in New Jersey average under 4 percent while the cities offer a labor resource at three or four times that level.
Fortunately, New Jersey's cities have begun to experience growing corporate and developer interest. Given public-sector assistance programs aimed at creating urban redevelopment opportunities (the state's Urban Enterprise Zone program, Urban Development Corporation, etc.) and a growing awareness of the cities (perhaps helped by Public Service's Urban Initiative Campaign), the future economic outlook of our cities should mirror the positive trend of the total state economy.
