HEADLINE: Campus Life: Wheaton;
Disciplinary Acts Raise Questions On Free Speech

DATELINE: WHEATON, Ill.

 BODY:
The right to free speech clashed with Christianideals of ''responsible freedom'' at Wheaton College last week as nine students were disciplined for pieces printed in a student-run alternative newspaper.
All students at Wheaton, a Christian-run liberal arts college of 2,500 in the west Chicago suburb of the same name and alma mater of the evangelist Billy Graham, are required to sign a ''statement of responsibilities'' at the start of freshman year. The statement enumerates Biblical principles of ''Christian character and behavior'' and outlines a Christian life style that excludes jealousy, lust, drinking and profanity, among other things.
Administrators and some students feel that a poem and a stream of consciousness article published in the last two issues of the paper, called The Ice-Cream Socialist, broke the principles of the statement, known as ''the Pledge.'' 
David Vanderveen, a political science major with one semester left before graduation from Spring Lake, Mich., was given a choice of withdrawing from the college at the end of the semester or facing expulsion proceedings. He published the poem in the March 30 issue of The Socialist drawing implicit analogies between surfing and sex.
 
A Dream Sequence
Mr. Vanderveen chose to withdraw. Administration officials say that the publication of the poem ends a two-year-long record of pledge infractions, which they declined to specify.
Two other students, Stephen Smith, a junior business and economics major from Buckland, Mass., and Robert Bruce, a communications major from Wheaton, face suspension during the fall semester for publishing the stream of consciousness piece, signed with a pseudonym. The piece, printed in the April 20 issue, included a dream sequence in which the author defecates on a stack of religious books on the desk of the dean of students.
Mr. Smith and Mr. Bruce were among eight editors of the newspaper. They accepted responsibility for publishing the article, but say it was the result of miscommunication among the editors. Those who decided which articles to print were not present when the paper was laid out.
The other six student editors involved face lesser penalties. They had to write letters to the administration explaining why the piece's publication was inappropriate and why they wanted to remain at the school. They were placed on disciplinary probation and will spend the summer writing papers, due in the fall, about ''being Christians in the world.''
Many students in the college believe the penalties levied on all nine students were too harsh, and 200 turned out for a rally on Tuesday afternoon, in the middle of final examinations week, charging that the college was stifling their First Amendment rights of free speech.
J. Richard Chase, president of the college, vigorously defended his administration's policy after the rally. ''Our students have the right to disagree with the faculty,'' he said. But he added that they must not do so in ''language we believe is unbecoming to a Christian community.''
Students involved with the paper maintain that the penalties were unreasonable. Jean Philips, a freshman literature and philosophy major from Glen Ellyn, Ill., said she thought that the administration's stance was not made clear until it was too late.
After the April 20 issue, she said, ''We were called in and told to use more discretion.'' Some time passed, no more issues ran and disciplinary decisions had not yet been handed down. Then, Ms. Philips said, ''We were told not to print anything else for the rest of the year.''
The students started the paper in September as an ''alternative, open forum newspaper,'' Ms. Philips said. They saw the paper as a way around the administration's control of the school's official newspaper, yearbook and literary magazine. Both students and administrators report that the newspaper was well received until the appearance of Mr. Vanderveen's poem.
Ms. Philips said they had been taking their editorial cues from a casual conversation she had earlier in the year with Mr. Chase. ''He said he didn't mind it as long as it didn't have an agenda to attack Christianity or higher education,'' she reported.
Wheaton officials stressed that two different issues are involved in the disciplinary procedures. Mr. Vanderveen was punished as an individual with pledge offenses, while the others were punished for allowing the offensive work of another individual to be published.

HEADLINE: Campus Life:;
A Different Kind Of Education: Going on Patrol

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
While other students are completing problem sets and studying for exams, some college students here are putting their fears aside, donning red berets and, as Guardian Angels, patrolling this city in an effort to combat crime.
Two of the roughly 75 members of the group's Chicago chapter - Gabriel Irono and Steve Mandis - are sophomores at the University of Chicago.
''There is so much violence here, especially close to the school,'' Mr. Mandis, an economics major from Grand Rapids, Mich., said. ''This is a solution.'' 
It is also a learning experience for him and Mr. Irono, a Japanese history major from Park Forest, a nearby suburb. ''There's a whole different set of values people get from living on the street,'' Mr. Mandis said. ''They struggle to survive from day to day. It's an education for me. I didn't grow up in that; I didn't even lock my door.''
 
'We're All the Same'
Founded in New York City by Curtis Sliwa in 1979, the Alliance of Guardian Angels now has chapters in 60 American cities as well as in Europe and Canada. Known for their red berets, the Guardian Angels are trained in the martial arts but do not carry weapons. Although their relations with the police are mixed, they frequently make citizens' arrests.
The makeup of the chapter here ranges from students like Mr. Irono and Mr. Mandis to former gang members, but Mr. Mandis and others insist that the different backgrounds matter little when they are on the job. ''On the street, we're all the same,'' Mr. Mandis said. About a third of the group's members are college students in the Chicago area, said Sergio Terrazas, the leader of the city chapter. ''They're a lot more mature and a lot more responsible than high school students,'' Mr. Terrazas said. ''They know it's important to be on time.''
A recent patrol was made up entirely of college students. Joining Mr. Mandis and Mr. Irono was Walter Kappel, who studies at the Moody Bible Institute in Chicago. They were led by Kyle Stanford, a junior from Indianapolis majoring in philosophy at Northwestern University.
 
'No Smiling or Talking'
Mr. Stanford's patrol began at the group's headquarters in the Wicker Park neighborhood on the north side of the city. Walking to a nearby elevated train station, Mr. Irono and Mr. Stanford stayed ahead while Mr. Kappel and Mr. Mandis lagged 10 paces behind them to avoid clumping up if they were attacked. In the last three years in Chicago, several Guardian Angels have been shot at but none have been wounded or killed, Mr. Terrazas said.
After boarding the train, the four spread out, moving from car to car. ''There's no smiling or talking,'' Mr. Irono said. ''You've got to look menacing to thugs but helpful to citizens.''
Mr. Mandis added, ''I just look at people's hands and make sure nothing happens.''
While on patrol, the Guardian Angels use what they call code names. Mr. Mandis, who plans to spend next year at the London School of Economics and serve as a Guardian Angel in London, is known as Professor. Mr. Irono chose the name Kaze, which means the wind in Japanese.
The patrol leader, Mr. Stanford, is called Phoenix. Each patrol leader has a two-way radio and checks in regularly with headquarters, known as ''The Cage.''
On this patrol, which proves to be uneventful, the four spend about two hours on the trains, riding between the north and south sides of the city. They switch trains frequently. Prayer Before Each Patrol Since joining the Guardian Angels nine weeks ago, Mr. Mandis and his patrol have stopped a mugging and disarmed a gang member who had a gun. ''There hasn't been much crime,'' he said. ''The best thing is for it not to happen. It's just a matter of presence.''
Both he and Mr. Irono said that fear comes with the job. ''I say a prayer before every patrol,'' Mr. Mandis said. Mr. Irono, who has been a Guardian Angel for almost four months, said: ''I'm always scared. The idea is to control it and not to let it show.''
After an hour and a half, Mr. Stanford heads home to Evanston and Mr. Irono radios ''Kaze to Cage, Mr. Phoenix has turned the patrol over to me.'' As patrol leader, Mr. Irono must keep an eye on his fellow Guardian Angels as well as the train's passengers.
Later, after returning to headquarters, Mr. Irono gives up his uniform and then makes his way back to Hyde Park and the life of a college student. ''It's good to take this weight off your shoulders,'' he said. ''You're not responsible for four people's lives anymore.''

HEADLINE: Campus Life: UCLA;
First a Newsletter, Soon a Newspaper On Muslim Issues

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Special-interest newspapers abound at the University of California at Los Angeles: Nommo, for black students; La Gente, for Hispanic students; Ha'Am, for Jewish students; Together, for feminists; Pacties, for Asians and Pacific Islanders, and TenPercent, for homosexuals.
Now add Al-Talib, first published as a newsletter several months ago to cover Islamic issues and culture.
Al-Talib - the name means ''the student'' - will be transformed from a newsletter into a newspaper through the Associated Students of the University of California at Los Angeles. Working through the association means Al-Talib can use its office space, advisers and equipment, including a computer system. 
Scheduled to appear six times a year beginning next fall, Al-Talib will be written and edited by students.
The Student Publications Board has selected Mansur Khan, a senior biology major from Monterey Park, Calif., as the paper's editor.
''Al-Talib is filling the void of a Muslim voice on campus,'' Mr. Khan said.
Maha Youness, a junior political science major from Glendale, Calif., who is Muslim, said that through Al-Talib, ''Maybe some Muslims won't feel so detached from our society.''
The president of the Muslim Student Association, Rushdi Cader, a senior biology major from Los Angeles, estimated that about 300 Muslim students are enrolled at UCLA.
''There has been a stereotype that Muslims are violent and thrive on terrorism,'' said Rumi Abdul Cader, a recent graduate from Torrance, Calif., who edited Al-Talib as a newsletter. ''But that really isn't true. We would like to use Al-Talib to dispel those myths by representing Islam as it is.''
Mr. Khan said the publication will try to reach a broad readership, including political science majors, would-be scientists and researchers or anyone else who expects to work with Muslims or in Muslim countries.
''It won't be the spokesman of a religious organization,'' said a publications board member, Sumit Chadha, a graduate student in economics from New Delhi.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Culture Shock in Hwang's 'F.O.B.'

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW

 BODY:
At the end of the first act of David Henry Hwang's ''F.O.B.,'' there is a mirthful eating scene that summarizes the conflict between an American-born young man of Chinese descent and a newly landed immigrant, fresh off the boat (F.O.B.) from China. The newcomer, played by Dennis Dun, pours a jar of fiery hot sauce over his dinner and eats it as if it were the most savory of delights. The American (Stan Egi) feels forced to compete, but his tastebuds have become accustomed to the blandness of fast food and he is soon gasping for breath. He continues the competition while the F.O.B. smiles - dare one say it? - inscrutably.
Mr. Hwang's play, first produced in New York in 1980, has been revived by the Pan Asian Repertory Theater at Playhouse 46, in a production directed by the author. While the play is not as poetic as his subsequent ''Dance and the Railroad,'' it offers a clear indication of Mr. Hwang's nascent talent and his social concern. In contrast to some of his subsequent work, it is free of pretension, even as it enters the world of myth. 
''F.O.B.'' begins as a comedy about the possibilities and perils of assimilation, but it aspires to a deeper metaphorical level. The F.O.B. regards himself as an incarnation of Gwan Gung, a legendary Chinese warrior. In response to his acting-out of a Gwan Gung story, his American friend (Ann M. Tsuji) assumes the air of a warrior queen.
Mixing ritual and music, the play enlarges the portrait of a people trying to determine its place in an alien environment. Each of the three characters has a disparate response. Mr. Egi, already racing on the fast track to economic success, has become overly Americanized. He is determined to remove himself from the ''yellow ghosts'' of his past. Ms. Tsuji seeks to combine ancient and modern traditions while going to college and working in her father's restaurant. Mr. Dun, as the mysterious F.O.B., is clownishly deceptive, pretending to be the rawest of greenhorns while actually being a man of intellectual mettle.
While one misses the balletic grace of John Lone, who played the title role in the original New York production, the author has given his play a stylish, highly professional production. Mr. Egi, as a man climbing up from the upper middle class, is an amusing picture of sleek American consumerism. His opposite, Mr. Dun - familiar to television audiences for his role on ''Midnight Caller'' - slips neatly out of his assumed naivete to his mission as cool master of martial arts.
In the pivotal role, Ms. Tsuji is charming. She is a born peacemaker trying to referee the conflict (over ethnicity as well as hot sauce) without discouraging the attention she receives from both young men. In common with Mr. Dun, she is agile in her stage movements, as choreographed by Jamie H. J. Guan. Alex Polner's scenic design for the back room of a family restaurant adds a necessary note of reality, but it is almost too detailed for a small stage. On opening night, the preponderance of properties turned the setting into an obstacle course for the actors.
Mr. Hwang, who also wrote ''M. Butterfly,'' has said that one of his inspirations for ''F.O.B.'' was Maxine Hong Kingston's book ''The Woman Warrior.'' Ms. Kingston returned the compliment in her foreword to a collection of Mr. Hwang's plays, expressing her wonder that through his work ''our private Chinese lives and secret language can be communally understood.''
In ''F.O.B.,'' the playwright entreats theatergoers to leave all preconceptions behind and to open their minds to the warring subdivisions in what would appear to be a homogeneous community. The fact of these differences within the Asian-American culture is itself a moving commentary, especially during a time of increased tension between races.
 
F.O.B.
 
Written and directed by David Henry Hwang; set, Alex Polner; lighting, Victor En Yu Tan; costumes, Eiko Yamaguchi; choreographer, Jamie H. J. Guan; composer and musician, Lucia Hwong; sound design, Robert Barnes; arranger and musician, Yukio Tsuji; stage manager, Sue Jane Stoker. Presented by Pan Asian Repertory Theater, Tisa Chang, artistic and producing director. At Playhouse 46, 423 West 46th Street.

Grace . . . Ann M. Tsuji
Steve . . . Dennis Dun

HEADLINE: Pastimes;
Stamps

BYLINE: By Barth Healey

 BODY:
An important focus of do-it-yourself stamp collecting is the maximum card, which straddles the intersection of philately and deltiology - the study of postcards.
The definition of a maximum card is as vague as the definition of a ''stamp,'' and forces yet another repetition of the hobbyist's first rule: collect whatever interests you, and let the self-styled purist stew.
In general, a maximum card is a picture postcard bearing a stamp or a cancellation, or preferably both, that is closely related to the subject of the card's design.
The first such cards date to the early years of this century, and typically show the portrait of a monarch, embellished with a stamp bearing a similar portrait, and canceled on a date important to the ruler, e.g., a coronation anniversary. 
As more countries began to issue pictorial stamps in the 1920's and 30's, collectors sought out postcards of the churches and castles that appeared on the stamps and had them canceled in the cities where the buildings were located. Such collections became an interesting way for travelers to mark their journeys with souvenirs and acquire a name: maximaphily.
In modern times, this sector has taken an entrepreneurial twist: commercial dealers now print postcards with designs or portraits similar to those on new stamps and then have the stamps affixed and canceled on the first day of issue. One of the largest such distributors is the Unicover Corporation, 1 Unicover Center, Cheyenne, Wyo. 82008.
Traditionalists will say that having a special card made for a stamp is cheating: much of the challenge of maximaphily is in finding existing cards to match the stamp. But the Unicover cards, though a bit pricey at $1.25 each, are of high quality and might interest younger or older collectors who cannot get around to flea markets and other sources of postcards. The cards, which are available by subscription, include historical notes on the back.
Several United States issues this year offer a chance to get started in maximaphily. The Classic Movies set, for example, can be used on old postcards showing Judy Garland, John Wayne, Clark Gable, Vivien Leigh or Gary Cooper. Try combining an appropriate card with its stamp, then send the card to the postmaster of the star's birthplace and have it canceled on the birthdate.
More difficult to find would be postcards showing the five lighthouses in the current booklet of 25-cent stamps. Add the stamps, then send the cards to the towns where the lighthouses are located and ask the postmaster to hand-cancel the cards.
Another issue this year that lends itself to maximaphily will be the five Olympians on a July 6 issue. (Only one has been named so far: Jesse Owens.) In each case, a hobbyist can take advantage of the 30-day grace period in requesting first-day cancels on cards franked with the new stamps. Hobbyists seeking more information about this area can write to the Maximum Card Study Unit, 1437 Maryland Drive, Cincinnati, Ohio 45230.
 
Model A Scholarship
An attractive replica of the 1929 Model A Ford postal truck is being sold through post offices and by mail to raise scholarship funds for children of postal employees. The toy would make an interesting gift for a youngster or decoration in a stamp den.
The replica, 6 1/2 inches long, has been produced by the Yorkshire Company, Glen Ellyn, Ill., and is priced at $29.95. Those ordering by mail can send a check or money order to the Hallbeck Scholarship Fund, 1300 L Street N.W., Washington, D.C. 20005. Add $3.50 for shipping and handling.
Two footnotes: This ''issue'' is described as the beginning of an annual series and collecting such models has become a mini-hobby in itself. When the last of the real Model A trucks was taken out of service in the 1950's, some were sold as scrap for as little as $8, about one-quarter the price of today's toy. Somewhere in there is a message about inflation.
 
INCH BY INCH: VAN GOGH VS. JENNY
Well, yes, van Gogh's ''Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' was sold this week for $82.5 million, a record for a piece of art. The price was well above the previous record of $53.9 million, which was paid for van Gogh's ''Irises'' in November 1987. At this rate, the value of art may well catch up with the value of United States stamps.
''Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' is 28 3/8 by 22 inches, or 580 1/4 square inches. So the $82.5 million works out to only $142,180 a square inch. But if we're talking real money, what about the plate block from the sheet of airmail stamps known as the ''Inverted Jenny,'' with the upside-down biplane in the center? This block went for $1.1 million last fall. It is 2 5/8 by 2 5/8 inches, or about 6.89 square inches, and that works out to $159,652 per square inch.
The most valuable United States stamp is an item most collectors have never heard of: The 15-cent black portrait of Lincoln from the 1860's with a Z grill on the paper, which absorbed cancellation ink to prevent re-use. The last time the 15-cent Z grill was sold, it fetched $418,000. It is only 1 1/4 square inches, so that works out to $334,400 a square inch. Keep plugging, art collectors! You may catch up!

GRAPHIC: Photo: New stamp, old postcard, first day cancel: voila, a maximum card.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 2048 words

HEADLINE: PEOPLE APART;
Can Politics Get to the Roots of Racial Strife?

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
IF David N. Dinkins was judged more harshly than his white rivals in last year's New York City mayoral campaign, as he repeatedly complained, he also benefited from a double standard: Some voters hoped that the election of a black, particularly in a city of reverberating symbols, might ameliorate racial tensions.
In the half year since Mr. Dinkins was elected, there is little palpable evidence that race relations have improved in the nation's largest city. What seems evident is that neither the persistent roots of racial tension nor its sometimes murderous manifestations are within a politician's power to control. Minority groups already have equal opportunity under the law, but there may be little any mayor can do about some of the causes behind racial conflict, particularly when the city has more good intentions than money. Moreover, as racially charged court cases heightened tension, it remained an open question whether Mr. Dinkins's polite appeals to reason would reach any deeper into the personal resentments of Bensonhurst and East New York than Edward I. Koch's sometimes prickly pronunciamentos.
Thursday, on the 10th full day of deliberatons, a Brooklyn jury convicted a 19-year-old white man from the Bensonhurst section of the racial killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins, a 16-year-old black youth from East New York. The next evening, another jury acquitted the accused ringleader of murder but convicted him of a dozen lesser charges. 
In a curious way, the murder conviction perhaps calmed Mr. Dinkins's uneasy white supporters for the moment even more than his election did and probably more than his subsequent campaign to paper over racial divisions with speeches. Meanwhile, the initial euphoria of Mr. Dinkins's supporters in the black community has been tempered by the harsh reality of austerity, which has further confined the Mayor's personal stamp on municipal priorities to the margins (even false hopes were better than no hope, Mr. Dinkins had suggested during his campaign).
But the pattern of dashed hopes is nothing new. Nathan Glazer, who wrote ''Beyond the Melting Pot'' with Daniel P. Moynihan three decades ago, now acknowledges that he was laboring under a ''New York illusion'' when he predicted that American-born blacks, like other newcomers to the city, would overcome the ghetto. However much ethnic ingredients can be merged in the city's simmering brew, blacks and whites will always be distinguishable. Ethnic identity, Mr. Glazer said, ''is pretty thin gruel compared to race.''
In few other nations than the United States and in few other cities than New York is racial tolerance put to so tough a test. Indeed, in 1947, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey declared that ''New York City is not a melting pot, it's a boiling pot.''
A century after the civil war, the civil rights movement largely succeeded in toppling the most visible forms of officially sanctioned racism. Racism has evolved into what most people consider a pejorative term. Yet most black Americans, as W.E.B. Du Bois once wrote, remain ''a part of the larger whole and yet apart from it.'' And if tense confrontations two or more decades ago represented a collision of institutional forces -the strike by city teachers over community control of schools, for instance - today's conflicts are more likely to be personal - a consequence, in part, of integration that has increased encounters between the races.
If, besides an affirmation of the jury system, any progress can be detected from the Hawkins case, it is that 30 years ago it might never have occurred to Mr. Hawkins to venture into the predominantly white neighborhood at all. Nor would David N. Dinkins have run for mayor, much less have won.
If New York is a latecomer to black political ascendancy in state and local government - Carl Stokes was elected mayor of Cleveland fully two decades earlier -Mr. Dinkins's victory revived a soul-searching debate: Purely from a racial perspective, is a black mayor a panacea or a placebo? Does Mr. Dinkins's election and those of fellow black mayors in Seattle and New Haven, and of L. Douglas Wilder in Virginia as the nation's first elected black governor last year, signal an overdue coming to grips with what Gunnar Myrdal called America's special dilemma? Or are the periodic violent confrontations that in recent years etched the names of two New York City neighborhoods - Bensonhurst and Howard Beach - into the collective memory of wary blacks symptomatic of enduring, if often latent, racism?
Mr. Hawkins's murder, and that of Michael Griffith in the Howard Beach section of Queens in 1986, dramatized how implacable are the unmapped barriers that divide many neighborhoods in the city. Several years ago, responding to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News survey, 7 in 10 white New Yorkers and 6 in 10 blacks said they lived in neighborhoods composed mostly or entirely of members of their own race.
''New Yorkers,'' Andrew Hacker, a professor of political science at Queens College of the City University of New York, once wrote, ''think and feel and act and react as if race was the critical demarcation in their city's life.'' But why? Denigrating others on the basis of race, said Shelby Steele, a professor of English at San Jose State University, has historically represented ''a shortcut to the American dream.'' Moreover, many people associate blacks with poverty and its most threatening consequence, crime. ''If white citizens act according to stereotypes,'' Mr. Hacker wrote, ''it is because they prefer playing it safe to a scholarly pursuit of truth. With respect to everyday decisions, racism may be the most rational response.''
The truth, painfully apparent to black people, is that while most criminals in New York are black, so are most of their victims. In 1984, the undercurrent of racial tension was epitomized when Bernhard H. Goetz, a white man, shot black teen-agers he believed were about to rob him on a subway train. A subsequent Times/ WCBS News poll asked riders whether they would feel unsafe if they saw several loud teen-aged boys on their subway car. Yes, 4 in 10 black respondents said, if the boys were white. What if the boys were black? In that case, 5 in 10 black respondents said they would feel unsafe. (Whites, generally, were more afraid of all unruly teen-agers, black and white.) In a Times/WCBS-TV News survey during last year's mayoral campaign, more than half the respondents said race relations are something a mayor can do a lot about. Only about 1 in 5 said the election of Mr. Dinkins would lead to a decrease in racial tensions. That was before the murder of Mr. Hawkins unsettled the city. Mr. Dinkins, perceived because of his personality and his race as the candidate who could best bring New Yorkers together, unseated Mr. Koch a few weeks later in the Democratic primary. But the general election campaign against Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican candidate, culminated in the city's closest mayoral race since 1905. A voter survey found that 4 in 10 Giuliani voters thought Mr. Dinkins would favor blacks; 4 in 10 Dinkins voters thought Mr. Giuliani would favor whites.
Two-thirds of the whites and 9 in 10 blacks voted for a candidate of their own race, a sharp division, but less severe than the cleavage in Chicago earlier last year, when 9 of 10 voters, whether black or white, voted for a mayoral candidate of their own race. However close the margin, New York had its first black mayor. ''That,'' said Frank J. Barbaro, a Brooklyn Assemblyman who lost resoundingly to Mr. Koch in 1981, ''could not have happened if New York City was a center of hate.''
Or could it? If Mr. Dinkins benefited at all from his fellow New Yorkers' fears and frustration over racial discord, he inherited a special burden in the hometown he frequently hailed as a ''gorgeous mosaic.''
''Along with that goes the obligation to keep the mosaic together,'' said Roscoe C. Brown Jr., president of Bronx Community College.
''There's an unstated white pressure,'' said Mr. Hacker: ''Why can't you control your people?''
It was precisely that pressure that moved Mr. Dinkins this month to denounce all of the disparate voices of racism in the city and to appeal for calm as juries decided the Hawkins case and as blacks continued a boycott of two Flatbush vegetable markets managed by Koreans.
That both Mr. Dinkins and his most visible appointee, Lee P. Brown, the Police Commissioner, are black may indeed have a leavening effect, though the record of black mayors elsewhere is inconclusive. ''By and large I would think they have had a harmonious effect,'' said Linda F. Williams, a fellow at the Joan Shorenstein Barone Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government. ''Maybe some things that would blow up don't. It would seem, at least, that in those cities the mayor certainly hasn't increased racial problems.''
But what whites want, the Rev. Al Sharpton said last week, is ''quiet, not peace.'' Mr. Sharpton, a provocateur par excellence, has made a career out of making certain that they don't get it. While Mr. Sharpton is, in large part, a creature of the white media, he has nonetheless struck a responsive chord among many blacks who daily suffer indignities ranging from discrimination in housing to taxi service. They resent a society that measures their lives in white terms - as one black professional said last week, commenting on the United States Supreme Court's landmark school desegration decision in 1954, ''it never occurred to anybody that white children separated from blacks would be irreparably harmed.''
There has been no major civil unrest in New York City for more than a decade, but the crime and dropout rates among young blacks constitute a quiet riot. The death rate among blacks under the age of 65 in central Harlem is nearly three times higher than that of American whites. The high school dropout rate among blacks is estimated as upward of 50 percent.
But once Mr. Dinkins exhausts all his legal sanctions against discrimination, how far will civility and good intentions reach into the hearts of bigoted New Yorkers? It is arguable whether the kind of educational effort he has launched can transform behavior more deeply ingrained than the failures of people to buckle seatbelts or pick up after pets.
Nor is it likely that harmony will be achieved before economic disparities - perhaps the root cause of the black boycott of Korean merchants - are bridged. Nor before people candidly address their differences. Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, recently returned from Israel where, she said, Israeli and Palestinian women spoke with more openness and honesty than she recalled hearing at similar discussions between conflicting groups at home.
An emerging recognition that poor blacks and whites share similar problems, the growing black middle class and the evolving integration of the workplace suggest, though, that time and contact might indeed alter attitudes. ''I see white and black kids at Queens college getting on in ways I never thought they would,'' said Mr. Hacker.
But many blacks remain consigned to poverty as a staggering number of new immigrants pass them by. As a result, New York and the nation are becoming more non-white, but not necessarily more black. Blacks are still the ''indelible immigrants,'' as Richard C. Wade, a City University professor, describes them.
The fundamental question is, when will differences of skin color no longer matter as much as class and culture? Does he harbor any such hopes, Dr. Kenneth Clark, the psychologist, was asked last week. ''I used to hope,'' Dr. Clark replied.
Marking 30 years since the completion of ''Beyond the Melting Pot,'' Mr. Glazer sounded an alarm last week against grasping for symbolic substitutes to integration as society becomes more fragmented instead of pulling together. Too much can be made of symbols. But as Mr. Glazer and his fellow panelists assessed how far beyond the melting pot American society has come in three decades, they sat in the trustees room of the New York Public Library before a tapestry that celebrates Africa and gazed upon an audience of more than 150 people that included four blacks.

Paul Burnett/The New York Times); policeman protecting a Korean-owned grocery store that is being boycotted by blacks in Brooklyn (Bridgette Cavanaugh/Picture Group) (pg. 4)

LENGTH: 1392 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Arms Talks: Essential, but Less Sexy

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
WHEN Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, began their talks here last week, Soviet television buried its reporting of the event in a 15-second film clip that followed agricultural news and an item about the visiting Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak.
This was no accident. The thrust of the Baker-Shevardnadze talks was an effort to complete a series of arms-control agreements in time for the summit meeting in Washington May 30, and what Soviet television seemed be implying was what many Soviet and American citizens have been asking themselves lately: In the post-cold-war world, why should I care about arms control anymore?
After their talks, Mr. Baker said he and Mr. Shevardnadze had overcome major obstacles to a treaty limiting long-range nuclear missiles and had achieved an agreement to ban production of chemical weapons. President Bush called the developments ''encouraging'' and ''interesting,'' but also said, ''It's a mixed review right now.'' Mr. Baker said differences remained on reducing troops and tanks in Europe. 
Having declared that his meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be the ''arms control summit,'' Mr. Bush has seemed to take the position that its success should be judged by the number of arms-control issues concluded. But that doesn't mean the rest of the world will look at it this way.
Soviet television has it right: Arms control is not the sole barometer any longer of the United States-Soviet relationship, nor is it the key factor in reducing tensions between the superpowers. Said Gregory F. Treverton, an expert on European affairs at the Council on Foreign Relations: ''In many ways, arms control is last year's business.''
To be sure, it could become next year's business if anything happens to Mr. Gorbachev and if, as a result, Soviet policy retreats to the more militaristic approach of the Brezhnev era. American officials are keenly aware of that possibility, and this is why they are so eager to get Mr. Gorbachev to sign treaties now that would lock in wide-ranging arms cuts.
American officials say they feel a bit like businessmen trying to close a deal with an ailing prospect. Just as he is about to sign, he becomes bed-ridden. So the businessmen gather around his bed, saying, ''Please, just sign here.'' In the case of Mr. Gorbachev, every time he seems to be reaching for his pen something stays his hand: His relatives from Lithuania show up and start making demands, his brother in the army complains that he is giving away the store, and he suffers internal pains.
When and if Mr. Gorbachev signs, though, it will probably be of little interest to many of his own citizens, who have become totally absorbed in internal affairs. They care little about whether the summit meeting will slash the number of long-range nuclear missiles to a level that would leave the superpowers capable of obliterating each other merely 50 times over rather than 100 times.
''No one is worried about U.S.-Soviet relations now,'' said Vladimir Kikilo, a foreign affairs expert at the Communist Party newspaper Pravda. ''Now everyone is obsessed with his own business: how to get some food; how to make ends meet; will the Communist Party split? ''I used to read the newspaper backwards,'' he said. ''I would start with the back pages, read the TV listings, sports, some arts, then skip to the front and read the international news. I would not read the domestic news pages in the middle. Now I go right to these pages first.''
Stephen M. Meyer of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, an expert on the Soviet military, said it is no wonder that arms control has been shoved downward on the Soviet agenda.
''If all major cities in the United States were involved in race riots,'' Mr. Meyer said, ''and people were calling for the impeachment of President Bush every day, and several New England states announced that they were seceding to join Canada, it would not be surprising if President Bush and Secretary Baker were not all that focused on arms control.''
''That is what Gorbachev faces,'' he added. ''Having a strategic arms agreement now or in five years doesn't really matter much if you aren't sure that there is going to be a Soviet Union in five years.''
 
Trade, Please
If Mr. Gorbachev returns from the summit with a trade agreement and trade concessions based on most-favored-nation status, Mr. Kikilo said, Soviet citizens will feel that the meeting has produced tangible results. ''But you can't feel the results of arms reduction agreements,'' he added.
Indeed, each of several Soviet analysts who was asked for this article about what he hoped to see come out of the summit responded: ''Trade.''
The most notable reason for the decrease in attention for arms control negotiations is the shift in the overall character of the United States-Soviet relationship. When East and West were locked in a nose-to-nose nuclear standoff during the cold war, even relatively small arms-control treaties could be felt psychologically and militarily.
Arms-control negotiations accounted for the most conspicuous diplomatic contacts between the two sides, and the ups and downs of these talks were considered synonymous with the ups and downs of the entire relationship.
But now the superpowers have entered an era when their talks are increasingly about areas of cooperation, not confrontation. The prospect of armed conflict in Europe seems remote, and McDonald's is selling Big Meks in Pushkin Square. One Soviet foreign-policy analyst remarked: ''The question people ask today about America is not will there be war, but what can we learn from America?''
The 1987 treaty limiting intermediate-range ballistic missiles, Mr. Kikilo said, ''was kind of a climax for arms control; after that people felt safe.
''Even though it only dealt with 4 percent of the nuclear weapons on each side, it had a great symbolic importance.'' he added. ''The treaty defused the threat of global war.''
So it is not surprising that the relationship is most affected today by those actions and events that could call into question the broad network of cooperative ventures the United States and Soviet Union have begun.
Failure to sign a strategic arms treaty soon might have little impact on the relationship. But a Soviet military crackdown in Lithuania could reverse all of the positive developments of the last few years, by prompting the United States to sever trade or diminish contacts.
As soon as aides to Mr. Baker heard last week that the Kremlin and Lithuanian officials seemed to be starting a dialogue, they sighed in relief that the summit meeting would now go off smoothly, no matter what happened in arms control.
 
Fear of Implosion
Militarily, the most immediate threat to the United States-Soviet relationship is not the possibility of one side's suddenly raining nuclear missiles on the other. The immediate danger seems to stem more from the possibility of a breakup of the Soviet Union from nationalist pressures or economic implosion, and the instability that would spill over into Europe.
That is the kind of situation that the arms-control agreements being negotiated would be powerless to control.
Indeed, the talks over conventional arms levels in Europe have been almost totally overtaken by events. The Soviet Union has had to withdraw tens of thousands of men and large stockpiles of arms from Eastern Europe in the last year simply because of the collapse of Communism there, and without a treaty with the West.
The United States, under pressure from Congress, will soon do the same. Any conventional arms agreement in Europe at this stage would not really be intended to reduce tensions in the traditional sense but simply to manage, and lock in, the withdrawal of Soviet forces.
To be sure, arms control has hardly become irrelevant, said Sergei M. Plekhanov, deputy director of the Soviet Institute for the Study of the U.S.A. and Canada. There are still too many dangerous weapons on the shelf and they will not get safer with age. ''Arms control is still a barometer of the relationship in a way,'' he said, ''but it is like the barometer in your house. You look at it when you expect a storm. When it is sunny, or partly cloudy, you just don't have to look at it every day.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In Search of Capitalism With a Human Face

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
TWO decades ago Communist reformers in Eastern Europe wanted to build a new type of economic system, one that would be a bold mix of Marxism and the free market. Eager to shun Stalinist repression and stagnation as well as to avoid capitalist evils like unemployment, these idealists dreamed of constructing ''socialism with a human face.''
Now that most Eastern European nations have sloughed off Communist rule, talk has turned away from such lofty abstractions to the practical problems of building what the region's economists call ''a regular economy,'' like those in Western Europe and the United States.
But decades of socialism have left an indelible mark. Even as Hungarians, Poles, Czechoslovaks and East Germans shun experimentation in favor of creating Western-style market economies, many hope to avoid the unhappiest aspects of capitalism. They want the growth, dynamism and flexibility of the free market without the ugly side, which often includes large-scale unemployment, homelessness and extremes in wealth and poverty. 
''We are almost in capitalism, but mentally we are still in socialism,'' said Andrzej Wroblewski, editor of Gazeta Bankowa, a Polish financial newspaper.
 
Clinging to Socialism
Though fervently anti-Communist, many Eastern Europeans still cling to socialist ideals about equality and jobs for all, and in the region's fledgling democracies, these keepers of the flame are making themselves heard. In Hungary, several newly homeless families camped out in front of Parliament to protest some all-too-capitalist rent increases. In Poland, Solidarity members complained that the Solidarity-led Government's free-market-inspired price increases and layoffs were causing too much pain. In East Germany, farmers blockaded border crossings, demanding protection for their subsidies and land.
Some reform efforts have already been bogged down because of worries about the negatives of capitalism. In Hungary, a program to privatize industry was overhauled because of public outrage that some investors had bought state-owned companies at bargain prices. In Warsaw, the Government's privatization bill is snagged partly because workers, who had a powerful voice in running their companies under Communism, are angry that they would no longer have a large say.
Just as it was hard to impose Communism upon capitalist Eastern Europe after World War II, so, too, will it be tough to install a smoothly running market economy after four decades of Communism. These nations cannot in one quick stroke scrap central planning, remove all price controls, end generous subsidies to businesses and consumers, and sell all state-owned industry to private investors; the pain and tumult would be unbearable.
It took Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, a perfervid free-marketeer, a decade to privatize less than 10 percent of British industry. No one says that Eastern European nations, where more than 90 percent of industry is state-owned, can sell off an appreciable chunk of the state sector overnight.
Government officials say it is important to privatize some enterprises immediately to create competition and force companies to worry about profits and efficiency. But Eastern Europeans have little in the way of savings to invest in shares.
''Here we have to privatize six times as much in three years'' as Britain did in a decade, said Marton Tardos, a leading Hungarian economist. ''If we do not privatize a significant amount in three years, we fear the Hungarian economy will collapse.''
To help their private sector grow, Eastern European nations will need a stock market, but Hungary has already discovered the difficulties of starting one. Communist teachings about capitalist exploitation have left many Hungarians ignorant and unenthusiastic about stocks and bonds. Even though the exchange is two and a half years old, less than $30,000 in stock changes hands in each day's trading.
''The most difficult obstacle is there hasn't been a stock exchange in 40 years,'' said Ilona Hardy, the exchange's executive director. ''People did not learn about it at school, and they do not understand what it's all about. What is more, a lot of people say a stock exchange is wrong and capitalistic.'' Privatization is also running into resistance because Eastern Europeans have been taught to reject private ownership. ''People in Hungary are scared of ownership,'' said Bela Kadar, director of the Institute of Economic Planning in Hungary. ''Many consider it immoral, un-Marxist.''
 
Too Much Capitalism
It seems that whenever a company is privatized, someone asserts that capitalist buyers are getting too good a price. The catch, of course, is that investors are usually unwilling to make an investment unless they believe they are getting a good deal.
It will also take years for Eastern Europe to develop an accurate accounting system because prices remain deeply distorted as a result of controls and subsidies. The crude state of banking is also holding back business development. Few individuals have checking accounts, business checks can take two months to clear. Little wonder that Polish executives travel with large satchels of money.
Another daunting prospect is to rebuild - or, in many cases, build - a modern infrastructure of roads, trains, airports and telecommunication networks. Anyone who has spent hours trying to make a phone call from Warsaw to the Polish countryside knows how crippled the region's infrastructure is.
''You cannot develop a market economy and attract foreign investors if you can't get a telephone call through or receive a fax,'' said Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir Dlouhy of Czechoslovakia. Economists estimate that it will cost East Germany more than $500 billion to upgrade its infrastructure to West German levels. Next to this amount, the $12 billion that the new Bank for European Reconstruction and Development plans to lend Eastern Europe seems paltry, as does the much-heralded $3 billion in aid that the West has pledged to Poland.
Equally painful will be dealing with Hungary's and Poland's huge debt burdens.
 
Fear of Unemployment
Another difficult task will be to push obsolete, inefficient companies into bankruptcy after decades during which enterprises were not allowed to go under and layoffs were all but prohibited. A C.I.A. report estimated that unemployment could hit 9 percent in Poland, up to 20 percent in Yugoslavia and East Germany and 5 percent or more in Bulgaria.
Eastern Europeans are so gung-ho about building a Western-style economy that they hardly bother to fuss what brand of capitalism to buy. At the moment, Eastern Europe's social democrats and Thatcherites are in agreement about the basic steps needed. Only after the region has planted the seeds for a solid market economy, they say, need they fight over which variant of capitalism should be their ultimate goal: the wilder variety espoused by Ronald Reagan and Mrs. Thatcher or the tamer versions of Sweden and West Germany.
Where the economic policies of Eastern European nations differ most is in their pace of reform. Confronting the region's worst economic crisis, Poland's Finance Minister, Leszek Balcerowicz, is using shock therapy to wipe out his country's 1,000 percent inflation rate and jolt the economy out of its Communist stupor. In his view, experiencing deep pain for a short time is the best way for Poland's enfeebled economy to regain its strength. In contrast, the Government in Czechoslovakia, where store shelves are full and where many people own summer homes, is moving more deliberately. Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus wants to first break up state monopolies and create competition before he scraps price controls.
To get from here to there while minimizing the pain, the nations of Eastern Europe have built elaborate safety nets and demanded debt relief from their Western creditors. In addition, these countries are clamoring for Western investment because they know Western money, management skills and technology will speed their economic revival.
Eastern European officials say they have learned from Hungary's experiment, which involved of modest reforms, beginning in 1968, that aimed to create a system between Communism and capitalism. The reforms either were sabotaged or backfired, and Hungary still finds itself in baleful economic shape.
''We see,'' said Ivan Berend, an economic historian and president of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, ''that half measures are not enough to create an efficient economy.''

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
For the Politicians, The Prize in 1990 Is Really 1992

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE rap on politicians is that they can't seem to think about anything but the next election. Not fair. This year they are focusing on the election after the next one.
In state after state, the 1990 midterm elections have emerged as a gigantic battle for political position going into the 1992 elections. The campaign themes have not been overwhelming, but the stakes are. 
Who will control governorships and statehouses as congressional and legislative lines are redrawn after the census? Will the Republicans pick up enough seats in the Senate to give them a running start on taking it back in 1992? Can the Democrats reinforce their stronghold in the House to protect them when new districts will be created, dozens of members will retire, and George Bush will no doubt be at the top of the Republican ticket?
Howard Schloss, spokesman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, described 1990 as ''the calm before the reapportionment storm.'' And indeed, except for a general antagonism toward politicians, there are few national themes - the sort that might develop in an economic tailspin or a foreign crisis.
Abortion and taxes are compelling issues. But the way they are being contested seems to be revealing as much about the strains within the Republican Party as about where the politicians or the nation stand.
Sensing a decided shift in the public mood in favor of abortion rights, Republican Party leaders encouraged pro-choice candidates. But several have had problems on their right, most notably Barbara Hafer, the party's favorite for Governor of Pennsylvania, who last week very nearly lost her primary race to an underfinanced opponent who came out of the anti-abortion movement. Politically wounded, Ms. Hafer will face Gov. Robert P. Casey, who opposes abortion, in the fall.
Opposition to taxes, a staple of the G.O.P.'s campaigns, is also producing internal problems. The sputtering economy has left state coffers short and forced governors and candidates for governor to accept, or at least to avoid ruling out, new taxes.
President Bush seemed to imply that he was ready to do the same thing, for the same reasons, when he summoned Congressional leaders for budget talks. Republican candidates for the Senate panicked, fearing that Mr. Bush was giving away their best issue. Last week, eight of them fired off a letter to him that said: ''The Republican Party stands for the working men and women of this country and has consistently opposed efforts to raise taxes. We respectfully urge you to reject any budget agreement which violates your pledge of no new taxes.''
So with national themes creating as much confusion as clarity, all politics are even more local than usual. Here are some of the more important contests:
 
The Stakes In the States
With population, and thus political power, migrating from north and east to south and west, great importance is placed in who controls redistricting in states that will gain seats (Florida, Texas, California) or lose them (New York, Pennsylvania, Illinois). Business and labor contributors are pouring millions of dollars into state races this year. Members of the House of Representatives have spent almost as much time raising money to give to state legislators as they have for themselves.
Democrats seem to be in command in New York and Pennsylvania. But in Illinois a tough race is under way between Jim Edgar, the Republican Secretary of State, and Neil Hartigan, the Democratic Attorney General.
Republicans control all three governorships in the states that are expected to gain the most Congressional seats, but they are vulnerable in Florida. Gov. Bob Martinez is expecting a stiff challenge from the winner of the Democratic primary, who at the moment seems almost certain to be former United States Senator Lawton Chiles. Mr. Chiles's acknowledgement that he took antidepressant medication does not seem to have done him nearly the political damage that Mr. Martinez's ill-fated effort to curb abortion did him. Republicans harbor hopes of capturing the State Senate, where they are now four votes short. If they did, it would be the first time since Reconstruction that the Republicans have controlled a Southern state legislative house.
A bruising primary gave Ann Richards the Democratic nomination for Governor of Texas, but gave Clayton Williams, her Republican opponent, the early advantage to succeed Gov. William P. Clements Jr. Some wonder whether Mr. Williams's down-home appeal can go the distance to November.
In the California Governor's race, Senator Pete Wilson, the Republican candidate, will face either Dianne Feinstein, the former Mayor of San Francisco, or John Van de Kamp, the state Attorney General. Mr. Wilson seems to favor a Van de Kamp victory; he has crossed party lines to attack Ms. Feinstein. As the June 5 primary approaches, the race is close.
 
Fighting Over The Senate
Republicans sense a big opportunity to close the 55-to-45 advantage that the Democrats hold in the Senate. Eight Republican House members have given up safe seats to run for the Senate. Five of them are challenging incumbents, in Illinois, Iowa, Rhode Island, Hawaii and Michigan. While there are a few vulnerable Republicans, including Dan Coats, Vice President Quayle's appointed successor in Indiana, and Jesse Helms, conservative warrior in a changing North Carolina, more Democrats than Republicans are at risk. A gain of even two seats would give Republicans a good base for 1992.
 
Opportunities In the House
Both sides say they expect a swing of only a few seats, at most, although a gathering anti-incumbent mood could upset these predictions.
In 1992, almost all incumbents will have to run in partially redrawn districts, and are doing what they can this year to remind constituents who they are. Many challengers, too, are approaching this fall as a dry run for 1992, when a rush of retirements is expected. Some incumbents' districts will be wiped out. Others won't want to run in the new districts they are handed, and a few older members will probably step down.
All told, there could be 100 districts without an incumbent in 1992. That compares with 27 in 1988. And given the way voters are talking about politicians, it seems like a trend that would not bother them much.

HEADLINE: HEADLINERS;
Unwelcome, Partner

BYLINE: By Laura Mansnerus

 BODY:
Last week, Ann B. Hopkins was celebrating, smoking cigarettes, drinking beer, making jokes and otherwise acting thick-skinned, the way she has through seven years of litigation over her right to be a partner in a big accounting firm. It was just that unfeminine posture that had led the firm to reject her, a Federal judge had found, and because of that the firm would have to take her back.
Ms. Hopkins had already won at every turn in her case against Price Waterhouse, which she said passed her over because they judged her to be masculine, abrasive and in need of ''a course at charm school.'' But the decision ordering the firm to make her a partner was the prize. It was apparently the first time a court had awarded a partnership as a remedy for race or sex discrimination. 
The award can be appealed, and Ms. Hopkins, who now works for the World Bank in Washington as a budget planner, said she thought the case was not over yet.
Ms. Hopkins was among 88 candidates for partnership in 1983, and had brought in more business than any of the others. But she also received more negative comments from partners, including some who said she should wear makeup and jewelry and walk, talk and dress ''more femininely.''
When an individual brings a discrimination suit, the issue is usually the employer's intent. Generally, employers can dismiss or reject someone for any reason or no reason, so long as it is not the wrong reason, such as race or sex. But when Ms. Hopkins brought suit, accounting firms, law firms and other professional partnerships were arguing that they were not subject to the same rules.
The Supreme Court rejected that contention in the 1984 case of Elizabeth A. Hishon, a lawyer passed over for partnership at the Atlanta firm of King & Spalding, although the justices made no finding as to whether Ms. Hishon had been wrongfully rejected. Ms. Hishon reached a settlement with the firm and never returned.
For Ms. Hopkins, there remained the question of whether Price Waterhouse would have to prove in a trial that it based its decision on legitimate and not discriminatory reasons. Last year, the Supreme Court ruled that the firm did have that burden.
Finally, after trial, Judge Gerhard A. Gesell of Federal District Court in Washington found that Price Waterhouse had not met its burden and that it would be pointless to simply ask the firm to reconsider Ms. Hopkins. He acknowledged that ''it is indeed a strained partnership relationship that lies ahead.''

PUB-DATE: May 20, 1990,

SECTION: Section 4; Page 20, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 517 words

HEADLINE: New Germany; Old Fears

 BODY:
By formal agreement concluded Friday, the two Germanys will become one on July 1, barely eight months after the wall's fall. To most people, what was unthinkable then seems unremarkable now. Polls indicate that Americans are less concerned about German unification than are the Germans themselves. 
But that calm is not universal. People who remember World War II, and the unlearned lessons of World War I, remain queasy about the breakneck movement toward unification. And if there is unease in this country, think how people must feel in the Soviet Union, on whose soil so many millions died.
Those who fought, suffered and learned the hard way are entitled to harbor doubts. Their question is entitled to be heard, and answered: are they right to fear that Germany will revert to militarism, fascism or expansionism, once its unity and sovereignty is fully restored?
Some Americans, fearing a revival of militarism, want Germany to disarm. And no one thinks Germany should have nuclear weapons. But a wholly disarmed Germany would sooner or later be an insecure Germany. And it would resent being denied, alone among its neighbors, the sovereign right of self-defense.
Indeed, many Germans, especially on the left, are wary of a professional army and are thus loath to end conscription. To assure that the draft continues to operate fairly, citizens in the eastern part of a united Germany will be eligible for military service.
But with the reduced Soviet threat, force cuts are fully warranted, and Bonn has already announced plans to shrink the Bundeswehr. It is also prepared to accept constraints on its armed forces as part of a 23-nation treaty soon to be concluded on conventional forces.
Beyond explicit arms arrangements, concerned observers can find reassurance in Bonn's well-developed political arrangements. Democratic traditions have taken hold in West Germany after nearly half a century. Traces of right-wing extremism and anti-Semitism persist on the fringe in West Germany, but they're much less of a concern than in, say, France.
It is the East Germans who, after two generations of totalitarian rule, may prove more susceptible to extremist excess. That's why Germany's friends have been especially concerned that unification arrangements respond to the deep-seated wishes and anxieties of the East German people.
The more plausible danger is that, if care is not taken, the Soviet Union of tomorrow may resemble the Germany of 1930. That's why Bonn and Washington, as they join in restoring full sovereignty to a unified Germany, will have to go out of their way to satisfy understandable Soviet desires for security, prestige and prosperity.
The Germany of 60 years ago was a deeply dissatisfied society, embittered by what many people felt was an unjust settlement of World War I, battered by depression and disdainful of a then-fragile democratic tradition. But not today.
Self-confident, Germany is more likely to flex its muscle in the economic realm. Such assertiveness may breed resentment, but it will contribute to, not threaten, the long peace in Europe.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 20, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 561 words

HEADLINE: How to Police Future Stock Futures

 BODY:
The staid Securities and Exchange Commission and the upstart Commodity Futures Trading Commission have gone to war. The issue is important, and heated: which agency should regulate the market in stock index futures.
Some experts look to a consolidation of the two agencies as a way to achieve regulatory consistency. Others would preserve regulatory competition as a way to keep both agencies on their toes. At the moment, the S.E.C. is winning the battle, having persuaded the Bush Administration to strip the C.F.T.C. of jurisdiction over stock index futures. But for all the hot contention, there's no need to choose between consistency and competition. With legislative tinkering, both can be achieved. 
The S.E.C. regulates the cash market for stocks, which is centered in New York. The C.F.T.C. regulates the market for futures - contracts to buy and sell assets at a future time and price - which is primarily located in Chicago.
Most futures contracts are for agriculture products like soybeans and pork bellies. But in recent years, the C.F.T.C. has approved futures for financial assets. One such product, the stock index future, is a contract to buy or sell the value of an index of stocks on a future date, thereby combining features of both stocks and futures.
These futures are used by some investors as an inexpensive way to offset the risk of owning stocks and by others as a way to bet on the movement of stock prices. The contracts are controversial because some observers think they worsened the 1987 and 1989 stock market crashes.
The S.E.C. contends that the markets for stocks and stock index futures are closely linked and should therefore be regulated by a single authority. Until they are, traders can evade the rules of one market by switching to the other. That, says the S.E.C., crimps its ability to weed out fraud and set margin requirements, which limit how much investors can borrow. And split regulation can limit the usefulness of ''circuit breakers,'' which halt trading when prices plummet. Another danger is a temptation to lower standards, to attract business from the other market.
But the C.F.T.C. has good arguments for split authority. The brash C.F.T.C. has innovated many products that energize capital markets. Yet studies fail to show that unequal margin requirements contributed to the 1987 debacle or cause instability generally. Besides, futures traders believe that the S.E.C., if it gained additional authority, would issue rules biased toward the cash markets it has historically regulated.
There is a way to have both regulatory consistency and competition. Two years ago, after the 1987 crash, a four-person Presidential Working Group on Financial Markets was created to oversee regulation. It was given only advisory power. But Congress could authorize such a group to impose coordinated margin requirements and other regulations if cooperation between the S.E.C. and C.F.T.C. should break down. And the group could provide a single regulatory voice when required, as in negotiating with foreign governments.
If Congress could start from scratch, perhaps it would be best to create a single regulatory agency that owed allegiance to neither New York nor Chicago. But history cannot be easily undone. Until a better solution emerges, a small oversight group is the best way to avoid petty turf wars.

HEADLINE: Care-Giving at Home Should Not Cost You Your Job;
A Path to Destitution

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Parental Leave: Leave It at That'' misses the mark when it suggests that the job guarantee contained in the Family and Medical Leave Act is a luxury useful only to middle-class workers. On the contrary, the least privileged, most vulnerable workers are also most likely to be without employer-provided, job-protected leave. 
Workers of all incomes need time to be with their infants during the first weeks of life, to care for immediate family members in times of medical crisis and to recover from their own serious illnesses. For poor families and families supported by single parents, losing a job because of such family and medical emergencies may well lead to debt, destitution and homelessness.
Furthermore, your recommendation that the legislation be limited to leave to care for the newborn fails to respond adequately to the needs of American workers and their families. Yes, families need to be together when a child is born or adopted. But families also need the care and support of their working members when a spouse, parent or child becomes seriously ill.
The aging of the American population underscores this need as people increasingly rely on their spouses and adult children for care-giving. And workers who are themselves temporarily unable to work because of serious health conditions need job security in order to ensure their families' economic survival.
As the House of Representatives recognized in passing this legislation by a wide margin, the Family and Medical Leave Act balances competing work and family responsibilities in a sensible and sensitive fashion. We hope that the Senate and President Bush will similarly act to ensure that American workers are not forced to choose between their jobs and their families.
 
JUDITH L. LICHTMAN
President, Women's Legal Defense Fund
 Washington, May 15, 1990

HEADLINE: PUBLIC & PRIVATE;
A Changing World

BYLINE: By Anna Quindlen

 BODY:
These are dark days for the boys of Bensonhurst. Their world is fading as fast as the summer sun over the city some of their fathers and grandfathers helped build. They are angry the way people are angry when they see a sure thing slipping through their fingers.
Life was easier a generation ago. They graduated from high school, or maybe they didn't. It didn't really matter, because someone from the family or the neighborhood could get them into the union or the civil service, could find them a job working construction or picking up trash. 
A couple blocks away would be the girl, pretty, with hair and eyes as dark as the subway tunnels, and then there would be the wedding, and later the kids. She would serve dinner on a tray table in front of the television if the game was on, or keep it warm if the boys wanted to get together to play a little ball. She did shirts just right. Looking good was the thing when the day's grime was scrubbed away.
That has not changed. Looking good is still important. Keith Mondello never had a hair out of place during his trial. Just looking at him you could hear the blow dryer going. Joey Fama was found guilty of murder. Keith Mondello beat the big charges but was convicted of being part of a riot. When the riot was over, a black kid named Yusuf Hawkins was dead on the Bensonhurst sidewalk. They said afterward that it ruined the Feast of Santa Rosalia.
The people of Bensonhurst will tell you the boys were protecting the neighborhood. Common sense will tell you that it doesn't take 40 guys with baseball bats to protect a city street from four teen-agers looking to buy a used car. It doesn't take a gun.
Maybe what they were after wasn't Yusuf Hawkins at all, but everything he represented. The lives the boys of Bensonhurst were banking on are as dead as Drexel Burnham Lambert, and for some of the same reasons. They liked to think they were tops in their neighborhood, and their neighborhood was tops in the city, and the city was the greatest in America, and America was the leader of the world. All ashes. America limps along, a superpower that, like a star high-school athlete grown middle-aged, ate too much but didn't exercise. It carries a paunch of second-ratedness. The girls that were once compliant talk back. They go out to work, and some of them even like it. The jobs aren't there anymore. The boys don't like to talk of slow housing starts, or municipal cutbacks. They talk of how the jobs were all given away to blacks and Hispanics. This week in Bensonhurst one of the delis put a picture of a watermelon in the window.
While the trial was going on, a study was released showing that, after blacks and Hispanics, Italian kids are most likely to drop out of school in New York. This came as a surprise to academia, but not to Bensonhurst. The kids who go to college move away, from the neighborhood and from their families, and that's no good. There's an Italian saying: It's a stupid man who makes his son better than he is.
When you say these things people will say you are anti-Italian, but ethnicity is beside the point. The boys of Bensonhurst have cousins all over America, from Irish-American boys in parts of Boston to good old boys in small towns down South. They were given to understand that they were better, not because they were smart or capable, but just because they were white men in a world that hated anyone who wasn't.
And then the world changed. But they didn't.
A black kid died in Bensonhurst, and someone killed him. You could argue that the whole block did it, although Mayor Dinkins refused to countenance group guilt. But these are places where people keep watch on the street, and as surely as someone is going to give my kids hell if they step off the curb on my block, someone watched that mob and they've kept quiet about it all this time. And they always will. This is the code of the boys, wherever they live: Take care of your own. No matter what.
Keeping the code, and the illusion of superiority, becomes harder every day. The economy is in the toilet, buying a house seems forever out of reach, and even when you get a job, you turn around and the guy next to you is black.
Yusuf Hawkins died fast on the pavement. The world of the boys of Bensonhurst, the world they try to protect by any means possible, will waste away and die more slowly. But it will not survive to convince another generation of its own superiority, an illusory arrogance that someone thought worth killing for.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

PUB-DATE: May 20, 1990,

SECTION: Section 4; Page 22, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 938 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
A Drug For Cows That Churns Up Opposition

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOUR years ago, John Kinsman stood outside his barn in Lime Ridge, Wis., and vowed to halt a new advance in farm technology, a genetically engineered drug to increase milk production in cows, that he believed would sweep small dairy farmers like himself from the land.
Last month, in a singular decision prompted by the political opposition generated by Mr. Kinsman, Wisconsin's Governor, Tommy G. Thompson, signed a law banning the sale or use of the drug in the nation's largest milk-producing state for more than a year.
The new law is the first in United States history to bar an advance in farm technology before it reached the market. Though largely a symbolic act, the law is the most vivid evidence yet of a widening view in rural America, and the political clout associated with it, that some technological advances have done more to hurt farmers and rural communities than to help them. It is a trend that frightens biotechnology industry executives but gives hope to small family farmers. 
''We're looking at technology in a different way,'' said Mr. Kinsman, who at age 64 milks 35 Holsteins twice daily on his 150-acre farm 70 miles northwest of Madison, Wisconsin's capital. ''We're asking whether this technology is another that could haunt us and cause problems, as some of the pesticides and drugs we used have. We're asking whether this is another expensive technology that's going to make its manufacturers rich but won't make us any more money.''
The drug, bovine somatotropin, has been touted by its manufacturers as the first economically important product of genetic engineering in agriculture. Produced from genetically engineered bacteria, artificial bovine somatotropin is a nearly identical copy of a natural hormone that controls milk production in dairy cows. When injected, it raises the levels of the growth hormone in the cow's blood and causes an increase of milk production by 10 to 25 percent - or 1 to 3 extra gallons to the 12 to 15 gallons a high-producing cow yields daily. Some analysts predict sales of $1 billion annually for the drug.
The Food and Drug Administration, which is considering the drug for approval next year, said the drug is harmless to people. And the four chemical and drug companies that hope to bring it to market - Monsanto, Eli Lilly, American Cyanamid and Upjohn - say the drug is a tool for increasing production and lowering costs that favors neither small nor large producers. It will be readily affordable to each, they say, although prices are as yet unknown.
Unlike Mr. Kinsman, some of Wisconsin's dairy farmers have said they are eager to buy the drug. ''It is an effective tool for improving efficiency in the dairy industry,'' said Judith A. Klusman, a dairy farmer from Oshkosh and a Republican state representative who opposed the ban. ''To compete globally, we can't afford to be cut out from using such an effective tool.''
But judging from several polls, Mr. Kinsman and others in Wisconsin were successful in turning bovine somatotropin into a crisp symbol of the technological determinism in modern farming that has sought ever-greater production and efficiency virtually at the expense of all other values. The costs of the system, he argued, have been enormous. Agriculture has become dominated by expensive technology that pollutes, causes toxic threats to the food supply and encourages enormous corporate farms.
 
A Return to Milk Surpluses
Bovine somatotropin represented a sublime technical achievement, Mr. Kinsman argued, but it was also the last thing dairy farmers needed. Consumers had indicated in polls that they were not anxious to buy milk containing an artificial hormone. Farmers were worried that if the drug were widely used, it would mean the return of the milk surpluses that had cost the Government more than $16 billion in the 1980's and driven tens of thousands out of business. Rural bankers and businesspeople were anxious about more bankruptcies caused by failed farms.
For nearly as long as Americans have farmed, rural communities have shown a persistent skepticism about new agricultural inventions - from steel plows to barbed wire - that has blossomed periodically in active protests. In the 1940's, Southern sharecroppers raised objections to the mechanical cotton picker, accurately predicting that its use would help to drive millions of farmers and field workers from the Deep South and shift cotton production to the West.
 
A Beneficial Trend
But not until the conflict over bovine somatotropin had concerns about new agricultural tools been translated into law. The Wisconsin law barring the drug led to enactment of a similar law in neighboring Minnesota. Legislators in Pennsylvania, New York and New England also are considering bills.
Executives at Monsanto said they are concerned about the laws, but expressed hope that the protest has peaked. On Tuesday, the Vermont legislature rejected a proposal that would have temporarily barred sales of the drug.
Other experts, though, view the new laws as a political trend that could benefit agriculture and the rest of American society.
''It represents a point in our history when people are questioning what progress is,'' said Pete Daniel, a curator at the National Museum of American History in Washington and author of ''Breaking the Land,'' a 1985 book on how technology transformed cotton, tobacco and rice farming. ''There is a conception in this country that science always produces something new and better. But is it progress if a new bovine hormone produces more milk that's not needed and puts people out of business?''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wisconsin and Minnesota have banned bovine somatotropin, a genetically engineered hormone that is injected in cows to boost milk production; Vermont has approved its use (Elliott Erwitt/Magnum)
