SECTION: Section 10A; Page 14, Column 1; Commercial Real Estate Report

LENGTH: 1692 words

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
European Opportunities Beckoning Developers

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
DURING the boom years of the 80's the United States was a land of opportunity for real estate developers and investors the world over. Now, with an ambitious plan to lift bureaucratic, legal and trade barriers among the 12 countries of the European Economic Community inching toward a 1992 start, and the political thaw in the Eastern Bloc raising hopes for an economic rejuvenation in those countries, many American real estate entreprenuers are looking to Europe for the next wave of opportunity.
Tishman Speyer Properties of New York, in partnership with Citibank and Kajima Corporation, a Japanese construction company, is building a 70-story office tower in Frankfurt, West Germany.
American Continental Properties Group, which owns commercial properties throughout the United States, has teamed with IMI, one of the largest banks in Italy, to convert the former Peroni brewery in Rome to a mixed-use development with office space, apartment and shops.
Emery Roth & Sons, a Manhattan-based architectural firm, is designing 10 hotel complexes for the Hungarian Ministry for Commerce and the Hungarian Hotel Association. 
Senie Kerschner International Housing Limited of Westport, Conn., signed an agreement last month to build a 528-unit rental residential complex on land owned by a farm collective on the outskirts of Moscow. The complex will serve both foreign and Soviet employees of American and European companies with operations in the Soviet Union.
In February, the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Jones Lang Wootton, an international commercial real estate brokerage and consulting company with 58 offices world wide, announced the creation of an international real estate investment fund. It is known as the Prudential Global Real Estate Investment Program and Jones Lang Wootton will serve as its adviser for the acquisition of properties in major cities around the globe, among them Frankfurt, London and Paris. So far, eight companies have committed a total of $2 billion to the investment program. Many more American entities are testing the waters. Security Pacific Bank, JMB Realty and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Lincoln Properties, Tishman West Management and Beyer, Blinder, Belle were among 50 American companies and agencies to send representatives to Cannes in March for the first international real estate trade fair. The conference, which drew 800 participants and exhibitors, was billed as a forum for trading information and making contacts.
''Participation exceeded our expectations,'' said Barney Benard, president of International Exhibition Organization, the event's organizer. ''After being sort of late to pick up on what is going on overseas, more Americans are taking the initative.''
Some American entreprenuers seem to be taking their cue from Olympia & York, a Canadian company with large holdings in the United States, which is building a $5 billion, 12 million-square-foot mixed-use project in London known as Canary Wharf.
But as enticing as Europe now appears, some economists and real estate professionals familiar with the scene there are offering some sobering observations on the barriers that American entrepreneurs face in pursuing European ventures.
''There is little question that Europe holds the potential of being the economic story of the 1990's,'' said Karl Casagrande, an executive vice president of Deutsche Bank Capital Corporation in charge of real estate investments. ''And obviously real estate development and investment are going to be significant parts of any change.''
''But I think the problem is that many foreigners, particularly American developers, see Europe after 1992 as being some sort of free-for-all in which all things are possible,'' he continued, referring to the date the European Economic Community plans to lift trade and commercial barriers. ''Yes, there will be opportunities, but there are also certain aspects of the real estate business in Europe that will probably not change for a long, long time - if ever.''
AMONG the barriers, some observers see a paucity of developable sites in major cities, zoning rules that severly limit new construction and a reluctance among both individuals and institutions to sell off their real estate holdings. In addition, rising expectations for Europe's economic future have pumped up prices of commercial properties.
Yet despite this tempered outlook for speculative real estate ventures, many, including Mr. Casagrande believe that Americans and other foreigners can and will benefit from the economic and political integration of Western Europe and from the new economic freedoms taking hold in the East.
Joint venturing has been the path that most American interests have followed to Europe. But others have gone overseas as the construction companies, architects or space planners for American companies building or taking space in Europe.
And many observers see opportunities in the future for American companies or individuals with expertise in fast-track construction technology.
''The landscape is changing so fast that every day brings a whole new backdrop against which decisions are made,'' said Anthony P. D. Edgley, managing director of Jones Lang Wootton's investment and corporate real estate services. ''So it is still too early to make a sensible prognosis for what sorts of opportunities will exist, and for whom.
''But because the new trade rules will involve special enterprise zones, there will be new growth regions. When that happens there is going to be a premium on the skills needed for the sort of fast track construction methods that Americans employ as a matter of course, but which do not exist in Europe.''
It was, in the main, its experience with high-rise construction that provided Tishman Speyer Properties with the opportunity to join Citibank and Kajima Corporation in the Frankfurt office tower project. The 920,000-square-foot tower, designed by Helmut Jahn of Murphy/Jahn, the Chicago architectural firm, will be the tallest office building in Europe.
Daniele D. Bodini, the Italian-born president of American Continental Properties, believes his $120 million plan to redevelop the brewery in Rome would not have stood a chance without an Italian partner.
''As far as development and ownership in Europe are concerned,'' said Mr. Bodini, who acquired the vacant brewery in 1985 when Italy's economy was in a slump, ''America by comparison is very open. In Italy you must have the right contacts - professional, financial and political.''
Even with those contacts it took nearly five years for the project to work its way through the approval process. It is not unusual, Mr. Bodini said, for some projects to be on hold for 10 or 20 years.
The brewery, in the heart of Rome's financial district, will have 80,000 square feet of office space, 60,000 square feet of retail space and 90 apartments. Mr. Bodini hopes to start construction later this year and finish the project in three years.
Some American companies have used their work for other American companies as their springboards into the development arena overseas.
Swanke Hayden Connell went to London in the early 80's as the architect and design consultant to Chemical Bank, Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrett and Shearson American Express when those companies were expanding overseas with the internationalization of the financial markets.
''WE had done work for these companies before,'' said Richard S. Hayden, a partner in the firm who now travels regularly to its London office, where it has 60 employees. ''When they decided to expand operations in London they had us do the work because we were familiar with their needs and how their operations worked. Hiring local designers and architects there would have been like starting from square one.''
Swanke Hayden Connell decided to open its London office after it won a design competition there and had been invited to submit other designs.
''We hit a building boom there,'' said Mr. Hayden. ''And at the same time development was slowing down at home. With economic unity approaching, it became clear that we should pursue opportunities in London and the rest of Europe.''
Mr. Hayden said his firm has found, as other American firms have, that familiarity with large-scale design has given it an edge.
''The projects now being built are a big jump for the local designers,'' he said. ''What we consider to be state of the art office design takes a certain discipline that you just do not see on a large scale overseas.''
While its largest volume of work is in London or its outskirts, Swanke Hayden Connell also has design assignments in France, Turkey and Germany.
One of its largest and most visible assignments is a new office development at 100 Old Broad Street in the Financial District, which recently won local planning approval.
The eight-story building, a joint venture of Wates City and Friends Provident Life, both of London, will hold 300,000 square feet of space. The new structure will have 40,000-square-foot floors, unusually large for London office buildings.
Involvement by American real estate professionals will probably not be limited to development and design work.
Cushman & Wakefield, an national commercial real estate brokerage and consulting company, announced a plan to form a joint venture with Healey & Baker, a London-based real estate concern with offices throughout the United Kingdom and Europe.
Stephen F. Anfang, for example, is a Manhattan-based investor who is currently negotiating to buy an interest in an real estate brokering company in London. Mr. Anfang is convinced that, despite the worldwide reach of international brokerage concerns like Jones Lang Wootton and Richard Ellis, there is room for expansion in the service end of the industry.
''I have spent time and money trying to find something that made sense,'' said Mr. Anfang. ''From what I have seen, the best opportunities are at the service end. We see potential clients in American companies that will be going abroad and for London-based companies that need real estate consultants in this country.''

LENGTH: 1305 words

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Amenities No Longer Just a Seductive Option

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
''WE don't try to make money on amenities,'' said Eric Eicher, president of Sabal Park, a big office campus outside Tampa, Florida, ''but in the long run, they pay for themselves.''
The developer, a past president of the National Association of Industrial and Office Parks, has become an expert on one of the fastest-growing sidelines of office development, the provision of special services, from the ubiquitous day care center to the exotic private limousine service.
Those services help to retain tenants and a happy work force while giving a sense of distinction in a market where one suburban office building often looks much like the next one.
When the first modern office towers were being built in American cities, tenants did not expect much from their landlords beyond elevator operators and a night watchman. Everything else employers and their employees needed - newsstands, coffee shops, transportation, banks and housing - were either just around the corner or nearby. 
But when American offices started moving out to the suburbs where more and more of their workers lived, developers and the companies that rented space from them found that more than just the scenery was different.
Particularly after the suburbs became crowded with office parks, the competition for an able - and stable - workforce awakened employers to the need to provide services and amenities they had taken for granted in the city, and to house these services right in the office park, next to the workplace.
Along with the parking lot and the cafeteria, employers have come to expect developers to provide day-care centers, health clubs, jogging trails, tennis courts, shuttle buses and even training centers.
Beset by high suburban housing costs, some employers have even moved the care of employees beyond the office building by starting programs to help them buy housing within a reasonable commuting distance of work.
These services and conveniences now have become part of the office culture. They cost money, but builders justify the costs as a kind of loss leader that is made up for in greater space rentals.
For in a post-industrial service economy where one glass box with an artificial pond in front looks much like the next one, and where one office job closely resembles another, both builders and employers are finding that a few extra amenities help distinguish their enterprises from the competitions'.
''It's true that amenities have costs associated with them, but so do high employee turnover rates or an inability to attract the people you need,'' said Mr. Eicher, whose Sabal Park is a 1,000-acre office campus.
The 3 million-square-foot Sabal complex includes amenities that have become almost standard in many big suburban complexes - tennis courts, a day care center, meeting rooms, a three-mile outdoor jogging path, a helicopter landing pad and more.
But Mr. Eicher also lured branches of the Hillsboro County Community College and the Irwin Technical High School to his complex, which offer on-site training in computers, accounting, management and other office skills for his tenants.
''They don't have to set up their own training program this way,'' Mr. Eicher said of his tenants, which include Coca-Cola, Boise Cascade and Snap-On Tools.
''If they want an employee to be able to use d-Base or Lotus 1-2-3, they don't have to assign someone to do the training, they can just send him to school for a while, almost right next door.''
Some companies, in fact, offer their employees amenities that reach even farther beyond the daily workplace.
The high cost of living within sensible commuting distance of the office has prompted several concerns to include help with employee housing, either by offering below-market mortgages, like the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark, or by supporting nonprofit housing development programs, as the the Giant Food Corporation of suburban Washington does, to expand the supply of housing for its employees.
Sill other companies are creating equity-sharing housing programs with employees, with the company paying a part of the price, and owning a share of the worker's house, as the Regional Health Maintenance Organization of Los Angeles does.
In all cases, the reach of corporate services beyond the office involves keeping workers loyal and on the job.
''There are many companies that would like tomove to certain areas but they know they couldn't find the workers,'' Mr. Eicher said. ''With 5 percent unemployment, you can move out to some parts of Connecticut and run an ad for 500 employees, and nobody shows up.''
One of the most unusual amenities to be added to an office complex is the public ampitheater, built into the side of a hill, that Childress/Klein Properties included in the Galleria, a highly successful office campus in Atlanta.
The developers turn the outdoor stage over to local musicians, who serenade picknicking employees at lunch time, and also make the theater available to community groups after working hours.
No element of the growth in corporate concern for the care and convenience of office workers has received more interest than office day-care centers, which seem to have become nearly as universal as potted palms in the lobby. ''Mr. or Mrs. Executive may not care as much about day care as the staff who works for them,'' said Melanie Circle, a vice president of Galbreath-Huff Companies, an office park developer in the Columbus, Ohio, area.
''BUT the office workers have come to expect that service and the executive may start having trouble getting people to work every morning if parents feel their kids aren't being property cared for.'' Galbreath-Huff has just completed the 1.1 million-square-foot Community Corporate Center, located just outside the northernmost stretch of the I-270 beltway.
Three years ago, Ms. Circle said, the hot item on the amenities list was the multistory atrium lobby with sunken seating spaces. Among other things, the big lobbies have become popular for parties, and civic groups like to use them for meetings on weekends.
Nowadays, transportation in the suburbs being what it is, Community Corporate Center has added an enormous Lincoln limousine with a driver at the tenant's beck and call, available 24 hours a day for $20 per hour - less than the cost of renting a common cab by the hour.
''They love to pick their clients up at the airport in it,'' she said.
But the year's most popular amenity, at least with the management class, is underground, controlled access parking, she said. Being able to park under cover and near the elevators, especially in bad weather, is an executive thrill.
''You can't build enough underground parking,'' Ms. Circle said.
OFFICE amenities have become so widespread in suburbia that they have begun to spread back to the city. The new $150 million Federal office building being built in downtown Chicago by Stein & Company, a local develpment and management firm, not only will have a health club and a employee medical services office, but it will also have the first downtown day-care center.
To get the day-care center, the developer had to win the repeal of a Chicago law prohibiting such child-care facilities within 4,000 feet of a licensed liquor outlet, which had effectively kept day-care centers out of the hotel- and restaurant-rich business district.
In addition, Illinois law reqires day-care-center entrances to be at grade level, usually the most valuable retail space in an urban setting, and to offer an outdoors playing area.
Stein & Compay solved this problem of child care by putting the children's center in a low-rise annex and the playground on a second-floor roof.
''We never expected the politics of office development to be so interesting,'' said Mark Appell, the project manager.

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: HONOLULU;
Debts Spur Land Auction

BYLINE: By FRANK BRIDGEWATER

 BODY:
THE Hamakua Sugar Company, one of Hawaii's biggest sugar companies, is hoping to sell 8,000 acres - almost all of it zoned for agriculture - to help pay off its debts. It will begin by offering 5,000 acres at two auctions here, on June 28 and Aug. 16, at which it expects to raise $65 million.
Hamakua was formed by consolidating seven smaller companies that date to the 1870's and 80's. Francis S. Morgan bought the company in 1984 from Theo. H. Davies & Company, where he was a vice president, and has been struggling to make it a success. He has modernized the sugar operations and diversified by developing a small retail cane syrup business and a beef operation that does everything from raising the cattle to slaughtering and packaging the meat. In addition, there have been layoffs and salary cuts, but the company is still being squeezed, in particular by what Mr. Morgan calls ''killer'' interest bills. 
He will use proceeds of the land sales to pay part of Hamakua's debt of about $98 million, $10 million of which is an emergency loan it got in 1988 from the Hawaii Department of Agriculture. Although Mr. Morgan, 71 years old, has been discussing land sales for some time, he was spurred on by two consecutive poor growing seasons. Bad weather, mostly heavy rains, and haze from the Kilauea volcano, resulted in low-quality crops.
The land being offered is primarily at the ends of the plantation. Mr. Morgan believes he will end up with a more economical plantation of about 23,000 acres on the island of Hawaii, which will continue to be the state's second-largest sugar plantation, behind Alexander & Baldwin, with nearly35,000 acres on Maui.
In the two sealed-bid auctions, Hamakua will sell 28 properties. The June offering is for smaller parcels at which bids are expected to be between $30,000 and $675,000, although Mr. Morgan said that 12 properties will be sold regardless of what the bids are.
The August offering will require minimum bids of $250,000 to $30 million. The properties range from two-acre homestead lots to a 2,640-acre parcel overlooking the Waipio Valley, with views of the Hiilawe Waterfall.
Also up for sale is the Kukuihaele plantation home, a turn-of-the-century 6,000-square-foot home built for the manager of the old Pacific Sugar Mill on a 14-acre site. It is priced at $2.5 million.
Among other parcels offered are ones suitable for golf courses or other tourist-related developments.

HEADLINE: VIEWS OF SPORT;
Winfield vs. the Yankees: A Case of Life and Law

BYLINE: By NORMAN DORSEN; Norman Dorsen is Stokes Professor of Law at New York University, and president of the American Civil Liberties Union. He is also a Mets fan.

 BODY:
Should it matter to us where a talented and rich and aging baseball player plies his trade? Should it matter whether a rich and controversial owner is leveling with the public when he says he opposed the player's trade despite a decade of rancorous disputes with that player? Should it matter whether the owner's aide insulted the player or merely showed insensitivity typical of employers who are ditching a once-valued employee?
The answer, apparently, is yes, at least for a large number of baseball fans. But why?
Race does not appear to be involved in this matter, although one cannot be sure that the Yankees would have treated an aging Don Mattingly or Dave Righetti the way they treated Dave Winfield. The principal owner, George Steinbrenner, conceded: ''It was handled about as poorly as we could handle it. It should have been handled differently.'' Amen. 
Does the controversy therefore reduce to the usual bottom line of what is best for the clubs - and players -involved? On a baseball level, maybe it does. The Yankees will be wondering whether Mike Witt will be the savior of an unsavory season. And the Angels, who are backing their judgment with big bucks, will be wondering whether Winfield has run out of gas. (He surely has charisma even if he isn't Reggie).
Even so, baseball isn't the whole story here. There was a hint of this in something Winfield said last Tuesday: ''In one sense I'm representing the rest of the players.'' There it is: Union solidarity. Keep the bosses in line. Another example of baseball players showing muscle after all those years as peons under the reserve clause.
Winfield also said, ''At this stage of my career I'm not going to let them walk all over me.''
These are the words of a proud man. The same man who didn't hesitate to stand up to Steinbrenner in the past and exact what he thought was due to him or to the David M. Winfield Foundation. A man who values dignity as well as dollars. A man like Curt Flood and Andy Messersmith, the sort who tries to change the world a little.
This is not merely a baseball phenomenon. History reveals many stiff-necked people who have provoked change. Rebellious auto workers chained themselves to their machines in the 1930's to force recognition of their union. And Rosa Parks, by refusing to sit in the back of the bus, helped ignite a movement that has altered race relations throughout the United States.
Baseball is not an isolated pursuit, but part of and a reflection of currents in the general society. When ballplayers say no, they continue a long tradition in which strong men and women refuse to allow others to rule their lives. The demands of workers for economic security, or racial or sexual equality, have always been personified by unyielding personalities.
We know that Winfield has long been unhappy with his treatment by Steinbrenner and the Yankee organization. What a heavenly result to be paid extra, even if by the Angels, to do what he may have wanted to do anyway: leave New York. And the Yankees had to pay him the full $100,000 in potential bonuses under his 1990 contract.
What about the law? By settling the case, and not going to arbitration, did Winfield and the Yankees cheat the public from a big decision, the sort that Flood and Messersmith provoked? Not likely.
The legal point at issue is narrow, whether baseball's basic labor agreement took precedence over Winfield's personal contract with the Yankees.
Under the basic agreement, only players with 10 years of major league experience and 5 years with the same team have the right to refuse a trade. We can assume that few of these veterans have a contract like Winfield's, which specifies teams to which he would accept a trade. While an arbitrator's decision in favor of the basic agreement or Winfield's contract would have clarified the legal situation, it would have affected only a small group of players.
So in the end it was life, not law, that decided Dave Winfield vs. the Yankees.

HEADLINE: Biotechnology Benefits From Glasnost

BYLINE: By CAROL STRICKLAND

 BODY:
AFTER communicating by satellite for 18 months, two high school students - one on Long Island and the other in Moscow - are about to realize their dream of establishing a center for biotechnology education in Moscow.
The goal of the New York State-Moscow School Telecommunications Project linking 13 schools in Moscow with high schools in New York was to foster cultural understanding and promote joint programs geared to solving problems shared by both countries.
Having an actual project as a focal point was crucial to the success of the program, according to David Egan, chairman of the Department of Social Studies at Cold Spring Harbor High School. Cold Spring is one of the two participating schools on Long Island; the other is Northport.
The students communicated about matters more important than, say, ''What music do you like?'' 
''That wears thin pretty fast,'' Dr. Egan said. ''Their friendships were also tested and strengthened by solving tough problems together.''
 
Electronic Pen Pals
The electronic pen pals and project partners - Steven Malloy, 17 years old, of Cold Spring Harbor and Nikita Skryabin, 15, of Moscow School No. 4 - had many problems to solve on their way to establishing a molecular biology ''exploratorium'' patterned after Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory's DNA Learning Center.
''I've always been extremely interested in both biotechnology and the Soviet Union,'' said Steven in describing the origin of his idea for the project. ''I was reluctant to give up either interest, and when people advised me to focus on one field, I revolted and said, 'No, I'll do both.' ''
Having worked as an intern for two summers at the DNA Learning Center, the only institution devoted entirely to biotechnology education, Steven was already familiar with the activities of a program like the one he envisioned.
In the five years since its inception, the Cold Spring Harbor center has educated 1,400 high school teachers and 5,800 students in recombinant-DNA technology. DNA, or deoxyribonucleic acid, is the basic hereditary material in chromosomes of all living organisms.
Steven soon discovered that his Soviet counterparts' level of gene literacy was much lower than in the States.
''There is not a lot of understanding of DNA in the U.S.S.R.,'' said Nikita, the son of three generations of Soviet biologists, on a visit to this country last December.
''The Soviet Union is particularly behind in this area,'' said Mark V. Bloom, assistant director of the Learning Center. ''It's logical for them to look to us for leadership, since the U.S. has played a pioneering role in genetic research.''
 
A Lag in Biological Sciences
Although Soviet science has produced breakthroughs in theoretical physics and mathematics, the biological sciences there have lagged far behind because of what David Micklos, director of the Learning Center, called ''a tragedy in the history of modern science.''
For about 30 years, until the mid-1960's, the Communist Party, under the influence of Trofim D. Lysenko, a plant breeder, officially approved the beliefs of the Frenchman Jean Baptiste Lamarck.
Lamarck (1744-1829) believed that traits acquired during one's lifetime could be inherited by offspring, a concept completely opposed to modern theories of heredity. Soviet geneticists who disputed this party doctrine were jailed or banished.
As a result, scientific investigation during the Stalin and Krushchev regimes was stifled. Although the ''green revolution'' of the 1950's and 60's produced ''miracle'' rice in the Far East and high-yielding strains of corn and wheat elsewhere in the world, plant and animal yields in the Soviet Union declined.
''Exactly at the critical period of the golden years in molecular biology,'' said Grigori Enikolopov, a visiting Russian scientist at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, ''we were kept from the mainstream and even from real science.''
The resulting loss of generations of geneticists, combined with a lack of information flow - Soviet scientists rarely attend international conferences and receive scientific journals a year late -are said to be chiefly accountable for the country's continued biotech backwardness.
 
What Everyone Said at First
Steven and Nikita were determined to remedy this deficiency in Soviet society, but initial reaction was skeptical.
''Everyone said, 'Nice idea, but are you really going to be able to do that?' '' Steve recalled. Even Dr. Egan believed originally that the project was too ambitious. ''It was very unlikely it could come to pass, but Steve just plugged away,'' he said.
Everyone involved in the project acknowledged the indispensable support of Nikita's father, Prof. Konstantin Skryabin, the influential director of the Engelhardt Institute of Molecular Biology.
Yet it was the Malloy youth who, in a series of April meetings in Moscow with high-level Soviet scientists and businessmen, hammered out the details of what will become the U.S.A.-U.S.S.R. Education Program for DNA and Biotechnology. Said Dr. Egan, who attended the negotiations: ''I tried not to take any leading role. My motive in this project is to have students realize they are more powerful and brighter than others give them credit for.''
 
Space in Institute Assured
Through Steven's efforts, a staff, a yearly budget of 30,000 rubles (the equivalent of $5,000) from the Soviet Ministry of Science and Technology and working space in the well-equipped, modern Shemyakin Institute in Moscow are now assured.
Evgeny Velikhov, Mikhail Gorbachev's personal science adviser, a Central Committee Member and vice president of the Academy of Sciences of the U.S.S.R., has sanctioned the proposal. In a letter to Dr. Bloom about the new center, he wrote:
''This would allow us to achieve a new level of education in the field of biology; it would open new opportunities to popularize this advanced direction among the widest circle of [the] community and to get rid of myths connected with DNA research.''
''One thing is clear,'' said Mr. Micklos. ''There is a level in the Soviet Government that has now come to think that educating young people about DNA is an important objective.''
Mr. Micklos and Dr. Bloom left for Moscow May 5 to spend 10 days consulting on how the Learning Center model may best be adapted to teach Soviet high school students.
This initiative represents as much of a departure for the Soviet system of education as, say, substituting a Big Mac for borscht. Soviet students are typically described as passive learners, being required to master rote memorization of facts more than problem-solving or critical thinking.
''Every Soviet school child has to learn exactly the same thing,'' said Mart Ustav, a visiting Estonian scientist who has three children attending Long Island schools. ''Here you have a more differentiated approach.''
 
'Kids Are Constantly Pushed'
Dr. Enikolopov, with two children in American schools, agreed.
''The most surprising thing about your system,'' he said, ''is that here kids are constantly pushed to do something on their own - to have an idea and try to implement it.''
His own children, he said, were at first ''shy, not believing in their own strength, compared to the kids here. But now they have more self-assurance and confidence in what they can do, which I attribute to the school system and the environment.''
Steven Malloy's self-reliance proved invaluable in overcoming obstacles presented by the Soviet system.
''I think the Russian word for 'deadline' is 'tomorrow,' '' he said. ''Soviets are very encouraging when you speak to them, but they're not action-oriented, and the work ethic is not so good yet.''
Everyone involved with the project attests to numerous frustrations caused by inefficiency, bureaucracy and the maddeningly slow pace of the Soviet mentality.
''Nothing goes smoothly when working with the Soviets,'' Dr. Egan said. ''You got about a week?'' he joked when a visitor asked him to specify the frustrations that he and Steven encountered.
Despite cultural differences and an ingrained aversion to risk-taking in the Soviet Union, the U.S.A.-U.S.S.R. Education Program for DNA and Biotechnology, patterned on the Long Island model, is scheduled to start instructing Moscow high school students this fall.
 
A Study in Contrasts
The hands-on, folksy, low-key approach of the Learning Center, which attempts to make science experimentation fun and exciting for students, will be in sharp contrast to the regimented, lecture-oriented Soviet system of pedagogy.
''We advocate letting young people get their hands dirty with the technology,'' said Mr. Micklos.
The fact that the Soviets are willing to learn from the theories and practice of former arch-enemies, and that such an international endeavor was conceived and promulgated by two high school students, reflects what Dr. Bloom termed ''glasnost, DNA- style.''
''Five years ago,'' Dr. Egan said, ''I would have said this was absolutely 100 percent impossible.''
One event that gave the American participants pause was the retention of a Cold Spring Harbor High School teacher's wife, a Soviet native, in Moscow when the American high school contingent left to return home.
''There are still remnants of the old closed society,'' Steve said of the incident, ''no matter how much you speak of glasnost.''
Mr. Ustav, a supporter of independence for the Baltic states and critic of the Soviet system, also cautioned about the transfer of technology to Moscow. ''How can you be certain it won't be used against you?'' he asked. ''I'm not optimistic about the Soviet economy in the future,'' Steven Malloy responded, ''but I don't think there will be a closure to western society. They can't turn back now.''

HEADLINE: Faded Glory of Syracuse

BYLINE: By MARY TAYLOR SIMETI; MARY TAYLOR SIMETI'S most recent book is ''Pomp and Sustenance: Twenty-Five Centuries of Sicilian Food''(Knopf).

 BODY:
ONE can never be sure how people will react to Syracuse, a city that appears hesitant, uncertain of its magnitude and its identity, belonging neither with the big Sicilian ports of Palermo, Catania and Messina nor with the smaller and sleepier provincial capitals like Agrigento and Enna. Some visitors to Syracuse are fascinated by the evocative atmosphere of faded glory in what was once the greatest and perhaps most beautiful of the Greek cities in the western Mediterranean. Others are put off by the ugliness of the new city, and by the decay and neglect that deface the old.
When I confided to Dr. Curcio, the vice director of the city's splendid new archeological museum, my doubts as to how to communicate my own enthusiasm for Syracuse without creating false expectations, she gave an answer that moved me: ''Only those whose eyes are veiled by history can understand Syracuse.'' In other, more prosaic words, it is only the awareness of what Syracuse has been (and of what, God and Sicilian politicians willing, it could become) that allows one to fully savor its present charms. 
The heart of Syracuse lies on Ortygia, a small island little more than a mile long and half again as wide, connected by bridge to the southeastern shore of Sicily and embraced by a large natural harbor and a wide and fertile plain. The advantages of such a site have attracted settlers since the beginning of the Stone Age and must have been readily obvious to the Greek colonists from Corinth who landed here in 733 B.C. and put the native Sicel population to flight.
Ideally situated for commerce and with a rich agriculture behind it, the colony thrived and expanded to the mainland, building bridges and causeways and extending its walls to incorporate each new neighborhood as it was settled, a first golden age of growth and power that culminated in an epic victory over Athens in 413 B.C. The passage of time has preserved the monuments of Ortygia from this period in an unusual fashion: the Fountain of Arethusa, a freshwater spring at the sea's edge, which the Greeks believed was connected to their homeland by an underground river, is still a favorite meeting place for the youth of Syracuse, who hang over the railings as they chat and throw bread (and, occasionally, garbage) to the ducks swimming among the papyrus. The process of history is most strikingly evident in the cathedral a few blocks away. Once past the graceful 18th-century Baroque facade, visitors find themselves inside the severe simplicity of an early Christian church, which, as closer inspection reveals, has evolved from the Temple of Athena, its peristyle filled in to form outer walls in which the Doric columns are still visible, and its inner walls, the former cella, pierced by arches. Subsequent transformations have done little to disturb the harmonious proportions of the ancient temple, the gifts of each age melding gracefuly with those of its predecessors.
Nature as well as man has worked to transform the monuments in the mainland neighborhoods of Akradina and Neapolis, which twice over, in classical times and after World War II, have seen Syracuse's residential expansion. Scattered throughout their curious mixture of archeological sites and apartment buildings are the Latomie, the quarries that provided first the stones to build Syracuse and then the space to guard its enemies: vines of ivy, capers and bougainvillea curtain the once barren walls, and fig and orange trees grow on the ground where the defeated and imprisoned Athenian soldiers once languished, in what are perhaps the most haunted and haunting sunken gardens in the world.
Syracuse in the fifth century B.C. was not just muscle. The courts of its rulers attracted poets like Pindar and Theocritus; Plato visited and complained of the vice and the overeating (Syracuse boasts the first cookbook and the first cooking school in the Western world, a tradition of good food that continues to the present), and Aeschylus is thought to have produced ''Prometheus Bound'' in the linear theater that was built on the mainland to his specifications.
This theater, still visible in the archeological park of Neapolis, is overshadowed by the neighboring and more spectacular semicircular theater that dates from the third century B.C. Here too successive rebuildings have created an enormously evocative site, which is still used for a biennial festival of classical drama. (This year Sophocles' ''Electra'' and ''The Persians'' by Aeschylus will be produced in Italian translation on alternate evenings from Tuesday to July 1.) It is an extraordinary experience to sit on these stones and watch darkness fall over the players and the full moon rise behind the backdrop of cyprus trees as an ancient tragedy comes to its inexorable close.
Syracuse fell to the Romans in 211 B.C. and lived quietly and happily on the outskirts of the empire for several centuries. It was an important center for early Christianity: St. Paul preached here, St. Lucy was born and martyred here and Syracuse's catacombs are among the most extensive in the world. Those that lead down from the gardens next to the ruined Church of San Giovanni are open to visitors.
DESPITE centuries of Roman domination Syracuse never lost its ties to the Greek language and customs and eventually became an outpost of the Byzantine Empire and then its capital during the reign of the Emperor Constans II. But Constans came to an inglorious end here in 668 (murdered in the imperial baths when struck on the head with a soap dish), and from then on it was downhill all the way. The city fell to the Arabs in 878 and then to the Normans. The population shrank, and those who remained withdrew to Ortygia, leaving the mainland to the sheep and the weeds. A brief period of prosperity came under the Normans in the 12th century, and then again from the 14th to the 16th centuries. Many of Ortygia's buildings date from this latter period, among them the lovely palazzo that houses the Bellomo Museum, where the newly restored Antonello da Messina ''Annunciation,'' Caravaggio's ''Burial of St. Lucy'' and a handsome collection of Sicilian decorative arts are on display.
Real wealth and power never returned, however. Even the wave of rebuilding after the 1693 earthquake, which created Noto and the other magnificent new Baroque cities to the south, only lapped at Ortygia's shores, redesigning in splendid fashion Piazza del Duomo and revamping the aristocratic palazzos with pillared courtyards that line the Via delle Maestranze. And prosperity, when in the 20th century it finally did arrive, almost proved to be Syracuse's undoing. The generalized improvement in economic conditions that accompanied Italy's postwar boom allowed the inhabitants of Syracuse to escape from the tiny and decaying medieval houses of Ortygia, one and two-room apartments with no heating, no sanitation and very little structural stability. In a wave of speculation, new apartment buildings, totally characterless but safe and comfortable, sprang up around the ruins of the temples and the theaters of Neapolis, Akradina and other classical neighborhoods of mainland Syracuse. At the same time the rent-control board declared Ortygia a ''decayed area,'' its rents stabilized at the same levels as the slum areas of the big cities to the north.
Although Italy neglects much of its cultural and artistic heritage, it must be said that the heritage to be cared for is vast. In Syracuse a beginning has been made. The most tangible evidence is that, thanks to the tireless battling of Syracuse's Superintendent of Antiquities, Giuseppe Voza, and after more than 20 years of intermittent planning and building, in January 1988 the new Paolo Orsi Archeological Museum was opened. The huge and splendid collection, which was once on partial display in Piazza Duomo, can be viewed in modern quarters expressly built for it in the gardens of Villa Landolina in Akradina.
The museum is still a work in progress: the upper floor with the Hellenistic and Roman collection is not yet ready, and the English translations of labels and other educational materials have not yet been installed, although they should be in place by the end of the year.
The building is vaguely triangular in floor plan, composed of hexagonal modules radiating from a center pavilion, which houses a general introductory display. The peripheral area is divided into three sections: the first deals with the development of eastern Sicily from the geological formation of the area until the arrival of the Greeks, the second with the establishment of the Greek colonies and the last with the period of Syracuse's expansion into the hinterland in the seventh and sixth centuries B.C. Temporal and geographical origins have been severely respected, in order not only to give the most possible information about the context of each piece but also to demonstrate the interconnections and reciprocal influences between the different local cultures and with those, such as the Mycenean, which came from overseas.
The single pieces on display - a Bronze Age portal that once blocked the entrance to a tomb carved in a cliff, with a haunting spiral design thought to be a schematized representation of the act of sexual intercourse; pre-Greek vases of unbelievable grace and elegance; an archaic terra cotta Demeter enthroned; a limestone statue of the Great Mother nursing twins - are so eloquent that they will speak for themselves to those who only want a rapid visit. Non-Italian speakers who wish to take full advantage of what the museum offers should apply to the nearby Provincial Tourist Office, which has a handsome free booklet on the museum, with a bilingual English and Italian text, and can on advance notice arrange for an English-speaking guide.
Things are looking up in Ortygia, too. In 1976 the Sicilian Regional Government passed legislation to protect the historical centers of its cities from speculation, and under the aegis of a commission of archeologists, art historians, architects and urban planners, a zoning plan for Ortygia has been drawn up, which maps out the city room by room and determines which buildings must be demolished and the criteria by which the rest can be restructured. This plan is in the final stages of approval, although problems remain: it is still necessary to decide what sort of development is possible in an area characterized by very small architectural units (hypotheses include the establishment of a university city and the creation of a port specially equipped for tourism) and to find political safeguards against the illegal overnight building that has disfigured so much of Italy.
Most encouraging of all, I found, is the passion for their work and their city that seemed to characterize many of the Syracusans that I talked to, from the chefs like Giovanni Guarneri or Egidio Maiorca, who have inherited Syracuse's ancient culinary tradition, to Dr. Curcio at the museum, who glows when she talks about what the museum is trying to do, or Gigliola Nocera, a young environmental activist, who after having dinner with us stayed up all night working with a lawyer to get a court order to block some illegal building in Ortygia. If the powers that be will stand behind people like this, there is hope that Syracuse can arouse once more the universal admiration bestowed upon her by the ancients.
 
Viewing the revival of a once-proud outpost
 
Where to Stay
Syracuse once had a wealth of beautiful hotels, all of which are now abandoned, bankrupt or in a state of decline. What remains are modern hotels in the new part of the city.
Jolly Hotel, Corso Gelone; telephone, from the United States: 011-39-931-64744. Room for two with bath: $150 (figured at the rate of 1,164 lire to $1). First-class hotel with recently renovated rooms; on the noisy main shopping street.
 
Park Hotel, 80 Via Filisto; 011-39-931-32644. Room for two with shower or bath: $90. Comfortable, recently redecorated second-class hotel with pool and tennis courts. On the outskirts of the city but well connected by bus to the center.
Hotel Bellavista, 4 Via Diodoro Siculo; 011-39-931-36912. Room for two with shower: $58; breakfast: $7.75. Small family-run hotel in picturesque location, easily accessible by bus.
 
Where to Eat
Syracuse has many restaurants, trattorias and pizzerias. The cooking is based mainly on fish, which tends to be expensive, and the bill will soar for lobster or giant shrimp.
Ristorante Don Camillo, 100 Via delle Maestranze 100; telephone, dialed locally, 67133; closed Mondays. Reservations advisable in the evening. An average meal with wine: $30 to $35 a person. A pleasant restaurant with an imaginative menu.
La Foglia, 29 Via Capodieci; 461569; closed Tuesdays. An average meal: $21 to $30. A good place to find the vegetables that Sicily is famous for. The food relies heavily on Sicilian tradition and is attractively served.
Ristorante Pizzeria Al Delfino, Riva Porto Lachio (Sbarcadero S. Lucia); 68229; closed Mondays. An average three-course meal: $17 to $25; a pizza and a beer: $4.25 to $9.50. It was a relief to track down Egidio Maiorca, who used to sell some of the best pizzas in Sicily at his place in Piazza Archimede. Pizza available in the evening only (which is true almost everywhere in Sicily); at noon Egidio serves pasta and fish or meat and if asked will produce typical Sicilian pasta dishes.
Trattoria Il Cenacolo, 9/10 Via del Consiglio Reginale; 65099; closed Wednesdays. An average three-course meal: $17 to $22; pizza and beer or wine: $4.25 to $9.50. A simple but sympathetic trattoria in a pretty court in Ortygia. As you go by, don't miss, farther down the street at No. 13, the lovely medieval arched doorway with St. George and his dragon carved on the keystone.
 
What to Buy
Syracuse is not particularly rich in handicrafts: the most common are small sheets of papyrus made from the plants that grow along the Ciane River and painted or printed with Greek or Egyptian motifs. I have been told that the best choice can be found at the Centro di Papiro next to the entrance to the Archeological Museum. My preferences are gastronomical.
All the typical sweets of eastern Sicily are on display at the Pasticceria L. Marciante (39 Via della Maestranze; 67303; closed Mondays), from cubbaita (sesame brittle of Arab origin) to fig-filled buccellati, plus wonderful works of marzipan. Be sure to step into the room to the right to see the Greek temple and Noah's Ark.
On 24-hour notice and for about $4.50, the Panificio Bianca (42 Via Roma; 65805; closed Sundays and Wednesday afternoons) will bake you a ruota di pane, an intricately woven and decorative wheel of bread two feet in diameter.
 
What to Read
I am very fond of the affectionate if slightly out-of-date descriptions of Syracuse in ''The Travellers' Guide to Sicily'' by Christopher Kininmonth (Jonathan Cape, 1965). The new Blue Guide is good for factual and recent information. Part of ''The Mask of Apollo'' by Mary Renault takes place in fifth century B.C. Syracuse and brings the stones to life, as does, in a more scholarly way, Thucydides' ''Peloponnesian Wars.''
 
Note of Caution
Syracuse is no longer a place devoid of crime. There is a great deal of purse snatching, and, as in other big cities, visitors should leave documents and valuables in their hotels and rely on pockets rather than bags.
 
Information
The Provincial Tourist Agency (Azienda Provinciale Turismo) has two information offices: one at 45 Via S. Sebastiano (67710) in front of the Church of San Giovanni, and the other at the entrance to the archeological park, Largo Teatro Greco (60510). They can, with a little prodding to overcome bureaucratic indolence, supply visitors with a booklet in English on the museum, with information on theater tickets, museum hours and the many sights in Syracuse and the outlying area. They can also arrange for English-speaking guides, preferably on advance notice. M. T. S.

HEADLINE: Focus: California;
Replacing S & L's as Financing Sources

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN SHARP

 BODY:
IRA C. NORRIS, a builder of affordable housing in Southern California, has been in business since 1977 and has never dealt with a savings and loan institution. Instead, his company, Inco Homes, based here, has taken the untraditional route of getting construction loans solely from banks.
Now, with the nation's savings and loan industry in deep trouble, he considers the financing he has done for the last 13 years more a matter of luck than shrewd foresight.
''I'm not brilliant,'' he said. ''I just don't do business with S. & L.'s.'' 
Dozens of California builders have been either lucky or shrewd in avoiding the credit crunch that has squeezed others throughout the country in the last nine months as Federal law has tightened savings-and-loan lending practices. Some have either increased their reliance on banks and mortgage lenders or discovered new sources of capital, such as pension funds and insurers.
''California isn't being hurt as much as other parts of the country,'' said Richard W. Nelson, vice president and chief economist for the the Federal Home Bank of San Francisco, which oversees thrifts in California, Arizona and Nevada. Mr. Nelson added that it is too early to gather statistics on the impact of the harder line taken by savings and loan associations.
Historically, savings and loans and banks have provided 95 percent of the financing for commercial and residential projects. In California, they have provided as much as 100 percent of start-up costs and have lent the bulk of the building funds.
This generous and long-standing practice changed drastically in August, when Congress passed the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act, known as Firrea, which severely limited savings-and-loan lending practices.
The law basically prohibits equity investments by thrifts in real estate projects, said Tom Kelley, a partner in the Irvine, Calif., office of Arthur Andersen & Company, the Big 8 accounting firm.
Another key provision reduced to 15 percent the amount of its core capital that a thrift can lend to any one borrower. This was meant to spread risks so that one thrift does not rely so heavily on the fortunes of one builder. But the effect has been that builders must seek more than one lender for a project. ''Everyone is scrambling for debt money,'' said Mr. Kelley. Smaller developers are scrambling the farthest, say builders. In February, Steve Hopkins of the Hopkins Development Company in Newport Beach was approached by four other developers, whose smaller projects had been canceled because of a lack of financing, he said. Each asked Mr. Hopkins if he would participate, but he refused. ''It's chilling to see what's happening,'' said Mr. Hopkins.
Indeed, many sources of capital no longer exist. Large lenders such as Imperial Savings in San Diego have been seized by Federal regulators. Others, such as Santa Barbara Savings & Loan, were prohibited from lending months before they were seized.
Compounding the problem is an advisory letter the Comptroller of the Currency sent out in February to national banks warning them to carefully control the amount and type of real estate lending. That further shrank the available pool of capital nationwide. Then, this month, Federal Reserve officials began urging banks not to restrict lending to borrowers they considered sound.
Despite the confusion, most California developers have not stopped building. The state's banks are filling part of the gap, according to Bob Skinkle, an economist with Wells Fargo Bank, based in San Francisco. At the end of the first quarter, real estate lending at California banks had jumped 28 percent from 1989 levels.
Some developers have been wooing other capital sources for years. In 1987, Warmington Homes in Costa Mesa, a builder of single-family homes, obtained equity participations from insurers To spread the builder's sources farther, Skip Beck, vice president of finance, said he has been talking with Japanese lenders, among them Mitsui Manufacturers Bank in Los Angeles and Mitsubishi Corporation's trust division.
''It's not going to be quick and easy introducing the Japanese to developing in California,'' said Mr. Beck. ''But we need to explore the possibility.''
Hopkins Development has made an end run around lenders by successfully forging an equity partnership with a pension fund. After having difficulty getting a loan from its long-time primary lender, a thrift, Mr. Hopkins started searching for another master partner. In 1987, he found the Massachusetts State Retirement System, which has bought a 50 percent stake in the Newport Beach development company.
''If it weren't for that, I'd be in the same boat as a lot of other developers,'' he said.
SOME experts think Firrea will restructure the nation's financial markets by slowly killing thrifts not only as a source of loans for developers, but also for home buyers. In a sample survey of its members, the California Association of Realtors found that 60 percent of the state's newly originated first mortgages to home buyers stemmed from thrifts as recently as 1987. Last year, that number dropped to 40 percent.
''Clearly, the trend is away from thrifts,'' said Leslie Appleton-Young, vice president of research and economics at the association.
Meanwhile, mortgage bankers have increased their share of first mortgages to account for 44 percent of California home loans to home buyers, compared to 30 percent in 1984. During the same period, the portion of bank mortgage loans doubled to account for 11 percent last year.
The slowdown in thrift lending follows the cooling of California's real estate market. The average number of unsold new houses has more than doubled in the last half of 1989, said Ms. Appleton-Young. ''The transactions sold in the first part of last year were in a very, very hot market,'' she said. ''Now it's a much more normal market.''
Climbing interest rates have also helped to slow the state's real estate market, said Gary Schlossberg, senior economist at Wells Fargo Bank. In January, the average fixed mortgage rate was 9.9 percent; by April it had climbed to 10.25 percent.
All these factors have prompted analysts to project further slowdowns in California residential and commerical construction this year. Ben Bartolotto, research director of the Construction Industry Research Board, a private organization based in Burbank, Calif., that monitors building permits in the state, forecasts a 12 percent drop in single-family housing this year, a 4 percent dip in multifamily housing and a 9 percent decrease in nonresidential building.
''We've been expecting a slowdown,'' said Mr. Bartolotto. ''But whether it has to do with changes in thrift laws - well, I suspect not.''
A building slowdown, along with tighter lending controls, makes for a healthy correction, according to Richard Peiser, professor of urban regional planning at University of Southern California in Los Angeles. ''I see this as a short-term correction of a market that has been overheated by rapid price increases in the last few years,'' he said.
Small developers may have trouble surviving the days of scarce credit, but Mr. Peiser sees the situation adjusting by 1992. ''There will be opportunities for institutions and investors who are willing to take the equity risks formerly taken by S. & L.'s,'' he said.

LENGTH: 1056 words

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION: SANTA BARBARA, CALIF.;
After 22 Years, a Downtown Mall To Fit the City's Low-Key Image

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN SHARP

 BODY:
IN just three months, this city's first downtown mall - the $150 million, 463,000-square-foot Paseo Nuevo, a joint private-municipal venture - is scheduled to open with The Broadway and Nordstrom department stores as its anchors in a total of 304,000 square feet.
So far, no tenants have yet signed for the mall's 60 shops and food outlets in 135,000 square feet, its 14,000 square feet of office space and its 10,000 square feet for an art gallery and a 200-seat theater.
But John H. Reininga Jr., chairman of the Reininga Corporation of San Francisco, the co-developer of the project with the Santa Barbara City Redevelopment Agency, said that he expects to have the mall 60 percent leased when it has its ''grand opening'' in November. The department stores alone will be open for business on Aug. 17. Major financing is being provided by JMB Realty of Chicago, which is also handling the leasing. 
The Spanish-style complex on State Street in the heart of the retail district is spread over two blocks seven blocks east of Route 101, which snakes along California's coast. Its realization is the culmination of a 22-year effort to draw local shoppers, who in 1988 spent about $100 million in retail purchases outside Santa Barbara County, into this city's stores.
The mall will include a system of walkways, interior courtyards, plazas, and fountains. At one corner will sit Nordstrom's 169,000 square-foot-store. At the opposite end will sit The Broadway's 135,000-square-foot-store. Laid out between them is 135,000 square-feet of retail space. Mr. Reininga said he would like to see 20 percent of that space occupied by local tenants, although many merchants have said they cannot afford the rent.
The mall's architect, John Field, has been working with the city's Architectural Review Board to maintain standards set in 1925. The Landmarks Committee also had to approve every structural design to insure that the mall retains the city's Spanish lines. Red-tiled roofs, white stucco walls, palm trees and hand-painted signs are regulated characteristics of this tourist town.
''THE degree and intensity with which Santa Barbara reviews a project's architecture cannot be found in any other part of the country,'' said Prof. David Gebhard, an architectural historian who teaches at the University of California at Santa Barbara. The only other cities in the nation with architectural review boards are Nantucket, Mass., and Santa Fe, N. M., said Professor Gebhard.
Eight other review boards and committees also had to sign off on various phases of development. Said Mr. Reininga: ''When you're developing in a slow-growth enviornment in a town as sensitive as Santa Barbara, it becomes a real challenge.''
For its part, the city has so far spent a total of $42 million on the project, including $411,000 for an archeological dig to make sure no major historical site lay beneath the mall. The excavation unearthed some 19th century medicine bottles and Chinese privies; the development proceeded.
To make room for the mall, the city spent $16.5 million purchasing seven acres of existing retail space; $2 million on relocating 35 small shops and businesses that were on that land and $13 million on two garages with 1,115 parking spaces.
IN return for its investment, the city expects to realize up to $2 million in annual sales and property taxes and 20 percent of any rent increases once the mall is fully leased. After 75 years, the land will revert to the city.
Situated 125 miles up the coast from Los Angeles, this city of 80,000 residents with its predominantly Spanish-style, tile-roofed buildings, is snuggled between the San Ynez Mountains and the Pacific. Its households have the highest levels of discretionary spending power in the state, according to the Santa Barbara Chamber of Commerce.
The chamber said county households spent $24,000 on discretionary purchases last year, which was 25 percent more than the California average and 34 percent higher than the national average. Yet only three other large department stores - Sears Roebuck and Robinson's in La Cumbre Plaza three miles north of downtown and Gotschalk's in Santa Maria - serve the 343,000 residents of Santa Barbara County.
Part of the reason for the slow pace of retail rentals in Paseo Nuevo could be the rents. They range from $30 to $72 a square foot, depending on the tenant and the nature of the space, as opposed to about $16.50 for existing downtown space.
This discrepancy has caused downtown landlords to sit on existing empty space, rather than commit to 10-year leases that might not reflect values two years down the road. Because of construction gridlock, noise and confusion caused by the development of Paseo Nuevo over the last two years and extensive road improvement projects downtown, many shops have shut down.
This, said Mark Schniepp, who is a research economist at the University of California at Santa Barbara, has helped to create double the available commercial space of a decade ago. Now, said Steve Cushman, president of the local Chamber of Commerce, there is about a 30 percent retail vacancy rate downtown - ''with a lot of big buildings sitting empty.''
But a 3 million-square-foot cap on commercial construction over the next 20 years, plus an open-ended moratorium on water hookups because of severe drought conditions, enhances the value of all commercial buildings, said Mr. Schniepp.
The open-air Pasa Nuevo is the result of the creation in 1968 of the Santa Barbara City Redevelopment Agency, formed to revitalize the downtown area by attracting a major retail center.
In the last 20 years, there have been two unsuccessful efforts to stem the outflow of retail dollars. In the early 70's, a proposal for a 650,000-square-foot shopping center was rejected by the Planning Commission as ''too big, not Santa Barbara scale,'' said John Bridley, assistant community development director for the Redevelopment Agency.
He noted that State Street is lined mostly with one-story boutiques, specialty shops and cafes - in keeping with the city's low profile.
And in the late 70's, voters soundly defeated a city proposal to bring in a 70,000-square-foot free-standing department store. Finally, in 1986, it awarded Reininga the project after considering proposals from a total of 10 developers.

HEADLINE: California Developers Find New Financing Sources

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN SHARP

DATELINE: UPLAND, CALIF.

 BODY:
Ira C. Norris, a builder of affordable housing in Southern California, has been in business since 1977 and has never dealt with a savings and loan institution. Instead, his company, Inco Homes, based here, has taken the untraditional route of getting construction loans solely from banks.
Now, with the nation's savings and loan industry in deep trouble, he considers the financing he has done for the last 13 years more a matter of luck than shrewd foresight.

Indeed, many sources of capital no longer exist. Large lenders such as Imperial Savings in San Diego have been seized by Federal regulators. Others, such as Santa Barbara Savings & Loan, were prohibited from making any loans months before they were finally seized.
Compounding the problem is an advisory letter the Comptroller of the Currency sent out in February to national banks warning them to carefully control the amount and type of real estate lending. That further shrank the available pool of capital nationwide. Then, this month, Federal Reserve officials began urging banks not to restrict lending to borrowers they considered sound.
Despite the confusion, most California developers have not stopped building. The state's banks are filling part of the gap, according to Bob Skinkle, an economist with Wells Fargo Bank, based in San Francisco. At the end of the first quarter, real estate lending at California banks had jumped 28 percent from 1989 levels. ''That's quite a pick-up in activity,'' he said.
Some developers have been wooing other capital sources for years. In 1987, Warmington Homes in Costa Mesa, a builder of single-family homes, obtained equity participations from insurers To spread the builder's sources farther, Skip Beck, vice president of finance, said he has been talking with Japanese lenders, among them Mitsui Manufacturers Bank in Los Angeles and Mitsubishi Corporation's trust division. ''It's not going to be quick and easy introducing the Japanese to developing in California,'' said Mr. Beck. ''But we need to explore the possibility.''
Hopkins Development has made an end run around lenders by successfully forging an equity partnership with a pension fund. After having difficulty getting a loan from its long-time primary lender, a thrift, Mr. Hopkins started searching for another master partner. In 1987 he found the Massachusetts State Retirement System, which has bought a 50 percent stake in the Newport Beach development company.
''If it weren't for that, I'd be in the same boat as a lot of other developers,'' he said.
Some experts think Firrea will restructure the nation's financial markets by slowly killing thrifts not only as a source of loans for developers, but also for home buyers. In a sample survey of its members, the California Association of Realtors found that 60 percent of the state's newly originated first mortgages to home buyers stemmed from thrifts as recently as 1987. Last year, that number dropped to 40 percent.
''Clearly, the trend is away from thrifts,'' said Leslie Appleton-Young, vice president of research and economics at the association.
Meanwhile, mortgage bankers have increased their share of first mortgages to account for 44 percent of California home loans to home buyers, compared to 30 percent in 1984. During the same period, the portion of bank mortgage loans doubled to account for 11 percent last year.
The slowdown in thrift lending follows the cooling of the real estate market in California. The average number of unsold new houses has more than doubled from mid-1989 to year-end 1989, said Ms. Appleton-Young. ''The transactions sold in the first part of last year were in a very, very hot market,'' she said. ''Now it's a much more normal market.''
Climbing interest rates have also helped to slow the state's real estate market, said Gary Schlossberg, senior economist at Wells Fargo Bank. In January, the average fixed mortgage rate was 9.9 percent; by April it had climbed to 10.25 percent. All these factors have prompted analysts to project further slowdowns in California residential and commerical construction this year. Ben Bartolotto, research director of the Construction Industry Research Board, a private organization based in Burbank, Calif., that monitors building permits in the state, forecasts a 12 percent drop in single-family housing this year, a 4 percent dip in multifamily housing and a 9 percent decrease in nonresidential building.
''We've been expecting a slowdown,'' said Mr. Bartolotto. ''But whether it has to do with changes in thrift laws - well, I suspect not.''
A building slowdown, along with tighter lending controls, makes for a healthy correction, according to Richard Peiser, professor of urban regional planning at University of Southern California in Los Angeles. ''I see this as a short-term correction of a market that has been overheated by rapid price increases in the last few years,'' he said.
Small developers may have trouble surviving the days of scarce credit, but Mr. Peiser sees the situation adjusting by 1992. ''There will be opportunities for institutions and investors who are willing to take the equity risks formerly taken by S. & L.'s,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Children Striving to Cope With the Homeless

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Two or three times a day almost every day, one disheveled person or another lurches in front of Faith Ryder and demands a dime or a quarter.
Faith is 12 years old - and when you are little, and it is an adult's face looming over you, even a request invokes a sense of menace.
''A lot of times I don't have extra money, and they say, 'C'mon, c'mon, it's just a dime,' '' says Faith, a seventh grader at St. Joseph's School on East 87th Street. ''It makes me scared, and then I feel really bad, 'cause I can't help.''
With a puff of schoolyard macho, 13-year-old Michael Brown declares in response to a question, ''Be scared of a homeless person, for what?'' But in the next sentence he says: ''If you say no, some of them might attack you. If I go traveling, I have an adult with me.'' 
Karen Zaidberg, 13, a seventh grader at Russell Sage Junior High School in Forest Hills, Queens, believes her feelings for the homeless are ''distorted.''
''Kids in this school are sheltered,'' she says. ''We're not made to live it and see it every day. I'm angered in the way that I'm not opened to it and I can't feel for these people.''
Countless children in New York City - those fortunate enough to have a home - are continually confronted by the fact that thousands in their midst lead wretched lives.
And if grown-ups wrestle with the emotional contradictions posed by that reality - the urge to care, squelched by the instinct to reject what is forced on one - then how is a child to cope?
''It's awful to think there are people out there who live that way when we just go around and buy meaningless things like magazines or toys or jewelry, 'cause you don't need that stuff,'' says Faith. The confrontations diminish Faith's faith - in adults, in government, even in herself.
''They're not really that worried,'' she says of politicians. ''They just say there's not much we can do because there's so many of them.''
And, she says, ''It goes through my mind that if I don't like finish school or whatever, I could be out there, 'cause it can happen to anyone.''
Children's fears, says Dr. Robert E. Gould, a professor at New York Medical College who specializes in adolescent psychiatry, ''fit into a basic question that kids have of what kind of world are we living in; why doesn't the city, why doesn't America, handle the problem?
''Children, from the beginning, have a fear of abandonment. And this compounds it.''
George McDonald, director of Ready, Willing and Able, an organization that trains homeless people to rehabilitate apartments, sees the problem in terms of a ''social mortgage.''
''People who amass wealth, the government and, indeed, ordinary citizens understand the necessity of an economic mortgage,'' he says. ''But too often they forget that there is a social mortgage that has to be paid.'' Children are paying installments. 'Hurt in the Heart'
Thirty youngsters, interviewed at random in various parts of the city in the last two weeks, spoke of their thoughts and feelings about homelessness with a clarity not blurred by an adult ability to rationalize, to detach. Their responses - sometimes simplistic, often startlingly sophisticated - touch on many of the subtleties surrounding the issue. And, always, they come straight from the heart, ''I feel hurt in the heart,'' says Michael Brown, 13, an eighth grader at Public School 67 in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn.
''If a homeless person asks for change, I just give him some,'' says Michael, seated on a park bench. ''It could be family. Suppose it was one of my uncles or something?''
Nine-year-old Gregory Stern, straggling behind a gaggle of kids streaming out of St. Ann's School in Brooklyn Heights one recent afternoon, says: ''They'll look at you and their eyes are like dim and wrinkled. It makes you feel unhappy and scared when some of them talk to you in this odd voice, kind of old and loud. I think the homeless are just people whose parents didn't like them too much, and they are saying I'm going to get them back by being a failure.''
''It came in my mind,'' Gregory adds, ''that I could be on the streets some day. People get old, and no one wants to see them anymore.''
 
A Limit to Compassion
As it does with adults, the daily barrage affects some children's capacity for compassion.
''I feel ripped off,'' says Tommy Ng, 16, a student at Junior High School 56 in Chinatown. ''I work for my money. Why don't they?''
Then, he adds, resignedly, ''I know unemployment is hard these days.''
Outside her apartment building in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, 12-year-old Velvet Ross says: ''I really don't have any reaction, because you see them so many times. Some of them are just lazy.'' But then Velvet says: ''I feel sorry. Just because you're homeless doesn't mean you're less of a person. You never know, some day you could be in a situation that you have no answer to.''
Velvet's 10-year-old sister, Ebony offers, ''Some of them want to be like that so people will feel sorry for them.'' And her sister, Jasmine, 8, admits that she has lost sleep thinking about those who have no bed: ''I think about them in the night sometimes.''
A sort of cynicism, an unwillingness to trust adults, can be fostered by the confrontations.
''Sometimes they have crutches on and they are lying,'' says Chris Spasov, 13, an eighth grader at Russell Sage Junior High School. ''That makes me mad, because the money you pay to these people can go to real people.''
Lauren Mechling, 12, a seventh grader at St. Ann's in Brooklyn, says: ''It really bothers me when they use children for begging. It's totally unfair, manipulative.''
 
Idealism Prevails
Still, as do most children, Lauren retains her idealism.
''On Earth Day I was walking with my friend and we saw so many homeless people that we bought bagels and juice and we just handed them out,'' she says. ''And it felt really nice for Earth Day and everything.''
Damien Mackie, 13, of Fort Greene says: ''When I go to P.S. 46 to play basketball, it's this homeless lady up there and people be spitting on her and saying, 'You stink.' So I buy her like a bag of potato chips and she says thank you. And I feel proud of myself.''
Eeyore's Bookstores for Children in Manhattan recently ran a contest asking youngsters to write essays on what it would be like to be homeless. About 1,200 entries were submitted, said Eeyore's owner, Joel Fram.
One, written by Kate Wilson, 8, of Morristown, N.J., said: ''Well, time to go begging on the street. Usually no one gives me anything, but it's worth a try anyway. Yesterday I didn't get anything because I was in a bad mood, yelling out all these bad words for no reason. See, no one understands that when you're homeless, you have so many trapped emotions inside that you just explode.''
Out of their idealism, the children offer simple, direct opinions about why homelessness persists and how it should be handled.
''Why don't they just give them work to do?'' asks Denny Wong, 12, of Intermediate School 131 in Chinatown.
 
'We Should Rebuild America'
''Government doesn't care because these people don't vote,'' says Matthew Silver, 14, participating in a round-table discussion of the problem at Russell Sage Junior High in Queens.
Tarik Clarke, 13, of Bedford-Stuyvesant, says: ''There should be more than like 'Comic Relief' for a few nights. The government should focus more on helping the homeless than they do on foreign aid. I'm not like against foreign aid, but we should rebuild America.''
''They should rebuild buildings,'' says 7-year-old Daniel M., who lives with his grandmother on the Lower East Side.
Daniel and his sister, Monica, 12, bring a special concern to the problem. Their mother, a drug addict, exists on the street.
''We see her sometimes,'' Monica says. ''We go up to her and say 'Hi.' We ask her to go to a hospital, but she won't listen.''
