LENGTH: 1592 words

HEADLINE: States Take Up New Burdens To Pay for 'New Federalism'

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
Nearly a decade after Ronald Reagan promised to return powers to the states with his ''New Federalism,'' state and local officials say their authority has instead been whittled away with a new generation of regulations giving them expensive responsibilities when there is less Federal money to help pay for them.
Although the ''New Federalism'' approach was intended to give states and municipalities more flexibility and authority, it was undercut by an avalanche of mandates imposed in Washington, from monitoring pollution to removing asbestos from schools to supervising nursing homes.
While this was going on, Congress made drastic cuts in Federal block grants and revenue sharing, which states and localities had used at their discretion. Revenue sharing had been initiated by former President Richard M. Nixon in the early 1970's as part of his own ''New Federalism'' proposal, which gave the states the money to carry out their new authority. Who Controls What? Simply put, the Reagan Administration relaxed the Federal Government's controls on business, not its controls on state and local government. One paradox of the Reagan years is that while Mr. Reagan cultivated the image of being a ''deregulator,'' his Administration forced state and local governments to assume new regulatory duties - in terms both of new rules to enforce and of responsibility for enforcing old ones. Under Mr. Nixon, Washington gave local governments more funds to exercise their new authority. Under the Reagan and Bush Administrations, Washington has given the states new tasks but less money. 
The ''New Federalism'' that Mr. Reagan introduced in his 1981 State of the Union Message simply reflected a conservative philosophy that local government is better equipped than Washington to assess needs and draw up programs on domestic issues. But there was never a specific plan, and in fact there was a sharp cut in Federal funds for states and localities.
From 1978 to 1989, Federal allocations to the states fell by 13 percent after inflation, according to the Advisory Council on Intergovernmental Relations, a Federal agency made up of Federal, state and local officials. In addition, the states had far less discretion in spending, as more of the funds were earmarked for payments to individuals.
The advisory council study was one of three new reports that document the lament of many governors and mayors who contend that Mr. Reagan's New Federalism was illusory. Another study was done by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress.
 
The View From California
A more narrowly focused study was done by Dr. Beryl A. Radin, professor of public administration at the University of Southern California's Public Affairs Center in Washington. It found that more than 70 California governmental units had offices in Washington - and that one-third of them had opened the offices or hired a Washington lobbyist within the past five years.
''The first thing that this tells me is that even in this age of the rhetoric about the New Federalism and returning decisions to local government, Ronald Reagan's own state finds that it needs an increased presence here,'' Dr. Radin said.
Mayor Robert M. Isaac of Colorado Springs, a Republican who will be the next president of the United States Conference of Mayors, said: ''I don't think there was any New Federalism. I don't think there's been any transfer of power. I think it's gone the other way.''
 
A Republican Complains
Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, a Republican, said, ''Instead of giving the power to the states, and giving us the flexibility of addressing the problems of the states, Congress keeps giving us new mandates.''
In recent years, mayors of big cities, especially in the Northeast, have struggled more and more to deliver services to poorer populations while drawing money from a shrinking tax base -and having less money coming from Washington.
Some officials see some good in this; they say the lack of money has forced them to be more innovative in their approaches to governing and raising revenue. Governors and mayors have taken the lead in trying to attract foreign investors, creating their own environmental and health programs, turning to private concerns to deliver public services and raising money through lotteries and new taxes.
Mayor Bill Hudnut of Indianapolis, a Republican, said, ''We've seen the dawn of the entrepreneurial American city, which is forced to be more innovative and creative and self-reliant because of the cuts coming out of Washington.''
 
'Caught in a Squeeze'
Some Democratic governors say the new regulations create a problem for them, because they represent worthy goals while restricting their flexibility.
Indeed, the National Governors Association pressed for the 1988 Federal welfare law, pushed by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, that requires states to provide job training for some recipients. And the Southern Governors Conference proposed the 1989 Federal law that requires the states to provide maternal and child health benefits to those whose incomes are less than one-third over the poverty level of $6,314 a year for an individual. This forced some states to increase their payments.
''The states are caught in a squeeze,'' said Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, a Democrat. ''People who want good things are imposing their priorities on the governors.''
Gov. James J. Blanchard of Michigan, a Democrat, said the regulations reflected ''good policies that ought to be pursued if you had the money, but wouldn't be among the top four if you didn't have the money.''
 
Bush Pledges to Ease Up
Money is one thing many states do not have. ''At least half the states are in fiscal distress,'' said Gerald Miller, executive director of the National Association of State Budget Officers.
President Bush pledged last July to observe a request from the National Governors Association for a two-year moratorium on new Federal mandates. ''It's very tough for them,'' said Debra Rae Anderson, deputy assistant to the President for intergovernmental affairs. ''They haven't come in and asked for more money. They've said, 'Don't cut what we're getting, and don't mandate new programs.' ''
The advisory council study found that, in actual dollars, Federal funds to states and localities amounted to $123.6 billion in 1989, as against $77.9 billion in 1978. But in 1982 constant dollars, the funds declined for the same period, to $94.7 billion from $109.77 billion.
At the same time, Federal payments to people on welfare, Medicaid and other programs grew from $35 billion to $50 billion, while discretionary funds from the Federal government to the States and locals were reduced from $50 billion to $25 billion.
 
Two Presidents Compared
Revenue sharing, which gave states and localities $7.3 billion in discretionary funds in 1981, was eliminated. ''Nixon gave us revenue sharing, and Reagan gave us revenue bleeding,'' Governor Blanchard said. In addition, Federal aid to employment programs declined, from $8.4 billion in 1981 to $3.5 billion in fiscal 1990. Community development block grants were reduced from $5.7 billion in 1981 to $2.9 billion in 1990, while mass transit funds were reduced from $5.4 billion in 1981 to $2.9 billion in 1990. Those figures are in real dollars, not adjusted for inflation, so the difference is more pronounced than it appears.
At the same time, Washington has imposed a raft of new regulatory responsibilities on states and localities since 1981. The advisory council study found that more than one quarter of all statutes in which the Federal Government pre-empted state and local laws - setting its own standards and telling the states to enforce them - were enacted in the Reagan years. Of 354 such statutes enacted since 1789, when Congress was created, 95 were enacted from 1981 to 1989. By comparison, 91 pre-emptive statutes were enacted in the preceding dozen years.
''Over all, state and local governments became subject to hundreds of new program standards and administrative requirements,'' the G.A.O. report said.
Most of those requirements dealt with health, safety and education:
* Municipalities were required to monitor pollution from thousands of storm sewers and to test for 77 additional chemicals in municipal water supplies. Local governments were also required to control 83 new drinking water contaminants.
* School districts were required to identify asbestos hazards and remove them from local schools.
* States were required to prepare reports on 152 new endangered species.
* States were required to monitor and enforce actions requiring businesses and industries to establish and maintain programs to protect hearing and guard against exposure to certain dangerous chemicals and asbestos.
* States were required to adopt a minimum drinking age of 21 or face 10 percent reductions in highway aid.
In addition, the Bush Administration has proposed a plan that would shift the financial burden of highway construction toward the states.
''We don't want to be cry babies,'' said Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin of Vermont, who announced last month that she would not seek a fourth term this fall, in part because of growing frustration with budget problems. ''We recognize that there are lots of innovative ways to do things that don't always require additional funds. But it's frustrating when there's a clear shift in Federal policy, as in highway construction. That's kind of gutless.''

I think it's gone the other way.'' (Colorado Springs Gazette Telegraph); Gov. Bill Clinton: Democrat, Arkansas - ''People who want good things are imposing their priorities on the governors. It's enormously increased pressure to raise revenues.'' (Associated Press) (pg. B14)

HEADLINE: U.S. Delegation Visiting an India in Political Crisis

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 20

 BODY:
When a high-level American delegation arrives here tonight for talks on Monday on the separatist war in Kashmir, it is likely to find the Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh preoccupied by its worst domestic political crisis since coming to power in December.
The American team is headed by President Bush's deputy national security adviser, Robert M. Gates. Significantly for India, Mr. Gates is coming here fresh from discussions in Moscow and Islamabad. India, accustomed to playing off American and Soviet interests, confronts for the first time what appears from here to be superpower consensus. 
The Americans are expected to convey Washington's concern about what the White House described as a ''deteriorating situation'' involving mounting human rights abuses in Kashmir, and the consequent threat of war between India and Pakistan over the disputed territory.
But the Indian Government's ability to deal with the Kashmir crisis appears to be falling victim to Prime Minister Singh's worsening internal political problems.
Like the only previous Indian Government not formed by the Congress Party, the Singh administration is being undermined by disputes in the governing coalition. Twelve years ago when that earlier non-Congress Government faltered, there was nothing of the magnitude of the Kashmir rebellion confronting India.
While the Prime Minister's allies on both the pro-Hindu right and Communist left complain that he is not being tough enough on Kashmiri Muslims, thousands of people are being arrested or hounded by Government forces, Indian human rights groups and fleeing Kashmiris say. As a result, no new political initiatives are being proposed. More damaging to Mr. Singh's standing is the growing embarrassment to his administration caused by the activities of Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal and his son, Om Prakash Chautala.
Mr. Lal, a powerful leader in the northern farm belt, has a history of violence and corruption that makes him anathema to the clean-government voters who propelled Mr. Singh to power in December. Mr. Chautala has been linked to vote fraud and poll violence in Haryana state. The violence culminated last week in the killing of a rival candidate in coming state elections in a constituency where Mr. Chautala, an unelected Chief Minister who inherited his position from his father, is seeking a seat.
Mr. Singh's association with Mr. Lal and his son proved costly this weekend, when the Prime Minister suffered two significant blows to his authority: Mr. Lal's candidate, S. R. Bommai, was chosen as president of Mr. Singh's own party, the Janata Dal, and one of his chief economic and social planners, L. C. Jain, resigned.
Mr. Jain, one of Asia's best known development experts and a follower of Mohandas K. Gandhi, resigned to protest Prime Minister Singh's silence on the recent events in Haryana, and his unwillingness to force Mr. Chautala to step down in the face of accusations of criminality.
Leading Indian newspapers are calling on Mr. Singh to live up to his image as a clean politician. Critics say the Prime Minister's pursuit of investigations into allegations of corruption in the administration of the former Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi, begin to look like witch-hunting if he refuses to punish criminality within his own Government and party.
When Mr. Singh took office in December, he was expected to bring a fresh approach to the problem of separatism in Kashmir and in Punjab state. In both cases, there was little disagreement among political analysts that shortsighted policies of Mr. Gandhi, framed for partisan purposes, had led to the flourishing of rebel political movements.
But Mr. Singh has chosen not to lay the blame for Kashmiri and Punjabi rebellions on Mr. Gandhi, on the late Indira Gandhi, who preceded him, or on the Congress Party. Instead, Mr. Singh, a skilled politician, has continued to rely on the use of military force.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Gorbachev's Military: A Bigger Role?

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
United States officials just back from Moscow said today that while President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appeared firmly in charge as Soviet leader in his talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, he also seemed to be giving his armed forces a somewhat greater role in the decision making.
Some analyses in recent weeks have suggested that the Soviet military is becoming dominant in the Kremlin, but one official who accompanied Mr. Baker to Moscow said: ''I'd say from what we saw Gorbachev has the military firmly under control. They are by no means resurgent.'' 
But another American official said that judging from Mr. Gorbachev's behavior at key moments in his five-hour meeting with Mr. Baker on Friday - the most important in the four days of talks the Secretary of State held in Moscow - Mr. Gorbachev ''certainly does not want to alienate the military at a time when he is being criticized for failing to improve the domestic quality of life, for allowing the union to disinegrate and for allowing an erosion of their overall security position''
 
Decisions Are Still Gorbachev's
What this means for the summit meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev scheduled to start on May 30, and for United States-Soviet relations generally, American officials said, is that on arms control Mr. Gorbachev will be able to continue making the big decisions, as he did in Moscow last week when a breakthrough was reached on the treaty limiting long-range nuclear weapons. But those decisions are likely to take longer now, and the negotiations more intense, because of the Soviet leader's need to give his armed forces greater input.
An official who took part in the arms control negotiations in the Kremlin between Mr. Baker and Mr. Gorbachev said one image seemed to sum up the relationship between the Soviet leader and his armed forces. At one point, the official said, Mr. Baker raised a highly technical arms control question and Mr. Gorbachev gestured to Col. Gen. Bronislav Omelichev, First Deputy Chief of Staff of the Soviet Armed Forces, to go over and clarify the point for him.
What was striking, the American official said, was that General Omelichev, probably the second most powerful general in the Soviet military, approached Mr. Gorbachev like a ''little boy coming to his Sunday school teacher.''
''He wasn't even sure if he should sit down or not,'' the official said.
But what was equally striking, the official said, was that General Omelichev was at the meeting at all. Previously Mr. Gorbachev would probably have consulted his personal national security adviser, Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, who is now retired, and might not have had any active-duty military officer present. Marshal Akhromeyev was also in the room this time, but the Soviet leader, American officials said, noticeably ignored him and went out of his way to give the representative of the armed forces his say.
 
Military More Assertive
Before leaving for Moscow, some American officials had begun to wonder exactly what was Mr. Gorbachev's relationship with his military. When Mr. Baker was in Moscow in February, he thought he had largely resolved virtually the same two issues that produced Saturday's breakthrough in the strategic arms reduction talks -how to limit air-launched and sea-launched cruise missiles. But when Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, came to Washington in April, the Americans found the Soviet military taking a more commanding role in the arms control negotiations and reopening issues that the United States thought were closed.
Indeed, after Mr. Shevardnadze's visit in April, General Omelichev came to Washington to follow up on the arms talks, raising the question of whether the Soviet military was not suddenly asserting itself generally.
American officials now believe that as the Soviet military began to take stock of the deteriorating security situation of the Soviet Union in light of the virtual collapse of the Warsaw Pact, the loss of its Eastern European security buffer and the rise of a united Germany, it began to grow extremely nervous about its ability to defend the country, as any military would. The leaders were also apparently unhappy at the way Marshal Akhromeyev was representing the military's point of view.
As a result, officials said, the armed forces demanded an opportunity to squeeze more from the Americans on precisely those arms control issues that affected the immediate security of the Soviet heartland - cruise missiles. These are relatively short-range nuclear weapons fired from planes or naval vessels. The shorter the range allowed by the treaty, the closer an American plane or ship would have to get to the Soviet Union and the easier it would then be to spot early and shoot down.
 
'A Sense of Uncertainty'
Mr. Gorbachev apparently decided that it would be ''politically and militarily prudent to bring in the armed forces more so that they would share more responsibility for key decisions,'' one official said, both because he identified with the concerns of the army and because he felt that when he was being vilified for his economic and political changes he could not allow himself to be accused also of giving away Soviet security.
The official added that in his talks with Mr. Baker, the Soviet President, more than ever, ''conveyed a sense of uncertainty of whether he was going to be able to pull off all his reforms.''
''The old confident optimism was not there,'' the official said. ''He talked openly about how difficult the transition to a market economy was going to be and the risks he faced of greater instability if they don't play it very carefully.''
This helps explain the roller-coaster talks last week. The Soviets insisted that air-launched cruise missiles that could travel 375 miles and up be covered by the strategic arms reduction treaty. But the Americans wanted a longer range - 500 miles and up - to protect a newly developed non-nuclear cruise missile, called Tacit Rainbow, that has a range close to 500 miles.
On Friday morning, Mr. Baker offered to accept Mr. Gorbachev's range limit if he agreed to exempt the Tacit Rainbow from the treaty. ''Gorbachev said, 'You got a deal,' and they shook hands,'' an American official recalled, A similar series of trade-offs produced a compromise package on how to limit sea-launched cruise missiles as well.
 
Soviets Demand Restrictions
On Friday afternoon, however, Soviet and American arms control experts met and the Russians started demanding that restrictions be put on Tacit Rainbow. The Americans insisted that Mr. Gorbachev had exempted Tacit Rainbow unconditionally and as part of a package deal. If the Soviets now wanted conditions, they said, the whole deal was off.
American officials now believe that the Soviet military did just what the United States military would have done under similar circumstances, demanded a chance to further restrict the abilities of the American cruise missile, and that Mr. Gorbachev did what American Presidents often do in such circumstances, gave in.
At noon Saturday, Mr. Baker, apparently feeling that the United States had compromised enough, decided to send Mr. Shevardnadze a letter explaining very generally the limitations and characteristics of Tacit Rainbow. He hoped that if the Soviet Foreign Minister had a letter it would better enable him to calm the Soviet armed forces. But Mr. Baker also made it clear that either the Soviets took the original Gorbachev-Baker package or nothing. Mr. Shevardnadze took it.
''The thing you have to keep in mind is that in the end Gorbachev's original deal was made,'' a senior American official said. ''So you have to make a distinction between the military having a role which gives them a chance to exercise influence and the military being resurgent. They are getting more input now, but they are not resurgent. The Soviet decision-making process may move less quickly now, but it is not likely to stop because the factors driving it in the first place have not changed.''

LENGTH: 408 words

HEADLINE: You Can't Sell a 'Gorgeous Mosaic' and Denounce Bigotry Too

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Mayor David Dinkins's stand on racial issues, though well meaning, hides a fatal inner contradiction. Unfortunately, that same illogic infects the discourse of nearly all our politicians these days, at all levels of government.
The sad fact is that one cannot promote a ''gorgeous mosaic'' and denounce bigotry at the same time. A mosaic is a system of tensions in which the place of every tile is strictly demarcated and no tile can be aware of the larger picture. It's because they're part of a ''mosaic'' that the Bensonhursts of the world become dangerous, cut off as they are from other communities and resisting incursion. It's the idea of the mosaic that lies behind ill-thought-out bilingual education programs that segregate Spanish-speakers and keep them from economic advancement. 
It's the idea of the mosaic that has corrupted American higher education over the last 20 years, substituting a free-for-all of special-interest courses in our colleges for the wider scope of ''Western civ,'' which, like it or not, still has more to do with how we live and how we got here than any number of courses on Hopi rituals or great Eskimo poets. In the end, the idea of the mosaic only lies behind the idea of ghettos.
The old ''melting pot'' concept of America, now much out of favor, at least held out an ideal of harmony. But in a society ruled by narcissism, nobody is willing to undergo the kind of melting that's demanded at either the personal or social level. We've been balkanized into groups, and it's seemingly more important to be black, or female, or Jewish, or Italian, or gay, than to be thought of as American, and our ''leaders,'' under pressure from special-interest groups and the cant of the day, help to promote such divisive sentiments.
Small-interest pride is breaking us up from within, and every Greek Day or Polish or Veterans Day parade up Fifth Avenue divides us only further. Why should we be surprised that there have been racist incidents and outbursts on all sides when our own cant sentiments about the sacred value of each individual cultural heritage are promoting factionalism?
''Civilization'' originally referred to the art of living in cities. That art demands active sympathy with one's neighbors, and sympathy doesn't come by emphasizing the specialness of one's corner in a mosaic. Small wonder we're all less civilized these days.
 
DAVID IVES
 New York, May 14, 1990

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Taking Baker to the Cleaners

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Why do you suppose Secretary of State James Baker's self-congratulations after his magisterial ministerial in Moscow -''real accomplishments,'' some ''heavy lifting'' - was met by a cool comment, ''mixed reviews,'' from President Bush?
More is involved than a President's pique at being cast as a supernumerary at his own summit. Mr. Bush knows that Secretary Baker's claim to have ''split the difference'' with the Soviets is untrue; the vaunted negotiator caved in to basic Gorbachev demands all the way down the line.
Only a few months ago, Mr. Bush was making plain that his primary goal in foreign affairs - that great end for which he was willing to so prudently ignore the economic coercion in the Baltics, and to make valuable trade concessions in advance to the desperate Soviet economy - was to get the Soviet Army out of Eastern Europe, perhaps even demobilized, so as to make perestroika truly ''irreversible'' without a new invasion.
A strictly secondary goal was a new agreement limiting nuclear missiles, an area in which both superpowers spend only one-seventh of their arms budgets. Our central purpose in that was to end the worst destabilizer of all: the Soviet monopoly on land-based, accurate intercontinental SS-18 heavy missiles, over 300 of which are always at the ready 30 minutes from the U.S. 
In contrast, the central Soviet purpose was to delay promised withdrawal from Eastern Europe, including 600,000 troops in East Germany, until Germany could be neutralized.
The other Gorbachev goal was to focus on strategic arms reduction -not, as Mr. Bush hoped, on conventional troop drawdowns - to maintain the Soviet heavy missile advantage, and to stop the improvement of America's potentially countervailing cruise missiles.
On the eve of the Bush formalization of the Baker accords, where does each nation stand?
The U.S., dealing from a position of unprecedented relative strength, has failed to obtain what Mr. Bush used to say was our first priority: the end of the Red Army's occupation of Eastern Europe. Forget about that conventional forces treaty; in the forgiving Baker formulation, ''our counterparts apparently weren't able to respond meaningfully at this time.''
The Soviet Union, having succeeded in changing the subject to nuclear arms, proceeded to take Mr. Baker to the cleaners on that.
Moscow retained the right to test and modernize its SS-18; even after reducing their number by half, the improved SS-18's will be as powerful a threat as today's 308 intercontinental missiles. We had hoped to allow the remaining half to atrophy untested, calling into question their reliability to any first-strike enthusiast; but Mr. Gorbachev told Mr. Baker to get lost. How about banning all land-based Mirved missiles? Don't even suggest it.
Nor would the Soviets then budge on the range of our air-launched cruise missiles. We originally wanted 1,500 kilometers, to be able to penetrate the Soviet Union if the Red Army attacked Europe; they said 600. We dickered downward; they said 600. The Baker ''split difference'': 600.
The negotiating breakthrough claimed by our side - the allowance of our 770-km missile, ''Tacit Rainbow'' - is vitiated by the Bush promise, in a side letter, not to modernize. We're way ahead of the Soviets in cruise technology; space-guided cruises with conventional warheads could knock out tank columns without devastating civilian areas. To give up the right to improve our newest defensive weapon, while giving the Soviets the right to improve their most fearsome offensive weapon, is naive horse-trading.
Having flip-flopped on his priorities, Mr. Bush cannot disavow Mr. Baker's get-a-deal imprudence now; next week, we will hear fanfare about poison gas and ballet-company exchanges to drown out the Bush-Baker failure to press the Soviets to withdraw.
How did Gorby do it? His strategy was daringly Orwellian: weakness is strength. He stressed his political fragility and his economic straits; he pointed in horror to the sinister forces who would take over unless he had a free hand in Europe.
Incredibly, paralyzed by fear of the who-lost-Gorbachev charge, the Bush Administration fell into the trap. Gorbachev gets what he wants on upgrading his SS-18's, freezing our cruises, denying our on-site verification of production facilities, protecting his intercontinental Backfire bomber, and occupying Eastern Europe.
We get to offer trade and aid, to turn a blind eye to repression, and to say the cold war is over.

HEADLINE: Overcoming Violence Is the Call at St. John's

 BODY:
Overcoming violence in New York City - from serial killings of taxi drivers to a shooting of a priest to a sexual assault on a student - was the theme of the Rev. Donald J. Harrington's commencement speech at St. John's University yesterday.
At the 120th Commencement, Father Harrington, the university's president, chose not to ignore recent accusations that had hurt the image of the largest Catholic university in the country.
Last month, six students, several of them members of the lacrosse team, were indicted on charges of sexually assaulting another student at an off-campus house.
As he spoke to the 1,432 graduates and more than 6,000 spectators who filled Alumni Hall, Father Harrington said the charges ''brought home to us very forcefully how fragile and vulnerable we are as individuals and as a community.''
Father Harrington, the only commencement speaker, talked about the shooting of a priest outside a rectory in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and the spate of shootings of taxi drivers in the Bronx and suggested to the graduates that perhaps they could be ''the answer which this city needs at this time.'' 
Yesterday was the second of two undergraduate commencement exercises at the Queens campus. On Saturday, 897 degrees were conferred.The two ceremonies were needed for the large number of graduates.
Honorary degrees were awarded to Estee Lauder, chairman of the Estee Lauder Cosmetics Company; Sister Veronica Greeley, Prioress of the congregation of the Holy Cross, and the Rev. Raymond Brown, a biblical scholar and a professor.
The St. John's University President's medal, which is awarded for outstanding loyalty and devotion to the alma mater, was awarded to two St. John's professors, Dr. John M. Sledz of the College of Business Administration, and Dr. Frank Kunkel of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences.
 
Adelphi University
Robert H. Bork, the former Federal appeals judge who is now a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, addressed the 2,983 members of Adelphi University's Class of 1990 yesterday. Mr. Bork was also one of nine writers, scholars and government figures to be awarded honorary degrees during the ceremonies in Garden City, L.I. The other honorees were: Betty Allen, the executive director of the Harlem School of Arts in New York City; Creighton Eddy Gilbert, an author and professor of art history at Yale University; Dudley Robert Herschbach, a Nobel Prize-winning chemist at Harvard University; Donald Kagan, the dean of Yale College; Fredrick Morgan, the founder of The Hudson Review; Richard D. Parsons, the president and chief operating officer of the Dime Savings Bank of New York; Simon Schama, an author and professor of history at Harvard, and Claire Shulman, a 1946 Adelphi alumna who is the Queens Borough President.
 
Bryn Mawr College
Cokie Roberts, a journalist for National Public Radio and ABC's ''This Week with David Brinkley,'' urged graduates of Bryn Mawr College not to abandon women's traditional role as nurturers.
''When women graduated 20 years ago, they didn't think about careers,'' Ms. Roberts told the graduates yesterday. ''When women graduated 10 years ago, they only thought about careers. All of us learned we have to combine careers and family.''
''You can do it all,'' she said. ''You just don't sleep very much.''
The commencement was the 105th at the college in Bryn Mawr, Penn. During the ceremonies, the college awarded 446 degrees, including 119 master's degrees and 29 doctorates.
 
Fairfield University
John J. Phelan Jr., the chairman and chief executive officer of the New York Stock Exchange, told 1,114 graduates at Fairfield University's 40th Commencement yesterday that ''materialism alone cannot feed the body and cannot feed the mind.'' Before receiving an honorary doctor of laws degree, Mr. Phelan addressed an audience of more than 9,000 and spoke of a ''contagion of democracy'' sweeping Eastern Europe. He also predicted, ''Europe will build a new and different civilization that we can all be proud of in 15 to 20 years.'' He likened the task to the resurrection of Hiroshima from the devastation of the atomic bomb, and said: ''The will of people will surmount all odds. The human spirit will overcome all obstacles.'' Other recipients of an honorary degree were Fortune R. Pope, former publisher of the newspaper Il Progresso and director and officer of the Pope Foundation, and Willie H. Ruff Jr., a member of the Mitchell-Ruff Duo that took jazz to Russia in 1959 and to China in 1981.
 
University of Hartford
Nearly three months after his death, Malcolm Forbes, the editor of Forbes magazine, was awarded an honorary doctor of laws degree by the University of Hartford for the ''imaginative zeal with which he pursued his life and his generosity in supporting philanthropic causes.'' His son, Christopher Forbes, accepted the honor during the school's 33d commencement yesterday, as 1,440 students received undergraduate and graduate degrees. Eleanor Holmes Norton, a civil rights lawyer who headed the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, addressed the recent spate of racist incidents on American campuses, saying, ''The new bigotry must be chased from campus not with rules that mock free expression by denying it, but with outspoken oral and written retorts from every section of the university community.'' Also receiving honorary degrees were: Stillman B. Brown, chairman of the school's Board of Regents from 1983 to 1988; Mark Lamos, artistic director of the Hartford Stage Company, and George McNeil, who teaches at the university's Hartford Art School.
 
Haverford College
Haverford College awarded four honorary degrees at its 157th commencement yesterday and, instead of having a keynote speaker, each recipient was allowed to address the nearly 260 graduates briefly.
Receiving the degrees were Ernest L. Boyer, former United States Commissioner of Education and Chancellor of the State University of New York; Gustavo Gutierrez, a Peruvian priest, theologian and author; Katherine Dunham, the dancer and choreographer who helped form Ballet Negre, the first African-American dance company in Chicago; and Felicia Nahoma Kentridge, a South African lawyer who has helped bring legal aid to the country's poor.
 
Hofstra University
During two days of ceremonies that conclude today, Hofstra University will have awarded degrees to 1,673 men and women in undergraduate and graduate programs. In his message to the graduates yesterday, the school's president, James M. Stuart, challenged them to ''always have a questioning mind.'' Honorary degrees were awarded to four alumni and to Rand V. Araskog, chairman of the ITT Corporation, who was praised as ''something of a management miracle.'' The following alumni were honored: Senator Wyche Fowler Jr., a Democrat from Georgia; George Vecsey, a sports columnist of The New York Times and the author of several books; Patricia Reilly Giff, the author of more than 40 children's books, and Dr. Harold J. Raveche, president of the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J.
 
Morehouse College
Randall Robinson, founder of the human rights organization TransAfrica, and the Rev. Dr. Fred Lofton, president of the Progressive Baptist Convention, spoke at Morehouse College's 106th commencement ceremonies in Atlanta.
Mr. Robinson addressed the 300 graduates of the all-male institution at yesterday's commencement on the campus lawn. He received an honorary doctor of laws degree. Dr. Lofton spoke at the baccalaureate ceremony on Saturday afternoon and received an honorary doctor of divinity degree.
 
University of Notre Dame
Bill Cosby, perhaps best known for his television series ''The Cosby Show'' addressed 1,800 who received bachelor's degrees and 600 who received advanced degrees at the University of Notre Dame's 145th commencement.
Mr. Cosby, who was the recipient of an honorary degree yesterday, has been a major benefactor of traditionally black colleges and universities.
Other honorary degrees were awarded to Rutherford Aris, a professor of chemical engineering at the University of Minnesota; the Rev. George H. Clements, a civil rights advocate; Jill Ker Conway, the former president of Smith College; Ernst L. Eliel, an author; the dancer Suzanne Farrell, and Emil T. Hofman, retiring dean for freshman studies and professor emeritus of chemistry at Notre Dame.
Others were receiving honorary degrees were Ignacio E. Lozano,Jr., editor of the newspaer ''La Opinion'' in Los Angeles; J. Richard Munro, former excutive of Time-Warner Inc.; Javier Perez de Cuellar, Secretary General of the United Nations; A. Kenneth Pye, president of Southern Methodist University; and Martha R. Seger, a member of the Federal Reserve Board.
A special honorary award was given to the late Sister Thea Bowman, a poet, evangelist and singer.
 
SUNY
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo called for unity, tolerance and the defeat of negativism during Commencement exercises at the State University of New York at Stony Brook yesterday.
Mr. Cuomo told the 2,600 degree candidates and their guests, ''Imagine what we could be if we could realize the full potential of all our people, if we could reaffirm the notion of family and reject - as we always have at our best - the proposition that we can exist and thrive as a house divided or a world divided, fractionalized by sex or nationality, by race or color or religion.''
After discussing the recent rise in racial and ethnic conflict in New York, he suggested that the diversity of the Stony Brook campus held a lesson for all. ''This is a community that draws students not just from Long Island, but from France, Poland, China, Italy, Israel, Peru and Vietnam,'' he said. ''You're showing all of us how we can live together better by learning more about one another.''
Honorary degrees were presented to an economist, Gary S. Becker, and two scientists, Paul C. Lauterbur and John S. Toll, who also was president of Stony Brook from 1965 to 1978.
SUNY campuses in Buffalo, Albany and New Paltz also held graduation ceremonies yesterday.
In Buffalo, Frederic V. Salerno, the new chairman of SUNY's board of trustees, told 1,000 graduating students that ''as Cadillacs are the top of the line of the U.S. auto industry, you graduates are the jewels of the American educational showroom.''
But Mr. Salerno said that ''one of the biggest obstacles to continued economic growth in New York - and throughout the United States - is the lack of basic skills among those seeking to enter the work force.''
Honorary degrees were awarded to Wynton Marsalis, who was called ''one of the country's most talented musicians''; Alonzo Church, a mathematician and philosopher, and Ira Michael Heyman, the chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley.
 
Smith College
Helen Caldicott, a leader of the anti-nuclear movement, told the 722 graduates of Smith College's 112th commencement yesterday she was pleased to be speaking at a women's college because ''the future lies in the hands of women.''
Ms. Caldicott, the former head of Physicians for Social Responsibility, said women make up 53 percent of the world's population and do two-thirds of the world's work, and yet only receive 10 percent of the income and 1 percent of the property in return. ''We have all the babies, and we have no power,'' she said. ''This must change.''
''You, this generation of women, were born for one reason - to save the world. That is your task in life, and that is why you graduated from Smith,'' Ms. Caldicott told the graduates. ''You are the intellectual elite in this country. I hand the torch to you.''
Some students tried to make a change yesterday. During commencement, about one-fourth of the seniors wore green and black ribbons attached to their graduation gowns, to show their opposition to Smith's recent decision to stop admitting students without regard to their ability to pay.
In addition to Ms. Caldicott, who received an honorary doctor of laws degree, other honorary degrees were awarded to Mary Frances Berry, a civil rights advocate, Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas; Anna Marie Petrioli Tosani, an art historian and director of the Uffizi Gallery in Florence, and Sheila Evans Widnall, an aeronautics engineer and educator.
 
Tufts University
Dr. Robert Coles, a Harvard research psychiatrist, urged more than 2,100 Tufts University graduates yesterday to exercise ''some trust and love and respect so that skin color and origin and class and neighborhood no longer divide us.''
Dr. Coles, who is best known for his studies on the impact of segregation and integration on black schoolchildren, was the featured speaker at the university's 134th commencement ceremonies and received an honorary doctor of humane letters degree.
The president of the Medford, Mass., college, Jean Mayer, praised Dr. Coles for his devotion to the poor and disenfranchised.
Tufts also presented honorary degrees to Yevgeny P. Velikhov, the vice president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences; H. Dudley Wright, the president of Orbisphere Corporation of Switzerland; Robert D. Ballard, an oceanographer who discovered the wreckage of the Titanic; Shelby Cullom Davis, the former United States Ambassador to Switzerland; Thomas R. Pickering, the United States Ambassador to the United Nations; Elma Lewis, the founder of the National Center of Afro-American Artists, and Weston Howland Jr., a trustee emeritus of the university.

HEADLINE: Stories Keep Coming to a Late-Blooming Writer

BYLINE: By D. J. R. BRUCKNER

 BODY:
William Trevor, who began to write fiction only in his 30's and who has become one of the most productive and honored short-story writers in the English language, will make a rare public appearance tomorrow night, reading from his newest collection, ''Family Sins and Other Stories,'' at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.
The 61-year-old author of 10 novels and dozens of plays for stage, radio and television, in addition to the scores of short stories that have won some of Britain's top literary prizes through the years, will share the stage with Edna O'Brien, who will read from her new story collection, ''Lantern Slides,'' in the closing session of the Y's Irish Literature Festival.
Mr. Trevor, who was born in Ireland, has had a home in England through most of his adult life and is often described as an Anglo-Irish writer. But he says he finds the English ''rather strange people'' and thinks an advantage of living in England is that ''it is sometimes easier to write about your own people from a foreign country.'' In fact, he is breaking his usual rule against giving public readings because ''this is an Irish festival, and I thought I would like to do this one.'' 
 
The Writer as Wanderer
His home in rural Devonshire, he said in a telephone interview from there, is an old mill surrounded by 40 acres of land that creates an island of solitude. ''It looks a bit like Ireland, and that is pleasant.''
Not that he is there all that much. When he began to write, he said, he became a ''wanderer,'' and he regularly spends half the year traveling in Italy or in Ticino, the nub of Switzerland that juts down into Italy. And he visits Ireland quite often during the other half of the year. But his house is in Devon. ''I don't have other homes.'' he said. ''I hate owning things. It's easy to rent a place or stay in a hotel. A hotel is a good place for a writer. You can eavesdrop a lot.'' Wandering is his habit in writing as well. ''I am always working on a number of different things at once,'' he said. ''The change is important; you're just a man alone in a room writing.'' He writes ''very rapidly'' and puts things away for a year or two before he returns to them ''to see if they worked.''
''Often I have forgotten a lot about them,'' he said. ''I forget characters' names, things that happen to them.''
When it comes to rewriting stories, he does them over completely, from beginning to end - ''you can't tinker with sentences or paragraphs in a story'' - typing them on colored paper before he sends them to a typist who produces a copy in black and white. ''They look different that way,'' he said. ''You get a different view of them.''
 
A Cinematic Novelist
On novels he works ''like a movie maker, cutting and splicing and pasting things in.'' But novels seem to annoy him. ''I think of myself as a story writer who also writes novels,'' he said. ''My novels just won't be maneuvered into short stories. I start writing away, and sometimes I find myself, to my considerable horror, in the midst of a novel.''
In part, he resents the time a novel takes when stories keep bubbling up. For, even though he insists he is ''a very lazy person,'' the stories are compulsive. ''If one wants to be written, it must be done. They're insistent. I can't make them go away.'' Nor can he stop to think about the course they may take. ''To me, being a writer is like being an athlete. You can't pause to analyze the game while you're in it.''
Where the stories come from he generally does not know, and he is reluctant to tamper with the springs of his imagination to find out. By now he has created many hundreds of vividly realized characters in stories notable for an almost Elizabethan richness of detail. Often it is something he observes or a remark he overhears that will start him off.
But that is only a nudge, ''that first little wrench out of reality that's needed,'' he said. ''That's where observation is useful.'' He has even been wrenched out of reality and into a story by a few of his own dreams. ''It doesn't really matter how a story starts; it's how you cultivate it that counts, like gardening.''
In praising ''Family Sins & Other Stories'' in her review in The New York Times, Michiko Kakutani wrote that ''decisive moments define the the lives of almost all of Mr. Trevor's characters, dividing their lives into an after and a before, a now and a then.'' She noted that ''the line of demarcation in a character's life has less to do with the loss of love than with the loss of innocence -something happens to fundamentally change how an individual sees himself or his family or a friend; and in the wake of that revelation, his entire relationship to the world is altered.''
 
Popular Dramatizations
One of the things Mr. Trevor is working on now is a television script of one story in the new collection, a tale of unusual violence called ''Events at Drimaghleen,'' about the deaths of two young people in love who are kept apart. Mr. Trevor's television versions of his stories have become enormously popular in Britain, and he is asked to dramatize many more than he is willing to do.
''But I do like the variety of the techniques,'' he said. ''The big job is to create images; those just suggested in stories are not usually right for television. What you trust your reader to imagine just doesn't work. Sometimes for television I have given the story a twist it doesn't have in the original. As long as the producers are willing to let me deliver when I am ready to, I enjoy this kind of writing. By now they know they'll have to wait a long time.''
He has never turned the process around and made a play or script into a story. But when he writes scripts for radio, he may also write the same story for publication because the script and the story ''can contribute a good deal to one another.'' He explains: ''The listener has to imagine in the same way a reader has to, and I find often that one version will tell me something about the other.''
 
'Still Bewildered'
The force that drives him in all this work is bewilderment. ''I believe in not quite knowing,'' he said. ''A writer needs to be doubtful, questioning. I write out of curiosity and bewilderment.'' After almost 30 years of writing, he adds, ''I am still bewildered about the world.''
Although critics often point out that his narrative technique is the traditional storyteller's, with few of the self-imposed limitations adopted by his contemporaries, he also insists: ''All writing for me is experimental. I never know when I start out whether a story will work. I am entirely an instinctive writer.''
Whether he is at home or traveling, Mr. Trevor writes from ''about 7:20 in the morning until 9, then drink a lot of coffee and gossip with my wife or whoever else is about, and then do another hour and stop altogether for the day.''
''If I don't write, I get melancholy,'' he said, ''and if for some reason I can't do it for a week, I can get very low. It's a kind of tonic.'' He does not mean merely a therapeutic one. ''Writing becomes a fix,'' he said, ''an obsession.''
That is only the manual part of it. ''All the rest of the day, you know, you are imagining people and wondering about them and working on things like disbelief. Your characters have to be believable. I have found it is very difficult for people to lie to me now because I am always dealing with the problem of deception.''
 
Artistic and Moral Vision
Not that readers of his stories would believe he had ever been unskeptical. Some of his stories have sharp humor, but the vision of life they present is often dark, and in them innocent people may be set upon, as one reviewer put it, by remarkably inventive and tenacious moral monsters.
Writing, Mr. Trevor said, has changed his view of the world - ''I've learned a lot I could not have learned if I were not a writer'' - but it has not made him a harsher judge of people. ''Personally I am pessimistic, but there is a kind of optimism in writing itself and it balances the pessimism'' he said. Presumably it is that tension that leads many critics to talk about his moral vision.
He does not talk about that. His original vision was artistic, strictly. As a boy he read thrillers, ''any crime story I could get my hands on, and I thought I would like to write those, too,'' he said. ''But in school I found everyone wanted to write, and why would I do what everyone else wanted to?''
So he became a sculptor and for about 15 years made his living with a chisel. ''But a terrible thing happened. My sculpture became more and more abstract, and finally I did not like it at all. There is hardly a worse thing could happen to an artist.''
Seeking a way out, he found a job writing advertising copy in the early 1960's. ''This was absurd,'' he said. ''They would give me four lines or so to write and four or five days to write it in. It was so boring. But they had given me this typewriter to work on, so I just started writing stories. I sometimes think all the people who were missing in my sculpture gushed out into the stories.''
So, does the uncanny accidental quality of many of his characters' lives belong to his own? If he had been able to determine his own life, he would still be living in County Cork where he was born, he guesses. Economic conditions there were terrible in the early 50's, when he left college. First he went to Northern Ireland to teach art, but his school went bankrupt and he went to England to find work. Once he became a writer, he said, he could have returned to Ireland. ''But by then I had become a wanderer, and one way and another, I just stayed in England,'' he said. ''I hated leaving Ireland. I was very bitter at the time. But, had it not happened, I think I might never have written at all.''

The Media Business
A new kind of bookstore is thriving by offering an immense range of titles and giving customers a comfortable atmosphere and expert sales help. The stores track inventories as large as 115,000 titles with computers. One group of stores requires job applicants to pass test to determine how well acquainted they are with a wide range of authors. [Page A1.] 
Television industry executives expect ''Twin Peaks'' to stay on the air when ABC announces its fall television season today. Despite a sharp drop in the show's ratings after the first episode, the size of its audience seems to have stabilized. [D1.]
While advertisers say they want breakthrough advertising, agency executives contend their clients want to play it safe and are relying too much on tests to determine how effective a campaign is in reaching consumers. [D14.]
A tiny ad agency in San Francisco serves as the conscience of the industry. The Public Media Center promotes consumer rights and social change. [D14.]
The Institute of Advanced Advertising Studies each year conducts a competition for the ad industry's best and brightest young people. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D15.]
 
 
 
Companies
The $1.5 billion merger of the Lotus Development Corporation and Novell Inc. collapsed after the two software companies failed to agree on the composition of the board for the new company. Although the merger intended to capitalize on trends in the industry, it received mixed reviews from analysts. [D1.]
After years of diversification, Coca-Cola has changed course and is becoming one-product company. By concentrating on soft drinks and on growing abroad, the company is hoping to increase its profits. [D1.]
Thomas J. Watson Jr., who led I.B.M. to dominance in the computer industry, recalls the glory and fame and the personal conflicts of his years with the company in his memoirs, which will be released on Wednesday. [D1.]

Xian Aircraft of China has shifted a large portion of its business from military to civilian production, and its executives dream of being the first Chinese manufacturer of large jetliners. [D4.]
Norway is worried that North Sea energy wealth has lulled the country into laziness and has decided to put oil and gas revenues in a special fund. [D4.]

Interest rates are expected to stay in a narrow range through the early summer, after wild gyrations in the last five weeks, bond market analysts say. [D13.]

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
At ABC, Several Motives For Keeping 'Twin Peaks'

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
The future of ''Twin Peaks,'' the most-talked-about new television show this year, will be decided today when ABC announces its schedule for the fall television season.
Industry executives say they expect ABC to order new episodes of the series, an offbeat, stylishly produced story of a small logging town in the Pacific Northwest, where murder and other intrigues lurk amid the dense trees.
Although the show's ratings dropped sharply after the first episode, they have leveled off in recent weeks. Still, the publicity surrounding ''Twin Peaks'' has not abated. It has already been labeled by critics as the show of the 1990's, establishing what all three networks are calling the trend for the next television season: originality in programming. Brandon Tartikoff, president of NBC Entertainment, and Jeff Sagansky, president of CBS Entertainment, have said that a main goal for the coming season is to create original programs with new formats. Their statements, made when they announced their program development plans to advertisers, have widely been interpreted in the industry as allusions to the creative originality of ''Twin Peaks.'' 
''Twin Peaks'' brought to weekly television the quality of movie directing, with unusually deliberative pacing, surrealistic themes, bizarre characters and unpredictable humor. It is directed by David Lynch, the director of the film ''Blue Velvet.''
This pursuit of original programming gives ABC an overriding reason for keeping the show on its schedule next fall, or at the least committing to it as a back-up series to replace a weak show from the fall lineup.
But ABC has other motives for holding on to what became the television phenomenon of the year.
''If ABC decides to pass, the Fox Network will pick it up and use it on Sunday night where it will only come back to haunt ABC,'' said Paul Schulman, whose agency, the Paul Schulman Company, buys television time for advertisers.
The series is almost certain to end up somewhere if ABC decides to cancel it because its production company, Worldvision Enterprises, is already making profits from the sale of ''Twin Peaks'' overseas, where it has proved to be enormously popular.
 
Link in Network's Plan
In addition, ''Twin Peaks'' is the last important link in ABC's five-year plan for rebuilding the network.
Ratings for the show indicate that it has found a dependable, if not hit-sized audience, of 18 to 19 percent of the viewers from 9 to 10 Thursday nights, even though it faces stiff competition from the high-rated ''Cheers'' on NBC. And its audience largely consists of younger women viewers, the most desired audience for advertisers because they buy the most consumer products.
''If the audience demographics stay that good,'' Mr. Schulman said, ''ABC may be in a situation where it can charge a premium price for commercials.''
Mr. Schulman cited the example of a former NBC show, ''St. Elsewhere,'' which never had strong overall ratings but attracted a loyal audience of young professionals. NBC made a large profit on it each season.
ABC has moved the final episode of ''Twin Peaks'' to Wednesday at 10 P.M. this week, the last night of the May ratings sweep period. ABC believes a substantial audience will tune in, hoping to see the central murder mystery solved.
 
Stoddard's Philosophy
No matter what its future, ''Twin Peaks'' has validated the programming philosophy of Brandon Stoddard, the former president of ABC Entertainment, who set in motion the plan to remake first the network's image and then its profit column.
Mr. Stoddard's philosophy was executed by Chad Hoffman, the vice president of drama series for ABC until last spring. Mr. Hoffman commissioned ''Twin Peaks'' from Mr. Lynch and the producer Mark Frost.
''We had a strategy to turn the network around by taking shots and being patient,'' Mr. Hoffman said. ''It was basically what NBC had done to pull itself up in the early 80's.''
NBC, after years of prime-time failure, adopted a strategy of inviting the best writers and producers in Hollywood to do their best work without the threat of network interference. At the time, ABC had a reputation for tightly controlling each series.
After NBC pushed ABC deep into the ratings basement, Mr. Stoddard was brought in by the network's new owner, Capital Cities Inc., as president of entertainment in 1985. He declared an end to the old style at ABC and said the network would strive for shows that ''stood for something.''
 
Economic Strategy
Mr Hoffman said, ''Underneath it all was an economic strategy: turn the network around and make money.''
That took some time. ''In our first year, we lost about $50 million,'' he said. ''This year ABC will make tens of millions from its prime-time shows. It's like anything else. All you have to do is commit yourself to making a good product.''
By the time that Mr. Lynch and Mr. Frost decided to make a television show, ABC had already accomplished part of its goal: it had put several new and unusual programs on its schedule. The most significant forerunner to ''Twin Peaks'' was a show that Mr. Hoffman had fought to get on the air, ''Thirtysomething.''
Mr. Hoffman met with Mr. Lynch and Mr. Frost and discussed their idea. ''I told them to think of it as 'Peyton Place' for the 90's.'' They first produced an elaborate map of the town, then a newspaper talking about its characters. Finally they turned in a pilot script.''
''I read it in about 45 minutes and said, 'we've got to do this,' '' Mr. Hoffman said.
Mr. Stoddard said the same thing. The deal for the series was made. Last spring, when networks begin to put together their fall schedules, Mr. Stoddard announced that he was leaving programming to take charge of ABC's production unit. Mr. Hoffman left at the same time to start his own production company.
Among the last recommendations Mr. Stoddard made to his successor, Robert A. Iger, was that he put ''Twin Peaks'' on the air. ''We said: 'The ball's in play. Keep it rolling,' '' Mr. Hoffman said.

LENGTH: 847 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Bigger Bank Role Is Urged On Latin Debt

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 20

 BODY:
A report on the Latin American debt crisis by the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America recommends that a greater share of the burden for resolving it be borne by commercial creditor banks.
The report says the banks ought to be ''confronted with a system of incentives and sanctions that politely push them collectively into settling their unserviceable claims.''
At the end of 1989, Latin America's combined foreign debt was $422 billion. About 60 percent of that was owed to commercial banks in the United States, Europe and Asia, and the rest to foreign governments and multilateral lending agencies. $90 Billion Is Requested The commission praises the approach of Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady of the United States -known as the Brady Plan - as being ''conceptually on the right track.'' But it said the Brady Plan's provisions should be formalized among the industrialized nations. Such an accord, it said, should include a tripling, to $90 billion, of public funds committed to debt reduction and the elimination of regulatory and tax obstacles to debt write-offs in creditor countries, particularly the United States. 
The study also notes that because application of the provisions of the Brady Plan is done on a slow-moving, voluntary basis that depends largely on the will of creditor governments and banks, the individual debtor governments have drawn attention to their situations by unilaterally declaring a moratorium on debt servicing.
The study was presented earlier this month in Caracas, Venezuela, before a ministerial level meeting of delegations from Western Hemisphere nations.
The study is a companion document to another study, which essentially endorses the shift toward free-market economies in most Latin American nations but raises questions about how money will be found to deal with the region's growing poverty and social needs while the economic adjustments are being made.
The debt study, which is not likely to produce any immediate response, says one way to find money to confront poverty is by eliminating that portion of each country's foreign debt that is beyond its servicing ability.
 
Strategy Has Flaws
''We think the international debt strategy is good, but it has flaws,'' Gert Rosenthal, executive secretary of the Economic Commission, said in an interview Friday at the organization's regional headquarters here.
''Voluntary measures are not enough,'' he said. ''Creditor governments have to move quicker and be more militant toward the banks.''
Mr. Rosenthal said the United States delegation at the conference considered the $90 billion cost for debt relief too high.
A spokeswoman for the Treasury Department said she could not comment on the report since she had not seen it.
In arguing for the foreign banks to directly assume greater losses in the Latin debt picture, the study asserts that the banks had a shared responsibility for the origin of the crisis through risky lending practices. It said the other causes were poor economic management by the countries accepting the loans and the collapse in the prices of commodities exported by Latin American countries in the early 1980's.
Mr. Rosenthal said there had been ''a lot of finger pointing'' about who was responsible for the crisis but that he thought the responsibility was the result of ''massive miscalculation in the late 70's and early 80's in terms of where the world economy was heading.''
''The multilateral agencies, the banks, and the governments all miscalculated,'' he said.
The study says the excessive lending to Latin America in the late 1970's was a classic case of overexpansion followed by troubles in the credit markets.
Contrary to the assertion that ''the market knows best,'' the report says that in times of plentiful money, lenders and borrowers tend ''to develop myopia concerning the underlying future repayment capacity and default risk.''
Noting that the big banks were then awash in petrodollars and were under pressure from their own governments to recycle them, the study says loans were often made because of a particular bank's desire to expand its market share rather than on the basis of creditworthiness.
Mr. Rosenthal acknowledged that debtor governments choosing to reduce their debt through the present Brady Plan or under the stepped-up provisions advocated in the study would not be able to consider again receiving voluntary credit from private banks for a very long time.
But he said he was not concerned about the possibility that debtor countries accepting debt reduction would be unable to return to private credit markets.
 
Banks for Short-Term Loans
''I think the commercial banks should go back to doing what they do well, which is short-term lending for trade and business,'' he said, ''and that international agencies should do the long-term development lending.''
He also said the lack of availability of credit from commercial banks would have the beneficial effect of forcing Latin American governments to ''marshal local savings'' for investments and development.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Seeking U.S. Aid For Health Care

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
AMERICAN companies have for years opposed national health insurance, and they still bridle at the phrase. But they have a history of falling back on Government aid in difficult moments - the Federal bailouts of the Chrysler Corporation and of various failing banks being prominent examples of this reliance in the 1980's. Now Corporate America is seeking Government help in controlling the cost of health insurance.
The incipient appeal makes many companies gun shy, even as they organize to present their case to Congress. Newspaper headlines in March, for example, proclaimed that a new lobbying group represented major companies seeking ''national health insurance.'' 
''When they saw that headline, a number of the companies almost dropped out,'' said William Ketchum, a vice president at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and a director of the lobbying group.
Nevertheless, a common corporate message is slowly emerging, one that starts with the observation that American business, on its own, cannot control health insurance costs. Government, therefore, has to help with the process. Even Allied-Signal Inc., hailed as perhaps the most innovative company at reducing health-care costs, demurs at continuing at the task without Federal assistance.
''The issue of cost-efficient health care is bigger than any one company, or group of companies, can ever hope to resolve alone,'' said Edward L. Hennessy Jr., Allied-Signal's chairman, in a recent speech. And Allied, with more than 100,000 employees, has trimmed the annual increase in its health insurance costs to less than 10 percent, from more than 25 percent in 1987. (The corporate norm is a rise of 20 percent to 30 percent a year.) Corporations resist being pinned down on proposals for Government help. But in interviews with nearly a dozen executives, union officials and consultants to corporations on health benefits, two themes repeatedly popped up.
One was that Government will probably have to pay for health insurance for certain groups. Retirees, for example, might be shifted entirely off corporate rolls and onto expanded Government health plans, including Medicare. And small companies without private health insurance might get Government subsidies to help pay the premiums for the 16 million workers on their payrolls. Or they might pay reduced rates for coverage through existing Government health plans.
''Once we set up an efficient Medicare-Medicaid program, I would permit any individual or any employer to buy into it at reasonable rates,'' said Walter Maher, who directs Chrysler's lobbying efforts to increase the Government's role in health care.
The second theme involves standards for medical care: the Government would set them for everyone. A youngster having his tonsils out might be required, under any health insurance policy, to have the operation as an outpatient. Another rule might set guidelines for coronary bypass operations. Such a rule might end up increasing the frequency of these operations in Hartford while reducing their number in Boston. Today, Boston doctors are much more likely than Hartford doctors to use the expensive procedure, a study by the Rand Corporation found.
''What a lot of companies are looking for is someone else, specifically government, to make the decisions on rationing health care,'' said Ralph Pollack, chief operating officer of Value Care, an employee health-care plan sponsored by 19 Connecticut companies. If a heart patient were to die and the family were to attribute the death to the failure to authorize a bypass operation, then the blame would fall not on the patient's employer, but on the mandatory government standards. ''That is one of the motivations for the push for government health policy,'' Mr. Pollack said.
For the time being, the big corporate cost-cutting push is ''managed health care.'' Allied-Signal, the Southwestern Bell Corporation and others contract with doctors and hospitals to treat their employees, usually at fixed rates for different procedures. Each employee selects a primary doctor to treat standard ailments and make referrals to specialists in the managed-care network.
The cost-cutting comes in two ways: the discount rates that big companies are able to get and the shifting of part of the cost to employees if they use non-network doctors.
But the pioneers in managed health care say that even with these programs, health-care costs still keep rising at nearly 10 percent a year. The question is whether the various corporate proposals for Government help will finally bring the cost increases into line with the nation's much lower inflation rate - or whether Corporate America will find itself pushing Congress ever closer to a health-care system operated and financed primarily by Government.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Civilian Shift For Chinese Plane Maker

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YANLIANG, China

 BODY:
Half a dozen years ago, the Xian Aircraft Company made military products exclusively, from early-warning systems to bombers.
But last year, only a fifth of the company's production went to the military, and a significant share of the $6.4 million profit came from sales of components to foreign aircraft companies. At the company's headquarters here in the Shaanxi Province in central China, the military production lines in one factory are still and empty. Across the plant floor, the commercial sections are humming and the workers bustling. 
Officials of Xian (pronounced SHEE-ahn) believe that future profits lie in developing products for civilian use. Their dream is to make Xian the first Chinese airplane manufacturer to build a passenger plane the size of a Boeing 737 or an MD-90.
 
Hopes for 'a Chinese Boeing'
''We want the chance to develop a new aircraft,'' Fu Baoxin, vice president of the company, said.
And Hong Chuanyu, a deputy director who spent more than a year training at the Boeing Company in Seattle, said, ''If our technical level and management level improves, I think Xian Aircraft Company will be a Chinese Boeing.'' Mr. Fu added that that prospect was years off.
Xian Aircraft, which employs 18,000 workers, is an example of the growing fascination among China's military producers with the civilian market. The company's record suggests the rewards that Chinese companies can reap in selling civilian products, but it also shows that it can be a very difficult transition.
One lesson the company says it has learned is that producing for the civilian market is much more demanding and requires an extensive marketing and sales staff, which the company did not have before.
''It is much harder to produce for the civilian market than for the military,'' Mr. Fu said. ''Safety is more important for passenger aircraft.''
 
Still Makes Bombers
The company still makes two kinds of bombers for China's military, but orders are rare.
Zeal for the commercial market has been one of the most visible changes in many Chinese military factories, as production has gradually shifted from guns to washing machines, clothing and even the service industry. The People's Liberation Army partly owns the Palace Hotel in Beijing, one of the finest hotels in China.
At Xian Aircraft, handfuls of workers still mill around with little to do, but during the last seven years, overall production has increased sixfold, to $64 million, the company says, and managers pay more attention to efficiency and quality. The company began producing aircraft in 1959, but 1985 was the first time it made a profit.
 
Passenger Plane Since 1987
Since 1987, Xian Aircraft has been making the Yun-7, which seats 45 passengers and is the largest passenger aircraft that China makes on its own. China's airline capacity is strained, but even with the shortage of seats domestic airlines have purchased only 60 of the 45-seat airplanes. Xian has the capacity to make 40 planes a year, but it is making only about 15, for lack of orders.
The plane does not meet international standards, but by the end of this year, the company hopes to have a lighter version, with advanced avionics from Western suppliers, ready for flight testing. Moreover, it is cooperating with Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm of West Germany, to design a 90-seat plane to cover medium distances. It is not clear whether the Chinese Government will finance the manufacturing project.
Transformation of the company, and of other military operations across the country, began in the early to mid-1980's, when the Government cut the nation's military by about one million soldiers and permitted military factories to produce civilian products.
 
Washing Machine Craze
At first, the company went into making washing machines, a craze in the early 1980's, but after a few trial runs and unsuccessful attempts at the consumer market, it returned to the aerospace industry and began to supply parts, under cooperative arrangements, for American and European aircraft companies.
Since March 1988, the company has been producing a vertical fin for Boeing, and now Xian Aircraft plans to make another airplane part, the horizontal stabilizer, under a similar arrangement. It also makes doors for the Airbus A300 and parts for Canadian, French and Italian companies.
''You're overwhelmed by the fact that the facilities are cold and the workers at the lathes wear no safety glasses,'' a foreign executive said. ''It is amazing they can accomplish what they can accomplish. They are very good craftsmen.''
 
Shortcomings and Competition
Xian Aircraft recognizes that its shortcomings put it decades behind foreign aircraft manufacturers and that it also has competition from other domestic makers, particularly those based in the cities of Shanghai and Shenyang. A Shanghai company currently assembles MD-80's in a co-production agreement with the Douglas Aircraft Company, a unit of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
Another aircraft maker in Harbin has already exported its Yun-12, a smaller though more advanced plane, to countries in Southeast Asia.
Mr. Fu, the Xian vice president, noted that Chinese companies had a long way to go to catch up with Western manufacturers. He said that his company was making 3 vertical fins a month, while Boeing was making 14 a month.
''The facilities cost money and the technology takes time to learn,'' he added. ''It will be at least 10 years before we can be like Boeing.''
