HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Frenchman Head of New Aid Bank

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 20

 BODY:
The 42 member nations that are creating a bank to provide financial aid to Eastern Europe have elected the chief personal adviser of President Francois Mitterrand of France to head the bank and have selected London as its headquarters.
After weeks of intense, sometimes bitter campaigning in which the Netherlands sought to have a former Dutch Finance Minister chosen, Jacques Attali, a 46-year-old Mitterrand aide and longtime Socialist, was elected on Saturday to be the president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
The head of the Dutch delegation, Cees Maas, said his country would continue to fight the decision on the presidency and location, asserting that Saturday's vote was not legally binding. $12 Billion in Capital Representatives at the meeting said they hoped that the bank, which will have $12 billion in capital, could begin lending money next spring to Eastern European nations to help them build efficient market economies. It will also lend money to fight pollution and for road construction and other public projects. The bank will be one of the largest international aid efforts since World War II. 
On May 29, ministers from the 42 nations, including the United States, Japan, the Soviet Union and the 12 European Community nations, are scheduled to sign a formal agreement in Paris setting up the bank.
The delegates to the meeting on Saturday failed to reach a consensus on who should head the bank, and the matter was put to a vote. Mr. Attali received 32 votes, while Onno Ruding, the former Dutch Finance Minister, received 8. Two nations abstained.
 
Selection Called Fitting
Several delegates said Mr. Attali's selection seemed fitting because it was President Mitterrand who originally proposed the bank last October, based on an idea of Mr. Attali's.
Mr. Attali led the series of meetings at which member nations negotiated the details of setting up the bank. The Netherlands, Belgium and several other small European Community nations objected, saying that the large industrial nations had been trying to impose the choice of Mr. Attali on them.
What is more, the Dutch complained, it was unfair that a Frenchman would head the new bank when the French already had top posts at so many international organizations. Jacques Delors leads the European Community, Michel Camdessus the International Monetary Fund and Jean-Claude Paye the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
 
Never a Banker
Several delegates said they had reservations about Mr. Attali because he never worked as a banker. Mr. Ruding, who long headed the I.M.F.'s policy-making committee, has a reputation as a tough fiscal conservative.
When the bank was initially proposed, some people suggested that it be based in Budapest or Prague, but European Community officials decided that since community members would be putting in a majority of the bank's capital, its headquarters should be in the community.
Delegates said that at the recent I.M.F. meeting in Washington a deal was struck in which Britain agreed to support Mr. Attali as president if France would support London as the headquarters.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Outlook Now Is for Stable Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Interest rates have gyrated wildly for five weeks, but credit market analysts say they are likely to fluctuate within a fairly narrow trading range through the early part of the summer.
If they are right, movements in interest rates would closely resemble developments from February to mid-April - when bond yields were locked in a band that ranged from 8 3/8 percent to 8 5/8 percent.
Fearful of inflation and an accelerating economy, traders in the period from mid-April until early May pushed bond yields up more than 40 basis points, or hundredths of a point, to just above 9 percent.
After economic data released over the last few weeks caused those worries to evaporate almost as quickly as they materialized, the Treasury bonds due 2020 were offered at a price to yield 8.69 percent by the end of last week. 
''For the time being, rates should trade within a relatively tight 8 3/8 percent to 8 3/4 percent range that has characterized most of 1990,'' said Mitchell J. Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The last few weeks, he said, have been ''a short, strange trip.''
 
From Hysteria to Calm
Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities, said that ''we have gone from a few months of hysteria in bond markets around the world to a calmer tone.'' He continued, ''That means we could have a pretty dull summer, which after the recent period might not be so bad.''
The abrupt rate swings were prompted in large part by economic and inflation figures that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned in February were apt to be distorted by weather and other special factors. The volatility has left many analysts unsure about how the economy and inflation really are faring.
''We think the economy is growing at a 2 percent to 2.5 percent rate and that the core rate of inflation is at 4.5 percent,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. ''But that is just a best guess.''
 
Interpreting Data Is Difficult
Interpreting recent data is almost certainly proving to be as difficult for the Fed as it has been for private analysts and traders. As a result, the Fed, which has not altered its stance on monetary policy since mid-December, will probably remain on hold for some time to come.
''I would side with the view that even after the Fed sees the next set of monthly reports in June it will be cautious,'' said Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc. ''I can see them holding steady for some time.''
As always, there are potential hazards to a steadier rate outlook.
Even though inflation appears to be receding from its rapid acceleration in the first quarter - a rate of 4.5 percent to 5 percent - it is still higher than the bond market and the Federal Reserve would like.
 
Concern About the Federal Deficit
In addition, concern about the Federal budget deficit, largely absent from the credit markets for the past several years, has suddenly re-emerged as an important but not yet overriding issue.
A revealing test of the market's sensitivity to the deficit may come today, when the Treasury releases its budget report for April.
Traditionally, income tax receipts have generated healthy surpluses in April, and most economists are confident that last month's figures were no exception. A surplus number that comes in under expectations, however, could be a problem.
''Estimates on last month's surplus range from a low of $37 billion to a high of $42 billion,'' said William N. Griggs, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. ''A number that is smaller than about $40 billion might be poorly received in the market.''
Bond prices tumbled on April 20 after the Treasury announced that the deficit in March had reached a record $53.3 billion.
''Over the past few years, as the numbers started to improve, the deficit became a positive,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities Inc. ''But recently we have started to move in the other direction, and sensitivity about the issue is developing.''
A record $10.8 billion auction of new two-year Treasury notes on Wednesday and continuation of discussions in Washington about ways to cut the 1991 fiscal deficit will also serve as a barometer of the Government's financial problems.
In addition to the record sale of two-year notes on Wednesday, the Treasury will auction $8.5 billion of new five-year notes on Thursday.
The auctions are likely to be the dominant events during a week when few new substantive economic reports are scheduled to be released.
Most analysts anticipate that durable-goods orders, scheduled for release on Wednesday, declined in April after two consecutive monthly gains. And a Commerce Department revision on Thursday of estimated growth in the first quarter is likely to show the gross national product expanded at a somewhat slower pace than the initial estimate of 2.1 percent.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
The Armies of Europe

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
President Bush and some of his advisers are deeply concerned about Soviet reluctance to move toward a treaty reducing conventional forces in Europe, which they see as the key to making political change in Eastern Europe irreversible by getting the Soviet Army out.
Although overshadowed in recent days by progress on limiting strategic arms and chemical weapons, the talks on conventional forces that are under way in Vienna have stalled amid signs that Moscow may be rethinking the value of an agreement that would drastically curtail its military presence in Eastern Europe.
In public, President Bush and his colleagues have put the best face on the outcome of discussions in Moscow last week, arguing that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has achieved enough to make probable a successful summit meeting next week. Mr. Bush himself said that what Mr. Baker had achieved on strategic arms meant that ''we'll have a good summit.''
 
Some Public Annoyance
But even in public, some irritation shows about the deadlock over conventional forces, the tanks, armies and non-nuclear air power that both sides have in Europe. Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, said on Saturday that United States-Soviet relations were back on track, but he also accused the Soviets of stonewalling on conventional arms. 
And a senior counselor to the President said ''the deadlock on Europe is really very disturbing at this late date, not because it will disrupt the summit - it won't - but because it may mean that we won't get a conventional arms agreement by the end of this year after all.''
If there is no agreement in the Vienna talks, which involve all the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Orgainzation and the Warsaw Pact, an important meeting of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Co-operation in Europe, tentatively scheduled for December in Paris, would probably be postponed.
 
Centerpiece, in U.S. View
For months, the White House has been arguing that the conventional arms treaty is the centerpiece of plans for a new, safer Europe - a kind of insurance policy, as one official put it, ''against a change of attitude in the Soviet Union.'' Another American strategist said, ''This treaty far exceeds any others in importance.''
What the United States wants to do is get most or all of 585,000 remaining Soviet troops out of Eastern Europe and oblige the Soviets to destroy tens of thousands of tanks and artillery pieces. Success would mean that no serious conventional military threat against Western Europe existed.
And once the Soviet Union pulled back, a White House planner said today, it would become far more difficult, if not in practice impossible, for any harder-line government in Moscow to try to re-establish power in eastern Europe.
On the surface, the issues stalling the talks are disagreements over the maximum number of aircraft to be allowed; limits on forces deployed by individual Western countires, as opposed to the Western alliance as a whole, and differences on the proper definition of tanks.
Some State Department experts argue that the Soviet stonewalling results from the inability of senior Kremlin officials to find enough time in the current chaotic situation in the Soviet Union to focus on the issue. Mr. Baker seemed to reflect that thinking last weekend when he said, ''Our counterparts apparently weren't able to respond meaningfully at this time.''
 
Sticking Point: Germany
But others in the Administration argue quite the opposite: that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his advisers are trying to figure out how to retain at least a modicum of military strength and influence in the former satellite countries along the western border of the Soviet Union, which Moscow has seen for decades as an indispensable buffer against NATO forces.
Another major element in their thinking, United States officials say, is how to deal with the troops that are brought home and to keep them from imposing fresh burdens on an already badly weakened economy. A third consideration, some analysts believe, may be a Soviet desire to keep major troop structures in place as a bargaining counter on a unified Germany.
''The Soviets will move on conventional forces when they think they've done all they can to neutralize Germany, and not a minute before,'' a European ambassador here suggested.
By yielding more on strategic weapons than on conventional forces, the Soviet leaders have in effect forced a reversal in the Bush Administration's priorities. Unable to make progress on their No. 1 goal, Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker have had to settle for progress toward a secondary though still critically important accord.
In addition, the Soviets are still holding out on the central question in German reunification. Economic integration is scheduled to take place in less than six weeks, on July 2, but there is still no agreement between the Soviet Union and the Western powers about what politico-military posture the new Germany will take up after unification.
 
'New European Architecture'
The United States and its allies have been insisting that Germany play a full role in NATO, but the Soviet Union insists on German neutrality or membership in both NATO and the Warsaw Pact, which is much the same. This difficulty and the related trouble in the conventional arms talks makes the ''new European architecture'' of which Mr. Baker has spoken seem remote.
But it may be that Mr. Gorbachev, who faces a difficult and potentially tumultuous Communist Party Congress only a month or so after returning to Moscow from Washington, wants to postpone any agreements on a new Europe - with the inevitable reminders of the greater Soviet strength in the old one - until after that meeting has ended.

LENGTH: 1446 words

HEADLINE: Young as Candidate: Hard Road, Light Touch

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 20

 BODY:
Andrew Young offers little homilies of hope as he travels around Georgia in his quest for the governorship.
He tells of the 84-year-old man who came up to him in Ben Hill County in south Georgia and identified himself as ''a Talmadge man'' - not Herman Talmadge, the former United States Senator, but his father, Gene, the suspender-snapping 1940's champion of rural values and strict segregation. The old man told Mr. Young, ''I've never voted for a colored before, but I reckon you got my vote.''
 
Defying the Norms
Mr. Young tells these stories to make people believe that a candidate who defies so many of the norms and odds of Georgia politics - as a black man, as a former lieutenant to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., as a former Mayor of Atlanta, which has long been considered a troublesome base for a statewide campaign - can make it to the governor's office.
But eight weeks before the Democratic primary here, Mr. Young's optimism is up against some hard political realities. 
He must overcome three major Democratic opponents and make his way through a Democratic primary, a runoff that is widely considered a certainty, and a general election. That is a much harder political task than what confronted L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, who became the country's first black elected governor last year. Mr. Wilder had held statewide office and was able to win the gubernatorial nomination at a state party convention. ''I've got three races to run,'' Mr. Young said. ''He only had one.''
 
Assembling the Coalition
As he tries to assemble a winning coalition, Mr. Young is walking a difficult line, trying to energize and reassure his base among blacks, trying to reach out to the younger suburban whites who are considered his best source of white support and trying to demonstrate that in the small towns of south Georgia he can win converts.
''My favorite spiritual is, ''Lord, I don't feel noways tired, 'cause we've come too far from where we started from,'' he told an audience in Macon last week. They were gathered in a setting that bore witness to the song: a restaurant in an antebellum mansion, a retrofitted husk of the Old South built by a farmer whose fortunes were dashed by Sherman's March to the Sea.
Mr. Young's career has long been emblematic of the onrush of history in the New South, from the streets of Birmingham to the halls of Congress, from the United Nations, where he served as chief United States representative under President Jimmy Carter, to the skyline of Atlanta, where he just finished two terms as Mayor.
Today, many politicians here say Mr. Young has a shot at the governorship, but no one underestimates how hard it will be for the 58-year-old Democrat to prevail. A poll last month by The Atlanta Journal-Constitution showed him neck and neck with Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller in the race for the nomination. He drew strong black support but 16 percent of the participating whites.
Blacks are expected to cast more than a fourth of the Democratic primary votes, so Mr. Young is almost assured a place in any runoff. Runoffs are held in Georgia if no candidate captures more than 50 percent of the vote.
Mr. Young's supporters say they hope he can stay largely above the fray in the first primary as the white candidates struggle for the second slot; Roy Barnes, a State Senator from the Atlanta suburbs, is considered Mr. Miller's strongest rival.
The other candidates include Lauren (Bubba) McDonald, a State Representative, and Lester Maddox, the former Governor and archetype of 1960's resistance to integration, whose support barely registered in the newspaper's poll.
That poll, conducted April 13-24, showed Mr. Young supported by 29 percent, Mr. Miller with 23 percent, Mr. Barnes with 10 percent, Mr. McDonald with 5 percent, Mr. Maddox with 3 percent, and 29 percent undecided. That telephone survey, based on interviews with 652 people considered likely to vote in the primaries, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
 
Young's Base Among Blacks
Even if the white candidate who makes the runoff is battered and bleeding, Mr. Young faces a difficult campaign. There is the factor of race. ''It's very hard to measure,'' said Merle Black, professor of political science at Emory University and a consultant to the Atlanta newspaper poll. ''But it's an underlying factor. It's an underlying factor everywhere, any time you have white and black candidates.''
Mr. Young's base among blacks may protect him from some of the harshest attacks; any Democratic nominee must look for strong black support to prevail in the Georgia general election. But Mr. Young has vulnerabilities. He says he is lagging in fund-raising behind Mr. Miller and Mr. Barnes. His free-wheeling oratorical style, notable in his days at the United Nations, provides rich fodder for 30-second attack ads, although none have been broadcast. And What of the G.O.P.? Moreover, any shortcomings as Mayor of this city of 452,900 people, which is 68 percent black, are expected to get an ample airing; Mr. Miller is already assailing Mr. Young for the rise in crime in Atlanta. James Carville, Mr. Miller's strategist, said of Mr. Young, ''He's not a mind-the-store kind of guy, and people traditionally like their governors to try to pay attention to that.''
Whoever emerges with the Democratic nomination will face a strong and well-financed Republican candidate. The expected nominee is Johnny Isakson, the minority leader in the Georgia House of Representatives, who has a base in Atlanta's suburbs. Republicans have not held the Georgia governorship since Reconstruction, but they scent a rich opportunity this year.
Much of the campaign debate so far has centered on education, economic development, crime and the environment. Mr. Young has gathered consultants and poll takers, masters of sound bites and targeted messages, but he has never been a tractable politician. His message on the campaign trail is vintage Young: a belief in the redemptive power of business, a buoyant pledge to bring the same economic development that has occurred in Atlanta to the entire state. [An adviser close to Mr. Young and Jimmy Carter said that the former President was staying out of the primary, as is his custom.] Pecans, Carpets, Factories He talks of doubling the exports of pecans and carpets, bringing the Olympics to Georgia in 1996 and bringing jobs to Willacoochee and Hawkinsville. He seeks alliances with small-town white businessmen like the banker from Hawkinsville who rose after a Young speech last week to boast about the former Mayor's international contacts and declare, ''I don't know any Bubbas, any Zells or any Lesters who could open those kind of doors.''
Mr. Young walks carefully on race. He told a small group of blacks at a house party in Macon last week that he had made sure his appearance at the recent convention of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's National Rainbow Coalition did not coincide with Governor Wilder's.
''If you had a picture of me, Doug and Jesse, I was convinced we would see that picture on the street the week before the election,'' he said. ''You know, saying, 'They took over Virginia; now they're trying to take over Atlanta.' ''
Mr. Young has distanced himself from a lawsuit filed here this month by the American Civil Liberties Union on behalf of a group of black political and community leaders who are challenging the runoff system as racially discriminatory, a cause pushed hard by Mr. Jackson in his 1984 campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
That suit has injected a powerful new element of uncertainty into the Georgia elections. Some of Mr. Young's supporters are worrying that that it will only exacerbate the race issue.
 
'Something I Have to Do'
''I'm interested in winning the general election - that's the only thing that counts for me,'' Mr. Young said in an interview, ''and I think the best chance of winning the general election is to go into it with a majority in the Democratic Party.''
He has long been known as an unflappable, optimistic man; old friends say it is an inevitable byproduct of the life he has lead. As his small plane left Atlanta the other day, left behind the gleaming skyline for the flat fields beyond, Mr. Young was asked if he had a burning desire to be governor.
''I just think it's something I have to do,'' he replied. ''If I don't get elected I think I'd probably say, 'Free at last.' But I have to give it the best shot I possibly can.''
When the flight got bumpy, Mr. Young went to sleep; sometimes, he said with a laugh, you have to ''put it in the hands of the Lord.''

HEADLINE: Montreal Journal;
They Speak French, but Their Language Is Money

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTREAL, May 21

 BODY:
Jacques Menard has a tan, a four-wheel-drive Jeep, a good golf stroke, volunteer duties at Oxfam, gold cuff links, a pool, and a watercolor of the Montreal stock exchange hanging on his office wall. But like any self-respecting executive in New York or Chicago, he bridles at the word yuppie.
''None of us see ourselves as yuppies,'' said Mr. Menard, who became a company director at age 29 and is now, at 44, a vice chairman and managing director of the Canadian brokerage firm Burns Fry Ltd.
He added, delicately: ''We went rather quickly into leadership positions. We didn't have time to engross ourselves in the consumer culture.'' 
The ''we'' that Mr. Menard speaks of is a new generation of French Canadian business leaders. Many of them were catapulted at young ages into high-level jobs left open by English-speaking Canadian executives who fled Quebec when the separatist government of Rene Levesque took power in 1967.
 
Heated Talk of Independence
Their successful rise in professions that were once the exclusive preserve of English-speaking Canadians has captivated Quebec. So much so that the phrase ''newly confident Quebec business class'' is repeated so often as an epithet that it has taken on a sing-song lilt. But the entrepreneurs are of particular interest in Quebec these days as heated talk of independence sweeps the province for the first time in a decade.
It is taken very seriously partly because several prominent Montreal business leaders, men like Michel Gaucher, chairman of the Steinberg supermarket chain, or Claude Beland, president of Mouvement Desjardins, Quebec's largest credit union association, have stated that Quebec is strong enough economically to survive on its own.
''It's the most established, gray-hair-at-the-temple types that are saying we are not afraid,'' Andre Louzon, 31, said admiringly. Mr. Louzon, who wears Italian silk ties and owns his own corporate communications firm, noted, ''If it were just young punks, people would say, 'Who cares what you think.' ''
Mr. Louzon, incidently, did not appear offended when asked whether he was, by any chance, a yuppie. ''Exactly,'' he said, beaming. Then he set the record straight: ''Actually, I'm a dink: dual income, no kids.'' He is also an enthusiastic Quebec nationalist.
Mr. Menard, who is also president of the Montreal Chamber of Commerce, was reluctant to give his personal views on the emotional issue of independence. Though he spoke strongly of French Canadians' rights, he spoke more cautiously about economic separation.
''Quebec would be better served staying part of a larger economic entity.'' he said. ''I don't feel like a raving, foaming-at-the-mouth Marxist-Leninist if I stick up for Quebec business.''
 
Fast Pace of Change
Mr. Menard, who studied business in both Quebec and English-speaking Ontario and who is perfectly bilingual, as are his business cards, is representative of the fast-paced social changes that have transformed Montreal society.
In 1960, a newly elected Liberal Party swept out the entrenched, corrupt government to pave the way for a nationalistic French Canadian resurgence. French Canadians call it ''the quiet revolution,'' but it was also a cultural revolution that among other things saw Quebec's birth rate fall from among the highest in the world to among the lowest.
In a survey conducted in 1967, French Canadian parents were asked what profession they would prefer for their sons. Overwhelmingly, the priesthood was the first choice. When the question is asked today, business is invariably at the top of the list.
There are now more business-school students and more new businesses created per capita in Quebec each year than in English-speaking Canada or the United States.
Jean-Marie Toulouse, a professor of Entrepreneurship and Business Policy at Hautes Etudes Commerciales, explains that Quebec's new fascination with business is inspired by patriotism as much as self-interest.
''Until recently, the collective challenge for Quebecers was to preserve French language and religion, which is why most Quebec students went on to teaching or the priesthood,'' Mr. Toulouse said. ''Now the collective challenge is the Quebec economy.''
 
'American Style,' Gallic Flair
Though newspapers often attach the words ''American style'' to their titles, most Quebec business people reject the notion, taking pride in their Gallic flair.
Snapping his fingers, Daniel Lamothe, 30, a business-school student in Montreal, said: ''We're more emotional, more expressive. We are Latins.'' Yet in his gray business suit, briefcase loaded down with a calculator as big as a toaster-oven, Mr. Lamothe looked anything but emotional.
Wait until you see Toronto, he said. ''I went to a party there once, and it was like something my mother would go to - tea cakes.''

An article yesterday about French Canadian business leaders in Montreal misstated the year that the separatist government of Rene Levesque took power in Quebec. It was 1976. In some copies, a picture caption with the article misstated the age of Jacques Menard, a vice chairman and managing director of a brokerage firm. He is 44 years old.

LENGTH: 916 words

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Breaking the Mold

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, May 21

 BODY:
By voting for a party dominated by former Communists in national elections, Romania's voters made their nation unusual in the context of Eastern Europe, where recent free elections have ousted the Communist parties that ruled Poland, Hungary and East Germany for four decades.
Romanian television announced early today that Ion Iliescu and his National Salvation Front, the group that has run the country since the violent revolution overthrew the Communist Ceausescu Government in December, had won a smashing victory in this country's first free national elections in half a century.
While full official results are not yet available, Infas, a West German polling organization that took samples across the country, made refined projections today suggesting that Mr. Iliescu had won 89 percent of the votes for President, plus a commanding 73 percent for his party of former Communists in the next Romanian Parliament.
 
Heirs of Ceausescu
The Romanian electorate of 16 million, which appears to have turned out almost in its entirety, was acutely aware that Mr. Iliescu and virtually all his aides in the front had been Communists who worked for Nicolae Ceausescu, the dictator ousted in the national uprising and executed. 
They were also aware that thousands of their compatriots view the front in general and Mr. Iliescu in particular with suspicion, even hatred, and have shown these feelings, including today on the streets.
The voters were aware, too, that some foreign governments, particularly the Bush Administration, were disdainful of the front.
A number of foreign observers, including members of the United States Congress, gave a preliminary assessment that the elections were generally fair, which may help President Bush change his recently frosty attitude toward Romania.
 
Almost as Outrageous
This vote comes within 10 percentage points of the fraudulent 98 percent majorities proclaimed by Mr. Ceausescu and his Communist predecessors in elections over the last 44 years. The fundamental question now, many scholars of the Eastern European political scene say, is what the Romanians are trying to say with their votes.
Judging from interviews with workers, farmers and intellectuals over the last four days, one of the messages is that Mr. Iliescu acquired genuine popularity in his five months as interim President of Romania - partly by dint of a personality many find winning, and partly because of popular measures he initiated.
''He means stability,'' said a film critic in her 50's who has been a lifelong anti-Communist. ''I almost voted for the National Liberals, the party of my father, but at the last minute I changed my mind.''
Her mother, who is 90 years old and who was a member of Bucharest society six decades earlier, also voted for the front for the same reason.
 
A Way to Stay Employed
For workers and farmers, most of them employed until now by giant Communist enterprises or agricultural cooperatives, the front offers a prospect of gradual transition to a market economy that will safeguard their jobs and wages.
The main opposition forces, the Peasants Party and the National Liberal Party, offer an alternative - swift moves toward a free market economy and privatization of land and industry - that apparently frightened away millions of voters.
The miserable showing of these parties, which trace their origins to the turn of the century, suggest that the prewar parties have no real future in Romanian politics.
In fact, the early returns show that two new parties, the Hungarian Democratic Union and the Ecologists Party, did as well or better than the traditional parties. The Hungarian Democratic Union represents Romania's restive Hungarian minority of more than two million people, most of them living in Transylvania. This party gained more than 6 percent of the vote for Parliament - twice as much as the Peasants Party.
 
Common Market Sales Pitch
In interviews and speeches during the campaign, Mr. Iliescu vowed to lead Romania into the European Community, which would fulfill the ardent desire of nearly every Romanian to have the country accepted as a Western nation whose heritage includes a Romance language.
''We will become a Social Democratic country,'' Constantin Girbea, a Foreign Ministry press official, predicted after the front's triumph became evident.
That may be stretching things a lot; while the Communist Party itself dissolved in the fierce uprising of Dec. 22, the internal structure of the former Communist Party remains intact in Romania's cities, towns and villages and has been incorporated into the National Salvation Front. But social democracy seems at least to be Mr. Iliescu's goal - a Romania that remains left of center.
 
A Land Where Destiny Dictates
There is another dimension to the election, which did not really end until 6 A.M. today - 24 hours after the polls opened and six hours after they were supposed to close according to the election law. A prophetic essay this week in a new Bucharest paper, Anunt, by Adrian Costea captured an aspect of Romania's character in its title: ''The Mioritic fatalism.''
It is a reference to the Miorita, or ''ewe lamb'' - a centuries-old tale of a young shepherd who is warned by the lamb that other jealous shepherds intend to kill him. Instead of trying to escape, the young shepherd calmly accepts his fate.
The Romanian electorate seems to have agreed that its destiny should lie in the hands of Ion Iliescu.

HEADLINE: Auto Union to Seek Job Guarantees

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 21

 BODY:
The United Auto Workers union, meeting today to begin setting its strategy for negotiations on a new contract, is clear about its primary goal: halting the loss of members' jobs.
Union leaders said in a draft of the union's bargaining resolution that they would ask the Big Three auto makers for ironclad job guarantees ''covering every contingency.''
''Fact No. 1 is that we have a more urgent need for job security and a more legitimate claim to job and income security for our members in every sector and every workplace than at any previous time in our history,'' said Owen Bieber, the union's president. He spoke today to about 3,000 delegates, retirees and observers from union locals attending the three-day convention, at which the union is to set an agenda for contract talks that will begin this summer. 
The draft resolution says the only condition under which companies would be allowed to lay off workers is ''if the companies' long-term financial viability is truly at risk as a result of conditions beyond its control.''
 
Closings a Constant Problem
Union leaders acknowledge that this would leave an opening that companies could turn to if they encounter serious economic trouble. And union staff members say privately that more plant closings are likely at the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation, regardless of contract language.
Plant closings have been a constant problem in the 1980's, and the union's membership has dropped by more than a third, from 1.5 million to slightly under a million. The U.A.W.'s contract with the Big Three covers about 450,000 hourly workers; other union members work for other automotive companies or in other areas including the aerospace industry.
The union has made an effort before to be flexible about economic conditions in the industry while trying to achieve job protection. Under the union's 1987 contract with General Motors, the No. 1 automaker was not allowed to close plants unless sales dropped to a level that made it uneconomical to continue producing vehicles.
That provision was meant to deal with temporary drops in sales, but General Motors used the clause to close several plants that probably will not open again. The union, claiming a violation of the contract's provisions on job security, invoked an arbitration clause, but an arbitrator ruled in the company's favor.
Nonetheless, union leaders are going to ask for tight job security provisions, which they believe could force the Big Three to stop buying parts from nonunion companies to cut costs, a growing practice known as outsourcing that has led to layoffs and plant closings.
''Management would have to get real serious real fast about bringing back outsourced work and creating new work opportunities if business should decline in existing product lines,'' said Mr. Bieber.
The companies are expected to argue that they cannot do this and remain competitive with the Japanese auto makers, which have cut deeply into sales by the Big Three since the early 1980's when the Japanese companies began opening plants in this country.
The union, whose contracts with the Big Three expire on Sept. 14, is expected to approve a final bargaining resolution on Wednesday. After a month or so of bargaining separately with each of the Big Three, union negotiators are expected to meet to compare their progress.
 
Chrysler May Seek Concessions
Then in early September the union will choose one company with which it will try to reach a contract, and go on strike against if it cannot. Under industry tradition, the first contract will establish a pattern for agreements with the other automakers.
For the first time since 1982, when a financially troubled Chrysler negotiated a separate contract that included concessions, the U.A.W. will be bargaining with all of the Big Three simultaneously. Union officials said they hoped a return to simultaneous negotiations would increase the union's impact by forcing all three to accept the same contract.
But a Chrysler labor relations executive, Anthony St. John, was quoted in Detroit newspapers this week saying that Chrysler, because it has again been harder hit than the Ford Motor Company or General Motors, needs a separate and less expensive contract.

HEADLINE: Lithuania's Way Out

 BODY:
The Parliament in Vilnius is now debating a momentous issue: whether to suspend its March 11 declaration of independence. By refusing to do so, Lithuanians might well spoil the upcoming summit meeting between Presidents Bush and Gorbachev. But that would not help achieve Lithuania's independence. It would only force Soviet leaders to get tougher and weaken Washington's positive influence. 
As a practical matter, Lithuania cannot attain its legitimate national goal unless the West continues to build its new relationship with the Soviet Union. The Lithuanian Parliament now has the opportunity to knit these two dynamics together along the following lines:
The Parliament can vote a moratorium on its declaration of independence - with qualifications. Such an act would meet Moscow's demand, without invalidating Lithuania's right to statehood. Vilnius also would have to carry out its pledge to suspend laws implementing independence, including those forbidding its citizens from serving in ''foreign'' armies. But in each matter, the operative word would be ''suspend,'' permitting principle to be maintained on both sides.
Moscow will continue to insist that the talks be governed by the Soviet Constitution. But that is a difficult and lengthy process. With suspension voted, the Parliament would have strong grounds for urging the amending of this procedure in the case of a nation forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union. Meantime, Moscow would have to suspend economic sanctions against Lithuania. The Parliament also can call on Western nations to insure that the process proceeds without undue delay. Western leaders can use the moment to reaffirm their support for Lithuanian independence and willingness to use their good offices with Moscow.
Mikhail Gorbachev could not easily reject this approach. To do so would brand as insincere his promise to deal fairly with Baltic independence. It would put him in direct conflict with President Mitterrand of France, Chancellor Kohl of West Germany and Prime Minister Thatcher of Britain, who have proposed a similar approach.
None of this will guarantee Lithuanian independence in a year or two. The bargaining will be hard because the issues are hard. They concern the rights of citizens who want continued union with Moscow, and their rights after independence. And they involve precedents for other Soviet republics.
Lithuanian leaders reportedly devised a new offer yesterday to break the deadlock with the Soviet Union. Though the contents of the new offer remain secret, Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene of Lithuania said they touched on the declaration of independence.
Touching on it will not be enough, as many Lithuanian leaders acknowledge privately. To break the Soviet economic knot that is strangling Lithuania and to start negotiations for actual independence, the Lithuanian Parliament will have to show much more flexibility. To suspend the declaration is the shrewdest way to avoid suspending ultimate independence.

HEADLINE: The Japanese Secret: Low Interest Rates

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You may argue as forcefully as you wish for government-sponsored research and development (editorials May 10 and 11) but please don't use my industry as an example of Japanese success in this area.
True, the Japanese dominate the world markets for memory chips, display screens, laser printer engines and optical disc drives. But although these items may seem miraculously high-tech to the uninitiated, they are among the most low-tech in the industry. None of them are as complex as what you will find under the typical car hood. Memory chips in particular are now ubiquitous. 
Japanese companies are successful in these fields for the same reasons they are successful in cars, televisions and cassette tapes. Historically, interest rates, their cost of capital, have been drastically lower than those in the United States. So a Japanese company can afford to invest huge amounts in equipment and receive a rate of return that would mean bankruptcy for a U.S. company.
My own section of the computer industry, microcomputer software, is a splendid illustration of the burden of U.S. interest rates and the strength of U.S. research and development. Software is a business notable for two reasons: there is virtually no capital investment required, so interest rates are irrelevant, and it is one of the few markets absolutely dominated by Americans. You will have a hard time finding imported software for your personal computer.
Your suggestion of spending $4 billion (which you astonishingly assert will not be missed) to improve U.S. research efforts strikes me as a solution to a problem that we do not have. Further, as it would contribute to the national debt and therefore help increase interest rates, it would have the effect of exacerbating the very problem you seem intent on curing.
 
NATHAN EIGERMAN
Cambridge, Mass., May 11, 1990
 The writer is a software engineer.

HEADLINE: California: Giant of the Future. . .

BYLINE: By Bill Bradley; Bill Bradley is author of the forthcoming ''The United States of California.''

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO

 BODY:
With California's June 5 primary just two weeks away, national and international attention is turning to America's megastate on the Pacific. California is in the midst of an unprecedented social experiment with vast ramifications.
California, a pre-eminent national power for 25 years, will become far stronger in the 1990's. After the census, the state is likely to gain seven Congressional seats, for a total of 52 - more than any other state in U.S. history. It will have one-fifth of the 270 electoral votes needed to win the Presidency in 1992. 
The old frontier in which continental America reached its geographical limit is now the locus of convergence of several new frontiers - in technology, the global economy and multi-culturalism - that will broaden and better define America's possibilities. Dominating these is the quest for balance between prosperous growth and environmental quality.
Two of the nation's four largest metropolitan areas are in California: the Los Angeles basin and the San Francisco Bay area. The population of the state as a whole grew by more than 20 percent in the past decade, to nearly 30 million; one out of every nine Americans now lives in California. Eighty-one percent of California's new growth was among nonwhites, mostly Latinos and Asians. The state's growth fuels the sixth largest economy in the world.
Contrary to popular myth, California's economy is highly diversified and no longer dependent on military spending. It is 50 percent bigger than New York's and more productive than Japan's.
California leads America in computers, microelectronics, biotechnology, aerospace, diversified manufacturing, entertainment, agriculture and international trade.
The state that pioneered personal computing is accelerating the development and diffusion of advanced technologies. As the information economy grows, California will become even more widely integrated into the borderless global economy as both exporter and partner.
California is already the locus of many effective transnational business alliances. High-profile foreign acquisitions, such as Sony's purchase of Columbia and Tri-Star Pictures, and the purchase of Genentech, the biotechnology leader, by Switzerland's Roche Holdings, have provided billions in capital and, at least in the Sony purchase, increased California control.
The Northeast has traditionally focused on Europe and the Middle East, but the nation's geopolitical orientation must now include a southwestern focus on Latin America and Asia. Yet California is not only an integral part of the fast-rising Pacific Basin; the European Community is its largest trading partner.
But to borrow a line from songwriter Don Henley, ''This ain't no Shangri-la.'' California is a many-splendored land of spectacular sprawl. Environmental challenges have grown and broad educational achievement, once a California hallmark, has declined.
There are increasing concerns about the quality of life, arising primarily from the dynamic but appallingly congested Los Angeles basin. The state's new high-growth area is its burgeoning middle, the Sacramento and San Joaquin valleys.
It's no accident that California is a global center of the renewed environmental ethic: witness ''Earth Day 1990,'' organized out of Palo Alto, and the enormously ambitious ''Big Green'' initiative on the November ballot. As California evolves, so does its politics.
The laissez-faire spirit of Ronald Reagan, Gov. George Deukmejian and the tax revolt of ''Proposition 13'' is giving way to a new politics of planning and public investment. Both Democratic gubernatorial candidates - Dianne Feinstein and John Van de Kamp - subscribe to this thesis. And the Republican candidate, Senator Pete Wilson, recently declared, ''We need considerable foresight and planning to balance our awesome growth with the necessary ingredients to secure a continuing quality of life.''
As it rather haltingly attempts to mold an environmentally sound, multiracial society, this vast mosaic with global reach must find the imagination and courage to invest in its people and plan for their future.
If it succeeds, California's influence will be difficult to overstate in a nation groping painfully for a new identity and in a post-cold war world striving for prosperity, cosmopolitanism and ecological balance.

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
The Military Role

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
One way or another, the role and structure of the military is up for argument in countries around the world as the prospect of war recedes. Argentina is no exception, although its military issues are essentially of the third-world variety.
Still, political change and the impulse to democracy have affected ideas of security here just as they have in the north. A decade ago, the possibility of war with neighbors seemed real. There was the Beagle Channel dispute with Chile, a serious arms race with Brazil that included an attempt for atomic weapons, and other local disputes, not to speak of the disastrous Falklands-Malvinas adventure. 
Now, nobody imagines a regional war, and a global strategic rationale has faded away with the cold war. President Carlos Saul Menem speaks of a ''process of integration with neighbors.'' But he wants to ''modernize'' Argentina's arsenal, so I asked him what the function of the armed forces is now.
The question apparently surprised him. He said: ''The role of the military is the same as in any other country. When it disappears in the U.S., France and so on, it will disappear here too.'' He argues that the military must have up-to-date weapons in the meantime for the safety of the men in uniform. ''The armed forces are an aspect of sovereignty.''
That was not quite the point. Even critical Argentines agree with him that the military here is now subordinated to civilian government. Nobody fears another coup in current circumstances, though the opposition says the key reason is direct participation in government of the financial powers that stimulated coups in the past to protect their interests.
In any case, losing a war cost the military the justification that it alone could protect the country's interest. Losing power after a brutal military dictatorship terrorized the country but achieved nothing else cost it the prestige and respect it cherished. Now it isn't sure of its purpose.
There are a number of traditional functions. Protecting a country against threats short of war remains a valid military role, though it suggests a very different shape of force when neighbors are reliably friendly.
Maintaining internal order has been a customary use of the military in undemocratic countries, but it makes the military the enemy of democracy, and usually assures that it will grow corrupt. Argentines insist they have had more than enough of that, although Mr. Menem is making the legal basis for domestic armed-forces intervention unclear.
In many third-world countries, especially in Latin America, the military has long served as a gateway for social mobility otherwise slammed shut by a dominating oligarchy. Every society needs some kind of ladder for the able, and providing it outside of the profession of arms is obviously an essential factor of development. Argentina relied less on the military for this service in the past than did others, but still, it mattered.
But Argentina relied more than many on the military as political arbiter, imposing power decisions when groups that consider themselves the natural custodians of power were at odds. That too is a role that inevitably undermines democracy.
And finally, a purpose of military forces almost everywhere, regardless of security needs, is to maintain the existence of the military. It is a corporative body that develops its own support systems and, like others only more so, finds it hard to reflect on the whys of its inherent desire to survive.
But if the military-industrial complex achieves weight beyond reason in such countries as the U.S. and France, it tends to provoke counterforces arising from competitive claims on the economy. This has also become true in the Soviet Union. The competition is weakened in countries without solidly based civilian government. The military's claims need determined review.
Ironically, arms reduction in the East-West context risks aggravating military clout in the third world. There will be a temptation to sell off rather than destroy weapons, and keep arms suppliers in business despite shrinking domestic markets. Constraints on this loophole must be included in East-West arms agreements.
More important, though, is to study the rationale of arms in the changing world. I am not against defense. Security is a basic need. But its means need review. Countries like Argentina already show the tremendous impact of shifting attitudes. The role of the military cannot be left out of plans for advancing democracy if a sturdier basis for peace with freedom is to be achieved.

SECTION: Section A; Page 27, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 740 words

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Leveraged Investment

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Six months ago Jiri Dienstbier was shoveling coal into a furnace for the Prague subway system. Now, as Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, he is putting forward a plan to help the Soviet Union and the countries of Central Europe move to market economies.
Mr. Dienstbier unveiled his idea while visiting Harvard University last week, choosing that locale because the Marshall Plan was born there 43 years ago. This week he is traveling in Europe to describe the proposal to other foreign ministers. 
It is an ingenious idea, with a mix much like the Marshall Plan's: idealism, economic incentive, cooperation. The most developed countries of the world - Japan, the United States, the members of the European Community - would in a sense make a leveraged investment. It would work like this: 1. The developed countries would advance $16 billion over three years to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, a new institution being set up now to help the changing economies of Eastern Europe. 2. The money would be credited to the Soviet Union, which could use it to buy industrial products from Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia. Those three countries of Central Europe would use the hard currency to modernize their industries - ''which means,'' Mr. Dienstbier said, ''that they'll spend it in the countries providing them money.'' 3. The Soviet Union would match the dollar credits in rubles, using the resulting fund for investment in its industry. That is the same approach as in the Marshall Plan, when recipient countries created counterpart funds in local currencies. 4. The European Bank would play an important role in planning use of the funds in both the Soviet Union and the three Central European countries. Mr. Dienstbier said:
''The money would be spent with supervision - that's too strong, people don't like supervision - with the coordination of the bank, which will advise on how best to use it.''
The purpose of his plan, Mr. Dienstbier said, was to give concrete form to what President Vaclav Havel told Congress when he spoke to a joint session in February: ''You can help us most of all if you help the Soviet Union on its irreversible but immensely complicated road to democracy.''
Since February economic strains in the Soviet Union have intensified. Mr. Dienstbier said he still thought its movement toward democracy was ''irreversible.'' But there would be a better chance for an orderly transition if the world helped the process of economic change.
In the three Central European countries, too, Mr. Dienstbier said, there would be a period of economic strain. As realistic market pricing takes hold, inefficient factories will close and people will be thrown out of work.
The difficulties will be the greater because the old Comecon system of trade among East European countries and the Soviet Union is being replaced by arm's-length trade at world prices. All of the countries will be looking to get hard currency by exporting to the West - but that will require new plants, and time.
''We need investment,'' Mr. Dienstbier said. ''And we need scholarships, because we have no managerial skills, no expertise in computers and so on.''
He called the $16 billion plan ''modest.'' The Marshall Plan cost the United States about 10 percent of its gross national product, he said. This proposal would cost Japan, the U.S. and the European Community 0.1 percent of their combined G.N.P.
Like his friend President Havel, Mr. Dienstbier made a sudden transition to office last December from the status of dissident outcast. A foreign correspondent of Czechoslovak Radio, he lost his job in 1968 when he would not praise the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia. He was imprisoned, with Mr. Havel, when he spoke out for human rights.
And like Mr. Havel, he seems somewhat bemused by the turn of fate that has made him a politician. He cannot be sure how long he will be in office, because Czechoslovakia is having elections on June 8. The new Parliament will draft a constitution for what is now formally called the Czech and Slovak Federative Republic, with many tricky questions about regional versus central power.
''We have 23 parties now,'' Mr. Dienstbier said. ''But they're all for the free market, pluralism, a free press and so on, even the Communist Party. I think we have only one problem. It will be difficult for people who are not used to choosing to make a choice among 23 lists.''

HEADLINE: New York's Clamor Intrudes on Koreans' Insularity

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
The newest Koreans in New York move uneasily between two worlds - the New York where they work and the Korea they have created in its midst.
Koreans can buy furniture, go to the doctor and get marriage counseling in Korean. Their children can go to one of 400 weekend Korean schools to study their homeland's culture and language. They can join the Korean Bowling Association or the Korean Scuba Diving Club. And for solace after a hard week's work, they can attend one of the hundreds of churches where the sermon will be in Korean.
This is a world where learning English is unnecessary, where the only contact the Koreans newest to the city may have with the American world around them is over a counter at a grocery or dry cleaner. They come to New York from a homogeneous society, where years of occupation, war, political turmoil and forced-march industrialization meant hard work or certain starvation. 
Here, in the poor neighborhoods where the newest Korean settlers set up shop, they see an America remote from the haven they dreamed of, a place of high unemployment, despair and crime. Here the insular society they have created has failed them, and the clash of two worlds sparks conflicts like the boycott by some blacks of two Korean groceries in Brooklyn.
 
'A Very Closed Society'
''We have lived in a homogeneous society with very little contact with outsiders,'' said Kay Lee, editor of the English edition of The Korea Times, one of several Korean newspapers in New York. ''As a result, Americans, especially blacks and Hispanics, are very different for us. A lot of people's minds and bodies are so tied up in managing their stores that they don't want to bother to learn the language or the culture.
''Among Koreans, we cooperate and communicate and give to each other. But we are a very closed society, like a ghetto.''
The world of South Korea in New York may be insular, but it is not monolithic. No one has an exact count of the number of Koreans who live in the metropolitan area, but the Korean Association of New York and The Korea Times estimate between 250,000 and 300,000. And though the number of unregistered immigrants is not known, the official Korean population is growing steadily, by about 2,500 a year.
In many ways, the Korean immigrant experience does not differ appreciably from those of previous groups who came to New York to seek a better life. Jews, Italians, Greeks, Russians, all were suspicious of outsiders, all clung to their own people, until they could gain a foothold in the new world.
Today, within their new world, Koreans observe the strictly ordered hierarchies of education, region and class that divide them almost as much as their fierce drive to succeed and national pride unite them. In New York, natives of the Korean southwest continue to distrust southeasterners and former classmates hold reunions and lend each other money.
Here live women as different as Mung Kim and Young Ja Lee. In the four years since the 39-year-old Mrs. Kim and her husband Jong opened their grocery near Columbia University, she has taken one day off - to visit the Statue of Liberty. They work 16 hours a day, seven days a week, tending to customers as their children ride bicycles outside or do homework behind the counter. In the 19 years since her husband opened his import-export company, Mrs. Lee has not had to work. Instead, she has raised their four children. She has time to make the trip from their Long Island home to the Flushing Y.M.C.A. in Queens, the heart of Korean settlement in New York. There she takes cooking classes and sings in a mothers' choir.
Mrs. Lee is a member of what Grace Lyu-Volckhausen calls the ''invisible'' Koreans, the first wave of immigrants who came to the United States in the 1960's and 70's. Like Mrs. Lyu-Volckhausen, who directs minority program evaluation at the State of New York Mortgage Agency, Mrs. Lee speaks fluent English and counts American politicians as well as Korean businessmen as her friends.
Many older immigrants are established professionals. They moved from selling wigs to selling real estate, from studying English to practicing law or medicine. Their children party at discos in Manhattan and Queens that hold special Korean nights to cater to an affluent crowd. This group may enjoy the comforts of New York's Korean world, but it has crossed over into America.
 
'This Generation Is Struggling'
But the newest wave of immigrants - the grocers, fishmongers and manicurists most New Yorkers see - remains at the periphery. Few speak English; few have time to study. Their children are their interpreters and guides to the new world. Few have non-Korean friends, or much time for friendship, other than church.
''This generation is struggling for adjustment in this strange land,'' said the Rev. Wontae Cha, pastor of the Korean Methodist Church on 115th Street near Riverside Drive. ''When they came over to this country, most of them thought it was the promised land. Soon they found their dreams were not correct. They didn't study this land deeply, and became strangers in the mainstream culture. The church is not only to console them, but to give them courage to live.''
For most Koreans, the early years in the United States are ones of privation. Many leave established businesses in Korea in hopes that the United States would offer wealth and political calm.
 
Raising Capital
First they seek out other Koreans, to learn a trade like running a grocery or a nail salon. To get the capital they need to open shops of their own, many new immigrants borrow from family, friends and college classmates, drawing on a long Korean tradition of mutual savings associations. In savings pools known as ''kye,'' for example, friends contribute a set amount and members can draw the whole pool when they need it.
Many blacks say they believe that banks and the Government are giving the grocers loans that would be denied to black entrepreneurs.
But Ms. Lee said, ''It's hard to get loans from banks here because they have no credit history. But they can get them through Korean connections. School alumni know this person is not going to run away with his $5,000.''
Most are aiming to set up their own shops, and do. A survey conducted by Professor Pyong Gap Min of Queens College in 1988 found that 52 percent of Koreans in New York own their businesses. Typically, Mrs. Lyu-Volckhausen said, they choose labor-intensive fields, where little English is required and where they can employ family members who work without pay, though occasionally local people are hired.
 
Hoping for Sundays Off
In all, there are an estimated 15,000 small Korean-run businesses in New York City, including about 5,000 grocery, vegetable and fish markets.
Jong Kim, who with his wife Mung runs a delicatessen near Columbia, left a job as a textile trader in Seoul. His wife was an accountant for a hospital.
''Now I never have a chance to rest,'' Mr. Kim said. ''The rent is so high, the real-estate taxes and so many stores are closing on Broadway because business is very slow. I wanted to start a trading business. Maybe in 10 years, I'm not even sure. Now my small hope is only to be able to close on Sunday.''
Suk Jong Lee, who runs youth programs at the Flushing Y.M.C.A., says the strains are aggravated by the strict social hierarchy Koreans carry with them to America.
 
Stereotypes Die Hard
''A lot of them have college degrees, and having a small business in Korea is more or less looked down upon,'' she said. ''They have to do this in order to survive, but it's not what they were trained for. I know Ph.D.'s running sneaker stores. A lot of pride has been hurt in the process.''
As Koreans have for generations, Korean parents pin their hopes on their children. But the schools they count on let them down, too, because they teach children heretical ideas like independence that violate Korean values of filial obedience.
All of these strains contribute to the racial tensions that broke out in Flatbush this year and in Harlem five years ago. Many Koreans say they believe that the latest conflict is the work of political opportunists whose aim is to drive Koreans out of black neighborhoods. But many blacks believe that they see a larger problem - rudeness, racism, and a failure to honor the American tradition of successful businesses contributing to the neighborhood.
Professor Min of Queens College, in an article published in The Korea Times, cites a combination of cultural differences between Koreans and Americans, long-held Korean stereotypes of blacks, and bitter personal experience with shoplifting.
Many Americans tend to see Asians as polite, subservient, and reserved, stereotypes absorbed from earlier Chinese and Japanese immigrants. Many Koreans do not fit this mold. ''We are not Japanese - we are more individualistic,'' said Ms. Lee of The Korea Times. ''We are feisty.''
What may seem to blacks and other Americans like rudeness or hostility is often poor English, fatigue, or frustration at long hours of work some see as demeaning. Korean women are taught not to look at people in the eye, smile at them, or touch their hands, Mrs. Lyu-Volckhausen said.
Before coming to New York, many Koreans have no experience of blacks beyond the villains on American police television shows and action movies or the soldiers out drinking and picking up prostitutes in Seoul's Itaewon bar district. Racial stereotypes offensive to blacks are common throughout much of Asia.
These preconceptions, compounded by the new immigrants' isolation from the broader world of New York, have kept many from learning the rules of race relations. Many speak bluntly and in generalizations that Americans stopped voicing out loud years ago.
Many new Korean immigrants work in the poorest and most dangerous neighborhoods in New York and they do not like what they see. ''Most Koreans do not understand the history of the civil rights movement, and think America is a wonderful country where you can achieve your dream,'' said Ms. Lee of The Korea Times. ''They see a lot of blacks on welfare. They don't see them striving very hard to meet the goal of their lives. From a Korean point of view - working 16 hours a day, not spending money, trying to send their kids to the best schools, giving up pleasure - they don't understand that mentality.''
Korean grocers say they are plagued by shoplifting, and the culprits in the neighborhoods they serve are usually black, often teen-agers.
''Too many people steal, especially colored people,'' said John H. Choi, who ran a string of delis in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan. ''They pick up something, I say open your shopping bag, they say no, no. I tell them, I saw you. You are stealing my food. Too much headache, so I sold out.''
Stephen Lynton, the associate director of Columbia University's Center for Korean Research, who grew up in South Korea and works with immigrants at a Korean church, says that theft is more the issue than race. Many Korean shopkeepers, he points out, speak warmly of black customers.
Mr. Cha, the Methodist minister, is one of several more established Korean immigrants who says he must help teach newcomers more about black history and theology, to help prevent misunderstandings. And Mrs. Lyu-Volckhausen is meeting with merchants to suggest a checklist of things they should do when they move into neighborhoods, including shopping at neighborhood stores, visiting local schools and offering donations.
''We have to show everyone we are here to stay,'' Mrs. Lyu-Volckhausen said. ''We are not going to be pushed around anymore. But I tell them, this is an investment. If you don't invest in your neighborhood, there is no peace.''

HEADLINE: City on Seneca Indian Reservation Reaches New Lease With Tribe

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 21

 BODY:
Nine months before its 99-year lease was set to expire, the city of Salamanca, the only city in the nation built on land leased from an Indian reservation, has reached a new rental agreement with the Seneca Indians, officials said today.
The agreement calls for a $60 million payment to the Seneca Nation from the Federal and state governments, and for annual lease payments from the city to the Indian nation to increase about 14 times, to $800,000 a year. The new lease would run for 40 years, with an option to renew for another 40 years. 
The $60 million payment is intended as compensation for the payments under the old agreement, which both sides conceded were unfairly low.
At a news conference today in Salamanca, 60 miles south of Buffalo, officials of the Seneca Nation and the city of Salamanca said they were satisfied with the arrangement.
 
Government Money Not Certain
''It shows that we and the Seneca Nation can work together,'' said Antonio Carbone, Salamanca's Mayor.
But officials here and in Washington cautioned that there was no guarantee that the government money that is built into the agreement would, in fact, be available.
''We haven't signed off on anything,'' Gary G. Fryer, a spokesman for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, said today. The agreement calls for a payment from the state of $25 million.
Thomas Lederer, administrative assistant to Representative Amory Houghton Jr., a Republican whose district includes Salamanca, said that the Federal share of the payment, $35 million, ''is not in the bank.'' But, he added, ''our feeling is if we get a bill in around June 1, it's do-able.''
It is unclear today what will happen if the Federal and state goverments do not make their $60 million payment, the centerpiece of the agreement.
 
Impasse Hurt Town's Economy
The original Salamanca lease was approved by Congress in 1892. It called for annual payments of $17,000 with no provisions for increases, although since then the Seneca nation negotiated new leases that brought the total annual payment to $57,000.
The original lease was to expire in February 1991. Salamanca and Seneca officials began negotiations on a new lease more than a decade ago, but because of disagreements about its terms the negotiations dragged on, creating uncertainty about the town's future that discouraged investment and depressed real-estate prices.
''The real hope here is to revitalize the economy,'' Mr. Lederer said. ''The instability in the lease arrangement has really inhibited that.''
About 90 percent of the property in Salamanca, a city of 6,600, lies on Seneca land, part of the 22,640-acre Allegany Reservation on the Pennsylvania border, the largest Indian reservation in New York. For decades, some tenants have paid as little as $1 a year for the leases on their homes.
Under the agreement announced today, a residential lease would be assessed at 8 percent of the market value of the land, excluding the value of buildings. The price of a non-residential lease would be 10 percent of the land value.
Salamanca officials said today the leases would total about $630,000 annually. The rest of the $800,000 payment they have pledged to the Senecas would be a direct contribution from the city. Salamanca's Mayor, Mr. Carbone, said he did not know how the city would pay for its share.

GRAPHIC: photo: The Seneca Indian tribe and Salamanca, N.Y., have agreed to a new lease for the land the tribe owns under most of the city. Doug Endreson, left, counsel for the Senecas, and, next to him, Patrick Callahan, negotiator for the city, announced details of the $800,000-a-year lease. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Franklin H. Williams Dies at 72; Lawyer and Former Ambassador

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Franklin H. Williams, a lawyer, educator and government official who was active in civil rights causes throughout a long career, died of lung cancer on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old.
Mr. Williams helped organize the Peace Corps, was a former Ambassador to Ghana and a former vice chairman of the New York City Board of Higher Education. From 1970 until his death he served as president of the Phelps-Stokes Fund, an educational foundation dedicated to advancing opportunities for American minority groups and Africans. 
He was born in Flushing, Queens, and graduated in 1941 from Lincoln University in Pennsylvania. After service in World War II in a racially segregated unit of the Army, he passed the New York State bar examination before receiving his law degree from Fordham University in 1945.
He became an assistant to Thurgood Marshall, then special counsel to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and now an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.
 
Open Housing and Employment
Mr. Williams, appearing before the Court, won reversals of death sentences for several black youths who had been convicted of capital crimes. In 1950 he was appointed regional director of the N.A.A.C.P. for nine Western states, Alaska and Hawaii.
He held the post for nine years, during which his office conducted drives for legislation on minority employment, open housing and other civil rights issues. Under his direction the N.A.A.C.P. won the first successful judgment in a major case involving school desegregation and the removal of restrictive covenants on real estate in California.
In 1959 Mr. Williams was appointed an assistant attorney general in California. Two years later he joined Sargent Shriver, the first head of the Peace Corps, traveling to nine countries around the world to prepare for the dispatch of American volunteers.
In 1961, as a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, he won passage of a resolution calling for an international version of the Peace Corps under United Nations auspices.
 
'Uses of the University'
Two years later, he became the first black person to be named United States representative to the Economic and Social Council and was later appointed Ambassador to Ghana. Relations between the United States and Ghana had been poor for years. But Mr. Williams was credited with bringing about substantial improvement during the three years he spent in Accra.
On his return from Ghana in 1968 Mr. Williams was chosen to head a new Urban Center at Columbia University, which initiated changes in curriculum and issued a major study, ''The Uses of the University.''
Upon assuming the presidency of the Phelps-Stokes Fund in 1970, Mr. Williams persuaded the organization's board to divest itself of holdings in corporations doing business with South Africa, seven years before the formulation of the Sullivan Principles, which have guided many other American institutions and businesses in such actions.
Phelps-Stokes had been established in 1911 to improve education for American blacks, American Indians and Africans.
Mr. Williams was named to the boards of many corporations, including Borden Inc., Consolidated Edison and the American Stock Exchange.
 
Helped Found Many Groups
He was also a board member of several nonprofit groups, among them the Council on Foreign Relations and the American Civil Liberties Union.
Mr. Williams helped to form a number of professional and cultural groups, including the Association of Black American Ambassadors, the Boys Choir of Harlem, the Caribbean Cultural Center and the Jackie Robinson Foundation.
In 1987, he was chairman of the New York State Judicial Commission on Minorities, which conducted a study of the treatment of members of minority groups in the state's courts.
Mr. Williams is survived by his wife, the former Shirley Broyard; two sons, Franklin Jr., of Manhattan, and Paul Anatole, of Lyme, Conn., and two grandchildren.
