HEADLINE: Tapping Ocean's Cold For Crops and Energy

BYLINE: By RICHARD HALLORAN

DATELINE: KEAHOLE POINT, Hawaii

 BODY:
ON a wind-swept point of black lava jutting into the Pacific Ocean, a small band of scientists and entrepreneurs is generating electricity, raising lobsters and growing strawberries using cold water from the depths of the sea.
Eventually, they say they hope the techniques they are devising here may increase food supplies and produce energy without pollution and without the use of fossil fuels.
For now, however, ''cold water is the resource we're selling,'' said Thomas H. Daniel, technical director of the Natural Energy Laboratory of Hawaii, where the projects are under way.
That water, pumped from a depth of 2,000 feet, comes up at a nearly constant temperature of 6 degrees Celsius, or 43 degrees Fahrenheit. It has a high concentration of nutrients like nitrates, phosphates and silicates that foster the growth of plants and algae. And it is pure, having been out of contact with the surface for centuries as it drifted slowly along the bottom, and thus is free of the pathogens that carry diseases. 
When the laboratory began the project about 10 years ago, scientists here were confident it would be possible to put the water to profitable use. While profits have so far been elusive, the researchers have demonstrated the feasibility of several ideas, solved formidable engineering problems and produced a wealth of data.
 
Promise of Growing Lobsters
The lab, which operates on a budget of $1.5 million a year and has a staff of 20, began by seeking to use the differences in temperature between surface and deep sea water to produce electricity in a process called ocean thermal energy conversion.
But it is the other projects developed on this 322-acre site that seem more promising today: growing lobsters in half the time it takes in their natural habitat along the coast of Maine; raising flounder, sea urchins and salmon; distilling fresh water and cooling buildings and industrial plants.
Next to the energy lab is the Hawaii Ocean Science and Technology park, a 547-acre site set aside by the state for commercial development of the laboratory's findings. Once a project developed at the lab becomes profitable, it must move out, either to the park or elsewhere.
Aquaculture Enterprises has already moved to the park. The company has been experimenting since 1987 with lobsters and has begun test sales locally. The lobsters are raised in shallow tanks under green tents that block the heat of the sun. They are kept in separate pans so they will not eat each other.
Joseph Wilson, a partner in the enterprise, said that by mixing cold and warm sea water to maintain a steady temperature of 22 degrees Celsius, researchers have eliminated the near-hibernation of the lobsters in winter. That has cut growing time to less than four years from the seven and a half years it takes in nature. As they learn more about the lobsters' environment, nutrition and genetics, he said, ''we think that could be cut again to 30 months.''
 
Purity of Water Is Important
But even more than the temperature, he said, the purity of the water was essential to raising the lobsters. Other aquaculture efforts have been plagued by diseases carried in surface waters.
He said his company planned to cover 20 acres with the shallow tanks through which the sea water flows constantly. ''We have to produce 500,000 pounds a year to have a viable unit,'' he said. The North American market for lobster is 140 million pounds a year.
Nearby, Gerald R. Cysewski, the scientific director for the Cyanotech Corporation, pointed to raceways in which paddles like small versions of those on Mississippi riverboats kept a green slime moving slowly. The algae, rich in protein and vitamins, are sold for pharmaceuticals and health food, like spirulina. For his operation, which was open to the sun, the temperature of the water made little difference. ''For us,'' he said, ''it's the purity and the nutrients.''
Mr. Cysewski said the company produced 8,000 kilos of spirulina a month and sold it for $17 a kilo. He said the company was also moving into production of beta carotene from the algae, a precursor to vitamin A that may help to prevent cancer.
Ocean Farms of Hawaii is raising hundreds of salmon in its 21 acres of tanks along with abalone that feed on the kelp growing from the bottom. Royal Hawaiian Sea Farms is growing ''nori,'' the spinach of the sea used to wrap sushi rolls. A Japanese company, Uwajima Fisheries is raising hirame, a flounder popular in sushi restaurants.
In early May, Hawaii Seafood Growers Inc. announced it would start a pilot operation to grow mahi-mahi, a favorite fish in Hawaii. Thomas J. Vincent, the company's chief executive, said the fish farm could produce 1.5 million pounds a year, or a third of annual consumption here.
 
Growing Plants That Like the Cool
But the cold water also finds uses on land. Run through pipes the energy laboratory has laid in strawberry, lettuce and flower beds, the cold water keeps the plants at the cool temperature they like and causes fresh water to condense on the pipes. The fresh water drips from the pipes to water the plants.
''When we want the strawberries to think it's winter,'' Mr. Daniel said, standing under a tropical sun, ''we just run the cold water faster.'' Strawberries with five times more sugar than those in nature have been produced.
The chairman of the laboratory, John P. Craven, said cold sea water could have an economic future in air-conditioning and industrial cooling.
Several buildings at the energy laboratory at Keahole circulate cold sea water through their air-conditioning systems. The systems must be carefully maintained so that they are not corroded. Even so, electrical costs for the buildings have been cut by about 75 percent, Mr. Daniel said.
So far, the energy laboratory and the commercial park have not drawn protests from environmentalists who have demonstrated against an experiment on the other side of the island, where scientists are trying to tap a volcano for its heat to produce power. The reason, Mr. Craven and Mr. Daniel said, is that the lab and the enterprises change the sea water little before returning it to the ocean.
 
An Idea a Century Old
The idea of generating electricity from differences in sea water temperatures is the energy laboratory's main goal. A French engineer, Jacques-Arsene d'Arsonval, first proposed the idea in 1881. His student, Georges Claude, built a pilot plant on the north shore of Cuba in 1930.
In the United States, the oil crisis of the mid-1970's set off a search for new forms of energy. The natural energy lab was set up here in 1974 as a joint venture of the State of Hawaii, the University of Hawaii and the Federal Department of Energy. Japanese researchers and engineers have also developed the technology.
The ocean thermal energy conversion process, which the laboratory is using to generate electricity, can be accomplished either with closed or open cycles. In a closed cycle, warm sea water is pumped in from about 40 feet beneath the surface, where it is between 25 and 28 degrees Celsius, or 77 to 83 degrees Fahrenheit.
It is pumped through a heat exchanger containing a fluid like ammonia which vaporizes at low temperature. The vapor expands to drive a turbine that, in turn, drives an electrical generator. The fluid passes through a second heat exchanger in which it is cooled and condensed by cold sea water. Then it is recycled back into the first heat exchanger.
 
Payoff From Bigger Pipeline
In an open cycle, warm sea water is pumped into an evaporator in which the pressure has been lowered to make the water boil. In this case, the water vaporizes to drive the turbine and generator. But when the vapor is condensed, in a condenser cooled by cold sea water, fresh water is siphoned off.
Electricity from the more efficient closed-cycle plants, according to Mr. Daniel, would cost up to 14 cents a kilowatt hour, as against 5.6 cents for electricity generated by burning oil at $20 a barrel.
The laboratory has nine pipelines from 12 inches to 40 inches wide, which can bring up 25,000 gallons of cold sea water a minute. But so far, it has taken more power to pump up sea water than the ensuing process has been able to generate. The laboratory is planning to experiment with a pipe that is eight feet wide to pump up enough cold sea water to produce a net gain in electric power.
Mr. Daniel and Mr. Craven said a breakthrough on heat exchangers, however, may lower the cost. Researchers from the Aluminum Company of Canada and General Electric Company of Britain, have found that heat exchangers can be made for 20 percent the cost now by using aluminum instead of titanium. The exchangers account for about one-third the cost of the plant.
Patrick K. Takahashi, director of the Hawaii Natural Energy Institute, a separate research organization at the University of Hawaii in Honolulu, said that a combination of power generation and food production might eventually be economical.
''This might be competitive as a package in certain places, such as the Pacific islands, where fossil fuels are expensive,'' he said.

LENGTH: 1633 words

HEADLINE: Pop Concerts, Once Cheap, Now Rival Broadway in Price

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
Pop music concerts, which used to be an inexpensive alternative to Broadway shows and other performing arts events in the New York metropolitan area, have been steadily going up in price.
This year, the top ticket prices for selected concerts at Radio City Music Hall have reached $50. That was the top price for Frank Sinatra's engagement last week at the Music Hall, which he postponed until mid-June after one performance. The ticket is only $10 below the $60 top price of the best seats for the most expensive Broadway musical, ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway,'' and only $5 less than a top ticket to any other major Broadway musical.
Mr. Sinatra's five sold-out shows at the 5,800-seat Music Hall are expected to gross more than $1.3 million. By comparison, the highest grossing Broadway show, ''Phantom of the Opera,'' is always sold out and brings in more than $550,000 for a week of eight performances at the 1,600-seat Majestic Theater. 
 
McCartney Hits $32.50
Similarly, the ticket prices for arena concerts by pop superstars have climbed to $30. Though the $30 barrier was cracked earlier by Michael Jackson, the Rolling Stones and a couple of other big acts, it is only now becoming commonplace.
Now all 55,000 tickets for Billy Joel's sold-out concert on June 22 at Yankee Stadium are also $30, and so are all tickets for the eight performances of Madonna's ''Blond Ambition'' tour in mid-June at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., and the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I. Tickets for Paul McCartney's two sold-out concerts at Giants Stadium on July 9 and 11 are $32.50. When the Beatles first performed at Shea Stadium in 1966, the tickets were $5.75.
With some exceptions, the tickets for shows that today cost $30 would have cost $20 to $25 five years ago. During that time top prices have risen from $35 to $50.
The performers stand to make astronomical profits from these shows. Mr. McCartney and Madonna will probably walk away from their New York area concerts with more than $2 million each. And even after they pay their staffs and road crews, they will earn well over a million dollars, The 3 Main Promoters ''There's been a giant jump in prices in the last 12 months and especially in the last three months,'' said John Scher, the president of the Metropolitan Entertainment Company. Mr. Scher, who is based in Montclair, N.J., is one of the New York area's three leading promoters of pop concerts. His two principal competitors are Ron Delsener, who runs Ron Delsener Enterprises, in Manhattan, and Radio City Music Hall Productions.
The rise in ticket prices for pop concerts is part of a national trend that promoters attribute in large part to bidding wars by representatives of competing arenas vying to book concerts by the most popular acts.
''Thirty dollars is going to be the going price now on a lot of shows,'' said Mr. Delsener, who is promoting the Joel, McCartney and Madonna concerts. Mr. Delsener compared the bidding for the top talent to an art auction. He said one consequence may be that concertgoers have less money for other concerts with lesser-known acts.
Mr. Delsener, Mr. Scher and Scott Sanders of Radio City Music Hall Productions said the downturn in the economy in the Northeast has not affected ticket sales at the concerts they are promoting.
 
How Price Is Determined
They said the ticket prices for their concerts are determined by several factors. The most important, they said, is the cost of producing a show, which includes signing the performers, renting the facility and advertising. In negotiating with a promoter, the agents for a top pop act ask for an average of 85 percent of the net receipts of a concert after expenses have been paid.
Costs vary from facility to facility and depend a lot on rental and labor costs. Mr. Scher said the total cost of an average arena concert, including the performers, runs to about $200,000 at Madison Square Garden, $110,000 at the Nassau Coliseum and $120,000 at the Byrne Arena. For shows that do not immediately sell out, advertising costs are $25,000 to $30,000. Rents for the three facilities range from $20,000 to around $30,000 a concert, plus a share of the profits.
Perhaps the biggest variable affecting ticket prices is the guarantee a promoter pays to an act. Some popular acts demand as little as $25,000, but the guarantees can go as high as $100,000 to $200,000. If a show is successful, the promoter earns 10 to 20 percent of the net receipts. Infrequently, a promoter can lose $200,000 to $300,000 from a poorly attended stadium event. Mr. Scher said that 80 to 85 percent of the his company's arena shows were profitable.
 
Other Costs Are Stable
Even while the price of talent has risen, he said, the other costs of promoting concerts in the New York area over the last year have remained steady, rising less than 5 percent at Giants Stadium and the Byrne Arena and decreasing slightly at the Nassau Coliseum.
Like almost everything else in Manhattan, the costs of producing concerts are considerably higher than they are in New Jersey or on Long Island. This summer, the top prices for Shirley Bassey's Carnegie Hall concerts on July 12 to 14 are $50, which is $10 more than her concerts cost last year. Mr. Delsener, who is promoting them, said the rise was a result of living-cost increases for Carnegie's unions.
At Radio City Music Hall, the first solo act to crack the $50 barrier was Ella Fitzgerald last year. For her one-night return engagement last month, the top price was again $50. Both concerts sold out, each grossing more than $250,000.
 
At the Low End
This is the second year that Radio City Music Hall will also promote the Reebok Riverstage series of pop concerts at Pier 84, starting on June 13. At the request of New York City, which leases the site to Radio City, the ticket prices will be markedly lower than at other concert venues. With few exceptions they will be $17 for advance tickets and $19.50 for those bought on the day of the show. The series opens with Rickie Lee Jones and Lyle Lovett. Some of the other performers scheduled to appear include Alice Cooper, Ziggy Marley, Tears for Fears, Bad Company, B. B. King and the Moody Blues.
Other variables also affect the pricing of pop concerts. Performers whose shows involve the aggressive merchandizing of T-shirts and other memorabilia tend to take into account the possibility that a high ticket price might cut into its merchandising revenue. Some artists can gross almost as much in T-shirt sales as in ticket sales. Acts like Def Leppard, Bon Jovi and New Kids on the Block, which have young, loyal audiences, sell as much as $10 in merchandise for each person attending.
 
The Age of the Audience
While the generational divisions in musical taste of the late 1960's and early 70's have blurred in the last two decades, they can be sensed in the ways that audiences of different ages approach pop music entertainment. Thus ticket pricing is strongly influenced by the age of the audience and the type of music being offered.
The standard method by which young rock bands build up audiences is through constant touring, going from clubs to middle-size halls to large arenas. Because those audiences are mostly teen-agers with limited income, new performers use lower-than-average ticket prices to cultivate and then hold a loyal audience. Mr. Scher cited Bruce Springsteen, the Who, the Grateful Dead, U2, Robert Plant and Def Leppard as top acts that have followed this course.
When the Who played Giants Stadium last year, for example, the tickets were only $23.50. Tickets for Depeche Mode, which has sold out its June 16 Giants Stadium engagement, are $22.50. New Kids on the Block's Giants Stadium shows on July 20 and 21 are $25. Depeche Mode and the New Kids both have young, ardent followings.
Successful and durable performers like Mr. Sinatra and Miss Bassey, who bills herself as ''the world's greatest female entertainer,'' cultivate a flashy, ''high rolling'' aura that attracts a ''big spender'' type of audience. By paying a lot for tickets and dressing up to see their shows, audiences partake in the glamour of the event.
Veteran rock acts like the Grateful Dead, however, build their reputations on a populist working class mystique. The Grateful Dead, it is believed, haven't played to an empty seat in a decade. This summer the Dead are embarking on an extended national stadium tour. Depending on the city, the ticket price will range from $22.50 to $25.
 
The Elegant Cabarets
Roughly the same measurements that apply to concerts also apply to clubs. Elegant cabarets like Rainbow and Stars and the Cafe Carlyle have a $35 cover charge for an affluent over-40 crowd that is expected to order lots of food and drink.
Jazz clubs that book big names have a long tradition of being pricey. Depending on the act, the Blue Note, New York's biggest jazz club, in the West Village, charges anywhere from $15 to $35 and a $5 minimum per person at tables.
In rock clubs, which have younger audiences, the prices are a little lower. The Ritz, on the site of the old Studio 54, charges around $20 a show with no minimums. But that also can mean no seating. In New York right now, the club that has held the line on ticket prices is the Bottom Line, a rock showcase club started in the 70's. The average ticket price at the Bottom Line is $13.50 on weeknights and $15 on weekends.
So far, the rise in concert prices has not encountered strong public resistance. But how far can it go?
''There is not a bottomless pit of discretionary income out there,'' Mr. Scher said. ''The public will pay anything to see the superstars. But at what cost to the economic health of the rest of the entertaiment industry?''

(Larry Busacca/Retna; Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Drug Industry Nervous on Prices

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
PHARMACEUTICAL company executives are watching nervously as drug prices come under growing criticism in Congress and states that are scrimping to pay for Medicaid programs for the poor.
Three of the largest pharmaceutical companies - Merck, Bristol-Myers Squibb, and Burroughs-Wellcome - have broken with the industry's longstanding policy of refusing to offer discounts on Medicaid drugs. Together, the three companies have at least 15 percent of the $36 billion American pharmaceutical market.
Bristol-Myers and Burroughs-Wellcome are backing a proposal by Merck that would offer the companies' lowest discounts to Medicaid. To get the discounts, Medicaid programs would have to accept all company products, exempting them from restrictions that currently exclude some expensive drugs. 
Most big drug companies oppose giving Medicaid discounts to the states, which spend $3.5 billion on drugs in Medicaid programs. The executive committee of the board of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a trade group, met on May 3 and formally rejected ''proposals to tie the availability of prescription drugs to the willingness or ability of companies to grant discounts or rebates.'' Although that was the substance of Merck's proposal, the company was not named.
But Bristol-Myers and Burroughs, a unit of the Wellcome Foundation Ltd. of Britain, had already taken Merck's side. And Glaxo Inc., the American division of Glaxo Holdings P.L.C. of Britain, also a large company, said it was keeping an open position. ''We will be watching this issue with great interest, as will the entire industry,'' said Robert A. Ingram, a Glaxo executive vice president.
''There is a lot of merit to the Merck proposal,'' said a spokeswoman for another leading drug maker, who asked not to be identified.
''The whole issue of pricing is a very serious one for the companies and their stock price-earnings ratios,'' said Hemant K. Shah, an independent pharmaceutical analyst in Warren, N.J. ''Drug unit sales are declining and about 70 percent of sales growth is coming from price increases.''
Indeed, he added, one advantage for investors of having drug stocks had been that the companies could always raise the prices of their products, even in a recession. ''But if this thing gets out of hand, the companies may have trouble raising prices even in economic boom times,'' he said.
Not surprisingly, Merck's offer plays to its own strengths. Merck has several important new products that it would like to sell in the Medicaid market. And Merck's deepest discounts are smaller than those offered by its competitors.
The Senate Finance Committee is preparing to hold hearings this summer on a Medicaid drug bill. The measure, which was introduced on May 10 by Senator David Pryor, the Arkansas Democrat who heads the Special Committee on Aging, would encourage state Medicaid officials to join in negotiating discounts deals. Both the Defense Department and the Department of Veterans' Affairs as well as many hospitals and large health maintenance organizations already get such discounts.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate Democratic leader, has promised to see that the Pryor bill is given consideration. And the Senate Finance Committee has already asked for comment from the Bush Administration and estimates on financing from the Congressional Budget Office.
Senator Pryor said negotiating discounts would save the states $100 million to $200 million. But the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association disagreed. ''It may even increase costs,'' said Gerald J. Mossinghof, the association's president, adding that patients whose drugs were restricted often required additional care from doctors in hospitals.
The manufacturers are also fighting a provision of the Pryor bill to establish a national committee of physicians and pharmacists to decide which products are ''therapeutically equivalent,'' that is, interchangeable. Makers of such drugs would have to bid against each other. ''Different drugs have different properties and different side effects,'' Mr. Mossinghoff said.
At least 19 states already have some restrictions on Medicaid drugs. Jim Parks, who heads the $570 million Medi-Cal Drug Discount Program in California, said that ''a couple of companies are showing interest'' in discussing discounts. Several Medicaid drug bills, including one that would strengthen Medi-Cal's leverage in bargaining for discounts and one supporting the Merck approach, have been introduced in the Legislature.
John L. Zabriskie, president of Merck Sharp & Dohme, Merck's drug-making unit, said that four states - Arkansas, Delaware, Utah and South Carolina - had indicated that they would accept Merck's offer. He added that there were ''active discussions'' with at least five others. Arkansas is one of 12 states that restrict some Merck products; Delaware, Utah and South Carolina do not.
''I am cautiously optimistic that something positive will happen in California,'' Mr. Zabriskie said. ''We are beginning the dance,'' Medi-Cal's Mr. Parks said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. to Link Dealers by Satellite

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 21

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation said today that it planned to link 9,700 United States dealers through what it said would be the world's largest private satellite network.
The network is scheduled to be completed in 1992. It will eventually replace the telephone lines linking computers in dealerships with G.M. and with one another, a system that has grown more expensive with increased use. 
Duncan A. Brodie, the G.M. manager in charge of dealer communications, said the current system of data exchange using telephone links could not handle the growing volume of data and electronic communications flowing between the company and its dealers.
Vehicle orders, and warranty and service data now move from dealerships to regional sales offices and to G.M.'s service technical group in Warren, Mich., and back again, by way of conventional high-speed telephone data communications.
Mr. Brodie said that a lack of communications capacity had prevented the company from using technology it had already developed. The network would allow dealers to expand their use of computers when diagnosing vehicle problems and allow them to take advantage of electronic shop manuals and invoicing, he said.
The proposed network would also enable top G.M. executives to address dealers directly through television on matters ranging from sales incentives and advertising campaigns to personnel changes.
Company officials would not disclose the projected cost of the satellite network.
General Motors said it would pay for the satellite dishes and had told dealers the new system would not cost them any more in communications charges than they currently paid.
But an official for the National Automobile Dealers' Association said he expected the costs of installing and operating the satellite network would eventually be passed on to dealers. ''It's overhead and somehow or other it has to be paid for,'' said Jake Kelderman, executive director of industry affairs for the dealer group.
GM Hughes Electronics will provide each dealer with a six-foot satellite dish and electronic support package. Multiple G.M. franchises will receive a satellite dish at each dealership location, the company said. Another G.M. subsidiary, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, will develop and operate the network.
General Motors is not the first auto maker to establish a satellite network for its dealers. The Chrysler Corporation contracted with Hughes in October to build a similar network connecting more than 5,000 Chrysler dealers.

HEADLINE: Economic Growth Seen

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The United States economy will skirt a recession through 1991 and set a postwar record for the longest period of business growth, the nation's top business economists predicted today.
The National Association of Business Economists said 82 percent of the 68 professional forecasters surveyed in April and May said the business expansion would continue slowly through next year. 
If so, the current expansion would top the record of 106 months of economic growth from February 1961 to December 1969. The present expansion began 90 months ago, in November 1982.
The forecast was considerably more optimistic than a similar survey last May, when 63 percent of the economists predicted a recession this year. Ninety-six percent of those questioned for the current survey said the economy would continue growing through this year.
The forecasters said the economy, as measured by the gross national product, would grow 2 percent this year and 2.4 percent in 1991. The G.N.P., the total output of goods and services, rose 3 percent last year.
They also said inflation, which was 8.1 percent in the first quarter, reflecting in part weather-related rises in food and energy prices, would drop to an annual rate of 3.7 percent in the last nine months of the year. That would make the 1990 inflation rate 4.7 percent, down from 4.8 percent in 1989.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Boom in Made-to-Order Building

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
With the nation's financial institutions curtailing their real estate lending, the commercial building projects with the best chances - and in some cities the only chances - of getting financing these days are those that are made to order for a specific buyer or tenant. These projects, known as build-to-suit developments, are experiencing a boom as the nation's developers, most of which build on speculation, try to compete in the custom market.
''The market in build-to-suits is getting really crowded because speculative development has dried up and companies with development staffs are competing for these opportunities,'' said Robert Williamson, the director of national marketing for the Prudential Property Company, a big national developer.
In build-to-suit projects, developers design and construct buildings to the needs of a primary tenant, which pays the developer a marginal fee for design and construction work and agrees to buy the completed building or occupy all or most of it in exchange for a favorable long-term lease.
 
Clear Numbers for Lenders
The projects are easier for developers to finance than speculative buildings because rental incomes are guaranteed through a contract, allowing lenders to see clearly how their loans will be repaid. 
''The banks will only come into a situation where debt coverage is clear and up front from the beginning, and right now that's in build-to-suits,'' said William Conway, managing director of Jones Lang Wootton, an international real estate concern based in New York.
But these projects are usually less profitable for developers than speculative developments. Custom builders must absorb any overruns themselves, because they are locked into fixed rental rates or selling prices before they complete a project.
By contrast, speculative builders can pass on all of their building expenses to their tenants, and they generally charge higher rental rates for taking on more risks, including the possibility that they will be left holding on to thousands of square feet of vacant office space.
 
Pricing Problem
As a result, many speculative builders are not well versed in the intricacies of build-to-suit pricing, leading to predictions that many will have trouble competing in the market.
Build-to-suit developments were pioneered by a few large developers in the 1970's for designing specialized industrial projects. But office space is increasingly being tailored this way.
The build-to-suit explosion has been going on in Texas for several years. It took hold there after a drop in energy prices pushed the economies of Houston and Dallas into recession and devastated real estate values.
David Shulman, the director of real estate research at Salomon Brothers, said, ''It's been happening in Texas for a long while now and it's not surprising that it's now happening elsewhere in the country.'' Texas Project for I.B.M. Among the most recent custom-made buildings in Texas is the new $150 million office complex in Austin that Dallas-based Prentiss Properties is building for the International Business Machines Corporation. In that deal, NCNB Texas National Bank beat out another large domestic bank and two Japanese banks to provide construction financing. Prentiss, which has generally limited itself to doing build-to-suit projects, prevailed over competition like the Trammell Crow Company to build the 1.1-million-square-foot office space.
''We got the project because we had already established a real good relationship with I.B.M.,'' said Michael Prentiss, president of the developer.
Prentiss had completed six other made-to-order buildings, valued at about $1 billion, for I.B.M.
''They had a tight time schedule and it's an important project, so they needed a partner that could deliver the product on time,'' Mr. Prentiss said.
 
Growth for Trammell Crow
Dallas-based Trammell Crow, the nation's largest developer, has more than doubled its build-to-suit business over the last two years, to 10 million square feet, said Marc Myers, a partner at Trammell Crow who oversees these projects.
''It's always been about a third of our business, and right now it's about 80 percent,'' he said.
''Over the next five years, on a sustained basis, I expect it will be about 60 to 65 percent of our business,'' said Mr. Myers, who added that the number of build-to-suits Trammell Crow is doing has doubled this year, to 10 million square feet. But many developers who excelled at speculative building are discovering what the build-to-suit developers have known all along: the two businesses are radically different.
 
'A Different Business'
''Build-to-suits are going to be the largest share of the business, and everyone is going to be competing for them,'' Mr. Myers said, ''but it is fundamentally a different business because it requires greater technical skills, greater pricing precision and a team approach.''
In the typical build-to-suit project, a prospective tenant approaches a builder with specifications for the type of building it needs. A period of exploration and negotiation between the developer's technical staff and the client follows. During this period, which can last for months, the developer nails down the specific kind of building the client needs.
The development team then offers the client a guaranteed price on the building based on computer-estimated costs of construction. Competition among builders prevents padding of the estimates in case of overruns, and usually if the cost of construction runs up because of rising interest rates after the project has begun, the developer assumes the expense.
 
Challenge of Pricing
''You have to price the rent precisely to fit the project and make a slight return,'' Mr. Myers said.
The developer then works closely with the architects and contractors to deliver the building on time and within costs.
''In order to be a really strong build-to-suit developer,'' said William Alter, president of the Alter Group, a build-to-suit company based in Wilmette, Ill., ''you have to be able to do the numbers properly because you give the client a guaranteed fixed price up front, and you have to have proper asset management ability.''
For instance, an unexpected engineers' strike delayed by six weeks a 1982 project by the Alter Group to build a 350,000-square-foot research center in Naperville, Ill., near Chicago, for A.T.&T.'s Bell Laboratories. Bad weather delayed the project by another three weeks. Nonetheless, the complex still had to be delivered within 17 months of the starting date. Alter not only arranged for nonstriking engineers to keep things going at 60 percent of capacity, but also increased the total hours logged weekly to make up for lost time.
The developer also had to absorb the cost of design changes ordered by the client. These changes doubled the cost of the cafeteria alone.
 
Land Problems
The most frequent source of overruns is problems with the land. Building codes and zoning regulations can change, and increasingly complex environmental issues can add to a developer's expenses.
Build-to-suit projects often require more technical skill because they often are specialized projects like research and development centers, manufacturing plants or distribution warehouses. Some projects combine many of these different functions.
Increasingly, big corporate tenants in such deals are not satisfied with favorable long-term leases or equity positions in the completed project. Many corporate tenants choose to buy the building, several builders said.
 
Lower Profit Margins
In part because they sell or invite tenants to take equity stakes in these buildings, custom developers' profit margins are less than those of speculators, who make much of their money on a property's long-term appreciation. Although it differs with each project, the margin on build-to-suit projects can sometimes be as thin as three-quarters of 1 percent between the rent and the cost of the construction, Mr. Myers said. But generally the industry tries to get closer to 2 percent.
And developers have no guarantee of getting financing even for those build-to-suit projects with large, well-known clients and long leases. The banks are rigorous in their due-diligence reviews and can be very reluctant to finance even these deals.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Expectation Of Steady Interest Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar gained ground yesterday in worldwide foreign exchange trading as speculation rose that United States interest rates would be holding steady for the time being.
Gold prices fell after rising in Europe. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $373.30 a troy ounce, off $1.40 from late Friday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold of $372.35 an ounce, down 90 cents. 
Currency dealers said the markets believed that the Federal Reserve would not ease its credit policies anytime soon, and that should keep interest rates at their current levels. Higher rates tend to support a currency.
Also helping the dollar, particularly against the West German mark, were reports of political discord in West Germany over reunification plans with East Germany, dealers said.
But Gabriele Schmitt, a corporate dealer for the Bank of New York, played down the dollar advance, saying trading was so light that any movement in the dollar might have been exaggerated. ''There really is not any liquidity in the market to have a reasonable trading pattern,'' she added.
The dollar rose strongly against the West German currency, ending at 1.66245 marks, up from 1.6483.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar traded in New York at 153.73 yen, up from 153 late Friday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar rose by 0.35 yen, to 153.25 yen, extending its gain to 1.95 yen in four days. And it traded at 153.45 yen in London.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound. Sterling rose in London to $1.6917 from $1.6910, and fell in New York to $1.6875 from $1.6900.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.4217 Swiss francs, up from 1.4050; 5.6020 French francs, up from 5.5595; 1,222.50 Italian lire, up from 1,212.75, and 1.17715 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17975.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $373.25 an ounce, from $369.75 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to $373.50 an ounce from $370.60.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 22 cents to close at $374.08 an ounce.
Silver prices firmed. Silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.131 a troy ounce, up from $5.122 late Friday. Silver rose in London to $5.14 an ounce from $5.06.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Soybeans Post Sharp Drop And Grains Also Retreat

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Soybean futures prices fell sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, continuing a recent trend linked to weather conditions and greater availability of South American supplies.
Grain futures also retreated in Chicago. On other commodity markets, energy futures tumbled, while precious metals finished mixed, along with livestock and meat futures. 
Soybean futures settled 10 cents to 11 3/4 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in July at $6.10 1/2 a bushel.
Wheat futures ended 2 1/2 cents to 3 cents lower, with July at $3.37 a bushel; May corn was 4 1/2 cents to 5 1/4 cents lower, with July at $2.77 a bushel, and oats were 2 1/2 cents to 3 1/4 cents lower, with July at $1.51 1/4 a bushel.
All contracts for May deliveries of grains and soybeans expired at noon yesterday. The May soybean contract went off the board at $6.04 1/2 a bushel, May wheat expired at $3.83 1/2, May corn at $2.80 and May oats at $1.44 1/2.
July soybeans have dropped by 50 cents a bushel since May 10, when the Agriculture Department projected a bountiful 1990 harvest of 1.9 billion bushels and an increase in the American soybean stockpile.
Analysts said more South American soybean exports have bolstered perceptions that Brazil and Argentina can handle current global demand and at prices that are generally lower than in the United States.
Weather conditions have undermined soybean prices. The rainy weather that has hampered corn planting in the Midwest has driven speculation that farmers will switch some of their planned corn acres to soybeans, since soybeans can be planted later with no loss of yield.
Yesterday's forecast called for relatively little rain this week in the Midwest.
''We should see some acceleration of planting of corn and soybeans both,'' said Walter Spilka of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
In a weekly report issued after markets closed yesterday, the Agriculture Department said corn planting was 76 percent finished as of Sunday, compared with the norm of 88 percent for that date; soybean planting was 17 percent done, compared with the norm of 43 percent.
The analysts linked additional selling across the board to speculation the Soviet Union might reduce its grain imports because the cost of importing grain is draining the Soviet economy.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, energy futures tumbled amid perceptions of rising American gasoline supplies, said Tom Bentz of United Energy Inc.
He said the traders would be watching today's weekly report from the American Petroleum Institute for an expected increase of about 2 percent in refinery runs, which would verify the market's view that gasoline supplies are increasing.

HEADLINE: U.S. Calls Off Brazil Inquiry

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The United States has ended its investigation of purported unfair trade practices by Brazil, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today. 
 
Mrs. Hills said she had told
Brazil's Minister of Economy, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, who is visiting the United States, that the investigation had been dropped because Brazil removed the import curbs that had prompted the inquiry.
Brazil had been cited under the 1988 Trade Act for general restrictions and prohibitions that had blocked shipments of foreign goods to Brazil. If it had not removed the curbs, Brazil could have been assessed increased tariffs up to 100 percent on some of its exports to the United States.

HEADLINE: Bush Called Ready to Renew China Trade Status for a Year

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
President Bush has decided to renew China's trade benefits for another year, concluding that the potential harm to American companies and to reform-minded Chinese outweighed a desire to register disapproval of Beijing's human-rights record, Administration officials said today.
There is also a domestic political dimension to Mr. Bush's move to renew most-favored-nation trade status. The President, who has said he agonized over the decision, is calculating that Congress will not react with the outrage that greeted his overtures to China last year, officials said.
The White House has spent weeks laying political groundwork for the decision, and officials said their soundings of Congress indicated opposition would not be strong, although George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, condemned Mr. Bush's decision today as ''contrary to American interests and wrong.'' 
 
Emphasis on District Profits
Representative Nancy Pelosi, the California Democrat who led Congressional opposition to Mr. Bush's China policy last year, said today that a resolution opposing the extension of the trade benefits would be introduced.
But other Democratic lawmakers and Congressional aides said they could not gather enough votes to block the move as long as Mr. Bush found a way to make it clear that the act did not represent approval of Beijing's policies and that Washington might reconsider the issue next year if the situation in China did not improve.
Administration officials said Mr. Bush, whose decision was first reported in The Wall Street Journal on Monday, was prepared to offer such assurances when he sends his decision on trade with China to Congress. They said he would also point out that other sanctions against China, including suspension of World Bank loans and a ban on military sales, would remain in effect.
 
Sanctions Seen as Ineffective
Supported by intense lobbying from Hong Kong business interests and other groups promoting trade with China, the White House is also counting on its belief that any undecided lawmakers will be swayed by the profits that their home districts reap from $18 billion a year in trade with China.
Under a Federal law known as the Jackson-Vanik amendment, China and other countries with nonmarket economies cannot be granted most-favored-nation status, which gives them the lower tariff rates granted to most American trading partners, unless the White House certifies that they are permitting free emigration.
That certification must be renewed each year and is due for China this year on June 3, the anniversary of the crackdown around Tiananmen Square.
The Administration also made the decision with an eye to future debates over trade with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. By sticking to the letter of the Jackson-Vanik rules, which address only emigration, the Administration hopes to reduce the impact that other issues, like the conduct of political activity, will have on discussions of trade with Eastern Europe.
Administration officials said that the White House and State Department were still completing formal documents on the trade issue for Mr. Bush to sign, but that the President had reached a decision to extend the trade benefits for another year.
After meeting with Mr. Bush at the White House today, senior Republican lawmakers suggested that Mr. Bush was prepared to approve the extension and said he promised to send his ruling to Congress before it recesses on Friday for the Memorial Day holiday.
Mr. Bush's decision follows an intense debate in the Administration over the political and diplomatic ramifications of extending the trade benefits. Some officials questioned whether the White House wanted to risk the harsh criticism that surfaced over Mr. Bush's decision to send two aides to Beijing on two secret missions last year.
Other officials, especially career diplomats in the State Department who opposed the extension of the trade benefits, argued that canceling most-favored-nation status would send a clear signal of American disapproval of the Chinese human-rights record.
To do otherwise, they said, would fly in the face of Mr. Bush's publicly expressed disappointment that his overtures to China have had little visible effect on Beijing's policies.
In the end, officials said, Mr. Bush, a former envoy to Beijing who runs China policy personally from the Oval Office, followed his own inclination to keep diplomatic and economic channels open to Beijing.
He also heeded arguments that canceling most-favored-nation status for China would cost $8 billion to $10 billion in the first year. The Administration has prepared statistics on how that will affect specific profits in individual lawmakers' districts.

HEADLINE: House Rebuffs Bush on Aid To El Salvador, but Bill Dies

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
In a rebuff to the Bush Administration, the House of Representatives voted tonight to cut military aid to El Salvador by 50 percent. But minutes later the decision was voided when the House defeated the overall bill authorizing funds for El Salvador and other countries.
The back-to-back votes left in temporary disarray President Bush's effort to obtain emergency economic assistance for Nicaragua and Panama. Aid to those countries was included in the same bill as the restrictions on assistance to El Salvador. 
The House will soon have an opportunity to consider aid for Nicaragua and Panama in a separate bill. President Bush has urged Congress to complete action on the aid before the Memorial Day recess.
Representative Joe Moakley, Democrat of Massachusetts, sponsor of the amendment, said he was surprised by the sequence of events today. ''I thought it would be very close, but I thought we would win,'' he said. ''Now it looks as if there was a cyclone out there that knocked us off our feet.''
 
Unusual Alliance
He said that the foreign aid bill was voted down by an unusual combination of politicians: Republicans who detested the restrictions on military aid for El Salvador; Democrats who dislike foreign aid in general, and ''liberal purists'' for whom the 50 percent cut for El Salvador did not go far enough.
The Administration, seeing approval of the Moakley amendment as inevitable, concentrated its efforts on trying to secure defeat of the overall foreign aid bill.
It was uncertain tonight in what form and at what time the limits on aid to El Salvador would be proposed again.
Despite the defeat of the bill, supporters of restricting aid to El Salvador said they were encouraged, contending that approval of the amendment to cut aid was an important symbolic victory.
Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, chief deputy whip for House Democrats, said the vote on El Salvador was ''a very big victory.'' He asserted that it ''changed the outlook on aid to El Salvador in a profound way'' and established ''a strong base for future negotiations with the Bush Administration on changing policy toward El Salvador.''
The overall foreign aid bill was defeated by a vote of 244 to 171. Ninety-four Democrats joined 150 Republicans in opposing the bill. Voting in favor of the measure were 155 Democrats and 16 Republicans.
Mr. Moakley led the effort to cut military assistance for El Salvador. His proposal, to halve such aid, was offered as an amendment to the foreign aid bill. The amendment was approved by a vote of 250 to 163, and the vote largely followed party lines.
Two-hundred-and-nineteen Democrats and 31 Republicans voted in favor of slashing military aid to El Salvador. Twenty-eight Democrats and 135 Republicans voted against the amendment.
The White House said Monday that it opposed the 50 percent cut in military aid to El Salvador and warned that President Bush was likely to veto any measure making such a cut.
Supporters of the legislation said it was needed to show United States concern over the failure of El Salvador to prosecute the people who killed six Jesuit priests and two women in San Salvador on Nov. 16.
They said the bill was intended to penalize the Salvadoran Government for not moving more effectively on the Jesuit case while at the same time providing new incentives to the Government and to leftist guerrillas to negotiate an end to the decade-long war. The Government and the guerrillas said this week that they hoped to arrange a cease-fire by mid-September.
The United States has provided more than $3.8 billion in aid to El Salvador since 1980. This year it is providing $315 million, including $85 million in military assistance for weapons and training. The aid issue has long been a contentious one. Tens of thousands of civilians have been killed in El Salvador in the last 10 years, most of them by death squads associated with the military.
Republicans, in Congress and the Administration, supported an alternative proposal that would have allowed Mr. Bush to suspend up to 25 percent of El Salvador's military aid if the Government there failed to take certain actions, particularly on human rights.
 
Incentives for Aid
The House bill included an elaborate set of incentives and disincentives. Military aid to the Salvadoran Government would have been cut in half, to $42.5 million next year. But it could have been restored to $85 million if the rebels failed to negotiate in good faith, continued to receive significant amounts of arms from outside El Salvador or staged a new military offensive that threatened the survival of the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani. The bill did not define good faith negotiations.
On the other hand, the Salvadoran Government would not have received any military aid from the United States if Mr. Cristiani was deposed in a military coup, if the Government failed to negotiate in good faith with the guerrillas or if it failed to prosecute those responsible for killing the Jesuit priests.
The Salvadoran authorities have arrested an army colonel, two lieutenants and five lower-ranking military men on charges of murdering the priests. But Democrats said the Salvadoran Government had made hardly any effort to determine if senior military officers ordered the killings.
Representative Gerry E. Studds, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today, ''Evidence in the Jesuit case has disappeared, and the investigation is at a standstill.''
Mr. Moakley said, ''The American people and the American Congress have been played for fools by the Salvadoran military and forces from both the left and the right who need war to continue in order to sustain their power in that troubled land.''
''Corruption is a way of life'' in El Salvador, he asserted. ''For 10 years now, American taxpayer money has been used not to build peace with democracy, but to destroy hope and build the private bank accounts of crooks who get rich at the expense of the Salvadoran people and the American people.''
Under the House bill, any funds withheld from the Salvadoran armed forces could be spent on child nutrition, health, housing or education programs in El Salvador.

LENGTH: 1591 words

HEADLINE: House Approves Bill Establishing Broad Rights for Disabled People

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
The House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved legislation today that would guarantee millions of disabled Americans access to employment, transportation, public accommodations and communications services.
Beating back amendments that would have significantly weakened its provisions, the House voted 403 to 20 for the proposed Americans With Disabilities Act, which supporters call the most sweeping civil rights bill in two decades.
The bill has already been approved by the Senate and is supported by President Bush. Although some differences in the versions passed by the House and the Senate remain to be worked out in a conference, sponsors of the legislation say they expect to have a bill on the President's desk before Congress breaks for its Fourth of July recess.
The measure would extend protections established by the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against discrimination based on sex, religion, color, race or national origin to people with physical or mental disabilities, including people with AIDS as well as recovering alcoholics and drug abusers. Both the 1964 law and the new measure bar discrimination in public accommodations, private employment and government services. protection. #200 Watching Supporters Cheer Many of the bill's requirements are already embodied in the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, which prohibits companies and government agencies receiving Federal aid from discriminating against people with disabilities. The legislation would extend this throughout the public and private sector; the businesses or agencies need not receive Federal funds to be covered. 
Many businesses will be forced to change their offices, factories or stores to accommodate the disabled. The bill is also expected to have a significant economic effect on government at all levels, although it is unclear what the ultimate costs to government or the private sector will be.
More than 200 supporters of the bill, many of them in wheelchairs, cheered, hugged one another and wept as Representative Bob Traxler, a Michigan Democrat who was presiding over the House, announced the final vote.
The group had followed the debate on television monitors in the National Statuary Hall, the marble-columned portico between the House Chamber and the Capitol Rotunda. For the first time, the televised House debate was translated in sign language.
 
'First Declaration of Equality'
''This is the first declaration of equality for people with disabilities around the world,'' said Justin Dart Jr., chairman of the President's Committee on Employment of People with Disabilities, and a longtime advocate of disability rights.
Taking effect two years after it is signed into law, the measure would require employers to make reasonable accommodations for qualified workers and job applicants with disabilities unless doing so presents an undue hardship. The measure defines undue hardship for businesses as something that would ''be too costly or be too disruptive or substantially alter the way they do business.''
The bill defines a person with a disability as someone with a physical or mental impairment that ''substantially limits a major life activity'' like walking, talking or working. It covers people with AIDS and drug abusers or alcoholics who have undergone treatment. It excludes people with emotional disorders like kleptomania, gambling compulsions or pedophilia. Congressional researchers have estimated that one in six Americans is disabled, or about 43 million in all.
Public and private transportation systems must make new buses and rail cars accessible to handicapped people, installing lifts for people in wheelchairs, if necessary. Elevators or ramps must be installed at many rail stations. New or renovated buildings must be free from barriers preventing the disabled from entering, and restaurants and retail outlets must make their premises and services available to disabled persons.
Three years after passage of the bill, telephone companies would be required to establish relay services between special telephones for people with speech or hearing disabilities and people using ordinary telephones. The handicapped people would use the special phones to type out their messages, and an operator would act as an intermediary between them and the users of ordinary phones. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company calculated last year that service to people with hearing problems would cost the telecommunications industry $250 million to $330 million a year.
 
Costs to Bus Operators
Although the final costs are hard to estimate, the Government estimated last year that as the result of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 and the legislation passed today, state and local governments would have to spend $20 million to $30 million a year over the next several years to purchase buses equipped with hydraulic lifts.
After the Senate passed its bill last summer, Greyhound Lines Inc. asserted that the company would have to spend $40 million to $80 million a year to comply. Officials of the New York City Transit Authority, which runs the nation's largest transit system, said the bill would not have a signficant impact on its operating or capital expenses. More than 80 percent of the city's buses are now equipped with lifts, and officials say the rest will be so equipped by the end of 1992. As a result of a settlement of a lawsuit in 1984 brought by disability rights advocates, the city is already spending $40 million to install elevators in 54 of the subway system's 469 stations by the end of 1992.
The issue of how to punish violations of the proposed law had been a contentious one.
Supporters of the measure were able to beat back an amendment by Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, that would have limited the remedies available to handicapped people who are the victims of discrimination to those embodied in the 1964 civil rights law: injunctions to halt biased actions by employers and back pay for victims of discrimination who were dismissed or passed over for promotion. Another pending measure, the Civil Rights Act of 1990, would expand the 1964 civil rights law to allow for punitive damages and jury trials in the case of intentional discrimination, and such changes would apply to the disability law as well.
The Bush Administration, which opposes allowing increased damage awards, had supported the Sensenbrenner amendment, which was defeated 227 to 192. Administration officials said President Bush, who promised in the 1988 Presidential campaign to help Americans who have physical or mental disabilities, would not veto the disability bill over the issue. The Administration will seek to amend the civil rights bill instead, they said.
Nancy R. Fulco, a lawyer for the United States Chamber of Commerce, which supported the Sensenbrenner amendment, said the House had ''chosen to put unreasonable damage awards and attorney's fees above the needs of employers and employees.''
The House narrowly passed last week by a vote of 199 to 187 an amendment on food handlers, offered by Representative Jim Chapman, Democrat of Texas. Supporters contended that without the amendment the bill would have put businesses at undue economic risk by making it impossible for them to move workers who carry communicable diseases like AIDS from jobs where they handle food. The amendment would require employers to provide infected workers with another job for which they are qualified.
 
'Not an Unrealistic Fear'
''This is not an unrealistic fear,'' said Mr. Chapman of the public perception of a health risk. ''There are real examples in the real world of how this caused a loss of business, the closing of jobs and the loss of employment.''
Public health officials, including Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and gay rights organizations had denounced the amendment. Opponents of the amendment circulated a letter from William L. Roper, director of the Centers for Disease Control, that said food service workers infected with the AIDS virus ''need not be restricted from work'' unless they show signs of other maladies as well.
''The food handlers amendment has no basis in the science of transmission of HIV,'' said Urvashi Vaid, executive director of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force. ''It was a close vote, and members seemed to be swept up by emotion, rather than reason.''
The House also amended the bill to increase the time given small businesses to meet the requirements. The amendment, offered by Representative Tom Campbell, Republican of California, would give companies with 25 or fewer workers an extra six months and businesses with 10 or fewer employees a extra year to comply with the provisions on public accommodations.
But the lawmakers defeated two amendments that would have weakened the bill's provisions regarding public transit systems. One, defeated by a vote of 290 to 110 would have allowed commuter railroads to make only one car in every train accessible to the disabled, including people in wheelchairs. The other, defeated by a vote of 266 to 148, would have exempted public transit systems in cities with a population of less than 200,000 from the requirement of making all new cars accessible if they made other transportation available.
The sponsors of the amendments argued that the bill needed to be changed because of its costs to public transit systems. Opponents said the effect of the proposed changes would be to segregate people with disablities.

HEADLINE: BANK DEPOSIT FUND HITS A RECORD LOW

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
For the second year, the fund that insures the nation's bank deposits declined, the Government said today. And at the end of last year less money was available to insure each dollar deposited than at any time since the fund began in the early 1930's.
By the end of December, officials of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said, the fund held only 70 cents in assets for every $100 of insured deposits at commercial banks, down from 80 cents a year earlier. Experts say a safe figure is $1.25. 
Despite the continuing drain on the fund from recent bank failures, no insured depositors at commercial banks or at savings and loan associations have lost money, and Congress has promised that no insured depositor will lose a dime.
The losses to the fund last year amounted to $851 million from the record of 206 banks that failed, including MCorp in Dallas, the Seamen's Bank for Saving in New York, Texas American Bancshares of Fort Worth and the National Bancshares Corporation of San Antonio.
 
Bigger Losses Than Expected
The F.D.I.C. losses in 1989 were greater than expected. They are apart from those that swamped the savings and loan industry in recent years.
The banking fund is now left with $13.2 billion in assets, and regulators and banking experts say the insurance fund is not in immediate danger. Still, if there is a strong recession and real estate values weaken further than they already have, several more large banks could fail, raising the possibility of a new bailout by taxpayers.
Real estate pressures contributed heavily to the collapse in the savings and loan industry which is now expected to cost taxpayers and the savings industry $300 billion to 500 billion over the next 30 years.
The F.D.I.C.'s bank insurance fund is separate and distinct from the currently depleted fund that insures deposits at the nation's savings and loan associations, the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. The management responsibility for the savings and loan fund was given to the F.D.I.C. in the legislation for the savings and loan bailout.
A large loss for the bank deposit fund was expected, so most analysts were unshaken by the report, saying that unless a severe recession strikes, the F.D.I.C. will be able to begin rebuilding its resources this year. Indeed, last year's loss was far less than 1988's deficit of $4.3 billion.
But they warned that the loss for 1989 comes at a time of other significant strains on the commercial banking system, particularly depressed real estate markets in the Northeast and scattered reports of a drying-up of credit.
''Clearly our results in the next year or two will depend on whether we have large banks that fail in the system,'' said L. William Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C. and the Resolution Trust Corporation, which manages the savings and loan bailout. ''Much depends on future interest rates and real estate markets.''
 
A Critical Point
The F.D.I.C.'s bank fund stands at a critical point in its history, from which it could either rapidly return to health of slip quickly into crisis.
The 1980's brought about dramatic change to the sleepy agency that for decades handled a handful of small bank failures a year. Within a few years, failures went from 10 a year to almost 200, creating what most experts say was a daunting administrative task for the agency. During Mr Seidman's five-year tenure, it has coped with the collapse of almost 700 banks, including many of the largest in Texas.
But if the economy stays on track and interest rates remain steady, the failure rate could change, and even fall, experts say.
An important indicator of future bank failures is the number of banks on the F.D.I.C.'s problem bank list. That number peaked in 1987 at more than 1,600 and has dropped since then, so that by the end of 1989, the list had only 1,109 problem banks.
 
Fewer Failures Seen
Mr. Seidman has said for several months that so far he sees no major bank failures this year. Moreover, he sees fewer failures this year, ''I'd say between 150 and 175,'' he said.
If all those factors remain unchanged, and the economy stays strong, F.D.I.C. officials said the fund might be able to show a considerable profit in 1990.
Robert Dugger, chief economist for the American Bankers Association, said he projected that the F.D.I.C.'s bank fund would fall again in 1990, before it finally bottoms out and begins moving upward.
His trade group, the industry's largest, expects the fund to fall as low as 62 cents for every $100 of insured deposits. It had expected the fund to fall to 64 cents in 1989.
Mr. Dugger said he did not expect the fund to reach the $1.25 level until 1996 or 1997.
 
Premiums to Rise
One factor working in the favor of the F.D.I.C. is that this year and next, the premiums that banks pay for deposit insurance rise sharply. This year, they rose to 12 cents for every $100 of deposits, from 8.33 cents. They will rise again in 1991 to 15 cents.
Mr. Seidman also has the option, if the five-member board of the F.D.I.C. feels the situation is serious enough, to increase the premium banks pay by another 7.5 percent to 22.5 cents a year.
By 1991 the F.D.I.C. will be collecting premiums of more than $2 billion above the 1989 levels.
''By 1991, the F.D.I.C. will have more than $4 billion to play with in premiums and investment income,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president for the Independent Bankers Association. ''Where are they going to spend that? I don't think any big bank failures are in the works, other than one bank in New England. I think we are over the hump.''
 
This Is the Rough Period
''We have known that the F.D.I.C. was going to have a rough period in 1998 and 1989, but the problems are largely behind us,'' said William M. Isaac, former F.D.I.C. chairman and now head of the Secura Group, a Washington-based financial consulting firm. ''Now it is a matter of giving the fund an opportunity to rebuild.
But Mr. Guenther and other experts acknowledged that the downside possibilities, particularly in case of a recession, were considerable.
Another problem for the agency has been the transfer of some of its best talent to the Resolution Trust Corporation to manage the day-to-day activities of the savings and loan bailout, a process that some have described as a brain drain.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Lithuanian Compromise With Moscow Unravels

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 22

 BODY:
Movement toward compromise on the Baltic republics' campaign for independence stopped today, as Lithuania rejected demands to suspend its declaration of independence and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned all three Baltic republics that they must abide by Soviet law.
Lithuanian legislators voted in principle today to suspend important laws enacted since the republic declared independence on March 11, as soon as Moscow agrees to begin negotiations. Parliament is expected to formally approve the text of a resolution on Wednesday, but none of the variations being considered includes any mention of freezing the declaration itself, and members of Parliament confirmed that such action had been ruled out.
Mr. Gorbachev has demanded that Lithuania place a moratorium on its declaration as a condition for beginning talks with Moscow about independence, and it seems unlikely that he will be satisfied by a move that puts a hold only on independence laws. 
The Soviet leader had a brief and tense conversation today with the President of Latvia, Anatolijs Gorbunovs, and the President of Estonia, Arnold Ruutel, and reaffirmed his intention to deal toughly with all three Baltic republics in their quest to leave the Soviet Union.
''Mr. Gorbachev confirmed his demand to the three Baltic states to abolish their decisions on independence,'' Mr. Ruutel told the Estonian news service tonight. He also described the 20-minute conversation as ''unpleasant'' for both sides, people who spoke with him said.
The Kremlin and the Baltic republics seemed to have struck more conciliatory tones toward one another during a visit by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to Moscow last week. During the Baker visit, Mr. Gorbachev met with Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene of Lithuania after the republic's Parliament proposed suspending independence legislation passed since its decision to break from the Soviet Union.
 
Advice From Baker
American and Lithuanian officials indicated that Mr. Baker had encouraged Mrs. Prunskiene to make some concession on the declaration itself, telling her that freezing the act did not amount to revoking it.
But in today's debate, only a handful of Lithuanian legislators proposed suspending the declaration and the vast majority agreed that there was no way to tamper with the independence declaration without leaving the republic vulnerable to Moscow.
''Let us be honest,'' Kazimieras Moteika, deputy chairman of the Lithuanian Parliament, told the legislators today. ''Having chosen the road of independence, we must be firm and remember that we will not veer off it.''
Lithuanian officials said that the resolution being debated differs from the proposal brought to Moscow last week by Mrs. Prunskiene in that Parliament now says it is not only willing to, but in fact will suspend independence laegislation when Moscow confirms that talks are to begin.
The Lithuanian decision was made despite the worsening effects of an economic blockade imposed by Moscow on the renegade republic more than a month ago.
Deputy Prime Minister Algirdas Brazauskas announced today that, as a result of a continuing Soviet embargo on fuel, stricter gasoline rationing would go into effect on Wednesday.
 
Hardships Ahead
Describing Lithuania as being in a ''crisis situation,'' Mr. Brazauskas said gasoline would be allotted only to ambulances, police and food transport vehicles. Fuel for public transportation will be cut back, he said, and for private vehicles will be cut off.
The new measures will put about 23,000 drivers out of work, doubling the number of people who have been laid off from their jobs since the economic sanctions were first instituted, a spokesman for the Lithuanian Parliament said.
Officials also said that hot water to homes would be reduced by Friday because of the fuel shortages and that power to most industries might have to be cut by the end of the week, although medical and food enterprises will continue to be served.
Most of the republic's apartment buildings are served by a central hot-water pumping station, officials said, adding that for the time being, those buildings that heat their own water with natural gas will not be affected.
In his conversation with Mrs. Prunskiene last week, Mr. Gorbachev threatened to broaden the economic blockade against Lithuania if the republic failed to comply with his demand to suspend its declaration of independence.
The Parliaments of Latvia and Estonia tried to avoid a similar confrontation with Moscow, by voting for transitional periods to independence after Lithuania had voted for a clean break with Moscow. So far, the kremlin has not imposed any sanctions against Latvia and Estonia, but Mr. Gorbachev has condemned both republics' actions as illegal and today repeated his warning that the only way any republic can leave the country is through a new law on secession recently adopted by the Soviet Parliament.

HEADLINE: Safety Board Urges F.A.A. To Order Use of Child Seats

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
The National Transportation Safety Board today called on the Federal Government to require that infants and small children sit in safety seats during airline flights.
It was the board's first endorsement of such a mandatory rule. The unanimous recommendation by the five-member safety board puts additional pressure on the Federal Aviation Administration, which is considering what its regulations should say about safety restraints for babies under 2 years old, who now may fly free of charge if they are held on an adult's lap. The safety board is independent of the aviation agency. 
Anthony J. Broderick, the F.A.A. official in charge of writing the new safety regulations, said it might take as long as a year for the agency to decide on a child restraint rule and expressed serious doubts about the wisdom of requiring safety seats for all babies.
''The result of this rule could be a very significant increase in airline revenues being borne by families with small children, many of whom are of modest income because they are very young,'' he said. A cost-benefit analysis by the agency suggests that a family that chose to save money by traveling by car instead of by plane would face a substantially higher probability of an accident, he said.
 
Crashes Renewed the Debate
Flight attendants, pediatricians and child safety experts have long urged that the use of child safety seats be required on aircraft. Since 1985, seats have been manufactured that meet Federal standards for both cars and aircraft. But their use has been optional in airplanes while it is mandatory in cars.
Several babies who were not strapped into safety seats were killed or injured in two crashes in the past year. The crashes, one in Iowa involving a United Airlines jet and the other on Long Island involving an Avianca jet, led to new calls for a rule requiring the use of safety seats.
In February, the nation's major airlines for the first time recommended that the aviation agency require infant seats for all infants on airplanes.
Representative Jim Ross Lightfoot, an Iowa Republican, and Senator Christopher S. Bond, a Missouri Republican, have introduced legislation that would require use of the seats.
 
An Even Stronger Rule
The safety board today went further than the airlines and its own staff in its recommendation, urging that the Government require children up to 40 inches tall or up to 40 pounds, regardless of age, to sit in approved seats when flying.
Jim Burnette, a board member, argued that automobile safety seats are designed to handle babies up to that size, and that the seats would provide the maximum protection for young passengers.
The board also asked the agency to investigate the possibility of designing improved restraints for even larger children.
The aviation agency published a preliminary proposal in February that did not include a mandatory seat rule. The proposal suggested requiring airlines to let parents use approved safety seats when they have bought a ticket for the baby, or when there is a vacant seat next to the parent.
The agency said it would consider public comments received by May 30 before making a final decision.
 
Some Would Pay Willingly
The several dozen comments received by the agency favored a mandatory safety rule by a margin of three to one. The commenters said the increased costs would be acceptable.
Airline executives have said that cut-rate fares for babies would still be available if a rule requiring child seats was adopted and that babies might even fly free on some flights.
After the vote today by the safety board, its chairman, James Kolstad, said, ''I don't think the economic cost for protecting an infant's life is too much to ask.''
